title: Unscrupulous Mechanics Are Widespread Plague
description: To the Editor:

title: Surviving Kafka and Other Rites of Passage
description: AS usual, Lawrence Cappello was cool. ''If you make a big deal out of things you get disappointed,'' he said. ''Basically, I take everything in stride.''

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/

title: THE FINAL SESSION
description: I am a psychoanalyst struggling with breast cancer. Bill Gordon's Lives essay ''The Final Session'' (Aug. 11) made me furious. When I learned I had cancer last year, I recalled how a colleague's patients, unaware that she was sick, heard of her death from a note on her office door. Determined to prevent similar scenarios, I shared with my patients my diagnosis, told them that my cancer could recur and let them know that they had the right to terminate therapy if they wished.

title: Critic Promotes the Music and Legacy of a 20th-Century Artist
description: IF there were a lost-and-found for obscure 20th-century American composers, Walter Simmons would be its custodian.

title: The 4th R Is 'Really Cramped'
description: If New York City's public schools were to admit only the students they had room for when they reopen this week, the overflow would fill Madison Square Garden. More than four times over.

title: Swimming Across America
description: I HAD been in such a hurry to leap into adulthood that driving across the country -- five kids jammed into a Volkswagen, heading vaguely for the Grand Canyon -- was a trip that had passed me by. At 25, I woke up, hopped into a car and headed across America. My early, brief marriage was over; I'd saved up enough vacation to put my job on hold. A friend was moving from the East Coast to California for graduate school. He wanted company; I happened to be available.

title: The Secret Is in the Spices, and She's Not Telling
description: Tahini bread that's an intriguing blend of the sweet and the savory. Tabouleh whose minty freshness dances on the tongue. Bountifully stuffed grape leaves. A cracked wheat salad called ich (pronouced EETCH).

title: Wistful Visit To Mountains Of Memory
description: BACK in the old hotel, Phil Brown was charming the guests, running around just about the biggest dining room in the world while his mother was banging pots and pans around in the kitchen, becoming a chef, and his dad was balancing the books, but barely.

title: INSIDE
description: IN PERSON

title: Proposed Dog Run Would Shrink Playground
description: To the Editor:

title: The Medical Detectives
description: Racing to the Beginning of the Road

title: Publishers Battle as The Brooklyn Eagle Is Reborn, Twice
description: A celebrated newspaper name, The Brooklyn Eagle, came back to life last month after a 33-year absence, used not by one but two publishers who are battling over the venerated title.

title: Vesco Jailed; Case Not Closed
description: After a quarter century of intrigue that brushed the White House of Richard M. Nixon and then careered around Latin America and the Caribbean, the strange odyssey of Robert L. Vesco ended ignominiously last week in Cuba, the country that had offered him luxurious sanctuary for more than a decade.

title: The Titanic, Cursed Again
description: The supposedly unsinkable Titanic has again proven itself to be eminently submersible. A commercial expedition to raise part of the luxury liner ended in failure in early morning darkness Friday when the nylon lines being used to lift a 21-ton section of the hull snapped and the chunk of steel, just 70 yards from the surface, dropped 2 1/2 miles back to the bottom of the cold North Atlantic.

title: Rutgers's Bad Start Becomes A Victory
description: Rutgers unveiled its new ''West Coast'' offense with three quarterbacks, no less -- and its third head coach in 13 years tonight when the Scarlet Knights opened their 127th season against Villanova.

title: In Lacey Township, a Zoo for Animals That Nobody Else Wants
description: The sign above the pile of black garbage bags says ''Elephant Manure -- Take One. It's Free. The World's Best Fertilizer.'' And that's how you know you have found the Popcorn Park Zoo in Lacey Township.

title: Was It a Funeral Floating By?
description: Sunday morning dawned clear and bright, and over on Pier 26, the Downtown Boathouse was becoming hectic, with kayakers and rowers eager to be out on the Hudson. But what was that drifting near the bulkhead?

title: Andrea Blaugrund and David Nevins
description: Andrea Blaugrund, the daughter of Drs. Annette and Stanley M. Blaugrund of New York, is to be married today to David Alan Nevins, the son of Suzy Nevins of Washington and Louis H. Nevins of Los Angeles and Washington. Rabbi Joseph Weinberg is to perform the ceremony at the Ram's Head Inn in Shelter Island Heights, L.I.

title: The Liberation of Dilbert
description: HOW can a book that's so funny at the same time be so sad? Recently, I spent a business trip reading ''The Dilbert Principle,'' the best seller by Scott Adams. It's an undeniably funny book, but after I chuckled through about 100 pages, I found myself feeling strangely depressed.

title: 'When You're a Jet': O'Donnell Is Already Singing
description: It has been such an intense six months up before 6 A.M., working after hours with the receivers, scolding, teaching, joking -- that there were times Neil O'Donnell thought Sunday would never come: opening day for the Jets.

title: The First Days of the Loaded Political Image
description: Thirty-two years ago this fall, as Barry Goldwater and Lyndon B. Johnson battled for the Presidency, there came a watershed in campaign advertising on television. For the first time in the brief history of the form, commercials began to focus as much on an array of emotionally charged visual images as on the candidates themselves. The shift in style occurred just as the postwar period of bipartisan consensus -- what the journalist Godfrey Hodgson has called ''conservative liberalism'' -- was fissioning into the stark ideological contrasts typified by Johnson's Great Society and Goldwater's New Right.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 1, 1996

Millhone probes an old bank heist. 3 2 Morning, Noon & Night, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner $7.50.) The mysterious drowning of a respected tycoon reveals a tangle of scandals. 4 47 SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Vintage, $12.) title: Trash Haulers Told: No Mobsters or Odors
description: Twelve regulations, most aimed at reforming New York City's mobster-scarred private garbage-hauling industry and lowering fees, will be imposed by a new city agency late this month.

title: Big Money at the Conventions
description: Two decades after Watergate, the struggle to limit corporate and big-money influence on the political system has been mocked by the fund-raising and influence-peddling spectacles at both parties' conventions this summer. Rivers of money flowed into the Republican and Democratic conventions from special interests, while donors were rewarded with skybox seats, parties, private meetings and other forms of access to policy makers. These abuses must now be met by a redoubled effort to reform the system.

title: How to Visit 1896
description: Yes, New Jersey has changed in 100 years. But there are still places where you can transport yourself to that time of gaslights and streetcars without even closing your eyes.

title: Andrea P. Martin, Buddy Gumina
description: Andrea Pollard Martin, a daughter of Stephanie and Judge Gordon A. Martin Jr. of Newton Centre, Mass., is to be married there today to William John Gumina, a son of Rosemary and Carl R. Gumina of Webster, N.Y. Msgr. William A. Granville is to perform the ceremony at Sacred Heart Church.

title: Under Streetlights, the Vulnerable Huddle
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Plimpton, James Murphy 3d
description: Sarah Ann Willard Plimpton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Austin Plimpton of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to James Patrick Murphy 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Murphy 2d of Yardley, Pa. The Rev. Mark Orten performed the ceremony at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: You've Read the Book! Now Sniff It!
description: Gravity's RainbowThis audio rendition of Thomas Pynchon's epic masterpiece makes your average book on tape sound like an old Edison cylinder. Fully digitized using the latest technology, ''Gravity's Rainbow: The DAT'' now brings you the novel Pynchon wanted you to hear. You'll duck for cover as the V-2's come screaming across the sky. You'll laugh and cry at the dialogue as read by an all-star cast that includes Robin Williams as the tumescent Tyrone Slothrop and Anthony Hopkins as Octopus Grigori. And you won't want to miss the legendary Dylan crooning the notorious ''Rocket Limericks'': ''There once was a fellow named Moorehead / Who had an affair with a warhead.''

title: Raise Your Hand if You Saw 'Escape From the Rock'
description: HOW ABOUT THOSE SUMMER action movies? Remember Plutoxin 7, VX gas rockets and Area 51? Remember helicopters, famous buildings exploding, cows and taxis flying through the air, shoot-outs, chase scenes, F.B.I. and C.I.A. guys, and heroes hanging by a thread from high-speed vehicles? Come to think of it, remember how the summer's big hits sometimes seemed strangely alike?

title: New York Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Deals and Discounts
description: WEEKEND WHEELS Budget Car and Truck Rental has announced a weekend rate of $25 a day from Thursday to Jan. 31 at participating locations in the United States. The rate is not available in the New York metropolitan area or in Hawaii, but a company spokeswoman says locations in ''most major markets'' will offer it. Customers must make reservations, mentioning either the special rate or ''Code OK.'' A two-day minimum rental is required, and the car must be picked up between noon on Thursday and noon on Saturday and returned by noon on Monday. The rate includes unlimited mileage and cannot be combined with another discount. Reservations: (800) 527-0700.

title: Smoke Glacken and 7 Furlongs Foil Kelly Kip
description: There may have been bigger upsets in the 127-year history of Saratoga Race Course, also known as the graveyard of champions, but this one will do. Kelly Kip, the 4-5 favorite and the star of the season, ran seventh in a field of eight today in the Hopeful Stakes, while Smoke Glacken was winning and injecting a new name into the race for 2-year-old honors.

title: Parents vs. Administrator, as Style Clash Makes Heavy Weather
description: The French are renowned for a sense of fashion, and maybe that is why an argument last winter over clothing -- a foolish argument, even the participants agree -- has erupted into a revolution at the Lycee Francais, the bicultural private school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Off Court, Too, Play Was Fierce
description: WHOEVER said the August doldrums are a time for rest and relaxation?

title: The Wrinkle Room
description: The first time I went to Fedora, in 1971, the small restaurant off Sheridan Square was already a relic of an earlier Greenwich Village; I had one meal there and decided not to go back.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 59 of the Television section today about Frederick Wiseman's documentary ''La Comedie-Francaise ou L'Amour Joue'' omits the broadcast time and channel. The showing -- 3 hours 43 minutes -- is tonight at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Sarah H. Bayliss, Michael L. Sand
description: Sarah Hudson Bayliss, a daughter of Barbara and Malcolm Bayliss of New York, was married last evening to Michael Lourie Sand, a son of Barbara Sand of Princeton, N.J., and Francis Sand of Mansfield Township, N.J. Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh officiated at Mr. and Mrs. Bayliss's house in Sheffield, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Donald W. McKinney, a Unitarian minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Anna S. Griswold, Thom Haskell
description: Anna Sophia Griswold, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Griswold of Belmont, Mass., was married yesterday to Paul Thomson Haskell 3d, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. Haskell Jr. of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Rebecca Spencer performed the ceremony at the Central Congregational Church in Providence, R.I.

title: No Headline
description: ''The war is done. Now we must think about the peace.''

title: Softening Gritty Urban Gray With a Little Green
description: There's a patch of wild pink petunias that come up every summer in the cracks of the cement in front of an apartment building on the corner of Sixth Avenue and Sixth Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn. The sun beats down, but these petunias seem to thrive in their concrete desert, and I always look for them if I'm passing by. Were they part of some lush perennial border, I wouldn't even give them a glance.

title: Canadian Exchange
description: All is not well at Gardner/Ross, the old-line Toronto brokerage firm at the center of TRADERS. Cedric Ross, the head of the company, has been hauled off to jail on fraud charges. His daughter Sally (Sonja Smits, above), a high-minded economist, is tossed into a snakepit of intrigue when she tries to save the business.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: A Company Philosophy in Bricks and Mortar
description: W.L. GORE & ASSOCIATES, whose Gore-Tex fabric is the stuff of high adventure, has broken ground on a $12 million, 165,000-square-foot manufacturing building here designed to feel like home.

title: Still Making 'em Like They Used To
description: THE good news was that I'd finally found a home for my old 286-chip computer, a monster circa 1986 that was unused but too useful to throw away. The bad news was that I had to take it from Long Island to a buddy in Pennsylvania -- and that had me in a dilemma.

title: Armchair Booking For the Trains in Spain
description: Visitors to Spain can now make train reservations and buy tickets before leaving home from V. E. Tours, a Spanish company with offices in Miami and a direct computer connection with Renfe, Spain's national railway. Tickets are available for any of Renfe's trains serving 47 cities; for the high-speed AVE train (Alta Velocidad Espanola) that travels between Madrid and Seville, and for long-distance trains that connect Spain with cities in the rest of Europe. Tickets bought over the telephone with credit cards are mailed to passengers. Information: (800) 222-8383.

title: For 15-Year-Old Player, The Future Is Now
description: Fifteen-year-old Anna Kournikova said it has always been her dream to play Steffi Graf.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE SOLITAIRE MYSTERY

title: Islanders Say Pataki Added Insult to Cut
description: When the State Legislature passed Gov. George E. Pataki's budget in July, residents of Roosevelt Island, where state-financed development began in 1971, protested the amount of money they did not get -- and the reason they were told they were not getting it.

title: Human Tests Weigh Product Safety
description: FRANCIS BACON argued in the 17th century that science would ultimately perfect the social order, bringing forth a new utopian civilization. Stephen R. Schwartz, a scientist toiling in Port Chester 372 years after the English intellectual's prediction, has more modest expectations. He relies on science to confirm that mascara will not smudge into gelatinous blotches, that sun block will not dissolve into a burning, viscous lather and that anti-itch ointment will not make skin break out with tiny red blisters.

title: Cordiality on Call In Theater District
description: BARBETTA *

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: FYI 2

title: Mixing Season's Bounty in a Single Dish
description: WILL it be the eggplant or the zucchini? The blackberries or the peaches? Cherry tomatoes or beefsteak beauties?

title: The Political System That Is Newt Gingrich
description: AT the Democratic convention in Chicago, he was a bogeyman. At the Republican convention in San Diego, he was in charge of beach volleyball. But here, at the 92d convention of the American Political Science Association, Newt Gingrich is a glorious, provocative experiment.

title: Is This Man Dangerous?
description: IT is nearing midnight, Saturday, and Times Square is pulsating, with mostly positive energy. Tourists and locals seeking to extend the night flock to the glittering lights blazing Broadway. Sailors in crisp uniforms rollick among vendors of love potions and three-card monte players. Lovers lock lips under the flashing neon signs.

title: Victoria Shonfeld, Jon Rotenstreich
description: Victoria Ann Shonfeld, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Shonfeld of San Francisco, and Henry Jonathan Rotenstreich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jon Wallace Rotenstreich of New York, are to be married today. Dr. Ronald Sobel, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, performed the cermony at the Beaulieu Estate in Rutherford, Calif.

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 18 about the television show ''Caesar's Writers'' misidentified the producer of the 1950's comedy show ''Caesar's Hour.'' He was Leo Morgan; Hal Janis was executive producer.

title: Michigan Run Sputters, But Wolverines Win
description: The plan is the same whether the fans in maize and blue are wearing tank tops and sandals or parkas and snow boots. Everything Michigan does starts with its running game, and its ability to stop someone else's. In a game that would establish the direction of its Big Ten season, Michigan showed an ability to establish control, if not necessarily dominate, in the area where games are won and lost.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Laura Getz, Andrew Missan
description: Laura Gail Getz and Andrew Paul Missan are to be married today at the University of California Botanical Garden in Berkeley. Rabbi Rona Shapiro is to perform the ceremony.

title: Welcome Mat Is Out For Gay Investors
description: ENCOURAGED by her employer, I.B.M., Cynthia Swain went to see a financial planner recently. But unlike many I.B.M. employees, Ms. Swain decided to go alone.

title: Why Some Vote Yes for Bosnia's Flawed Elections
description: IN a large warehouse in downtown Sarajevo, thousands of ballot boxes and cartons of pens, ballot seals, ink stamps and posters are stacked up to the ceiling. The paraphernalia is now being laboriously trucked to NATO bases in Bosnia for delivery to polling centers in time for elections a week from this coming Saturday.

title: Year of the Elephant
description: THAT Jan. 21, 7,000 joyous Republicans from all over the state gathered in Trenton for a victory parade.

title: Signs of Summer's End
description: Beside a county road near the town of Hygiene, Colo., stands a cottonwood that turned completely yellow the second week of August. To southbound cyclists the tree lies hidden, lurking behind a sharp dip in the road. One coasts along in summer's full incumbency -- the scent of hay practically creasing one's forehead -- when all at once the asphalt slopes away, and the lone cottonwood presents itself, its leaves shimmering in a bright wind that suddenly seems autumnal, full of the brittleness, the preternatural clarity of fall.

title: A School in a Quandary
description: A NATIONAL magazine, Redbook, named the Stratfield Elementary School in Fairfield one of the best schools in the country. It is one of only 108 schools nationwide to be twice named a blue ribbon school by the Federal Department of Education. And its principal, Roger Previs, has attained a legendary status among students, parents and teachers.

title: Adelphi Trustees Ignored Auditor's Advice
description: For four years, Adelphi University's trustees ignored their auditor's recommendation that they disclose any conflicts of interest, the trustees' audit committee chairman told a state review panel on Friday.

title: It's Small, Temporary and Turbulent, but a Beach Is a Beach
description: It isn't as startling as the discovery of what may be bacterial fossils from Mars, but it's still surprising: there's a beach in Red Hook.

title: In a Bergen Borough, Diversified Growth
description: THE lights seem to flicker off a little later at night in homes set along quiet tree-lined streets in the Bergen County Borough of Westwood.

title: English as a Second Language
description: SO FORTH

title: Teaching Science
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pension Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: West Indian Parade Returns To Fill Streets of Brooklyn
description: In Kelvin Davis's home, the wine-colored carpet is covered with a dusting of white feathers. Racks of beaded costumes stand where a coffee table ought to be. Visitors drop by, stay till dawn, leave, and are back within hours.

title: Celebrating The Power Of Theater In France
description: Correction Appended

title: The Smoke Thickens But Managers Don't Run
description: Given the recent political and legal setbacks for the tobacco industry, what are mutual fund managers doing with their big stakes in tobacco stocks? So far, a good number appear to be sitting tight and even buying more shares as values emerge, an informal survey of fund managers found.

title: Cowgirls
description: To the Editor: ''Montana Cowgirls For a Week'' (July 7) contained misimpressions that are disturbing to readers like me who have been vacationing in Montana for decades (since 1955). The cattle drive described is just another example of the exploitation of the movie ''City Slickers.'' The author describes it as having taken place ''every summer since 1992.'' But unless one has been in Montana for a hundred years or so, he is considered a newcomer.

title: Corrections
description: A table last Sunday with an article about investing in unlisted stocks misstated 1995 financial data for two such stocks. Rhinelander Telecommunications of Rhinelander, Wis., had net income of $2.1 million in 1995 and cash flow of $6.0 million; neither number was negative. Maui Land and Pineapple of Kahului, Hawaii, had cash flow of $2.1 million; the number was not negative.

title: Mosquito Threat Draws Swift Action
description: AT the end of a cool, wet summer with few beach days and no heat waves, a mosquito-borne virus has cast yet a deeper pall on areas of Long Island near mosquito breeding grounds.

title: Given More Hospital Time, New Mothers Are Taking It
description: Mothers of newborns in New Jersey are staying in the hospital 10 to 12 extra hours now that the state has a law requiring insurance companies to pay for longer stays, according to a study by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Punching More Than The Clock
description: Your workplace can be tense, and sometimes the people around you make it that way. Tempers have been known to flare and, yes, punches have been thrown. Have you ever witnessed a fistfight in the office? Have you been involved in one? We want to hear about it. Send your best ringside story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send it by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Tricia Eisenstein, Renier Brentjens
description: Dr. Tricia Lynn Eisenstein and Dr. Renier Joseph Brentjens are to be married this evening at Sail Harbor, a catering establishment in Bayville, L.I. The Rev. Emil Swiatek, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate, with Rabbi Michael Rosen taking part in the ceremony.

title: Board 2's Stubbornness Blocks Needed Ball Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: For Convention Viewers, One Person's Pizazz Was Often Another's Pshaw
description: Tough as nails at 6-foot-5 and in a hard hat and steel-toed boots, Duane McGowan, a brewery worker, just about melted as he talked about some heart-tugging moments at the Democratic National Convention.

title: Dana L. Herman, Joseph P. Covey
description: Dana Lauren Herman, a daughter of Paula and Stuart Herman of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., is to be married today in Mamaroneck, N.Y., to Joseph Paul Covey, a son of Sylvia and Alan Covey of Center Moriches, L.I. Rabbi Paul M. Steinberg is to perform the ceremony at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: A New Rebel Peril for Mexico
description: Surprise guerrilla raids across Mexico last week roiled the nation's politics and sent jitters through the economy just as the country was beginning to recover from a punishing recession.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLATBUSHThey Got the Dodgers, But They Left the Chevy

title: Rethinking Ways to Combat Campus Rape
description: THERE is general agreement among rape crisis workers that about 60 percent of the young women who are raped or otherwise sexually assaulted at college experience those attacks in the first semester of their freshman year, when they are most vulnerable.

title: Victoria Weinberg and Barry Singer
description: Victoria Faith Weinberg, the daughter of Debra and Laurence Weinberg of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Barry Alan Singer, a son of Sharon and Thomas Singer of St. Louis. Rabbi Steven Moskowitz performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: Julie A. Schumm, Arthur S. Torrey
description: Julie Ann Schumm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Schumm of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Arthur Starratt Torrey, a son of Carolyn York of Huntington, L.I., and William Torrey of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Msgr. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: A Museum Honors Bats Of Wood And Legend
description: Thirty years ago in Connecticut, Kevin Williams took his first swing at bat in the Stratford Little League while his father, the team's coach, stood by.

title: In Sardinia, Sea, Ancient Stones ...
description: WHEN God made the world, says a Sardinian legend, He gathered up all the leftover bits of dirt, hurled them down and stamped His foot on them. Thus He created Sardinia. The story is evidently multicultural, since the Greeks called Sardinia ''Ichnoussa,'' meaning footprint. This was both descriptive -- according to what passed then for cartography, and because it was a steppingstone in the sea -- and prophetic. Stepped on for millennia, Sardinia is still underrated. Italians generally think of only one thing in connection with Sardinia: summer vacation. And most non-Italians think of only two, bandits and the glamorous resort area called the Costa Smeralda, one undesirable, the other expensive. But the first is not a problem and the second is not the only destination on Sardinia.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: YORKTOWN FAIR

title: Q. and A.
description: From Merida to Palenque

title: Lamps for the Eyes, Art for the Soul
description: Although the advent of electricity in the late 19th century changed the way light was produced, the grand old fixtures of the pre-electric era have never been discarded. Candlestick lamps, chandeliers and lanterns, outfitted with flame-shaped bulbs, are adaptations of old designs for modern use with an aura of the past.

title: Computer Design Becomes Reality for Students
description: FOR an eager group of Pleasantville High School students, this academic year cannot arrive soon enough. Spurred by a course in computer-aided design, the dozen or so students are about ready to put their three-dimensional, computer-animation projects on a World Wide Web page.

title: Beating a Drum for the State University
description: THOMAS F. EGAN of Rye did not go to the State University of New York. Neither do about 115,000 other New York college and graduate students each year, and Mr. Egan, chairman of the board of trustees of the State University, wants to do something about this.

title: 'West Indian Immigrant' Does Not Mean Only 'Black'
description: To the Editor:

title: Curators, Too, Can Be Collectors,Within Limits
description: One of the reasons i got involved with Egyptomania as a collector was as an attempt to understand some of the strange things the public asks me in relation to my serious work,'' says Richard Fazzini, chairman of the Egyptian, classical and ancient Middle Eastern art department at the Brooklyn Museum, which houses one of the finest Egyptian collections in the country. ''Questions kept popping up, like 'Did ancient Egyptians have really long fangs?' When you are curating a show or writing a text, you have to deal with certain misconceptions.''

title: L.I. Vines
description: Riesling

title: Rohina Gandhi, David Hoffman
description: Dr. Rohina Gandhi, a daughter of Dr. Sushma Gandhi and Dr. Om Gandhi of Cedar Grove, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. David M.J. Hoffman, a son of Barbara Hoffman and Dr. Stephen M. J. Hoffman of Farmington Hills, Mich. Rabbi Ari Fridkis is to officiate at the Brooklake Country Club in Florham Park, N.J. Jyoti Gandhi of Arya Samaj of New Jersey, a Hindu religious organization, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Jets and Giants: So Different, Yet So Similar
description: NEVER before have the Giants and the Jets opened the season with such different philosophies and in such different atmospheres. But each team's future appears to be the same: no berth in the Super Bowl XXXI playoffs.

title: Yanks Create Bad Vibes By Yapping
description: HEARING the Yankees whine about the addition of Charlie Hayes reminded me of how old Yankee teams reacted when management brought in veterans for the pennant run.

title: Gail F. Levine, Ian Gershengorn
description: Gail Felice Levine, the daughter of Marcia and Dr. Jules Levine of Dallas, is to be married there today to Ian Heath Gershengorn, the son of Judge Wendie Gershengorn and Dr. Kenneth Gershengorn of Weston, Mass. Rabbi Yitzchak Cohen is to perform the ceremony at the Westin Galleria Hotel.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the Electoral College strategies of President Clinton and Bob Dole referred incorrectly to the vote mechanism. There are not 51 separate ''winner take all'' contests. As the maps noted, electors from Nebraska and Maine are not required to vote unanimously for the popular-vote winner in their states.

title: In His Own Words
description: JACK KEMP

title: BREAKING THE RULES
description: I enjoyed Patricia T. O'Conner's On Language column ''Breaking the Rules'' (July 28). The attempt to teach ''It is I'' often results in the hypercorrection ''She gave it to Jane and I'' or in avoidance of the pronoun even where it would occur in normal speech, as in ''Harry and George and myself went to the game.''

title: U.S. Calls Alert As Iraqis Strike A Kurd Enclave
description: Ignoring strong American warnings, armored Iraqi divisions drove into the north today and seized an important city in the Kurdish enclave. President Clinton ordered American troops in the region on high alert and sent in reinforcements.

title: Fuhgeddaboutit
description: ''WILL COPYWRITERS EVER CAPTURE the vernacular of New York City?'' asked a ''reefer'' (a boxed promotion referring the reader to an article on an inside page) in The New York Times. The answer: ''Fuhgeddaboutit.''

title: The Seanachie
description: UNLIKE SO MANY OF TODAY'S MEMOIRISTS, WHO OFTEN SUM UP THEIR LIVES from the vantage point of their late 20's, Frank McCourt waited until he was in his 60's to write down his life story, a feat of literary restraint that he shrugs off dryly in his Irish brogue. ''I'm a late bloomer,'' he says. Forget that when he did finally manage to write about his life, in what would turn out to be his first book, the manuscript sailed down a stream of writerly acquaintances accumulated over a life spent among a significant percentage of the authors and journalists living in New York: McCourt's book was not a triumph of connections. He had a childhood worth writing about -- a sad, hard Irish-American childhood -- and a refreshingly unembittered voice with which to tell it, and that is why the book, just published by Scribner's and entitled ''Angela's Ashes,'' appears to be on a trajectory less associated with the output of retired public-school English teachers, which McCourt happens to be, than with that of youthful literary sensations.

title: Baghdad's Move Puts the Future of Kurdish Safe Haven in Doubt
description: The assault by Iraqi troops and Kurdistan Democratic Party guerrillas yesterday to oust a rival Kurdish faction from the city of Erbil in northern Iraq could spell the end of the independent Kurdish enclave.

title: Yanks Have Lots of Veterans but No Leader
description: As the Yankees work hard to regain their balance in the American League East standings, one can't help thinking of just what intangible the richest team in baseball still needs to beg, borrow or buy in order to secure a post-season berth.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Fiscal Clash Over Special Classes
description: As the nearly 21,000 students of Community School District 2 stream back this week in the annual chaos that is the opening week of school, there is some strife and confusion at the adult end of things. Last week, the community school board clashed over the budget, especially over more than $10 million in spending for students with disabilities.

title: 'We'll Be Right Back, After This Hip and Distorted Commercial Break'
description: Race was never a big issue with him. When someone would ask about it, Tiger Woods would demur, saying he didn't care anything about being ''the best black golfer'' or ''the best minority golfer,'' just the best golfer, period. He wasn't interested in being a role model, he said, adding that he would play his sport the best way he knew how and let the rest take care of itself.

title: Correction
description: A map on Aug. 11 with a front-page article about the long wait for tee times on public golf courses in New Jersey misspelled the name of a private course. It is the Metedeconk Golf Club, in Jackson.

title: Cinema Verities
description: THE FILM EXPLAINER

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE YEAR OF THE FLOOD

title: The Many Myths About Sex Offenders
description: THE California solution for child molesters sounds so simple -- just castrate them, or make them take a chemical that takes away their sex drive, and they will offend no more. The plan comes at a time when both political parties are vying to see who can be toughest on crime. And it targets the criminals Americans find most disgusting.

title: Inside the Lunchbox: Cream Cheese and Jelly? Nah. How About Noodles?
description: MY children attend a school that encourages parents to observe and participate in all aspects of school life. This otherwise sound policy has one drawback. Once you see what children actually eat at lunch time, you'll never peel carrots with enthusiasm again.

title: Serb Militants Are Running Hard for Posts in Bosnia Election
description: The first thing Slavko Aleksic plans to do if elected to the joint Croat-Muslim-Serbian Parliament next month is to destroy it.

title: License Revoked
description: Aaron Nabil's eyes are black circles; he is unshaven, weary. ''The idea,'' insists the Rock Creek, Ore., computer consultant, ''was just to make drivers accountable.''

title: IT'S HIS PARTY
description: I am an average American who feels that the Reagan years made me proud of an honest and moral leader -- one who did his best, had faith in human nature and lifted this country's spirits and patriotism to heights I hadn't observed since World War II.

title: A Bat Mitzvah, Beaming Faces
description: WHEN Rebecca Leader had her bat mitzvah this summer, she did what most children do on this special day. She chanted Hebrew blessings, she read from the Torah and she gave a speech thanking her family and teachers.

title: Teaching Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Saving Energy Out of Style?
description: ENERGY conservation is important to Robert Wiedenmann Sr., a Wallingford contractor who lives in a passive-solar house heated by burning wood and by the sun. ''But I guess I'm a dying breed,'' he said.

title: 36th Bridge Crosses The Seine in Paris
description: A new bridge spanning the Seine in Paris has opened to traffic and pedestrians. The Pont Charles de Gaulle stretches from the Quai d'Austerlitz on the left bank to the Quai de la Rapee in the southeastern section of the city, and stands between Pont de Bercy upstream and the Viaduc d'Austerlitz. Costing $43 million, it is Paris's 36th bridge, its eighth and the last scheduled to be built within the century. Designed by Roman Karasinski & Arretche, it is a simple steel roadway 115 feet wide with an ''airplane wing'' profile set on two white concrete pillars.

title: Dole Asserts The President Is Neglectful On Drug Fight
description: In his weekly radio address, Bob Dole today pledged that if elected President, he would do more than President Clinton is doing to curb the abuse of illegal drugs.

title: New York City's Gift to Clinton: A Lower National Crime Rate
description: NEW YORK CITY'S Republican Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, may or may not endorse President Clinton, but he probably has already done as much to re-elect him as any Democratic mayor.

title: They Warmed to Camp, Even if Summer Was Cold and Rainy
description: Last week, after a full summer of swimming, horseback riding and cabin raiding, Y.M.C.A. Camp Bernie sent home all its happy campers, ending its 40th season. Situated on 250 acres in the rolling mountains of Hunterdon County, this coed sleep-over camp brings together children aged 8 to 16 from cities and towns all over New Jersey -- plus, this year, Spain and Russia.

title: A Prince's Passion for His Lost Ballerina
description: A MELANCHOLY Prince with 22 useless titles is in mourning for his love, the mysterious ballerina Leocadia. She chewed orchids all day long, swathed in scarves of immense length. One of those scarves was the death of her after she knotted it too extravagantly and too tightly after a long discussion on the meaning of art.

title: Israel's Leadership Vacuum
description: Events always tend to move swiftly in the Middle East, but even for this region it is striking how swiftly all the bad ideas Israel's Prime Minister, Bibi Netanyahu, came into office with have been swept aside by the realities of his neighborhood. None of this should be surprising. It was obvious during the campaign that Mr. Netanyahu was very adept at playing on Israelis' anxieties about the Labor-led peace process. But it was equally obvious that Mr. Netanyahu never had any plan of his own for delivering the ''peace with security'' that he promised. So his first 100 days have been characterized by a series of half-baked proposals that have gone nowhere -- so much so that the Israeli press is full of talk about the leadership vacuum at the top in Israel.

title: Those High-Cost Birthdays Have a Psychic Cost, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Doormen Told: Hold Doors, Not People
description: If this story were told on a daytime talk show, the title might be ''Doormen Who Love Too Much and the Tenants Who Love Them (and a Few Who Don't).''

title: Take My E-Mail, Please
description: ''FW: FWD>FWD-(FWD) a joke for y'' is the heading on this morning's E-mail. Something tells me that I'm not the first person to read it.

title: Man Confesses to Killing
description: A Long Island City man arrested in the killing of his estranged companion has confessed to stabbing her on a subway platform last week, a spokeswoman for the Queens District Attorney said yesterday.

title: CONNECTUCUT GUIDE
description: YALE CONNECTION

title: For Both Dole and Clinton, Congress Can Be a Real Problem
description: THE argument was made time and again last week at the Democratic National Convention: Bill Clinton must be re-elected, because a Democratic President is the last line of defense against an onslaught by a reactionary Republican Congress.

title: Checkmate In Chechnya
description: After 20 months of a war that has ravaged Chechnya but has perhaps even more profoundly scarred the battered Russian psyche, the leading military officials from both sides have now announced that the bloodshed is over.

title: Welfare-to-Work Plans Show Success Is Difficult to Achieve
description: Deborah C. Washam shook her head with an emotion that appeared to be equal parts sorrow and exasperation.

title: Michelle Kang, Michael S. Kim
description: Michelle Inah Kang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. M. Kang of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Sangyun Kim, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Soo Young Kim of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Alistair Drummond, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Huguenot Memorial Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Suzanne Wishnack, R.A. Morris Jr.
description: Suzanne Cary Wishnack, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Bennett Wishnack of Richmond, is to be married today to Richard Ainstworth Morris Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris of Grand Rapids, Mich. Judge Thomas O. Jones of the District Court of Richmond is to officiate at the Homestead in Hot Springs, Va.

title: Expansion, Yes. Humiliation, No.
description: The National Football League's latest expansion teams, the Carolina Panthers and the Jacksonville Jaguars, experienced phenomenal success during their opening seasons in 1995. Expansion teams such as the Dallas Cowboys of 1960, the Minnesota Vikings of 1961 and the New Orleans Saints of 1967 were not as fortunate.

title: The Progress of German Unification
description: When the Iron Curtain fell in 1989, there was no more important consequence than the reunification of Germany. Seven years later the joining of East and West Germany attracts less attention but is no less critical to the future of Europe. Fortunately, for an undertaking this gargantuan, unification is progressing relatively well. It seems to be meeting everyone's expectations -- except the Germans'.

title: Chang Does A Belly-Flop, But Still Beats Spadea
description: From Vince Spadea's modest vantage point, the book on Michael Chang was a forbidding one: he never misses, he never surrenders and he never gives the Vince Spadeas of the world any room to breathe, particularly not when they're sharing his Grand Slam oxygen.

title: Derring-Don't
description: HACKS

title: Goldsmith Inlet, Other Views
description: The article $(''State Looks for Solution for a 300-Foot Jetty'' (July 28$) fails to present the complexity of the issues that face the communities east, west, and south of the Goldsmith Inlet Jetty. The town is ready to leap to action. But there are many questions before a constructive, as opposed to destructive, plan can be contemplated. .

title: Error Fans Fears of Chemical Cleanup at Utah Plant
description: When the big $650 million factory finally started crunching up chemical weapons here in the Utah desert a week ago, the Army boasted that it was using some of the most advanced technology in the world to destroy some of the most lethal weapons ever created.

title: Is There Ever Enough Studio Time?
description: Guaranteed to happen this season: Feeling it lacks adequate time for features about assistant coaches who teach retired postal workers the huckle buck, ESPN expands its 90-minute ''N.F.L. Countdown'' pre-game program to two hours. Fox steps up to 120 minutes because that's the only way Howie Long and Terry Bradshaw will remove the gag from newcomer Ronnie Lott's mouth. NBC, which has just doubled its time to 60 minutes, adds 30 more of taped rhythmic gymnastics every week. Said John Tesh, the newest ''N.F.L. on NBC'' co-host: ''Football needed more drama. I'll goose it up.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 11 about Vienna misstated the German word for a tavern that serves new wine. It is heurige, not heuringer.

title: From Laundry To a Church
description: To the Editor:

title: No School for Scandal
description: IN response to public cynicism about how much students are learning, many states are adopting new mandatory standards for their elementary and high school students. For example, New Jersey has just adopted standards for seven academic fields; students will be tested in grades 4, 8 and 11 to see how well they have mastered these subjects. And New York State ruled recently that all students will be required to pass its Regents exams to get a high school diploma.

title: 'Give Back to Your Community,' She Said
description: A Harvard Medical School dean was musing over my future career options as a doctor the first time I heard the phrase ''giving back to the community.'' Puzzled by what she might mean, I wondered what it was that I could have unwittingly stolen. (Having grown up in white America, I suppose I must have been taught that the dark one in the room must always be guilty of something; in my case especially, this was usually in fact true.) It seemed virtually impossible to me that I owed anybody anything, given the history of numbing loss that was all that I had inherited from my Cuban family. Indeed, it seemed to me that someday reparations would have to be made to me, for the lost sugar plantation and the 1,000 slaughtered head of cattle, for the nameless stream that ran with our blood and the salt and sand quarries in which our murdered bodies were dumped.

title: In Song and Dance, Orphan and a Con Man
description: NEAR the end of the second act of ''Paper Moon,'' Addie Loggins, an 11-year-old orphan, and Moses Pray, a con man who just might be Addie's father, reach out in song: ''Who Belongs to Who?'' (hers) and ''You With Me?'' (his). For more than two hours the musical has been blatantly programming the moment of contact, the crucial connection between two lost souls. At last, it is made.

title: A 12-Story Rental On Edge of Little Italy
description: A new 12-story brick rental building on the northwest corner of Houston and Elizabeth Streets that is to be ready for occupancy in the middle of next month consists mostly of one-bedroom apartments.

title: No Small Victory: At Least Both Want to Win
description: Their relationship is like that of a divorced couple who every weekend must tolerate each other when one parent stops by to visit the kids. The couple in this case are quarterback Dave Brown and Coach Dan Reeves. The child is the New York Giants, something the two men desperately care about and spend every weekend trying to make a winner. And the strained relationship between Brown and Reeves -- both hard-working, smart and stubborn in their own ways -- must remain civil if the Giants are to have any success this season.

title: At Dawn In Bronx, The Joys Of Golf
description: ''I'LL be in a little late tomorrow,'' I tell the boss. ''I've got an early morning meeting in the Bronx.''

title: Here's Something New: The U.S. Beats Canada
description: Until tonight, the United States was 0-7-1 against Canada at this level. Never had the best American professionals defeated the best Canadians in the four previous Canada Cup tournaments.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
description: HARD COVER

title: Schools Tightening Academic Rules for Athletes
description: HUNTINGTON High School athletes will find it tougher to make the team in the fall, since the school board has decided to tighten its eligibility requirements for participation in sports.

title: Lights, Camera, Avarice: A Securities Soap Opera
description: AS a floor trader at the American Stock Exchange in the 1980's, I would unwind at night by channel surfing, zipping past all the standard newsroom, mod squad, public defender, private eye and forensic medical shows, and wonder, ''When will they ever do a show about us?''

title: Elizabeth Dodge And Evan Olson
description: Elizabeth Burt Dodge, a daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. Charles Wolcott Henry Dodge of Gorham, Me., is to be married today at her parents' summer house in Rockport, Me., to Evan Eldon Olson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Olson of New York. The Rev. Woodbury Bowman, an Episcopal minister, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: AFTER LIBERALISM

title: Challenging a Star, Yet Again
description: Tyrone Butler is everything Susan Molinari is not. He is not a baby-toting mother, a perky party leader or a hometown guy recognizable in the grocery store.

title: Singing End-of-Beach-Season Blues
description: IT is almost here the day that for some is worse than April 15, when taxes are due; worse than the day after Christmas. Within hours it will be upon us: a day loathed by those who love summer, dreaded by those who cannot shake that back-to-school feeling even if they are grown up now.

title: Stay Away From Whales, U.S. Agencies Tell Boaters
description: Cape May and Sandy Hook were busy whaling centers in the 18th and 19th centuries, and today whales still migrate northward near the New Jersey coast from December to March. Now the Coast Guard, which operates two cutters out of Sandy Hook, and the National Marine Fisheries Service are taking steps to protect the mammals when they appear.

title: Remaking a Treasure Chest of Tools and Trades
description: THE Museum of Early Trades and Crafts here is closed on major holidays, including Labor Day. But since the history of labor in pre-industrial New Jersey is its reason for being, it observes the occasion with a traditional Labor Day picnic on its grounds. Those who attend must bring their own lunches, but tomorrow from noon to 4 P.M. the museum will provide a bill of fare that includes puppet shows, bicycle decorating followed by a parade of the jazzed-up bikes, and 19th-century folk and popular music. A small exhibition on the history of Labor Day will be mounted just inside the doors of the museum's Victorian-era building.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Out to Lunch. Forever.

title: Back to School
description: Great Books

title: Wildfires in the West Spreading Destruction at a Record Rate
description: At midday, the skies turned black over the Sundance subdivision, about six miles southeast of Bend in central Oregon. A firestorm -- fanned by erratic 35-mile-an-hour winds -- roared through the pines toward the 2,900-square-foot house of Charles Blakeslee.

title: Sneakers on Phone Wires Had Innocent Origins
description: To the Editor:

title: Zeke Segal, Journalist, 78
description: Zeke Segal, a former Southeastern bureau chief for CBS News who was considered the dean of Atlanta's media corps during the years when what has been called the New South was emerging, died on Aug. 22 in Atlanta. He was 78 years old.

title: Developing Nations Rely on Our Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking a Train With a View
description: TRAVELERS contemplating a trip by rail across North America are probably wondering what impact Amtrak's recently announced cutbacks will have on their plans.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE FLIGHT OF THE RED KNOT

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A LETHAL INVOLVEMENT

title: Back to Harrods
description: To the Editor: A poem:

title: Back to Harrods
description: To the Editor: In writing about the lavatories at Harrods, Stanley Nehmer (''A Costly Loo,'' Letters on Travel, Aug. 4) questions our policy of charging his wife a pound to use the lavatory, particularly as she had spent the equivalent of $170 in the store. Mr. and Mrs. Nehmer will be pleased to know that, in light of their complaint, Harrods has changed its policy. Since June 27, any customer who spends 100 pounds ($160) or more may use the lavatories free of charge upon presentation of the sales receipt. There is also no charge for account customers, the disabled, children, expectant mothers and patrons of our restaurants and bars.

title: As Israel Tilts To the Right, Envoy to U.S. Makes an Exit
description: As Israel's Ambassador to the United States for the last four years, Itamar Rabinovich faced up to American Jews who lobbied the American Government against Israel's attempt to find peace with the Palestinians and Syria. And when the halting pace of those negotiations helped defeat the Labor Party Government that appointed him, Mr. Rabinovich resigned from his post immediately.

title: Senior Statesmen?
description: To the Editor: Remarkable! Betsy Wade is ''delighted'' to take advantage of a 50 percent discount on New York City transit fares, yet shocked and unhappy when the electronic display reads ''elderly.''

title: Catherine O'Brien, Thomas Strong
description: Catherine Judith O'Brien and Thomas Joseph Strong, reporters for The Associated Press in Washington, are to be married today at the First Parish Church in Cohasset, Mass. The Rev. Ivan Fleischman, a nondenominational minister, is to officiate with the Rev. Richard Bourgeois, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Airline Safety Data: How Useful Are They?
description: An old question has been raised again in the aftermath of the Valujet crash three and a half months ago: Why doesn't the Government make safety data on the airlines more readily available to travelers?

title: The Importance of Being Jackie
description: JACK AND JACKIE

title: Goldsmith Inlet, Other Views
description: The Goldsmith's Jetty has lost its function completely, because it is all filled with sand. It accomplished what it was set to do, namely, maintenance of the inlet and the severely eroded beach west of it.

title: Proposed Dog Run Would Shrink Playground
description: To the Editor:

title: Have Bulldozer, Will Move Dirt (and Make History)
description: CINDY KUBY can spin a 50-ton bulldozer in a tight circle. She can lift and dump 10,000 pounds of dirt with a loader in a single scoop. She can dig a 15-foot hole in 20 minutes with a backhoe.

title: Rolling Down the Highway With the Clinton Road Show
description: It was only a matter of time until it happened, and just a few minutes before midnight Friday, it finally did. After a round of rip-snorting speeches and fireworks under a nearly full moon along the Ohio riverfront in Paducah, Ky., the Willie Nelson tape blared out.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Labor Day will be observed tomorrow.

title: Red Sox's Rise Starts After Some Weight Is Shed
description: Putting this season's most remarkable comeback in perspective, the Boston Red Sox gained 11 1/2 games on the Yankees in 4 weeks. Teetering at a distance of 17 games Aug. 1, the Red Sox slashed that deficit to 5 1/2 before the weekend. In 1978, when the Yankees overcame a 14-game Boston lead, they gained 7 games in 4 weeks and needed 7 weeks and 2 days to gain as much as the Red Sox this season.

title: Caseworker Is Dismissed in Fatal Beating Case
description: A city caseworker has been dismissed for mishandling the case of Elisa Izquierdo, the 6-year-old girl who was beaten to death by her mother while her case was under the city's watch, officials said yesterday.

title: Mailboxes Yield Some Secrets, Many Wallets
description: Andrew Sozzi remembers his days as a mail carrier, making his way up Central Park West early on Monday mornings, his keys jangling and each mailbox he opened spilling over with more than just letters and bills. ''They would be teeming with wallets,'' he said. ''I guess it makes sense after all the action in the park on the weekends.''

title: Haitians Serve Politics At Festival
description: It won't be all rum punch and steel bands at the West Indian Day Parade in Crown Heights tomorrow. Hoping to inject a dose of politics into the annual Caribbean festival, a coalition of Haitians will use the occasion to call attention to recent Federal legislation that cuts off government benefits to legal immigrants.

title: Huh?
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Therapy Unit Celebrates 10th Year
description: MUSIC has its players and listeners, its professionals and amateurs, its teachers and students. Less widely recognized are the music therapists, who use rhythm, melody and song to help treat a number of conditions.

title: Katka Stranska, J.E. Silverblatt
description: Dr. Katerina Stranska, the daughter of Justice Olga Stranska and Dr. Jiri Stranskych of Prague, is to be married today to Jonathan Edward Silverblatt, the son of Annamaura and Dr. Fredrick Silverblatt of North Kingstown, R.I. Rabbi Michael Z. Cahana is to perform the ceremony at Nelahozevas Castle, in Nelahozevas, Czech Republic.

title: Condemned in South Korea
description: Former President Chun Doo Hwan, 65, was convicted and sentenced to death in South Korea last week for mutiny and insurrection in a landmark case that seemed to close a chapter of repression in the nation's past.

title: Another Game, Another Memory
description: THE National Football League is back, and all's well with the world.

title: On Planning Care For After 65
description: The Long Island Q&A $(''The Need to Plan for Care After 65'' Aug. 4"$), omits the crucial issue of buying insurance for long-term care. Such insurance, although costly, is widely available and can provide combinations of professional care in your home or in a nursing home. No one's ''after 65 plan'' is complete without, at least, reviewing these options.

title: Few Tears for the Death of the Network Convention
description: THE curtains have rung down on the overly managed political conventions of 1996, and broadcast executives and journalists are asking themselves whether the 44-year tradition of live network coverage is doomed. What they should be asking is: Who cares?

title: Blue Ribbon Goes to Clinton At This Year's County Fair
description: This is county fair week here, a testament to America's ability to turn most anything into a competition, whether it is the quest for Stark County's heaviest pumpkin squash (a 183.5 pounder, grown by Linda Parker), the county's best pie (an apple, baked by Betty Datkuliak), the top Limousine breed steer (raised by Joey Milano) or the best all-around burpless cucumber (produced by Viola Deremer).

title: Mexico's President Vows to Fight, but Not Repress, Rebel Group
description: President Ernesto Zedillo, seeking to reassure a worried nation before his most important speech of the year, has pledged to fight a new left-wing rebel group that made wide-ranging attacks this week with arrests and other legal means, not repression.

title: Boom Boxes Are Booming. But Why?
description: News item: while audio sales as a whole have declined steadily over the last several months, compact stereo systems are showing modest growth.

title: Two Marriotts Open In Mexico City
description: Marriott International now has two hotels in Mexico City, the 312-room J. W. Marriott Hotel, which opened last month on the Paseo de la Reforma, and the 600-room former Hotel Continental Plaza at the capital's Benito Juarez International Airport, which changed its name in July to the Marriott Aeropuerto.

title: Schools Greeting New Year With Optimism
description: OVER all, Long Island school districts, including the more troubled ones, are starting the school year in an optimistic mood, educators say.

title: Scandal or Scapegoating?
description: DUBIOUS CONCEPTIONS

title: O Governor, Won't You Buy Me a Mercedes Plant?
description: FOR Alabama, first in little but college football, the quest three years ago for the nation's only Mercedes plant touched deep, unrequited desires. ''We're going to get Mercedes and we're going to make them love us,'' Gov. James E. Folsom Jr.'s wife, Marsha, told him and anyone else at the mansion who needed bucking up as dozens of states courted the auto maker with costly promises.

title: And Now, Day-Care Training by Video
description: Trying to trim its budget even as it prepares for a surge in day-care needs, New York State plans a major overhaul of the way it trains people who provide in-home child care.

title: 'Gay Friendly' Fund Has Blue-Chip Focus
description: THE first mutual fund to invest in gay-friendly companies tries not only to identify those that already have progressive policies but also to persuade other companies to meet its criteria.

title: Whimsical Stitchery From Times Past
description: SAMPLERS created by young women in the 18th and 19th centuries serve as inspiration today. In fact, a group of 100 women, members of the Laurel Chapter of the Friends of Counted Embroidery, have been meeting for the past 14 years at Christ the King Lutheran Church in Newtown, to share their common interest: embroidery.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Now It's Chic For Women, Too

title: Helping Homeless Bake Their Way Out of Poverty
description: Carmen Wiggins is homeless and a recovering drug addict, but armed with a rolling pin, a pastry knife and a fully stocked kitchen, she is anything but helpless.

title: Dallas
description: No longer does the State Fair of Texas in Dallas feature tattooed ladies and, as in the early 70's, H. L. Hunt, then probably the world's wealthiest man, hawking his HLH Gastro-Majic indigestion pills. But later this month, you can ride a 212-foot-high Ferris wheel, witness the judging of the champion Brahman bull or Angora goat and marvel at King Tusk, billed as the world's only performing hippo.

title: Helen H.B. Seitz, Steven L. Crystal
description: Helen Hillary Brewster Seitz, the daughter of Suzanne Manning Barr of Lovettsville, Va., and Raymond Seitz of London, is to be married today to Steven Louis Crystal, a son of Laura Crystal and Dr. Raymond F. Crystal of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Barbara Henry, an Episcopal minister, is to officiate with Rabbi Arthur Blecher at the home of the bride's mother.

title: No Vacancy
description: The Case Against Immigration

title: In India, Attacks by Wolves Spark Old Fears and Hatreds
description: When the man-eating wolf came to this tranquil village toward dusk on an evening in mid-August, it was every child's worst nightmare come true.

title: Huge Minnesota Mall Adds Big Aquarium
description: The Mall of America, the immense shopping and entertainment complex outside Minneapolis, now has a 70,000-square-foot aquarium, Underwater World, beneath its main level.

title: Stopping the Scalpers
description: To the Editor:

title: Perfect Role Model For Sports in 90's
description: The player to watch this season is Arliss Michaels, the charming, sleazy superagent who calls his clients ''our last warriors'' and declares, ''My job is to make their dreams come true.'' His clients include ''a role model'' who was sacked attempting a quarterback sneak with a transvestite, and a young basketball player who suffered a heart attack right after signing a guaranteed multimillion-dollar contract.

title: How to Clean Your House's Exterior
description: MOST homeowners realize the value of interior cleaning, but they often fail to appreciate how important it is to clean the exterior of the house. It is, after all, the first thing your visitors see. More important, a good washing will remove the dirt and grit particles that collect during the year. When agitated by the wind and rain, these abrasive particles can quickly mar or damage your siding or masonry. An annual cleaning can help prolong the life of those surfaces.

title: A Total, Loving Picture of Animal Health
description: WHAT animals need now is love, sweet love, says a best-selling veterinarian-author. From Dr. Allen Schoen's point of view, all the money in the world can't replace what there's just too little of.

title: They Live to Be Yankees, but Lately It's Tough
description: Sure it's been excruciating for any Yankees fan, sitting and yelping helplessly at the grave reality of the Bronx Bombers getting shellacked day after day, allowing their once fat and impregnable lead to shrivel to nearly nothing. No wonder all the radio call-in shows are full of vitriol. No wonder aggrieved people are kicking the dog.

title: Board 2's Stubbornness Blocks Needed Ball Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: Sadistic Yellow Vitriol
description: From the boys-will-be-boys annals:

title: Unscrupulous Mechanics Are Widespread Plague
description: To the Editor:

title: The Civil War Is Back, as a Cottage Industry That Is
description: THE centennial of the Civil War came and went in the 1960's without any tremendous fanfare. Perhaps it was because it was not the best of times to reflect on a war that had torn the United States apart. In the 1960's the country was fixated on another agonizing internecine battle, this one fought in the streets in many cities, over an unpopular war half a world away in Vietnam.

title: Again, Setback In Gala For Opera
description: IT is the time of year to begin considering some fall vocal and orchestral events, many taking place at Purchase College, which not only offers its own series but also serves as home to the subscription concerts of three professional orchestras and the Westchester Hudson Opera.

title: Multiple Personalities
description: Everyone in this picture has two things in common. First, they are all wearing sweaters by Giorgio Armani, who served up the best knitwear collection for fall. And second, they are all John Leguizamo, the actor who created Mambo Mouth and Spic-o-Rama and who is truly a multiple of one.

title: Whistling for Voters
description: PERHAPS Bill Clinton is not such an untraditional Democrat after all.

title: It Takes Some Tennis To Make a Collegian
description: THE most heartwarming tennis story I've heard is not at the United States Open. Never was, never will be, though that's not to say that walking onto the green hardcourts of the Louis Armstrong Stadium wasn't Juan Garcia's dream, once upon a time.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-15

title: A Question About God? Just Hand It to the Usher
description: On a Saturday evening at Calvary Church, a modern structure beside Interstate 96, the Rev. Rob Bell finished his sermon and reached for the slips of paper that ushers have collected from among the 400 people in the pews.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: As you might imagine, John Tierney's article ''Recycling Is Garbage'' (June 30) has caused quite a stir in Seattle. We can't begin to know what New York City's problems might be, but here recycling is a proven, cost-effective part of the solid-waste-management system.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Key Puts the Yankees on Cruise Control for a Rout
description: A dozen Yankees surrounded a small television in a corner of the visitor's clubhouse at Anaheim Stadium this afternoon, watching the Baltimore Orioles play the Seattle Mariners. They shouted encouragement like typical fans, criticized players and plays like typical fans and, unlike typical Yankees fans, actually seemed relaxed.

title: Little League Team Faces a Loss, of Hard-Won Field
description: To Maurice Faucette, the Little League baseball field at 115th Street between Lenox and Fifth Avenues, which he helped carve from a rat-infested garbage dump, has taught some indifferent youngsters, now known as the South Harlem Reds, teamwork and grit. And, Mr. Faucette contends, it must be preserved. ''Give the children an environment in which to breathe and grow,'' he said last week. ''Give them this field.''

title: For the Great White Way, More Glitz
description: MICKEY MOUSE is going up on 42d Street, a larger video screen will replace Sony's Jumbotron at the south end of Times Square and even the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is planning to get into the act.

title: Does Cost Outweigh Risk in the War on Terror?
description: THE vaunted military and security organs of the United States, bereft of the clarity of the Soviet enemy or the probability of traditional war, have turned considerable attention and resources to the scourge of international terrorism, the weapon of the weak and dispossessed.

title: Electronic Hitch
description: To the Editor: Early in May I purchased a United air ticket to Hawaii as a graduation present for my son. The reservation was made over the phone and issued as an ''electronic ticket'' charged to my credit card. My son received a confirmation itinerary in the mail noting he would need to present a photo identification at check-in. I paid the bill.

title: A Sculptor Who Collaborates With Nature
description: TEA BAGS were what drew my attention to Jim Toia used tea bags laid on a shelf at eye level. It was a gag, but one well composed and a lot prettier than anything Duchamp thought up. The time was a few years ago; the scene, a show tried by a jury of one at Montclair State College, now a university.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Opening Up the Ranks

title: N.F.C. Scouting Reports
description: (Teams are listed in predicted order of finish)

title: Greeley Doesn't Rip
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A.
description: What's A 'Wrap' Mortgage?

title: One of the Three R's Is Revenge
description: ACTS OF REVISION

title: Jessica deSecundy, Jonathan Lubow
description: Jessica Julianne deSecundy, the daughter of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg of Flint Hill, Va., and Claudia deSecundy Lewis of Cambridge, Mass., is to be married today to Jonathan William Lubow, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Lubow of Convent Station, N.J. Rabbi Barry Greene is to perform the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Four Days in the Footsteps of Pioneers
description: AFTER hefting my backpack at the trail head to Lower Muley Twist Canyon in Utah's Capitol Reef National Park, I began tossing things out.

title: Talk Station Comes to Rescue Of a Troubled Big-Band Brother
description: WJUX-FM, the endangered big-band station in Dumont that calls itself Jukebox Radio, may survive after all.

title: And Now, a Tomato Big Enough To Serve a Football Team
description: Richard Tempalski says he could eat tomato sandwiches all day. A good thing, because he has 35 tomato plants in his yard in Franklin Park.

title: A Seven-Hour Hike By a 'Great Eccentric'
description: To the Editor:

title: Up From the Farm
description: STAY HERE

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on Aug. 18 about a Holocaust memorial under construction in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, misstated the origin of its design. Markers commemorating 11 specific groups persecuted by the Nazis were part of the original design by the architect, George P. Vellonakis, but have since been dropped. The architect did not add 10 such tablets to his original proposal.

title: Miss Newberry And Mr. Barclay
description: Margaret Gillies Newberry, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Jay L. Newberry 3d of Wayland, Mass., was married yesterday to William Anson Barclay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Douglas Barclay of Pulaski, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Hill Downes performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Anne's in-the-Fields in Lincoln, Mass.

title: SCHOLARSHIPS FOR THE RICH
description: THEY CALL IT ''SENDING THE LIMO.'' IT'S THE phrase Ivy League admissions officers use when a school outside the league tries to lure away a top student with a lavish deal. There is still talk at Columbia, for instance, about Kevin Seal, who was accepted into the class of 1997 from Indian Hills High School near Cincinnati (terrific board scores; editor of the school newspaper; proficient on saxophone, bassoon, oboe and piano). Kevin's father, who owns a small software firm, balked when Columbia offered his son no financial aid. So Kevin is now a senior at Indiana University, where he enjoys an all-expense paid deal.

title: Study Faults Procedures For Choosing U.N. Chief
description: The Clinton Administration's threat to veto a second term for Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali without publicly naming alternative candidates has given new life to an old debate: Is there not a better way to choose the leader of the United Nations than through back-room deals among influential governments?

title: Both Tropical And Topical
description: These pets don't sing, they don't bark and they won't replace hats. Still the iguana is becoming fashionable. And for many youngsters, these prehistoric-looking animals are reminiscent of miniature dinosaurs. This summer, the iguanas, their nails cut to avoid scratching, could be seen perched on the heads or shoulders of their owners. When they were taken outside, usually when the weather was warm, many owners used harnesses. At 58th Street and Fifth Avenue, a woman known as the ''iguana lady'' (left, center) has been displaying her pets for years. Iguanas, native to Mexico and South America, often live high in trees, where their bluish-green or beige and brown colorings become camouflage. In captivity, they like to climb curtains.

title: Through the Eyes of a 102-Year-Old Painter
description: The son of Russian immigrants who lived in East Harlem, Alfred Levitt arrived in Greenwich Village in 1913. He studied at the leftist Ferrer School on East 107th Street, where he was a nude model so that he might hear the lectures of the painter Robert Henri for free. He shared a house on 14th Street with Marcel Duchamp, and helped a Greenwich Village pol named Fiorello La Guardia get elected to Congress in 1916. Mr. Levitt turned 102 on Aug. 15. From his apartment on La Guardia Place, he spoke about his life.

title: An Unpretentious Italian Food Outpost
description: BALZARINI'S is the least hip restaurant in the Hamptons and proud of it. The Southampton spot has been doing business at 210 Hampton Street (283-0704) since 1923. Its present owners, Marge and Renato Galante, bought it with a handshake in 1975.

title: Want to Be Governor? Have a Party
description: Bill Clinton was not the only candidate at the Democratic National Convention seeking to create excitement for his campaign. A whole new generation of New Jersey Democrats, mostly in their 30's and 40's, spent a lot of time and money wooing party regulars for their potential campaigns to unseat Governor Whitman next year.

title: Mary Caffrey, Thomas Hastie Jr.
description: Mary Katherine Caffrey, a writer, was married on Friday to Thomas Joseph Hastie Jr., the assistant counsel to the Democratic members of the New Jersey State Senate in Trenton. Msgr. Thomas Trapasso performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Lambertville, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Cyberscout column on Aug. 18 about the Internet Travel Network misstated a reservation procedure. The reservations are made by the client through the network, and the client's travel agent issues tickets and processes payments; the travel agent does not make the reservations.

title: Sex, Lies and Semiconductors: The Human Links
description: PRESCHOOLERS looking at a bag of popcorn on a television screen are likely to predict that it will spill if the TV set is turned upside down. Adults, of course, know better. But just how much better? Do we, too, confuse the media world with the real one?

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Music By Proxy, Or Rather, Several
description: Music these days travels largely by way of messengers. Itinerant troubadors used to deliver their messages face to face, but notation let them stay at home and ship off pictographic codes written on paper. The elaborate music boxes of the 18th century created, for a few at least, a new kind of proxy. Electronic reproduction, needless to say, has become the most sophisticated messenger of all.

title: African Statesman Still Sowing Seeds for Future
description: To visit the man they call Africa's elder statesman, you have to fly in a propeller plane to the small port of Musoma on Lake Victoria, then drive 30 miles over a dirt road past mud-walled cabins, goats and ragged children, up a lane lined with flowering jacaranda trees, until you come to a one-story house on a rocky outcropping above the village of Butiama.

title: Beasts in the Jungle
description: TOUCHED WITH FIRE

title: Labor's Voice in the Days of Downsizing
description: THESE are not the best of times for Connecticut's labor movement. Membership is down, as are wages, and unemployment is up. Still the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the umbrella organization for about 600 member unions in the state, represents 200,000 working people and adds up to a powerful political force.

title: Nancy Kellman, Andrew Leighton
description: Nancy Lynn Kellman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gary L. Kellman of New York, is to be married today to Andrew David Leighton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Leighton of Woodbury, L.I. Rabbi Beth Klafter is to officiate at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, L.I.

title: A Story His Father Might Have Told
description: WHEN DUSTIN Hoffman made his debut 29 years ago as Benjamin Braddock in ''The Graduate'' and won an Oscar nomination, the film's producer assumed Mr. Hoffman's success was due in part to perfect casting.

title: Is There a Composer in the House? Not Always
description: FOR MORE THAN A DECADE, mysterious figures have lurked on the margins of American musical organizations, especially symphony orchestras. Their duties may be precisely delineated or barely defined, their power substantial or illusory, their achievement lasting or transient. Though rarely seen in public, they may be trotted out when their presence is useful. They go by several names, the most common being composer-in-residence.

title: Will the Otto Kahn Palace Become a Health Spa?
description: OHEKA, a 109,000-square-foot turreted chateau set high on a manmade hill in this unincorporated area of the Town of Huntington, has known both opulence and decay.

title: Stock Trading, Step by Step
description: The rules that govern stock trades are changing, thanks to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which last week approved new regulations intended mainly to clean up problems at the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Give Audiences More Than a Nibble
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia and Chechens Face Unsure Peace
description: After 20 months of a war that has ravaged Chechnya and profoundly scarred the battered Russian psyche, the leading military officials from both sides have now announced that the bloodshed is over.

title: To Have an A-Plus School Year
description: For students and teachers: It's back-to-school time. What would make this a really great year for you?

title: IT'S HIS PARTY
description: Your reminder of Reagan's legacy is necessary. Many of today's voters were too young to vote during his tenure and are unaware of the problems his Presidency brought.

title: Just the Facts, Straight, the American Way
description: While watching the recent Olympics on television, I was often reminded of a great American painting that dates from the golden age of pure sportsmanship. It was an age in which neither hype nor huckster had made its debut. Artificial aids to performance had never been heard of. As for endorsements, neither cap nor shirt, shorts nor shoes had ever borne a brand name.

title: CLINTON AND DOLE SHARPEN MESSAGES IN RACE'S FINAL LEG
