description: The Presidential candidates embarked this weekend on a final 66-day frenzy of charges and countercharges, sound bites and debates, in which President Clinton is offering himself as a youthful leader for the next century and Bob Dole is seeking to ride to the White House on the promise of a 15 percent tax cut.

title: On the One Hand. . . but Then . . .
description: IT was hard to decide what to do this Labor Day weekend. Should I spend three days stuck in traffic around the Hamptons? Or head for the Jersey shore and enjoy a long weekend at the George Washington Bridge? Or should I be more adventurous and pass the holiday standing in line at various airports? In the end I decided to stay home and watch taped reruns of the political party conventions.

title: The Young And the Exhausted
description: AN old friend told me an interesting story recently. She is a junior associate at a white-shoe New York law firm. A product of Yale Law School, she has the world on a string. She has her pick of firms and what type of law to practice. Her first job pays nearly six figures. She has a secretary and a private office with a view of Manhattan. One day several weeks ago, she had a crying spasm at work.

title: A Top? Not While The Money Pours In
description: To those of a contrarian mind, the signs of a stock market top are plentiful:

title: World Airways to Stop Scheduled Service
description: World Airways is ending its regularly scheduled passenger service to focus on its more profitable cargo and charter business. Service stopped Aug. 23 on the airline's New York-Johannesburg route and is scheduled to end on Tuesday between New York and Tel Aviv. World Airways will also withdraw from scheduled European charter routes at the end of this month.

title: So the Personal Does Turn Out to Be Political
description: WHEN Bill Clinton found his purported marital infidelities splashed across tabloid pages during his first run for President, he and his aides fought back furiously, challenging reporters to explain what relevance such tales about a candidate's personal life had in a political race, particularly when presented in a supermarket tabloid.

title: Bang! You're Pinpointed
description: Redwood City, Calif., is a posh Silicon Valley community with some tough neighborhoods, and the police there have had problems with ''celebratory gunfire'' -- guns shot into the air, Beirut-style, to mark a birthday, holiday or nothing at all.

title: Holding Their Own After the Rout
description: AGGRESSIVE-GROWTH stock funds may be bloodied, but they remain unbowed.

title: William J. Stromberg -- T. Rowe Price Dividend Growth Fund
description: WHEN William J. Stromberg studies a stock for his growth-and-income fund at T. Rowe Price, he is not looking for growth at any price or even for high income. What interests him are ''growth at a reasonable price'' and a dividend with the potential to rise. It is all the better if the stock is cheap and the company has some extra cash in its coffers, ready for a possible acquisition.

title: Facing Criticism, Thai Leader Is Having a Hard Time Holding On
description: When he celebrated his 64th birthday this month, Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa was accused of fraud. He was born in July, his critics said, but wanted to have the same Aug. 19 birthday as President Clinton.

title: Betsy L. Jacobson, William Friedman
description: Betsy Lynn Jacobson, a vice president at J. P. Morgan Investment Management in New York, was married on Wednesday to William K. Friedman, the vice president of corporate affairs at Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. in New York. Anne M. Collins, a clerk of the Superior Court of Rhode Island, officiated at the Town Hall in Jamestown, R.I.

title: A Sleep-Away Camp for the Young at Heart
description: A CAMPER ambled toward the kitchen to put his sack of freshly caught bass in the freezer. Bunches of tall purple woodruff growing wild around the lake swayed in the breeze. A circle of six people were dancing the hora on a terrace overlooking the water. Others were sitting, talking and watching the dancers. One person was wearing a sweatshirt that said, ''I Love Grandpa.'' In the arts and crafts studio some were oil painting. Another group was attending a workshop on how to critique a film after having just seen Woody Allen's ''Mighty Aphrodite.''

title: Rosina Quarles, 94, An Aviation Adviser
description: Rosina Cotton Quarles, who was the Federal Government's liaison with women's aviation groups in the 1960's, died on Aug. 3 at a hospital in Pensacola, Fla. She was 94 and lived at the Azalea Trace retirement community in Pensacola.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ANATOMY OF RESTLESSNESS

title: Air Safety Plan Calls for Selective Inspections of Baggage
description: Persuaded by the airlines that it would be too expensive and time-consuming to inspect every checked bag with the latest equipment to detect for explosives, security officials are urging the White House instead to order that computerized background checks of passengers be used to decide whose bags to search.

title: Saluting Animals, Live and in Art
description: It may not have been Noah's Ark but the animals did file into Elaine Benson's gallery in Bridgehampton the other day for the annual ''Creatures'' art show.

title: Fresh Ideas From Aspiring Eagle Scouts
description: ABOUT three years ago, Patrick Shaw, a Boy Scout from Troop 170 in Farmington who was working on his Eagle rank, decided to do something a little different from what most Scouts do for the top honor. He solicited donations of thousands of toiletry items, assembled them into more than 400 personal care kits, and gave them to homeless people staying at St. Elizabeth House in Hartford.

title: A Pinch Of Common Sense
description: JUST AS A ROOKIE MIGHT GAZE UPON AN Olympian and study his technique, the amateur cook tries to copy the professional. Amateurs study cookbooks, read magazines and watch cooking shows on television, all in the hope of acquiring that ineffable something that will render them fearless in the kitchen.

title: Sylvia S. Flender, Barry A. Goldberg
description: Sylvia Scott Flender, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Flender of New York, is to be married this evening to Dr. Barry Allen Goldberg, a son of Evelyn and Moses D. Goldberg of Charleston, S.C. Arthur England, a former Chief Justice of the Florida Supreme Court, is to officiate at the Delano Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in the ''Sunday'' pages on Aug. 11 misidentified a sculpture at the Museo de la Revolucion in Havana. The figure to the left of Che Guevara is Camilo Cienfuegos, not Jose Marti.

title: Hold Private and Public Schools to Same Rules
description: To the Editor

title: Things They Didn't Teach In Drivers' Ed
description: Obviously, I drive. Obviously, growing up in a suburb, I got my license on my 16th birthday.

title: Revisiting Leo Strauss
description: To the Editor:

title: It's My Movie
description: At a recent screening of ''Basquiat,'' a movie about Jean-Michel Basquiat, the painter who rose to prominence in the 80's and died young of a drug overdose, the audience was populated with artists, gallery owners and various other downtown personages watching Hollywood actors play them on the screen. There was Mary Boone, the art dealer, sizing up Parker Posey as Mary Boone; Posey had been outfitted in Chanel, Boone's uniform. There was Rene Ricard, the poet and critic, observing the events of his own life as enacted by Michael Wincott. There was Julian Schnabel, the painter and the movie's director, basking in Gary Oldman's portrayal of him as the dashing hero of a prodigious era.

title: Betsy Sokolow And Len Sherman
description: Betsy Sokolow, the daughter of Diane Sokolow of New York and the late Mel Sokolow, was married last evening in Scottsdale, Ariz., to Len Sherman, a son of Edith Sherman and Dr. Bernard Sherman of Ardsley, N.Y. Rabbi Martin Scharff performed the ceremony at the Scottsdale Princess Hotel.

title: Jennifer Gabler and Scott B. Rose
description: Jennifer Lynn Gabler, the daughter of Toni Hilton of Aurora, Colo., and Dr. Lawrence Gabler of Denver, is to be married today in Old Greenwich, Conn., to Scott Barrett Rose, a son of Barbara and Arthur Rose of White Plains. Rabbi Mark Lipson is to perform the ceremony at the Hyatt Regency Greenwich.

title: The Flag, in Its Glory and in Dispute
description: THE exhibition ''Consensus and Conflict: The Flag in American Art,'' at the Whitney Museum in Stamford, is not the same one that caused a storm of controversy earlier this year at the Phoenix Art Museum in Arizona. Many who saw the show in Phoenix -- and many more who only got wind of it -- protested the irreverent treatment of the nation's emblem by many artists in the 1960's and after.

title: Inner Space
description: THE MOJAVE

title: In a Time of Gray on Gray, a Gleam of Brightness
description: Spirits are low in dance these days, at least in New York. It is a time of art in a minor key, as Clive Barnes put it in the current Dance magazine. But for Barbara Weisberger, founder of the Pennsylvania Ballet and more recently the Carlisle Project for ballet choreographers, things are not completely bleak.

title: Pregnant Woman Abducted; Ex-Lover Is Sought
description: Police officers were searching yesterday for a pregnant Brooklyn teen-ager and the former boyfriend who, her family said, abducted her at gunpoint earlier this week.

title: New Tool to Fight Spousal Abuse
description: AS the last details of her divorce are being settled and her husband has moved out, a 49-year-old mother of three, married for 23 years, is able to move on with her life.

title: A Long, Strange Field Trip
description: ONE RIVER

title: The Song That Launched a Thousand Cruise Ships
description: YOU know a song has been around the block when the Vice President threatens to dance to it on national television and happy delegates to the Democratic and Republican conventions have already given themselves up to it on the floor.

title: Serious Work Meets Summer Fun
description: WEARING dark sunglasses to replace her regular pair, which were broken, 11-year-old Sarah Karr of Los Angeles looked every bit the movie star she is.

title: Janet Reilly and Andrew Hawkes
description: Janet Marie Reilly, a daughter of Gail and Richard J. Reilly Jr. of Eureka, Mont., and South Salem, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Farrand Hawkes, a son of the Rev. Daphne Wolcott Parker Hawkes of Princeton, N.J., and the late Dr. Dudley Farrand Hawkes. The Rev. Henry J. Steinhoff officiated at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Eureka. The bridegroom's mother, an assistant rector at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Trenton, participated.

title: Scott and Zelda: Their Style Lives
description: MY grandfather F. Scott Fitzgerald would have been 100 years old this month. But it's hard to imagine him being anything but young. Somehow Americans will always picture him and my grandmother Zelda as the footloose adventurers who rode down Fifth Avenue on the tops of taxicabs, danced on tables at the Waldorf and took their famous plunge in the fountain at the Plaza or who partied in Paris.

title: Modell Is in Baltimore, But the Scars Remain
description: This is what happened in October 1960 on Art Modell's first trip to Cleveland:

title: Ilana Eden and Timothy Matteson
description: Ilana Lee Eden, a daughter of Beryl and Avrim Eden of Cliffside Park, N.J., is to be married today to Timothy John Matteson, a son of Barbara and Arthur Myers of Old Tappan, N.J. Rabbi William Dreskin is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: S.A.T. Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons in Schmoozing and Noshing
description: BRIGHTON BEACH is home to roughly 25,000 Russian Jews, many of them elderly, and though the sight of a babushka on the boardwalk is increasingly rare, it's still a place where the knishes are baked, not fried.

title: Abortion Issue Turns Republican Primary Into Family Feud
description: So far, the challenger has accused the incumbent of election law violations, ethical lapses and an anti-Catholic voting record.

title: As Unions Get Pushy, They Also Get Sued
description: THIS summer, a television station in Paducah, Ky., received a letter from the Republican National Committee that frightened the station's president, Richard Paxton.

title: Kosher? In Eye of Beholder.
description: How kosher is kosher?

title: Russian Declares Peace in Chechnya
description: The 20-month war in Chechnya is at last over. At least that's what Aleksandr I. Lebed, the self-confident Russian national security adviser, says.

title: In Rye Brook, Testing the Refined Palate
description: BROUGHT here blindfolded, one might imagine, upon entering, that Bacco was a stylish Manhattan wine bar. That the place is tucked into a suburban shopping center, however, is testament to the increasingly sophisticated palates in this part of the county. Bacco does not always adhere to the rigorous standards that Gotham's competition imposes; yet diners here can pick up bagels for breakfast or a video before leaving the parking lot.

title: ... And Food, Earthy and Elegant
description: TRADITIONAL Sardinian gastronomy divides itself fairly cleanly into coastal luxury on the one hand, and the hardscrabble pastoral life of the mountains on the other.

title: Itsy-Bitsy Dance Craze
description: To the Editor:

title: Myths and Legends
description: What do the Frog Prince, George Washington and an Indian ''Cinderella'' named Morning Light have in common? All three are heroes in legendary folk tales about honesty, tales that have been recreated in cartoon form for a new PBS series, ADVENTURES FROM THE BOOK OF VITURES.

title: But Can It Conduct A White House Tour?
description: WHAT A 35-inch-tall, $495 collectible Jackie doll, whose manufacturer intended it to be a tribute to Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis.

title: A.F.C Scouting Reports
description: (Teams are listed in predicted order of finish)

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the use of Schumann lieder in the play ''Old Wicked Songs'' misidentifies the director of the play's premiere production, at the Walnut Street Theater in Philadelphia in 1995. He was Frank Ferrante, not Seth Barrish.

title: When It Comes to Parties, See This Man
description: RAIN? It couldn't rain on a Marty Richards party. Not with those panoramic views of lawn, gardens and sculptures, and that teasing sound of a pounding surf just behind the hedges. Mr. Richards's oceanfront mansion in Southampton was made for outdoor entertaining. In the summer the dinner parties on the patio -- lit by twinkling candlelight and that old devil moon -- rival any 1940's movie set.

title: The California Cutoff
description: Gov. Pete Wilson of California said he was simply applying the law of the land when he ordered state agencies and colleges last week to stop doing anything that might help illegal immigrants. The new Federal welfare bill enacted on Aug. 22 made any foreigner ''who is not a qualified alien'' ineligible for all but a handful of public benefits.

title: Magazine Seeks to Cover All With Eclectic Approach
description: CURIO, a new magazine based here, is a study in contrasts. It is a glossy, four-color quarterly with full-page advertisements for such mainstream products as Dewar's Scotch. It costs $3.50 a copy and has the look of a sleek, well-heeled publication.

title: JUST KIDDING
description: Does the title ''Just Kidding -- Back-to-school clothes with a sense of humor'' (Style: Aug. 4) refer to the clothes or the prices? Corduroy pants, $124; shirt, $115 -- stay out of the mud, kid!

title: A Sideman's Life: Whichever Way the Horns Blow
description: When cadence, a jazz and blues magazine, printed a photo of the alto saxophonist Steve Wilson and identified him as Steve Coleman, another alto player, Mr. Wilson was amused but unfazed. Anonymity is a fact of life for a jazz sideman.

title: Vigilant Volunteers and Free Bags Are a Litter Pick-Me-Up
description: There are 26,000 public litter baskets in the Naked City. Joseph Mojica's is just one of them.

title: Nature and Art United by the Locomotive
description: THE view from the Hudson River Museum here is reason enough for a visit, but it is also a permanent installation with which temporary exhibitions must compete. There is no contest at the moment, however, for the locomotive, which precipitated the 19th-century surge in landscape art, has again brought nature and art together, this time in the museum. The point, already implied by the paintings in the current railroad extravaganza, is emphasized by a group of landscapes drawn from the permanent collection and titled ''Natural Selections.''

title: If We Were Serious
description: The prime-time convention shows have come to their balloon-drop endings. The mini-movies, zingers and dramatic speeches are over. What follows now, we are told, is the ''serious campaign.''

title: Designer Football
description: Today in Charlotte, N.C., the N.F.L.'s Carolina Panthers will christen Ericsson Stadium, a $187 million football Xanadu that's eliciting envy-squeaks from owners around the league. ''By comparison,'' Carmen Policy, president of the San Francisco 49ers, has said, ''we're living in a bombed-out zone.'' What's all the fuss about? Here's a look.

title: Here's Another Switch, Mets Actually Win One for Valentine
description: It was a good thing the Mets pounded out 13 hits yesterday at Shea Stadium, including back-to-back home runs by Roberto Petagine and Alvaro Espinoza. It was even better that starter Robert Person finally delivered a decent outing and got good support from relievers Dave Mlicki and Doug Henry. The Mets needed all of it to give Bobby Valentine his first victory as their manager -- and to render harmless a potentially damaging mistake he made late in the game.

title: Speeches, Rewards, Celebrations
description: Promoting peace and prosperity, education, racial equality and excellence

title: Don't Simplify Art's Complexities
description: To the Editor:

title: A Large Something Seems to Be Missing
description: No one ever said the gas tanks were a beautiful sight. They were smelly at times, weird-looking -- two gargantuan cylinders encased in a grid of orange-and-white steel rising more than 200 feet above Grand Avenue -- and they cast a shadow over an entire Elmhurst block starting at 3 P.M. most days.

title: Senior Statesmen?
description: To the Editor: I find it regrettable that Betsy Wade was glad when the New York transit system, under pressure, changed the electronic display for the half-fare card from ''elderly'' to the awkward, mealy-mouthed ''senior citizen.'' (Practical Traveler, ''Age Pays Off, If You Ask,'' July 21).

title: Unscrupulous Mechanics Are Widespread Plague
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Race Men
description: SHORT STORIES OF LANGSTON HUGHES

title: When the Rain Won't Come
description: ONE EXPECTS TO SEE, STANDING just beyond the frame of this photograph, a weathered Sudanese cowherd leaning on his stick, gazing impassively at his rib-thin cattle. But this photograph was taken in early August on a ranch in Starr County, Tex., not far from Rio Grande City, where a drought has been unrelenting for months, as it has throughout the Southwest. Dust has begun to drift along the fence lines. The few cattle that have not been rounded up are reduced to eating cactus that has been burned to make it more palatable. Most cattle have gone to auction already, underweight, before their time. The animals in this photograph -- Brahman cattle, mostly, suited to the heat of south Texas -- proved too wily to gather. Whether they will prove wily enough to survive the summer is another question.

title: It's Back to School for Teachers, Too
description: THERE were 40 of them. They waited on the sidewalks wondering about all that was ahead in the new school year. When was that bus going to come?

title: Style points don't count. Ability is not enough. In the N.F.L., winning only comes with attitude.
description: IT IS KICKOFF '96 today, and everything looks nice. Such high hopes. The 30 National Football League teams held their drafts in April, finished training camps and the preseason in August and trimmed their final rosters last week. Each one has a plan to reach Super Bowl XXXI in five months in New Orleans.

title: Is the Sound Being Overfished?
description: THIS summer Peter Studwell's skiff has bobbed idly at a mostly empty dock area here on Long Island Sound -- breaking a family tradition for the first time in three centuries.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE ASSAULT ON TONY'S

title: A Jim Crow Sperm Bank?
description: Is Floyd C. Kimble a kindly philanthropist? Or a creepy amateur geneticist? A recent report in The Spokesman-Review in Spokane, Wash., alleged that Kimble's Foundation for the Continuity of Mankind -- a $40 million sperm bank in Spokane -- is soliciting donations only from Caucasians, out of a belief that a hybridized white race will need pure sperm for future replenishment. Kimble, a 68-year-old Ohio businessman, pleads innocent, saying that the misunderstanding stems from unfortunate quotes by his sperm-bank manager, Dora Vaux, who once worked for a ''genuis'' sperm bank in California. (Vaux, above, said that even if the bank accepted sperm from blacks, it would be kept in a separate freezer.) Kimble is worried about hybrids -- he says they are disease-prone -- but insists his goal is to preserve pure semen stocks from healthy, smart people of all races. ''If there is a superior colored person, we want that person,'' he says. ''We definitely want some of the Orientals.'' But, thanks all the same, no artists. ''Artists,'' says Kimble, a nuts-and-bolts type, ''are not a prerequisite for the survival of mankind.''

title: In Hanoi, an Austere Film Diet
description: Almost no one in Vietnam has seen ''Cyclo,'' the stunning but violent new movie about the underbelly of life in Ho Chi Minh City, filmed by a Vietnamese director who lives in France. But then, very few people here have seen any Vietnamese films lately.

title: For Pitney Bowes, a Federal Plan May Spell Profit
description: FOR decades, Pitney Bowes has held a hammerlock on the market for leased postal meters used by 1.5 million companies and organizations.

title: Jerry Nachman Signs Off
description: TWO years ago Jerry Nachman -- the hard-boiled, roll-up-your-sleeves, DiNobili-chomping news hound who had previously run The New York Post and WNBC-TV's local news division -- came to WCBS-TV as news director. He was charged with invigorating Channel 2's flagging local newscasts, which were finishing third in a three-way ratings race.

title: Whitman Does It Again! Why Do I Feel Uneasy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Playgrounds Bloom Where Drug Dealers Roamed
description: SolMaria Salas did not have a safe place to play when she was growing up in Newark's East Ward. Shady characters infested the vacant lot next to the St. Columba School, dumping needles and other drug paraphernalia on a field already strewn with rubble and weeds. Muscle cars prowled the streets, leaving the air thick with the aroma of burning rubber and the wail of sirens.

Jandrucko of Garrison. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, and Rabbi Charles Lippman took part in the ceremony.

description: It finally happened. After a 15-year marriage that began with hope and glory at St. Paul's Cathedral and ended with a clerk's rubber stamp in a musty courthouse office, the Prince and Princess of Wales were officially footloose and fancy free last week.

title: The Sound of Memories
description: MUSIC IS AN ELUSIVE ART FOR MANY reasons. For one, it is often said, music exists only in the present. Like other half-truths, this may in fact be half true. But for most music lovers of any experience, music plays in the past as well, and scarcely less vividly.

title: Wilhelm Angele, 91, Engineer in Space Program
description: Wilhelm Angele, a member of the team of scientists who began the American rocket program in the 1950's and whose last contribution will help test parts of Einstein's general theory of relativity in a project scheduled for the year 2002, died on Aug. 22 in a hospital in Richmond. Mr. Angele, who was 91, formerly lived in Huntsville, Ala., where he worked at the George C. Marshall Space Flight Center.

description: Great Moments in 'D.I.Y.' History

With a 10-point lead in the polls and the presidential election less than two months away, the supporters of Arnoldo Aleman were feeling supremely confident about their man's chances.

title: Nicole Gueron, C.H. Strickland Jr.
description: Nicole Lucille Gueron, a daughter of Judith and Henri Gueron of Manhattan, is to be married today to Carter Heston Strickland Jr., the son of Nan and Carter Strickland of Fayetteville, N.Y. Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan will officiate at Great Camp Sagamore, a historic house on Raquette Lake in upstate New York.

There are other changes, too: the rush-seated, ladderback chairs have been painted sage green, and a frosted glass and brass partition separates the narrow dining room from a newly created, attractive bar area that is decidedly bistro in atmosphere.

description: Sydney Archer, a research professor of chemistry and former dean at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute who developed medicinal drugs against an array of diseases, died on Aug. 22 at Albany Medical Center. He was 79 and lived in Delmar, N.Y.

title: The 60's Had Free Love; The 90's Have Free Information
description: LEE FELSENSTEIN didn't go to Chicago for the Democratic National Convention in 1968. He didn't make it to Chicago this year, either. Both times he had his hands full as a revolutionary.

description: SISTER

title: Wide Swath of Coast Braces for Storm
description: Deferring to the omnipotence of nature, the United States Navy suspended its efforts to retrieve the remaining wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 from the waters off eastern Long Island yesterday, as the approaching Hurricane Edouard roiled the Atlantic Ocean and coastal communities prepared for storm-related mayhem.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Picking Up the Shattered Pieces of a Lifetime of Saving
description: FIVE years ago, Olga Monetti and Fannie Monetti were arguably New York's most unlikely millionaires. The two 60-something sisters shopped in thrift stores, refinished discarded furniture for their home in East Harlem and drove a car that had seen much better days.

title: Debra Rosenthal, Andrew Shure
description: Debra Aliza Rosenthal, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Gilbert S. Rosenthal of Great Neck, L.I., is to be married today to Andrew Frederick Shure, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. William Shure of Woodbridge, Conn. The bride's father is to perform the ceremony with her grandfather Rabbi Benjamin L. Teller at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

title: Stumbling Into Happiness
description: Lies of the Saints

title: Howdy. Now Keep Your Mitts to Yourself
description: As Labor Day jolts us out of summer sloth, take a moment to consider that most venerable of workplace greetings -- the handshake. Firm. Honest. Dangerous? ''Absolutely,'' insists Robert E. Swindle, 68, a business professor at Glendale Community College in Glendale, Ariz., and the chief crusader in the lonely cause of handshake abolition. The ritual, Swindle says, has lost its practical value, which was originally a demonstration ''among primitives'' that one wasn't carrying a concealed weapon. Besides that, it's just plain vile. ''Think of all those unwashed hands,'' says Swindle. ''You're talking about fungal viruses, cold viruses, warts. Who wants warts?'' Dead-serious in his quest, Swindle refuses to glad-hand anyone. ''I usually try to soften the blow,'' he says, ''by telling them I fractured a finger playing basketball. But you have to be careful. Sometimes they'll reach for your left hand, like they do with Bob Dole.'' Hmmm. That probably doesn't soften the blow much, which may explain why Swindle's only convert is his wife. Is there a better way? Below, with help from Swindle and our own crack team of office hypochondriacs, some options.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Out to Lunch. Forever.

title: Last-Minute Chaos As MTV Primps For Awards Show
description: The MTV Music Video Awards on Wednesday may look like a 24-7-365 production. That is, the sets will be so glittery and the celebrity lineup so high powered that viewers may think the producers worked 7 days a week, 24 hours a day, for the 360-some days since the last one.

description: PERHAPS the torso is human, the figure angular -- but horned! Is the most prized chess piece itself contemplating a move?

description: For 20 years, Ben Fischer was a praiseworthy officer of the Central Intelligence Agency. Then, two years ago, Mr. Fischer says, a procession of rumor, gossip, hearsay and innuendo ruined his career.

title: Reaching Past Party's Base, Kemp Gives Speech at Factory
description: Continuing his outreach to voters who have traditionally supported the Democratic Party, Jack Kemp today visited a partially unionized manufacturing plant here to say that the economic plans of his running mate, Bob Dole, are compatible with the concerns of the labor movement and hourly workers.

title: Finding a Soul Mate In Miss Alma
description: YEARS LATER, TENNESSEE Williams would still talk about the shadow of death that hung over him that year of 1946 when he was writing ''Summer and Smoke.'' In fact, the 35-year-old playwright was hospitalized three times that year; yet what haunted him was not so much a physical as a creative death.

title: Carolyn Lutz and Marcello Mannelli
description: Carolyn Jeanne Lutz, a daughter of Betty Lutz-Naegeli of Ermatingen, Switzerland, and Robert A. Lutz of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married on Friday to Dr. Marcello Mannelli, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Italo Mannelli of Pisa, Italy. Town Justice P. Haemmi officiated at the town hall in Coppet, Switzerland. The Rev. Gerard S. Moser, an Episcopal priest, is to perform a religious ceremony today in the Protestant Church of Celigny, Switzerland.

title: Cardinal Defends Plan to Promote Discussions
description: In a formal reply to criticism from among fellow church leaders, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Archbishop of Chicago, defended an effort he is leading to promote discussion and a sense of shared purpose among opposing groups within the church, saying his initiative recognized the primacy of church teaching and did not legitimize dissent.

title: Standing for Columns
description: To the Editor:

description: TAKEN CAPTIVE

title: Speculating on Politicians, Not Pork Bellies
description: In a political futures market run with real money, Bob Dole's bounce was barely a blip, and President Clinton is sitting fat.

title: South Fork Winery Out of Business
description: AFTER nearly 29 months under its new owner, the Bridgehampton Winery, the third winery to open on the East End, will close its doors on Sept. 30. Those doors opened in 1983.

title: The Do-It-Yourself Dealers
description: IT IS RAINING ON THE MORNING OF MAY 3, nasty, chilly showers that add a smell of damp to the scant charms of the shabby-genteel Gramercy Park Hotel. The third annual Gramercy International Contemporary Art Fair will officially open here at 6, and by noon Kenny Schachter is up to his ankles in art. Last night, alarmed by the tininess of his quarters -- the fair's organizers assigned him the bedroom half of a small, rather dingy suite -- he frantically tried to phone the 25 artists he had invited to show their work, asking them to scale back. No luck. Artists bearing half a dozen pieces each arrive in a regular parade. In no time the place looks like Groucho Marx's stateroom in ''A Night at the Opera.''

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: ALONG with three top-of-their genre films - in biography, the western and comedy - comes a quirky spoof of the hard-boiled thriller to lend spice to the week.

title: Services For Finding Roommates
description: DEE KING just can't seem to get a break.

title: Photos and Discussions Of Racism in the City
description: In June 1980, the grand Gothic apartment building at 178th Street and Vyse Avenue in the South Bronx was spotted with graffiti, but a single curtain glowed red in a downstairs window. Teen-agers lounged on the steps.

title: The Whole Gorey Story
description: Edward Gorey's art is macabre, but despite his fixation (or, rather, passion) for murder and mayhem, it is by no means gory. His detailed black-and-white line drawings so perfectly express the mood or capture the mystery of an otherwise brutal scene that there is no need to revel in blood or guts or even torn undergarments. Edward Gorey, the author, illustrator, set designer and ballet maven, has for the better part of his professional life been a master of a genre of graphic storytelling -- his work is a synthesis of the comic book and the graphic novel best described as a picture book for adults. His satires (often of tawdry Victorian mysteries) are not mere commentaries on the manners and mores of a distant age; they are inventive narratives about evil adults, mischievous children, illicit lovers and improbable beasts. They tickle the funny bone as they raise hair on the back of the neck. A brilliant draftsman, Mr. Gorey has raised the crosshatch, a timeworn 19th-century mannerism, into a timeless visual language. Gorey fans who, like me, have enjoyed his three previously published ''Amphigorey'' anthologies of graphic tales will welcome THE WORLD OF EDWARD GOREY (Abrams, $29.95), by Clifford Ross, an artist, and Karen Wilkin, an art critic. A superb sampling of classic stories, visual essays, covers, posters and sketches is sandwiched between an informative interview with Mr. Gorey and a concise analysis of his work at the beginning of the book and a complete bibliography and photographs of his library and studio at the end. His best-known drawings, for stories like ''The Hapless Child,'' ''The Gilded Bat,'' ''Other People's Mail'' and ''Edward Gorey's Dracula,'' are treats, to be sure. But I particularly adore the lesser-known treasures, like the excerpt from ''The Inanimate Tragedy.'' The caption for the last panel, showing three inanimate objects on a landscape, characterizes Mr. Gorey's dry wit: ''The Two-Holed Button concealed its apprehension.'' Steven Heller

title: Oh, to Be Sneaky and Well Dressed
description: LYDIA KEYS eyed the $5,000 tie she had just tied around someone else's neck. It eyed her back.

title: Far From His Mexican Town, He's Still the Town Father
description: The Father of Chinantla has no doorbell, but then he is rarely at home. The easiest way to find the elder statesman of ''La Quince,'' as the Mexicans who live on and around 15th Avenue call their neighborhood, is to pop into a bodega on 36th Street and say, ''Margarito?''

title: India Sets Inquiry into Pilgrim Deaths; Toll at 239
description: The official toll of Hindu pilgrims killed in a blizzard in the Himalayas has risen to 239, and the Interior Minister has told Parliament that the Government will begin an inquiry into why officials allowed more than 100,000 people to embark on a 27-mile ascent into the mountains ahead of the storm.

title: Richard Westfall Dies at 72; Wrote Biography of Newton
description: Richard S. Westfall, an authority on the scientific revolution of the 17th century and the author of the standard work on the life of Sir Isaac Newton, died on Aug. 21 at Bloomington Hospital in Bloomington, Ind., where he lived. He was 72.

title: A Smart Road Starts to Take Shape in california
description: LATE next year, 10 specially outfitted Buick LeSabres will take part in the first test of an automated highway, one on which drivers surrender control of their cars to sensors and computers and whiz down the road no more than 6 feet behind the car ahead.

title: Ms. Stahlman And Mr. Kearns
description: Kimberly Shelton Stahlman, the public affairs director for New York's Department of City Planning, and Michael Justin Kearns, a researcher on artificial intelligence at AT&T Labs in Murray Hill, N.J., are to be married today in Healdsburg, Calif. Dr. Andrew Kahn, a civil-marriage celebrant, is to officiate at the Fieldstone Winery.

title: The League Is Taking Harder Look At Security
description: A few weeks after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded shortly after takeoff and a week after a pipe bomb explosion in Atlanta's Centennial Park during the Olympics, the New England Patriots were deploying a bomb-sniffing dog through Foxboro Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: A table last Sunday with an article about the growing popularity of home exercise equipment misstated the industry's annual sales in the United States. The amounts were in billions of dollars, not millions.

title: On Labor Day, Memories of a Strike Bring Hopes for Peace
description: For 10 years Corrado Meola, who immigrated from Naples as a young teen-ager, worked for Trio Dyeing and Finishing Company, rising from laborer to shop steward. Everyday he drove a mile or so from Hawthorne to the mill in Paterson, founding city of unions, where the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Union of which he was a member had shaped labor history.

title: In Search of Shipwrecks, Sometimes Lobsters
description: EACH year, hundreds of Connecticut residents don wetsuits and go scuba diving in the state's lakes as well as in Long Island Sound. They find a lot of marine life, sometimes even treasure from hundreds of ships that have sunk along the coastline.

title: The Bands Play On
description: To the Editor:

title: Tuning Up Again, Orchestras at Work
description: THE lull between performing seasons is a good time to look at symphony orchestras' upcoming programs.

title: Joel Treisman, Marjorie Jacobson
description: Marjorie Sue Jacobson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Jacobson of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., is to be married today to Joel Harold Treisman, a son of Dorothy Cullman Treisman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Norman J. Treisman of New York. Rabbi Mark Winer is to perform the ceremony at Sleepy Hill, the home of the late Susan Lehman Cullman, the bridegroom's grandmother, in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Settling In, With the Hamptons Look
description: HARBOR ROSE is emerging after being overwhelmed by wave upon wave of curious diners when it first opened. It has the potential to be a solid Hamptons' classic. It is not there yet but this attractive Sag Harbor newcomer is a much more satisfying spot on Labor Day than it was on Flag Day. An off-season visit might be the most pleasant of all, since it is open year round.

title: Miss Davis, Mr. Wilmerding
description: Mary Virginia Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Nichols Davis Jr. of Asheville, N.C., is to be married there today to Alexander Wilmerding, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pratt Wilmerding of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Michael Brown is to perform the ceremony at Central United Methodist Church.

title: Computers, Sculpture and Acids
description: Digital Art

title: Laura J. Segal, Matthew C. Petrie
description: Laura Jane Segal, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon J. Segal of Hartsdale, N.Y. and Woods Hole, Mass., and Matthew Cooper Petrie, a son of Dr. and Mrs. George R. Petrie of Brecksville, Ohio, are to be married this evening in the Lillie Auditorium at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole. Dr. Segal, the laboratory's chairman, has been granted permission by the State of Massachusetts to officiate at his daughter's wedding.

title: Carter-Clinton 'Coolness' Isn't the Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura Getz, Andrew Missan
description: Laura Gail Getz and Andrew Paul Missan are to be married today at the University of California Botanical Garden in Berkeley. Rabbi Rona Shapiro is to perform the ceremony.

title: IT'S HIS PARTY
description: Garry Wills seems to be claiming that Ronald Reagan is personally responsible for our hostility to Government. Surely he must know that this animus is as old as the Republic.

title: Michele Stolls, David M. Baker
description: Michele Stolls and David Marshall Baker are to be married today at the Algonquin Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Joel S. Goor is to perform the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Corsica: Idyllic with an Edge
description: FROM the medieval Corsican city of Bonifacio, on limestone ramparts 200 feet above the translucent Mediterranean, you can see the Italian island of Sardinia just across an eight-mile-wide strait. Bonifacio is farther south than Rome, and nearly as many Italian tourists as French roam the narrow cobbled lanes of the spectacularly situated old town, but Corsica has been part of France for most of the past 228 years.

title: Like Other Television Shows, Convention Had Sponsors
description: With the Democratic National Convention ended, with the media and politicians packed and gone, Richard C. Notebaert, chief executive of the Ameritech Corporation, a telecommunications giant, can reflect on the events. ''This,'' he said, pointing to an advertisement of a Democratic donkey talking into an Ameritech telephone, ''is what it is all about.''

title: Starting With Shrimp, Ending in Success
description: WHEN it comes to starting a business, timing can spell the difference between success and failure.

title: Warning to Sellers: Let the Buyer Be Aware
description: NOT that long ago, a buyer who found the right house in the right place at the right price would be satisfied if the plumbing and heating worked, the roof was free of leaks, the basement free of seepage and the beams free of hordes of hungry termites.

title: Marla Radinsky And Gregg Felton
description: Marla Jean Radinsky, the daughter of Myra Radinsky and Dr. Stephen Radinsky of St. Louis, was married last evening to Gregg Jon Felton, the son of Rhetta Felton and Dr. J. Maxwell Felton of New York. Rabbi Jeffrey Stiffman performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton in St. Louis.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: DARK SUN: The Making of the Hydrogen Bomb

title: For Debate Commission, A Predicament on Perot
description: With the three main candidates officially nominated, the Commission on Presidential Debates is struggling to decide whether Ross Perot should be included this fall, as in 1992, even though his poll standing has been slumping.

title: Expos? Russia Beats Slovakia
description: Only in Montreal, where people's love for hockey exceeds all else, could World Cup organizers hope to sell seats for a game matching Russia and Slovakia on the same day the Expos were battling for a playoff berth. And while empty seats clearly outnumbered fans at the Molson Center today, a very respectable crowd of 10,733 chose hockey over baseball and saw what they expected: an offensive game with little defense and few body checks, won, 7-4, by Russia.

title: Arafat Warns Arab Uprising Could Return If Peace Stalls
description: Cranking up the pressure on the Israeli Government, Yasir Arafat warned today that Palestinians might have to revert to violence if the peace with Israel broke down.

title: Colombia's Legal System Puts Few Rapists in Prison
description: On occasion, Omaira Gomez still sees the man who she says repeatedly raped her two daughters: He is their uncle and lives just down the road.

title: Spiritual Values Are In, But, Please, No Sermonizing
description: FOR much of its history, when Hollywood made a religious movie, it left little to the imagination. Oceans parted, bearded prophets led surging crowds, and God's voice roared from on high.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: I thought you would like to know that there is a city recycling advocate in Honolulu who thinks that Tierney's article will benefit the recycling effort.

title: Underage Agents Fight Alcohol Sales to Minors
description: THE woman is a 19-year-old undercover agent of the Peekskill Police Department. She takes part in sting operations to catch merchants selling alcohol to minors. Her job is to walk into delicatessens with $10 and no identification and try to buy a bottle of beer. In two days this spring, she helped the police arrest cashiers in eight delicatessens. The stores were then reported to the State Liquor Authority.

title: The Last Hurrah
description: FOR men, bachelor parties have always been about escape -- from the women in their lives, sobriety, political correctness, even consciousness. Typically a night of debauchery, the traditional bachelor party offered one last visit to the underworld before entrance into the married world.

title: Making Noises About an Art-Rock Revival
description: Pop in the 1990'S, it has often been said, can be read as a sequence of reprises of 20-year-old culture: the Carpenters revival, disco redux, the new punk. Right around now should come No Wave, that blip of radical art music made by insightful thinkers who, for the most part, could barely play their instruments. And sure enough, over the last year or so, nearly every important document of the music has been reissued. Some of the progenitors of the movement are picking up long-dormant careers, and a few new bands bear its squalid mark. Will No Wave be the next recyclable?

title: BEST SELLERS: September 1, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Fiction 1 1 EXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) The Vice President has problems when an explosion kills the President and most of the Cabinet, Congress, the Joint Chiefs and the Supreme Court.

title: Rosemarie Zaloum And Craig Foster
description: Rosemarie Zaloum, a daughter of Richard and Carol Zaloum of New York, was married yesterday to Craig Edward Foster, the son of Michael and Lenore Foster of Dearborn, Mich. The Rev. John Faraj, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Pratt Mansions in New York.

title: A Weed That Woos the Many Butterflies
description: IF ever a plant was well named, it is butterfly weed. The bright orange flowers are beacons to these elegant fliers that grace the garden.

title: Mel Schneeberger and Chris Robbins
description: LIKE a woman out of a Hemingway novel, Melanie Schneeberger fly-fishes and skis; she beats most of her friends at pool; she drinks bourbon on the rocks.

title: Graceland in the Philippines
description: For rowdy American servicemen stationed in the Philippines in the early 1990's, all roads lead to Olongapo, the spilled-beer and barbecued-meat-scented Sodom that caters to their every whim. Here, at a ramshackle former movie theater renamed Graceland, two young brothers, Chester and Albert Lane, team up with Ward Wiggins, a fortyish former college professor, to perform a stunning nightly ritual, transforming the life story of Elvis Presley into a parable of birth, death and resurrection. With Chester as the romantic young punk from Tupelo, Albert as the jaded movie idol and Ward as the bloated, sequined, drug-addled Aztec Superfly, the three work their collective magic on increasingly enraptured crowds. For the Lane brothers, the show is a lark, but for Ward it's nothing less than a spiritual calling. ''We were realer than real,'' he says, looking back. ''I wasn't an impersonator. . . . I was Elvis.'' In his latest novel, BIGGEST ELVIS (Viking, $22.95), P. F. Kluge, the author of ''Eddie and the Cruisers,'' writes lyrically, whether he's describing the gaudy onstage triumphs of his Elvis trinity or the crushing hardships of life around the Subic Bay naval base. And he links the stages of Big E's life to what he sees as the phases of America's identity -- a descent from vigorous pioneer nation to aging, swollen colossus. Yet as time passes, the Philippine inhabitants of Olongapo, mired in poverty and trapped in a military economy, come to see Ward, the Biggest Elvis of the book's title, as a sort of ecumenical saint and community savior; just how that happens is the subject of this dreamy, melancholy tale of economic and pop-cultural imperialism. Sarah Ferguson

title: Influential Group Brought Into Campaign by Kemp
description: Not long after Bill Clinton defeated President Bush in 1992, Theodore J. Forstmann, a New York investment banker, sat down with Jack Kemp to discuss creating an organization in Washington to chart a new course for conservative causes, particularly Mr. Kemp's advocacy of stimulating growth by cutting taxes.

title: End of the Line Is Sometimes the Start of Something Big
description: THE lease on your car is about to end and you finally have to make the decision that has been waiting for you since you signed the contract: Do you buy the car or hand it back to the dealer?

title: A Job That Truly Takes a Toll
description: IN a town called Pleasantville, on the fringes of salt swamps and rolling meadows, the Pleasantville toll plaza on the Atlantic City Expressway Plaza stands like a mythical troll before a bridge, demanding that motorists stop and pay at least 25 cents (as much as $1 for buses and big trucks) to drive the two miles connecting Absecon Island, on which Atlantic City sits, to the New Jersey mainland.

title: IT'S HIS PARTY
description: Thanks to Garry Wills for a clear-eyed assessment of the Reagan legacy in 90's America (''It's His Party,'' Aug. 11). It could not have appeared at a more appropriate time. As Bob Dole further betrays himself with the choice of a blinkered supply-sider for a running mate, who can doubt that this election will prove crucial in determining the future of that legacy?

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: The Rev. Doctor Banker
description: SAVE for a few white lilies sprouting from gaudy plastic flower arrangements near the stage, there is little evidence that the New York Christian Life Center in East New York, Brooklyn, is a church. There is hardly any Christian iconography. The setting is like a television studio, with a band near the stage playing snappy interludes, contemporary gospel selections that the pastor calls ''positive message music.''

title: Beth S. Noveck, Robert B. Kastner
description: Dr. Beth Simone Noveck, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Simon Noveck of Toms River, N.J., is to be married today at her parents' house to Robert Bernhard Kastner, a son of Dr. Lieselotte Kastner and Georg Kastner of Vienna. The bride's father, a rabbi, will perform the ceremony.

title: Dirty Hands
description: Sitting under a cheap stamped early light fixturehe could imagine it was he who drove the Pontiacall the way to Florida on only one quart of oil,something impossible to explain to his new girlfriendfloating in her hot tub under a Niagara grape arbor.He took a bite of sandwich and lived on the richnessof that dark wallpaper; he thought it was round fishesand not just some green design made in Toledo,the wallpaper capital of the world before the First War.He wanted to tell her how worn out he used to beat four in the morning crossing the empty highwayto start his second night and how he struggledwith the dirty stove so he could just move his fingers;and he wanted to tell her what it was like pulling eggsin the Union Station in all that smoke, his lungsturning to stone, his hands blackened for years,his eyes bloodshot, but that was when he touchedher face, and the moon came through the grapes, the partwhere the roof didn't shade the arbor, making a valleynot so different from what he knew, two cloudsbreaking off like dogs breaking off, the rabbit silentand running with his legs on fire, it wasa memory of the sun; he thought of their mouthsall open, the grapes were hard, the water was boilingdriving through West Virginia, the oil was smokingunder the hood, his eyes were closed, his hands were soaking.

title: Today, Cone's True Story Continues
description: David Cone vividly remembers being sprawled in a hospital bed almost four months ago, listening while Dwight Gooden pitched an inspiring no-hitter against the Seattle Mariners. Cone recalls how, woozy and weary from surgery, he thought that Gooden was an awesome human-interest story, that the Yankees were filled with such stories and that he absolutely had to recuperate and add his own neat chapter.

title: Davenport Finally Hits A Sour Note
description: Lindsay Davenport had become a favorite song, something to be played over and over again. People couldn't get enough of her.

title: Broncos Besiege O'Donnell in an Ugly Jets Opener
description: Money can't buy happiness, the stunned Jets confirmed today. Nor is it a guarantee against injuries.

title: Effective Drug Crime Tactics
description: New York City continues to experience a steady decline in violent crime -- a decline that is more pronounced than in other big cities or in the country as a whole. In the latest advance, the New York City Police Department has reported impressive reductions in drug-related crime in several of the city's toughest neighborhoods. Scholars and analysts argue over how much to credit new policing techniques compared with wider social trends or community activism. But there is no doubt the streets are safer.

title: James Elward, 67, Who Wrote Novels and Half of a Best Seller
description: James Elward, a writer who enjoyed an unusual publishing success when he finished a half-written novel after the death of its better-known original author, Helen Van Slyke, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

title: Teachers Lack Contracts
description: Labor Day arrives on a bittersweet note for teachers in 132 of the state's approximately 600 school districts, who are going back to work this week without contracts. Most of the contracts expired at the end of the last school year, but a few disputes have been dragging on for a year or more, according to the New Jersey Education Association, a teachers union. No strikes are looming, said Linda Bowman, a spokeswoman for the union, although negotiations are tense in Cherry Hill, Morris Township and Bradley Beach.

title: Bosnian Leader Hails Islam at Election Rallies
description: Campaign rallies by Bosnia's President, Alijia Izetbegovic, are not intended to alleviate the fears of those who believe he wants to set up a Muslim state.

title: Different Groups, Different Dole Themes
description: Bob Dole campaigned before two distinctly different audiences here today, telling the National Guard that he would enlist them in the war against drugs and telling members of B'nai B'rith that he was intolerant of discrimination, which he said he understood because of his physical disability.

title: Listen: No Thump. Speed Humps Are Lower. Also Quieter, Kinder and Gentler.
description: In a city where traffic lights and stop signs often do little to control the flow of traffic, a less costly deterrent is being given a chance to show whether it can keep drivers from speeding through congested neighborhoods.

title: Images of Disability
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Needs Emergency Shelter? Mothers There Speak Out
description: Under the harsh fluorescent lights of a squat, lackluster building in the Bronx, three mothers recently converged on a slab of tile to wait their turn for a bed and a roof. One had worked on and off until the bills caught up to her. Another prayed to God late at night for an apartment of her own, a crisp high school diploma and a job in computers. And a third discovered just how fragile a home life she had after her sister pointed her out the door.

title: Direct Talks on Cyprus
description: To the Editor:

title: Asians Join Scramble To Build Regional Jet
description: SINGAPORE  At least three rival groups based in Asia aim to begin assembling regional jetliners, but analysts warn that the market is already crowded and growth potential limited.

title: Rebels Kill 80 in Strongest Attacks in Colombia in Decades
description: Left-wing rebels mounted one of their deadliest offensives in decades over the weekend, killing at least 80 soldiers and policemen in separate incidents throughout the country.

title: Johnson And Big D Take Over In Miami
description: As Jimmy Johnson gathered his new team for a pre-game speech today, defensive end Dan Stubbs and the players around him expected Johnson to be animated and loud.

title: G.O.P. Might Well Make Use of Clinton Strategist's Departure
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Ball, Chicago Says the Slipper Fits
description: As far as anyone knows, this city has never had an exorcist on the payroll, even during the heyday of political patronage and the once mighty Machine.

title: After Pettitte and Key, Wheels Fall Off Again
description: For all those trying to fathom just why it is that the Yankees of the first half and the Yankees of the second half sometimes look as different as Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, look no further than the last three games against the California Angels.

title: Bridge
description: It is quite rare, on a major occasion, for a team to gain 70 or 80 imps in the course of a 16-deal session, averaging close to 5 imps a board. A record in this area appears to have been set during the 1994 Far East Championships in Wellington, New Zealand. In the last session of the tournament the Chinese Under-25 team gained 76 imps in a stretch of 8 deals, averaging almost 10.

title: U.S. Buoyed by Victory Before Playing Russia
description: On a wall in Team USA's locker room in CoreStates Center on Saturday night was a list of commands. The sixth said, ''Take This Team Wide,'' suggesting that Canada could be beaten with speedy skating to the outside. The seventh, and final, order simply said, ''No Respect.''

title: Jose Toribio Merino Castro, 80, Chilean in '73 Coup and Junta
description: Jose Toribio Merino Castro, a Chilean admiral who played an important role in the violent military coup in Chile in 1973 and was in the ruling military junta from then until 1990, died on Friday in a military hospital in the port of Valparaiso. He was 80.

title: Mexican Leader Vows to Fight New Guerrilla Violence
description: Addressing a country still stunned by last week's guerrilla attacks, a somber President Ernesto Zedillo pledged today to fight the insurgents with the ''full force of the state.''

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: A Pitcher (Their Own) Fools Yanks
description: So much for George Steinbrenner as a motivational guru, at least for enigmatic Kenny Rogers.

title: Reports of the death of the Internet have been greatly exaggerated.
description: THE Internet death watch is in full dirge. According to the latest morbidity reports, national networks like Netcom and America Online are crashing with increasing severity, packets of your precious bits are being scattered and lost throughout cyberspace, popular sites on the World Wide Web are being choked by callers and overall service is degrading as hordes of tourists pile onto the Internet gripping copies of ''The Internet on $19.95 a Month.''

title: Whitewater Testiness
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Attention and Respect For the Humble Accordion
description: Don't assume that all those accordionists one hears at wedding receptions, suburban restaurants and polka clubs in the Catskills are content with their lot. Many of them are composers and artists frustrated by the hurtful stereotyping of the accordion as a lowbrow instrument of the people.

title: There's No Time for Strategy at 132 Miles an Hour
description: IN the very first game of what vaguely resembled a conventional tennis match, this is how Mark Philippoussis served notice yesterday to Cedric Pioline that the Frenchman was in for a grim, swift and artless execution from the United States Open:

title: Titles, Titles Everywhere But Not a Page to Turn
description: The entry to Bette S. Feinstein's quaint New England book shop is marked with a virtual sampler, a welcome sign embroidered with crimson hearts and a blue needle pointed toward the name of her thriving business, ''Hard-to-Find Needlework Books.''

title: Woods Impresses Crowd With His Hole-in-One
description: Special people do special things. So it should come as no surprise that Tiger Woods, 20, even in an ordinary debut at the Greater Milwaukee Open, left his first tournament as a pro with an extraordinary bang.

title: An Ode to Seasonality
description: Labor Day celebrates the nation's working men and women. But once it also served another useful function, marking the beginning of election campaign season. Now, of course, the idea that a candidate would restrict his or her campaign to 10 weeks seems quaint, like the idea that corn on the cob can be eaten only in the summer or that the basketball season should not stretch into June.

title: Debates: One on One
description: American voters are entitled to see candidates with a ''realistic'' chance of being our next President face off in a series of television debates.

title: Tragedy of a Revolutionary Enigma
description: THE ROAD TO HELL

title: Burmese Junta Seems Headed for Showdown
description: It was raining hard on Saturday, but for an hour applause and whistles and laughter came from under a sea of black umbrellas as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a spray of pink flowers in her hair, taunted the military Government, saying, ''Why are you so afraid of us?''

title: Perot Begins Campaign, on TV, With Charts
description: Ross Perot began his television campaign for the Presidency last night with a folksy ''infomercial'' that called for privatization of Social Security, reorganization of Medicare and an end to ''one-sided trade deals.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article yesterday refered incorrectly in some copies to the mission of a European official in Chechnya. The official, Tim Guldimann, heads the Chechnya mission of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, not the Chechnya mission to the security organization.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Farrar, Straus & Giroux, the publisher whose logo is three kite-shaped fish, turns 50 this year, and its monthlong birthday celebration has a distinctly fishy flavor.

title: Iraq Tests the Limits
description: Whatever else Saddam Hussein may be up to in northern Iraq, he is probing to see if the United States and its allies are still prepared to enforce the tight limits they imposed on Iraqi military activity following the Persian Gulf war. Washington needs to respond firmly. President Clinton was right to move military forces to a higher readiness, but the first response should be economic, aimed at halting the plan to allow limited Iraqi oil sales.

title: German Service Stays Nimble Atop On-Line Continent
description: Those who think of Deutsche Telekom A.G. only as a slow-footed corporate giant might be surprised to learn that the state-owned German telephone company also runs the biggest on-line and Internet-access service in Europe.

title: Ex-Aide to Clinton Rejects Defeat
description: When he turned his back on his Republican clients and went to work as a strategist for a wounded Bill Clinton, Dick Morris liked to say that he and his President would share the same fate in the 1996 election: ''If we're both good enough, we'll work our way out of it. If not, we're both sunk.''

title: No Headline
description: ''I feel good. I'm confident. Sleep good. Work hard. I mean I like to work. I like to campaign. I like people.''

title: Computer Program Clears the Static
description: When Islanders hockey fans gazed up at the banners and retired jerseys displayed at Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum on Long Island, they connected with a history of the team and the sport. But when the names and numbers of players on the ice were read over the public address system, the people in the stands were suddenly disconnected. The 20-year-old sound system produced only garbled squawks.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: College Is Over; Let the Tests Begin

title: Dole to Press 'Broad Message' On Economy, Drugs and Crime
description: As he starts the final leg of what is likely to be his last campaign, Bob Dole, the notoriously undisciplined campaigner, says he has figured it out: ''We just need to keep pounding the message and pounding the message.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Equity Offerings Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Violations Don't Bar Deals
description: Ten New Jersey companies that had been ordered to pay penalties for workplace safety violations received Federal contracts in 1994, according to a report released yesterday by the General Accounting Office. The report was prepared for Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, who is sponsoring legislation to make companies ''with a clear pattern and practice'' of violations ineligible for Federal contracts for three years. The New Jersey companies include Biocraft Laboratories, a pharmaceutical company with offices in Paterson and Fairfield; All American Poly Corporation of Dunellen, and Vineland Kosher Poultry.

title: As Game Heats Up, Giants Find Cool Zone While the Bills Sweat
description: Behind the Buffalo Bills' bench at Giants Stadium last night were six huge fans, the type you might see on a movie set in Hollywood where producers work to create a windy effect. These fans are popular in football now. They are called Cool Zone. And they do just that on a hot, muggy night -- keep you cool.

title: Credit Offerings Expected During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to Tuesday's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: AT&T Assails a Study by Economist
description: It is hard to imagine anybody getting worked up over a book entitled, ''The Failure of Antitrust and Regulation to Establish Competition in Long-Distance Telephone Service.''

title: Kemp, in Montana, Urges End to Estate Taxes
description: Having told poor people in the inner city, rich people in suburbia and workers in a factory that tax cuts would greatly improve their lives, Jack Kemp made the same pledge tonight to wheat and barley farmers here on the windswept plains.

title: Chef Starts Cooking Class
description: At Jeffrey's Restaurant, you can not only compliment the chef, you can learn some of his secrets. Jeffrey Schnee kloth, the chef, also loves to teach, so in addition to running the restaurant, which opened in May, Mr. Schneekloth is teaching a cooking class. On Sept. 16, Mr. Schnee kloth will show how he prepares gingered tuna ravioli with orange sauce, chicken stuffed with zucchini, Boursin cheese wrapped in potato crust and German chocolate cake. Demand has exceeded Mr. Schneekloth's expectations, so he will hold the class twice more to accommodate the 300 people who have signed up.

title: The Morris Betrayal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Halts Deal for Iraq Oil Sales As U.S. Pledges Action on Attack
description: The Clinton Administration vowed today to punish Saddam Hussein for Iraq's military thrust into the Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq, and the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, suspended the recent agreement to allow Iraq to sell oil to raise cash for food and medicine.

title: New Night of Horror In S. Carolina Lake As 7 Visitors Drown
description: The saddest place in the little mill town of Union, S.C., has a fresher horror now.

title: Truckers Need New Plates
description: About 2,600 New Jersey trucking companies can no longer send their rigs out of state legally without special permission because they do not have new international license plates, The Associated Press reported. Yesterday New Jersey became the last of the lower 48 states to join the International Registration Plan, which allows trucks to obtain one plate good in all member states and Canadian provinces but requires them to pay fees to other states based on how much they travel in those states. New Jersey truckers caught out of state without the special plates face fines of up to $2,000.

title: Clinton Starts at the Beginning Once Again
description: President Clinton returned to Arkansas for a sentimental send-off rally for his re-election campaign tonight, addressing a cheering throng in front of the Old State House, where he first declared his candidacy for Governor in 1978, announced his intention to run for President in 1991 and claimed victory in 1992.

title: 'Democrat' as Insult
description: To the Editor:

title: On Watching $73.7 Million Turn Into 0
description: IF it happened on Wall Street, somebody would be indicted.

title: Last Run for Beach Train
description: Since 1949, a miniature train running along narrow tracks in the sand has shuttled people from a public parking lot at the north end of Point Pleasant Beach a half-mile down to the amusement arcades. But the beloved little train with its open-air cars made its last run on Saturday, victim, like many of its bigger cousins, of rising costs and declining ridership. The train's owner, Rick Zitaross, said that an amusement park in New York State had expressed interest in giving the train a new home. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Philip Morris Denies Report on Inquiry
description: Executives of the Philip Morris Companies have not been subpoenaed and are not facing indictment in a Justice Department investigation of the company, Stephen Parrish, a senior vice president said today.

title: Day For Giant Serves, And Giant Reputations
description: Stefan Edberg, that soon-to-be retiree who is playing his 54th and final Grand Slam, dwarfed his opponent before he even struck a ball; all it took was the Swede's reputation. Goran Ivanisevic and Mark Philippoussis dwarfed their rivals with bulldozer serves, and Monica Seles dwarfed hers with sheer willpower.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: In His Own Words
description: JACK KEMP

title: Internet Future At I.B.M. Looks Oddly Familiar
description: I.B.M.'s plans for the Internet, which the company is set to describe in detail later this week, have a back-to-the-future quality.

title: Mets Make It Two Straight for Valentine
description: As Mookie Wilson stood in front of a microphone at home plate and thanked his family, the fans and his former teammates for his induction into the Mets Hall of Fame, Fred Wilpon, the club's co-owner, was asked if he thought any of the current young Mets might someday be rewarded with such an honor.

title: Ticket by Ticket, One Small Circus Makes Ends Meet
description: If Hollywood is caught these days between escalating budgets and unpredictable audiences, so is an older, gentler form of entertainment: the traveling circus. And although studio moguls may while away their lunches calculating what Demi Moore is worth on screen without clothes, Frank Murray faces a more modest but equally vexing financial question: the cost of feeding an 8,000-pound Asian elephant.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Dole on His Presidential Campaign Agenda
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Bob Dole on Saturday in his campaign headquarters in Washington:

title: American Summer
description: Each day was a time clock that scarcely moved,

title: Corrections
description: The mutual fund tables on Saturday carried incorrect numbers for the five-year percentage returns for all funds. Morningstar Inc. supplied The Times with figures for the previous four weeks, rather than five years. The five-year returns will appear next Saturday.

title: Team Magic Wins Again
description: Match-racing along the protected shores of Manhasset Bay is a long way from America's Cup duels in the open waters off San Diego. But members of last year's victorious Black Magic team from New Zealand proved today that it doesn't matter much.

title: Baltimore's New Birds Knock Off Raiders
description: The railings around Memorial Stadium were festooned in red, white and blue bunting. Grown men wore bird cages over their heads. Scalpers got four times the face value of a $29 ticket.

title: Familiar Faces Vie for New Mayorship
description: In the moments before one of their televised debates, there was Maurice A. Ferre, former Miami Mayor and Dade County commissioner, sharing a joke with Arthur Teele Jr., former commissioner and at one time Miami mayoral candidate against Mr. Ferre.

title: Electric Society Wins A Nose-to-Nose Battle
description: If baseball is a game of inches, then horse racing is a game of noses. And you had to wonder whose nose would catch the finish-line photo today as Powder Bowl and Electric Society came barreling down the homestretch of the Diana Handicap, noses apart.

title: Whistle-Stop Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: For First Time, U.S. Court to Weigh Claim of Rights Abuses in Foreign Land
description: When the soldiers finished with Jose Siderman, having tortured him for most of the first week after the military seized power in Argentina in the spring of 1976, they dumped him in the night by a firing range on the outskirts of his hometown.

title: Markets Closed
description: Financial and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today for Labor Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed. Most foreign markets will be open.

title: Giants Start the Season With a Moral Victory
description: Anyone who says they truly thought the Giants had a chance to beat the Buffalo Bills, a team that many think is going to the Super Bowl, should be strapped in a chair and given a lie detector test. About the only people who thought they had any shot were Giants Coach Dan Reeves and his players.

title: INSIDE
description: Rebels Face Mexican Wrath

title: Record labels are forcing their music on the film industry.
description: WHAT do the movies ''Escape From L.A.,'' ''Clerks,'' ''Johnny Mnemonic,'' ''Mortal Kombat'' and ''Bad Boys'' have in common? They all featured the music of Stabbing Westward, a new industrial-rock band on Columbia Records, a division of Sony Music. The conclusion one might draw from this relatively obscure band's inclusion in so many films is that a lot of directors are fans of Stabbing Westward.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Merrill Lynch Is Told to Pay Two Clients
description: Merrill Lynch & Company must pay two former clients nearly $1 million after an arbitration panel found that the firm had put them into unduly risky investments.

title: Holiday Today
description: Labor Day is observed today.

title: Heartfelt Tales From the Mean Streets
description: ''This here has never been done before,'' the Lost Boyz announce at the beginning of their debut album, ''Legal Drug Money'' (Universal). Of course, what follows has been done a hundred times in the last few years: a crew of tag-team rappers mix party chants and morality tales from the mean streets as a disk jockey drops slow, skidding beats in the background. But the Lost Boyz, whose album entered the pop charts earlier this summer at No. 5, do it well and, except for their introductory claim, honestly.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Harsh Living Conditions Contrast With Champagne Breakfasts
description: Salvador Moreno arrived here nearly two months ago to take part in this town's most festive season, a time when the annual opening of its famed racecourse ushers in weeks of society balls, champagne breakfasts and high-stakes horse racing.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AMY CARTER, 28, the daughter of former PRESIDENT JIMMY CARTER, was married in a homespun ceremony yesterday on the bank of a pond near Plains, Ga.

title: A Century of Piano In One Summer Night
description: Summergarden is almost certainly the best free music series to be found in New York. Rather than pander to a summer taste for mindless entertainment, Joel Sachs, the chairman of the music history department at the Juilliard School, invariably chooses a sprawling, ambitious concept around which to organize his annual concerts in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Office for Blind to Close
description: In a move intended to save $570,000 a year, the State Commission for the Blind will close its Paterson office on Oct. 1 and lay off 10 supervisors statewide. John McKeegan, a spokesman for the State Department of Human Services, said service would not be affected because clients do not typically visit the Paterson office. But Jose Morales, a supervisor in Paterson who is being laid off, said that about 15 people a day come to the office to apply for services and to use large-screen computers and large-type printers.

title: 'Choosing' Death?
description: To the Editor:

title: Honeywell Figures Out The Things It Does Best
description: It is almost a truism: Technology creates as many problems as it solves. Invent electrical ways to wash dishes, cool homes and run factories, and you'll need complex systems to keep fuses from blowing and utility bills from soaring. Make bigger, faster airplanes, and it becomes a major undertaking to coordinate the navigational instruments with the fuel gauges and the maintenance routines.

title: Consumer Reports Forges a TV Identity
description: The magazine Consumer Reports has a formidable reputation, built on images of earnest scientists seizing upon faulty toaster ovens, tinny stereo speakers, or wobbly baby strollers, and precisely enumerating every imperfection, all in the name of giving unbiased guidance to the average consumer.

title: Steeple Yields a 'Signature'
description: Work on rebuilding the 225-year-old steeple of St. Peter's Episcopal Church will not begin for another week or so, but the restoration effort has already produced something new: the knowledge that the steeple was designed by one of the Colonial period's most noted architects, Robert Smith, who also designed Nassau Hall at Princeton University and Carpenter Hall in Philadelphia. The evidence was in the steeple's cracked roof trusses, said the Rev. Francis N. Hebert, the rector at St. Peter's. The trusses, one of Mr. Smith's hallmarks, allow for a large open space within the building that does not require supporting posts. The church, which served as a hospital during the Revolutionary War, is still in active use.

title: Labor Is What Others Do for Us
description: My family owns a farm, and last week we shipped a 28-pound box of Castleman plums to the East Coast. We received $7 for that box, but it will probably be sold at retail for somewhere between $50 and $70.

title: Master of Protocol, and No Slouch at Martial Arts
description: To anyone who has watched Georges Ouegnin, the legendarily stern and punctilious director of presidential protocol here over the years, the story of how he landed his job 36 years ago can only provoke surprise.

title: With Ship's Hull Back on the Ocean Floor, Titanic Buffs Return to New York
description: At sunrise yesterday, an 11-ton section of the Titanic was to have made its way into New York Harbor on a salvage ship, symbolically ending the doomed journey the ocean liner began 84 years ago from Southampton, England.

title: The Selling Is Virtual; The Errors Are Human
description: In the best of all virtual worlds, a few keystrokes of a computer produce a carefully wrapped book on your porch in just three days.

title: Miguel Godreau, a Lead Dancer With Alvin Ailey, Dies at 49
