description: Miguel Godreau, a former lead dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, died on Thursday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 49 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pathologist's View
description: To the Editor:

title: Round sails that hoverlike parasols and work like helicopters.
description: IMAGINE a marina on a warm day: the water is flecked with dozens of triangular sails. If David Lekhtman had his way, however, such a tableau would look vastly different. Those sails would be round, and instead of hanging vertically from a mast, they would hover horizontally, parasol-like, above the craft.

title: Speakers Bureaus Are on the Web Now Making Planning a Conference Easier
description: Conference planners looking for speakers on anything from marketing and sales to New Age spirituality now have dozens of bureaus, and hundreds of speakers, from which to choose on the World Wide Web.

title: Party Sidelines a Leader Who Was a Thorn in Mandela's Side
description: A month after embarrassing President Nelson Mandela by disclosing that he had accepted a 1994 campaign donation from a businessman under investigation for bribery, a high-level African National Congress official has been stripped of his party membership.

title: Welcome to the Club
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Tests Now Plumb New Depths of the Job Seeker
description: Members of America's professional and managerial classes have always left college and graduate school confident of at least one thing: Unless they let their driver's licenses lapse, they had taken their last test. Charm, cunning and a record of accomplishment would propel them up the corporate ladder.

title: How to Slap Iraq?
description: Presidents find it politically useful to stand up to bullies. Especially in campaign season. And most especially when their opponents have distinguished war records and they have none.

title: Smith Sees Clear Path And Makes Giants Pay
description: Bruce Smith was surprised. For a defensive end with enough quickness for 126 1/2 sacks in 11 pro seasons, he has maneuvered himself into many a clear path to the quarterback. But none was quite like this.

title: Girl, 4, Is Dead in Manhattan And Her Mother Is Charged
description: An emaciated 4-year-old girl who had apparently been systematically starved was found dead by the police in a Washington Heights apartment Saturday night, and her mother was charged with murder yesterday after confessing on videotape that she had not fed the child regularly for a year and had not sought medical help even after it was obvious that she was dying.

title: American Topics : 3-D Images, Without Funny Glasses
description: A researcher at Stanford University has developed a system that will allow people to view three-dimensional color images without the cardboard glasses that were a fad in the 1950s.

title: A COMPUTER GAP IS LIKELY TO SLOW WELFARE CHANGES
description: It sounds simple. The Federal Government will impose a five-year lifetime limit on welfare payments to any family, starting no later than next July. But state and Federal officials say it will be months, probably years, before they have the computer capability to enforce such restrictions throughout the country.

title: Navratilova Against History: Love-15
description: To the Editor:

title: With Crime This Low, Honesty Is Easier
description: In this hard-working town, where wheat fields lap to the edges of backyards, Albert (Buzz) Olson has found a novel way to sell gas and to work across town as postmaster -- at the same time.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-7

title: More Assisted-Suicide Laws, More Kevorkians
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Japanese stocks were trading slightly higher here early today, after a run of recent losses. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 36.78 points -- nearly one-fifth of 1 percent -- to stand at 20,203.68. On Friday, the Nikkei index fell 386.26 points, or 1.9 percent.

title: Hurricane, Easing, Grazes Eastern L.I.
description: Losing intensity as it lumbered north, Hurricane Edouard skirted the New York City area last night, bringing rain, heavy surf and tidal flooding to eastern Suffolk County as it set a course for the southern coast of New England.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When it comes to the Tokyo String Quartet, the pianist RUTH LAREDO is starting to feel ''like a member of the permanent Red Cross.''

title: PALESTINIAN TALKS WITH ISRAEL NEAR
description: Despite all the dramatic gestures, public rancor and political wrangles on both sides, the new Israeli Government and the Palestinian Authority are reported to be near an understanding on moving forward with their peace, Israeli officials said today.

title: In the South Bronx
description: Afternoons I walked past broken signs and bright graffiti,grief's wild signatures scrawled across abandoned buildings,to the store I worked in -- my family's store --where my tasks were simple ones because I was a child:dusting, sweeping, arranging greeting cards on skinny silver shelving.

title: A Soloist Decides To Be Part Of the Team
description: ''This seems to be more difficult for other people than it has been for me, strangely enough,'' a bemused Carter Brey said of his decision to scale back a thriving solo and chamber music career to become the principal cellist of the New York Philharmonic, starting Sept. 18, when the orchestra opens its season. ''It certainly catches people off balance. They don't know what to make of it.''

title: Airbus Pins Hopes on 'Super-Jumbo'
description: PARIS  Believing that its use of state-of-the-art technology gives it an important edge over the Boeing 747, an aircraft based on an original 1960s concept, the European Airbus consortium seems set to press ahead to build a "super-jumbo" that will seat 550 passengers in its initial standard version.

title: Applaud Those Boring Political Conventions
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: I.N.C's New Image

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball
TUESDAY

title: The Pressure of Being Perot's No. 2
description: As Ross Perot searches for a running mate, those on his list would do well to remember the experiences of my father in 1992. Adm. James B. Stockdale reluctantly agreed to do his old friend a favor then. He still wishes Ross well, but this year he'll be voting for Bob Dole.

title: N. H. Hollow, 76, Tribal Leader Of Montana Reservation, Is Dead
description: Norman Harry Hollow, a former tribal chairman of the Fort Peck, Mont., Indian reservation, which is home to members of the Assiniboine and Sioux tribes, died in his sleep early Saturday at his ranch near Fort Kipp, Mont. He was 76.

title: Even the Promo Is Bad
description: Should WNBC-TV/Channel 4 be sued for lying-in-advertising -- or cruel and unusual punishment -- for its Jets' promotional campaign? Shameless is the only word for spots promoting such a dismal team with such false lyrics:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Accounts
description: E.& J. Gallo Winery, Modesto, Calif., to Citron Haligman Bedecarre, San Francisco, as the first agency for Gossamer Bay, a new ''midpriced varietal'' line of California table wines. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: More Fans, but Fewer Bets At Saratoga This Season
description: The 127th season of horse racing in the Adirondacks came to a close today with Flitch and Langfuhr winning the last two stakes, Bill Mott winning the trainers' title for the fourth time and Jerry Bailey winning the riding title for the third time in a row. But there was also a business puzzler: attendance at the track was up but betting was down.

title: Pageant Contestants Arrive
description: The Miss America Pageant is not until Sept. 14, but yesterday, the 50 contestants arrived in town. ''We're in the fun business, so have some fun over the next two weeks,'' The Associated Press quoted Mayor James Whelan as telling the visitors. But not too much fun: Pageant rules prohibit contestants from setting foot in a casino, drinking alcohol, smoking in public, wearing a state crown or going anywhere without a chaperone. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Hurricane Skirts, and Slaps, Cape Cod Area
description: Hurricane Edouard, which had threatened to pound Nantucket with 110-mile-per-hour winds and torrential rains, flirted with the island today and then veered east.

title: Friends of slain man set up crime-  and violence-prevention projects, many aimed at young people.
description: A GROUP of executives who are prominent in the agency and media industries in New York are working to help bring life from death.

title: Full-Time Power-Supply Insurance for Your Data
description: A U.P.S., in computer language, is not a way to deliver packages but a way to deliver peace of mind. If the power goes out, even for a fraction of a second, the computer forgets everything in its memory, everything you have done since the last time you saved files to the hard disk. A U.P.S., for Uninterruptible Power Supply, takes over when the main power fails, giving you a few minutes to save files and exit gracefully.

title: Auto Workers Union Close to Choice for Final Talks
description: After a week of intense negotiations with General Motors and Ford Motor, the United Automobile Workers union is on the verge of choosing one of them for a final round of talks aimed at producing a national labor contract that the union would try to apply across the industry, union officials said today.

title: Workplace Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: The United States Defeats Another Superpower
description: In a span of less than 50 hours, the hockey team representing the United States convincingly defeated the sport's two world superpowers, Canada and Russia.

title: Latest Drownings Add To the Infamy of a Lake
description: Six-year-old Erica just wanted to wade in the shallows of John D. Long Lake, but her mother, Michelle Edwards, did not want the water to touch her.

title: Forces of the Future Win One, Lose One At the U.S. Open
description: The pert pair of 15-year-olds, wrinkle-free and underwhelmed by the occasion, were ready and waiting to upstage the incumbents on the Stadium Court. Prodigies are like that. They clutched their tennis racquets just like best friends, then swung them like weapons when the curtain went up on a double dose of fourth-round confrontations between the establishment and the newcomers.

title: The 30-Homer Club Grows
description: When Eric Karros hit a two-run home run in the eighth inning at Shea Stadium yesterday, it did more than increase the Dodgers' lead to 6-3 over the Mets. The home run, Karros's 30th, set a major league record. The Los Angeles first baseman became the 29th player with 30 or more home runs this season, eclipsing the record of 28 established in 1987, the year hitters also set a major league record for total home runs.

title: An Oddly Shaped Molecule Is Used To Switch New Genes On and Off
description: USING drugs with exotic shapes, molecular biologists have tackled a fundamental problem of gene therapy: once a gene is added to cells, how can it be controlled? With the new drugs, researchers have successfully switched genes on and off at will in animal experiments.

title: A New Notebook Fleet Sets Sail
description: THE naming of computers, like T. S. Eliot's naming of cats, is a difficult matter. Precisely why a line of notebook machines might be named after a Spanish fleet that was soundly defeated more than 400 years ago is a bit hard to fathom.

title: Please, Quieter Subways
description: To the Editor:

title: Roughing It for Class
description: Colleges are encouraging students to backpack, canoe and camp together to get to know one another before starting their class work.

title: Back to Work, to Markets Fearful of Higher Rates
description: As summer vacation wound down last week, it appeared that stocks and interest rates would end up little changed from where they were last spring, when schools closed and camper vans were being loaded.

title: Police Dept. Internet Site Is Not New York's Finest
description: In the boundless new world of cyberspace, linguists can study Yiddish, vacationers can book safaris, and epicures can order vintage white Burgundies. But the pickings are still pretty thin for police buffs looking for N.Y.P.D. Blue.

title: Bell Atlantic's Litany of Snags In Mexico Deal
description: In the first heady days of the free-trade pact between the United States and Mexico, the Bell Atlantic Corporation spent more than $1 billion to buy a piece of a feisty Mexican cellular telephone company that had big plans to grow.

title: States' Wrongs on Abortion
description: Although the debate about national abortion policy is the one drawing headlines, the real action on abortion today is not in Washington but in the states. In state legislatures around the country, abortion's opponents are winning a stealth war to limit women's right to choose. In many states, access to abortion is now prohibitively daunting for all but a small percentage of women. Today 84 percent of American counties have no abortion providers. North Dakota's only abortion doctor lives out of state and flies to Fargo once a week. In many states, women must drive four or five hours to the nearest clinic.

title: Now It's City Opera's Turn To Fiddle With the Sound
description: The New York City Opera, long unhappy with the sound at the New York State Theater, is undertaking an acoustical renovation that involves the addition of acoustical panels at the sides of the house and absorptive materials on the rear walls of the balconies, as well as changes in the orchestra pit. Sherwin Goldman, who as executive producer is in charge of the company's administration and finances, said that the renovation would cost about $200,000, a fraction of the bill for the last overhaul, a full-fledged, $5.2 million reconstruction in 1982.

title: Can Steelers Recover From Lloyd's Injury?
description: The Steelers, the defending American Football Conference champions, are reeling one game into the season. Linebacker Greg Lloyd is gone for the year with a torn patella tendon in his left knee and Jim Miller, who won the quarterback derby in the preseason, was benched in Pittsburgh's 24-9 loss to Jacksonville in Sunday's opener.

title: Crime Wave Leaves Mexicans Wary of Federal Police
description: When 10 masked men in jeeps and brandishing automatic rifles blocked an elegant street here recently to search the home of one of Tijuana's eminent families, witnesses took them for what their black uniforms proclaimed them to be: Federal Judicial Police.

title: In a Mine, a Paean to Danger and Daring
description: Chris Ledvina was a safety inspector for the Old Ben Coal Company, working in Mine No. 26 in Southern Illinois, when he found a place ''that wasn't so safe.''

title: Looking Taller in Leggings
description: Leggings can be as casual as jeans, worn at home or on the weekend with an oversize shirt or big sweater. But wait. Karl Lagerfeld showed leggings under long skinny jackets in his fall haute-couture show for Chanel, and suddenly they are the height of fashion.

title: 24 Hours Didn't Ease Jets' Pain
description: After the Jets paid penance today by watching tapes of Sunday's 31-6 opening-day rout by the Denver Broncos, the appraisals flowed freely.

title: Kemp Tries to Rein In His Words
description: At a rally last week in Costa Mesa, Calif., Jack Kemp was supposed to speak for seven minutes. Aides clocked him at 22, and counted themselves lucky he did not go on longer.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Christine Pascal, 42, Actress and Director
description: The actress and film director Christine Pascal, who made her movie acting debut at 21 and directed her first film at 25, has died at the age of 42, her husband's production agency said yesterday in Paris.

title: Introduction to Graham From the Junior Troupe
description: Those who fear that dance is dead might have been heartened to see the standing-room-only audience on Friday night at a performance by the Martha Graham Dance Ensemble at the Damrosch Park Band Shell in Lincoln Center Out of Doors. The audience was rapt, too. And the program and performers were the perfect outdoors entertainment, holding their own against street noise and the cityscape around them in dances that were a fine introduction to Graham's art and influence.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICKEY ROURKE, the film star known for his tough-guy performances on and off the screen, was briefly hospitalized over the weekend while in Italy, where he was shooting a film.

title: After Chemical Merger, Chase Promotes Itself as a Nimble Bank Giant
description: For the three million New York area customers of the old Chase Manhattan and Chemical Bank, the merger announced a year ago to create the nation's largest bank may finally seem tangible today.

title: Digital Faces Tough Market For Altavista
description: Dear Investor:

title: Chechen Peace Pact Draws Fire in Kremlin
description: Just two days after Russian and Chechen officials signed an agreement to end the Chechen war, top Kremlin officials bluntly expressed misgivings today about the accord.

title: Agency Had Noted Problems in Home Where Girl Starved
description: The head of New York City's Administration for Children's Services acknowledged yesterday that evidence of neglect was found 15 months ago at the home of Nadine Lockwood, the 4-year-old girl who investigators say was starved to death by her mother. But he said that after an initial review of records, he could not say what action, if any, was taken by city social workers.

title: A-Plant Managers Try Attitude Adjustment
description: Unit 3 was supposed to have been the good reactor at the Millstone Nuclear Power Station -- the newest, the biggest, the most advanced, the best operated.

title: Bad Season Ahead
description: Evil temper is everywhere. It doubtless has to do with the political campaign. Presidential campaigns often bring out the worst in people, and not just in politicians, but in your relatives, friends, associates and complete strangers.

title: Welfare Mothers Deserve Care, Not Contempt
description: To the Editor:

title: Inspiration Behind a Dugout
description: Ed Cone wanted his trip to be a secret. He had always planned to attend his youngest son's comeback start against the Athletics today, but he refused to tell David. He did not want to add more pressure to an already pressure-filled day. Pressure on David Cone? What pressure?

title: Bradley, Eyes On Horizon, Takes a Stroll
description: It was Senator Bill Bradley's final trek up the Jersey Shore this Labor Day weekend. And as he trudged through the sand and strolled along the boardwalk, over and over again people rose from their towels and beach chairs to bid farewell to the senior United States Senator from New Jersey and urge him to remain on the political scene.

title: 'Hired Gun' Finds Bullets In His Heart
description: HE was ready, but the mound wasn't. In a stride that was as purposeful as his attitude, the 33-year-old pitcher had arrived at the mound for the Yankees for the first time since May 2, eight days before his sudden surgery for the aneurysm in his right shoulder. And now he began digging at the mound with his right shoe.

title: Clinton's World Vision
description: Republicans have complained that the Clinton foreign-policy record has focused on peripheral national security issues and does not understand the importance of consistency or the need to honor commitments.

title: Scofflaw Held in Brooklyn
description: The police, responding yesterday to a call about illegal dumping at Myrtle and Nostrand Avenues in Brooklyn, arrested a driver whose license had been suspended 190 times, the police said. A review of state records showed that many license suspensions for the driver, Andrew Dean, 36, of 741 Martin Drive, Uniondale, L.I., were for unanswered summonses.

title: Gary Lynch, Defender of Companies, Has His Critics
description: When a company is accused of wrongdoing, who can it call to help repair its reputation?

title: 26 Years Deep in the Paleocene
description: A 10-YEAR-OLD boy's curiosity about a man who was chopping rocks along the banks of the Mississippi near here led, decades later, to the unearthing of one of the world's richest sites of Paleocene fossils. The man told the inquisitive boy that he was a geologist and showed him fossils he had dug from the river bank, sparking an interest that produced a paleontologist who has greatly enriched knowledge of the ancient history of North America.

title: Richards Group Opening New Office
description: The Richards Group is opening the first office outside its headquarters in Dallas by hiring Virgil Shutze, a longtime agency executive in the Southeast, to head a joint venture based in Atlanta.

title: Chess
description: The play in this year's United States championship looked as if it had come under the influence of Gata Kamsky: slogging held sway.

title: A Further Freedom: To Catch Up With Trash News
description: The uses of lobbying and the impact of print and broadcast journalism are not uninspected subjects, but tonight's first installment of ''The People and the Power Game'' uses case histories to good effect to bring home why they have become so troubling in recent years.

title: Butler Plans to Play Friday
description: If all goes well, Brett Butler will be in the Dodgers' starting lineup Friday night when Los Angeles plays the Pittsburgh Pirates at Dodger Stadium. It would complete a remarkable comeback from surgery and treatment for throat cancer that was diagnosed on May 6.

title: 'Crow' Is No. 1 at Box Office During the Labor Day Weekend
description: Miramax Pictures' ''The Crow: City of Angels'' opened as the top-grossing film on Labor Day weekend, setting a record with $10.1 million in revenue, according to preliminary studio estimates released today.

title: INSIDE
description: A Battle Brews Over Jobs

title: Bill May Pit Five Boroughs In Jobs Battle
description: A little-noticed bill approved by the State Legislature would take away some of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's authority over economic development and give it to the five borough presidents. It raises the unusual prospect of the boroughs competing against one another -- and against City Hall -- for jobs by dangling ever-larger incentives in front of private businesses.

title: Whose Heaven Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Caribbean Beat Gets Brooklyn Dancing
description: Hundreds of thousands of people danced in the streets of Brooklyn in the annual West Indian-American Day parade yesterday. The parade, which started as a small pre-Lenten festivity in Harlem half a century ago, has become an international event that organizers estimate attracts up to two million people each year. ''I wouldn't miss it for the world,'' said Ken Atherton, 42, who was born in Trinidad and who has come to New York from Winnipeg, Canada, for the parade every year since 1976. ''It's fun! Isn't that enough?''

title: Mets Are Done In by the Dodgers' Rookie of This Year
description: The Mets thought they might have a chance to wrestle the rookie of the year award from the Dodgers, who have had a stranglehold on it for the past four years.

title: Granular Objects, if Jiggled, Mimic Atoms and Molecules
description: A GROUP of physicists at the University of Texas has reported an astonishing discovery: when a thin layer of tiny brass spheres is spread over the flat bottom of a container and the container is jiggled up and down at a certain rhythm, the spheres spontaneously organize themselves into patterns that seem to mimic behavior of atoms, molecules and crystals.

title: Fix the Chaos at Crowded Schools, Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Goes Caribbean on West Indian-American Day
description: Atop the flatbed of a red, white and blue truck riding through the streets of Brooklyn yesterday, Trecia Grant gently swayed to the strains of calypso. But her mind was elsewhere.

title: Coach Faces More Charges
description: More charges have been filed against a 45-year-old soccer and softball coach who was accused last week of molesting two girls. The coach, Richard A. Gibbs, a volunteer at the Medford Youth Athletic Association, was charged on Friday with molesting two other girls, the authorities said. Prosecutors said last week that they expected more victims to surface, and the Medford Township police reported over the weekend that they had received calls from 20 parents. Mr. Gibbs also tutored students in computer skills at the Taunton Forge Elementary School in Medford and was co-owner of a day-care center in Merion, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about United States and United Nations policy toward Iraq misspelled the given name of the spokeswoman for the United Nations Secretary General in some copies. She is Sylvana Foa, not Sylvanna.

title: Midtown Direct on Weekends
description: New Jersey Transit will offer its Midtown Direct train service on weekends beginning this Sunday. The service, which takes passengers on the Morris and Essex Line directly to Pennsylvania Station in New York without the need to switch to PATH trains or ferries in Hoboken, saves riders 20 minutes. Trains will run about every hour, beginning at 5:15 A.M. Sunday, with 19 round trips in all, said Penny Bassett Hackett, a spokeswoman for the transit agency. The railroad expects the number of people riding the line on weekends to rise to 3,850, from 3,300, with most of the increase on Saturdays, she said.

title: U.S. Attacks Military Targets in Iraq
description: The United States early today launched a cruise missile attack on military and command targets in Iraq in retaliation for its incursion into the northern Kurdish enclave.

title: The Notion of Murder as the Way to a Man's Heart
description: Puffing on still another cigarette, Robbie Coltrane's Fitz, easily the most offbeat murder-mystery hero of recent seasons, makes a characteristically nose-thumbing exit from the British series ''Cracker'' on A&E tonight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: From a Life Of Wealth Into a Life Of Danger
description: THE LAST THING HE WANTED

title: Growing Up at Flushing Meadows
description: THERE is no strategy for being 15. No racquet grip, no perfect toss, no choice of shot, no advice from coach, Mom or Dad, to prepare a kid for the Stadium Court of the United States Open. For the hot afternoon sun and a noisy crowd and a tight match against a world-class champion that feels as if it is slipping away.

title: American Air And Its Pilots Reach Accord
description: American Airlines and its pilots' union reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a new contract, ending two years of negotiations that had prevented the airline from growing.

title: Saskatchewan Company In Accord to Buy Arcadian
description: The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan Inc. said today that it would acquire the Arcadian Corporation in a transaction valued at up to $1.23 billion in cash and stock, ending an agreement for Arcadian to be bought by Freeport-McMoran Inc.

title: Corn Hides Inmate's Escape
description: A Hackettstown man escaped from the Warren County Correctional Center on Saturday while pulling up cornstalks during a work detail, officials said. The prisoner, Stephen Wydner, was about a quarter-mile from the jail when he slipped out of view behind tall corn, said Sgt. Robert Ackerman, a spokesman for the county corrections division. Mr. Wydner had served two years of a five-year sentence for trying to break into his girlfriend's house in Washington Township by firing a shotgun, Sergeant Ackerman said. He said the cornfield was near train tracks and the Delaware River.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: TUESDAY

title: In the Lead, Clinton Plays the Underdog
description: President Clinton wound up nine days of intense campaigning with a brace of Labor Day celebrations in Wisconsin today, one at a picnic on traditionally Republican turf near Green Bay and the other in an old-fashioned evening rally with liberal leaders of big labor in Milwaukee.

title: Burmese Junta Says Democracy Leader Aids Subversion
description: The military Government today accused the leader of the democratic opposition, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, of collaborating with subversives, including American citizens. Steps will be taken against her ''if and when required,'' officials of the junta said.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: As Officials Recalled Elisa's Fatal Abuse, Another Girl Lay Dying
description: Only hours before the stick-thin body of 4-year-old Nadine Lockwood was found in her mother's Washington Heights apartment on Saturday night, the head of the city's child-welfare agency announced the dismissal of a caseworker for negligence in another case.

title: Fire Museum Extends Hours
description: The Hoboken Fire Department Museum, situated in a former firehouse dating from the early 1800's, has a permanent collection that includes a restored 60-year-old pumper truck, antique alarm systems, extinguisher, uniforms and more than 1,000 historical photographs. But few people besides students and participants in the Fire Prevention Week activities held each October ever got to visit the museum. Beginning this week, the museum will be open every Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., offering tours led by firefighters.

title: If Inflation Is Tamed, Does It Have to Be Killed?
description: Central bankers, exemplars of caution, are not ones to proclaim victory, especially over so resilient a foe as inflation.

title: Electric Cars, Clean Air And the Latest Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hip-Hop Challenge: Longevity
description: Like the star-filled runway show staged by the rap magazine Vibe last Friday, hip-hop fashion has attracted a sparkling sheaf of celebrity entrepreneurs, like Shaquille O'Neal, Spike Lee, the entertainment mogul Russell Simmons, Chuck D. of the rap group Public Enemy and the newest and most unlikely entrant this summer, Mike Tyson. These are just the marquee names.

title: Karadzic Is Out of Sight, But Not Out of Voters' Minds
description: On a platform set up in a small soccer stadium, an empty wooden picture frame was tacked behind the podium surrounded by red, white and blue Serbian flags.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One might think that cutting hair at a military academy would not leave much room for experimentation. But this year, DAVE CREATURO, who clips locks at the Citadel, had his first female cadets. So it was time to come up with an alternative to the standard ''knob'' haircut.

title: Cosmetic Surgery Benefits From More Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Saddam's New Weapon
description: Saddam Hussein is attacking the Kurds of Iraq with tanks, heavy artillery, infantry and a particularly powerful weapon that he acquired only when the gulf war ended.

title: Satellite Radar Unveils Subtle, Slow Wrinkling Of the Planet's Surface
description: THE surface of the earth is alive with motions too subtle for direct human observation, the slow wrinkling of the planetary skin, that pose considerable risks to cities and people. Slow shifts of the earth's plates regularly build up strains that cause earthquakes. Volcanoes swell before they explode. Glaciers move and polar ice packs break up as the earth warms, raising seas and threatening to flood coastal areas.

title: An N.F.L. Record of Guts and Guile
description: In his early years as a professional football player, Jack Kemp displayed perseverance. Leadership came later.

title: Western Butterfly Shifting North as Global Climate Warms
description: THE research required 45,000 miles of driving and 14 months of living in a tent, but Dr. Camille Parmesan, a California biologist, has come up with what scientists say is the clearest evidence so far that global warming is forcing living species to move toward the poles and to higher altitudes.

title: Betita Cabrera Coty, 50, Oakland Crusader
description: The Rev. Betita Cabrera Coty, a Nicaraguan-born evangelical minister and community leader who fasted for four weeks in an effort to end a teachers' strike in Oakland, Calif., early this year, died on Saturday at her home in Oakland. She was 50.

title: Giants Set the Tone, But Couldn't Deliver
description: Confidence is something safety Tito Wooten never lacks. But going into the Giants' season opener with Buffalo on Sunday night, he was as confident as he had ever been. He had been ignoring the predictions of people who thought the Bills would step on the Giants en route to the Super Bowl. He knew the game would be tight.

title: The Meaning of Electric
description: To the Editor:

title: No Storm, Just Waves
description: Huge waves spawned by distant Hurricane Edouard washed over the beach at Gateway National Park at noon yesterday, flooding the peninsula's main road, Hartshorne Drive, and making it impassible, park officials said. Earlier, 50 beachgoers were sent home, said Tom Lobkowicz, a supervisory park ranger. The park was reopened at 3:30 P.M., but the flooding is expected to recur because last winter's storms eroded portions of the beach, particularly at one critical point in the middle of the island, Mr. Lobkowicz said. Elsewhere at the Jersey Shore, beaches were open, but swimming was banned at some beaches and permitted only late in the day at others.

title: Hall of Fame Formed by Agencies
description: Thirteen agencies that specialize in medical advertising are forming a Medical Advertising Hall of Fame to recognize outstanding campaigns.

title: Iraqi Troops Said to Round Up Kurd Leaders
description: Iraqi soldiers who captured the town of Erbil this weekend conducted house-to-house searches for Kurdish leaders they view as enemies and killed hundreds of people, relief workers who fled the region said today.

title: A Ban on Chemical Weapons
description: The Senate plans to vote next week on ratification of the Chemical Weapons Convention, negotiated during the Reagan and Bush Administrations and signed by the United States and 129 other nations shortly before President Bush left office. By voting to ratify, senators can make it harder for a future Saddam Hussein to endanger American troops with chemical weapons and harder for future terrorists to unleash lethal gases on subway commuters, as happened in Tokyo last year.

title: Sensational Comeback for Cone: Seven Innings, No Runs, No Hits
description: David Cone's incredible comeback story evolved into an unbelievable pitching tale today when he returned to the Yankees less than four months after surgery to remove an aneurysm from under his right armpit and no-hit the Oakland Athletics during his seven-inning appearance.

title: Trailing, Dole Vows A Touch of Truman
description: Invoking the come-from-behind victory of Harry S. Truman 48 years ago, Bob Dole opened his fall campaign today by describing this year's contest as a vivid choice between ''old-style liberal vision'' and a conservative vision that would roll back the Government. Mr. Dole devoted more than one-third of his speech to his promise of a tax cut.

title: U.S. Markets Closed
description: Financial and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses were also closed for the holiday. Many foreign markets, however, were open yesterday. $(D6.$)

title: A Model City With Everything, and Now Poverty
description: Thirty-six years after this planned city rose in the no man's land of the Brazilian interior, it still has no neighborhoods. Along the wide roadways, signs lead to sections named not for national heroes but by numbers and letters, leaving travelers with the feeling of climbing over a three-dimensional blueprint rather than a breathing city.

title: British Firm Halts Trading In Some Funds
description: Morgan Grenfell Asset Management, one of Britain's largest fund managers, halted trading in three funds today and suspended a fund manager after it said that it had discovered ''possible irregularities'' in some unquoted securities held by the portfolios.

title: Guarding Her Father's Legacy With a Smile
description: George S. Kaufman left a large theatrical legacy, more than 40 plays and musicals, almost all written in collaboration with partners like Moss Hart, Irving Berlin and George and Ira Gershwin. Two musicals, ''The Cocoanuts'' and ''Animal Crackers,'' (and the movie ''A Night at the Opera'') were heavily indebted to the Marx Brothers. In the 35 years since Kaufman's death, his daughter, Anne Kaufman Schneider, has become the keeper of his fame.

title: Classic Sports Network Gets $20 Million in New Capital
description: Warburg Pincus Ventures has invested $20 million in the Classic Sports Network, the year-old cable television service dedicated to showcasing and repackaging oldies sports programming.

title: Car Crash Kills Woman
description: A 43-year-old Newark woman was killed late Sunday when her car veered off Route 22, flipped over a berm and landed on New Jersey Transit train tracks, the police said. A westbound train on the Raritan Valley Line was stalled for 41 minutes while the woman's car was pulled from the tracks, and the eastbound lanes of Route 22 were closed for three hours yesterday while the police investigated the accident, said Sgt. Anthony Mayor of the Hillside police. The cause of the crash was not known. The police did not release the woman's name.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Union Moves Closer To Picking Ford for Talks

title: Eli Lilly Rival Wins Round in Court Battle
description: Novo Nordisk A.S. of Denmark said today that it had won a preliminary injunction against Eli Lilly & Company of the United States in a dispute over the marketing of insulin cartridges.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an obituary yesterday about Miguel Godreau, a former lead dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, reversed the positions in the photo in some editions. Mr. Godreau was on the right; Judith Jamison was on the left.

title: Official State Animal, It Seems, Is an Annoying Overachiever
description: The residents of Sylvia Lake blew up a beaver dam this summer, but dynamite proved no match for America's most industrious rodent. Within four days the beavers had rebuilt their dam, stopping up a crucial outlet and raising Sylvia Lake to problem levels once again. On the Fourth of July, people barbecued on docks under six inches of water.

title: 5 Groups At the Clubs This Week
description: The CMJ Music Marathon brings hundreds of bands to town this week to play for college-radio programmers and alternative-rock magnates. Here are five of the groups.

title: A Virus That Speaks Of a Deadly World Plot
description: What can you make of a hero whose license plate reads ''EBOLA''? It's probably best not to take him, or the entertaining but goofy series he's in, too seriously.

title: Poland Is Resisting U.S. Call That It Sell Tanks to Bosnia
description: In a bow to the European Union, but a rebuff to the United States, the Polish Government is resisting selling battle tanks to the incipient Bosnian Army, American and Polish officials said.

title: No Headline
description: ''Maybe the devil is working to destroy him because he is going the way of God. I am a religious person and I swear to God this is true. It's a big mistake. My son, he wouldn't hurt a fly.''

title: Republicans Shined
description: To the Editor:

title: For AIDS Doctors, a Needed Tonic
description: After more than a decade caring for patients who might not survive to middle age, Dr. Howard A. Grossman of New York has begun to imagine a day when gay men would need his services as a geriatrician.

title: Prosecutors Are Stalled In '91 Clash
description: The prosecutor leading the investigation into the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic scholar during racial violence in Crown Heights in 1991 says the possibility is becoming ''more and more remote'' that additional people will be charged in the killing besides the two men indicted so far.

title: They're Hitting the Trail Before Hitting the Books
description: At a spot along the Appalachian Trail, somewhere in western Connecticut, voices echo through the trees. The sound is faint at first, then strong enough to be recognized as singing. Loud singing.

title: Seminarian Held on Bomb Charge at Airport
description: Roman Regman, 21, who lives with his mother in Florida and has been studying at a Pennsylvania seminary for a priesthood in the Orthodox Church in America, hardly fit the profile of a terrorist bomber or hijacker. His manner at Tampa International Airport was polite, deferential, calm and cooperative.

title: Q&A
description: Feverish Cats

title: Smith Hurt as Bears Upset the Cowboys
description: In the first half, the Chicago Bears used trickery to stay close to the Dallas Cowboys, the defending Super Bowl champions. In the second half, the Bears did not need mirrors or magic.

title: Clark Enters a Pennant Race and Finds It Fun
description: Cinderella's gown turned into rags at midnight. Dave Clark's clothes turned into the uniform of a pennant-contending team just before midnight.

title: After Youth Boot Camp Comes a Harder Discipline
description: Nelson Colon misses waking up to the blast of reveille. He sometimes yearns for those 16-hour days filled with military drills and nine-mile runs. He even thinks fondly of the surly drill instructors who shouted in his face.

title: A Traipse Through Summer's Business Folly
description: Yes, the dreaded day is here. Schoolchildren must be yanked away from the beach and the bliss of staying up late, and grown-ups must put on oh-so-solemn faces and concentrate again on the tasks at hand. Call it Labor Day + 1 -- no, make that Refocusing Day.

title: The Congressional Primaries
description: New York City's members of Congress almost all face minimal opposition in November, and few are being challenged in next week's primaries either. This lack of competition may be pleasant for the New York delegation, but it is bad for the quality of city representation.

title: N.H.L. Is Going High-Tech With Its Stats
description: The National Hockey League and I.B.M. yesterday announced a venture that they believe will transform how hockey data, audio, video and photos will be used by fans on the Internet, as well as by players, coaches, broadcasters and the news media.

title: Taming the Food In the Wilderness
description: Guests at the Crystal Creek Lodge, deep in the bush of southwestern Alaska near Bristol Bay, spend the day fly-fishing in pristine wilderness. But when they return from remote rivers, in a fleet of 40-year-old DeHavilland Beaver seaplanes, they leave the wilderness behind for an evening of fine dining.

title: Slow Road Back for Schools
description: Seven years after the state seized control of Jersey City's ailing public schools, students' scores on standardized reading, writing and math tests are still too low to justify returning the district to local control, a state education official said yesterday. While scores improved in all three subjects, only 70.8 percent of the fourth graders passed the reading test, 61.7 percent of the eighth graders passed the math test, and 11th graders fell short in all categories, according to figures from the State Department of Education.

title: U.S. Gold Medalist Joins Pro Ranks
description: DAVID REID, whose dramatic knockout gave the United States its only Olympic boxing gold medal at Atlanta, turned pro yesterday with a little-known new promoter who said Reid could make up to $50 million. Reid, 22, and his longtime coach and adviser, AL MITCHELL, bypassed such established promoters as DON KING and BOB ARUM to sign with Amerika Presents, owned by the former television executive MAT TINLEY.

title: A Measured Response to Iraq
description: Saddam Hussein's talent for mismanaging Iraq is matched by an uncanny ability to misread the United States. Just as he once mistakenly figured Washington would condone his invasion of Kuwait, Mr. Hussein apparently assumed America was too engrossed in Presidential politics this year to answer a new demonstration of Iraqi belligerence. President Clinton has swiftly proved otherwise.

title: Muting His Criticism of Clinton, Dole Backs Troops in Iraq Raid
description: Eighteen hours after he assailed President Clinton for ''weak leadership'' in dealing with Saddam Hussein, Bob Dole backed away from his criticism today, instead offering his support ''without hesitation or reservation'' for American military forces in the Middle East.

title: The Race for Mayor of Dade County Is Headed for a Runoff
description: The freshest face among four front-runners received the most votes today in the voting for the first ''strong'' mayor of Miami's metropolitan area.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 16 about management and financial turmoil at Danskin Inc. was accompanied by charts with the heading ''Missing a Boom.'' They showed that Danskin's corporate sales fell in each of the last three years while sports apparel sales grew moderately in the industry over all and rose rapidly at Nike, a major competitor.

title: Sun Setting Over Courts And Careers
description: THERE is a transient feeling to this year's United States Open -- personified by the free-floating seeding, personified by the hurricane that never arrived, personified by the new stadium looming on the westward flank of the old place.

title: U.S. Launches Further Strike Against Iraq After Clinton Vows He Will Extract 'Price'
description: The United States launched a second missile strike against Iraq's southern air defenses tonight, just hours after President Clinton vowed that he would make President Saddam Hussein ''pay a price'' for sending his troops into the Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq.

title: Casinos Take In Record Pot
description: After dipping slightly in July, casino revenues set a monthly record in August, the Casino Association of New Jersey reported yesterday. The city's 12 casinos took in $374 million, a 3.1 percent increase over last August, the association said.

title: Wooing Democrats, a Republican Ducks Labels
description: Can this be a foot soldier in the Gingrich Revolution?

title: Bard of Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Beyond 'Hi, My Name is Pat'
description: RESTAURANTS are turning up the gas. An early Labor Day has only shortened this elusive summer, and as the calendar rushes toward fall, new dining spots are about to open.

title: Yanks Fall One Rally Short Against A's
description: Once, twice, three times the Yankees rebounded tonight against the Athletics and made what looked like a depressing night extremely interesting. For every picture of the Yankees slumped in the dugout with pained expressions, there was a shot of them hollering after another energizing comeback.

title: Good Pay, Perks and Constant Calls From Headhunters
description: When 31-year-old Radek A. Gronet returned to his homeland four years ago after working in a Chicago law firm, he found an explosive job market hungry for his youth and skills and appreciative of his American-accented English.

title: Guru of India's Congress Party Hangs On
description: Four months ago, as votes were being counted in a general election, Indians thought they were watching the political burial of P. V. Narasimha Rao, Prime Minister for five years. Mr. Rao's Congress Party turned in its worst election performance ever, taking less than a third of the popular vote and a less than a quarter of the parliamentary seats.

title: Swordfish for Grilling, Indoors or Out
description: As long as the weather is right for outdoor cooking, today's recipe for swordfish can be tried on the grill, or be made inside under the broiler.

title: Philip Morris Employees Get Subpoenas
description: The Philip Morris Companies said today that as many as 12 midlevel managers and other lower-ranking employees had received subpoenas to testify before a Federal grand jury and that the top executives of the tobacco company had not.

title: Texas Immigrants Worry As Cuts in Welfare Loom
description: Here on the Texas-Mexico border, officials have long had an emergency plan for the occasional hurricane that rampages through this tropical stretch of the Rio Grande Valley. But now they need an emergency response to another disturbance that is bearing down on this area and others across the country: the new Federal welfare legislation.

title: Cone's Return Sends Rogers to the Bullpen
description: On the first day after David Cone's remarkable return to the Yankees, he went to lunch with his father, Ed, sent his lucky charm of a dad to the airport and, most important, reported no problems in his valuable right arm. The Orioles, the Red Sox and any teams the Yankees might play in the post-season saw highlights of Cone's seven innings of no-hit baseball against the Athletics, applauded his comeback in a 5-0 victory and then grimaced. He is back.

title: Facing Saddam, Again
description: Three years and eight months into his presidency, Bill Clinton is fighting the war against Saddam Hussein that George Bush never finished.

title: S.I. Man Is Found Dead in Home After Firing on Police Officers
description: An unemployed auto mechanic opened fire yesterday on police officers responding to a complaint of a domestic dispute at his house on Staten Island, officials said. The mechanic, identified as Michael Nunno, 48, was found dead inside the house, although it was unclear last night if he was killed by the officers' bullets or if he killed himself.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: On the Class of 2000
description: September brings predictable back-to-school TV specials, but CBS News has gone to some lengths with its version. A series of reports on the Class of 2000 -- students entering ninth grade this fall, who will graduate from high school at the turn of the century -- will appear all over CBS's schedule.

title: PARK-OHIO MAKES $170 MILLION OFFER FOR SUDBURY
description: Park-Ohio Industries said today that it had offered to buy Sudbury Inc. for $11 a share, or $170 million in cash. Park-Ohio, a manufacturing company based in Cleveland, said the offer was made in a letter to Jacques R. Sardas, the chief executive of Sudbury. The letter stated that Park-Ohio had initially proposed the merger on Aug. 20 and that Mr. Sardas had met with Park-Ohio's chairman and chief executive, Edward Crawford, and its president, John J. Murray, on Aug. 22 to discuss the proposal. Sudbury officials were not immediately available for comment. Park-Ohio said the offer would expire next Monday. Sudbury, also based in Cleveland, makes iron castings, coatings and machinery. Sudbury stock closed at $10.625 a share, down 12.5 cents. Park-Ohio shares closed at $14.125, down 37.5 cents.

title: Moves Against Iraq Send Oil Prices Surging
description: Oil prices soared yesterday in the wake of the American retaliatory attack against Iraq and the United Nations suspension of an agreement to allow Iraqi oil exports.

title: New Director for A.C.L.U.
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey has appointed a new legal director, Lenora M. Lapidus, the organization said yesterday. Ms. Lapidus, 33, a public interest lawyer in Newark, replaces Marsha Wenk, who died in March. Top priorities for the A.C.L.U. are challenges to a law authorizing AIDS testing for people charged with sexual assault and to Rutgers University's refusal to provide benefits to domestic partners of lesbian and gay employees, Ms. Lapidus said.

title: Kinder to Miss Irish Opener
description: A leg injury will keep Notre Dame tailback RANDY KINDER out of tomorrow's season opener against Vanderbilt, the university said yesterday. Kinder, Notre Dame's leading rusher last season, pulled a quadriceps muscle in his right leg during practice Sunday. It wasn't clear whether Kinder would be ready to return to the field in time for the Fighting Irish's Sept. 14 game against Purdue. ROBERT FARMER will start in his place. (AP)

title: Even Bacchus Might Like Beer and a Slice
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Peril to Child Was Missed

title: Another Sign Of Strength At Factories
description: Factory activity expanded for the third consecutive month in August, an industry group reported today, but because analysts and bond traders had been braced for an even stronger performance, the report was met with some relief and the bond market recovered from an early morning drop.

title: Good Taste Has Its Price (And It's Up)
description: Sticker shock. Remember that? When cars that cost 4 grand one year seemed to jump to 14 grand the next? All old hat now; a car -- a real car -- goes for $20,000 or more. Anything below that is just transportation.

title: Argentina Is Reported to Agree To Settle Rights Suit in the U.S.
description: Scrambling to avoid becoming the first foreign government to be tried in the United States for human rights abuses committed in its own country, Argentina has tentatively agreed to a large monetary settlement for a Jewish businessman who was tortured and forced into exile under the former military government, people familiar with the case said today.

title: First, Do No Harm
description: Let's not kid ourselves: Bill Clinton does not have much of an economic program. What he proposes to do is tinker at the edges -- a tax credit here, a government-subsidized volunteer program there.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RUTH STAFFORD PEALE was married to Norman Vincent Peale for 63 years before his death in 1993, so when she turns 90 on Sept. 13, she will mark the occasion by unveiling a life-size bronze sculpture of her husband by JOHN SODERBERG of San Francisco.

title: Chrysler Sales Increased by 9% in August
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that its sales last month rose 9 percent over its strong sales in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: De Benedetti Steps Down as the Chairman of Olivetti
description: Carlo de Benedetti, the ebullient chairman of Olivetti S.p.A. who built the company from a sleepy Italian typewriter maker to one of Europe's largest electronics groups, stepped down last night as a result of the company's continued large losses.

title: Gilkey Hits As Mets Still Lose
description: Mets outfielder Bernard Gilkey has found himself in the middle of the cutthroat, stab-your-colleague-in-the-back world of sports agents.

title: ACCESS HEALTH TO MERGE WITH INFORMED ACCESS
description: Access Health Inc. signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Informed Access Systems, a privately held health information services company based in Broomfield, Colo., for more than $290 million in stock. Access Health, which is based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., said it would issue 5.375 million shares of stock to acquire Informed Access Systems. Access Health's stock closed at $54.25, up $3.50. After the merger, Access Health would have 19.2 million shares outstanding, with current Informed Access Systems shareholders owning 28 percent. Access Health provides membership-based personal health management products. It expects to take an unspecified fourth-quarter charge for integration and transaction-related expenses.

title: Smith Is O.K., but Cowboys Seem to Lack Old Spark
description: Here is the good news for Dallas.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: How Lovely To Be Back In the Pink
description: Molly Ringwald walked onto the sunny Chateau Marmont terrace with red pixie-cut hair and a pure white sleeveless dress, looking just like what she is: a sort of Wendy, not to Peter Pan's lost boys, but to a lost generation.

title: British Building Concern Posts 12% Profit Rise
description: Blue Circle Industries, a British building-materials company, said yesterday that first-half pretax profit for 1996 rose 12 percent as a turnaround in heating and strong cement sales in the United States and Malaysia offset falling demand at home.

title: O'Neill and Nelson Suspensions Irk Yanks
description: The Yankees were fuming today after Paul O'Neill and Jeff Nelson were each suspended for two games and fined $1,000 for their actions in a bench-clearing incident in Seattle last Wednesday night, while John Marzano, who was given only a two-game suspension, was the only Mariner who was banned.

title: Humanizing Dictators of the Kitchen
description: THE touchy, temperamental chef-artiste who would as soon hurl knives as tolerate a line cook late with a sauce, is a cliche. But talk to anyone who has worked in a professional kitchen, and it becomes clear that there is truth to this particular chestnut. Stories of diva-esque chefs are as common as they are sometimes outrageous.

title: No Headline
description: ''Our missiles sent the following message to Saddam Hussein: When you abuse your own people or threaten your neighbors you must pay a price.''

title: The Squeeze on Medical Costs
description: Three years ago, when medical costs were soaring and a new President was flailing about for a solution, a prediction that the rate of increase in health-care costs could be cut to well below 10 percent annually would have been greeted with smirks. But this week came further confirmation of radical change.

title: In Defense of Brasilia and Its Neighborhoods
description: To the Editor:

title: United Technologies Deal
description: United Technologies said today that its Carrier Transicold unit had acquired Sutrak Transportkalte G.m.b.H., a closely held German manufacturer of bus and railroad air-conditioning equipment. Terms were not disclosed. Sutrak's markets are in Europe, Africa, and Asia. The deal does not include Sutrak's United States operations, which will operate independently. Carrier Transicold, based in Syracuse, is a unit of the Carrier Corporation.

title: Charles H. Kirbo, 79, Is Dead; Was Carter's Closest Adviser
description: Charles H. Kirbo, the courtly Georgia lawyer who was known as President Jimmy Carter's one-man kitchen cabinet, died on Monday at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta. Mr. Kirbo, who lived in Roswell, Ga., an Atlanta suburb, was 79.

title: Publisher Denies Deal To Sell Australian Stake
description: The Canadian media owner Conrad Black said yesterday that he still wanted to increase his 25 percent stake in an Australian newspaper publishing group, John Fairfax Holdings, and denied speculation that he was under pressure to sell it. The Australian, a daily owned by the News Corporation, reported last Friday that Mr. Black was believed to be preparing to sell his stake in Fairfax.

title: The Endless Battle, Iraq, the Kurds and the United States
description: Six years after Iraq invaded Kuwait the United States remains mired in conflict with the regime of Saddam Hussein, this time striking with cruise missiles in retribution for his army's operations in Kurdish regions in the north. For years, rebellious Kurds have fought against the Baghdad authorities and among themselves. After expelling Iraq from Kuwait in 1991, the American-led coalition came to the Kurds' aid and forbade Iraq from repressing them within a protected enclave. But as one Kurdish faction turned to Baghdad for aid against an Iranian-backed rival, Iraqi forces drove into the protected zone, triggering this week's American attack.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a tentative contract agreement between American Airlines and its pilots' union misstated the action now needed for approval. The pact requires votes of the more than 9,000 members of the pilots' union and of the union's board, not the board of the the airline's parent company, AMR.

title: Parched Texas Rejoices In Hurricane's Aftermath
description: It is nowhere near enough rain to declare this year's devastating drought to be over. But it is rain nonetheless.

title: Animation for Nickelodeon
description: Another side of MTV -- the side that brought you ''Beavis and Butt head'' -- is getting an infusion of investment. MTV Networks announced yesterday that it would spend more than $420 million over the next five years on original animation. MTV Networks, a unit of Viacom, is the parent of MTV, its music-video sister VH1 and Nickelodeon, the children's cable network, where most of the new animation will appear.

title: Battle Rages Over a 5-Letter Four-Letter Word
description: Minnesota's enactment of a law last year ordering counties to rename any natural geographic place identified by the word ''squaw'' was a victory for the state's 55,000 American Indians, many of whom had campaigned for the change.

title: Auto Workers Choose Ford As the Lead Contract Target
description: The United Automobile Workers union decided today to focus on the Ford Motor Company in national labor negotiations, while continuing talks with General Motors and Chrysler, people close to the negotiations said.

title: If Menu Says 'Healthy,' It Had Better Be
description: RESTAURANTS that want to make nutrition claims for their meals will now have to back them up.

title: Labor Talks Take Another Step Forward
description: Baseball's chief labor negotiators embarked last night on what very likely was the beginning of the end of the sport's longest labor dispute.

title: As Intimidation Persists, Doubts Grow on Bosnia Vote
description: The legitimacy of Bosnia's national elections, coming in two weeks, is being undermined by the continued intimidation of opposition parties and the ineffectual response of the international organization responsible for overseeing the vote, say foreign monitors and Western diplomats.

title: From Allies, U.S. Hears Mild Applause or Silence
description: The rest of the world, including most of America's NATO allies in Europe, made it clear today that the United States was on its own in taking military action against Iraq.

title: Metropolitian Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Forest Hills Community Welcomes Disney, Wistfully
description: Even a decade after the arrival of the Gap and Benetton on Austin Street in Queens, next to boutiques and bistros owned by locals, some old-timers in Forest Hills Gardens still refer to the short shopping strip as ''the Village.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Research Hints Vitamins D and C May Slow Down Osteoarthritis
description: ARTHRITIS sufferers have long believed, or at least hoped, that dietary changes might somehow relieve the discomfort in their creaky joints. But while many have sought relief by, for example, eliminating ''nightshade'' vegetables like tomatoes and eggplant from their diets, scientists have yet to demonstrate a connection between specific foods or nutrients and the wear-and-tear type of arthritis, called osteoarthritis, that afflicts most older people.

title: Teacher Head Gives Warning On Crowding
description: As New York City schools prepared to open today to their worst crowding in decades, the president of the teachers' union threatened yesterday to take her members out of any school where conditions posed a danger to students or staff.

title: Terrorism Trial Is to Continue, Despite a Phone Call by a Juror
description: A Federal jury resumed deliberations yesterday on whether three men plotted to bomb American jetliners in Asia, after the judge met with lawyers on both sides to discuss an unsanctioned telephone call that one juror made over the weekend to a witness for the prosecution.

title: Former Dole Aide in Futures Trading Post
description: David Spears, 39, a former aide to the Republican Presidential candidate, Bob Dole, was sworn in today as a commissioner of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Unabomber Suspect's Kin
description: CBS News's ''60 Minutes'' has taped the first television interview with the family of the suspected Unabomber, Theodore Kaczynski. His mother, Wanda; the brother who reported him to the authorities, David, and David's wife, Linda Patrik, discussed Mr. Kaczynski's past with Mike Wallace and Lesley Stahl last week in New York. No broadcast date has been set.

title: Texaco Narrows A Review
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had narrowed a review on its corporate advertising account, which has been handled by Bates USA in New York since late 1994, to five finalists. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $25 million to $30 million.

title: Hanks Signs $22.4 Million Deal
description: MERTON HANKS's new deal with the San Francisco 49ers will pay him $22.4 million over seven years, putting him among the three highest-paid defensive backs in the league. The two-time All-Pro safety's deal includes a signing bonus of $4.75 million. The only defensive backs with a high per year salary than him are DEION SANDERS (a $35 million, seven-year deal with Dallas) and AENEAS WILLIAMS (a $17 million, five-year deal with Arizona.) (AP)

title: Financial Star Is a Recruiter For His Faith
description: RONALD RASBAND stood on Fordham Road the other day, intent on closing the deal. His prospect smiled and listened as Mr. Rasband drew her into his confidence. What he was offering, he promised, would bring more than a lifetime of happiness.

title: '95 Report Saw No Malnutrition in Child's Family
description: Acting on a report that a mother was starving one of her seven children to death, a city child welfare caseworker evaluated the children last year and came to a different conclusion: ''All children observed,'' the caseworker's report said in June 1995. ''No signs of malnutrition.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO., Cleveland, sold two adhesives businesses acquired in January as part of its takeover of Pratt & Lambert United Inc. It sold Pierce & Stevens to Sovereign Specialty Chemicals Inc., Chicago, and Miracle Adhesives Corp. to TACC International Corp., Rockland, Mass., for a total of $58 million.

title: Rebels' New Cause: A Book for Yankee Bashing
description: To describe his feelings toward America, Zhang Xiaobo, 32, a poet, author and onetime pro-democracy rebel, told a reporter from a state-run press agency recently: ''I admire some things American. When we were students, we yearned for American novels and movies.''

title: Lawsuit by Travel Agents Against Airlines Is Settled
description: A lawsuit pitting travel agents against five of the nation's major airlines was settled yesterday with an agreement in principle in which airlines will pay the agents to drop the suit but will likely keep caps on commissions for ticket sales.

title: Belgian Utility's Shares Rise on Bid Report
description: Shares of Tractebel S.A. rose yesterday amid expectations that Societe Generale de Belgique S.A. is prepared to pay at least 50 billion Belgian francs ($1.63 billion) to buy a stake in the Belgian utility. Electrafina S.A., a holding company that owns 20.2 percent of Tractebel on behalf of its parent company, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert S.A., said it might sell its Tractebel holding.

title: DATAFLEX TO SELL 2 OPERATIONS TO AMERIDATA
description: The struggling Dataflex Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Eastern and Midwestern operations to Ameridata Technologies Inc. for $50 million in cash and assumed liabilities. Dataflex of Edison, N.J., a provider of computer software and services, said the two segments have combined revenue of $175 million. Earlier this year, Dataflex sold its Western regional operations, with revenue of $145 million a year, for an undisclosed amount. The company said that sale would help it to reduce its debt and expand its personal computer repair and support services business. Ameridata is a unit of the General Electric Company's GE Capital Technology Management Services division. Dataflex stock was down 25 cents at $3.875.

title: British Company Buying Swedish Bus Line
description: Stagecoach Holdings P.L.C., a major British bus and train operating company, said yesterday that it was buying Swebus of Sweden from Swedcarrier. It will pay $:115.6 million in cash and assume $:117 million in debt and interest owed by Swebus to Swedcarrier and to Statens Jarnvagar, the Swedish state rail system.

title: Ohio School Voucher Plan Is Unconstitutional
description: To the Editor:

title: Targets Were Chosen to Punish and Weaken Hussein, U.S. Officials Say
description: To punish President Saddam Hussein for his military raid into the Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq, the United States launched limited missile strikes at targets in southern Iraq hundreds of miles away to avoid the appearance of taking sides in a factional fight, Administration officials said today.

title: In Inner-City Chicago, Kemp Makes Pitch for Black Votes
description: In one of his strongest pitches yet for black votes, Jack Kemp grappled again today with his position on affirmative action, telling an inner-city audience that he had not abandoned his support for it and promising that economic revival for urban areas would be a keystone of a Dole-Kemp Administration.

title: Boatswain Has Doubt; Johnson Has Faith
description: Moments after the Jets' crushing performance in Denver, Harry Boatswain was indignant about the aura that surrounds the team he grew up rooting for in Brooklyn.

title: Mix-and-Match Cuisine in the West 20's
description: THE scent of cumin and garlic hangs in the air at the Urban Market, 117-119 West 26th Street, a homey yet highly professional new food shop that offers an unusual blend of cuisines for takeout and catering. The owner, Claudia Sidoti, is a caterer with a diverse family background: her father is Italian, her mother is Colombian and her mother-in-law is Antiguan. They all contribute to the cooking. In a neighborhood that is home to the flower market, sewing-machine repair shops and photography studios, such a mixture of cuisines feels right.

title: A Revolutionary's End: Fool or Saint?
description: It's a sad commentary on the cynical, spin-doctored age in which we live that selflessness of the sort many ascribe to the Marxist revolutionary Ernesto (Che) Guevara is not an easy concept to swallow. Wasn't the man who served as a handsome bearded poster boy for America's radical left in the late 1960's a grandiose dreamer with a martyr complex? How else could he have seriously imagined that he and a ragtag band of guerrillas might foment a peasant uprising against Bolivia's military dictatorship?

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM ACQUIRES 3 CHEMICAL PRODUCERS
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired three chemical producers in separate transactions for a total of about $146 million, including $127 million in stock. The acquired entities are Laurel Industries of La Porte, Tex., which produces a chemical used as a flame retardant in plastics; Natural Gas Odorizing of Baytown, Tex., which produces chemicals for use in natural gas and propane production, and a plant in Augusta, Ga., that produces silicates used to make soap, detergents and paper. The Georgia plant was sold by Power Solicates Manufacturing Inc. Occidental, which is based in Los Angeles, intends to increase its specialty chemicals business to $250 million in annual earnings by 2000, from $65 million now.

title: Out Magazine Executives Leave
description: The top two advertising executives of Out magazine in New York are leaving for new posts.

title: Stratton Oakmont's drama with an initial public offering.
description: CURSES! Foiled again!'' snarls the villain at the end of old movie melodramas (at least until the next installment).

title: If all goes as planned, Pan Am should be back in the air within a few weeks.
description: THE new Pan Am, an airline with a past, should be back in business in a few weeks. ''We've tentatively found them fit to fly,'' said William Mosley, a spokesman for the Department of Transportation, which overruled objections of two organizations that represent relatives of victims of the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. And this week the airline is completing safety-oriented ''proving flights'' required by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Chechnya Toll Is Far Higher, 80,000 Dead, Lebed Asserts
description: In the grimmest assessment to date of the toll in Chechnya, Aleksandr I. Lebed said today that about 80,000 people had been killed in the fighting and that some 240,000 had been wounded.

title: Team That's 0-58 May Have Broken Rules
description: Prairie View A&M, which has lost a record 58 games in a row, suspended its head football coach and athletic director, HENSLEY SAPENTER, and started an investigation into possible infractions of National Collegiate Athletic Association and Southwestern Athletic Conference rules. The university said in a statement yesterday that the allegations involve the use of ineligible players in Saturday's 42-24 season-opening loss to Texas Southern. ''This statement is all we are going to have to say on this matter for now,'' said LARRY RAAB, special assistant to Prairie View's president, CHARLES A. HINES. Sapenter, who is in his second year of trying to review the athletic program, was suspended with pay. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Aug. 15 about home care insurance policies for the elderly misstated the headquarters location for the First Unum Life Insurance Company. It is Portland, Me., not Oregon.

title: Weak Data Help Bonds To Recover
description: Prices of Treasury securities bounced up from morning lows yesterday as investor concern lessened that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates to slow an economy that may be growing too rapidly.

title: Erskine Childers, 68, Former U.N. Official
description: Erskine Childers, a long-serving United Nations official who devoted the last years of his life to promoting reform of the organization, died in Luxembourg on Aug. 25 soon after delivering a speech to the World Federation of United Nations Organizations. He was 68.

title: Defections Cloud Music School's Debut
description: Thirty musically gifted kindergarten and first-grade children in New York City, chosen from scores of applicants after testing and auditions, have looked forward to a school year with rigorous instruction in the Russian tradition. But some last-minute changes in instructors have clouded the first day of class.

title: So Is It to Be Tchaikovsky Or Is It to Be Chopsticks?
description: Thirty musically gifted children in New York City have looked forward all summer to a school year with rigorous instruction in the Russian tradition, one that has nurtured prodigies and let them flower into immortals.

title: Letterman: No Interruptions
description: Is David Letterman really going to do a show without commercials?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the merger of Chase Manhattan and Chemical Bank omitted the full name and affiliation of a company official who was quoted commenting on money order fees. He is John J. Stack, managing director of direct financial services at Chase Manhattan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There was good news yesterday about MOTHER TERESA, the Nobel Prize-winning missionary who has been hospitalized for two weeks with malaria,pneumonia and heart problems. Her health has been improving steadily for about a week, and she has begun pressuring her physicians in Calcutta to let her return to her religious order, the Sisters of the Missionaries of Charity, Reuters reported yesterday.

title: Zenith's U.S. Unit Says Chief Has Gone
description: Zenith Media Worldwide, the media-services unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York, said yesterday that William J. Grimes, president and chief executive of United States operations, had left with the expiration of his two-year contract.

title: Dole Says Nation Declined As Clinton Forsook Values
description: With an American Legion service cap on his head, Bob Dole today scorned anyone who thought family, God, honor and country were ''relics of the past,'' and warned that abandonment of those values had contributed to the nation's decline under President Clinton.

title: Coetzer No Match For Seles
description: Monica Seles said that, unlike other players, she looks forward to playing tennis after dark. That may be. But Seles did not waste any time blasting her way off Stadium Court last night.

title: Flight 800 Investigators Hoping Storm Didn't Shift Evidence
description: With waves subsiding after Long Island's brush with Hurricane Edouard, two Navy ships returned yesterday to the crash site of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 and prepared to send divers down to find out if the storm scattered the wreckage.

title: Jefferson Smurfit Profit Off 37% in Paper Slump
description: The Jefferson Smurfit Group, the Irish paper and packaging company, said yesterday that its first-half pretax profit slumped 37 percent as global paper prices fell and the industry suffered from overcapacity. Pretax profit fell to 126 million Irish pounds ($204 million) from 201 million a year earlier. Sales fell 12 percent, to 1.35 billion, reflecting lower paper prices and volumes.

title: Don't Limit Debates To Clinton and Dole
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES RIVER AND CROWN VANTAGE SETTLE FEDERAL CASE
description: The James River Corporation and Crown Vantage Inc. have settled a Federal case involving air and water pollution violations at a New Hampshire paper mill, the Government said yesterday. The agreement calls for payment of a $200,000 fine, as well as an assessment of current antipollution procedures and operations, the Government said. The Environmental Protection Agency also said James River had spent $466,000 to reduce air pollution resulting from the release of sulfuric compounds at the mill to levels below those required by Federal law. James River, which is based in Richmond, sold the plant to Crown Vantage, of Oakland, Calif., last year. The Government said James River had failed to act on a 1993 sulfuric acid spill in the Androscoggin River. Acid from the spill interfered with a wastewater plant at Berlin, N.H., and as a result, the city exceeded limits set in its wastewater discharge permit, the Justice Department said.

title: Even Amid Abundance, Edinburgh Looks Back Instead of Forward
description: Anyone attending the final days of this year's Edinburgh International Festival could not help noticing how established stage directors seemed to feel safer turning to the past, even when they wanted to say something new about the future. So have successful contemporary playwrights and composers become an endangered species?

title: Choices Reshaping Schools Landscape
description: As American children return to school this fall, politically volatile programs are changing education in many areas, allowing parents to choose or even shape schools.

title: A World Cup the United States Just Might Win
description: If it is possible to seem both happy and forlorn at the same time, this was Jeremy Roenick's appearance as he walked the back corridors of Madison Square Garden.

title: Don't Limit Debates To Clinton and Dole
description: To the Editor:

title: Civil War Enemies, Drawn to Each Other
