description: Chris Cooper, so powerful as the troubled and thoughtful sheriff in John Sayles's ''Lone Star,'' is just as compelling in a role that sends him back more than a century in time. In ''Pharaoh's Army,'' set in Kentucky in 1862, he is a Union Army captain, once an ordinary farmer, now trying to remain human and moral in the middle of war. This small-scale story of an encounter between Capt. John Abston and a Confederate farm woman, Sarah Anders, offers a smart, intimate glimpse at the personal confusion of sworn enemies.

title: Airbus Says New Orders Have Helped Triple Its Business in a Year
description: Airbus Industrie said today that it had won $3 billion in new jetliner orders, bringing its plane orders for the year to $17 billion, triple the figure for all of 1995.

title: Labor Day Auto Deaths Rise
description: Nineteen people died in automobile accidents in New Jersey over the Labor Day weekend, up from six last year, the state police said yesterday. Part of the rise may be attributed to a change in the tracking system: the holiday weekend officially began at 12:01 A.M. Friday instead of 6 P.M., and six of the deaths occurred before 6 P.M. Three of the accidents were determined to be alcohol-related, while six were still being investigated, said Sgt. Daniel Cosgrove, a police spokesman.

title: 'Portable' Insurance?
description: Signed with great fanfare last month by President Clinton, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act is supposed to be a big step in health reform. And the people it purports to help the most are the millions like me who have a pre-existing condition.

title: Edberg and Sampras Play On at the Open
description: He isn't the grand old man of this Grand Slam quite yet, but unseeded Stefan Edberg, the two-time Open champion who is using this United States Open as his definitive Slam swan song, continued to cut an elegant swath through the competition.

title: Case May Fit Pattern of Singling Out a Child
description: As investigators examined the tortured family history of Nadine Lockwood yesterday, child welfare experts said her death appeared to conform to a pattern seen in extreme cases of abuse: one child is singled out among several siblings as the focus of an abusive parent's irrational rage.

title: Seldon to Rely on His Athleticism
description: In the elemental world of boxing, it is easy to think of Bruce Seldon as the anti-Tyson.

title: Peru Is Considering Transfer Of Imprisoned New Yorker
description: The government of Peru has said it will consider a proposal by a United States Congressman that would allow Lori Helene Berenson, a New York woman who has been serving a life sentence in Peru for treason, to be transferred to the United States, Peruvian and American officials said yesterday.

title: Not Only Laborers Suffer Wage Disparity
description: To the Editor:

title: George B. Roberts, 102, Director Of Citibank Economics Division
description: George B. Roberts, a retired vice president of Citibank and a longtime editor of its influential newsletter, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 102.

title: Giant Book Emporium Enters New York Fray
description: The super-scale bookstore, like the corner deli, is largely a New York invention. Barnes & Noble, which grew up in the city, helped establish the idea that books should be purchased by the cartload, and took that notion to middle America in the 1970's, becoming in the process the nation's largest bookselling chain.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about a plan by the Digital Equipment Corporation to spin off Altavista Internet Software Inc., referred incorrectly in some editions to a one-time charge taken by Digital in July. The amount was $492 million, not $492 billion.

title: Building on successful work for Volkswagen, a Boston agency tries to establish a national profile.
description: SOME hear ''Arnold'' and think muscle-bound movie star. Some conjure up images of the Revolutionary War. Others even smell bread. But can the Arnold name also be inextricably linked with advertising?

title: TRACOR IN $65 MILLION DEAL FOR CORDANT
description: Tracor Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire closely held Cordant Inc., a developer and provider of information technology services, for $65 million in cash. Cordant, which is based in Reston, Va., provides information systems for use in medical data bases, personnel, national intelligence, mail processing, public access, records management and computer-aided design. The combined annual sales for the new business are expected to be more than $200 million in 1996, Tracor, which is based in Austin, Tex., said.

title: Arrest in Tollbooth Robbery
description: An Irvington man was arrested early yesterday and charged with robbing a tollbooth on the Garden State Parkway. According to the state police, the man, Frank Smith, 32, pulled his car over to the shoulder at the Raritan South toll plaza in Sayreville late Monday, forced his way into a tollbooth, shoved the toll collector aside and took an undisclosed amount of money.

title: Hampton Shelves Retirement Plan
description: Rodney Hampton has many admirable qualities as a football player, besides his legs of steel, heart of iron and flawless work ethic. Another is his desire not to be a distraction to the team. It was that impulse that kept one of the more amazing stories of last year from becoming public.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Where Art, Unrest And Guts All Thrive
description: The Watts district of Los Angeles has come to symbolize urban unrest, artistic vision and grass-roots determination. All three aspects of the community were evoked on Sunday afternoon when the Lula Washington Dance Theater performed in the open air on a platform near the fountain in Lincoln Center Plaza.

title: A Premiere (Cut Short) And a Bit Of History
description: Most of the major figures in black postwar Los Angeles jazz came from two high schools, Jefferson and Jordan. Without much further thought, there lies context for a historical tribute.

title: Focus at Lab Groundbreaking Is Biotech Research, and Jobs
description: The State University at Stony Brook broke ground today on a $40 million biotechnology research and teaching center, the first new academic building on the campus in two decades.

title: Not Only Laborers Suffer Wage Disparity
description: To the Editor:

title: Kobe Bryant Breaks His Wrist
description: KOBE BRYANT, who is making the jump from high school to the National Basketball Association, has a fractured left wrist that will sideline him a minimum of six weeks, the Los Angeles Lakers said yesterday. Bryant, 18, who is right-handed, fractured his wrist while playing in a pickup game Monday, the Lakers said. The Lakers open training camp Oct. 4 in Honolulu. (AP)

title: Personal Health
description: MEN may be justified, though incorrect, in thinking that they are invulnerable to osteoporosis. This bone-wasting disease occurs slowly and silently and has been labeled ''a woman's disease'' because women are far more vulnerable to it and the fractures it causes. Half of all women develop it, and one woman in two over the age of 65 suffers one or more bone fractures because of it.

title: The Serious Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Slaying Puts Top Soldier In Canada On the Spot
description: In Canadian military jargon they are called R.T.Q.'s, or responses to queries -- the briefing notes used by military public affairs officers in response to queries from journalists.

title: A Choice of Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: S.& P. Upgrades Mexican Bonds
description: In spite of a wave of attacks last week by a guerrilla group, the Standard & Poor's Corporation upgraded its outlook on $63 billion in Mexican Government bonds today to stable from negative.

title: Mayor Shifts Blame for Abuse to Families
description: Having assumed responsibility for the city's child welfare system after overhauling it earlier this year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani tried to deflect some of that burden yesterday when faced with yet another death of a child apparently at the hands of her mother.

title: When TV Is an Unwelcome Guest
description: Enthusiast though I am of television in courtrooms (and at most other official activities), I cannot get exercised over the decision of Judge Hiroshi Fujisaki, a Superior Court judge in Santa Monica, Calif., to bar cameras from O. J. Simpson's civil trial, which begins this month. If press and television, defense lawyers and prosecutors and even the judge in the famous murder trial set out to prove they cannot resist temptation, they succeeded sensationally.

title: MAGNA TO BUY HOMELAND BANKSHARES FOR $216 MILLION
description: Magna Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Homeland Bankshares Corporation, the second-largest bank based in Iowa, for $216 million in stock and cash. Homeland, with $1.2 billion in assets, owns four commercial banks and one savings bank, operating a total of 33 branches in Iowa. Magna expects $8 million in savings by consolidating the combined company's bank charters and its back-office operations. Magna, based in St. Louis, agreed to issue 5.04 million shares of common stock and to pay $92 million in cash to acquire Homeland. Each Homeland share would be swapped for 1.55 Magna shares or the equivalent in cash. Magna's shares fell 6.25 cents, to $24.8125, in Nasdaq trading, while Homeland rose $1.75, to $35.75.

title: Not Only Laborers Suffer Wage Disparity
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Sweatshop' Again Tied To Celebrity
description: Four Brooklyn garment factories, including one that produced clothing for a line that Kmart sells under the Kathy Ireland label, have been raided by law enforcement officials, and their owners and managers have been arrested for operating sweatshops, the Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Nebraska Needs to Find A New System of Justice
description: The calendar said it was August, but everywhere you looked last weekend, a new season was already attracting the attention of your senses. The first burgers on the grill. The first appearance of high-stepping bands. The first Nebraska arrest. Can brightly colored leaves be far behind?

title: AIDS Drugs Made Available
description: A group of drugs shown to have prolonged the lives of some people with AIDS will be available free starting Oct. 1 to some 1,700 New Jerseyans who earn less than $30,000 a year, Len Fishman, the State Health Commissioner, said yesterday.

title: Transit Passes Are Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A diagram caption in Science Times yesterday about the use of drugs to control therapeutic genes misidentified the outer layer of a human cell. It is a membrane, not a cell wall.

title: Grand Themes, Modest Proposals: A Clinton Mix
description: BETWEEN HOPE AND HISTORY

title: Steinbrenner Plays the Fan
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, became George Steinbrenner the Yankee fan as David Cone amazingly spun a no-hitter for seven innings against the A's on Monday. But Steinbrenner did not screech at the television set when Manager Joe Torre removed Cone with his no-hitter intact in the 5-0 victory.

title: Herbs and Produce Replace Quilts
description: Since Sandi Cote and Bobbi Whitacre opened their hilltop Village Green Grocer in Manchester, Vt., four years ago, it has become a gourmet's haven in a land of the stubborn Yankee tastebuds.

title: Britain Sells Shares In 3 Power Companies
description: The British Treasury said yesterday that it had sold almost all of its remaining shares in National Power P.L.C., Powergen P.L.C. and Southern Electric P.L.C. as part of a plan to raise $:1 billion ($1.56 billion). The Government said it had sold 28.47 million shares of National Power, or 2.4 percent of the company; 17.13 million shares of Powergen, or 2.5 percent of the company, and 856,928 shares of Southern Electric, or four-tenths of 1 percent. At current prices, the shares were worth $:203 million. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: A View From Teheran
description: You couldn't possibly see or hear the U.S. cruise missiles smashing into Iraq from here in downtown Teheran, but you sure could feel the political fallout raining down on the region.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: De Benedetti Steps Downs As Olivetti Posts Big Loss

title: Last Days of Summer Are the Time of the Crab
description: EATING crab is like playing badminton: it can be a matter of some refinement or a boisterous, rowdy and altogether convivial affair. This comes about because while crab meat has a rich, sweet, almost ethereal flavor, extracting it is a messy business best enjoyed when you are in the mood for getting down and definitely dirty.

title: Federated to Buy 6 Mutual Funds
description: Federated Investors said today that it had agreed to buy the assets of six State Bond mutual funds from ARM Financial Group Inc. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Trelleborg of Sweden Seeks Rubber Company
description: Trelleborg A.B., a Swedish mining, metals and rubber products company, said yesterday that it wanted to buy the rubber products company Horda A.B. for 276 million kronor ($41.8 million).

title: In Charleston, S.C., Saks Fifth Avenue is the latest to open in the historic district.
description: SAKS FIFTH AVENUE has opened a store in the historic district of this port city, a development that advances the recent arrival of major retailers in downtown Charleston.

title: Big Mall's Curfew Raises Questions Of Rights and Bias
description: Marcus D. Wilson, 18, has been coming to the Mall of America here once or twice a week since it opened four years ago. He buys tapes, plays video games and sees his friends, especially his girlfriend.

title: Lamoriello's Two Teams
description: Lou Lamoriello, president and general manager of the Devils, has had another team on his mind all summer: America's team.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Gov. WILLIAM F. WELD of Massachusetts yesterday nominated MARGARET H. MARSHALL, 52, the general counsel of Harvard University and a native of South Africa who was a leader in the student anti-apartheid movement there, as an associate justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Court.

title: Bomb Suspect's Lawyers Seek to Unseal Affidavits on Searches
description: Lawyers for Richard A. Jewell, the security guard being investigated in the July 27 bombing at Centennial Olympic Park, filed court papers today asking a Federal magistrate to unseal any affadivits that were used to justify a series of searches of Mr. Jewell's property.

title: School Girds for New Regents Test Standards
description: Larry Gutman, a teacher of remedial math, grew increasingly impatient during his first faculty meeting of the school year yesterday as he listened to a description of the stiffer testing standards the State Board of Regents handed down to all public high schools late last spring.

title: At a Mexican Festival, 'La Bamba' and Beyond
description: For eight and a half hours on Monday, Mexican music and dance took over Lincoln Center Out of Doors. Three groups played ''La Bamba''; two led sing-alongs on ''Cielito Lindo.'' But there was ample variety in a program that included traditional, modernized and contemporary performances.

title: Iraq Fills A Power Vacuum
description: There was nothing unforeseen or unavoidable about the current crisis in northern Iraq. Saddam Hussein has long been contemplating a military move against the semi-autonomous Kurdish enclave set up after the gulf war. But over the past two years, the Clinton Administration has ignored the danger signs and allowed a dispute between rival Kurds to cloud the issue of long-term strategic American interests. Worse, Washington's hesitation has seriously damaged the credibility of American defense in the gulf.

title: Zapatistas Rebuff Mexican President and Criticize Other Rebels
description: The Zapatista guerrillas broke off peace talks with the Government late Monday, rebuffing President Ernesto Zedillo as he confronts a separate armed leftist group that burst on the scene with wide-ranging attacks last week.

title: It's Mr. Pepsi's Team Now
description: Now that SHAQUILLE O'NEAL has joined the Los Angeles Lakers, the Coca-Cola Company has opted not to renew its sponsorship of the Lakers and Los Angeles Kings. That's because O'Neal is a major Pepsi-Cola spokesman. ''It makes no sense for Coca-Cola to sponsor a team whose marquee player endorses the competition,'' the Coca-Cola spokesman STEVE KOONIN said. (AP)

title: South Korea to Focus on Account Deficit
description: The South Korean Government will focus on checking inflation and stimulating corporate activity this year as it tries to reduce a growing current-account deficit, the nation's top economic official said today.

title: MTV Counters a Trend
description: For the world of rock music, it doesn't matter at all that the MTV Music Video Awards draw far fewer viewers than almost every other major awards show. The show invariably brings together more of the hottest acts in music than any other annual event.

title: Game, Not Cattle, On Texas Ranch
description: In 1982, Mike Hughes retired from corporate life and moved with his family to a ranch in the Texas Hill Country, a rugged region west of Austin, because they appreciated the beauty of the land. Not too long after settling in, he saw a business opportunity on his property, the Broken Arrow, and surrounding ranches.

title: A Matter of Two Princetons
description: A commission recommended this year that the borough and township of Princeton be merged, but the question may not appear on the November ballot since no one filed the measure with the Mercer County clerk. According to Catherine DiCostanzo, the clerk, the filing deadline for ballot questions was Aug. 23. But clerks for the borough and township say that they have until 60 days before the election, or Sept. 6, and yesterday they asked the Superior Court to compel Ms. DiCostanzo to put the measure on the ballot, said Michael Herbert, a lawyer for the borough.

title: District Weighs Video's Mention of Evolution
description: For at least 10 years, ''The Miracle of Life'' video was a staple in the sophomore science classes at Wheat Ridge High School. But in May, the showing of the film about human reproduction ran into opposition when a student complained about its reference to evolution.

title: Senate Candidates Set Off With a Little Image Work
description: Richard A. Zimmer and Robert G. Torricelli kicked off their fall campaigns for the United States Senate today by trying to reach voters through the well-known images of others.

title: State Reports Budget Surplus of $250 Million in Hartford
description: Connecticut finished the state's fiscal year on June 30 with its largest budget surplus in nine years -- $250 million -- benefiting from a windfall in income tax revenue, State Comptroller Nancy Wyman announced today.

title: Corrections
description: Automobile travel directions in Weekend on Friday with an article in about Newport, R.I., misidentified a bridge. From Manhattan, take I-95 North to the exit for Route 138 East, near Wyoming, R.I., then follow the signs to the Jamestown and Newport Bridges (not to the Newport/St. James Bridge).

title: 'History's Losers' Fight Neighbors and Each Other, Often Assisted by Foes
description: Few peoples on earth have tasted as much defeat and betrayal as the Kurds. Although they are 20 million strong and have lived in the same swath of mountainous land for 2,000 years, they have no true friends and an imposing array of enemies.

title: State Senate Primaries
description: Only a few of New York City's State Senate districts are holding primaries next Tuesday. Here are our endorsements in some of the more competitive contests.

title: New Choices for Parents Are Starting To Change U.S. Education Landscape
description: As 51 million students return to their classrooms this fall, American education is being reshaped by politically volatile programs allowing parents to choose their children's schools and sometimes even to create them.

title: Food Notes
description: Fancy-Food Grocery

title: Dole Is Facing a Tough Sell In a Suburb of Swing Voters
description: If the 1996 Presidential election is to be fought out in bedroom communities like this home to endless subdivisions -- and some of the most independent-minded voters in America -- there is worrisome news for Bob Dole.

title: Japan May Postpone Consumption-Tax Rise
description: The Japanese Government may postpone for one year the increase in the consumption tax that is scheduled for next April, the Finance Minister, Wataru Kubo, said yesterday. Mr. Kubo said any delay in raising the tax to 5 percent from 3 percent would be part of an economic-stimulus package that could amount to as much as 10 trillion yen ($91.7 billion).

title: The Assembly Primaries
description: New York City sends more than 60 legislators to the State Assembly, but most do not face difficult races this November, and only a few will be opposed in next Tuesday's primaries. Here are the more serious contests.

title: Smart Phones: The Highest I.Q.'s Yet
description: WHILE pundits are busy predicting that the television will transform itself into a computer, telephones have quietly added so many features that they have almost done so already.

title: Stadium Plan Is Delayed
description: Plans to build a $22 million minor league baseball stadium in Newark's Ironbound section have been delayed after environmental tests on the site revealed possible contamination.

title: New York Re-enters the Sitcom Universe, Wryly
description: Los Angeles remains unchallenged as the center of television's prime-time universe, but this year New York has taken a higher profile than usual because two of the most talked-about new sitcoms are being taped here: CBS's ''Cosby,'' starring Bill Cosby, and ABC's ''Spin City,'' starring Michael J. Fox.

title: Melanie Totenberg, 79, Violinist's Wife and Manager
description: Melanie Shroder Totenberg, who acted as business manager for her husband, the violinist Roman Totenberg, for five decades, died on Sunday at her summer home in Blue Hill, Maine. She was 79 and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: Not Corporate Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OMNICARE INC., Cincinnati, acquired the long-term-care pharmacy business of Revco D.S. Inc., Twinsburg, Ohio. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Calendar: Art Tours And Crafts
description: Inside Artists' Studios

title: Scientist Explains T.W.A. Uncertainty
description: An expert in the chemistry of explosives at the University of Rhode Island has completed an experiment that could help explain the tentative, almost teasing, results of tests for explosives residue on wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Hughes Is Said To Be Nearing An Agreement For Panamsat
description: Hughes Electronics is in the final stages of negotiations to acquire Panamsat in a deal worth nearly $3 billion that would create the world's second-largest satellite company, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: Bill MacPhail, 76, Pioneer In Development of TV Sports
description: Bill MacPhail, a self-effacing sports television executive who hired Pat Summerall, Jack Whitaker, Frank Gifford and Jim McKay for CBS and created the CNN sports department, died yesterday. He was 76.

title: Top-Level Changes At Cole & Weber
description: Cole & Weber, a unit of the WPP Group, is making a series of top management changes.

title: Is Dick Morris Right?
description: Whenever I watch the ritual of the sultry blonde, the shamed pol and the betrayed-but-loyal wife, I secretly wish that just once, poor Lee, poor Hillary or poor Eileen would step up to the bouquet of microphones and let loose: ''I'd like to tie that pathetic loser to a stake in the boiling sun and pour honey on his face and let red ants eat his eyes out.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: How To Stop Abuse
description: After the emaciated body of 4-year-old Nadine Lockwood was found in a locked bedroom in Washington Heights on Saturday night and her mother charged with murder, city officials confirmed that the family was already ''known'' to the city's Administration for Children's Services. Nicholas Scoppetta, the new commissioner of the department, formerly the Child Welfare Agency, assured the public that caseworkers who ignore or neglect to follow up on signs of child abuse ''will be held accountable for their failures.''

title: Thousands Flee Homes in Carolinas as Hurricane Nears
description: Hundreds of thousands of people fled South Carolina's low country today as Hurricane Fran moved toward the coast with 115-mile-per-hour winds and carrying giant tides.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Bridge
description: The state of Florida seems to have an irresistible attraction for experts who have learned the game in the New York metropolitan area, and a match between New York and New Yorkers in Florida would probably be won by the transplants. They could draw on Michael Becker, a recent arrival; Drew Casen, Bernard Chazen, Bill Eisenberg, Bobby Levin, Bill Passell, Richard Reisig, Ron Rubin, Bill Root, Neil Silverman and David Strasberg.

title: Bond Prices Down Before Job Report
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday, erasing much of Tuesday's gains as the market turned its focus to this week's labor statistics. Investors are waiting to see if the data will confirm suspicions about the strength of the economy.

title: Weary Blues: A Tired Gooden Struggles
description: Dwight Gooden strained and struggled to locate the strike zone against the Athletics Tuesday night and then Manager Joe Torre strained and struggled to describe the pitcher's fragile status as more glowing than gloomy.

title: Giants Prepared To Pounce On Dallas
description: When the Giants were watching film of Deion Sanders playing wide receiver against the Chicago Bears on Monday night, they noticed something interesting. As the game wore on, Sanders began taking plays off, even though he was in the game. If the play went to him or his side, he ran full speed. If it went away from his side, he ran half-speed and didn't try to block downfield. Sometimes he even walked or jogged off the line of scrimmage.

title: All-Girls School Opens To Muffins and Media
description: New York City opened its first single-sex public school in a decade yesterday, and the 50 girls in the pioneering seventh-grade class spent their day sipping tea and nibbling croissants with the school's philanthropic founders, having their portraits snapped by a society photographer, venturing into Central Park for a walk and fielding questions from a horde of reporters.

title: Dreyfus Seeking Entry-Level Fund Buyer
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, in an aggressive effort to attract the mutual fund investors it all but ignored during one of the great bull markets, plans to introduce a low-cost financial planning service this fall to offer investment advice to fund customers with as little as $10,000 in assets.

title: Looking Back 11 Billion Light-Years, a Glimpse at Galaxy Birth
description: Focusing for 24 hours on a single patch of sky, the Hubble Space Telescope has taken pictures of clumps of dense star clusters 11 billion light-years away, some 85 percent of the way back to the beginning of time. Astronomers think these distant clusters are the ''building blocks'' of galaxies and thus a first glimpse into the mystery of how galaxies formed early in the universe.

title: Dole Camp Breaks the Mold, Trying an Ad That Will Last a Full Five Minutes
description: In a stark departure from the conventional fare of 30-second political advertisements, the Dole campaign will reintroduce its candidate to the public in a five-minute network commercial on Thursday night.

title: U.N. Teams Investigating Iraq Are Ordered to Stay in Baghdad
description: As a result of the extension of a no-flight zone near Baghdad by the United States and Iraqi threats to shoot at American planes, the head of the commission responsible for eliminating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction has grounded inspectors' aircraft and called off trips by investigators outside the Baghdad area.

title: Executive Changes
description: BOEING CO., Seattle, said Frank Shrontz would step down as chairman at the end of this year, completing the company's transition to the leadership of its chief executive and president, Phil Condit.

title: Graf's Impulsive Smile Is Ruined by Reality
description: It was caught on film, so it must be true: Steffi Graf smiled yesterday.

title: 3Com Selects Poppe Tyson
description: The 3Com Corporation in Santa Clara, Calif., which markets computer networking products, said yesterday that it had named Poppe Tyson Silicon Valley in Mountain View, Calif., to handle its account, which had been handled for six years by the Anderson & Lembke unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million. Poppe Tyson, which is a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, was awarded the account after a two-month review that had been narrowed to that agency and one other finalist, Woolward & Partners in San Francisco.

title: In a Subway, An Immigrant And a Lesson
description: IT'S no fun coming back to work after Labor Day. No fun at all. It rarely is, and if you are in the news business, it has been downright depressing this year.

title: Team Owners Delay Meeting
description: The efforts to resolve baseball's long-running labor dispute took another turn yesterday -- perhaps for the better.

title: First-Half Net Income Plunged at Wharf
description: Wharf Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that its six-month net income fell almost 57 percent, compared with earnings in the corresponding period last year that had been inflated by the sale of a Singapore unit. The decline masked a 37 percent rise in operating profit that was driven by the Hong Kong conglomerate's port and property divisions. Wharf's cable-television unit continued to lose money.

title: Girl Is Held in Son's Abuse
description: A teen-ager who left her 17-month-old son tied to a park bench with shoelaces was arrested early yesterday and charged with child abuse, the police said. The infant's grandfather notified the police after his daughter, 17, returned home at 3 A.M. without her son, said Detective Andrew Murray of the Paterson police.

title: Vote Means New Stadium for Buccaneers
description: The biggest victory in Tampa Bay Buccaneers history didn't come on the field.

title: State Senate Race Opens Rift Within New York City G.O.P.
description: In New York City, where more than four-fifths of registered voters are Democrats, skirmishes among Republicans are rare. But a race for State Senate in parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island is serving as a vivid example of how deep the fissures can become when Republicans do battle.

title: Clinton Finds Little Support At the U.N. for Iraqi Strikes
description: Six years ago this fall, following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, a powerful coalition was painstakingly assembled here that ultimately gave the Bush Administration's war against Saddam Hussein not only the cover of the United Nations but also the backing of many of the world's major countries.

title: Dole Gained Reputation in Senate As a Master of Special Tax Breaks
description: In promoting his plan to cut taxes and balance the Federal budget, Bob Dole has called in recent days for creating a fairer tax system and closing the special-interest loopholes that riddle the tax code and save wealthy businesses billions of dollars each year.

title: For TV, or Even Popcorn
description: IS it art -- or gizmo overkill? In October, RCA will introduce a $59 remote control (right) that can operate televisions and VCR's by an infrared beam and also control lights and appliances through a 310 megahertz radio signal. With the Home Control Kit, you can flip channels or pop corn all without leaving the couch. (A separate $12.95 key-ring unit, at left, can turn on lights from outdoors.) The remote control, which glows pale blue to be visible in the dark, is pure sculpture. But accessory items (like plug-in receiver units for table lamps and appliances, and special wall switches) cost extra, and could bring the total to $300. And you may need to negotiate with neighbors to use a different frequency to avoid triggering their popcorn poppers or bedside lamps.

title: Jews in Odessa Rediscover Their Heritage Through Yiddish
description: Each week, 40 elderly members of the Lovers of Yiddish Club gather here in a building that once housed a K.G.B. listening post and do what they were unable to do during the long years of Soviet rule -- sit in a circle and chat openly about their Jewish heritage.

title: Furniture That Catches Up as Children Grow
description: MOST furniture for very young children is outgrown as quickly as a pair of booties. So Warda Geismar, 43, and Ken Kane, 32, designers who are also parents of Sophie, 14 months, invented a collection of plywood furniture called Leap Frog, intended as hand-me-ups.

title: Opening Pleasantries At All-Girls School
description: New York City opened its first single-sex public school in a decade yesterday, and it was a day for the 50 girls in the pioneering seventh-grade class to get to know their new surroundings: the top three floors of a commercial building on East 106th Street in East Harlem. The girls spent the day sipping tea and nibbling croissants with the school's philanthropic founders, having their portraits snapped by a society photographer and fielding questions from a horde of reporters.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: G.M. Says Its Vehicle Sales Slipped 7.9% in August
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that its sales last month dropped 7.9 percent from the strong levels of a year ago, partly because of weak demand for large sedans and luxury cars, and partly because dealers did not have an adequate supply of trucks to sell.

title: German Unification Is More Than Fiscal
description: To the Editor:

title: Campbell's Earnings Climb And Shares Rise on Rumors
description: The Campbell Soup Company reported strong fourth-quarter earnings yesterday as its shares rose on speculation that the company would make a restructuring announcement today.

title: Starving a Child to Death
description: Nine months ago the Giuliani administration embarked on an ambitious plan for restructuring New York City's child welfare agency, which has often failed to remove children from abusive homes, resulting in a series of horrific and highly publicized deaths. Now comes the case of 4-year-old Nadine Lockwood, who died last weekend after being starved by her mother. The heartbreaking case predates the city's child welfare overhaul, but it underscores how urgently reform is needed.

title: Insanity Defense Doubtful in 'Zodiac' Case
description: A lawyer for the Brooklyn man charged with killing three people and wounding five others in the so-called Zodiac attacks said yesterday that a psychologist had found some degree of current mental illness but had not concluded it was severe enough at the time of the attacks to support an insanity defense.

title: McEwen Sues Rams' Phillips
description: A civil lawsuit filed by KATE McEWEN, a former girlfriend of LAWRENCE PHILLIPS, accuses the St. Louis Rams' rookie running back of beating, threatening and sexually assaulting her during a two-year relationship at the University of Nebraska.

title: A Friend in Need
description: A leader of the Kurdish faction supported by Iraq insisted that the alliance was no more than a temporary, tactical partnership. Page A11.

title: Circle in the Square Appoints A Leader to Take a New Tack
description: Officials of Circle in the Square, the venerable New York subscription theater that declared bankruptcy last month, announced yesterday that Gregory Mosher, the former artistic director of Lincoln Center Theater, had been hired as head of the troubled institution.

title: Islanders Trade Severyn to Colorado
description: The Islanders yesterday traded defenseman BRENT SEVERYN to Colorado for the Avalanche's third-round selection in the 1997 National Hockey League entry draft. Severyn, who was acquired from the Florida Panthers in March 1995, played in 84 games for the Islanders, scoring 2 goals and 11 assists for 13 points.

title: The Economy Grows With Government's Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Patient Is Found Hanged
description: The body of a Clifton man who had been reported missing at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital Monday night was found hanging from a tree yesterday afternoon in a wooded area on the hospital grounds, officials said. The patient, James Williams, 35, took his own life, said John McKeegan, a spokesman for the State Department of Human Services.

title: The Pop Life
description: Where the Scouts Plan to Go

title: Nascar Releases Schedule Early
description: For the last several years, the Nascar Winston Cup schedule for the next season wasn't released until early December, although anyone could have figured it out from the ticket brochures of participating tracks, which knew they could count on the same race weekend from year to year.

title: Bowing to Strategists, Kemp Keeps Campaign in Low Gear
description: In a typical day on the stump for the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, Jack Kemp spent today raising money in private, preaching his economic message to friendly crowds in public and trying to steer clear of anything that would put him within reach of controversy.

title: A Failed Race Against Time: U.S. Tried to Head Off Iraqis
description: Last Friday, as Saddam Hussein sent tens of thousands of troops toward the protected Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq, American diplomats raced to the United States Embassy in London in a last-ditch attempt to save the fractured Kurdish alliance that has been a bulwark of United States policy in the region.

title: CLINTON, CLAIMING SUCCESS, ASSERTS MOST IRAQI TROOPS HAVE LEFT KURDS' ENCLAVE
description: After two American missile strikes, Iraq pulled back most of its troops from a contested Kurdish enclave today, and United States-led air patrols met only token resistance enforcing a newly expanded prohibition on Iraqi military flights, President Clinton said.

title: Knicks Keep Williams; Kittles Signs With Nets
description: The Knicks have re-signed the veteran center/forward Herb Williams and the Nets have completed the formality of signing the rookie Kerry Kittles. The terms of Williams's contract were not disclosed. Kittles's deal is for three years and is believed to be worth $4.6 million.

title: Perot Sees Politics as Motivating Clinton's Raid on Iraq
description: Ross Perot bluntly refused today to rally behind President Clinton's air raids on Iraq, saying, ''War is not a place for politicians to create a positive image and get a bump in the polls.''

title: Accounts
description: Elida Faberge, London, a unit of Unilever P.L.C., to Bartle Bogle Hegarty, London, to handle three brands -- Pears soap, Salon Selectives hair-care products and Lynx skin systems -- with combined billings estimated at $9.4 million.

title: Clinton to Name Health-Care Panel, With Eye to Second Term
description: President Clinton will soon appoint a Federal advisory commission to recommend ways of protecting consumers against changes in the health care industry that threaten the quality of care, Administration officials said today.

title: Snubs for the Sagging
description: To The Home Section:

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: Albee and Lemmon to Receive Kennedy Center Honors
description: The playwright Edward Albee and the actor Jack Lemmon are among five artists chosen to receive this year's Kennedy Center Honors for their lifetime contributions to the nation's culture. The others named yesterday were the country music singer Johnny Cash, the saxophonist and composer Benny Carter and the ballerina Maria Tallchief.

title: River Rats, Alive and Boating
description: KATE NEWELL drives her boat into her house the way most people pull into their garages. The home she and her husband, Allan, are restoring sits at least partly in the St. Lawrence River in upstate New York -- it is an 1890's yacht house on a private island.

title: C.F.T.C. Halts Illegal Advice
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has ordered a man in Florida and one in Texas to stop offering illegal trading advice over the Internet in the agency's first enforcement crackdown in cyberspace.

title: First-Half Net Income Climbed 45.3% at Total
description: The French oil company Total S.A. said yesterday that its net income rose 45.3 percent in the first half of the year on higher oil prices and a 15 percent increase in production. Total said it had earned 2.63 billion francs, or $519 million, in the first half, up from 1.81 billion francs. Sales rose 20 percent, to 80.66 billion francs.

title: Dole Declines White House Offer For National Security Briefings
description: Bob Dole said today that he would decline, at least for now, an offer by the White House for the national security briefings that incumbent administrations customarily offer political challengers during Presidential campaigns.

title: Safety Board Cites Rules Lapse in 1995 Subway Crash
description: If a simple rule in the subway operator's manual had been followed, the fatal crash on the Williamsburg Bridge last year might have been prevented, but the rule was often ignored and rarely enforced, Federal safety investigators reported today.

title: What's Bad for Hussein Seems Good for Clinton
description: ''All politicians,'' Abba Eban observed at a party celebrating his 80th birthday last year, ''take their decisions on the basis of national or political interest and explain them in terms of altruism.''

title: Prison Marriages Are on the Increase, Despite Daunting Rates of Failure
description: The wedding cake and the guests were scanned by a metal detector, and a few hours after the ceremony, bride and groom had to say goodbye to each other. But these constraints did not seem to diminish the ardor between Nelson and Marie Castellanos after they had exchanged vows in the stark visitors room at Eastern Correctional Facility, a maximum security prison in Ulster County.

title: Zell Company in Hostile Bid Of $387 Million for a Rival
description: Manufactured Home Communities Inc., which is controlled by the Chicago investor Sam Zell, said today that it had started a hostile $387 million bid for the rival Chateau Properties Inc. after Chateau ignored its earlier offer.

title: The Yanks Need More Than Cone
description: WHAT'S the Yankees' magic number?

title: Two-Sport Star Joins Women's League
description: NATALIE WILLIAMS, an all-American in basketball and volleyball at U.C.L.A., has signed with the Portland Power of the new American Basketball League for women. The track and field star JACKIE JOYNER-KERSEE had also been a candidate for a spot on the Portland team. But Portland Coach GREG BRUCE said he believed Williams will be a bigger help on the court. Tuesday's signing completes the Power's roster. (AP)

title: A Gift, Torn Away
description: To The Home Section:

title: Coach Is Rewarded by the Panthers
description: DOUG MacLEAN, who coached the Florida Panthers to the Stanley Cup finals in his first year, yesterday signed a new three-year contract with the team through 1998-99. Terms weren't disclosed.

title: Judgeship Is Forever?
description: To the Editor:

title: VITALINK PHARMACY SERVICES AGREES TO BUY GRANCARE
description: Vitalink Pharmacy Services Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Grancare Inc. for about $266 million in stock, based on Tuesday's closing price, and the assumption of $107 million in debt, after Grancare spins off its skilled-nursing operations. Vitalink, a provider of pharmacy services to institutions, said the Grancare businesses it was buying -- those not affected by the spinoff -- were primarily pharmacy operations. Vitalink is 82 percent owned by Manor Care Inc. Under the agreement, Vitalink will issue 11.6 million shares for Grancare's stock and options. The shares of Grancare, which is based in Atlanta, rose $1.125 yesterday, to $19.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock of Vitalink, which is based in Naperville, Ill., fell $1.625, to $21.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: President of AT&T Credit-Card Unit Quits
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that David K. Hunt, the president of its credit-card subsidiary, had resigned.

title: Kevorkian Allows the Dying to Have Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Philadelphia Exchange Investigates Chairman Over Contract
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange is investigating its chairman for investing in a small company that subsequently won a major contract with the exchange -- a contract that was the main attraction when the company sold shares to the public this year.

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: North Carolina

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Day Lilies

title: Philadelphia Is in Accord In Police Corruption Case
description: In a court settlement reflecting the city's deep concern over repeated cases of police corruption and racial bias, Philadelphia agreed today to expand supervision over the police force.

title: Schlichter Is Facing Felony Charges
description: The former National Football League quarterback ART SCHLICHTER, released from Federal prison last month, faces new felony charges that could send him back to jail for up to 19 years.

title: Issue of Yeltsin's Health Bungled, Kremlin Admits
description: Asked about the health of President Boris N. Yeltsin, his chief of staff, Anatoly B. Chubais, admitted today that there was a problem.

title: So Let's Make a Deal: Doors Open for Toledo
description: U.C.L.A. settled for Door No. 3.

title: Andrew Lloyd Webber is breaking new ground beyond Broadway and London's West End.
description: SIR Andrew Lloyd Webber, who has taken the Broadway musical to new heights of popularity, is breaking ground in the advertising business as well.

title: On Day 1, Adelphi U. Is Divided
description: When Michelle Coutu moved here from Cape Cod two weeks ago to become a nursing student at Adelphi University, she was unaware of the controversy surrounding its president and trustees.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Campbell Soup Profits Rise As Revamping Is Expected

title: Courville Gets a Berth on Amateur Squad
description: JERRY COURVILLE JR. yesterday was given the berth TIGER WOODS would have had on the United States squad for this autumn's world amateur team competition. Woods, who left the amateur ranks last week, defeated Courville in the second round of the United States Amateur Championships en route to his unprecedented third straight title.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 28, about an American Government-owned corporation that acquires uranium from Russia misstated the title of Richard Falkenrath of Harvard University, who criticized the corporation's profit motive. He is the executive director of the Center for Science and International Affairs at the Kennedy School of Government, not the director.

title: Powlus Return No Passing Fancy for Irish
description: When the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame open a season of high expectations at Vanderbilt tonight, the return of the high-profile quarterback Ron Powlus and a series of imaginative offensive formations will not conceal the basic plan. For the Irish to succeed this season and compete for a national championship, the passing game will be asked to produce enough to become a distraction for defenses stacked to stop the run.

title: In airline safety, too much vigilance can be a bad thing.
description: THE loss of 230 lives on T.W.A. Flight 800, most likely to a bomb, shows once again that the price of airline safety, among other things, is slower travel and higher ticket prices. It costs passengers and the airlines time and money for everything from bomb-sniffing German shepherds to the now-familiar game of ''20 questions'' at the check-in counter.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Multi-Market Radio Deal
description: Multi-Market Radio Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the radio station WKSS-FM in Hartford from the closely held Precision Media Corporation for $18 million. After the pending acquisition of Multi-Market by SFX Broadcasting Inc., WKSS-FM would become part of a cluster of four stations owned by the company that all serve Hartford. The others are WMRQ-FM, WHCN-FM and WPOP-AM. Multi-Market Radio, based in New York, owns, provides programming for, or has agreed to acquire 13 radio stations.

title: Agassi Bulls Past Muster Into a Semifinal Meeting With Chang
description: It was a bullfight without a matador, a prizefight without a punch being thrown.

title: Yankees Hire Firm for Advice on Stadium
description: A week after city officials announced that they had hired a consulting firm for advice on how to finance either a new or renovated stadium for the New York Yankees, team officials said yesterday that they, too, had hired a financial adviser.

title: Pentagon Defends Missiles' Accuracy
description: The cruise missiles used to strike Iraq's southern air defenses are acclaimed by the military for their accuracy at great distances. Today, senior officers defended that reputation despite the need to return for a second missile strike to finish the mission on Tuesday.

title: Pettitte Quietly Reaches Lofty Victory Plateau
description: Getting Andy Pettitte to concede that winning 20 games is monumental or getting him to smile about the prospect of the achievement was more difficult than hitting a home run against him. Pettitte shrugged, shook his head, stared at his shoelaces and acted agitated when asked about 20 victories.

title: Likely New Rules on Shipping Plutonium Are Criticized as Unsafe
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency is expected to approve new standards next week for packaging plutonium for shipment by plane, but environmentalists and groups that oppose nuclear proliferation are challenging them, saying that the containers would not withstand crashes.

title: Surrogate Court Election Follows Party Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Skeptical About Romance
description: How is an attractive, sophisticated woman with a snappy sense of humor to choose when pursued by a pair of ardent suitors, each offering his own personal vision of paradise for two? While one (Jason Workman), in the song ''Nebraska,'' paints a bucolic vision of ''sheep getting shorn getting born in the corn,'' the other (Mark Waldrop), in ''Normandy,'' promises ''a meadow covered with mustard flowers.'' But when the object of their devotion is a performer as spirited and savvy as Faith Prince, don't expect either man to come out a winner.

title: Staples to Buy Office Depot In Stock Swap
description: In a transaction that would create the nation's largest retailer of office supplies, Staples Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Office Depot in a stock swap valued at $3.4 billion.

title: Her Velvety Voice, Her 'Magic': Friends Honor Claudette Colbert
description: Claudette Colbert would have loved it. She might have protested modestly in what was described as her cream-of-tomato-soup voice, but she would probably have been the first to chuckle over the anecdotes and reminiscences at the memorial service held for her yesterday in Manhattan. The legendary actress, who made more than 60 films and appeared in a number of stage productions, died on July 30 at her home in Barbados at the age of 92.

title: His Agent of Good Fortune
description: ROBERT WUHL's amiable, rubbery face, one that is molded for spasms of laughter, broke into an astonished grin. Yankee Stadium fans were calling him by name. Well, not his name exactly. His character's. The morals-impaired, cover-his-clients'-backs-at-all-costs sports superagent he plays on ''Arliss,'' the hit new HBO series that skewers the money- and Nike-obsessed sports world.

title: Dole's New Campaign Style Delights a Friendly Crowd
description: Amid cases of motor oil, charcoal briquets and pizza flour stacked on a stockroom floor, Bob Dole today tried a type of campaigning he has largely avoided until now: a 30-minute, free-flowing conversation with a curious, though invitation-only, audience of supporters.

title: Mayor Seeks Stricter Curbs on Business Improvement Districts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to scale back the growing influence of the city's business improvement districts by sharply limiting or ending their ability to sell bonds, which would make it difficult for them to undertake multimillion-dollar projects, administration officials said yesterday.

title: Otto Luening, the Composer And Innovator, Is Dead at 96
description: Otto Luening, the composer, conductor, flutist, teacher and tireless advocate for contemporary music, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 96.

title: Unfinished War
description: To the Editor:

title: British Grocer to Pay $409 Million for Rival
description: Booker P.L.C., a British food producer, wholesaler and distributor, said yesterday it would buy the discount food and goods wholesaler Nurdin & Peacock P.L.C. in a transaction at $:264 million, or $409 million.

title: Turnpike Agency Settles Suit
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority agreed yesterday to pay $8.5 million to settle a 1993 lawsuit over the failure of a housing project. The suit had been filed by a development company whose project foundered while it waited to find out what part of its property would be condemned to make way for a road.

title: Oil Prices Fall After Report Of Pullback by Iraqi Troops
description: Crude oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after President Clinton said Iraqi troops appeared to be withdrawing from Kurdish areas they attacked on Saturday, easing tensions that sent oil soaring.

title: Man Held in Carjacking
description: A man jumped into an empty car yesterday, dragged its owner 500 feet through Upper Montclair and led the police on a mile-long chase before trapping himself on a dead-end street, officials said.

title: A Sports Shop That Rivals A Theme Park
description: DOORS will open on Sept. 13 at the $30 million Seattle flagship of Recreational Equipment Inc., commonly known as R.E.I., the retail chain featuring outdoor sporting gear. The 98,863-square-foot complex is the latest entry in the national competition for existential theme-park shopping.

title: Candy Now Caminiti's Power Boost of Choice
description: The food of the gods, 20th century style, is whatever the advertisements declare it to be, with Mickey Tettleton's Fruit Loops and Michael Jordan's Ballpark hot dogs somehow winding up on the same chain as Popeye's spinach.

title: Auto Emissions
description: To the Editor:

title: And the Winner Is . . . Iran?
description: The use of American military force against Iraq can weaken Saddam Hussein and deter further aggression by him. But no amount of military or diplomatic power can arbitrate a dispute that involves Turkey, Iran and Iraq, or bring about the unification of the Kurds. Indeed, the attack by the United States has had the unintended consequence of strengthening Iran, the country that has benefited the most from the power vacuum in northern Iraq.

title: MetroStars' Loss Leaves the Players and the Coach Searching for Answers
description: The MetroStars are in a deep slump at the most crucial time of the season. They suffered their fourth consecutive defeat tonight, 2-0 to the Tampa Bay Mutiny at Giants Stadium, and put their playoff chances in jeopardy.

title: A Fervent Traditionalist in Japan (an American?)
description: It seems perfectly natural that a great defender of Japanese traditional arts should live in a gorgeous 400-year-old wooden house here in a small town near Kyoto, the ancient Japanese capital.

title: For Dead Child's Family, Long History of Troubles
description: Prison was only the last stop on Carla Lockwood's miserable family journey, one that over the years brought the troubled mother and her children into contact with far more institutions than just the city's child welfare agency. Before her daughter, Nadine, 4, was found starved to death last week, there were public schools, hospitals and welfare offices, among other social-service agencies, that touched the family.

title: Gay Republican Group Backs Dole
description: A year after the Dole campaign accepted and then rejected its $1,000 campaign contribution, an organization of Republican homosexuals has officially endorsed Mr. Dole for President.

title: Evergreen and EZ Swap Radio Stations
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation said today that it had agreed to swap six radio stations in Charlotte, N.C. for two Philadelphia stations owned by EZ Communications Inc., plus $10 million in cash.

title: America Online Blocks 'Junk' E-Mail Aimed At Users
description: Responding to a torrent of complaints from subscribers who say electronic junk mail is clogging their computer in-boxes, America Online took the unusual step yesterday of blocking all incoming messages from five Internet sites that it said were responsible for sending millions of unsolicited commercial messages over computer networks each week.

title: In Barcelona, Seating And Sitting Are Arts
description: I FLEW to Barcelona, Spain, to go sitting. Some people think paintings embody culture. I think chairs do it better. My logic is simple: If chairs are really miniaturized architecture, as all chair-designing architects argue, then people ought to take their seating more seriously.

title: Be Nobody's Puppet
description: ''The son is not the father.''

title: AMRESCO AGREES TO ACQUIRE A MORTGAGE BUSINESS
description: The financial-services concern Amresco Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Quality Mortgage USA Inc. and Calmac Funding Inc. for $95.2 million. Quality Mortgage is a residential mortgage company in Irvine, Calif. The company, which originated more than $1.2 billion in residential mortgages in its latest fiscal year, has 56 branches in 34 states. Calmac Funding is the co-owner of Quality Mortgage, along with DLJ Mortgage Capital Inc. An undisclosed portion of the purchase price will be paid in stock. The shares of Amresco, which is based in Dallas, fell $1.125 yesterday, to $22, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Times-Mirror Seeks Buyer For Publisher of Art Books
description: In a move that had been expected for some time, the Times Mirror Company said yesterday that it was looking for a buyer for its prominent art-book publishing house, Harry N. Abrams Inc., as part of its refocus on its core information businesses.

title: TITANIUM METALS TO BUY UNIT OF SWEDISH COMPANY
description: The Titanium Metals Corporation of Denver said yesterday that it would acquire substantially all the assets of Axel Johnson Metals Inc., part of Axel Johnson A.B. of Sweden, for $90 million. Axel Johnson Metals and Titanium Metals each own half of Titanium Hearth Technologies, a maker of aerospace and industrial titanium products. Axel Johnson Metals, which operates in several parts of the United States, had revenue of $46.5 million for the six months that ended on June 30. Titanium Metals had sales of $226.4 million in that period. The stock of Titanium Metals jumped $2, to $26.50, yesterday on Nasdaq.

title: No Headline
description: ''I might have to make a new class, but I don't know where I'll put it -- maybe on the roof.''

title: In a Stasis of Sound: Dron-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-ne
description: Every generation of musicians rediscovers the drone. The fixed, sustained note, resonating with overtones, has carried centuries, perhaps millenniums, of mystical music and folk songs from East and West. Minimalist composers like La Monte Young and Alvin Lucier rediscovered the drone; rock bands like the Velvet Underground made it their own as they realized that the electric guitar, amplified to magnify every sonic nuance, was born to drone. Drones can be soothing and meditative or foreboding in their immobility, though they never seem entirely still; human perception continually searches for changes within the stasis, focusing on various levels of harmony or imagining a hidden melody.

title: Valentine Is Pleased With Mets' Extra Effort
description: About the only reason most Mets fans have to come out to Shea Stadium these days is to see if Todd Hundley will launch another home run.

title: Clinton Ex-Partner Is Held in Contempt In Whitewater Case
description: A Federal judge held Susan McDougal in contempt today for refusing to answer a Whitewater prosecutor's questions about whether her former business partner, Bill Clinton, had testified honestly at her trial.

title: 4 Officers in Washington Hts. Face Arrest
description: New York City police investigators are preparing to arrest four Washington Heights police officers on felony theft charges in the next couple of weeks, according to a law enforcement official involved in the case.

title: TCI Is Seeking Music Company
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable company, has offered to buy the digital music programmer DMX Inc. through a new corporation to be formed by TCI. TCI already owns about 45 percent of DMX's shares outstanding.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday tracing Iraqi history since 1988 misstated the nationality of Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz in some editions. He is Iraqi, not Iranian.

title: CRH of Ireland to Buy U.S. Concrete Maker
description: CRH Group P.L.C., an Irish building-materials company, said yesterday that it would buy Tilcon Inc., the United States crushed-stone and concrete business owned by BTR P.L.C., for $220 million in cash and the assumption of $109 million in debt. Based in Hartford, Tilcon is a large construction-materials company in the Northeastern United States, with 60 operations in nine states.

title: To Let In Light, Start With a Hatchet
description: WHEN Stephen McKay, a SoHo designer, was 6, his best friend got a log cabin playhouse as a gift. Mr. McKay pronounced it flawed: ''It had no windows.'' So he chopped holes into its walls with a hatchet.

title: French Economy Slipped 0.4% in Second Quarter
description: France's economy shrank four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter from the first, according to data released yesterday. The national statistics institute, which revised first-quarter growth downward to 1.1 percent from 1.2 percent, said the fall was partly caused by a drop in consumer spending.

title: MTV Awards Create a Delightful Chaos
description: For the third year in a row, the celebrity-fueled spectacle of the MTV Video Music Awards turned several crowded blocks of midtown Manhattan into a strange meeting ground last night where teen-agers strained to see rock stars as weary office workers strained to get free of the crowd and go home.

title: Bill Would Expand Busing
description: Thousands of New Jersey children who have to cross busy highways to get to school would be able to ride the bus under legislation proposed yesterday. Assemblywoman Shirley K. Turner, Democrat of Ewing Township, said her bill would require the state to pay for so-called courtesy busing. The state now pays only to transport children who live two miles or more from school. Many local districts pay the bill for children who live closer.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''It takes chutzpah for me to associate with great chefs,'' ITZHAK PERLMAN declared yesterday. ''It is like having an amateur music lover conduct a great orchestra.'' Nevertheless, he added, ''I am into the chutzpah business.''

title: Fallen Clinton Aide Signs Book Deal
description: Dick Morris, the former White House political adviser who resigned after his liaison with a prostitute was made public last week, has signed a book deal with Random House, the publisher said last night.

title: Fox Presents Its Lineup for News Channel
description: Fox News will enter the 24-hour cable news competition next month with a mixture of analysis, features and news, including a newscast every half-hour, 24 hours a day, Roger Ailes, the chairman of the new channel, said yesterday.

title: Belle's Side of the Story
description: Albert Belle tells the film maker Spike Lee in next Tuesday's edition of HBO's ''Real Sports'' that he should have decked Milwaukee second baseman Fernando Vina five innings before he actually leveled him in a May 31 game. The action led to a three-game suspension for the Cleveland Indians slugger.

title: Olivetti Shares Rise After Chairman Resigns
description: The shares of Olivetti S.p.A. climbed yesterday as the resignation of Carlo de Benedetti as chairman seemed to raise investor hopes that the company would emerge from five years of losses. Olivetti shares soared as much as 73 lire in the first 10 minutes of trading in Milan, before trading in them was temporarily suspended. The shares ultimately closed up 23 lire at 749.

title: Classes Open in New York City, In Closets, Hallways, Cafeterias
description: With classrooms crammed into oversized closets, cordoned off in auditoriums and plunked into locker rooms, New York City schools opened yesterday to the worst overcrowding in decades.

title: When Indoor Plumbing Was Do-It-Yourself
description: To the Editor:

title: Concerns Persist About Wage Inflation
description: Trinity Packaging's plant here recently hired a young man for a hot, entry-level job feeding plastic scrap onto a conveyor belt. The pay was O.K. for unskilled labor -- a good $3.00 or so above the Federal minimum of $4.25 an hour -- but the new worker lasted only one shift.

title: Boeing Receives Jet Order for $1.18 Billion
description: The Boeing Company said today that Philippine Airlines Inc. had ordered seven of its 747-400 jetliners valued at $1.18 billion.

title: A Welcome Peace in Chechnya
description: The war in Chechnya is over, or at least suspended for now. The shooting has stopped, Russian soldiers and Chechen fighters are patrolling the streets together and Moscow's forces are expected to withdraw this fall. Though few of his Kremlin colleagues are willing to admit it, they owe thanks to Aleksandr Lebed for this belated peace.

title: NETANYAHU MEETS WITH P.L.O. LEADER
description: After weeks of mounting tensions, pressures and secret negotiations, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu finally met face to face today with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader he repeatedly reviled during his election campaign.

title: EARNINGS ARE EXPECTED TO FALL, AND STOCK PLUNGES
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter and the year would fall below levels a year earlier, because of price cutting in the cereal market. The company said its third-quarter earnings would fall 20 percent below the $1.05 a share reported a year earlier. Kellogg said its results for the year would fall below the $3.48 a share last year. The company had been expected to earn $1.06 a share in the third quarter, according to 12 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. For the year, Kellogg was expected to earn $3.37 a share, according to 21 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. Kellogg's shares fell $3.25, to $66.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Very Cool 15-Year-Old Marches Into the Semifinals
description: The smile smacks of the Cheshire cat, a storybook character Martina Hingis has been far too busy to encounter in this lifetime; she does her prowling in tennis stadiums, not libraries.

title: AQUILA GAS TO RAISE ITS STAKE IN OASIS PIPELINE
description: The Aquila Gas Pipeline Corporation said yesterday that it would raise its stake in the closely held Oasis Pipeline Company to 40 percent by buying 25 percent of the company from Dow Hydrocarbons and Resources Inc. for about $84 million. In July, Aquila paid Dow Hydrocarbons $47.1 million for a 15 percent stake in Oasis Pipeline, related preferred stock and 120 million cubic feet a day of natural-gas transportation rights. Before yesterday's transaction, Dow Hydrocarbons, which is closely held, owned 55 percent of Oasis, a natural gas transportation company based in Houston. The Channel Gas Marketing Company, a unit of Tenneco Inc., owns 30 percent of Oasis, which has about 600 miles of pipeline and related compression equipment. Aquila Gas Pipeline is 82 percent owned by the Aquila Energy Corporation, a unit of Utilicorp United Inc.

title: President Has Minor Operation to Remove Cyst
description: An apparently benign cyst was surgically removed from President Clinton's neck in a minor 12-minute operation, Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said tonight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Study Finds a Three-Decade Gain in American Eating Habits, but a Long Way to Go
description: Although the American diet improved during the last three decades, fewer than 25 percent of people surveyed eat a healthful one, a new study has found.

title: Deutsche Bank Evaluating Cost of British Fund Bailout
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. said today that it was too early to say how much it would cost to bail out three funds managed by its British unit, Morgan Grenfell, after ''possible irregularities'' were discovered.

title: Chase Gives $750,000 to Carnegie Hall
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday announced a gift of $750,000 to Carnegie Hall to support the institution's recital series over three years.

title: Of Brokers and Bribes: a Federal Case
description: In late 1993, the stock of Malvy Technology went crazy in the Nasdaq small-capitalization market, rising from pennies a share to a peak of $6.56. Unfortunately, those who bought were destined to suffer.

title: U.S. Missed Its Chance in Dealing With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Adding Up the Numbers at Saratoga
description: The weather was stunning, the racing dramatic, Cigar drew crowds even when he ventured from his private barn on the elegant old Greentree property just to work out and a record total of 803,086 spectators watched 34 days of horse racing at its finest. This was the best of times at Saratoga Race Course in its 127th season, and it bucked a trend that has been devastating the racing business for several years.

title: Cadbury's Pretax Profit Grew 12% in First Half
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profits rose 12 percent in the first half of its fiscal year on growth in its main beverage and candy businesses, particularly its Dr Pepper brand. Cadbury earned $:231 million, or $361.7 million, in the six months that ended on June 15, compared with $:206 million a year earlier. Sales climbed 13 percent, to $:2.3 billion, or $3.6 billion.

title: Modern, Yet Distinct In Form
description: Lee Hyla

title: Study of Electric Cars Ignores Recycling Gains
description: To the Editor;

title: CHRONICLE
description: For years, the romance between NELSON MANDELA, the President of South Africa, and GRACA MACHEL, the widow of Samora Machel, the President of Mozambique who was killed in a plane crash in 1986, has been the subject of speculation. This week, Mrs. Machel, 50, said the relationship would not lead to marriage.

title: Junk Into 'Art'
description: RICK PHELPS'S work ennobles the humble and plainspoken. A landscape designer from Santa Fe, N.M., he was born into a Missouri farm family of quiltmakers and learned to sew at 4. ''Farm people were resourceful, but we didn't call making things 'art' '' he said.

title: Johnson's Message to the Jets Is Loud and Clear: I Should Start
description: After catching only one pass last Sunday, Keyshawn Johnson has seen enough. So today he compared himself to Michael Irvin and Deion Sanders. If they get the ball, why not him?

title: Key Kurd Calls Deal With Iraq A Stopgap
description: A leader of the Kurdish faction backed by Saddam Hussein insisted today that the alliance was just a tactical and temporary partnership of the kind that have sustained the beleaguered Kurds for centuries.

title: Mexico Builds a Picture of a Fanatic Rebel Group
description: The rebel army that attacked police officers and soldiers across Mexico last week is a fusion of a dozen leftist factions around a dominant one with a 20-year history of clandestine recruitment, murders and kidnappings, including the kidnapping of a banker that is thought to have netted $30 million in ransom, the Government says.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SALES FORCE TO GROW BY 1,200
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb Inc. said yesterday that it planned to add 1,200 employees to its worldwide sales force by early next year; that will increase the company's United States sales staff to about 3,000. The new sales representatives will be used to promote two cardiovascular drugs that Bristol-Myers is developing and to try to increase sales of existing drugs, which include the anticholesterol medication Pravachol and the diabetes treatment Glucophage, the company said. The new sales representatives come on top of 370 hired in the first half, the company, which is based in New York, said.

title: Muscling In on the Mafia, and Even Doing Worse
description: THE NEW ETHNIC MOBS

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a plane on an American warship in the Persian Gulf misidentified the plane, the source of the picture and, in some copies, the vessel. The plane was an F/A-18 Hornet, not an F-14 Tomcat or a Tomahawk cruise missile. The ship was the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson, not the destroyer Laboon. The picture was from the U.S. Navy, via Agence France-Presse, not Reuters.

title: Young Legs Entwined
description: To The Home Section:

title: TV Consortium Is Disbanded
description: Television Production Partners, a consortium of 10 giant advertisers that was formed in 1992 to produce programming for members to sponsor, has been disbanded, though its efforts may continue on an ad hoc basis.

title: INSIDE
description: Limits for Business Districts

title: IRAQ PULLING OUT, BUT LEAVING SPIES BEHIND, U.S. SAYS
description: Saddam Hussein is withdrawing most but not all of his forces from the Kurdish enclaves in northern Iraq that he invaded over the weekend, and is leaving behind a group of spies and secret agents to reassert his power in the region, American officials said today.

title: Graf's Father Bids to Clear Her Name
description: STEFFI GRAF's family was promised tax breaks to stop the tennis star from moving to a tax haven abroad, her father testified yesterday. He also sought to clear his daughter's name in the tax-evasion affair.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOE JAMAIL, the lawyer who represented Pennzoil against Texaco in the case that drove Texaco into bankruptcy, has given $17 million to seven Texas institutions, including $5 million to his alma mater, the University of Texas at Austin, The Associated Press reported Wednesday.

title: A Grown-Up Hingis Is in the Big Time Now
description: First, she outgrew her toys. Then she outgrew the junior circuit: when you are just 13 but you have already won the junior French Open two years in succession, it's time to move on and give the real kids a fair shake in their events.

title: $25 and Under
description: Mr. Tony was in a lather. For the first time in the 18 months he has been serving modern Southern dinners in this charming 25-seat restaurant, his father and several tables of relatives were visiting. Mr. Tony is normally a gregarious fellow, patrolling the dining room, kneeling by one table to describe the specials, sitting at another to make recommendations. But under the pressure of family scrutiny, Mr. Tony had shifted into hyperdrive.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Getting Away With Murder

title: How Hair Tonic Perks Up Cornflakes, and Other Secrets
description: It is just shy of 10 A.M., and Brett Kurzweil has already been to two supermarkets, a farmers' market, a natural foods store, the Gourmet Garage and Balducci's. He is in search of the perfect garlic.

title: New York Officials Vow to Sue To Keep Bronx Factory Open
description: City and state economic officials announced last night that they would sue a manufacturer in New Jersey for breach of contract unless it agreed to continue operating the Farberware plant in the South Bronx for three more months.

title: Apodaca Gains Instant Respect as Mets' New Pitching Coach
description: It was a move the Mets considered making shortly after the All-Star break, but should have made a month into the season when their pitching first started showing signs of collapse. No, this has nothing to do with the firing of Manager Dallas Green and replacing him with Bobby Valentine, but everything to do with why the Mets' season has gone sour.

title: DUTCH COMPANY TO BUY 55 PERCENT STAKE IN FEI
description: Philips Electronics N.V. agreed yesterday to buy 55 percent of the FEI Company, which makes computer work stations for electron emission technology. The companies did not say how much the Dutch company would pay for the stake or whether FEI, based in Hillsboro, Ore., would issue new shares. FEI would become the new parent of Philips Electron Optics B.V., which makes electron microscopes. Combined, the new entity would employ about 900 people. Shares of FEI jumped $2.25 yesterday, to $12.50. At that price, the company has a market capitalization of more than $96 million.

title: Girls' School: New Clamor Over Old Idea
description: FOR a refugee from the 60's, memories were gently stirred when school opened with 50 girls in East Harlem squeezing past squadrons of uniformed guards and cameras to go to class. Flash back to similar commotion in places like Birmingham and Little Rock in the old civil rights days.

title: Netanyahu Warns Right-Wing Aides: Back Me, or Quit
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu issued a stern warning to his right-wing ministers today that if they did not like his handshake with Yasir Arafat, they could leave his Government. Though there was some loud grumbling, there were no takers.

title: But Intelligence Unit Is Said to Stay Behind In Kurdish Region: U.S. Sees Expanded Zone as Permanent (folo)
description: Washington  Brian Knowlton of the International Herald Tribune reportedfrom Washington:

title: Deutsche Bank Backs 3 Equity Funds
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. disclosed yesterday that it had pumped $:180 million ($270 million) into three equity funds at its Morgan Grenfell Asset Management unit in London. The German bank said it had made the payment to buy certain unlisted securities in three stock funds managed by Morgan Grenfell whose value has been questioned. The funds have 90,000 investors.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Russia's Top-Flight Cardiology Hospital
description: The cardiology center where President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia is likely to have heart surgery later this month has high success rates that are comparable to those in many American hospitals, leading American heart surgeons said yesterday.
