title: Dole Is to Visit Today
description: On his second trip to New Jersey since last month's Republican National Convention, Bob Dole is to visit the Switlik Parachute Company today.

title: A Lawyer Crusades For Campaign Limits
description: Charles W. Juntikka, a bankruptcy lawyer who lives on the Lower East Side, has tackled New York's arcane and complex petition process to promote a major change in the city's campaign finance law. Mr. Juntikka said he has spent his $40,000 savings to send teams of teen-agers to collect signatures in the hopes of placing two questions on the Nov. 5 ballot, one creating a $100 limit on campaign contributions and another requiring public debates for all city candidates who take public financing.

title: Father in Abuse Case Asks for Custody
description: The father of the 4-year-old girl who died of malnutrition in her mother's Manhattan apartment said yesterday that he would seek custody of the six surviving children as well as the twins the mother was found to be pregnant with.

title: 2 Agencies Expand In New Media
description: Two agencies are expanding in the realm of new media.

title: Shifting Character
description: To the Editor:

title: Issue of 'Second Tax-Free Year' Gives Talks Degree of Doubt
description: Just when baseball's labor negotiators thought they were a signature away from a deal, the phrase ''service time'' surfaced and dried up their pens. That was last week and the couple of weeks before. This week, the operative issue that owners say stands in the way of a deal is the ''second tax-free year.''

title: Ivanisevic Shuts Door On Edberg's Last Slam
description: Stefan Edberg, the elegant serve-volleyist, had the curtain brought down on his prolific Grand Slam career last night at the United States Open, the Slam he learned to love enough to win twice.

title: Clinton Seeks Florida Votes With a Focus On Medicare
description: Gently mocking the Republican-led Congress's proposals for Medicare, President Clinton took his campaign to Florida today and swept from a high school to a theater full of retirees in a battle for a state that has not voted for a Democratic Presidential candidate in two decades.

title: Carrying On a Venerable Brush-and-Ink Tradition
description: ''The Fragrance of Ink: Korean Literati Paintings of the Choson Dynasty (1392-1910), From Korea University Museum'' is the hefty title of a lovely, lighter-than-air season-opener at the Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery of Columbia University.

title: A Weekend of Bands All Over Manhattan
description: The CMJ Music Marathon, featuring performances by more than 500 rock bands, runs through Sunday at clubs in Manhattan. A $325 pass ($170 for students) provides admission to all events; otherwise, ticket prices are set at the clubs. Passes can be bought today and tomorrow in the lobby of Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. Marathon information: (516) 466-6000. Here is a listing of clubs and other locations for performances this weekend; call the clubs for performers, show times, admission and other information.

title: U.N. Council Members Negotiate, Fruitlessly
description: After several days of intense back-room bargaining and sharp exchanges between Russia and several Western nations, the Security Council was still unable today to agree to a resolution condemning the Iraqi attack on the Kurdish town of Erbil last Saturday.

title: ECHLIN BUYS CANADIAN AUTO PARTS MAKER
description: Echlin Inc., an automotive parts maker based in Branford, Conn., said yesterday that it had bought Long Manufacturing Ltd., a privately held Canadian auto parts maker, for $160 million. Long Manufacturing, which had $165 million in sales last year, is based in Oakville, Ontario. It makes engine and transmission oil coolers and air-conditioner evaporators, and has about 1,000 employees in plants throughout North America. Echlin had sales of $2.7 billion last year.

title: Saddam Moves Along
description: While the Clinton Administration is embarrassing itself by claiming military success against Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi himself is not only contentedly mopping up Kurds and their land, but is moving ahead handsomely toward three military goals of special importance to him. They are: arming Iraq with more biological and chemical weapons, extending the range of missiles that could deliver them and putting together a new nuclear-weapons program.

title: A Longing For Death And Life
description: ''Maborosi'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 29. The film -- in Japanese with English subtitles -- opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: Everyone Wants to Carry a Gold-Medal Gymnast
description: She hit the ground screening phone calls.

title: In Search of a Pulse
description: To the Editor:

title: President of Spelman College Says She'll Quit in June 1997
description: Johnnetta B. Cole, one of the nation's most charismatic black educators who over the past decade has gained national attention for her academic and fund-raising success at Spelman College here, announced today that she would resign as president of the college at the end of the academic year next June.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Pre-Politically Correct'

title: Mr. Netanyahu, Meet Mr. Arafat
description: The awkward body language caught the spirit of Wednesday's first meeting between Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat. The Israeli Prime Minister resolutely maintained a poker face, determined to display no hint of pleasure in greeting a man he has long vilified. By contrast, the Palestinian leader could not stop beaming, delighted to show the world that the new Israeli Government had recognized his importance and the need to engage him in renewed peace talks.

title: Jets Are Trying to Avoid Colts' Follow-Up Punch
description: Someday the Jets will face a team and only good memories will flow. But not yet, not this Sunday, when they stage their home opener against the Colts and Jim Harbaugh.

title: Corrections
description: A Calendar listing in The Home Section yesterday misstated the date for guided tours of artists' studios in SoHo. They are this Sunday from 1 to 6 P.M., not on Saturday.

title: Condo, With Air Rights, Rising on the East Side
description: Sales began this week for apartments in a 31-story luxury condominium that is being built using air rights from an adjoining landmark church on the Upper East Side. The $45 million condominium, called the Siena, has been designed to complement its historic neighbor, St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church and Rectory.

title: A Boy, an Invisible Pal And a Substitute Mom
description: Snub-nosed, mop-topped 7-year-old Albert (Haley Joel Osment) lives with his mom (Nancy Travis), the nicest showgirl in Las Vegas. She works in a magic act with a group of whimsical French performers. But when she is home with Albert, she does maternal things, like admiring his school report on Ethiopia or telling him to brush his teeth.

title: Bizarre Behavior in Solar System: Comets and Asteroids in a Switch
description: Comets and asteroids, small chunks of drifting solar-system material that sometimes collide with planets and produce fireworks, have long been considered separate types of celestial bodies. But the distinction between them has blurred, and last month a comet that is behaving like an asteroid turned up, and a supposed asteroid has sprouted a comet-like tail.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Hating the Government
description: As we endure the trumpery of the 1996 Presidential campaign -- has there ever been a greater absurdity in American politics than the parties vying in their devotion to ''family values''? -- we might think about what we are missing. If a candidate talked sense to the American people, what would his subject be?

title: The Spoken Word
description: CANDACE GINGRICH, A Different Light, 151 West 19th Street, Chelsea. The author, a half-sister of Newt Gingrich, will read from her book, ''The Accidental Activist: A Personal and Political Memoir.'' Today at 7 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 989-4850.

title: Bribesville's Solitary Prisoner: He's Crying Scandal
description: It has been more than four years since a team of Milan prosecutors opened the corruption investigation that led to the collapse of Italy's ruling political class.

title: Life Beyond Avenue A
description: I DECIDED to move out of my neighborhood in Alphabet City the night I heard a couple getting held up at gunpoint outside my window.

title: Presidential Panel Says Pentagon Lacks Credibility for Inquiry on Nerve Gas Exposure
description: Investigators for a Presidential advisory committee said today that the credibility of the Defense Department had been ''gravely undermined'' by its inquiry into the possible exposure of American troops to Iraqi chemical weapons during the 1991 gulf war. They recommended that the investigation be taken away from the Pentagon and handed over to an outside body.

title: Profit Triples For Lukoil Holding
description: Lukoil Holding, Russia's biggest oil company, said yesterday that its profit tripled in the first half of the year to 1.774 trillion rubles ($332 million) as it raised the production and export of oil products. Revenue advanced to 23.641 trillion rubles from 6.769 trillion rubles. In the period Lukoil raised exports of crude oil 8.6 percent, to 74.7 million barrels, while exports of oil products nearly doubled, to 11.8 million barrels.

title: Pete Shows His Courage In Marathon
description: THERE was no place for a sick man to hide. All Pete Sampras could do was shuffle to the edge of the court and hang his head even farther than it had been drooping for most of the match. And then he was sick.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A white-haired gentleman in Maloney & Porcelli this week ordered a martini (with olive), then went on to a grilled rib-eye so large it hung off both ends of the plate, and a half bottle of red wine. He polished them all off very happily.

title: Notre Dame Escapes With a Victory After 4 Lost Fumbles
description: Notre Dame survived tonight, barely. That achievement may not have seemed impressive when the Fighting Irish kicked off their season against the Vanderbilt Commodores, a team they dominated in a 41-point victory a year ago. But on an odd, loud evening in which the Fighting Irish, in their own words, became discouraged, embarrassed and shellshocked, a fourth-quarter rally and a 14-7 victory became enough of a reward for one night.

title: Market Place
description: AS the National Semiconductor Corporation hit bottom? Some analysts are betting that it has, after yesterday's disappointing earnings report.

title: Rough Seas Cripple Crash Wreckage Efforts
description: On the 50th day after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, senior investigators said that persistent rough seas off Long Island had paralyzed efforts to collect the remaining wreckage of the shattered jumbo jet.

title: Adelphi Offers Lesson For Higher Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Aug. 15 comparing car models that were popular with first-time buyers in the past included one photograph in error. The photograph, with sales and price figures for the 1951 Volkswagen Beetle, showed a 1958 Beetle.

title: Dole, at Site of Bosnia Accords, Says They Have Failed
description: Speaking from the city where the Bosnia peace accords were reached 10 months ago, Bob Dole today proclaimed their results a failure so far and urged an indefinite delay in Bosnia's Presidential and parliamentary elections scheduled next week.

title: Looking Past Hollywood for the Classics
description: ''The Best of the Indies,'' the independent film series that opened yesterday at Anthology Film Archives, augurs a renewed vitality for this previously underutilized cinematic resource in the East Village. The series, presented in association with Fabiano Canosa, continues through Sept. 15 and will bring back for one screening a mixture of classics and well-regarded contemporary films that you probably won't see soon again in a theater because they have been released as videos. For many movie lovers, catching up with a film by videotape is a poor substitute for seeing it in its proper shape on the big screen.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-17

title: Officer's Child Wounded
description: The 4-year-old daughter of a New York City police officer accidentally shot herself in the head with her mother's service revolver yesterday, the police said.

title: Where History Is at Rest
description: IF New Yorkers tend to ignore their city's history, it's not entirely their fault. In the daily dash forward, who has time to look back? Who even knows where or how? Yet it can be done, and pleasantly. Forget the car and take the BMT to 25th Street in Brooklyn. Ignore the drab environs of workaday Sunset Park as you exit onto Fourth Avenue. Walk a single, gently inclined block to the superb outer gates of Green-Wood Cemetery. Don't be put off by the stern signs warning of ''Armed Guards and K-9 Patrols.'' Walk on to the soaring multi-spired, inner gateway incorporating cemetery offices and chapel. They were designed in Gothic Revival style in 1861 by Richard Upjohn, architect of some of the city's best churches, including Trinity Church on lower Broadway in Manhattan.

title: Yeltsin Reveals He'll Undergo Heart Surgery
description: Ending months of silence about his health and shattering a Kremlin taboo, President Boris N. Yeltsin acknowledged today that he needed heart surgery and said he would have an operation later this month in Moscow.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TREX MEDICAL CORP., Danbury, Conn., a maker of medical equipment, acquired Continental X-Ray Corp., Broadview, Ill., for about $19.3 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARILYN FREEH, the wife of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's director, LOUIS J. FREEH, gave birth to the couple's fifth son on Tuesday, LIAM PATRICK FREEH, who weighed in at 9 pounds 6 ounces. Their other children are Justin, 11; Brendan, 10; Sean, 6, and Connor, 4.

title: Belmont Opens Today; Cigar Drills at Saratoga
description: More than 1,800 horses left Saratoga Springs this week after their five-and-a-half-week season in the Adirondacks, and about 1,400 of them headed back to Belmont Park, where the fall meeting opens today.

title: Foes of Gay Marriage Are Foiled in California Senate
description: Outside Hawaii -- where a court case set to begin next week may lead to the granting of marriage licenses to couples of the same sex -- California is one of the most important battlegrounds in the nationwide fight over same-sex marriages. Not only is it the most populous state, it has a highly visible homosexual population and is a gateway to Hawaii.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: A Friendship Lost and Improbably Regained
description: Don't ask how Adam Sandler and Damon Wayans end up sharing the honeymoon bungalow in a cheesy Arizona motel where Mr. Sandler caterwauls an excruciating gospel travesty of ''I Will Always Love You'' in the shower. This jovial serenade would probably not amuse Whitney Houston. But it is one of the few moments in ''Bulletproof'' to capture a spirit of goofy playfulness that is painfully absent throughout much of the rest of this blood-drenched action comedy.

title: Jones to Put Title on the Line at the Garden
description: Roy Jones Jr., the International Boxing Federation supermiddleweight champion, will defend his title against Bryant Brannon on Oct. 4 at the Theater at Madison Square Garden.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: FIRST DATA AGREES TO BUY DONNELLEY MARKETING
description: The First Data Corporation of Hackensack, N.J., agreed yesterday to buy Donnelley Marketing Inc. for $185 million in cash from DM Holding, a privately held investment group. Donnelley Marketing, based in Chicago, provides marketing services and research, analysis and data bases on consumer buying and marketing trends. First Data, a credit card processor, plans to offer Donnelley Marketing as part of its services to businesses. DM Holding, based in Chicago, bought Donnelly Marketing, which was founded in 1917, from the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation in 1991.

title: Internet Sales Offer an Insurance Alternative
description: James W. Bishop Jr. does not like insurance agents. So when he decided he needed more life insurance, he did not call his local agent; in fact, he did not pick up the phone at all. Instead, he just went up to his bedroom and turned on his computer.

title: Sale of Fighter Jets to Indonesia Is Postponed
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it would postpone the sale of at least nine F-16 fighter jets to Indonesia for four months because of Congressional objections to Indonesia's recent crackdown on political dissent.

title: Auto Talks Are Said to Focus on Parts Compromise
description: Detroit's Big Three auto makers and the United Automobile Workers union are actively discussing a landmark proposal to resolve their dispute over moves by the manufacturers to buy more auto parts from outside suppliers, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Fast Protests School Plan
description: Lawrence Hamm, the chairman of the New Jersey Million Man March Coalition, and several other black leaders began a fast yesterday to protest Governor Whitman's school financing plan.

title: Grand Metropolitan Begins Revamping
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food and drinks company, said today that it would revamp its European food business, with the first step being the sale of its Erasco Group, Germany's market leader in canned meals and soups, to the Campbell Soup Company for $:140 million, or $210 million.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: 'Debates/Debates'

title: An Alternative To Methadone Is Approved
description: In a move that could make it easier for heroin addicts to adhere to treatment, New York State has approved a longer-acting alternative to methadone, the synthetic narcotic used to stave off the cravings of heroin addiction. Unlike methadone, which must be taken every day, the new drug, marketed under the brand name Orlaam, is taken three times a week.

title: Magellan Fund Cut Bond Holdings in July
description: Fidelity Investments' flagship Magellan Fund cut its bond holdings in July as investors continued to withdraw money from the nation's biggest mutual fund.

title: A Tearful Neely Announces Retirement
description: CAM NEELY, the Boston Bruins' hard-hitting, high-scoring forward, tearfully announced his retirement yesterday in Boston because of a degenerative hip condition.

title: The C.I.A. Seeks Out Informers On Terrorism, and Finds Them
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is recruiting informers on terrorism at a rate that far outstrips past efforts, its director said today.

title: Canada Stops German Team
description: Team Canada had everything to lose after limping through the World Cup of Hockey's first round. Germany, though, had nothing to lose, having beaten a highly favored Czech Republic team to get here.

title: Baghdad Saw Kurd Raid As a Sure-Fire Gamble
description: For President Saddam Hussein, the benefits of his assault into the Kurdish area of northern Iraq have far outweighed the military and economic costs, diplomats from Middle Eastern countries and Iraqi opposition figures said today.

title: Unspeakable Names
description: Minnesota has a rebellious county on its hands. Lake County has refused to comply with a state law, enacted last year, that orders counties to rename any natural geographic place with the word ''squaw'' in its name.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Holt & Ross Merges With DKB
description: DKB & Partners, an advertising and public relations agency in Morristown, N.J., and Holt & Ross Inc., a public relations agency in Far Hills, N.J., have merged to form an agency, using the DKB & Partners name, with combined billings estimated at more than $50 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Hurricane Fran Pounds Coast Of Carolinas
description: Hurling winds with more speed than a major league fastball, Hurricane Fran slammed on Thursday night into the same stretch of Carolina coast that was battered less than two months ago by Hurricane Bertha.

title: When the Hate Group Is Made Up of Rogue Cops
description: What Mark Fuhrman wrought in the O. J. Simpson trial in Los Angeles will be haunting police departments around the country for a long time to come. Entertainment exhibit No. 1: ''Gang in Blue,'' a Showtime presentation on Sunday night about rogue white officers whose virulent racism turns murderous. It is hardly the portrait Mr. Fuhrman had in mind when he was giving his startling ''insider'' tips to a budding screenwriter.

title: G.O.P. and 'Ic'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rates to Vary by Hour
description: The Board of Public Utilities yesterday gave GPU Energy permission to begin a pilot program for 240 New Jersey customers in which electric rates would vary depending on the time of day, much as long-distance telephone rates do.

title: Homecoming: Yankees Appear Relaxed and Confident
description: The sky was black when the Yankees boarded an airplane early yesterday morning and began their journey from Oakland, Calif., to New York. By the time they landed five hours and three time zones later, an intense sunlight shone through their window seats. It looked pretty and promising.

title: The Hope of Connection in Williams's World
description: ''The pieces don't fit!'' exclaims the crazy, exasperated Mrs. Winemiller, the preacher's wife in Tennessee Williams's ''Summer and Smoke.'' She's talking about a jigsaw puzzle or, if you're thinking symbols (and you don't have much choice but to think that way when it comes to ''Summer and Smoke''), about the eternal rift between body and soul.

title: In New York, Many Outlaw Drivers Carry a Badge
description: They career through traffic in squad cars, fire engines and ambulances, hastening to an array of urban ordeals. They are supposed to be providing help, but a new report suggests that a relatively high number of these police officers, firefighters and other municipal workers in New York City may be hazards themselves when they get behind the wheel.

title: Clear Goal in the 1890's Is Unclear by the 1990's
description: A century ago, when Jacob Riis photographed the slums of New York, he knew what he was after: more space, more windows and better ventilation and sanitation for the poor. Today, after a hundred trends in urban renewal have come and gone, there is no longer a simple idea for improving poor neighborhoods.

title: Car and Truck Sales Mostly Off in August
description: Sales of cars and trucks sagged in August, signaling that auto sales in the last half of the year will be significantly off the unexpectedly brisk pace set in the spring and early summer, auto executives, economists and Wall Street analysts said today. Over all, car and truck sales dropped 2.3 percent from the comparable period a year ago.

title: Treasuries Take Another Sharp Fall
description: Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday for a second consecutive session, as concerns about economic strength mounted before today's employment report for August.

title: Majority Give Clinton Credit On the Economy, Poll Finds
description: The American public, feeling better about the economy than at any other time in the last eight years, now gives President Clinton credit for a turnabout, leaving Bob Dole's appeals to voters' economic anxieties without much potency, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: Lilco Chief Threatens To Halt Talks On Rate Cuts
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company warned today that he would suspend talks on Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to reorganize electric service on Long Island if the Public Service Commission ordered an immediate 5.2 percent cut in company rates.

title: School Overcrowding to Last, New York City Officials Say
description: As New York City's 660 elementary schools reopened yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said that the overcrowding at many schools would be a fact of life for tens of thousands of students and teachers for some time to come.

title: Let Ross Perot Debate
description: With Bob Dole still well behind President Clinton, the next event that could affect the standings in the Presidential race is likely to be the debates between the candidates. One big question is whether Ross Perot should be invited. Republicans worry that Mr. Perot's presence could hurt Mr. Dole. But the decision whether to include Mr. Perot, or anyone else, should be based on whether a candidacy has the earmarks of a valid national campaign. Such tests of viability include ballot position, fund-raising ability and a history of performance in previous campaigns.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about new ways of using radar to measure changes in the earth's surface referred incorrectly to two images of Mount Etna and an image of the Landers Fault in California. The top image of Mount Etna showed the actual deformation of the volcano obtained after processing of radar data, not the raw data. The bottom image was a computer simulation of the deformation made from a mathematical model; it did not come from the radar. Similarly, the image of the Landers Fault was a computer simulation of the fault's deformation.

title: Residents-Only Parks Fought
description: An ordinance in Haledon that bans nonresidents from borough parks was challenged for a second time yesterday by the state chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: KEYSTONE INVESTMENTS SAID TO SEEK PARTNERSHIP OR SALE
description: Faced with years of lackluster mutual fund asset growth, Keystone Investments Inc. is exploring the possibility of teaming up with an outside company or selling the company, according to people familiar with the situation. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., might be interested in acquiring Keystone. First Union and Keystone declined to comment. Keystone, which is based in Boston, would fetch about $230 million in a takeover, or 2 percent of the company's assets, based on recent acquisitions in the mutual fund industry, analysts said.

title: City Government Can't Hide From Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Lives Pulled Along by McNamara's War Policy
description: THE LIVING AND THE DEAD

title: Factions on Death Penalty Issue Gird for Battle
description: When the man behind the battle royal between the Bronx District Attorney and the Governor of New York dies, does the battle expire, too?

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * Starlight Foundation of New York to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, as the first agency to handle its account.

title: McDonnell Wins Lufthansa Order for Cargo Jets
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it had won an order worth as much as $1.3 billion from Lufthansa for its MD-11 jet, to be used as a cargo aircraft.

title: Wallace Found Not Guilty of Charge
description: RASHEED WALLACE of the Portland Trail Blazers was found not guilty on Wednesday of using a car to block the mother of his child as she tried to leave a parking lot.

title: Cultural Views: Differing Outlooks
description: Has Bob Costas, who was host of the Summer Olympics for NBC, ''poisoned'' the Olympic spirit, as an advertisement in last Sunday's New York Times charged? Is he biased against Chinese athletes?

title: Babe Dahlgren, 84, Successor to Gehrig When Streak Ended
description: Babe Dahlgren, a footnote to baseball history as the man who took over at first base for the New York Yankees when Lou Gehrig's streak of 2,130 consecutive games ended, died Wednesday in Arcadia, Calif. He was 84.

title: Yeltsin's Health Hurts Mark; Dollar Gains on Rate Outlook
description: The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday after President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia said he would have heart surgery this month. Signs of political instability in Russia help the dollar and hurt the mark because Germany is Russia's biggest creditor and trading partner.

title: The Unthinkable Becomes a TV Event: Cuban Aide Debates Anti-Castro Leader
description: In an initiative that has unsettled hard-liners both here and in Havana, a senior Cuban Government official and the leader of the most powerful anti-Castro Cuban exile group in the United States faced off in a rare direct encounter as part of an unusual debate broadcast tonight.

title: Man Held in Police Death Is Found Hanged in Jail
description: The man whose arrest in the slaying of a police officer sparked a battle over the death penalty between the Governor of New York and the Bronx District Attorney took his life yesterday, hanging himself with a belt from his jail cell bars, the authorities said.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Hot House'

title: Moves by Campbell Soup Send Shares Surging to Reach a High
description: Shares of the Campbell Soup Company shot to a record high yesterday after management announced a $160 million restructuring plan, the $210 million purchase of a German soup business, a $2.5 billion stock repurchase plan and a large increase in its advertising budget.

title: U.S. JURY CONVICTS 3 IN A CONSPIRACY TO BOMB AIRLINERS
description: Mr. Yousef's conviction was important to the Government, which views him as representing a new breed of terrorist, one intent on bringing overseas conflicts to American shores. Mr. Yousef, who said he had been born in Pakistan and raised in Kuwait, and had received explosives training in Afghanistan, brought his rage over American support of Israel to the United States, investigators said. Until his arrest in Pakistan in 1995, the United States considered him the most wanted fugitive alive, with a $2 million reward for his capture.

title: Art Teacher's Crusade For Vandals With Honor
description: The simple and effective documentary ''Kids of Survival'' celebrates the achievements of Tim Rollins, an art teacher who has worked for 15 years with teen-age students in the South Bronx. Mr. Rollins's audacious, much-publicized methods involve appropriating important literary works and making them canvases for far-reaching, politically aware art.

title: Retailers Had Mixed Results During August
description: Retailers threw out a mixed bag of back-to-school sales results yesterday, and the market responded like a stern vice principal, handing down mild praise for good performance and swift punishment for those with poor showings.

title: At the MTV Awards, All the World's a Stage
description: The MTV Video Music Awards on Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall attracted a spectacular array of pop stars and celebrity hangers-on. From Sharon Stone to the Smashing Pumpkins, from Dennis Rodman to Claudia Schiffer, they presented awards, won awards or just watched, basking in the glow of a show dedicated to their favorite art form: themselves.

title: Adviser Had Secret Deal For Book
description: President Clinton's now-fallen political adviser, Dick Morris, struck a secret agreement with the publishers of Random House nearly five months ago to write a memoir chronicling his years as a top strategist for the White House, the head of the publishing house said.

title: Accounts
description: * Dow Jones & Co., Princeton, N.J., to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, to handle circulation marketing for The Wall Street Journal, which includes direct-response and image advertising. Those duties had been handled by J. Walter Thompson New York, a unit of WPP Group. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: A Tearful Neely Announces Retirement
description: CAM NEELY, the Boston Bruins' hard-hitting, high-scoring forward, tearfully announced his retirement yesterday in Boston because of a degenerative hip condition.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Truth About Cats and Dogs

title: People
description: * Craig W. Branigan was named managing director at Landor Associates, San Francisco, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., succeeding Peter J. Harleman and Kay Stout, who were promoted to area managing director for the Americas and chief marketing and creative strategist, respectively. Mr. Branigan had been president and chief executive of the San Francisco office of Y.& R.

title: Clashes, Lies and Always, Always Music
description: STEPHEN HOFFMAN is as abrasively American as any Yankee whom Henry James ever sent to Europe. Standing amid the shabby Austrian sumptuousness of a voice teacher's studio in Vienna in ''Old Wicked Songs,'' Jon Marans's deeply satisfying, remarkably assured new play at the Promenade Theater, this young man seems like a jittery, walking rebuke to what surrounds him.

title: Restaurants
description: ''We won't need a reservation,'' I said confidently the second time I went to Ansonia. ''Last time I was here, the restaurant was empty.'' I pulled open the door.

title: Kemp Earned $6.9 Million, Mostly as Speaker, Since '92
description: Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, made $6.9 million, mostly in speaking fees, in the three years after he stepped down from his job as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, according to income tax returns released today by the Dole-Kemp campaign.

title: Addressing Air Safety
description: The White House is preparing to ask Congress for a $300 million emergency appropriation to improve air safety. Page B9.

title: To Morris and His Media Deals: Just Say No
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Panel Issues Rebuke For Conduct On the Bench
description: For the second time in six months, an appeals court panel has reprimanded Kevin Thomas Duffy, the judge in the trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, for his conduct in other cases. The panel overturned a jury's guilty verdict because of ''hostile'' comments Judge Duffy directed at a lawyer and a witness.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK TWO
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Which Future?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about sales in August for several auto makers referred incorrectly in some editions to the comparison with sales a year ago for the American Honda Motor Company. Sales fell 13.7 percent; they did not rise 6.4 percent.

title: Public Still Worries, but Less, About Economy
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll showed that feelings of economic insecurity among the American public had ebbed somewhat since a benchmark poll The Times conducted last December for a series of articles, ''The Downsizing of America.''

title: WATTS INDUSTRIES SELLS UNIT TO TYCO INTERNATIONAL
description: Watts Industries said yesterday that it had sold its Waterworks Valve Group to Tyco International Ltd. for $90.6 million. Watts Industries, based in North Andover, Mass., said proceeds from the sale would be used to finance its stock buyback program and to support acquisition efforts. The company said the Waterworks Valve Group had sales of more than $85 million in the year that ended on June 30. Watts Industries makes valves for the plumbing, heating and energy markets. Tyco, of Exeter, N.H., makes disposable medical products, packaging materials and electrical parts. Shares of Tyco slipped 62.5 cents yesterday, to $42.375. Shares of Watts were unchanged at $18.75.

title: For Children
description: 'Rapunzel' Puppet Show

title: Inside Art
description: Arts America, a Budget Casualty

title: TV WEEKEND
description: 'Passion'

title: JAMES RIVER ACQUIRES REMAINING INTEREST IN JAMONT
description: The James River Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired full ownership of Europe's third-largest paper towel and tissue company by paying $201.4 million for the remaining 13.6 percent stake in Jamont N.V. James River, the maker of Dixie cups and Quilted Northern bathroom tissue, bought the stake from Europaper Inc., a closely held investor group. The purchase was made after Europaper exercised its rights to sell the stake at a previously agreed on price. Jamont, based in Brussels, had 1995 sales of $1.7 billion. It was formed in 1990 when James River, based in Richmond, Gruppo Ferruzzi of Italy and the Nokia Corporation of Finland contributed their European consumer products businesses to the venture.

title: A new campaign is trying to restore Sharper Image's edge.
description: THE prototypical product sold by the Sharper Image is perhaps a gauge that measures latitude, longitude, altitude and even fortitude -- everything, alas, but attitude.

title: Renaissance Hotels To Bozell Agency
description: Renaissance Hotels and Resorts, a Cleveland-based subsidiary of Renaissance International Hotels Inc. of Hong Kong, said yesterday that it had selected Bozell Worldwide in New York to handle its account, which had been handled by Wyse Advertising in Cleveland. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million.

title: Guillermina Rico, Boss of Mexico Vendors, 63
description: Guillermina Rico, a lemon peddler who bargained her way to wealth and power as the head of a political machine she forged from the ranks of Mexico City's itinerant vendors, died on Wednesday of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 63.

title: Say the Secret Word? It Isn't 'Gambling'
description: To the Editor:

title: In Still, Moonlit Beauty, Fields of Death and Ruin
description: ''Landscapes of the Civil War: Newly Discovered Photographs From the Medford Historical Society'' conveys the brutality of 19th-century warfare in the grave, measured tones of 19th-century photography. The 100 vintage prints that form the exhibition at the International Center of Photography come from a trove of thousands of recently re-discovered images, all taken by Northerners, at the Medford (Mass.) Historical Society.

title: Dole Replaces 2 Aides to Sharpen Message
description: Less than nine weeks before Election Day, the Dole campaign squeezed out two of its top strategists today in a shake-up that reflects the campaign's continuing struggle to project a winning message and image.

title: Anti-Discrimination Proposal Delays Senate Vote on Bill Opposing Same-Sex Marriage
description: The Senate today postponed a vote on a bill to bar Federal recognition of same-sex marriages after Republicans and Democrats failed to agree on which amendments could be offered to the bill.

title: To Morris and His Media Deals: Just Say No
description: To the Editor:

title: Ljuba Welitsch, 83, Is Dead; Soprano and Vivid 'Salome'
description: Ljuba Welitsch, the flame-haired Bulgarian-born soprano whose career was highlighted by her debut at the Metropolitan Opera in ''Salome'' in 1949, died on Monday in a hospital in Vienna. Miss Welitsch, who had become an Austrian citizen, was 83.

title: Home Video
description: 10 Hours of the Fab Four

title: Paris Offers Scant Backing But London Is Supportive
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher did not succeed today in his effort to persuade the French to join the Americans and British in patrolling the extended flight-exclusion zone in southern Iraq, which was expanded unilaterally on Wednesday by the United States.

title: Inquiry on Patient's Suicide
description: Prompted by the suicide Wednesday by a patient at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital who had fatally stabbed his uncle, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday that a task force was being formed to examine how the state deals with people who have been charged with crimes but found unfit to stand trial or not guilty by reason of insanity. About 175 of them are currently housed in state psychiatric hospitals.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 159.46 points -- more than three-quarters of 1 percent -- at 20,220.36. On Thursday, the Nikkei gained 177.95 points.

title: Essex Bonds Are Upgraded
description: Essex County's short-term bonds have received the highest rating from Moody's Investors Service, the county said yesterday. Moody's cited newly stabilized finances under County Executive James W. Treffinger, who has cut spending by $70 million over two years, as a main reason for the MI G1 rating.

title: An Enigmatic Personality Whose Mission Was to Punish America
description: With his conviction yesterday on charges of plotting to bomb 12 U.S. airliners, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef assumes his place as the most ambitious and visible member of a new generation of terrorists.

title: S.& L.'s Had Record Profits in 2d Quarter
description: The United States savings and loan industry earned a record $1.89 billion in the second quarter, which produced the industry's best profit margin in 37 years, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Sergeant Bilko

title: Luxury Boxes for Football
description: The Jets and Giants football teams have reached a preliminary agreement with the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to build 46 luxury boxes in Giants Stadium, officials said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: ''I want to have a society based on truth. That means no longer hiding what we used to hide.''

title: Tyson Distracted Before Seldon Fight
description: The inmates are running the asylum or Don King's boxing card.

title: Schemers and Drifters, More Gray Than Noir
description: The film noir plot of ''The Big Squeeze'' unfolds in oddly bouncy fashion, which is only one of this film's maladroit touches. Written and directed with awkward exuberance by Marcus De Leon, it presents something like the hair-moussed rock-and-roll version of John Steinbeck's ''Tortilla Flat.'' But its ties to that atmospheric novel are loose at best. Perhaps meaning to do for the Highland Park area of Los Angeles what Steinbeck did for Monterey, Mr. De Leon creates a group of quarrelsome schemers and then gives them nowhere to go.

title: Art in Review
description: Polly Apfelbaum

title: To Morris and His Media Deals: Just Say No
description: To the Editor:

title: Independent Booksellers Defy the Cyberniche
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Cuban and Exile Leader Debate on Television

title: Education Gap Between Races Closes
description: After steadily improving their educational performance for five decades, young blacks are for the first time getting high school diplomas in roughly the same proportions as young whites, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Sampras Survives Gut-Wrenching Five-Setter
description: Pete Sampras could not have chosen a worse afternoon to take up sleepwalking.

title: Surrogate's Court Primaries
description: Next Tuesday's Democratic primary elections for the obscure but powerful post of Surrogate's Court judge in Manhattan and Brooklyn have sparked intense competition and bitter debates over personality and patronage. Voters need to decide which of the candidates have the best mix of integrity, expertise, judicial temperament and administrative skills for a job that entails overseeing wills, estates and adoptions and dispensing millions of dollars in fees to lawyers acting as executors, guardians and estate trustees.

title: Gone With Communism Is One Team's Character
description: Ronald Reagan called the former Soviet Union the evil empire, and few would dispute that it had some flaws. But that Russian-based, Communist-led nation also had a certain mystique, especially in hockey.

title: Stone Blocking Out the Criticism
description: He doesn't wear his $10,000 Super Bowl ring. Smart move. No Giants player wants to see a Cowboys' ring in the locker room, especially when the team is preparing to meet Dallas on Sunday. Besides, Ron Stone said, he only wears it on special occasions, and going to practice doesn't quite qualify.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 29 about Yasir Arafat's call for a general strike to protest Israeli policies misstated the amount that the Canadian Government had donated to a Palestinian day-care center in Jerusalem that the Israelis demolished. It was about $22,000, not $30 million.

title: Pitt Recruit Fighting N.C.A.A. Ruling
description: A Pittsburgh running back recruit is appealing a National Collegiate Athletic Association ruling that would keep him from playing this season because of a class he took as a high school freshman.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Drop in Auto Sales Hints at Weak 2d Half

title: White House Seeks $300 Million for Airport Bomb Detection and Other Safety Measures
description: The White House, responding to the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, is preparing to ask Congress for a $300 million emergency appropriation to improve air safety, mostly for the purchase of bomb detection equipment to be installed in more than 50 airports nationwide.

title: German Economy Showing Modest Strength
description: The German economy grew more strongly than expected in the second quarter, the Government said today, but an increase in unemployment suggested that the recovery was not yet robust enough to create jobs or fuel inflation.

title: In Streets of Scarred, Darkened Kurdish City, Fear and Jubilation Mingle
description: Overrun by a Kurdish faction backed by Iraqi military might five days ago, the city of Erbil lay dark and somber this evening, lacking electricity, water and the verve that once kept its fabled souk lively deep into the night, residents of the city said.

title: Preservation on the Net
description: To the Editor:

title: In Polyglot Queens, Overflowing Melting Pot Adds to Pupils' Obstacles
description: Nazma Agwan held her son Pervez, 5, with one hand and a bassinet containing her 1-month-old son, Ahsan, in the other as she stood fourth in a long line of parents registering their children at Public School 69 in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday morning. Mrs. Agwan had waited until the last minute because she was busy taking care of her newborn and her husband worked all day, ''6 to 11,'' she said, at a candy store.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Olivetti Denies Ex-Official's Charge
description: Olivetti S.p.A. said yesterday that comments by its former chief operating officer, Renzo Francesconi, raising doubts about the truthfulness of the company's accounting were ''totally unfounded'' and said it might take legal action. Mr. Francesconi resigned Wednesday night, saying that Olivetti, the Italian computer company, had not stated the full extent of its half-year losses. His resignation came just a day after Carlo de Benedetti stepped down as chairman.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT ELLSWORTH, the dealer and collector of Asian art, took off for Beijing yesterday, but it was no routine journey -- not even for an admirer of Chinese calligraphy.

title: Behind an Internet Message Service's Close
description: Pressure from the Church of Scientology International was at least partly responsible for the recent shutdown of a well-known Internet messaging service based in Helsinki, according to the Finnish operator of the service.

title: Law on Rights Allowed Inmate To Wear Belt Used in Suicide
description: Like all inmates awaiting trial on Rikers Island, Angel Diaz was wearing his street clothes in his jail cell because of standards established in Federal court almost two decades ago.

title: Most Americans Support Clinton on Iraq
description: A majority of Americans, including majorities of Republicans and Democrats, support President Clinton's decision to launch a cruise missile attack against military targets in Iraq, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: The Talk of Teheran
description: The first thing you notice when you arrive in Teheran is that it has its own time zone -- really. It isn't eight hours from New York and it's not nine hours. No, when you land you are told to set your watch eight and a half hours from New York. Never seen that before, but it's an early sign that this is definitely its own unique place. Nowhere is that more true than when you try to answer the question: How do Iran's rulers rule?

title: Viacom and Chief to Buy Back Up to $500 Million of Its Stock
description: Viacom Inc. announced a stock repurchase plan yesterday under which it and its chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, as well as a company he controls plan to buy up to $500 million in Viacom stock.

title: Lebed, Snubbed in Moscow, Is Cheered at Rally in Chechnya
description: The crowd chanted, ''Lebed! Lebed!'' as the Russian security adviser addressed hundreds of Chechen women, children and rebels in this war-torn town 30 miles south of Grozny.

title: For Adelphi's President, A Honeymoon Gone Sour
description: The same faculty that is pressing for the removal of Peter Diamandopoulos as president of Adelphi University had welcomed him and his vision for a new curriculum when he took office in 1985, the faculty's leader testified yesterday.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Playing Hero in More Ways Than One

title: A Crusade for $100 Campaign Gifts
description: Charles W. Juntikka apologizes every time he uses a military analogy, but only because it offends his own liberal sensibilities.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Up Close and Personal

title: Testing the Limits of Camp
description: A crucial tenet of the camp esthetic holds that we are all mud-spattered brothers and sisters in the sludge heap of popular culture. A good comic wallow in the trough of bad taste is supposed to be a purgative, liberating immersion that transcends all sexual and social taboos and permits anything to be said.

title: Not Appreciating the Humor
description: Those ad agencies have done it again. A Hawaii-based sunglasses company has had a laugh at New Jersey's expense, with a magazine advertisement depicting big-haired ''Gert and Irene.'' ''To protect yourself from ozone depletion,'' the ad says, ''either wear our sunglasses or ask all those ladies in Jersey to stop using so much hair spray.'' Assemblywoman Loretta Weinberg, Democrat of Teaneck, said she did not appreciate the joke. ''I didn't recognize either Gert or Irene as a stereotype of any of the very au courant women I know in this state,'' she said in a letter to the company, Maui Jim. Noelle Baker, vice president of the Schiller Group, the agency that handled the account, said no offense was intended. ''This is part of the ad campaign in which we used humor to show the benefits of the product to protect your eyes. We didn't mean to hurt anyone's feelings,'' she said. The ad, which ran from May to August, is not expected to run again, she said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Holtz Says Irish Fumbles Will Not Be Tolerated
description: Somewhere between here and South Bend, Ind., between late Thursday night and this morning, Notre Dame's sense of relief immediately after a surprisingly narrow 14-7 victory over Vanderbilt was replaced by the harsh responsibilities of playing football for the Irish, at the highest stakes.

title: Judge Keeps Bronx Factory Open to Allow Talks
description: The Farberware factory in the South Bronx, which was scheduled to close yesterday, got a short lease on life when a judge ordered a New Jersey-based company to keep the plant open at least until Monday.

title: Idolized and Despised, A Felon Makes a Debut, And Acting Isn't at Issue
description: Mop-haired, ruggedly handsome, with the energy of an athlete and the charm of a scoundrel, Bernard Tapie has always fascinated the French, during both his flamboyant rise to fame as a wealthy industrialist, soccer team owner and leftist politician and more recently his dramatic fall from grace for committing several crimes.

title: GENZYME PLANS TO BUY NEOZYME II FOR $109 MILLION
description: The Genzyme Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy the Neozyme II Corporation for $45 a unit, or about $109 million in cash. The acquisition protects Genzyme shareholders from dilution of their interest because Neozyme units include Genzyme stock warrants. Genzyme has an option to buy Neozyme, which is headed by Genzyme's chief executive, Henri Termeer, that expires at the end of the year. If Genzyme did not exercise the option, Neozyme would have been free to sell the gene therapy technology it is developing to treat cystic fibrosis. Holders of Neozyme units would also have been able to exercise warrants for Genzyme shares. The units gained 68.75 cents yesterday, to $44.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Giuliani on Overcrowding in the Schools
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's remarks at City Hall yesterday about overcrowding in the New York City public schools, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7

title: Mayor Critical of Report on Outlaw Drivers
description: The Giuliani administration yesterday criticized a report that found that nearly 1,200 city workers who are authorized to drive city vehicles, including members of the Police and Fire Departments, did not have valid driver's licenses.

title: Raising Hope About Schools
description: I don't know how many television programs I've watched over the years announcing victories in the classroom, but the number is doubtless higher than many second-graders can count. Yet generations of children continue to come out of schools, particularly in the inner cities, with a major in ignorance. It's enough to stir skepticism, along with despair.

title: INSIDE
description: Storms Imperil Crash Site

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article yesterday about a stylist who prepares food for magazine photo sessions was omitted from some editions. The complete article is reprinted today on page 27.

title: Sampras Sends Word: He's 'Physically Fine'
description: The good news for those allegedly partisan United States Open officials who created pandemonium with their selective seeding is that there are three Americans in the semifinals. The bad news is that the last time the host country sent three of its own to the final four, the solitary foreigner, Stefan Edberg, won the 1992 title.

title: From the Battlefront
description: To the Editor:

title: Turner's Pay Is Lower Than Was Expected
description: Ted Turner, the chairman of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., will receive a much lower pay package than had been anticipated after Time Warner Inc. acquires his company.

title: Well, It Creates Jobs
description: But surely the terrorists have already won. The best that terrorism can ever hope for is to sow fear, confusion and panic widely enough to make us uncomfortable with the world we inhabit and, so, force us to change it.

title: Butler Back After Battle With Cancer
description: The only evidence was a scar the shape of Texas.

title: The Cost of Electricity Per Species
description: Government, hoping to conserve fish species, has long put restrictions on sport and commercial fishermen -- limits on seasons, gear, catch, size and fishing locations. But it has failed to curb the truly voracious and indiscriminate fishermen: power plants.

title: Promise Versus Reality
description: MARTINA Hingis's dream match with Steffi Graf ended almost before it began yesterday, after a tantalizing taste of action. When the United States Open semifinal was postponed until today because of rain, Hingis, the 15-year-old phenom, led the first set by one game to none.

title: Flatley Staying in New York, as a Ranger
description: The Islanders will pay Patrick Flatley about $600,000 not to play for them this season. That's the buyout price on the contract of their former captain, released this summer after 13 seasons.

title: Kemp Courts Harlem Voters With Open Arms, Little Hope
description: Jack Kemp came to Harlem yesterday, the first Republican in at least half a century to take a Presidential campaign directly to the country's historical wellspring of black political power.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: About the Funds Tables
description: The mutual fund tables today omit prices for 372 funds, including many from Merrill Lynch, Smith Barney and Dreyfus. The funds were unable to report their net asset values to the National Association of Securities Dealers because a fiber optic cable was cut off by Hurricane Fran.

title: Iraqi Offensive Into Kurdish Zone Disrupts U.S. Plot to Oust Hussein
description: Saddam Hussein's assault on the Kurdish zone in northern Iraq has undermined a covert operation by the Central Intelligence Agency aimed at overthrowing the Iraqi leader, senior Administration officials say.

title: Officials Try to Save TV Crime Show
description: Law-enforcement officers are asking the Fox television network to reconsider its cancellation of ''America's Most Wanted,'' arguing that the prime-time show serves as an all-points-bulletin beamed into millions of households and has helped capture more than 400 fugitives from justice in the last eight years.

title: Montana's Senate Race Focuses on Money, Whose and How It Was Spent
description: It is hard to spend campaign money in Montana, except to charter planes to fly long distances, but that has not stopped Senator Max Baucus and Lieut. Gov. Dennis Rehberg from arguing about each other's cash.

title: Seldon Takes His Jabs And Plots His Strategy
description: If this were a decathlon, Mike Tyson would be the underdog. But this is a world championship fight, and the underdog is a 6-foot-1-inch rock who has run track, swum the 200-meter freestyle and dunked a basketball from a standing position.

title: A Determined Seles Tops Martinez to Reach Her 4th Open Final
description: One player was content to compete. The other was not.

title: Talks on TV Plant's Sale
description: Philips Electronics N.V. is in talks with a ''potential buyer'' for its television plant in Greeneville, Tenn. A spokesman for the Dutch company declined to elaborate on the potential suitor or price asked. The plant would continue to produce Philips television sets, the spokesman said. It employs about 2,000.

title: COCA-COLA TO ACQUIRE 6% STAKE IN CHILEAN BOTTLER
description: The Coca-Cola Company agreed yesterday to buy a 6 percent stake in Chile's largest Coke bottler, Embotelladora Andina S.A., expanding its hold on Latin America's soft-drink market. In exchange, Coke will sell Andina 79 percent of the Argentine bottler Inti S.A. Industrial y Comercial, and all of Complejo Industrial PET, a maker of plastic bottles. ''At today's market prices, the 6 percent stake is worth about $127 million,'' said William Landers, an analyst at Lehman Brothers in New York. The transaction, scheduled to be completed in December, will give Coca-Cola a seat on Andina's board and the potential to increase its stake to 20 percent.

title: Move to Censure Iraq Fails
description: Britain today abandoned efforts to pass a resolution critical of Iraq for its attack on the Kurdish town of Erbil a week ago.

title: $46 MILLION STOCK-AND-DEBT BID FOR UTILITY SUPPLY
description: The United States Filter Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Utility Supply Group from CGW Southeast Partners for $22 million in stock and $24 million in assumed debt. Utility Supply, based in Waco, Tex., provides water- and wastewater-related products and services to industrial and municipal customers. It had revenues of about $157 million for the year ended Dec. 31. United States Filter, based in Palm Desert, Calif., is a maker of water and sewage treatment systems. Its shares rose $1.375, to $25.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Clinton Passes Muster of Masters of Oratory
description: Out in the crowd listening to President Clinton come and plead for re-election, Annie Harris, a preacher's wife and a connoisseur of good oratory, leaned back with a show-me, tell-me smile and watched Mr. Clinton take over a microphone still smoking from the previous speaker's star performance.

title: Hi. My Name Is Lake.
description: To the Editor:

title: Textile Sanctions Imposed on China
description: The Clinton Administration imposed sanctions against China today affecting $19 million in textile and apparel exports, saying China had violated a 1994 trade agreement.

title: Oilers Trade Thornton for Kovalenko
description: The Edmonton Oilers acquired right wing ANDREI KOVALENKO from the Montreal Canadiens yesterday for left wing SCOTT THORNTON, 25. Kovalenko, 26, who is playing for Russia in the World Cup, has a year left on a two-year contract he signed with the Colorado Avalanche. (AP)

title: For Carmen Miranda, With Fruit, of Course
description: With feathers and sequins and (simulated) fruit, a tribute to Carmen Miranda wound up the season for Lincoln Center Out of Doors. On Wednesday night at Damrosch Park, Brazilian musicians revived the Miranda repertory, updating the music but holding on to the high spirits.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal to cut the Long Island Lighting Company's electric rates misstated the number of jobs eliminated by the company in recent years. It is 1,000, not 100.

title: Shirtless, Near Middle Age And Comfortably Vulgar
description: To put the supergroup the Neurotic Outsiders in its proper context, you must at least have passing familiarity with an Aaron Spelling TV series or Movieline magazine. They're pure Hollywood, honestly and comfortably vulgar, and castaways from once-hugely popular acts: Steve Jones and Duff McKagan, grizzled guitarists formerly with the Sex Pistols and Guns 'n' Roses; still baby-faced John Taylor, formerly a bassist with Duran Duran, and the drummer Matt Sorum, also once in Guns 'n' Roses.

title: Canal Plus Is in a Deal For Nethold
description: Canal Plus S.A. of France said today that it would acquire Nethold B.V. of the Netherlands in a $1.6 billion deal that would cement its position as Europe's biggest pay-television operator.

title: India Sets Measures To Aid Stock Market
description: The Indian Finance Minister, P. Chidambaram, announced a package of tax relief measures yesterday aimed at helping India's stock markets, which have suffered after his budget was introduced in July. He exempted all investments in mutual funds from capital gains taxes and doubled the amount investors could borrow from banks against shares to one million rupees ($28,570).

title: Rival Kurds Can't Decide Who's Loyal
description: Seeking to contradict reports that their operations in northern Iraq had been demolished, officials of the Iraqi National Congress said today that they expect to resume soon their broadcasts calling for the overthrow of Saddam Hussein.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a Turkish military offensive against Kurdish rebel bases in northern Iraq misidentified the subject and the age of the picture. The guerrillas were members of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan or P.U.K., a group made up of Kurds living in Iraq that was not the target of the Turkish offensive; the target was the Kurdistan Workers Party or P.K.K., a group composed of Turkish Kurds. The picture was made in 1995, not this week.

title: Braves Use Mets To Right Themselves
description: The Braves need not have worried about the five-game losing streak they carried into tonight's game. After all, they were returning from their worst road trip since 1992 to play the Mets, a team noted for solving everyone's troubles but its own.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Still Mumbling and Disheveled, Accused Mob Leader Appears in Court
description: A week after a judge ruled that he was faking insanity, a gaunt and disheveled Vincent Gigante stumbled into a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday, trembling and moving his lips incessantly, as he was arraigned on charges that he was a powerful Mafia boss who had ordered murders and led lucrative rackets.

title: Dow Gains 52.90 as Fears Over Rate Rise Are Eased
description: Stocks bounded higher yesterday, following the release of August nonfarm payroll data that eased investor fears that corporate profits would be hurt by a Federal Reserve decision to raise interest rates.

title: Police Break In on Patient's Meeting With Kevorkian for an Assisted Suicide
description: The police today stopped Dr. Jack Kevorkian from videotaping an interview with a patient who wanted him to help her commit suicide.

title: LG of South Korea Plans Europe and Russia Deals
description: LG Group of South Korea said yesterday that it would invest $2.5 billion to build factories, develop natural resources and offer telecommunications services in Central Europe and Russia by 2000.

title: G.O.P. Lawmaker Considers Calling Ex-Clinton Strategist
description: The House Republican who is leading an investigation into the White House's improper acquisition of as many as 900 confidential F.B.I. files said today that he might soon subpoena Richard Morris to testify about whether Hillary Rodham Clinton had had a role in the matter.

title: Taking a Stand Against Disney And Its World
description: DISNEY'S blitz marches on, its beachheads surging into shopping strips, playgrounds and schools filled with kiddie troops wearing the uniforms of Pocahontas and Quasimodo. Some days you have to wonder if we'll all wind up taking orders from the Mouse.

title: Chicago Seven Reunion Wasn't Just Nostalgic
description: To the Editor:

title: Cozza Will Retire From Yale After Season
description: CARM COZZA, who has graced Yale's sideline for more than three decades and coached the Elis to 10 Ivy League football championships, confirmed this will be his final season, The Yale Daily News reported yesterday. ''It was a very difficult decision for me,'' Cozza, 66, told the school newspaper. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A photography review in Weekend yesterday about ''The New American Ghetto'' misstated the address of the Municipal Art Society, where the show is on view through Sept. 25. It is at 457 Madison Avenue, not Park Avenue.

title: Civil Court Choices
description: There are five Civil Court judgeships at stake in New York City's Democratic primaries next Tuesday. The winners are almost certain to prevail in the general election. Here are our choices.

title: JOBLESS RATE FELL TO 5.1% IN AUGUST, LOWEST IN 7 YEARS
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell to a seven-year low of 5.1 percent in August and hourly earnings posted their second healthy increase in three months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A Father Says, 'I Wasn't There'
description: Child welfare officials are still trying to figure out how 4-year-old Nadine Lockwood was starved to death as city agencies and other organizations stood by. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has said that the hard questions being asked of caseworkers should first be put to Nadine's family. He asks, ''What did the father know, and when did he know it?''

title: Uneasiness in Camden
description: The restructuring of the Campbell Soup Company will have little direct effect on Camden since only 35 of the employees who work at company headquarters live in the city, Camden's top economic development official said yesterday. But the company's announcement that it would lay off 175 of its 1,700 Camden-based employees could have grave symbolic import in a city with an unemployment rate higher than 16 percent, said Thomas A. Roberts, executive director of the Camden Redevelopment Agency. ''It does not send a real positive signal to other businesses that we might try to attract,'' he said.

title: Pope Arrives in Hungary To an Ecumenical Letdown
description: It was supposed to have been a moment heavy with symbolism and history, a crack in an ancient wall dividing East and West in Europe.

title: Senate Weighs Bill on Gay Rights on the Job
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

title: Fielder Pours It On With Two Homers in Victory
description: Cecil Fielder wasn't watered down. He was straight up and strong in the rain last night.

title: What Lies Beyond the Finish Line?
description: Given that he is a lame duck, a badly trounced Presidential candidate and, as an abortion rights backer, a sometimes divisive misfit within the Republican Party, Gov. Pete Wilson should be easing into the political sunset, by most reckonings.

title: Stocks and Bonds Stage a Surprising Rally on Jobs Data
description: A healthy August jobs report led to a surprising rally in the bond and stock markets yesterday, although the employment data seemed to convince more analysts and investors that the Federal Reserve was likely to raise short-term interest rates later this month.

title: A Storm Delay for Dole
description: Bob Dole canceled his trip to New Jersey yesterday, saying he did not want to tie up the police and emergency workers who might be needed to cope with the remnants of Hurricane Fran. But his campaign office said the Republican Presidential nominee is almost certain to visit the Switlik Parachute Company soon. ''We'll have more warning next time,'' said Richard J. Switlik Jr., president of the family-owned company, which was once the largest parachute manufacturer in the country. The Switliks had less than 48 hours to prepare for the visit, shutting down a production floor, putting the life rafts and vests it now manufactures on display and arranging for employees and local suppliers to meet Mr. Dole.

title: Hard Market Grows Harder for Musician Soloists
description: To the Editor:

title: Schroders of Britain Posts 35% Profit Rise
description: The British merchant bank Schroders P.L.C. said yesterday that pretax profit rose 35 percent in the first half, but the bank's chairman said lofty stock markets make the outlook for the second half uncertain. Schroders said it earned $:115.9 million in the first half, up from $:85.6 million in the first half of 1995. (AP)

title: New Law, New Hope In Kiryas Joel Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Murray Hits 500th Homer to Join Elite Group
description: On the same date that Cal Ripken Jr. surpassed Lou Gehrig one year ago, Eddie Murray last night joined Hank Aaron and Willie Mays.

title: Under My Skin
description: I am a person of color or at least that is how people often categorize me. Yet what do they mean by that?

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Shot on S.I. Expressway
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was in stable condition last night after being shot while riding in a car on the Staten Island Expressway as he and his partner headed for work, the police said.

title: What's in a Name? Oddly, City Conceives Museum
description: Good Armagnac and a swashbuckling musketeer tradition are what this charming little town in Gascony would like to be known for, and in France it has been since the mid-19th century.

title: Taylor Released From Hospital
description: The former Ohio State basketball coach FRED TAYLOR was released from a hospital in Columbus, Ohio, yesterday. Taylor, 71, underwent surgery for an aneurysm April 30. Taylor's wife, EILEEN, said he will continue his rehabilitation at home. (AP)

title: New Plaque Affixed to Statue of Liberty
description: It's not exactly ''your tired, your poor, your huddled masses.'' It's a ''Peace-Blossom'' poem, and the author is one Sri Chinmoy, the leader of a spiritual group that believes that athletic feats -- long-distance somersaulting, for instance -- are a means to transcendence.

title: Augustine A. Mandino, 72, Motivational Writer
description: Augustine A. Mandino, an insurance salesman who with one book, ''Greatest Salesman in the World,'' was propelled into a long career as a popular motivational writer and speaker, died on Tuesday. He was 72.

title: Toomer Shakes Jitters And Catches On Fast
description: Even for pro football veterans, the half-hour before a game can be torment. They fret, they sweat and sometimes they surrender their pre-game meal.

title: Axa Adds to Its Stake In French Insurer
description: The holding company Axa Groupe said yesterday that it had bought Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A.'s 10.8 percent stake in the French insurer Axa S.A. for 5.9 billion francs ($1.16 billion). Axa Groupe already owns a minority stake in Axa S.A. Generali acquired the stake in January when it converted its indirect holding in Axa S.A. to a direct holding. Axa S.A. raised 5.9 billion francs through the offering in January and February.

title: Rejoicing in Housing
description: For years, the parishioners of the Smyrna Missionary Baptist Church hoped to see affordable housing on the vacant lots surrounding their church in Newark's Central Ward. But before that could be accomplished, the sanctuary collapsed and the church was demolished. The Rev. Francis Gilliard and others persevered, and now they have something to celebrate. Yesterday, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and others visited the new Horizon Village, a $4.1 million complex of 27 two-family homes for low-income families. The $79,900 homes, which come with three-bedroom rental apartments, were built with the help of the state Urban Homeownership Program, the City of Newark, Summit Bank and JP Affordable Housing, a developer, said Angela Crawford, a spokeswoman for Newark.

title: Summit Dismisses Chief Executive
description: Summit Technology Inc. said today that it had dismissed David Muller, the company's founder and chief executive, amid rising losses, a Federal inquiry and a plunging stock price.

title: 46 Pupils, 43 Chairs, and One Teacher Fighting to Be Heard
description: Derrick Reid, 6, closed his eyes and cupped a palm over each of his ears.

title: Clinton Urges a Jobs Role on Churches
description: President Clinton today called on churches to lead the way in hiring welfare recipients, saying, ''We cannot create a Government jobs program big enough to solve this whole thing.''

title: Wheelchairs Propelled by the Imagination
description: An announcement for the Mixed Ability Dance Festival '96 states that this annual event features ''artists with and without disabilities.'' The festival program that Mobility Junction Dance presented on Thursday night at the Vineyard's Dimson Theater also featured imagination.

title: For Literacy, We Need Teachers, Not Tutors
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Ellen Jones, 73, Crucial Researcher on DNA
description: Mary Ellen Jones, a biochemist whose studies of the components of DNA were part of the foundation of basic cancer research, died on Aug. 23 in Waltham, Mass. She was 73 and had lived in the Boston area for the past year.

title: Lawyers See A Plot to Sow Controversy At Adelphi
description: Lawyers for Adelphi University yesterday accused the school's critics of purposely tarnishing Adelphi's reputation as part of campus power play.

title: FRITO-LAY SAYS THAT U.S. SEEKS DOCUMENTS IN INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department has asked Frito-Lay Inc. to provide documents as part of its investigation of possible anticompetitive practices in the $15 billion salty-snacks industry, according to an internal company memo. The letter, sent by Frito-Lay's general counsel, Art Starrs, on Aug. 22, instructed about 10,000 of the company's managers not to delete any computer files or discard any documents or correspondence until it was clear exactly what information the Justice Department wanted. The department initiated its investigation of Frito-Lay, a unit of Pepsico Inc. and the world's largest maker of pretzels and potato chips, this spring, questioning several of Frito-Lay's rivals before talking to Frito-Lay.

title: A Terrorist, Not a Defense Lawyer
description: In the end, it may have been Ramzi Ahmed Yousef's own ego that helped convict him of plotting to blow up American jetliners in Asia, a crime that may keep him in prison for the rest of his life. Much of the evidence against him was circumstantial, collected halfway around the world in the Philippines. But Mr. Yousef supplied the most damaging evidence himself, then further weakened his case by acting as his own lawyer.

title: Unafraid Of Emotion And Play
description: Jazz still suffers under the notion that it is a form that gives expression solely to a musician's emotions. But as a double bill at the Blue Note on Wednesday showed, the music can also be gestural. And finally much of its pleasure comes from its sense of play, where subtle differences in repetition or in the music's narrative qualities, can draw a listener in.

title: Sumitomo Trust Plans to Buy 52 Planes
description: The Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company announced plans today to buy 52 passenger aircraft through two related companies from the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie for $4.2 billion.

title: Smarter Eaters
description: A long-running study of the nation's eating habits shows that Americans are consuming foods more wisely, but that less than 25 percent have a truly healthy diet.

title: Infighting Hobbles Group Opposed to Iraqi
description: Even though the Kurdish fighters controlled by Massoud Barzani battled this week alongside the army of Saddam Hussein, the dictator whom all opponents of the Iraqi Government have vowed to topple, Mr. Barzani had not been formally removed from his seat on the three-member presidential council of the main opposition organization, the Iraqi National Congress.

title: On Farms, Devastation Replaces Bounty
description: Along State Road 24 from Fayetteville east through small rural towns farmers and residents climbed onto their roofs today, chainsaws in hand, to cut through the giant tree trunks that Hurricane Fran had tossed onto their houses as it barreled 100 miles inland from the Carolina coast.

title: American Home Sells Food Unit To Hicks, Muse
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, a Dallas leveraged-buyout firm, has made its largest purchase yet, agreeing to buy the American Home Products Corporation's food division in a deal valued at $1.275 billion.

title: Trapped on Rikers Island
description: For four months Stanley (Eric) Washington has refused to plead guilty to a robbery he insists he didn't commit, even though he probably wouldn't face a day in prison if he agreed to a plea bargain. Still, the 19-year-old may relent: fear of further incarceration on Rikers Island, he told me, may overwhelm his fear of a life ruined by a felony conviction. It is an unreasonable choice that he should not have to make.

title: India Counts on Vote to Blunt Kashmir Insurgency
description: From his mansion on a hillside overlooking a lake famed for its beauty, the man who has overseen the largest Indian military operation in the 25 years since the last of India's three wars with Pakistan is preparing for what he believes will be a decisive step toward ending the Pakistani-backed Muslim insurgency here.

title: Johnson to Start in Place of Moon
description: WARREN MOON was unable to practice yesterday, which means that BRAD JOHNSON will get the first start of his National Football League career when the Minnesota Vikings play at Atlanta tomorrow. The Vikings will wait until just before game time to decide whether Moon or the No. 3 quarterback, JAY WALKER, will be Johnson's primary backup. Moon is recovering from ankle and foot injuries. (AP)

title: Corrections
