description: The Weather Report on Thursday erroneously repeated the Metropolitan Forecast and National Forecast from Wednesday's issue. The Metropolitan Almanac and the maps were correct. The Times regrets the error.

title: Spindler's Heart and Smarts
description: With his scruffy stubble and bandanna- covered head, Marc Spindler looks like one of the bad guys in a Rambo movie. He even talks like one.

title: A Food Beautician Reveals How a Nectarine Grew Fuzz
description: It is just shy of 10 A.M., and Brett Kurzweil has already been to two supermarkets, a farmers' market, a natural foods store, the Gourmet Garage and Balducci's. He is in search of the perfect garlic.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC TO SELL REALTY UNITS FOR $693 MILLION
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Marathon Realty and Centrixx Realty Holdings units for $693.3 million. The units will be sold to a newly incorporated company that will be owned equally by Oxford Properties Group Inc. of Toronto and GE Capital of Stamford, Conn., the financial services unit of the General Electric Company. Canadian Pacific, based in Montreal, said Marathon's portfolio comprises about 12 million square feet of office and retail property in Canada. The agreement does not include Marathon's United States retail assets. Oxford is a commercial real estate ownership and management company.

title: A Downtown Marathon Of Doers and Makers
description: It was hot in the theater, and the program ran three hours. But the ''Dance Now'' program on Wednesday night at the Dia Center for the Arts on Mercer Street, the first event in the mammoth four-day SoHo Arts Festival, was both a giant dance party and a model of imaginative, knowledgeable and sleek production.

title: Landfall of Hurricanes Is Mostly Laid to Chance
description: The gods do not have it in for North Carolina. It is simply that a particular conjunction of air masses that has dominated the North Atlantic this summer has pointed three hurricanes in the general direction of the Tar Heel State.

title: New South Africa Constitution Is Rejected by the High Court
description: South Africa's highest court rejected the country's new Constitution today, saying that in several areas it failed to meet the criteria agreed to in talks for a peaceful transition from an apartheid government to a non-racial democracy.

title: Chechen Rebels Trying to Act As a De Facto Government
description: Six days after the signing of a peace agreement in Chechnya, the rebels who fought the Russian Army to a standstill have begun to assert themselves as a budding government in the disputed republic.

title: Protecting Children
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate at 7-Year Low, As Hourly Earnings Rise

title: No Headline
description: ''In the Dole Administration, you'll be the drug czar.''

title: Undermining New Democracies
description: Worried about a return to the dynasties and caudillos of the past, the constitution-writers of Latin America's and Central Europe's new democracies chose parliamentary systems or limited their presidents to a single term. Now popular presidents, chafing at those limits, are carelessly fiddling with their constitutions to allow additional terms.

title: Financial Gyrations Fail to Deter Foreign Investors
description: It is among workers earning the barest of incomes that the benefits of the Real Plan, Brazil's two-year-old economic reform program, are most keenly felt.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about military activities in Iraq misstated the origin of the ban on flights over a Kurdish-populated area of northern Iraq. It was imposed by the United States, Britain and France, claiming authority under a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning the repression of Kurds and others in Iraq. The United Nations did not create the zone and disputes the assertion that the Security Council resolution authorizes one.

title: Popov Leaves Hospital After Stabbing
description: The Russian Olympic swimming champion ALEKSANDR POPOV was discharged from a Moscow hospital yesterday, almost two weeks after being stabbed in the stomach in a brawl, the Itar-Tass news agency reported. Popov, considered the world's fastest swimmer, lost some weight, but generally feels fine, the chairman of the Russian Olympic Committee, VITALY SMIRNOV, told Itar-Tass. According to the report, Popov met with Smirnov immediately after leaving the elite Moscow Clinical Hospital. (AP)

title: Life Plus 13 in Wife's Killing
description: Last December, prosecutors say, Esterlin Melendez flew into a jealous rage and forced his wife to bend over a gas stove. As he held her head perilously close to the flames, he told her, ''You'll never look at another man again,'' said Michael Ravin, an assistant prosecutor for Essex County. His wife, Gloria, pressed charges, and when she refused to drop them, Mr. Ravin said, Mr. Melendez shot her seven times outside her daughter's home, killing her. Yesterday, Mr. Melendez was sentenced to life in prison, plus 13 years.

title: HOSPITAL DATA SERVICE IN DEAL FOR SOFTWARE MAKER
description: HBO & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire privately held Management Software Inc. for about $45 million in stock. Management Software, based in Springfield, Mo., makes software for the home health care industry and has annual revenue of $15 million. HBO & Company, also based in Springfield, provides information services like billing and patient tracing, mainly to hospitals. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of the month. HBO & Company's stock jumped $3.125, to $53.635, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Measures for Aviation Security
description: The Presidential commission on aviation safety and security has moved with surprising speed to develop recommendations to make airports and airliners safer from sabotage and terrorism. The panel, formed under the chairmanship of Vice President Gore after the Trans World Airlines explosion in July, held its first public meeting this week, and Mr. Gore promptly outlined a broad array of proposals that would be included in a preliminary report to President Clinton on Monday. That will prompt a request to Congress for a quick $300 million, mostly to buy bomb detection equipment for more than 50 airports.

title: Right: Let the States Make Abortion Decisions
description: To the Editor:

title: For Ankara, a Chance To Hit Kurdish Rebels
description: The latest conflict in Iraq has burdened neighboring Turkey with new economic and political problems, but it has also given the Turkish Army a chance to strike out once again at Kurds in northern Iraq who have been fighting for more than a decade to build an independent homeland in Turkey.

title: Company Briefs
description: CITADEL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC., Dallas, said it would acquire the Tabworks software line from Xerox Corp.'s Xsoft unit. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Storms Shift Sands, Possibly Covering Up T.W.A. Crash Evidence
description: Some waves spawned by back-to-back hurricanes in the Atlantic over the last 10 days were large enough to stir up sand on the sea floor around the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, possibly burying valuable evidence, oceanographers and underwater search experts said yesterday.

title: Patsyprospect Wins Opener
description: Belmont opened its fall meeting in relative privacy yesterday, with only 6,337 spectators watching Patsyprospect win the Gen. Douglas MacArthur Handicap.

title: Down on Drumming
description: To the Editor:

title: 17 Die as Hurricane Slashes Across the Southeast
description: The remnants of Hurricane Fran brought heavy rain and fears of flooding to central North Carolina and Virginia today as the death count from the vicious but highly capricious storm rose to 17 in the Carolinas, Virginia and West Virginia.

title: Can Unemployment Fall Further Without Setting Off Inflation?
description: Beyond the clear political gain it represents for President Clinton, the decline in unemployment to its lowest level in seven years has focused added attention on an issue that increasingly dominates policy debates and financial markets: whether the economy has changed so fundamentally in recent years that it can accommodate a lower rate of unemployment, and the resulting wage increases, without reigniting inflation.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: Russia Defeats Finland
description: Russia reached the final four of hockey's World Cup tournament tonight by beating Finland, 5-0, in businesslike fashion at the Corel Centre. Russia (2-2) will play the unbeaten United States here Sunday night in a semifinal game.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER

title: Police Suspect Link to Sex Ring : Belgians See Break In Politician's Killing
description: BRUSSELS  In 1991, Andre Cools, a former deputy prime minister, was gunned down outside his girlfriend's apartment, the opening chapter of an intrigue that has cast a pall of suspicion over Belgium's entire political class.

title: Term Limit Question Called Deceptive
description: When New Yorkers step into the voting booth on Nov. 5, they will face the usual array of candidates for Federal and state offices. But they will also be presented with a 137-word ballot question on term limits that opponents say has been deliberately made dense in hopes of confusing voters enough to win approval.

title: Another Office Is Issue In Surrogate Court Race
description: The primary election race for an obscure but important judgeship, Manhattan surrogate, has become embroiled in a debate over an even more arcane office, that of the public administrator.

title: Striking Iraq Isn't The End Of It
description: The American military has succeeded in containing Saddam Hussein in the south of Iraq, where it counts. It has also extended the no-flight zone to the outskirts of Baghdad, putting American planes in range of the regime's nerve center and further bottling up Mr. Hussein's military.

title: Ticket Policy in Case of Rain
description: On an ominously cloudy day when rain first hit conveniently between the men's doubles final and the start of the women's semifinal slate, then later postponed the Steffi Graf-Martina Hingis match after one game, the United States Open yesterday announced its rain cancellation policy for the weekend matches.

title: M.M. Feldman, 81, New York City Manager
description: Maurice Milton Feldman, one of the cadre of highly educated Depression-era recruits who ran New York City's municipal services with rare professional distinction for decades, died on Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 81 and had been an acting sanitation commissioner and a commissioner of water resources.

title: Real Architects Know About Real Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 2 Employees Charged in Garbage Truck Thefts
description: Yesterday, almost four years after 11 New York City garbage trucks disappeared, two sanitation workers were arrested and charged with helping a scrap metal dealer steal them, and with plotting to steal 10 more.

title: Ferry to Link Wall St. Area And East Side
description: Upper East Siders headed to lower Manhattan have long had to contend with an overcrowded commute: the Nos. 4, 5 and 6 carry about half of the subway system's 3.5 million daily riders. The Lexington Avenue bus line hauls 50,000 people along what the Transit Authority considers the most congested route in the city.

title: Value of S.A.T. Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Instruments To Aid Anam's Growth
description: The Anam Group of South Korea said yesterday that it would invest $3 billion by 2002 to produce nonmemory semiconductors with technical assistance from Texas Instruments.

title: Bridge
description: An international tournament with a world dimension begins this weekend in Beijing. It is sponsored by Marlboro and has a prize fund of $80,000. In the Open Teams there will be strong entries from Poland, France, the United States and several other countries.

title: Insurers Say Storm's Damage Will Probably Top $1 Billion
description: Hurricane Fran's damage to the Carolinas and neighboring states is likely to exceed $1 billion, insurance industry experts said yesterday, an estimate that puts the storm in the ranks of some other recent disasters, although not among the most severe.

title: Real Architects Know About Real Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: BELLSOUTH BEGINS BUYBACK THAT IT ANNOUNCED EARLIER
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it had begun a stock buyback that its board authorized six months ago, taking advantage of a recent slide in its price to buy cheaply. Atlanta-based BellSouth, the largest regional Bell operating company, did not say how many shares it would buy or how much it would spend on the repurchase program. As of June 30, it had 994 million shares outstanding and 1.12 million shareholders, making BellSouth's stock the second-most widely held in the United States, behind the AT&T Corporation. BellSouth's shares have fallen 17 percent since July 3. They closed yesterday at $36.125, up 50 cents.

title: Rose Williams, 86, Sister And the Muse of Playwright
description: Rose Williams, Tennessee Williams's sister, who was the model for Laura Wingfield, the shy, lame young woman in ''The Glass Menagerie,'' died on Thursday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 86, and had moved to the hospital from the Bethel Methodist Home in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Frederick Rope, 81, Who Demystified U.N.
description: Frederick T. Rope, a retired diplomat who was a spokesman for the American Mission to the United Nations in the 1950's, died on Thursday in Burlington, Vt. He was 81 and lived in Westford, Vt.

title: Beliefs
description: The Religion Newswriters Association is a professional association of about 200 reporters who cover religion for the secular press. Every year members gather to give one another prizes, socialize and trade stories about their editors pretty much the way early Christians gossiped about the temperaments of various lions.

title: Meticulous With the Frenzy, Or, Misery Loves Discipline
description: After two years on the arena circuit, Nine Inch Nails renewed its alternative-rock credentials with a packed, club-size show at Irving Plaza on Thursday night. As part of the CMJ Music Marathon, Nine Inch Nails topped the bill in a showcase for Trent Reznor's label, Nothing. Mr. Reznor records as Nine Inch Nails, adding other musicians for his touring band. Meanwhile, as a mogul, Mr. Reznor has built Nothing in his own image. The other Nothing acts that performed -- including Marilyn Manson and Pop Will Eat Itself -- all share his taste for paranoid rants and pitiless noise.

title: GAN to Sell Reinsurer To Canadian Company
description: The French insurer GAN agreed yesterday to sell its reinsurance unit Compagnie Transcontinentale de Reassurance to the Canadian company Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. for 700 million francs ($137.9 million). GAN said the disposal was part of a strategy to refocus on core activities. For Fairfax, ''this purchase offers an opportunity to get a significant foothold in the reinsurance market in Europe,'' GAN said. (Reuters)

title: Fox Broadcasting Replaces Executive
description: In a long-expected move, Fox Broadcasting yesterday announced that John Matoian will leave his position as president of Fox Entertainment. He will be replaced by Peter Roth, who for two years has been president of 20th Century Fox Television, the television production arm of the Fox studio.

title: Harald N. Johnson Dies at 89; Was an Expert on Pathogens
description: Dr. Harald N. Johnson, an internationally known expert on rabies and arthropod-borne viral diseases who was as much at home capturing dangerous animals in the field as working in the laboratory, died on Aug. 28 in South Shore Hospital in Weymouth, Mass. He was 89 and lived in nearby Scituate.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Rape Reported at Greystone
description: The day after a patient at the Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital was found hanged in a suicide, a patient at the hospital raped another, the authorities said. The Associated Press reported that the Morris County Prosecutor's office and the State Department of Human Services Police were investigating the attack, which occurred on Thursday. After the rape, the state's Human Services Commissioner, William Waldman, revoked privileges -- ranging from unsupervised walks to brief visits home -- of all patients with criminal backgrounds. Another patient, James Williams, 35, disappeared while on an unescorted walk on Monday. His body was found on Wednesday.

title: SmithKline Beecham in Settlement With U.S.
description: In the latest big settlement by a clinical laboratory company of Federal Medicare fraud charges, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. expects to pay the Government about $300 million this year, without admitting any wrongdoing. Analysts said the Laboratory Corporation of America also expects to settle similar charges by the end of the year.

title: U.S. Tries to Speed Integration of Russia in NATO
description: In a speech commemorating the American decision to promote the reintegration of a defeated Germany into the world community after World War II, Secretary of State Warren Christopher called today for a formal charter to govern NATO's relations with a new Russia.

title: REMEDY'S STOCK SURGES ON EXPECTATIONS FOR YEAR
description: The shares of the Remedy Corporation rose 19 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of help-desk software, predicted higher-than-expected 1997 revenue and wider operating margins. Remedy's stock rose $9.50, to $58, in Nasdaq trading. The company told analysts in a conference call that revenue would grow 60 to 65 percent in 1997, beating previous estimates of 50 to 54 percent because of strong international sales growth and new products. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., said margins would also improve to 26 percent from 24 percent as it cuts marketing costs by selling more products to old customers.

title: Liggett's Tobacco Settlement In Danger of Coming Undone
description: The Liggett Group, which stunned and infuriated its larger rivals in the tobacco industry in March by agreeing to settle lawsuits that involved all the companies, is negotiating to avoid being dragged back into the litigation, lawyers involved in the talks say.

title: Mary B. Newlin, 91, A Magazine Editor
description: Mary Bass Newlin, an author and former executive editor of Ladies' Home Journal, died at her home in Amagansett, L.I., on Aug. 26. She was 91.

title: Rx: Surgery With Candor
description: Boris N. Yeltsin finally admitted last week what everyone has suspected: He suffers a serious heart condition and will have a bypass operation later this month.

title: Sans Teeth
description: From time to time, curmudgeonly polemicists like Joseph Epstein proclaim that American poetry is dead. On the other hand, wide-eyed hypesters like Bill Moyers assure us that we are living through an unprecedented poetry renaissance. Which to believe? From my perspective, neither. I'm not one of those who think poetry is irrelevant because it hasn't managed to attract a mass audience: why should it be required to have one? I still count myself a fan of contemporary American poetry (even wrote two books of it myself), and I continue to teach it, read it and sit on literary panels judging the stuff. The overall level is no disgrace: we can boast a few dozen professional poets with international reputations, while in the trenches, more people are able to write a ''competent'' poem than perhaps at any other time in our country's history. Yet I cannot help feeling that contemporary American poetry is -- has been for some time -- in a holding pattern.

title: Isabelle Bleecker, David VanLuven
description: Isabelle Primavera Bleecker, a book editor, and David Erik VanLuven, an ecologist, were married yesterday in Boiceville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Linda H. Anderson, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Onteora Mountain House, a bed and breakfast.

title: Made for Each Other
description: INTO THE GREAT WIDE OPEN

title: Pope, in Hungary, Causes Renewed Speculation About His Health
description: The Vatican does its best to avoid the topic, but the health of Pope John Paul II is once again a recurring theme, not just within the Vatican press corps, but among Roman Catholics who are concerned to see their once-robust Pope looking tired and frail.

title: Miss Meltzer And Mr. Miniter
description: Gillian Erin Meltzer, the daughter of Mrs. Irving W. Meltzer of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Mr. Meltzer, was married last evening in her mother's house to Sylvester Francis Miniter 4th, the son of Catherine Ann Miniter of Annapolis, Md., and Mr. Miniter 3d of Kiawah Island, S.C. The Rev. Beverly Bell Winslow, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, performed the ceremony.

title: Teen-Agers at the Mall
description: To the Editor:

title: San Diego
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in San Diego,'' by James Sterngold (July 28), was quite informative, as far as it went. But how about the Old Globe Theater in Balboa Park? It is one of the finest regional theaters in the United States and has sent many shows to Broadway, including ''The Cocktail Party,'' ''Into the Woods,'' the recent revival of ''Damn Yankees,'' and the current off-Broadway success ''Cowgirls.''

title: Wake Up! It's Primary Time
description: ON a humid morning last week, Michael D. Benjamin stood at the entrance to the subway station at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, passing out campaign material and urging riders to vote for his candidate. Some people stopped and listened. Many simply darted by, looking more than a little annoyed. After all, Mr. Benjamin was stumping for a candidate in the Democratic primary for Brooklyn Surrogate.

title: Big Stores Invite Mega-Sparring
description: A new proposal that would allow the giant box-shaped stores that have proliferated in the suburbs to open in New York City's waning industrial areas was debated last week at a packed public hearing held by the City Planning Commission.

title: Literary Journey
description: Only a handful of the millions of books written become classics, shaping perspectives and broadening an understanding of the world. Donald Sutherland plays host for a 36-hour GREAT BOOKS FESTIVAL, which includes premieres and encores from the Learning Channel's ''Great Books'' series. Beginning SATURDAY at 9 A.M. on TLC, viewers are taken on a journey through the classics. there is Lewis Carroll's ''Alice in Wonderland,'' about a fantasy world where cats grin and a mad hatter serves tea; H.G. Wells's ''War of the Worlds'' ; Mark Twain's ''Huck Finn,'' about two runaways on the Missippi, and ''Moby-Dick,'' Herman Melville's story of The Pequod, the 19th-century whaler, and her captain and the great white whale that obsesses him.

title: Litany of Misery
description: AGE OF DELIRIUM The Decline and Fall of the Soviet Union. By David Satter. 424 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: The Season of Heartbreak, and Some Hope, at Shelters
description: Steve Dash's heart breaks every day.

title: A Master Plan for the State Seeks to Put the Individual at Its Center
description: AS THE State Council on the Arts prepares for public hearings this month on the future of the arts in New Jersey, it could point to 17-year-old Johe Guerrero as an example of how art can be a vital part of everyday life.

title: Emily R. Liman, Donald B. Arnold
description: Dr. Emily Ruth Liman, the daughter of Ellen and Arthur L. Liman of New York, is to be married today to Dr. Donald Bruce Arnold, a son of Dorothy and George Arnold of Scarborough, Ontario. Rabbi Joel S. Goor is to perform the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: Child Welfare Chief Provides A Glimpse at Decentralization
description: The head of New York City's child welfare agency wants to replace much of the vast bureaucracy responsible for protecting the city's most vulnerable children with dozens of neighborhood-based networks of churches, medical centers and social service organizations that would handle the care and monitoring of troubled families.

title: Maggie Rokous, Amor H. Towles
description: Margaret Rosemary Rokous, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Rokous of North Andover, Mass., was married yesterday to Amor Hollingsworth Towles, a son of Eleanor Hollingsworth Towles of Boston and Stokley P. Towles of Westwood, Mass. The Rev. John T. Mathison, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at South Congregational Church in Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Mark Hollingsworth, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bridegroom, took part in the ceremony.

title: Arithmetic Lesson
NEXT TARGET: NICOTINE
description: In his article ''Next Target: Nicotine'' (Aug. 4), Jeffrey Goldberg wrote that I was ''stumped'' to name particular drugs delayed by the Food and Drug Administration. This is nonsense. In the nine years that the Competitive Enterprise Institute has been involved in F.D.A. reform, it has published a series of analyses that try to answer a basic question ignored in your article: If the F.D.A. approves a therapy that will start saving lives tomorrow, then how many people died yesterday waiting for the agency to act?

title: Bathroom Liberationists
description: I'VE SEEN A FEW frightening dramas on Broadway, but nothing onstage is ever as scary as the scene outside the ladies' room at intermission: that long line of women with clenched jaws and crossed arms, muttering ominously to one another as they glare across the lobby at the cavalier figures sauntering in and out of the men's room. The ladies' line looks like an audition for the extras in ''Les Miserables'' -- these are the vengeful faces that nobles saw on their way to the guillotine -- except that the danger is all too real. When I hear the low rumble of obscenities and phrases like ''Nazi male architects'' I know not to linger. I fear that someone will someday figure out how to fit an automatic weapon inside an evening purse -- and that no jury will ever convict the perpetrator of the Men's Room Massacre.

title: And 201 Begat 908; Now What Comes Next?
description: It has been only a little more than five years since the 201 area code was split and many residents of central and northwest New Jersey had their area code changed to 908. Now, eight years early, the state needs two new area codes, in part because of fax machines, cellular telephones and modems.

title: In the Wings, a Chorus Of Home-Grown Voices
description: SILENCE, AS GARY COOPER WAS GOOD AT reminding us, is a golden American virtue. But it is of limited use to playwrights, whose principal traffic is in talk. So it is heartening to be able to look forward to a symphony of eloquent American theater voices, some of whom (we do not include the dauntingly fertile Terrence McNally) have been quiet for too many seasons.

title: I'll Take Provence
description: To the Editor:

title: Colonial Trappings, Pub Menu and More
description: FITTINGLY, the Cornwall Grille and Pub in Cheshire, installed in a 250-year-old clapboard house with a stone foundation, quietly conveys a Colonial atmosphere with its graceful metal chandelier above the stairwell, pale beige walls hung with framed prints, brass hunting horn wall sconces, captain's chairs and soft gray-green patterned carpet. A display of musical instruments hangs above the stairs leading up to the dining room from the cozy, fieldstone-walled pub at ground level. One may opt to eat in the pub itself, where it is possible to order from the regular dining room menu, not just the abridged pub menu.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19

title: Of Zeffirelli and Carmen: Memories and Reacquaintances
description: IF A NEW VERSION OF ''CARMEN'' is hardly earth-shattering, anything by Franco Zeffirelli is, at the least, news and, at the most, a massive frisson. The news is bigger yet, since Zeffirelli is returning to the Metropolitan Opera for the first time in six years, in October, to mount a new production of Bizet's opera, starring Waltraud Meier and Placido Domingo, with James Levine conducting.

title: The Black Face That's a Mirror For Everyone
description: IT IS HARD TO IMAGINE insomniac devotees of Nick at Nite being comforted by doses of Bill Cosby in the same way that they might depend on infusions of Dick Van Dyke or Mary Tyler Moore. ''The Cosby Show'' was a hit in the mid-1980's, and maybe not enough time has gone by for anyone to be nostalgic for the way things were then. Maybe some miss the boom years in these downsized times. Mr. Cosby himself is back in a new series (''Cosby,'' Mondays at 8 on CBS, starting Sept. 16) as a family man who has been laid off. Issues, issues.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: A Lucky American Childhood By Paul Engle. University of Iowa, $24.95.

title: Meet the Anti-Newt
description: I am a no-limits guy,'' says Michael Coles, Newt Gingrich's Democratic opponent for Congress. He's also an early-rising guy. It's 5:37 A.M. and Coles, a founder of the Great American Cookie Company, is pedaling a stationary bicycle in his home gym, watching CNN and monitoring his pulse. ''If you're going to handle problems all day,'' he huffs, ''it helps to start by doing something you know you can control.''

title: Dana L. Fields, Daniel F. Gearon
description: Dana Leslie Fields, a publishing executive, and Daniel Frederick Gearon, an advertising executive, were married last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated.

title: POP MUSIC
description: Here is a selective guide to coming cultural events in New York and beyond. Events that are starred are those that Times critics consider particularly noteworthy. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear on page 80.

title: Navy Runs To First Victory
description: When Navy held on to the ball, it was fine, and the Midshipmen held on long enough to grind out a 10-6 victory tonight over Rutgers.

title: The Speaker's Sister Speaks
description: THE ACCIDENTAL ACTIVIST

title: Sara E. Goodman, W. Mott Hupfel 3d
description: Sara Eugenie Goodman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Goodman of New York, was married last evening to W. Mott Hupfel 3d, the son of Alice B. Hupfel of Chadds Ford, Pa., and Mr. Hupfel Jr. of Waterford, Conn. Shirley Fingerhood, a retired State Supreme Court justice, officiated at Mr. and Mrs. Goodman's house in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: The Grand Old Man of Tanks
description: Wallace Rosenwach is on the phone, preparing for his company's 100th-birthday party at a Queens restaurant called Water's Edge. ''From there,'' he says, ''you can see the entire New York skyline.''

title: Susan Morris and Brett Holey
description: Susan Blair Morris and Brett Allen Holey were married yesterday by the Rev. Donald J. Muller at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

title: Literary Lion
description: One August night, I was having cocktails with a couple of Times reporters at the Jefferson Hotel. We were sulking about the tedium of the campaign. Little did we know, the biggest political story of the summer was unfolding right above our buttery Chardonnay.

title: Fishing for Rainbows in Semiprivate Paradise in Montana
description: The morning air smelled of warm, sweet cinnamon. Maybe it was the aroma of freshly mown hay mingling with the acres of wild mint along the bottom land of the Hanson Ranch on Sheep Creek in south central Montana. The night before, we had fished our way up a mile of lightly pressured stream and kept a few wild fish that I fried up and flaked over hash brown potatoes with peppers and frizzled onions.

title: No (Letter) Jacket Required at St. Ignatius
description: The waist-length coats are dyed the blue of new denim. Wool with leather sleeves. Sewn across their left breast is a large maize-colored 'I.' These are the varsity letter jackets of Cleveland's St. Ignatius High, a longstanding academic and athletic power located just across the Carnegie Bridge on the city's West Side.

title: Dialing France, Fingers Will Walk Farther
description: As France introduces new area codes on Oct. 18 at 11 P.M., dialing to and within France will change in many cases. There are to be five area codes: 01 for Paris and the surrounding area and 02 for the northwestern section of the country, 03 for the northeast, 04 for the southeast including Corsica and 05 for the southwest.

title: Circadian Night Football
description: Here's news that should interest scientists, football fans and (especially) pinkie-ring-wearing Las Vegas guys named Smoothie and Lucky. According to Roger Smith, a sleep-medicine specialist who just completed a fellowship at Stanford University, circadian rhythms -- fluctuations in body functions through the course of a day -- can be used with impressive accuracy to predict the outcome of Monday-night football games.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: EMELIN THEATER FAIR

title: Ensemble to Accompany Puppets
description: IT will be a while before the concert season reaches full speed, but early stirrings are apparent. Although Philharmonia Virtuosi's season does not officially begin for more than a month, players from the ensemble and the music director, Richard Kapp, will be on hand this afternoon to accompany the White Rabbit, the Flower Girl and other denizens of Paul Peabody's Old-Fashioned Marionette Theater.

title: A Modest Proposal
description: THE CASE FOR SAME-SEX MARRIAGE

title: Moroccan Ends Morceli's Streak, but Ottey and Johnson Can Still Fly
description: It has been a surprisingly rough month for the established pecking order in track and field, and although the eternal Merlene Ottey became the second-fastest woman in history and Michael Johnson strutted away as a convincing winner today in the Grand Prix final, the post-Olympic shift in the wind was again unmistakable.

title: 4-H'ers Raise the Dogs That Help the Blind to See
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridging Boundaries With His Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Cozza to Quit After 32 Years at Yale
description: Carm Cozza, the latest and the longest lasting -- in a pantheon of legendary coaches at Yale, announced today that he would step down at the end of the current football season.

title: Southern Comfort
description: When I heard that Krispy Kreme doughnuts had reached New York, and furthermore had become stylish, I hustled down to 23d Street and ate five. Don't do that. I was thinking I was 12 again, eating Krispy Kremes in Atlanta.

title: Amy A. Shipley And Dan Ligon
description: Amy Ashley Shipley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Shipley of Newark, Del., was married last evening to Jon Daniel Ligon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Ligon of Houghton, Mich. The Rev. Roy Martin performed the ceremony at the Lower Brandywine Presbyterian Church in Greenville, Del.

title: 'Coleus!' Squeaked a Voice, and One Man Listened
description: Times change. Ten years back (you know, when tuberous begonias were big), only the clueless grew coleus. They were gaudy relics from Grandmother's generation: you couldn't give a coleus away.

title: Adventurous, But Not Too
description: MODERATE, or ''soft,'' adventure trips are increasing in popularity. Leaders describe their clientele as being in their 40's or older, with women predominating. Because these trips are kept small -- a maximum of 10, 16 or sometimes 24 -- they attract people who want to make friends as well as those who are eager for an active vacation.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Heroin Moves In On a New Generation
description: SHE started taking drugs when she was 15. First it was marijuana, then she moved on to pills and cocaine. She dropped out of high school but she always worked, most often as a waitress. The woman, who lives in Fairfield County, married and divorced and got into a new relationship. When that relationship ended, nothing would take the edge off the pain she was feeling -- not the pills, nothing.

title: In Jersey City, He's Paid to Do Nothing but Watch the Clock
description: For more than 70 years, the Colgate Clock has kept time on the Jersey City riverfront across from lower Manhattan. The clock, installed on a Colgate-Palmolive factory rooftop in 1924, was moved to ground level at the edge of the Hudson River when the cosmetics giant closed its manufacturing plant in Jersey City in 1989. The company plans to keep the clock as part of a waterfront redevelopment project.

title: Irene Longstreth, Richard Hedeman
description: Irene Catlin Longstreth and Richard McIver Hedeman were married yesterday at the First Church of Christ Congregational in Sharon, Conn. The Rev. Terrence Ryan performed the ceremony. The Rev. Luther Tucker, the bride's great-uncle, who is an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: Counting All Those Wet Noses: The Census Takers' Task
description: THERE is a joke going around here these days. The punch line varies. The answer is, depending on who is asked, either ''Just my wife'' or ''Just my husband.''

title: A Cabin, a Lake, a Memory
description: LAST August I went back to visit a lake in northern Wisconsin, Rest Lake, that I had not seen in 29 years. During that time I had moved from Illinois to California to Boston to Atlanta, lived in Belgium and London, climbed the Sierras, made a dozen trips to Ireland and spent 14 summers on Cape Cod. Yet I had never forgotten the pine-fringed lake with its hard sand bottom and water so clear you could see the fist-sized tadpoles dart away from your footfall.

title: A Pair Who Picked a Plant for Packing Pickles
description: ''People ask me what I do,'' said Michael Rosenblum who, with his father, manages a Hackensack factory called Sunshine Fresh Inc. ''I say, 'I run a pickle plant.' We make pickles and sell them to delis. They always smile.''

title: Michael D. Hintze, Janet S. Chung
description: Janet Shirley Chung and Michael David Hintze, associates at Washington law firms, were married yesterday in Bluemont, Va. Judge Lee H. Rosenthal of Federal District Court in Houston performed the ceremony at Whitehall, a private house used for parties.

title: Ernest Dale, Writer on Management, 79
description: Ernest Dale, an academic, author and management consultant to leading corporations, died on Aug. 16 in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Credit-Card Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Dogs In Search Of Homes
description: CATEGORIES like ''Best Tail Wagger,'' ''Clever Canine Tricks'' and ''Heinz 57 Mixed Breed'' are not the usual ones for a dog show. But then ''Puttin' on the Dog,'' being held today from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. at Havemeyer Field behind Town Hall in Greenwich, is not the usual dog show.

title: Decision Time in Bosnia
description: The king has deployed all his horses and all his men throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina. The 55,000-strong, NATO-led military force will be joined this week by 1,200 election supervisors and 850 observers for the national election on Saturday. There are already countless nongovernmental organizations and freelance do-gooders also bracing themselves for the latest stage in the byzantine task of putting Humpty-Dumpty together again.

title: More Whitewater Pressure
description: Susan McDougal appears to be heading to jail tomorrow for defying a Federal judge who ordered her to begin talking to a grand jury about her former partner in the Whitewater land venture, Bill Clinton.

title: Be Careful in Cutting Lilco Rates
description: ON Wednesday, the State Public Service Commission will vote on whether to lower the Long Island Lighting Company electric rates and if so, by how much. While every Long Islander would agree with me that our electric rates are too high, we must be careful that we lower them in a way that does not harm electric service. Unfortunately, there are some rate reduction proposals that would do just that,

title: WORK
description: Wilson weaves his seemingly rational argument with beguiling quotes designed to promote his caring agenda. Just look at the list of stifled liberal wants suggested as solutions to the problem: Federally sponsored day care, health care, income supports, jobs programs, housing and education. But this is not the way the political wind is blowing. It is not meanspiritedness or budget frugality behind the mounting rejection of Federal Government solutions. It is the deliberative learning that results from 30 years of failed policies.

title: HIS LIFE IS HIS MIND
description: I read with mixed emotions Dee Wedemeyer's article about the Jungian analyst James Hall (''His Life Is His Mind,'' Aug. 18). While I certainly felt some admiration for his ability to make sense of his life despite his severe handicap, my thoughts kept coming back to his wife, Suzanne. To me, she is the real hero of the story. She must have an enormous amount of kindness, forgiveness, love and loyalty to ''be there'' for this man still. In my opinion, these qualities count for much more than all eight pages of her husband's curriculum vitae!

title: Grief Stirred By a Sex Case Grips Belgium At 2 Burials
description: With grief glaringly public and intensely private, the people of this town today buried two victims of a sex-crimes case that has confronted Belgium with unaccustomed self-doubt, anger and fear.

title: Transitory Vampires
description: To the Editor:

title: Alternative Folk Rock Plus Dashes of Daring
description: WAS ALTERNATIVE rock a flash in the pan? Has hip-hop returned to cult status? Does punk have any more commercial staying power than it did in the 1970's? The pop music business doesn't know the answers to any of those questions, but for the first part of this season it will fall back on an old reliable: folk rock, now a little noisy and weather-beaten but still depending on good old chiming guitars.

title: Judging Jets Begins Early This Year
description: It is here again today for the Jets, another Sunday on which, believe the faithful and the critics, the whole season hinges.

title: Some Iraqis Are Still Dug In Inside the Kurdish Region
description: Fifteen miles southeast of here, several hundred Iraqi soldiers with armored vehicles, light tanks and artillery have been seen encamped in the most visible presence that President Saddam Hussein has retained in Kurdish territory since his forces joined in the assault on this city a week ago.

title: Jennifer Stutman And Peter Turchin
description: Jennifer Sue Stutman, a daughter of Janet Stutman of Worcester, Mass., and Robert Stutman of Eastham, Mass., was married last evening to Peter Turchin, a son of Cheryl and Martin Turchin of Palm Beach, Fla. Cantor Robert Abelson performed the ceremony in the the Tower Room at the Equitable Center in New York.

title: What's New at G.M.? Cars, for a Change
description: GENERAL MOTORS, once one of America's most successful corporations, developed a reputation in the 1980's as a confused car-making bureaucracy that rolled out one look-alike product after another with little fanfare and modest sales success.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Here is a selective guide to coming cultural events in New York and beyond. Events that are starred are those that Times critics consider particularly noteworthy. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. title: Beth Phillips, George Dooneief
description: Beth Ann Phillips and Dr. George Harman Dooneief are to be married today at the Stanhope Hotel in New York. Rabbi Leonard Kravitz is to perform the ceremony.

title: Spirits High But Not Dry After Towns Get Drenched
description: At midnight on Thursday, shortly after the eye of Hurricane Fran passed through Wilmington, a young woman called the disk jockeys at WGNI-FM in a hyperventilating panic. Her 16-year-old brother was having an asthma attack, the family had no medication and ambulances could not make it to her home. The disk jockeys could hear the girl's mother tending frantically to her son in the background.

title: Christine Dolan, Scott A. Bennett
description: Christine Rose Dolan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Charles Dolan of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Scott Allen Bennett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gary Charles Bennett of Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Michael C. Palmer performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Actress Lends Talent to Young Pupils
description: IF 14-year-old Adriana Cepoi had a shy bone in her body, none could be readily observed recently as she sang and danced her way through the Broadway standard ''There's No Business Like Show Business.''

title: Building in Context
description: To the Editor:

title: Slow Start Brings Farmers Some Gains, Some Losses
description: New Jersey crops had a slow start this year because of the cool, wet July. But if the warm days with little rain continue, most may catch up before the end of the season, agriculture experts say.

title: Another Handshake Jolts Israel's Right
description: As a candidate last spring, Benjamin Netanyahu lacerated Israel's Labor-led Government for negotiating with Yasir Arafat, making himself a rallying point for all those Israelis who recoiled at the recognition of Mr. Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization and the subsequent talks that had led to Israel's exchange of land for the hope of peace. It was the issue on which Mr. Netanyahu was elected Prime Minister.

title: Sampras Still Striving To Fulfill Expectations
description: A FLAWLESS serving match, three sets and out, was on Pete Sampras's racquet yesterday, and then, in a eye blink, it was not. Loose backhand volley. Two net-cord service faults. Tentative rally. Three match points gone. Perfection lost.

title: Back To Work And Play
description: LAST Wednesday, like students returning to school with new backpacks, expectations and perhaps a few neuroses, the shakers and movers of Manhattan returned to their social treadmills.

title: U.N. Leader Proposed Establishing an Army
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: The Art column on Aug. 25 about landscapes at the Katonah Museum of Art misstated the telephone number. It is 232-9555.

title: In Georgia, Gore Pushes Tax Credits For College
description: Vice President Gore today took his sales pitch for subsidized higher education to Georgia, where the state's Hope Scholarship Program became the model for President Clinton's proposed tuition tax credit.

title: Plastic Pier Is Worm-Free But It Melts
description: The gribbles and the shipworms could not gnaw away at the plastic Tiffany Street pier off Hunts Point, but nature found a quick way to wreak havoc there.

title: Sally R. Handy, William Shutkin
description: Sally Russell Handy, an education professor at Lesley College in Boston, and William Andrew Shutkin, a lawyer in Boston, were married last evening in Old Lyme, Conn. Roger Payne, a Congregational minister who is the director of the Interface Institute in Cambridge, Mass., performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Old Lyme Beach Club.

title: A Rain Forest People Rarely Glimpsed
description: PEOPLE of the Lake and Forest: The Semelai of Tasek Bera,'' an exhibition at the Peabody Museum in New Haven through February 1997, may be the right show for those who think they have seen it all.

title: Four Hotels In A Revived Downtown
description: I'VE been to San Francisco many times, but until recently seldom ventured South of the Slot, as the area now known as SoMa (South of Market) used to be called, because it was on the wrong side of the cable-car line that ended at Market Street. There was nothing to see there but sleazy bookstores and pinball arcades.

title: In Planned New Supermarket, Island Sees Its Character for Sale
description: Now that the summer crowds and traffic are gone, people here can get back to worrying about another major threat to this island's quaint tranquillity: the proposed supermarket. The one that would have an outdoor herb garden, fruit trees, brick walkways and a playground, as well as five additional stores.

title: Suzanne Shelley, Bruce Margolin
description: Suzanne Alison Shelley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Shelley of Princeton, N.J., was married there last evening to Bruce David Margolin, the son of Councilwoman June M. Eisland of the Bronx and Arthur M. Margolin of North Arlington, N.J. Donald Matthews, the Mayor of Montgomery Township, N.J., performed the ceremony at Bedens Brook Country Club.

title: Shtetl For a Week
description: RABBI NACHMAN OF BRATSLAV ONCE PREACHED, ''EAT OR DON'T eat, sleep or don't sleep, pray or don't pray, as long as you're with me on Rosh ha-Shanah.'' This week, thousands of his followers will obey the injunction. They will leave wives and daughters behind in France, in Israel, in the United States. They will hurry to Uman, the small city in the farmlands of central Ukraine where the rabbi settled after his long sojourn in Bratslav. As the Jewish New Year begins, they will crowd and cram and crush up to . . . his grave. Rabbi Nachman died in 1810.

title: Striptease Club Breathes Its Last, Heavily
description: The life of the last striptease club in downtown Brooklyn, Steam Heat, was short but contentious.

title: Why Public Golf Courses Are Worth the Long Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Suddenly, the Offbeat Is the Standard
description: MOST OF THE USUAL THEMES seem to have fallen by the wayside in what promises to be one of the oddest seasons in dance in recent memory. The avant-gardist Karole Armitage will get things off to a properly nutty-sounding start next month with ''The Predators' Ball,'' a dance chronicle of the rise and fall of Michael Milken, the junk-bond trader. The American debut engagement of Les Ballets C. de la B. sounds equally goofy. This hot young Belgian company will present a piece set to fragments of Purcell scores played by an orchestra of 10 accordionists. What's next? Wagner on the kazoo?

title: Mr. Wrong
description: OUT OF SIGHT

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE WORLD AT NIGHT

title: Bosnia's Last Best Hope
description: THEY ARE CLOSE FRIENDS, born and raised in Sarajevo, and in their telling it was once the best place in the world. They remember it as a place of parks and music and outdoor cafes, and what they remember most is the beauty of its setting, how wherever they happened to be in their valley city they could look past rooftops to see the stony, pine-covered hills that towered above it. They are now in their early 20's -- Nedim Haveric, 20; Ines Milunic, 21; Emir Ganibegovic, 23 -- but already they have about them a sense of nostalgia, a rose-tinted wistfulness for the lives they once had.

title: Expanding on the Stay Of Rochambeau Troops
description: The Aug. 18 article about Yorktown and the juncture of American and French troops at a most critical time in our struggle for independence $(''Yorktown Marks Anniversary of Rochambeau's Encampment''$) somehow skipped their two months of joint encampment in mid-Westchester -- before the battle on the Virginia peninsula, which gave that town its name. I would guess that the preservers of the Rochambeau house in mid-Westchester will also be offering corrections to that article.

title: Wendy Plumb, Douglas Corper
description: Elizabeth Wendell Plumb, the daughter of Marilyn McClure Plumb of Katonah, N.Y., and Peter C. Plumb of Bondville, Vt., was married yesterday to Douglas Philip Corper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Corper of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Terrence L. Elsberry performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Subdivision Days
description: It is 1963 and in the suburban subdivision where 12-year-old Suzanne Keller is growing up, the houses are clean and freshly painted. Suzanne's parents and their neighbors are young marrieds, hopeful families settling down on President John F. Kennedy's New Frontier. Even the trees that dot the lawns of Blue Spruce Lane and Mountain Laurel Drive are so new they allow the neighbors ''a clear view of each other's yards. Nothing was secret or hidden.'' In Marly Swick's first novel, PAPER WINGS (HarperCollins, $21), America's communities are still cradled inside one another, like a set of nested dolls: family, neighborhood, nation. Ms. Swick likes to fix certain moments in her sights: the humming, slow-motion instants before everything changes. And so, when Lee Harvey Oswald takes aim at J.F.K., he is drawing a bead on Suzanne's family too -- and their white-collar neighbors with their wistful dreams for the future. By the time Lyndon Johnson has been sworn in as President, the Kellers' lives have already begun to alter in slow but permanent ways. Suzanne's mother begins to close herself off, retreating behind dark glasses like Jackie Kennedy. Suzanne's father starts the long drift that will lead him away from his wife and into the arms of another woman. If Ms. Swick's book sometimes feels a little too kitschy -- like a time capsule crammed with Tupperware and old 45's -- it's saved by her self-assured tone. In her confident hands, ''Paper Wings'' becomes a moving elegy to the era that, like John Updike's mythical 50's, still looks to many like ''the last happy time.'' Rose Kernochan

title: West Indian Favorites in a Humble Roadhouse
description: FREIA'S, in East Quogue, offers an offbeat experience in the off-season. This humble newcomer, with a ramshackled roadhouse look at 412 Montauk Highway (653-5045), has spent the summer trying to establish a beachhead in unfamiliar territory. Its modestly priced, West Indian cuisine makes it one of a kind on the fashionable East End.

title: Campaigning on Portents of Doom and Boom
description: BILL CLINTON, while walking across your bridge to the 21st century, take a long look back at the middle part of this one. Divorce was rare and most children were born into two-parent families.

title: Paula Cozzarelli, Drew Greeley
description: Paula Catherine Cozzarelli, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James D. Cozzarelli of Chalfont, Pa., is to be married today to Dr. Drew Peter Greeley, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. Robert P. Greeley of Mountainside, N.J. The Rev. John McCrone, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Church of St. Martha in Point Pleasant, N.J.

title: The Golden Rules
description: Gold is good. Especially on the face, where the new shimmery lipsticks and shadows make up for the minimalism in fashion. Still, before buying in, a few cautionary hints:

title: Nothing Funny About This Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss von Schreiner, Mr. Sullivan
description: Heidelinde von Schreiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heinrich G. von Schreiner of Fort Myers, Fla., was married yesterday to Christopher Cletus Sullivan, a son of Paula Gorenstein and Anthony R. Sullivan, both of Hartford. The Rev. Mary N. Hawkes performed the ceremony at the Wilmington (Vt.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Kevin A. Barry, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Abby Sosland and Mark Goodman
description: Esther Abigail Sosland, a daughter of Blanche and Neil N. Sosland of Shawnee Mission, Kan., is to be married today to Alexander Mark Goodman, whose father, George J. W. Goodman of Princeton, N.J., is the financial writer and broadcaster known as Adam Smith.

title: May S. Bloomer, Spencer Bartels
description: May Saenz Bloomer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kent Bloomer of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday in New Haven to Donald Spencer Bartels, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bartels of Chilmark, Mass. The Rev. Grant Barber, the Episcopal chaplain at Yale University, performed the ceremony at Dwight Memorial Chapel on the Yale campus.

title: Art That's Still Armed and Dangerous
description: IN 1911, WHILE DANCING THE ROLE of Albrecht in ''Giselle,'' the 21-year-old Vaslav Nijinsky decided not to wear the floppy pair of shorts that modesty required male dancers to wear to ''cover themselves.'' Instead, he stepped out onto the stage of St. Petersburg's Imperial Theater clad only in his ballet tights. He might as well have danced out naked. The scandalized stage manager immediately ordered him to correct this impropriety. Nijinsky refused, was suspended for insubordination and then resigned from the company. Though the term had not yet been invented, Nijinsky's defiant act of artistic independence -- this flagrant public advertisement of his sexuality, flying in the face of common decency -- might well be considered the birth of the art movement known as Dada.

title: Varied Work, Veering Far From Traditional
description: ''The Masters X''

title: Blue Ridge Parkway
description: Fall foliage has little competition on the Blue Ridge Parkway. There are no billboards or convenience stores, nothing to dull the golden poplars, scarlet sourwoods and orange sassafras. A few cluttered stretches notwithstanding, travelers can spend hours on the 469-mile road without seeing a telephone pole, power line or anything more obtrusive than the occasional farmhouse.

title: Frances Mantell, 79, School's Co-Founder
description: Frances Meyer Mantell, a co-founder of the Jewish Foundation School of Staten Island and of Skylight, a psychiatric rehabilitation center on Staten Island, died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Medical Center on Staten Island. She was 79 and lived in St. George, S.I.

title: After Sonic Saturation, a Quiet Return to Hi-Fi Values
description: IF YOU AREN'T IN THE HOME theater business, say many proprietors of what were once hi-fi salons, you aren't going to be in business long. Such is the degree to which the audio market has come to be driven by the mania for multichannel sound and, especially, movie soundtracks.

title: Beach Volunteers Sought
description: On Sept. 21, thousands of volunteers, led by beach captains from environmental organizations, will take part in the 11th yearly international beach cleanup. Last year, 391 Westchester volunteers cleaned and documented the litter on 10 miles of shoreline and beaches along Long Island Sound and the Hudson River.

title: Waterfront Battle In Tarrytown
description: LATELY, John T. Cooney Jr. has become a fighting man. For 75 years and three generations, his family has been manufacturing asphalt along the Hudson River here, with Mr. Cooney, the latest heir to oversee the business, often dreaming of handing it down to his offspring -- as his father and grandfather did before him.

title: Stony Brook Wonders How to Unclog Harbor
description: LESS than two years after Suffolk County spent $1.2 million to dredge Stony Brook Harbor, the channel is impassable at high tide.

title: Accordion Trills of Old For Bosnia
description: What was amazing was not merely how Perica Simonovic caressed his accordion to produce the quavering Middle Eastern-flavored tunes that enchanted his audience and make him the one of the most popular folk musicians in Bosnia.

title: In the War Room
description: Orit Gadiesh, stylish with her purple hair and tight black skirts, is a native of Israel. But in her first job after high school, she wore far less colorful garb, as an assistant in the Israeli Army to Ezer Weizman, the deputy chief of staff, who is now the President of Israel.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: YOUNG men, young guns, young rebels and young detectives give this week's top films their kick.

title: Requiem for a Metaphor Too Far
description: AS political metaphors go, it's a humble one. It's not a shining city, or a new frontier or anything as sparkling as a point of light -- just a bridge. But since President Clinton turned it against Bob Dole in his acceptance speech at the Democratic convention last month, that particular item of infrastructure has become the dominant oratorical image of the 1996 campaign.

title: The Info Footpath
description: WHERE WIZARDS STAY UP LATE

title: THEY LAUGHED AT GALILEO TOO
description: It is a sorry commentary on the state of our society that, as we have become more and more dependent on scientific advances in computers, medicine, communications and other areas, a large segment of the population has correspondingly embraced what has been termed the ''flight from reason'' and believes in the garbage of pseudo science (''They Laughed at Galileo Too,'' Aug. 11). Chip Brown's article makes the point that almost half the population believes in ESP and more than half believes that it has had a psychic experience.

title: A Pushy Newcomer Shakes Up Cancer Treatment in New York
description: The largest chain of for-profit cancer treatment centers in the nation is making a brash assault on New York's $4 billion cancer-care market. If you have cancer and live in New York, Salick Health Care is determined to take care of you.

title: Bringing a Cozy Touch of Irish Cheer to the Burial Business
description: F. DANIEL MOLONEY has given a new look to his place of business by painting the walls with bright-colored flowers (even in the bathrooms), filling wall shelves and tabletops with Hummels and porcelain figures and lining the floor with genial toy animals. The music piped in is mood-lifting too, mostly traditional Irish folk tunes with soft religious rock and the Celtic mysticism of Enya blended in. On a sunny day, light streams in from every window, bathing the cushioned, comfortable furniture that makes the interior resemble a large living room.

title: Kathleen McKitty And Marc Harris
description: Kathleen Tara McKitty, the daughter of William and Margaret McKitty of Ridgefield, Conn., is to be married today to Marc Adam Harris, a son of Robert and Delores Harris of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Joel Baehr, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y.

title: U.N.C. Deflates Syracuse in Dome
description: Expected to zoom into the higher elevations of college football this season, Syracuse failed to rise off the floor of the Carrier Dome tonight.

title: How to Land a Promising 'Huge Cap' Stock
description: TRYING to catch a whale surely isn't like other kinds of fishing, and the same holds true for picking stocks. When investors choose among behemoths like AT&T, Coca-Cola and General Electric, many of the traditional yardsticks don't seem to work. Very low-priced stocks, for example, frequently perform more poorly than expensive ones, and the fastest growers are not always rewarded handsomely.

title: Following Orders, or Not
description: It took Michael H. Jordan less than a year to rethink his original post-master's-degree plan to go for his doctorate in chemistry. ''I liked using the lab fire extinguishers to cool off the beer we'd buy across the street,'' he recalls, ''but other than that, I just couldn't see myself spending four years in a research lab.''

title: New Account Adds to the Mystery About the Fate of American P.O.W.'s in North Korea
description: One of the most elusive and maddening mysteries swirling about East Asia concerns the occasional ''sightings'' of American prisoners of war still supposedly held by North Korea, more than four decades after the end of the Korean War.

description: To the Editor:

title: Waste Not, Want Not: Recycling Prison Food for Cows
description: Each month, New Jersey pays garbage haulers about $40,000 to take 500,000 pounds of leftovers such as chicken, rice, beans and greens out of the state's 14 prisons and into the nearest landfill.

title: A Prosperous Enclave of Gracious Living
description: FROM the crest of Manhasset Avenue, it is possible to view two features that help make well-to-do Manhasset -- a blue-chip area that, by tradition, includes most of five incorporated villages.

title: THE 00's
description: No contest -- the year 2000 will usher in the double-oh decade (On Language: ''The 00's,'' by Jack Rosenthal, Aug. 18). The class of double-oh will be followed by double-oh one, double-oh two and so on. The class of double-oh seven will be called the Bondies.

title: TV Remedy for a TV Malady
description: IF THERE WAS EVER any doubt, the coming flood of television commercials will remind us: money governs our politics, and the high cost of those TV ads is largely to blame. Bill Clinton and Bob Dole are offering tax cuts that translate directly into personal checks to make us all complicit in their sellout of political values. We come to the end of the century, the century of Teapot Dome and Watergate and S & L's, as a nation of bribe givers and takers, thoroughly corrupted by our ever-advancing skill at converting money into votes and political power. Only Ross Perot self-righteously disdains the big donations; he has spent more than $70 million of his own money so far to bid for the White House, and the Supreme Court says we can't stop him.

title: Meredith Vederman, A.T. Greenberg

Tired of the Victorian excesses that were fashionable into the 1890's, designers like Josef Hoffmann in Europe and Gustav Stickley in America turned to the medieval style to create the sparest possible furnishings.

description: THE Miss America Scholarship Pageant is a week away, but Bruce Boyajian has already picked a winner.

title: With Iran Population Boom, Vasectomy Receives Blessing
description: In the vasectomy department of a birth control clinic serving this city's hard-pressed southern quarters, a single letter stamped with official seals lies pressed under the doctor's glass desktop.

title: Arcadian World, Faithful Watercolors
description: NOTHING in the exhibition ''Color, Light and Atmosphere: The Art of Charles and Mary Roberts Ebert'' at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme suggests that the pair lived anything but an idyll.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Rigors of Farming Give Way to Leisure
description: AS the wind was picking up on Mecox Bay one Sunday, John Halsey hauled his fiberglass sailboat past 20 acres of apple orchards, seven acres of pumpkins, a little pond, and a field of sorghum on his Bridgehampton farm. Finally, he had reached the edge of the bay.

title: Elizabeth Elliott, Andrew Faintych
description: Elizabeth Vaughan Elliott, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Le Roi Layton Elliott of Washington, was married yesterday to Andrew Lawrence Faintych, a son of Bertha Faintych of Newport, R.I., and the late Dr. Max Faintych. Judge Joan Zeldon of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia officiated at the home of the bride's parents. Capt. Victor Smith, a United States Navy chaplain, took part in the ceremony.

title: Lisa M. Gallin, Timothy G. Lynch
description: Lisa Miriam Gallin, a daughter of Nancy C. and Dr. Richard G. Gallin of New York, and Timothy Gerard Lynch, a son of Patricia O. and Gerard B. Lynch of Binghamton, N.Y., were married yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York. The Rev. Alexei A. Michalenko, a Roman Catholic chaplain at the Georgetown University Law Center in Washington, performed the ceremony. Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg took part in the service.

title: The Classics March Toward The Millennium
description: EVERY VIDEO SEASON has its vintage major motion pictures in new packages, but this year so many big old movies are lined up for rerelease, one wonders where they'll find room for ''Twister'' and ''Mission: Impossible.''

title: A Glimpse of the Beat Generation
description: IN 1964, Larry Keenan was 21 and living in Oakland, Calif. He borrowed a black Rolls-Royce from his parents' undertaking establishment, got a camera and started taking pictures in and around the Haight-Ashbury district of San Francisco, a crossroads of the counterculture. Sixty of those photographs, reprinted from their original negatives, will be on display at Great Modern Pictures beginning Thursday.

title: In Search of the Center
description: WHO'S IN CONTROL?

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: G.O.P. Showdown In Tuesday Primary
description: REPUBLICAN voters on Tuesday will send Joseph J. DioGuardi packing -- to political retirement or possibly back to Washington -- when they resolve the intense intraparty fight between him and the freshman incumbent, Sue Kelly, for the nomination for Congress in the 19th Congressional District.

title: THE 00's
description: What to call the 00's? The ''ou's,'' of course, as in ''ouch.'' Baby boomers will soon be turning 50, and some even 60, competing for the already shrinking Social Security and Medicare funds; high-school and college graduates will be struggling to find work in the downsized economy; the poor and unemployed will be, well, poor and unemployed, and middle-aged workers will be paying huge taxes to keep us all afloat.

title: Hilary Winston and Mark Oskam
description: Hilary Chisholm Winston, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. Lee Winston of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Bradley Oskam, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Oskam of Hong Kong and Manchester, Vt. The Rev. Richard D. Ringenwald officiated at the First Congregational Church in Manchester.

title: Roots of School Overcrowding Stretch Back Two Decades
description: Only 20 years ago, New York City had schoolrooms to spare. From 1975 to 1982, nearly 100 schools were given away, sold off, left vacant, turned into administrative offices, torn down.

title: Robin A. Kaplan, Troy J. Beutel
description: Robin Ann Kaplan, the daughter of Cynthia and Philip Kaplan of Manhasset, L.I., was married last evening to Troy Jerry Beutel, a son of Gail U. Beutel and the late Jerry J. Beutel of Lockport, N.Y. Rabbi David B. Kudan officiated at Gedney Farm in New Marlboro, Mass.

title: Ms. Jefferson, Mr. Ackerman
description: Elizabeth Patrick Jefferson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen James Jefferson of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday to Jay Rossin Ackerman, a son of Frani Cooper Ridder of Long Beach, Calif., and Jack Rossin Ackerman of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Douglas G. Scott performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Radnor, Pa.

title: Banking on the Really Big Names
description: THE STARS HAVE IT. TELEVISION stars, THAT IS. At least that's what network executives are hoping as they painfully absorb the fact that audience ratings for their top 20 shows last season crumbled by 6 percent.

title: The Tensions in District 28 Go Far Beyond Individuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Slur Turned La Guardia Against the Hurdy-Gurdy
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: ROOSEVELT ISLAND

title: Amanda Holt, Bernard Chang
description: Amanda Carrie Holt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Macdonald Holt of Merrimack, N.H., is to be married today to Bernard Shaw-Farn Chang, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tien Min Chang of Metuchen, N.J. The Rev. Barbara Ross, an interfaith minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Mark, a hotel in New York.

title: At Rutgers, Liberal Arts For Adults
description: Rutgers University has long provided continuing-education programs for adults who want to return to school part time, but most courses are strictly practical. Corporate types can sharpen their computer skills, for example, and farmers can bone up on mulching techniques.

title: Peaks, Pubs and Plenty of Rain
description: IS there something about small countries that causes an obsession with details? When I planned a trip to north Wales last fall, a modest highlights tour of the Snowdonia mountain country, it seemed so simple that I almost felt guilty. Surely someone with a lifelong romantic attachment to Wales should put more into it than that.

title: The Digital Picture Begins to Clarify
description: IN AN EPISODE OF ''THE XFiles'' called ''Conduit,'' a little boy sits in front of a snowy television screen, feverishly copying onto large sheets of paper something he alone can see: an endless stream of ones and zeros. It turns out that when all the sheets are correctly fitted together, the binary profusion becomes a simple mosaic: a picture of the child's sister, who has apparently been kidnapped by aliens.

title: Wendy Haller, John Krigbaum
description: Wendy Anne Haller, the daughter of May Haller of Manhasset, L.I., and Barry A. Haller of Bellerose, Queens, was married yesterday to John Sanders Krigbaum, the son of Virginia Lee Stone of Gloucester, Mass., and Charles R. Krigbaum of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. Norman J. Catir Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan.

title: Alison Kartiganer, Dennis Rogalsky
description: Alison Beth Kartiganer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kartiganer of New York, was married yesterday to Dennis Wayne Rogalsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene W. Rogalsky of Hutchinson, Kan. Robert Hopkins, a notary public, officiated at the Squirrel Island (Me.) Chapel.

title: Experts Doubt Gulf War Link To Symptoms
description: As evidence mounts that more troops may have been exposed to chemical weapons in the Persian Gulf war than had earlier been believed, scientists say there is still little evidence that such exposure could result in some of the long-term illnesses reported by veterans and collectively known as gulf war syndrome.

title: Mr. Arafat's Repressive Rule
description: When the Palestinians began limited self-rule two years ago, Yasir Arafat took on a job that might tax even an experienced national leader. His Palestinian Authority must provide services to an already impoverished region whose hardships are intensified by Israel's closing of Palestinian territories after terrorist bombings in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. He has been rightly pressed by Israel and the United states to combat Palestinian terrorist organizations.

title: FILM
description: Here is a selective guide to coming cultural events in New York and beyond. Events that are starred are those that Times critics consider particularly noteworthy. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear on page 80.

title: Yes, Cut Medical Costs, but First Do No Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Forceful Graf Outlasts Hurricane, and Hingis
description: For two turbulent days, three ladies on a first-name basis with their public, Steffi, Martina and Fran, jostled for control of the Stadium Court. On Friday, the death throes of the passing Hurricane Fran were persuasive enough to force the veteran Steffi Graf and the ingenue Martina Hingis off the court, and to force their much-anticipated semifinal match at the United States Open into an overnight holding pattern when it was just one game old.

title: Man Arrested In Car Shooting Of an Officer
description: A Staten Island man was arrested and charged with attempted murder yesterday in the shooting of an off-duty police officer on the Staten Island Expressway on Friday night.

title: Madeleine Chait and Steven Brand
description: Madeleine Cynthia Chait, the daughter of Jocelyn and Allan S. Chait of New York, is to be married today at Temple Emanu-El in New York to Steven Brand, a son of Helen and Abraham Brand of Ventura, Calif. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, the congregation's senior rabbi, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Stalking, and Snaring, a Reasonable New Colonial
description: ALAIN GROSJEAN and his wife, Patricia, were looking for what seemed the impossible. The couple, who have a 6-year-old daughter, had outgrown their condominium in Cortlandt. They wanted to find a newly built colonial with three to four bedrooms in northern Westchester. The rub was that they wanted the house to cost less than $300,000.

title: PLACES
description: ALICE TULLY HALL 721-6500

title: Great Stone Faces
description: Defaced by time, pigeon gunk and insensitive landlords eager to remove potential liabilities, New York's once abundant crop of architectural stonework has suffered countless indignities. However, some of the city's most hardscrabble neighborhoods are still graced by a noble array of gods, gargoyles and fanciful bas reliefs. To 19th-century developers, such carvings were an inexpensive way to dress up otherwise dreary buildings, masking the unrelieved misery of tenement life within. The photographer John Yang has made a haunting record of Manhattan's ornamental stonework, most of which hovers above the city's streets unnoticed by passers-by and uncared for by its owners. From East Harlem to the Lower East Side, Mr. Yang's OVER THE DOOR: The Ornamental Stonework of New York (Princeton Architectural Press, $34.95) dispassionately captures grinning nymphs, mythical griffins and busts of long-forgotten children, often modeled on the buildings' original inhabitants. The worn-away and vandalized faces -- some with noses and eyes gouged out -- bring to mind the broken remnants of Roman antiquity and a more enlightened culture ravaged by barbarians. Mr. Yang's stark photographs almost implore New Yorkers to look up, take stock of their sculptured heritage and stop the destruction. Andrew Jacobs

title: For Mutual Funds, New Political Muscle
description: LIKE the lanky adolescent who startles beach goers by turning into a muscle-bound young man, the chief trade group for the mutual fund industry has grown seemingly overnight into one of Wall Street's most powerful forces in Washington.

title: THEATER
description: Correction Appended
