title: Past Is No Guide to Stands Taken by Candidates
description: Barely two years ago, President Clinton was envisioning the greatest expansion of Government social policy in at least a generation. The transformation of the American health care system, he proclaimed, was his ''most urgent priority.''

title: More Than Just Numbers
description: In a small way, the career of Arthur C. Martinez is back where it started.

title: For 'Bookend' Twins, Independence Is Key
description: LAUREN and Kristen Scopaz, 18-year-old identical twins, shared identical interests and friends throughout high school, where they were referred to as the twins. When it came time to go to college they chose to make the decision independently of each other. Thinking alike for their entire lives was a hard habit to break. This fall they will both attend Dartmouth College.

title: Ms. Liverzani And Mr. Prame
description: Christine Ann Liverzani, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Liverzani of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Prame, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn B. Prame of Rochester. Msgr. George F. Bardes officiated at the Church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: When the Calm Breaks Down
description: Sometimes people become so frustrated at work that they just want to hit someone. Usually they don't. Usually they stay calm, keep their cool, remain mature. But maybe there are exceptions -- and maybe you've witnessed an office fistfight. We'd like to hear about it. Send your best story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Breaking New Ground, But the Roots Hold Fast
description: TIME TO DROP POP MUSIC. Leave the Butthole Surfers and Pearl Jam to the kids. But not R.E.M. Through 11 albums, it has built a reputation for innovation and artistic integrity. And yet, with its new Warner Brothers deal, it has become one of the world's highest-paid bands. This 80's alternative-rock band from Athens, Ga., turned 90's superstars -- now in their 30's -- keeps breaking rich new ground. Or new-ground, as we say in the South.

title: Murray Hits a Milestone; Is the Hall of Fame Next?
description: Eddie Murray has joined Hank Aaron and Willie Mays in the select 500-3,000 club, and five years after he retires, those numbers are expected to elevate him into the club known as the Hall of Fame.

title: Beatrice Segal, David B. Segal
description: Beatrice Ann Segal, the daughter of Lore Segal of Manhattan and the late David Segal, is to be married today to David Barry Segal, the son of Ahuva and Nathan Segal of Salisbury Mills, N.Y. The two families are not related. Rabbi Jules Harlow is to perform the ceremony in Manhattan.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: I'll Always Have Paris

title: Katherine Felsen, Luca Di Pietro
description: Katherine McClintock Felsen, a daughter of Katherine de Saulles Ellis of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and David Macdonald Felsen of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Luca Di Pietro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emilio Di Pietro of Nereto, Italy. The Rev. Michael Perry, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Richard E. Cross, 85, Executive And Civic Leader in Michigan
description: Richard Eugene Cross, a former chief executive of the American Motors Corporation and Michigan civic leader, died on Aug. 31 at his home in Rochester Hills, Mich. He was 85.

title: Maura M. Casey, John C. Dolan
description: Maura Margaret Casey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Casey of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to John Christopher Dolan, a son of Margaret T. Dolan of Concord, Mass., and the late Robert F. Dolan. The Rev. Michael F. Groden performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: New Seller Option: Range in Pricing
description: THE traditional way of pricing a house for sale is about to be challenged on Long Island.

description: To the Editor:

title: They'll Always Have Tokyo
description: IDORU

title: Cameron Arterton and Daniel Wrinn
description: Cameron duBignon Arterton, a daughter of Judge Janet Bond Arterton and Dr. F. Christopher Arterton of New Haven, was married yesterday to Daniel Edward Wrinn, a son of Marilyn and Eugene Wrinn of Wallingford, Conn. The Rev. Ellen Tillotson performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Milton, Conn.

title: Coming Home To a Musical That Sounds Like America
description: THE NEWS THAT ''CHICAGO,'' the 1975 John Kander-Fred Ebb-Bob Fosse musical, is coming to Broadway this fall is hardly a surprise (it opens on Nov. 14 at the Richard Rodgers Theater). Anyone lucky enough to have attended one of its four concert performances last May in the acclaimed Encores! series at City Center will understand why.

title: Brahms and Schubert, All Day, All the Time
description: BRAHMS AND SCHUBERT ARE EVERYWHERE THIS SEASON, OR WOULD BE but for one detail: neither composed anything of lasting consequence, if anything at all, for the opera house. Yes, Schubert contributed ''Fierrabras'' as his most considerable stage effort, and, yes, the work will be performed in concert by Robert Bass and the Collegiate Chorale. But Schubert is more typically and richly represented, 200 years after his birth, in orchestral works, with Christoph von Dohnanyi leading the Cleveland Orchestra, and in the song cycles, by Peter Schreier and Andras Schiff.

title: Nina M. Beattie, Michael I. Eberstadt
description: Nina Minard Beattie, a daughter of Diana L. and Richard I. Beattie of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Ignaz Eberstadt, a son of Vera and Walter A. Eberstadt of New York. Judge Kimba M. Wood of the Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Food and Art, With a Flourish
description: Indoor and outdoor activities benefit young people, a hospital and the fight against AIDS, and also celebrate a birthday.

title: The Leading Theories for the Giants' Earthbound Offense
description: When Giants quarterback Dave Brown has been asked if he would like to throw the ball more, he usually thinks his answer through carefully. He doesn't want to appear to be politicking for more passes or attention, something that would certainly irk the sensitive Dan Reeves. So Brown answers with politically correct responses, like, every quarterback would like to throw a lot but in this particular offense, that isn't going to happen.

title: Correction
description: The Restaurants column on Aug. 25, about fast food in New Jersey, misstated the county for East Brunswick, home of a Boston Market franchise. It is Middlesex, not Bergen.

title: A Day in the Life of Ivan Subovitch
description: The first annual Substitute Teacher Appreciation Week begins today, honoring those who, in its founder's phrase, ''get no sick days or respect.'' Is it really that bad? To find out, we called Paul Emus of Imperial Beach, Calif., a typical sub whose four years in various southern California school districts inspired ''Not Young Enought to Know Everything,'' a self-published book of tips for fellow sufferers. Emus admits to being ambivalent about sub life; intrigued, we asked him to blend his experiences into a composite day. A composite worst day.

title: Chinese Can Say No And Keep Ties to West
description: To the Editor:

title: London at War
description: Sylvia Sidney and Oscar Homolka are an odd couple in the gloomy but classy SABOTAGE (1936). Hitchcock leaves us on our own, but we know she's American and a New Yorker at that - she looks it, sounds it and behaves it. As for the bulky Oscar, his iron-curtain 5 o'clock shadow and formidable Slavic accent shout Russian. Here they are stumping around an apartment connected to London's grungiest cinema. Then things happen. A handsome war office snoop (John Loder) turns up and asks disturbing questions. The wife's young brother, a child, is dispatched to a crowded London bus carrying a bomb. The sequence is deadly and deliberate, minus carnage. It's based on Joseph Conrad's ''Secret Agent,'' originally titled ''A Woman Alone'' - SATURDAY at 9 P.M. on CUNY.

title: Ms. Einhorn, Mr. Futterman
description: Amy Debra Einhorn, an editor at Pocket Books in New York, was married last evening to Matthew Futterman, a reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y.

title: Was Fight a Fix? No. Just Seldon's Glass Jaw
description: MOMENTS after Mike Tyson's left hooks took the World Boxing Association title from Bruce Seldon after only 109 seconds of the first round last night, the chant of ''Fix! Fix! Fix!'' rumbled through the 9,494 cynical customers in the MGM Grand Garden. But this wasn't a ''fix'' in the sense that Seldon was bribed to take a dive.

title: Woods Suits Golf's Needs Perfectly
description: Tiger Woods opened last week by hitting a hole-in-one on the last day of his first professional tournament. By week's end, he was already a disappointment for not having walked on a water hazard. If ever an athlete needed to be cloned just to satisfy all the expectations of others, much less his own and his father's, it is this newest spokesman for Generation Swoosh.

title: Dinkins's Day at the U.S. Open Blends His Passion and His Politics
description: A shower delayed the start of the semifinal match between Monica Seles and Conchita Martinez at the United States Open on Friday afternoon, and the man who was once New York's pre-eminent tennis fan (actually, he may still be) took shelter with hundreds of others under the stands.

title: The Zephyr Is Boarding on Track 29, Near the Birdbath
description: JERRY HUBER of Suwanee, Ga., always wanted a model train set, but he never had room for one. Now space is not a problem. Nor is money, apparently. Mr. Huber has spent $2,500 during the last two years to turn his whole backyard into a Lilliputian railway, running 250 feet of track around trees and over a pond full of goldfish.

title: Visiting Midway
description: To the Editor: In your article ''Study Tours on Midway Island'' (July 7), you say the public is being allowed there for the first time since 1941.

title: Psst! Got the Time?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: A Flagship Store That Sets the Pace

title: WORK
description: I know people want to work. It breaks my liberal heart when I hear of 2,000 people in line for 10 job openings at a new hotel or plant. I liked Wilson's pragmatism. He gave concrete suggestions instead of lambasting the system or wringing his hands and misplacing blame, as many politicians are wont to do.

title: Torch Is Passed. Recipes Too.
description: Horst Nord wrapped an assortment of hard candies for a customer last week -- Italian Perugina fruit and chocolate-rum flavors -- and put the Koch & Nord seal on top. ''I told the customer it was very warm, and not to take chocolates,'' he said.

title: Stones of Brittany
description: To the Editor: Don Wallace's ''Silent Stones of Brittany'' (July 14), an account of his family's trip, evoked wonderful memories of that region of France where I was born, at Vannes on the gulf. I was grateful that this interesting, charming corner of France finally came to the attention of the world, to show its beauty and importance in history.

title: NEXT TARGET: NICOTINE
description: It seems to me that the greatest paradox in the Congressional Republicans' argument is their affirmation that Kessler is endangering human lives by withholding potentially lifesaving drugs, when his purpose -- and the necessary reason for prolonged investigation -- is to insure public safety. It can hardly be worth jeopardizing the health of Americans by trusting to luck that a product will be safe. The G.O.P. says it wants to save lives, but is using the American public as a guinea pig truly acting in the people's best interest?

title: A Trotskyite in Love
description: SPECIAL DELIVERY

title: How Saddam Hussein Survives by Losing
description: THE first question to John Deutch, the Director of Central Intelligence, after he gave a speech on terrorism last week was the one that a lot of people may have been wondering about but were afraid to ask:

title: Reaching Viewers Has Its Virtues
description: Folk tales with lessons about honesty, hard work, responsibility, compassion, self-discipline and courage came to brightly colored cartoon life on TV three nights last week, in a series for families called ''Adventures From the Book of Virtues.'' Adapted from the best-selling book edited by William Bennett, a former Education Secretary who is now co-director of Empower America, the tales were broadcast in prime time on PBS.

title: 3 Ideas but No Progress
description: Facing the prospect of increasingly dilapidated schools and overcrowded classrooms at the beginning of 1996, three leading officials -- the Mayor, the Speaker of the City Council and the Speaker of the State Assembly -- offered differing proposals for raising money for renovation and construction.

title: To Some, Still a Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: 15% Hasn't Been Dole's Solution
description: THREE years ago this fall, a relatively unknown New Jersey politician from a locally famous Republican clan, Christine Todd Whitman, frustrated Gov. Jim Florio's bid for re-election, largely on the strength of promised (and subsequently delivered) tax cuts. She and her campaign have since cast an iconic spell over her party, not least Bob Dole and Jack Kemp.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: JANE AND THE UNPLEASANTNESS AT SCARGRAVE MANOR Being the First Jane Austen Mystery. By Stephanie Barron. Bantam, $19.95.

title: Some Stars Are Away, Others Play
description: Over the last month, many of the world's finest players have used the World Cup of hockey as their training camp. For the less elite, training camps opened this weekend, with the usual number of questions.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Manhasset, L.I.; A Prosperous Enclave of Gracious Living
description: FROM the crest of Manhasset Avenue, it is possible to view two features that help make well-to-do Manhasset -- a blue-chip area that, by tradition, includes most of five incorporated villages.

title: If Hunger Hits At Lincoln Center
description: CAFE LUXEMBOURG **

title: Lindsay Lavine, W.M. Webster 4th
description: Lindsay Anne Lavine, a daughter of Mrs. Michael Pakenham of London and Henry Lavine of Washington, was married yesterday to William Mendenhall Webster 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Webster 3d of Greenville, S.C. The Rev. Susan Gresinger performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Kate B. Everitt, Peter L. Denious
description: Kate Bell Everitt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Everitt of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Lockwood Denious, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Denious of Villanova, Pa. The Rev. Edward B. Gammons Jr. performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head, N.J.

title: Argentina Ducks a Fight
description: Twenty years after Jose Siderman was abducted by soldiers in his native Argentina, tortured and forced into exile, he was to have had an extraordinary hearing last week in a Federal court in Los Angeles. The Government of his homeland was scheduled to be in the dock, and it would have been the first time a foreign regime had been tried in the United States for human rights abuses committed in its own territory.

title: THEY LAUGHED AT GALILEO TOO
description: Psychic researchers are wasting their time trying to make robots throw M & M's. They should be studying why women who work in the same office regularly show up wearing the same color outfits (without prior discussion). For example, one day my co-workers and I all showed up (unplanned and somewhat embarrassed) wearing white, raw-silk pants and Indian-embroidered, beaded tops. People kept saying, ''When's the sitar concert?''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: SPORT

title: After Summer Comes The Dark
description: From the Hamptons to Manhattan, many women welcomed the Labor Day week by packing up their light summer colors and putting on their inky all-black outfits. While fashion rules and designer dictates were abandoned decades ago, a psychological fashion change to dark colors continues to take place for women when September rolls along. Just about anything goes, so long as it's all black. For instance, at the Hampton Classic Horse Show (three photos on right), the outfits du jour were dark pants suits, dark dress and dark sports-wear separates. In Manhattan, daytime was for a Gucci T-shirt and trousers, and ankle-length dresses, including one woman out for an afternoon of shopping in a dark lace dress. Remember, there are no fashion rules.

title: Influencing How People Pray and Where They Sit
description: ACCORDING to the United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism, the policy-making organization for Conservative synagogues in North America, a synagogue's ritual or religious affairs committee has these responsibilities:

title: State of the Union
description: FOR MICHAEL ROMANO, THE CHEF AT the Union Square Cafe in Manhattan, cooking is an act of self-discovery. The discipline it takes to prepare lunch and dinner for 500 people, five days a week, was acquired when he was a young chef at the Bristol Hotel in Paris and later at La Caravelle in Manhattan. It is the sort of discipline that becomes second nature to a cook who is schooled in the classic French style. And yet it's safe to say that at 43 Romano is wed to no school.

title: Chemical Reactions
description: Inside the Brain

title: Clubs Where, for a Price, Japanese Men Are Nice to Women
description: A middle-aged woman in a skimpy suit enters an ornately decorated club in the Shinjuku section of Tokyo and a row of sharply dressed young men bow as she descends the spiral staircase. The maitre d'hotel gives the woman his standard greeting: ''Good evening. Whom do you select, Madame?''

title: Q. and A.
description: Evicting A Tenant In a Co-op

title: A Twist, a Cut, a Spin: Penn State's Enis Rolls
description: Curtis Enis had to know that his number would be called early and often today. Two weeks after gaining 241 yards and scoring three touchdowns in the Nittany Lions' season-opening victory against U.S.C. at Giants Stadium, Enis awed the home crowd today.

title: For Abandoned Campuses, Recycled Lives
description: IN other Septembers, the buildings and lawns of Upsala College were filled with the sounds of rambunctious students beginning a new year. Today, amid shuttered buildings and scraggly lawns, the loudest sounds on the East Orange, N.J., campus are those of passing cars.

title: Cristine Sherman, Kellian Robinson
description: Cristine Anne Sherman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Spencer E. Sherman of New York, was married last evening to Kellian Edward Robinson, the son of Dr. Warren Clayton Robinson of Washington and the late Elizabeth Gallup Robinson. The Rev. Samuel W. Edleman officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel took part in the ceremony.

title: You Could Look It Up
description: EVERY high school freshman in this Middlesex County suburb started a course in world history last week, but some received textbooks that do not mention the collapse of the Soviet Union, the military crackdown in Tiananmen Square or the Persian Gulf war. Perennially short of funds, the school district managed to buy new books for the course in 1994, but not enough for every student. So several dozen ninth graders will make do with books published in 1987, which lack the latest maps, photographs and chronicles of history.

title: Crime
description: The centerpiece of Sarah Smith's elegant period novel THE KNOWLEDGE OF WATER (Ballantine, $23) is the torrential flood that nearly swept Paris away in 1910. Dark secrets are washed clean in the deluge, including the identity of the person who killed a winsome street singer known as Mona Lisa, slashing her to death and throwing her into the Seine. Even more brilliantly clarified is the related matter of an art forgery, involving characters who resemble Colette, Picasso, Gertrude Stein and other bohemians in a conspiracy to steal the ''Mona Lisa'' from the Louvre and toss it into the river. A third conundrum is a mystery of the heart: how can Alexander von Reisden (the dashing hero met in Ms. Smith's striking novel ''The Vanished Child'') win his beloved Perdita without compromising her ambitions to become a concert pianist?

title: Co-op Sales Rise In Manhattan
description: Sales of co-op apartments in Manhattan surged in the second quarter of 1996, rebounding from a sluggish first quarter and hitting a four-year peak in volume, according to a survey of transactions reported to the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: McIlvaine Prepared To Trade Pitchers
description: Joe McIlvaine, the Mets' general manager, has a reputation for collecting pitchers the way some people collect baseball cards. Keep all the ones you think might be worth something some day. Never make a trade you might regret.

title: Recital Season Returns At Schools in State
description: CONSERVATORIES, colleges and music schools are returning to the musical swing of things, and concert opportunities are proliferating as well.

title: Manning Pulls it Out In Fourth For Vols
description: With the intense attention of his adopted state suddenly shifted from a game two weeks from now to a growing crisis tonight, Tennessee's Peyton Manning found a way to make everything right.

title: Author Goes To Berlin To Debate Holocaust
description: Imagine a German author touring the United States to tell America's premier scholars that they had gotten the history of slavery all wrong.

title: The Tensions in District 28 Go Far Beyond Individuals
description: To the Editor:

title: The Z-Car, From A to Zzzzz
description: ROADSTERS have caught the public's fancy, at least for the moment, and there is enough demand to justify new designs for high-priced grand-touring cars like the Jaguar XK8 and the Aston Martin DB7. But the conventional, affordable, enclosed sports car seems increasingly endangered. The latest casualty was the Nissan 300ZX, put to rest last month, ending a 26-year run for the widely acclaimed ''Z car.''

title: With Redistricting in Vogue, Velaquez Takes a Spot in Line
description: This was when Nydia M. Velazquez had expected to hit her stride. After staking out a position as a vocal spokeswoman on issues like immigration and housing, the two-term Congresswoman had hoped to establish herself this year as a major Congressional player.

title: DIARY
description: POLITICS

title: Sooner or Later You're Sure to Know Why You're Late
description: WHEN Dr. Linda Sapadin, a clinical psychologist, taught a seminar on overcoming procrastination, she said, she could not find books to recommend to her students at Hofstra. A few books dealt with time management rather than the psychological dynamics that she believed were at the root of procrastination.

title: An Insider Gets Rich On Trades, And Walks
description: James H. O'Hagan was a lawyer in a Minneapolis firm who learned that a client of the firm planned to make a big takeover offer. So he bought stock and stock options in the target company. He made $4 million.

title: Office Space Is Again Drawing a Crowd of Investors
description: THESE are good times for northern New Jersey's office sector, prompting a steady flow of investors who are returning to the market with an increased appetite for acquisition.

title: 1915 Equitable Building Becomes a 1996 Landmark
description: IT was, in its time, the biggest, baddest, light-blockingest, street-congestingest space-hog ever to touch down on Manhattan bedrock. But this summer the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the 1915 Equitable Building, at 120 Broadway, an official city landmark. Is it a monster -- or a monument? Or both?

title: Gertrude of Arabia
description: DESERT QUEEN The Extraordinary Life of Gertrude Bell: Adventurer, Adviser to Kings, Ally of Lawrence of Arabia. By Janet Wallach. Illustrated. 419 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $27.50.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE BOOKSELLER By Matt Cohen.

title: Separate Plaques Belong In Holocaust Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: An Indian Casino To Share Its Roots
description: AMONG the things that distinguish the Foxwoods Casino are a large, translucent archer who shoots a laser arrow into the sky to make rain, the costumes and feathers worn by cocktail waitresses, and a very modest Mashantucket Pequot museum in the casino's basement (though a $130 million museum and research center is scheduled to open in 1998).

title: Union Members March On a Rescheduled Day
description: With thousands of hospital aides, teachers and electrical workers as well as a re-election-minded Mayor stepping down Fifth Avenue, yesterday's union parade was in many ways like Labor Day parades of old, but with a new date and theme as part of labor's efforts to gain members and clout.

title: Life at NY 1, Where the News and Reporters Never Seem to Stop
description: AFTER a typical day on overdrive - covering a news conference on adult protective services and acting as a host for the nightly talk program ''Inside City Hall'' - Dominic Carter was finally fast asleep when the telephone jolted him awake, at 2:50 A.M.

title: Federal Welfare Shift Spotlights Unusual Amendment to State Constitution
description: One warm summer day, a prominent Republican stood before a group of civic-minded people, some of them pillars of his party, and told them that the welfare system was ''unworkable and cumbersome.''

title: An Attention to Detail
description: Almost every day during the summer of 1972, Scott G. McNealy pushed a broom around the lot of Roger Penske's Chevrolet dealership in downtown Detroit. But that simple job gave him his first taste of pressure. Because also every day, Mr. Penske would walk the lot, making sure that not one cigarette butt was left on the ground.

title: NEXT TARGET: NICOTINE
description: Your article on David Kessler makes it obvious why the Commissioner's grab for jurisdiction over smoking in America is such a dangerous idea. He states quite clearly that if his current plan to combat youth smoking doesn't work, he will move on to other undefined steps. But consider what such undefined steps could include, keeping in mind that on previous occasions Kessler has said that under F.D.A. rules he might have to ban cigarettes altogether. The crucial issue is this: Would Kessler, or some future commissioner, consider a form of prohibition for adult smokers as a way of trying to solve the complex social problem of youth smoking?

title: New Role, at Long Last, For a Many-Sided Barn
description: FINALLY, on July 21, after 10 long years of what often seemed a never-be-done effort, the fully restored Bradley-Wheeler Cobblestone Barn opened. The seven-sided (with octagonal roof) cobblestone building, tucked behind Wheeler House, the Westport Historical Society's headquarters, stands as one of the only structures of its type in Connecticut.

title: On the L.I.E., Lane Cheaters Go to the Rear
description: THERE is nothing so democratic as a traffic jam, nothing so heartwarming as the sight of a pristine Mercedes idling next to a sputtering and dusty Datsun. In those moments, it seems, we have answered Rodney King's plea: we are getting along, if ever so slowly.

title: A Lake of Tears
description: ''I didn't want it to touch me,'' Michelle Edwards said, in explaining why she refused to let her 6-year-old daughter wade in the shallows of John D. Long Lake. After last week, it was hard not to be superstitious. Last weekend, the infamous lake in Union, S.C., swallowed up a family of five and two other people who had been drawn to the site where Susan Smith drowned her two young sons two years before.

title: Yes, Cut Medical Costs, but First Do No Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Away From the Bars, Gays Find a Place to Meet
description: ''The gay people are on Christopher Street.'' That sentence, remembered from a book, was the only hint 18-year-old Steven Segal had when he came to New York that there was a place in the city where homosexuals gathered. Growing up gay in Ukraine had left him feeling isolated and confused. So he made his way to the Village and wandered the street made famous by the Stonewall uprising. Problem was, he did not know what a homosexual looked like. ''In my mind, I was the only one,'' he recalled. ''I thought I was a freak.''

title: Ferry Stays Afloat, Part Time
description: Under pressure from commuters, NY Waterway has resumed its ferry service to midtown from Hunters Point during the morning and evening rush hours.

title: Odd Couples
description: LOVERBOYS

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: NIGHTMOVER:

title: Is Your Home Adequately Insulated?
description: WITHIN the last 30 years, insulation and caulking have become major concerns for homeowners and builders. Before the energy crunch of the 70's, homeowners found that fuel was inexpensive and the cost of keeping the home warm was low compared with the cost of installing insulation.

title: Anticipating A Boon To Sellers
description: IN their quest to win the hearts and minds of voters, both Bill Clinton and Bob Dole have promised to virtually eliminate the capital-gains tax imposed on profits from the sale of a principal residence. If whoever wins follows through on the promise, and Congress goes along, the end of the tax could have a profound impact on real estate sales, life-style choices and the bottom line for millions of homeowners.

title: Hotel Problems
description: To the Editor: Last May we had written confirmation of our reservations in hand, and had paid a deposit, at the King David in Jerusalem. We chose it because it was part of the Leading Hotels of the World. We called the day before we arrived, and were assured that everything was in order and that our room would be waiting. When we arrived, it was not available. Personnel at the King David explained that it was under extensive remodeling, and that the administration had believed the renovations would be finished in time. We never called the day before, they said, otherwise they would have told us; but even had we called it would have made no difference because the rooms were not finished and it is not hotel policy to give such information over the telephone.

title: Caldrons Like the Kurds' Require High Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubting Keeper of Mexico's Guadalupe Shrine Is Stepping Down
description: For much of the last year, the head of the Roman Catholic Church here has been seeking to oust the aging abbot who administers Mexico's most important shrine, the Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe. But the abbot has clung tenaciously to his post.

title: Nursery Plan or Sand Mining?
description: FOR perhaps as long as 21,000 years, a kame formed by a retreating glacier has risen from an area now in the pine barrens preserve in Manorville. Now a plan by the operator of a tree farm to level the hill to expand a nursery may erase it in fewer than five years.

title: Roast Tomatoes for Enriching Vegetables or Topping Pizza
description: SOMETIMES a technique crops up so simple you wonder why everyone has not been using it for years. When sun-dried tomatoes first appeared on the market, I tried unsuccessfully to make my own by putting them on a rack and setting them out in the sun under a pane of glass.

title: A Sort of Open House, With a Puppet
description: THINK of it as a talk show without the couch. On ''Fox After Breakfast,'' the Fox network's new weekday entry in the 9 to 10 A.M. slot, the scene often resembles not so much Leno or Letterman as it does an open house, or perhaps a garage sale.

title: Hard Times, Not Paradise, For Young Cubans in U.S.
description: They were lost in the Florida Straits, drifting atop rope-lashed planks of wood and sagging rubber dinghies. But as they pitched across the shark-infested waters, the 139 Cuban teen-agers who had abandoned family and country kept their hopes alive with visions of life in the United States.

title: A Hotel Boom In Puerto Rico
description: A hotel construction boom is under way in Puerto Rico, with 10 new or upgraded properties scheduled to open within the next two years. Among those opening this year are the Westin Rio Mar Beach Resort and Country Club and the Wyndham Old San Juan Hotel and Casino.

title: JAZZ
description: Here is a selective guide to coming cultural events in New York and beyond. Events that are starred are those that Times critics consider particularly noteworthy. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear on page 80.

title: Connecticut Arms Against Mosquito-Borne Virus
description: Connecticut health officials are taking precautionary measures to prevent the spread of Eastern equine encephalitis, a deadly mosquito-borne virus that has been found in insects in neighboring Westerly, R.I., as well in central and eastern Long Island.

title: The Tensions in District 28 Go Far Beyond Individuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Tips on Avoiding Noisy Leaf Blowers
description: Here's a solution to Bedford's noisy leaf blowers cited by Kenneth L. Golub $(Letters to the Editor, Aug. 11$): Allow grass cuttings to lie fallow, to decay and enrich the soil and for fallen leaves to be reserved for the compost pile.

title: June Lessons Make for a Smooth First Day
description: WHEN classes began at John Pettibone School in New Milford this year, teachers were delighted to find most of their elementary students unusually relaxed, prepared and willing to get down to business right away.

title: A Terrorist Is Convicted
description: Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the man accused of organizing the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center, was found guilty last week of hatching another audacious plot -- a conspiracy to blow up a dozen American jetliners in Asia last year.

title: Why Cambodia May Overlook Its Past
description: THERE have been few political makeovers to equal it. Ieng Sary, a creator of one of the world's most stringent and brutal Maoist societies, is now advertising himself as a liberal democrat.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THE DEVIL PROBLEM And Other True Stories. By David Remnick. Random House, $25.95.

title: More on the Problem Of Incontinence
description: In the Westchester Weekly on July 21, there was a Q&A column with the headline ''Treating an Embarrassing Ailment.'' Two types of incontinence are described: stress and urge. The cause of urge incontinence was described as ''some sort of neurological problem . . . like a stroke or a brain tumor or something else like that.'' Brain tumors rarely cause incontinence, but sometimes patients with strokes, sometimes in the acute phases, are incontinent.

title: Watercraft Take a Toll, On People and Environment
description: Three people have died in New Jersey using personal watercraft (the generic name for Jet Skis and other water sports equipment); 32 more have been injured. With about a month of the boating season to go, that represents a record number of deaths and a record-setting pace for injuries, the State Police said.

title: LOOPHOLES ALLOW PRESIDENTIAL RACE TO SET A RECORD
description: Even though Republicans and Democrats strongly argued for campaign finance reform this year, both parties are taking advantage of a variety of loopholes to get around Federal campaign spending limitations, making the 1996 Presidential race the most expensive in history.

title: Nothing Ugly About This Duckling
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. VINES
description: Blanc Fume

title: Susan Chrein, Robert Yules
description: Susan Cheryl Chrein, a newspaper executive, and Robert Brown Yules, a lawyer, are to marry today at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman is to officiate.

title: The Cult of the Individual
description: THE PERVERSION OF AUTONOMY The Proper Uses of Coercion and Constraints in a Liberal Society. By Willard Gaylin and Bruce Jennings. 270 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: Separate Plaques Belong In Holocaust Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Buying Vs. Renting
description: To the Editor:

title: Gathering a Nosegay of Apples From an Orchard of Specialties
description: WHAT has a ''fruity spicy aroma blend, integrating elements of apricot, musk, almond and fennel?'' A ''light subdued flavor with a juicy, effervescent note?'' ''Accents of strawberry and 7-Up with added pleasure impact from succulent and unexpectedly tender, almost slippery flesh?'' Red Ribster, Lady Sudely and Mantet, respectively.

title: The Wrong Way to Lure Business
description: The financially strapped government of New York City doles out hundreds of millions of dollars each year in tax breaks and loans to encourage businesses to remain or expand within the city. In pursuit of that goal, the city sometimes gets into self-defeating bidding wars with Connecticut and New Jersey just to keep businesses from moving a few miles away. There are few overall benefits to that kind of competition. But now the State Legislature has passed a bill guaranteed to make the situation worse by giving the five boroughs new resources to engage in bidding wars of their own. Gov. George Pataki should recognize that the city's broad interest lies in a veto of the bill.

title: A Nonchain Bookstore Bucks the Tide
description: IN a day and age when mega-bookstores are taking over the planet, the opening of an independent book shop deserves attention.

title: One More Spin of the Wheel for Atlantic City
description: ''The great hotels stood behind the boardwalk, one next to the other, their awnings flapping in the sea wind, their immaculately painted porches lined with rocking chairs and white wicker settees. Nautical flags flew from the cupolas and at night they were lighted by rows of incandescent bulbs strung along their roof lines.''

title: Peg LaCentra, 86, a Singer With Shaw Orchestra
description: Peg LaCentra, a singer with Artie Shaw's first orchestra, died on June 1 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 86.

title: Skim the Milk, Gorge on Fries
description: What did you eat yesterday?

title: In a Building That Symbolizes Crowding, a Principal and a Parent Square Off
description: Last week, Intermediate School 61 in Corona, Queens, provided the backdrop for a photo opportunity for leaders of the city's teachers union as they decried systemwide overcrowding. But behind the scenes, the chronically oversubscribed school, also known as the Leonardo da Vinci School, is confronting some other problems, including a dispute between the principal, Phyllis LaPerchia, and the head of the school's parent association, Nellie Aguilar.

title: A Home for Rising Playwrights Is Ready for a Broadway House
description: WHATEVER PEOPLE might say about Broadway -- that it is solely an outlet for mass entertainment, for example, or that there is no room on it for serious drama, or that it is merely a musical circus for tourists -- no one is immune to its allure. It remains the prime showcase of American theater, the place for actors, directors, playwrights and producers to have their wares exhibited to greatest effect; the place for bright lights, big crowds, Tony Awards. And so it beckons.

title: Kohl Finds Yeltsin 'Active' But 'Worried' About Surgery
description: An ailing President Boris N. Yeltsin today received his first foreign visitor since his re-election in July, giving Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany a chance to size up Mr. Yeltsin's condition during a four-hour informal meeting.

title: The Packers Are Back for More
description: The Green Bay Packers will tell you that they are good, that they believe in themselves and that they are willing to work. That is their blueprint to reach the Super Bowl.

title: Wrong Lights
description: To the Editor:

title: Dick Morris's Behavior, and Why It's Tolerated
description: FIRST came shock. Then the titillation and the jokes from the late-night comedians. Now the book deals.

title: Old-Fashioned Fare, and Steak Is Prime
description: DECORATING the walls of a narrow dining gallery on the perimeter of the capacious bar area are charming photographs of Port Chester's past, when the city flourished as a busy port. The prints show factories, warehouses and other signs of commerce that filled the dusty little streets, which stopped just short of the Byram River. Most of these buildings have been razed, but a few remain and have been recycled. The Willett House is one of those, employing with care and skill the old bricks and timbers in this beauty of a restaurant that serves, appropriately enough, a type of old-fashioned fare that seems to be making a comeback -- aged prime steaks.

title: Bright Young Authors For Textbook Jazz
description: JUST FIVE YEARS AGO THEY

title: Criticizing Regulations, Dole Courts Small-Business Owners
description: Bob Dole campaigned today for support among small-business owners, denouncing the ''long arm of the Federal Government'' as he assailed ''overboard'' environmental regulations and a law, signed by President Clinton, which allows family members time off to care for newborns or ailing relatives.

title: Summer's Over. Back To School We Go.
description: LITERATURE, MUSIC AND modern history. It sounds like a school curriculum, but it is a description of what this season's flashier movies are offering. On tap are no fewer than three adaptations of Shakespeare, a Henry James and other Eng. Lit. classics. There will also be four musicals, including Woody Allen's ''Everyone Says I Love You'' and ''Evita,'' about Eva Peron.

title: A Native American Sun-Worshiper
description: THE sunflowers are filling out, coming into their own with golden ray petals circling the brown center, or disk, flowers. Quite often the flower heads flop over because they are so heavy with the rich seed that will make superb winter bird food. If the plants are being raised for their valuable seed, however, it is helpful to put a cheesecloth or old potato bag over the flower as it ripens to keep the flocks away for now.

title: Auction Could Be Curtains for Theater
description: La Tea Theater is going ahead as if everything were normal: rehearsals have begun for its fall plays, like ''Mofongo Con Ketchup.'' One flight up, workers are finishing the new Kabayitos Puppet Theater, where puppeteers from as far as the Czech Republic are to perform at its opening next month. But the shows might not go on.

title: A Children's Fund That Adults Might Envy
description: The Stein Roe Young Investor fund is sizzling. The fund captured first place among 735 growth funds with a 30.2 percent return for the 12 months ended on Thursday, compared with 10.9 percent for its group. It's up 20 percent in 1996, through Thursday, nearly triple the average return for its peers, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund researchers.

title: Miss Hammond And Mr. Pyle
description: Elizabeth Powell Hammond, a daughter of Page Smoot Hammond of Salisbury, Md., and Edward Hopkins Hammond Jr. of Berlin, Md., was married yesterday to Russell Townsend Pyle, a son of Mrs. Charles McAlpin Pyle Jr. of Dedham, Mass., and the late Mr. Pyle. The Rev. Graham T. Rowley performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Berlin.

title: Besieged by Calls? Rally 'Round the Flag
description: WHEN stocks tumbled in the middle of July, Jim Gately, captain of Vanguard's ''Swiss Army,'' put his forces on alert, fearful that the company would be inundated by calls and that extra troops would be needed to handle the volume of orders, answer myriad questions about fund performance and just hold some hands.

title: An L.I. Connection Fills a Gap Created by NASA Budget Cuts
description: ORBITING the Earth, Dr. Lawrence J. DeLucas said, is quite different from being on it. In the 14 days he was in space, the biochemist found that he slept less than usual, gained weight and lost muscle mass.

title: 2 1/2 Minutes With 21 Chances for Success
description: ARMED with monologues, songs and 21 copies of their resumes, the hopefuls, ages 18 to 70-something, were waiting for their two and a half minutes. One reclined against a piano. One did stretches and warm-ups on the floor. One was reciting lines to the wall. Most just paced.

title: Catherine Crane, John Robinson 3d
description: Catherine Wilson Crane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight B. Crane of Boston, was married yesterday to John Clark Robinson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Robinson Jr. of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. Gildon D. Stillings performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of South Dartmouth in Padanaram, Mass.

title: Gordon Stein, 55, Who Exposed Hoaxes, Dies
description: Gordon Stein, who made the celebration of secular humanism and the exposure of spiritualism and secular hoaxes the focus of his work as a librarian, bibliographer, author and editor, died on Aug. 27 at a Buffalo hospital. He was 55 and the director of libraries at the Center for Inquiry in the Buffalo suburb of Amherst.

title: For Japan's Children, A Japanese Torment
description: SUMMER vacation? Yusuke Terao, an elementary school principal, hardly had even a moment to relax.

title: Stanley Salvigsen, Market Analyst, 53
description: Stanley D. Salvigsen, a Wall Street analyst and investor who co-founded the money management firm Comstock Partners, died on Aug. 30 in Kinnelon, N.J. He was 53.

title: Jaime Chwatt and Evan Friedman
description: WHEN people ask Jaime Chwatt and Evan Friedman how they met, they say, ''Oh, by accident.''

title: Hurricane Season
description: Hurricane Fran left her mark last week on the Carolina coast and later brought torrential rains and flooding to central North Carolina and Virginia. Twelve people died in storm-related incidents and property damage was sure to rise into the hundreds of millions.

title: Clinton Again Urges Senate to Back Chemical-Arms Ban
description: With United States pilots patrolling an expanded no-flight zone in southern Iraq, President Clinton renewed his call today for the Senate to ratify the international Chemical Weapons Convention to put pressure on ''rogue states'' like Iraq.

title: Lisa M. Reed, James Mooney 3d
description: Lisa Marie Reed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Reed of Lynnfield, Mass., was married yesterday to James F. Mooney 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mooney Jr. of Boston. The Rev. Charles J. Higgins, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Victories in Boston.

title: Darcy McCulloch And Barry Rice
description: Patricia Darcy McCulloch, a daughter of Mrs. John I. B. McCulloch of New York and the late Mr. McCulloch, was married yesterday at her mother's house in East Hampton, L.I., to Barry Melville Rice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce O. Rice of Brisbane, Australia. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, the Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Getting a Real Grip on Motorcycling
description: SLOW, look, lean, roll -- and try to stay within the cones. It seemed a daunting task to those who had never driven a motorcycle, but by the end of the first day of the Connecticut Rider Education Program, each student had successfully made the 45 degree turn at least once.

title: 2 Charged in Store Worker's Killing
description: Two Brooklyn men were charged yesterday in the fatal shooting of a jewelry store worker during a daylight robbery late last month in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Dancing to 'Beehive'
description: FOR certain tastes, it has been strange pickings at the Phoenix Theater Company. A play about the dying Count Leo Tolstoy's estranged and demented wife (''Sonya'') was followed by the absurdist comic relief of ''Below the Belt,'' a syllogistic workout beyond the grasp of some audiences.

title: A Bustling Arena for Italian Soul Food
description: LONG ISLAND loves Italian food. Nick Diangelo is confirming that. This new Merrick hot spot, with the same owners as George Martin, a popular bistro in Rockville Centre; has met with instant success.

title: DANCE
description: Here is a selective guide to coming cultural events in New York and beyond. Events that are starred are those that Times critics consider particularly noteworthy. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear on page 80.

title: An S.R.O. Hotel Makes Room For Tourists
description: Five months ago, the 12-story building at 161 Lexington Avenue was a single-room-occupancy hotel with 165 building-code violations. It was inhabited mostly by low-income residents, some of whom paid less than $200 a month in rent.

title: A Call to Clear Pollution From Skies in the West
description: ARE the great open vistas of the West becoming hazier, or clearer? When a haze descends, is it more likely to come from nearby vehicle traffic or from faraway factories and power plants? And what should be done to protect a resource as plentiful and as easy to waste as a skyful of emptiness?

title: THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: California

title: A Revue's Girl Groups, Lots of 60's Big Hair
description: FOR certain tastes, it has been strange pickings at the Phoenix Theater Company in Purchase, N.Y., this season. A play about the dying Count Leo Tolstoy's estranged and demented wife (''Sonya'') was followed by the absurdist comic relief of ''Below the Belt,'' a syllogistic workout beyond the grasp of some audiences.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PRISCILLA TWICE

title: INSIDE
description: Iraqi Troops Menace Erbil

title: Kevorkian Helps 40th Suicide, Day After Police Tried to Intervene
description: Less than 24 hours after the police disrupted a counseling session for assisted suicide between Dr. Jack Kevorkian and a 60-year-old California woman, his main lawyer announced here today that she had killed herself with the doctor's assistance at an undisclosed location.

title: A Classic Goes To Europe, Returning Brand New
description: TO enter the Vitra furniture factory here, you first have to grasp a few metaphors. The metal door handle, for example, looks abstract but is shaped like Switzerland. A right-hander's palm would rest on Basel, home to this Swiss-based furniture company, which has emerged as one of Europe's leaders in fostering good design, a successor to Braun or Olivetti.

title: Just a Little Inflation, And Everybody's Happy
description: A NEW theme is gradually inserting itself into the debate over inflation. The traditional stance -- beat down inflation -- still draws plenty of applause. But after a long spell of mild inflation, economists, politicians and corporate executives are migrating toward the view that the present inflation rate should be preserved, perhaps nourished.

title: Faith McGauley, C.T. Whitman
description: Faith Marie McGauley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. McGauley Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Thomas Whitman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Thomas Whitman of Memphis. The Rev. Val Handwerker, a Roman Catholic priest who is the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Church in West Hartford.

title: Home Shopping Network
description: SAY what you will about the Big Freeway, but you can get absolutely anything you want in this state.

title: Defer Capital Gains on Stock Sales? Here's the Catch
description: IN studying the tax code for his financial-planner exam, Damian Gallina was drawn to a rule that allows people to defer capital-gains taxes. All that taxpayers had to do was to reinvest money from stock sales in a way that helped businesses run by women, members of minority groups, Vietnam veterans and others hampered by social or economic disadvantages.

title: That Cold Caller Might Have Been Me
description: DID you get a call from me this summer?

title: Community Input Ignored On More Than One Front
description: To the Editor:

title: A Half-Hearted Tyson Punch Is Enough to Knock Out Seldon
description: Mike Tyson found the only underdeveloped part of Bruce Seldon's body: the jaw.

title: So Far, Jobs Are Hot Item At New Mall
description: Each day for two weeks, in a line that snaked around a city block in downtown Brooklyn, hundreds of men and women stood under the hot August sun vying for the first jobs at the Atlantic Center, the mammoth mall slated to open this fall on Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues. By Labor Day, some 375 had landed jobs as cashiers, stock clerks and sales representatives at the Caldor's store.

title: A Promise of Refuge, Aloft and Afield
description: ARCHITECTURE TODAY OFFERS FLASHES OF HOPE and inspiration against a background of deepening unease. Their profession still economically pinched, many architects are feeling as if they themselves are down for the count. And their art form is particularly vulnerable to the perils of ''the risk society.'' No sector of society is safe from system collapse, and buildings can seem like metaphors for a psychological shelter that is increasingly out of reach.

title: New York City Primary Elections
description: When: Tuesday. Polling places will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: ID at Airports
description: To the Editor: In regard to ''Identity Crisis at the Airport'' (Practical Traveler, June 23) I want to tell you about the most stressful time of my life. Just after arriving at my daughter's home in Baltimore on March 8, I was told that my husband was in critical condition at a South Carolina hospital. It was 5 P.M.

title: Rollins Redux: A Political Moment
description: Any political Peeping Tom would love to have peered inside the green room of CNN's Larry King Live program in San Diego last month, just to observe the body language of Governor Whitman or perhaps see the look on her face. As she waited to appear on the show that day, Mrs. Whitman came eyeball to eyeball with a nightmare from her past.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Here is a selective guide to coming cultural events in New York and beyond. Events that are starred are those that Times critics consider particularly noteworthy. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear on page 80.

title: No Headline
description: ''Money is distorting democracy now. Money not only determines who wins, but often who runs. If you've got a good idea and $10,000 and I've got a terrible idea and $1 million, I can convince people that the terrible idea is a good one.''

title: WORK
description: Nowhere in his article does Wilson examine the effect of the 1960's counterculture redefinition of ''work'' as ''meaningful jobs.'' As an educator in the Bronx from 1966 to 1995, I was witness to this catastrophic change, as students who once snickered at friends and relatives on the welfare line now sneered at parents, relatives and friends who had less than the culturally defined ''meaningful jobs.'' The shame of ''work'' had replaced the shame of welfare. It was an easy step from having a ''no-account job'' to being ''a no account.''

title: Jersey Tomatoes Are Hitting the Road, Seeking Markets Away From Home
description: IT'S been a cool, wet summer for New Jersey's tomato farmers -- not the most ideal growing conditions -- but Phil Neary takes solace in the fact that cat-facing and zipper scars are at a minimum.

title: For a Family of 6, A New Harlem Home
description: A MIDDLE-AGED MAN in a khaki work outfit, faded to the color of a ripe wheat field on a sunny day, greeted a neighbor on the street, nodding and wishing him ''good day.'' The largest of three chatting women was overheard by a passer-by in the midst of a sentence: '' . . . because it goes from generation to generation to generation -- on this same block!'' The other two women nodded sagely.

title: U.N. Assembly to Consider A-Test Ban Tomorrow
description: Using a maneuver never tried before to win adoption of a major international arms control treaty, Australia and more than 115 other countries will go to the General Assembly on Monday and seek approval of a pact banning all nuclear explosions worldwide. The treaty could be adopted and ready for signing by individual countries within a few days.

title: Ms. Carpenter, Mr. Mills Jr.
description: Camilla Sanderson Carpenter, a vice president of film programming at Home Box Office in New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Albert Mills Jr., the president of Hyperion Resources, a management consulting concern in New York. The Rev. Elizabeth S. McWhorter performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Correction
description: A theater listing on page 75 of the Arts and Leisure section today for the October production of ''The Waiting Room'' misstates the telephone number of the Vineyard Theater. It is (212) 353-3874.

title: A Quarter-Century of Educational Tides
description: WHEN Dr. James P. Kennedy returned to his New England roots in 1972 to become superintendent of schools in Manchester, it was to a suburban, middle-class town that had 10,000 public school students including a 2 percent minority enrollment.

title: Bonnie Barrett, Michael Leverone
description: Bonnie Barrett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Barrett of Westboro, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Leverone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Leverone of Norfolk, Mass. The Rev. Mark C. Hallinan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Canada Edges Sweden In Double Overtime
description: Never had Team Canada missed the final of this tournament's predecessor, the Canada Cup. And thanks to Theo Fleury, Team Canada will not miss the finals of this one either.

title: German Unity Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Republicans Come to Town, One on a Mission, One More Mellow
description: Years can go by and nothing of political import happens on Easton Street, but this week two major Republican events were held there, and though they were just across the way from each other, they felt a half a century apart.

title: TELEVISION
description: Here is a selective guide to coming cultural events in New York and beyond. Events that are starred are those that Times critics consider particularly noteworthy. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear on page 80.

title: Maxwell E. Cox, 73, A Lawyer, a Novelist And a Civic Leader
description: Maxwell Evarts Cox, a lawyer, novelist and community leader, died on Thursday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 73 years old.

title: Heritage, Tradition and Lists, Lists, Lists
description: THE rabbi is polishing his sermon. The cantor is reviewing the music. Karen Rose is making lists.

title: Christine Smith, Alexander Guettel
description: Christine Campbell Smith, the daughter of Joan and Douglas Smith of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday in Dorset, Vt., to Alexander Burton Guettel, a son of Mary Rodgers Guettel and Henry Guettel of New York. The Rev. Leslie Smith, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the United Church of Dorset and East Rupert, Vt.

title: Runaway Mom
description: THE OTHER FAMILY

title: Why Lilco Rates Are So High
description: The New York State officials in ''Officials Moving To Readjust Lilco Rates'' $(Aug. 18$) are in the position of burglars who excuse their entry on the grounds that they need the money.

title: Driver's Ed, Where Driving Is a Blood Sport
description: IT was Elizabeth Miller's fifth driving lesson and the August sun had turned her instructor's 1992 Chevrolet Geo into a sauna. Both hands gripping the wheel, her back straight, her shoulders tense, Mrs. Miller, 27, carefully maneuvered the car around the hundreds of double-parked vehicles along the often narrow streets of Morningside Heights.

title: Child of Basquiat
description: HE may, sighting for sighting, be one of the most visible painters in town. His work adorns the walls of SoHo and NoHo buildings and is appreciated daily by everyone from hipsters to garage mechanics, though it has also been torn down and ripped apart and has suffered the gross insults of the street. He's prolific, he has fans and he has started, just started, to have a taste of success.

title: Jennifer Ehrhardt, Philip L. Iglehart
description: Jennifer Gamble Ehrhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dyson Price Ehrhardt of Baldwin, Md., was married yesterday to Philip Lonsdale Iglehart, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Corning Iglehart of Glyndon, Md. The Rev. Philip B. Roulette performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Glyndon.

title: Corporate Citizens and Their Critics
description: BUSINESS is being urged to embrace ''corporate citizenship.'' Just as with the individual citizen, the good corporate citizen is expected to act with integrity and be socially responsible, which has come to mean not only acting responsibly in fulfilling its primary function of producing goods and services, but also ''doing good'' in seemingly unrelated areas -- by improving working conditions, for example, for the employees of overseas suppliers.

title: Elizabeth Riley, Bernd Bressel
description: Elizabeth Taber Riley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gregory Riley of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Bernd Bressel, a son of Stefanie Freitag of Barsinghausen, Germany, and Horst Bressel of Wennigsen, Germany. The Rev. Churchill G. Pinder performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: BECAUSE WE ARE HERE Stories and Novellas. By Chuck Wachtel. Viking, $24.95.

title: 'Freedom' on the Water Comes Down to Chaos
description: To the Editor:

title: Muskrat Love, Meet Beaver Arithmetic
description: To the Editor:

title: Reconfirming the Unending 'Housing Emergency'
description: THE rental housing market has strengthened in New York City in the last three years, the result of a stronger economy combined with extremely low new housing production.

title: Teen-Ager Sees Politics as G.O.P. Page
description: IN what is apparently becoming more and more atypical for a teen-ager or young adult, Marielle K. Sack, a 19-year-old from Briarcliff Manor, finds politics and government fascinating and says they are relevant to her life. Her interest led her to apply for -- and with the help of the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke -- obtain a position as a volunteer page at the Republican National Convention in San Diego.

title: A Season of Diversity In Which Outsiders Find Their Way In
description: WHAT MAKES THE 1996-97 ART SEASON different from others? Difference itself: an increasing cultural diversity is everywhere evident. On all fronts, the margins will invade the mainstream with increasing force. There will be an unusually large number of museum shows devoted to women and minority artists, to outsider artists and to non-Western art.

title: Waiting for Ayatollah Gorbachev
description: What produces a Mikhail Gorbachev? That is the question.

title: Near Vancouver, the Chinese Stake Is Growing
description: A CHINESE presence is becoming pervasive in this city on the southern outskirts of Vancouver as developers scramble to build malls, condominiums and homes to serve wealthy new residents emigrating from Hong Kong and Taiwan and others arriving from elsewhere in Canada.

title: Learning To Love The Sawtooths
description: PEOPLE who love mountains often become captivated with a particular chain. As a child, I bonded with the Front Range of the Colorado Rockies, scrambling among the mountains crowded around the town of Estes Park with my family for two weeks, 10 summers in a row. Even though I've since seen the volcanoes of Hawaii and the Chilean Cordillera, the ideal mountain to me is still Longs Peak, or Twin Sisters, or Flattop -- all peaks in the Front Range's unmatched skyline.

title: Glass Show In Venice
description: Venice will play host to ''Open Glass,'' the city's first international exhibition of contemporary glass art, from Sept. 12 to Nov. 10. The exhibition will feature the work of more than 100 contemporary glass artists from around the world, including Dale Chihuly from the United States, Stanislav Libensky from the Czech Republic, Bert Frijns from the Netherlands and Antoine Leperlier from France.

title: The True Terror is in the Card
description: LAST WINTER, A FRIEND OF MINE from Washington was mugged in New York City and had her wallet stolen. Shaken by the experience, she wanted only one thing, to get back home. Luckily, her employer's headquarters is in Manhattan and she was able to borrow cash to get to the airport. But she had some fast explaining to do there because Delta was demanding that passengers produce a driver's license or other ID before boarding the plane. After some trouble, she was finally able to convince the airline of her identity by proving she was a Delta frequent flyer. She would have an even harder time today because airlines are much more stringent since the Olympics and the T.W.A. crash.

title: Choosing Beauty Over the Beast
description: To the Editor:

title: Shall We Dance?
description: Fred Astaire's incomparable footwork and the grace of the lovely Leslie Caron as his newest partner highlight DADDY LONG LEGS (1955), an otherwise okay but rather frail tale adapted from the old Jean Webster novel by Phoebe and Henry Ephron. Durable sunshine, with a score that has one terrific number - you'll see. It' a picture whose heart - along with the feet of the two stars - is in the right place, no question about it. Basically this is the same old story of the millionaire (playboy, here) benefactor loved by the delectable orphan (now French, of course) who has never seen him. Enter Astaire, at the girl's college and the complications set in. So does the fine dancing along with a nice batch of tunes by Johnny Mercer - THURSDAY at 11:15 A.M. on SHOWTIME.

title: It Walks Like Vanguard, but It Talks With a Different Accent
description: WHEN John Wandell tried to sell some of his no-load mutual funds six months ago, the fund company talked him out of it. He said he was glad it did.

title: Adam J. Rak, Allison M. Clinton
description: Allison Mary Clinton and Adam Joseph Rak, legislative aides in Connecticut's Congressional delegation in Washington, were married yesterday in Squaw Valley, Calif. The Rev. Paul Soukup officiated at Queen of the Snows Roman Catholic Church.

title: Air Tax Returns, But Price Rise Holds Off
description: Air fares change often, but rarely quite so rapidly as they did late last month when the Federal Government started collecting a 10 percent ticket tax on domestic fares, a tax that Congress let lapse at the beginning of the year.

title: Karaoke Crackdown Stirs Ethnic Anger in Palisades Park
description: On Broad Avenue, the aptly named main drag of this working-class borough, there is a nocturnal world that most of its 16,000 residents never see: a world of Korean businesses that hum until the wee hours.

title: Caution Urged on Offer Of International License
description: An organization called the Pan American Auto Travel Association, with a post office box in San Juan, P.R., is offering international driving permits by mail through a site on the World Wide Web although the United States Department of State has authorized only two organizations to sell these permits in the United States: the American Automobile Association and the American Auto Touring Alliance.

title: Down Through a Sea of Memory, Long Branch as It Was
description: Winslow Homer's 1869 oil painting ''Long Branch, New Jersey,'' is a highlight of the Homer exhibition that runs until Sept. 22 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, but it has hung vividly in my memory since I first gazed at it, transfixed, in the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston eight years ago.

title: A Native American Sun-Worshiper That's Fun to Grow and Harvest
description: THE sunflowers are filling out, coming into their own with golden ray petals circling the brown center, or disk, flowers. Quite often the flower heads flop over because they are so heavy with the rich seed that will make superb winter bird food. If the plants are being raised for their valuable seed, however, it is helpful to put a cheesecloth or old potato bag over the flower as it ripens to keep the flocks away for now.

title: Downtown Kicks Up Its Heels
description: THERE may be no place on earth better to witness humans making the transition from day to night than lower Manhattan. It has, of course, a five o'clock image that is firmly entrenched in our collective consciousness -- the offices in the towers of finance emptying, hordes filling the narrow manmade caverns and commuters fanning out toward the channels of transportation that will take them elsewhere for the night. But what is less well-established is nonetheless so: Not everybody leaves at night.

title: Bernard Posner, 80, Advocate For Those With Disabilities
description: Bernard Posner, a Government bureaucrat who was so moved by the plight of disabled veterans that he put his very able body on the line as a leading champion of the rights of all Americans with disabilities, died on Wednesday at nursing home in Rockville, Md. He was 80 and had been executive director of the President's Committee for the Employment of the Handicapped.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: BOY CLINTON

title: F.Y.I.
description: Hydrotherapy?

title: R.B.I. Adding Up at Record Pace
description: The increase in the number of home runs hit and the number of players hitting them in ever increasing totals has been well documented. Now consider a byproduct of all of those home runs and other hits: runs batted in.

title: Socialist Surrealism
description: ESCAPE HATCH & THE LONG ROAD AHEAD

title: Subway Rules
description: To the Editor: Paul S. Nadler's letter, ''Singapore Subway'' (July 14), described an unpleasant experience in the Singapore Mass Rapid Transit system, saying he and his wife were threatened with arrest for loitering. As public affairs manager for the system's operating company, I wish to clarify the situation.

title: Even With Mortgage Brokers, Let the Borrower Beware
description: SIX years ago, Earl Ranson, now 66, and his 79-year-old wife, Mary, were being pressured by hospitals after serious medical problems had left them in debt. So in November 1990, when they went to a Richmond mortgage broker to refinance the loan for their five-bedroom Colonial, they didn't spend much time dickering over terms.

title: New Environmental Threats
description: The 104th Congress has only a month to go before its members scatter for the fall re-election campaign. The post-Labor-Day period in the second year of a Congressional session is usually a dangerous time. Members eager to build a last-minute record tend to ignore the niceties of committee hearings and measured debate. The nation's environment will be particularly at risk in this fevered atmosphere.

title: Q and A
description: Rose Bowl Tickets

title: European Green Police Have Carrot but No Stick
description: If nature on this continent could be a little more like the new European Environment Agency, Europe would be close to being an impeccable place.

title: Jacqueline Loeb, Craig E. Moffett
description: Jacqueline Loeb and Craig Eder Moffett were married last evening in Wainscott, L.I., by Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson.

title: Racquet and Broom: Chang Sweeps Agassi
description: Revitalized, rehydrated and regrouped after his treacherous quarterfinal marathon, Pete Sampras reached his second consecutive United States Open final yesterday with a masterful 6-3, 6-4, 6-7 (9-11), 6-3 subjugation of Croatia's fiery Goran Ivanisevic.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Business Diary column on Aug. 18 about the market performance of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, misstated the estimated daily increase in his net worth in the last year. It was $12.5 million a day, not $125,000.

title: 'Mechanic From Hell' Drives Through a Loophole
description: Motke Barnes was dubbed ''the mechanic from hell'' by city officials for his talent for charging motorists thousands of dollars for repairs that he never did. After the city closed his garage under a law intended to shut drug dens and brothels, Mr. Barnes was prohibited from ''aiding and abetting'' car repair in the city without a valid registration.

title: Living in the Moment of the Next Move
description: WITH A CHOREOGRAPHER like Trisha Brown, who since the exuberant days of the Judson Dance Theater more than 30 years ago has succeeded in consistently looking ahead to fresh creative puzzles, how do you look back? By mixing the new and the old, and the old reconfigured. Starting on Oct. 1, in ''Trisha Brown at 25: Post Modern and Beyond,'' the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music will offer a weeklong Brown retrospective and new season all in one, celebrating a formidable conjunction of anniversaries: her 60th birthday, in November, and her company's 25th.

title: Home Is Where The Art Is
description: A simple two-room cottage etched by a homesick sailor into whalebone and labeled ''Sweet Home'' symbolizes the importance of architecture in the lives of Americans, who, despite hardship, managed to teach themselves to create vibrant images of the buildings that surround them, according to Stacy C. Hollander, curator of a show that opens this Saturday at the Museum of American Folk Art.

title: A Double Dose of Work
description: Elaine L. Chao, by her own admission, was a very serious child.

title: WORK
description: The strictures of political correctness at Harvard probably prohibited Wilson from a more incisive discussion of the unfortunate state of the job market for black ghetto dwellers. Thanks to three decades of more-or-less open-door immigration policy, the market for low-skilled labor is greatly oversupplied. As Wilson notes, employers seem to prefer to hire immigrants first, native blacks last.

title: Helen Shapiro, Brian Deitelzweig
description: Helen Gail Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Shapiro of Manhattan, was married last evening to Brian Marc Deitelzweig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Deitelzweig of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Merle Singer performed the ceremony at the Pierre hotel in Manhattan.

title: Sandra S. Guylay, Hugh J. Lawson
description: Sandra Sylvianne Guylay, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley R. Guylay of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Hugh James Lawson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Lawson of Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Phillip C. Ellsworth Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York.

title: 'The Most Optimistic Man'
description: PANGLOSS FOR Veep'' was the headline above George Will's column in Newsweek, commentating on Bob Dole's selection of the buoyant Jack Kemp as his running mate.

title: HIS LIFE IS HIS MIND
description: Whatever the depth of Suzanne Hall's bitterness toward her now-bedridden husband and his admitted infidelities, her comment, ''God has punished him in ways I never could,'' is appalling. If this is what the Greater Life Christian Center is teaching, then someone had better introduce it to Jesus and to the true gospel of love and forgiveness.

title: Law and Order
description: LEGAL REASONING AND POLITICAL CONFLICT By Cass R. Sunstein. 220 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: Carefully Chosen, but Sometimes Not Universally Accepted
description: IN Wildwood last year, a parent protested the use of ''I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,'' by Maya Angelou, in a 10th- grade English class. In 1994, a group of parents in Bloomfield complained that a video series used in a sixth-grade health class encouraged homosexuality. And in 1993, an organization affiliated with the Christian Coalition tried to block the adoption of a sex-education textbook in West Windsor-Plainsboro, on the ground that it undermined parental authority.

title: Climbing One Ladder
description: Daniel P. Tully had no grand plans when he got out of the Army 41 years ago. Maybe it isn't surprising that a former soldier's goal at the time was simply to ''put one foot in front of another.'' What may be a surprise is where the steps took him: to the top of the firm he joined all those years ago as a 23-year-old accounting clerk.

title: From Grains of Sand: A World of Order
description: HIKING the mesas and canyons of northern New Mexico, a visitor is occasionally startled to find a shard of broken pottery decorated with intricate geometrical designs. The Anasazi, who lived here hundreds of years ago, craved not only food and sunlight but pattern. Not all the symmetries found along the trail are artificial: spiraling pine cones, shimmering crystals, radiating petals of flowers. There seems to be something natural, almost effortless, about the way pattern arises in nature -- with or without the help of human hands.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS
description: Here is a selective guide to coming cultural events in New York and beyond. Events that are starred are those that Times critics consider particularly noteworthy. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear on page 80.

title: A Neighborhood For Art and Leisure
description: WHEN Willie L. Brown Jr. was inaugurated Mayor of San Francisco early this year, he chose the city's new village green, the popular Esplanade in Yerba Buena Gardens, as the site of the festive ceremony. It was a symbolic gesture, because this successful redevelopment with stunning views of the downtown skyline celebrates the city's diversity and inclusiveness.

title: O.K., So I'm Fat
description: SOME PEOPLE ARE NO DOUBT FAT BECAUSE OF glandular disorders or the wrath of an angry God. I am not one of those people. I am fat because I eat a lot.

title: Offering a Reason For Babe Ruth's Visit
description: In the July 28 article titled ''Babe Ruth Signature Inspires Awe and a Lawsuit'', the curator of the Babe Ruth Birthplace and Museum in Baltimore stated that he did not know why Babe Ruth was in Peekskill.

title: Not Always the Berries
description: George M. C. Fisher had an inauspicious entry into business. He was maybe 8 years old when his mom sent him and his older sisters to pick strawberries for a farm down the road.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Bobby Farrah
