description: For 30 years, Ibrahim (Bobby) Farrah has taught Middle Eastern dancing in the West. His workshops at Studio Maestro near Lincoln Center (the next one begins this week) draw students from all over the world.

title: Victoria Garbuz, Stephen Cowles
description: Victoria Garbuz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kim Garbuz of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Stephen B. Cowles, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Symon Cowles of Sea Girt, N.J. Msgr. Thomas Hartman is to officiate.

title: N.J. v. Hauptmann, Time and Again
description: LIKE most cops, Sgt. Jack Davis of the State Police shifts into the present tense when ticking off the indicators that point to whodunit.

title: WATER WORK
description: The photo essay by Bruce Davidson and Tony Hiss (''Water Work,'' Aug. 4) was visually splendid and poignant in telling the stories of some of the people who make New York the greatest port in the world. One of those is Lars Hansen, depicted high up in the crosstrees of the bark Peking at South Street Seaport Museum (on your table-of-contents page). Lars, for over 25 years a master rigger for many of the most important vessels in and out of New York Harbor, has spent the past 10 years aloft, almost single-handedly re rigging New York's tall ships. A native of Denmark, Lars was a freedom fighter in the Danish underground during World War II -- for which he received decorations from his King and country -- before committing to a life at sea. A man of iron with a heart of gold, Lars Hansen is what makes us a seaport city.

title: The American Way of Walking Out
description: THE LAST THING HE WANTED

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE ISLAND OF THE MAPMAKER'S WIFE & Other Tales. By Marilyn Sides. Harmony, $23.

title: Taking Away The Privileges Of Prisoners
description: People have become accustomed to dinner-hour interruptions by telephone solicitors.

title: Multiplex, by Magic Johnson
description: In decades past, Jamaica Avenue was a center of shopping and entertainment. There were major department stores like Gertz and a string of first-run movie theaters. But the stores were gradually replaced by the discounters and small retailers that now line the commercial strip, and the movie houses went dark.

title: Sarah Lesemann, Robert B. Davis Jr.
description: Sarah Margaret Jackson Lesemann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Lesemann of New York, was married on Friday to Robert B. Davis Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Davis of Purchase, N.Y. The Rev. George W. Busler officiated at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, L.I. The Rev. Thomas E. Davis, a Roman Catholic priest, participated in the service.

title: Cozying Up to the Glock 19
description: THE Glock 19 felt surprisingly light and the .22 Browning Buck Mark felt heavy for a .22 target pistol. But what did I know, so many years from my own shooting days. One by one, in plastic bags, the guns came out of the safe in the closet of an Upper West Side apartment, to be broken open, checked and rechecked for live ammo, then dry-fired at the wall. I dismissed the clunky .45 I remembered from Fort Dix. And then the .38 Smith & Wesson emerged, a dark metal snake that lay cool and balanced in the hand, six inches of barrel and a cylinder that crooned as it spun. ''Beautiful,'' I heard myself say.

title: Ms. Brandwene And Mr. Lese
description: Deborah Ann Brandwene, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Brandwene of Kingston, Pa., was married last evening to Jonathan Frederick Lese, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Lese of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Storm's Rains Bring Flooding In Two States
description: With power out, water use restricted, roads impassable and bridges blocked, North Carolina struggled today to recover from the destruction caused by Hurricane Fran.

title: Libraries: Books and Tapes and, Yes, Coffee
description: ON late Thursday afternoons this summer the asphalt on Main Street in Hartford was alive with the sound of music, coming from a terrace where some people were dancing and others were just listening and swaying to the beat.

title: New School Ushers In Old Complaints
description: A brand new school might be expected to bring a smile to the faces of parents in central Brooklyn. Instead, many of those who brought their children to Public School 22, at St Mark's Place and Classon Avenue, in Crown Heights, on Thursday and Friday had little but complaints -- about unfinished construction work, buses that arrived late or not at all and a confusing registration process.

title: A Love for Brands
description: Charlotte Beers's first job in marketing was almost her last.

title: Ms. Schrader, Mr. Anderson
description: Esther Schrader, the daughter of Cecile and Martin Schrader of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., is to be married today to Nicholas Anderson, the son of Ellen Masland Salyer of Sebastopol, Calif., and Marvin Anderson of Montara, Calif. Rabbi Helene Ferris is to perform the ceremony at Maxime's, a restaurant in Granite Springs, N.Y.

title: All Disenchanted On the Chechen Front
description: EIGHT days ago Aleksandr I. Lebed, the Russian national security adviser, moved to end the unpopular war in Chechnya by signing a peace deal with rebel leaders that called for a truce while deferring the question of Chechen independence. For now, Russian forces remain in the secessionist republic -- demoralized, disorganized and often hungry 21 months after being sent there with unfounded bravado by the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE DAY GOGO WENT TO VOTE: South Africa, April 1994. By Elinor Batezat Sisulu. Illustrated by Sharon Wilson. Little, Brown, $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) Gogo is Thembi's great-grandmother, and she is so old she has been housebound for years. But she is determined to cast her vote the first time she is eligible and takes Thembi to the polls with her. This is powerful and moving story of civic celebration seen through a child's eyes.

title: WORK
description: Wilson's proposition that work itself provides the structure for healthy and constructive social behaviors is plainly true. Consequently, the Government bears a responsibility, along with the private sector, to create jobs in times of crisis. It is bad policy to punish people for joblessness while offering them no possibility of employment. Merely being born poor has become so stigmatized as to be virtually criminal.

title: Dawn Kirby, Marty Arnold
description: Dawn Marie Kirby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Kirby of New York, was married yesterday to Charles Martin Arnold, the son of Kathleen R. Arnold of Norwich, Conn., and the late Dr. Charles R. Arnold. The Rev. Donald T. Oakes performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Lenox, Mass.

title: There's Room For 2 Aces In This Deck
description: JUST ASKING, but is there some king-of-the-hill, lord-of-the-jungle, leader-of-the-pack law that says there can only be one acknowledged ace of the Yankee pitching staff at any given moment?

title: Two Suspects in Oklahoma City Bombing Seek Separate Trials
description: The two men charged in the Oklahoma City bombing asked this week for separate trials, arguing through their lawyers that the evidence against one would tarnish the other every step of the way and make it impossible for a single jury to deliver a fair verdict.

title: WORK
description: In ''Work'' (Aug. 18), William Julius Wilson writes extensively about the absence of jobs in the inner city without ever mentioning the anti-business bias that has caused businesses to flee. As much as the inner city may have suffered from racial bias, its economic deterioration has much more to do with an anti-business agenda accepted by the community and supported by its leaders.

title: Shunning 'He' and 'She,' They Fight for Respect
description: In Boston, Nancy Nangeroni is helping arrange a courthouse vigil for a slain male-to-female transsexual. In Washington, Dana Priesing lobbies for laws that would ban discrimination against ''transgendered'' people. And in Southern California, Jacob Hale and the rest of the local Transgender Menace chapter occasionally pull on their black Menace T-shirts and go for a group walkabout, just to look people in the eye with collective pride in who they are.

title: How to Make Roles? Make Movies
description: FIFTEEN MINUTES, WHEN THE TRAFFIC is light, is what it takes Stanley Tucci to get from his Westchester farmhouse to his parents' place, and he likes to visit often. It is the house where he grew up, a single-story ranch that his father, a sculptor and retired high-school art teacher, built much of himself. On an August afternoon, Tucci, an actor, drives his wife's Honda over and bounds up the front walk. He is a slight man, weighing in at about 150 pounds, and although his receding hairline makes him look older than his 35 years, he comes off as a poised but hammy post-adolescent whose behavioral indulgences have just begun to be tamed.

title: Courtnay Coffey, Robert W. Kittell
description: Courtnay Mulderig Coffey, the daughter of Mary and James Coffey of Rochester, was married there yesterday to Robert West Kittell, a son of Mary and Donald Kittell of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Peter Clifford performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Demons of Salem, With Us Still
description: WHEN ARTHUR MILLER'S drama ''The Crucible'' first opened on Broadway in 1953, the country was in a panic about the so-called Red Menace. On Nov. 27, the first American movie of ''The Crucible'' will have its premiere. To understand why it took 43 years to make this film -- not to mention its contemporary relevance -- it pays briefly to recall the red hunt that no longer beleaguers us.

title: A Native American and Follower of the Sun
description: THE sunflowers are filling out, coming into their own with golden ray petals circling the brown center or disk flowers. Quite often the flower heads flop over because they are so heavy with the rich seed that will make superb winter bird food. If the plants are being raised for their valuable seed, however, it is helpful to put a cheesecloth or old potato bag over the flower as it ripens to keep the flocks away for now.

title: To the Defense Of the North Fork
description: I take offense to the condescending attitude taken to our beautiful North Fork in ''Bed and Breakfasts Gaining on East End'' $(July 28$). It should be noted that we are the owners of Shorecrest Bed and Breakfast, our beautiful Victorian home, overlooking Long Island Sound, which was not visited by your reporter.

title: SCORES COUNT
description: TO HIS STUDENTS, Michael A. Johnson is a little like one of those slightly overbearing parents -- the kind who is always packing off his kids to private schools and tutors or Stanley Kaplan courses to make sure that they get into an Ivy League college. The principal and founder of the Science Skills Center, a three-year-old public high school at the base of the Manhattan Bridge in Brooklyn, Johnson -- that's Mr. Johnson to you and me -- is physically and spiritually imposing. At 45, he has closely cropped hair, a thin mustache, big round glasses and an irrepressible laugh, and typically greets his students in the hallways with an enveloping bear hug.

title: 3,800 Acres, All Private, Meant for the Public's Pleasure
description: IN a state where encroaching development has become the rule, Litchfield County has earned a reputation for holding the line, sticking to a vision of Connecticut more in keeping with its rural heyday than its suburban present. Nowhere is that reputation more in evidence than at the White Memorial Foundation.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Sonorous Pipes at the Lab

title: The Mad, Mad World of R. D. Laing
description: THE WING OF MADNESS

title: Life on the Bottom Rung: Top Executives Remember
description: Just as it's hard to imagine our parents as teen-agers, it can be difficult to envision chief executives and chairmen as nervous youngsters starting their first jobs. Even if they were burger flippers, you can just see them towering over their co-workers or pondering the dynamics of broiled versus fried.

title: Lodging in Lower Manhattan
description: NOT too many years ago, visitors who wanted to stay at a hotel in lower Manhattan were out of luck. Then, bit by bit, the situation changed. The Vista was the trailblazer in 1981, a gleaming, 21-story neighbor for the World Trade Center's twin towers. By 1992, the Wall Street area had acquired two more large hotels, the 561-room Millenium Hilton and the 517-room New York Marriott Financial Center.

title: Yes, That Is Tony Mandarich in a Backup Role for the Colts
description: Coming out of Michigan State in 1989, Tony Mandarich was supposed to be the next Art Shell and Anthony Munoz rolled into one. His devastating pancake blocks were chronicled in the same way as quarterback sacks and touchdown passes.

title: Paying the Price for Traffic Jams
description: A Port Authority study concludes that raising rush-hour tolls could significantly reduce traffic jams at the Hudson River crossings, although the agency says it has no plans to do so. What do you think of the idea?

title: 100 Years of Very Small Political Statements
description: MORT BERKOWITZ is not famous, but he has shaped our nation's discourse in his own small way. When the First Lady referred to herself as ''Hillary Rodman Clinton'' during her speech at the Democratic national convention, she was quoting from his work.

title: Other People's Worlds
description: FOLLOW ME

title: THE 00's
description: An overlooked possibility for describing the next decade: ''the zed's.'' The British equivalent of ''aught,'' zed captures a certain mysterious whimsy.

title: One Rough Inning From Cone Is Too Much for the Yankees
description: It should have been stirring and inspirational. If this had been David Cone's first game back, if he had just pitched for the first time since his surgery to remove an aneurysm, everyone would have been moved.

title: Cortlandt Welcomes New Train Station
description: THE first new railroad station to be built in the state since Metro-North was formed in 1983 has made its debut here, and commuters are smiling. They praise its design, its convenience, its spacious parking lot. Few fail to mention their previous alternatives, the far smaller Hudson Line stations of Crugers and Montrose, which are now closed.

title: In Defiance
description: Aleksander Wat Life and Art of an Iconoclast. By Tomas Venclova. 359 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/

title: Parents' Veto Stalls Choice Of a Principal
description: On Friday morning, the man in charge of of Public School 99 in Midwood, Brooklyn, roamed the schoolyard, coaxing, cajoling and hollering at the school's 1,000 students to file inside.

title: When You Invest With Angels, the Portfolio Is Never Boring
description: AFTER 25 years, Elizabeth T. Frank was ready to call it a career.

title: Tight End Dilger Makes Things Happen for Colts
description: In his words, Ken Dilger is ''a country kid from Mariah Hill, Ind., population 200 or 300, 45 minutes east of Evansville, with two restaurants, one service station, no grocery store and no movie theater and that's about it. A place where not much happens.''

title: The New Innovators Salute the Old
description: In 1952 at the Museum of Modern Art, the composer Otto Luening and his colleague Vladimir Ussachevsky presented the first concert of electronic music on tape in the United States. Last week, Mr. Luening died at 96. On Friday, as part of the four-day SoHo Arts Festival, a concert of new music presented by Composers Recordings Inc., the nonprofit record company of which Mr. Luening was co-founder more than 40 years ago, was dedicated to his memory. And in a touching way, this funky event at the American Opera Projects performance space in SoHo, featuring two style-bending ensembles called Chez Vees and Twisted Tutu, was a fitting tribute.

title: Defenders Are Blue In the Face
description: An off-season conditioning program doesn't mean much when a team's defense is on the field for more minutes than it should be. Against Dallas today, some Giants defenders were so exhausted they had to sit out.

title: Marriage Advised in Some Youth Pregnancies
description: To the overburdened caseworkers of the Orange County Social Services Agency, it seemed an innovative solution to the nation's growing problem of underage girls who are made pregnant by adult men.

title: Gypsy Moth Damage Is Down
description: If it sometimes seems that most things are getting worse, consider the gypsy moth. Last year, agricultural officials warned of a renewed threat from the pesky creatures that attack hickory and oak trees. Now, these experts predict that gypsy moths will defoliate less than 20,000 acres of forest in New Jersey next spring -- 10,000 acres less than anticipated and quite a drop from 1990, when 431,235 acres were defoliated. Credit goes to entomophaga maimaiga, a fungus disease that is ever more zealously decimating the gypsy moth population, said Bob Balaam, director of the division of plant industry for the state Department of Agriculture. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Part Artist, Part Hacker And Full-Time Programmer
description: From the outside, the so-called browser war appears to be an epic corporate struggle: Netscape vs. Microsoft in a classic David-and-Goliath fight, with each side vying to control computing in the Internet era.

title: New Editor Shakes Up Staff at U.S. News
description: James Fallows, who takes over as editor of U.S. News & World Report today, has begun his tenure by making big changes in the magazine's leadership.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the writer Charles O'Neal on Thursday misstated the date of his death. It was Aug. 29, not Sept. 1.

title: Bomb Trial Jurors Say Panel Had No Doubts
description: The jury that convicted Ramzi Ahmed Yousef and two accomplices on Thursday harbored no doubts that they planned to blow up American jumbo jetliners abroad, according to 2 of the 12 jurors. The jurors, a man and a woman, also said that Mr. Yousef hurt his case by acting as his own lawyer, though they admired his performance.

title: 6 New Yorkers Are Acclaimed As Living Monuments to City
description: Their jaws may not be as finely chiseled as those of the four guys on Mount Rushmore. They are not as green as the Statue of Liberty, as tall as the Empire State Building, as resonant as Carnegie Hall or as deep as the Grand Canyon. But they are in decidedly better shape than whoever is buried in Grant's Tomb.

title: Pettitte, the Yankees' Safety Net, Loses
description: They had called for security. So Andy Pettitte came running after a three-day break, the only one who could protect the Yankees from the rest of their division.

title: At Vanity Fair, Successor Finds His Footing
description: After E. Graydon Carter took over as editor of Vanity Fair in 1992, he caught a bad case of chills. He caught it from advertisers, from media experts and from other publishers and editors among whom the consensus was: Without its departing editor, Tina Brown, Vanity Fair would go cold.

title: Offense Futile As Cowboys Win in a Waltz
description: Early in the third quarter today, Giants quarterback Dave Brown tried his best to fire up an offense that had absolutely no life in it. He challenged the players to play better, telling the Giants they were still in the game. But at that point it was like bringing a cup of water to a three-alarm fire.

title: Governor Raises Possibility Of Fed Interest Rate Increase
description: The drop in the unemployment rate to 5.1 percent in August raises the risks of unacceptable wage inflation, Laurence H. Meyer, one of the newest members of the Federal Reserve Board, warned this evening.

title: All Ahead Slow As Cable Companies Enter Cyberspace
description: After two years of anticipation, delays and jitters, the cable television industry is finally heading into cyberspace -- though hardly at rocket speed.

title: Shooting For Excess
description: New Kingdom aimed for overload when it headlined a CMJ Music Marathon hip-hop showcase on Saturday night at Wetlands. Led by two rappers from Brooklyn, Nosaj and Sebastian, the group also included a disk jockey, a hard-rock guitarist, a drummer, a percussionist and a masked dancer who brandished lighted swords out of ''Star Wars,'' hunkered around like an ape and crashed cymbals. The controlled chaos onstage mirrored the dense, rowdy, ambitious songs.

title: Eli Lilly is exploring anti-obesity proteins that might be used in treating weight disorders.
description: A FAT lab mouse became a media darling recently with the discovery that a genetic deficiency caused its obesity. Speculation -- and hopes -- flared that the pudgy mouse might someday provide an answer to weight problems in humans, too. In that vein, a team of researchers at Eli Lilly & Company have won three patents for anti-obesity proteins that may be used to treat weight disorders the way insulin is used to combat diabetes.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Tuesday about the creation of the Medical Advertising Hall of Fame referred incorrectly to the planned honors. They will go to individuals in medical advertising, not to campaigns.

title: Small Businesses Use the Web To Prospect for Customers
description: Small-business owners are forever searching for quality leads -- prospective clients and customers who want their services and goods. Finding these leads can take a good deal of time, travel and aggravation.

title: Planned Merger of Big Colorado Ski Resorts Reflects Tougher Competition
description: Adam Aron recently gazed out a bay window at the forest-green slopes of Vail Mountain and mused aloud, ''The ski lodge is the ship's cabin, and the mountain is the recreation area.''

title: Storm Ebbs, but Its Effects Linger
description: Four days after Hurricane Fran first lashed the North Carolina coast, its effects continued to be felt yesterday throughout the states of the mid-Atlantic and Northeast as rain-swollen rivers spilled their banks and unstable weather patterns spawned violent thunderstorms in New York City and New Jersey.

title: Troubled Rapper Is Injured Again in Shooting Near Las Vegas Strip
description: The rap artist and actor Tupac Shakur, whose career has been marked by violence and run-ins with the law, was in critical condition today after being shot four times near the Las Vegas Strip, the police and hospital officials said.

title: Divided Loyalties: Burundi Strife Splits Its Diplomats Abroad
description: The first and second counselor at the Burundian Mission to the United Nations were university classmates in Bujumbura, Burundi's capital. In New York, they socialized over dinners and with each other's families.

title: Forest Fire
description: A hot southerly wind blew through central Wyoming recently, disturbing the dogs and turning the cottonwood leaves silver side out. A small forest fire had been burning for days near Stockwell Creek in the Bighorn Mountains. It was nearly extinguished when the wind blew the fire over Little Goose Peak and onto the steep walls of an adjacent canyon. What had been a narrow plume a few hours earlier was now an inverted pyramid of smoke, its source steadily broadening, its edges keenly incised by the wind in an otherwise perfectly blue sky.

title: Burmese Democracy Will Not Be Stopped
description: To the Editor:

title: Victory in Canada Makes Hull Proud to Play for U.S.
description: When Brett Hull's face appeared on the scoreboard tonight at the Corel Center, Canadian fans chanted: ''Traitor! Traitor!''

title: Tennessee Adjusts, And Now Prepares
description: The weekly spectacles are built upon limitless passion, brassy horn sections and frightening contact. But the game is distinct from the spectacle. The game is determined by responsiveness and patience, by calm interpretation that can overcome a crisis. As early as the first full weekend of play, the season is taking shape because some players and coaching staffs discovered solutions while others remained stifled by problems.

title: The Powers That Be Make the Right Calls
description: THEY tossed the ball high in the air and swatted a perfect ace. Was it blind luck or perfect wisdom or flat-out justice? Does it matter?

title: My Flag Shows Her Champion's Heart in the Gazelle
description: Neither rain nor flood nor gloom of day nor pace of race could stop My Flag yesterday as the great filly made two moves to the outside, found running room and raced to a dramatic victory in the mud over Escena in the Gazelle Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Sampras Reign Intact With Sweep of Chang
description: To Pete Sampras, who had his first brush with mortality this spring at 24, this United States Open title represented an affirmation: In a year marred by the death of his longtime coach and a somber trio of premature exits from the three other Grand Slams, the Open was going to be a lifesaver.

title: Pilot Reports Seeing Missile From Jet Off Virginia
description: The pilot of an American Airlines jet has told the Federal Aviation Administration that he saw a missile off the wing of his plane while he was flying along the coast of Virginia.

title: Perot Urges Redesign of Tax System
description: Ross Perot took on taxes last night, exhorting a national television audience to ''get rid of the I.R.S. and create a new tax system that works.''

title: THE PRESIDENTAL RACE
description: If It's Tuesday . . .

title: Programming Languages: Survivors and Wannabes
description: Whether they are in the vanguard with new languages like Java, or toiling in the catacombs of Cobol, programmers speak a variety of tongues in their intimate conversations with computers. And each has its own vocabulary, mixing algebraic statements with simple words to tell the computer to perform repetitive tasks.

title: Bosnia Election Rally Wasn't an Islamic Event
description: To the Editor:

title: Bosnians Campaign on Old Hatreds
description: If Kresimir Zubak, the ethnic Croatian candidate for the Bosnian presidency, has a plan to rescue Bosnia and Herzegovina from the plagues of hatred and crushing poverty wrought by war, he isn't telling anyone.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Tyson Strikes Quickly in Hurry to Fight Holyfield
description: Mike Tyson's tripleheader Saturday night was Bruce Seldon, Evander Holyfield and a rack of prime rib. He discombobulated Seldon in only 109 seconds, broke his religious oath when he snapped at Holyfield and still pulled his limousine into Nicky Blair's restaurant at a decent hour: 10:15 P.M.

title: Helping the Black Jews
description: Maybe, as readers of I Kings 10:13 surmised, King Solomon had an affair with the Queen of Sheba before her return to Arabia. Or perhaps, after the destruction of the Temple in 586 B.C.E., a tribe of Israelites fled to Africa.

title: New Damage Feared in Park As Flooding Follows Storm
description: For the second time this year, the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park, which runs along the Potomac River from West Virginia to Washington, suffered extensive damage from flooding.

title: Aristide, Out of the Limelight, Keeps Place in Haiti's Heart
description: He has been out of office since his term expired in February, and nearly two years have elapsed since 20,000 American troops landed here to restore him to power. But Jean-Bertrand Aristide's hold on the imagination and aspirations of his countrymen seems as strong as ever.

title: Sudden Storm Forces 3 Delays of Game
description: A thin but furious line of thunderstorms formed from sultry air left in the wake of Hurricane Fran raced over most of New Jersey and the New York metropolitan region yesterday, knocking down power lines, briefly closing airports and temporarily halting three professional sports events.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Hail and farewell: it will be a bittersweet occasion for CAROLYN ROSSI COPELAND tonight as she rings down the curtain for the Lamb's Theater Company she founded 17 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Frederick T. Rope, a retired diplomat, misstated his age. He was 87, not 81.

title: It's in Texas. It's Big. It's Japanese Art.
description: It was a clash of cultures perhaps destined to occur.

title: Slur Is a Slur
description: To the Editor:

title: 'E.R.' and 'Frasier' Win Top Emmys
description: ''E.R.,'' NBC's fast-paced hit medical series, won the Emmy last night that many people expected it to receive a year ago, as best drama series. And for the third year in a row, ''Frasier,'' the ''Cheers'' spinoff about a class-conscious Seattle radio psychotherapist and friends, won the Emmy as outstanding comedy series.

title: Primary Races Are Obscure, but Reputations Are on the Line
description: In a bustling storefront headquarters in Crown Heights, Clarence A. Norman spent most of yesterday commanding troops of campaign volunteers, discussing last-minute strategies on leafleting and getting voters to polls. While Mr. Norman, a State Assemblyman, faces his own race in tomorrow's Democratic primary, his more pressing focus was on the candidacy of Michael Feinberg, who is running for Brooklyn surrogate.

title: Giuliani Defends Financing to Build Schools
description: With New York City schools struggling to cope with their worst crowding in decades, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended yesterday the amount of money his administration has allocated for school construction and maintenance, saying the Board of Education had presented ''unrealistic budgets'' over the years and had ''wasted'' millions of dollars.

title: Giuliani Backs Catholic Offer Of School Slots
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that an offer from the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to educate as many as 1,000 of the city's public schoolchildren in Catholic schools was an ''excellent proposal,'' and that he would look aggressively into its feasibility.

title: Junk E-mail Costs Receivers Real Money
description: To the Editor:

title: As Always, Raiders Find Way To Lose
description: What would it be this time? A blocked field-goal attempt? An interception? A fumbled snap on a field goal attempt? A safety?

title: Drama, Comic Touches and a Delicate Balance
description: Intelligence and good performing stood out in the second marathon in the '96 SoHo Arts Festival Dance Now series, presented on Saturday afternoon at the Dia Center for the Arts. And those qualities were combined to impressive effect in 4 of the 16 dances on the program.

title: Rivers Posing Flood Threat In Lowlands
description: The Dan River, some 30 feet above flood stage and the color of mud, rolled over its banks today and swamped warehouses, roads and anything built on low ground.

title: Attack Junk Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Hours to Vote
description: Primary elections will be held in New York State tomorrow. Polling places will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: It's Moving Day, and the Antelope Are Up in the Air
description: The airplane dropped out of the twilit sky above the savanna just in time, only minutes before darkness enveloped the dirt airstrip. It taxied quickly to a flatbed truck huddled in the gloom at the runway's end. A side-door sprang open.

title: Danger Signs in Haiti
description: Two years after American intervention rid Haiti of a murderous dictatorship, the soldiers and paramilitary thugs of that regime are showing a new boldness that threatens Haiti's democratic Government. In mid-July, the leader of an organization of dissatisfied former soldiers was assassinated after he disclosed a coup plot by some in the group. Last month, police arrested 19 former soldiers for allegedly planning to attack Government offices. Two right-wing politicians were subsequently killed and gunmen fired on the police headquarters and Legislative Palace. Eight off-duty policemen have been murdered since March.

title: The Giant Question: When Will Dave Brown Step Up?
description: THE search started at halftime. While falling behind the Cowboys, 21-0, the Giants' net passing yardage was 0. Zero. Zip. Zilch. By the end of the third quarter, it was even worse. Minus-6 yards.

title: Party Girl by Night, Library Clerk by Day
description: Whatever anyone imagines about young partygoers in downtown Manhattan, one thing's for sure: they don't come with a hokey Hollywood laugh track. ''Party Girl'' is a sometimes appealing but sanitized sitcom about Mary, party creature by night, library clerk by day. The relentless laugh track is the first clue that the series has more to do with Hollywood than SoHo.

title: Fires at 3 Homes, 1 Factory
description: Four separate fires swept through Newark early yesterday, destroying a factory and damaging three homes. The fires were not related, city fire officials told The A.P. The blaze at the Interstate Shoe Case and Store Fixture Company, which manufactures counters and display cases for stores, also heavily damaged a restaurant and bar.

title: Arthur S. Flemming, 91, Dies; Served in Eisenhower Cabinet
description: Arthur S. Flemming, who was Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare from 1958 to 1961 under President Dwight D. Eisenhower and held other high posts in government and education, died on Saturday in the Washington House, a retirement home in Alexandria, Va., where he spent his last few years. He was 91 and had been a longtime resident of Alexandria.

title: Supermarket tabloids lose circulation, even as they divulge major scandals.
description: THERE are 29,800 supermarkets in America, according to the Food Marketing Institute. The median number of checkout counters is 10, and anyone who shops (an average of 2.2 times a week) knows that those counters are a good place to look for the latest headlines: Liz's Hubby's Drug Bust; Six Signs that PROVE the World is Coming to an End; Sexy Blonde Tells All and (now for the good news) Garlic Miracle Cure.

title: Not Even A Delay Stops Errors or Colts
description: As lightning flashed in lead-gray skies and windswept paper swirled around Giants Stadium today, a stunning scene greeted the Jets' defense: thousands of fans, lashed by rain, stood and cheered and pumped their fists as if to defy the gods. That defense, the fans were imploring, would halt the Colts on fourth-and-7 from the Jets' 12 in the final period. And after that -- who knew?

title: Huddled Masses in the Schools
description: New York City's students went back to school this week, taking their seats in overcrowded classrooms -- and in closets and locker rooms and spaces carved out of auditoriums. What is to blame for the congestion? You need not look much further than the huge and continuing increase in the population of immigrant students.

title: Last Rays at Suntan Lake?
description: For 26 summers, Suntan Lake has attracted suburban and, more often lately, urban families to swim, barbecue and ride paddle boats. But if the Riverdale Planning Board decides on Thursday to approve a developer's proposal to build a shopping mall on the site, the sun may set for the last time on the 46-acre lake complex this weekend.

title: Hartford Could Use That Budget Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned Thursday.

title: More Trucks, More Accidents
description: As more and bigger trucks fill New Jersey's roads, fatal accidents involving large trucks rose by 13.4 percent in New Jersey last year, according to Federal statistics cited by The A.P. yesterday. There were 76 such accidents in 1995, up from 67 in 1994. Truck traffic has increased dramatically in recent years: The number of miles logged by large trucks rose 37.5 percent from 1984 to 1994 and is expected to rise another 29 percent in the next decade.

title: Protecting the Pine Barrens
description: The Pinelands Commission, the agency that controls development of a million acres of New Jersey's fragile Pine Barrens, is often criticized by property owners and local governments for the complexity of its regulations. The commission wants to change that: within two months, it expects to publish a plain-English handbook for the more than 1,500 people who apply for building or development permits each year.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about Israeli-Palestinian negotiations misidentified a former chief negotiator, Ahmed Qurai. He is president of the Palestinian legislative council, not an Israeli one.

title: Ailing? Yeltsin Bags 40 Ducks and a Boar
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin, who is preparing for heart surgery, shot more than 40 ducks and a hefty wild boar during hunting trips last week, Interfax news agency said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Leroy Dickerson, the father of a 4-year-old girl who was found starved to death, omitted the site of an interview with Mr. Dickerson. It was in a lawyer's office in Brooklyn. A picture with the article, showing Mr. Dickerson at his home in the Bronx, was taken a week before the interview.

title: PRO-HUSSEIN KURDS TAKE ANOTHER CITY IN NORTHERN IRAQ
description: Thousands of Kurdish civilians and hundreds of armed guerrillas fled Koi Sanjaq in northern Iraq today as the Kurdish faction that has been backed by President Saddam Hussein's forces mounted an eastward offensive and overran the city.

title: Van de Kamp's Selects Eisner
description: Van de Kamp's Inc. in St. Louis has named William Eisner & Associates in Hales Corners, Wis., to handle advertising for its frozen-food products. Billings were estimated at $30 million, including future spending on brands recently acquired.

title: Be, a novel start-up, can offer software to Apple beyond conventional systems.
description: INSIDE the beleaguered Apple Computer Inc., a comment is often heard about the appointment earlier this year of Gilbert F. Amelio as chairman and president: ''Thank God there's finally some adult supervision around here.''

title: No Headline
description: ''The tacit assumption of the political consultant is that the candidate is a lump of clay, and you use polls and focus groups to shape him.'' MICHAEL R. BESCHLOSS, a historian of the Presidency. $(A14:4$)

title: In the Days Of Baseball's Innocence
description: Remember when baseball was just a game? When sports idols did not spend the off-season in rehab or completing their community service? Was there ever such a time? For the nostalgic, Eddie Frierson is offering a visit to a bygone era of baseball with ''Matty,'' an appealing one-man show about Christy Mathewson, the clean-cut boy next door who was one of the game's greatest pitchers.

title: Accounts
description: * Gordon Biersch Brewing Co., San Jose, Calif., to Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley, San Francisco, to introduce Gordon Biersch bottled beer, to be sold in stores, as well as Gordon Biersh's restaurants and brew pubs. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Goose Roundup Flopped, But Mayor Is Undaunted
description: In this Rockland County bedroom community, Supervisor Charles Holbrook may forever be known as the man who took on the geese.

title: Sara Lee Unit Shifts Agencies
description: Champion sportswear, a division of the Sara Lee Corporation, is moving its account, with billings estimated at $10 million, from one New York agency owned by the Omnicom Group to another.

title: Prudential Unit To Kirshenbaum
description: Prudential Health Care in Roseland, N.J., has named Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York to handle its consolidated national account, with billings estimated at $20 million. The account had been divided among three agencies: W. B. Doner & Company in Baltimore, which continues to handle some direct marketing; Larkin Meeder Schweidel in Dallas, and Noble Steed Associates in Lutherville, Md.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: INSIDE
description: Okinawan Vote Snubs U.S.

title: Bridge
description: Most players are baffled by the following ''simple'' question: Which is greater, the number of possible hands or the number of possible auctions?

title: Pataki Courts Democrats For Bond Act
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the Republican machinery behind him claim they can muster a huge upstate Republican voter turnout for Bob Dole, the same electoral game plan that carried Mr. Pataki to office.

title: Home Run Records Are Gone
description: The season that has featured an all-out assault on home run records on every line in the book produced a major league record yesterday for home runs hit in a season. A home run by Gary Sheffield of the Marlins against Pedro Martinez of Montreal in the fifth inning of their game in Florida provided the record-breaker, the 4,459th home run hit this season.

title: Cancer Survivor Finds a 'Lifeboat'
description: In sobering detail, a surgeon outlined for Daniel L. Lawrence what would be a 19-hour operation to remove his cancerous vocal cords and reconstruct a new tongue with tissue taken from his armpit.

title: The New Campaign Story: Consultants Steal Spotlight
description: It was the zenith, or perhaps the nadir, of three decades of change in how campaigns are run and covered: over the last 10 days, consultants at times eclipsed both of the major-party Presidential candidates. The debacle of Dick Morris, the Presidential consultant, was the more spectacular, but both the Republicans and the Democrats generated headlines that turned not on daring ideas or stirring oratory, but on the jettisoning of top political strategists.

title: Patience Is the Key To Victory For Hart
description: For the better part of six years, he has fought. The battles were against himself, his temper, injuries and self-doubt. It was all supposed to be so easy for Dudley Hart when he arrived on the PGA Tour in 1991 as an acclaimed collegian, a four-time all-American from the University of Florida, a smiling blond kid with looks and game and as much talent as any rookie in years.

title: Pentagon Sees Slim Chance of U.S. War Role in Northern Iraq
description: The United States is unlikely to be drawn into the fighting between two Kurdish factions in northern Iraq, despite reports that Iraqi troops are continuing to fight alongside one of the factions, senior Pentagon officials said today.

title: Believe It: People Get Signals on the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Same-Sex Marriage Rights
description: More than 50 gay and lesbian protesters and their families marched outside Assemblywoman Marion Crecco's office yesterday morning to protest a bill she has introduced outlawing same-sex marriages. With the Legislature set to reconvene Sept. 19 after its summer break, Gina Reiss, president of the New Jersey Lesbian and Gay Coalition, said the group wanted to remind lawmakers to ''uphold the Constitution, not the Bible.'' Edward Martone, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, said that the bill violates couples' rights to freedom of association and equal protection.

title: Former Socialist Official Is 5th Suspect : Ex-Belgian Minister Held in Political Killing
description: BRUSSELS  Belgium was shocked anew Sunday by the arrest of a former federal minister for the murder in 1991 of Andre Cools, a Socialist Party leader and once a deputy prime minister.

title: The Gay Life, With a Sting And a Tickle
description: When the songs and skits in Mike Oster's revue ''Disappearing Act'' concentrate on the manners and language of gay men, they are sharp, fast and funny. Even numbers that remind one too insistently of scenes from old Broadway shows and films get some sizzle in the production, at the 47th Street Theater, from the energy of the director, Mark Frawley; the pianist, Ron Roy, and the cast: Branch Woodman, Michael McElroy and Jamie MacKenzie.

title: Laud Limits on New York Business Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: Befriending Luminaries to Tell All
description: SOME REMARKABLE MEN

title: Part Spanish, Part English But Transcending Both
description: The singer Gloria Estefan, who sold out three shows at Madison Square Garden over the weekend, has had one of the more precarious careers in pop. Not long ago she could have become the Eric Estrada of the music world, a huge mainstream star who vanished, for English-speaking fans, into the perceived darkness of Hispanic pop. In 1993, after nearly 10 years of stamping out pulp fare in English, Ms. Estefan, a Cuban-American from Miami, veered off the predicted path by recording ''Mi Tierra,'' a Spanish-language album.

title: Clean Up Election Minefields
description: Gov. George Pataki and the State Legislature got deserved praise this year for simplifying New York's notoriously picky rules on how candidates qualify to get on the ballot. But the weeks leading up to tomorrow's primaries have made it obvious that the system is still a mess and that more changes are needed.

title: Graf Is Leaving No Doubt About Just Who Is No. 1
description: The charcoal storm clouds and the rumble of thunder drifted in from the west, like a two-minute warning in a football game. Actually, Steffi Graf would have three full minutes before the Louis Armstrong Stadium would be deluged yesterday, three minutes to serve Monica Seles off the court and out of the rain.

title: CHRONICLE
description: So who's minding the store? New York has been deluged by major fashion designers from Paris, Milan and London, among them GIORGIO ARMANI, GIANFRANCO FERRE, VALENTINO, EMANUEL UNGARO, JOHN GALLIANO, VIVIENNE WESTWOOD, JIL SANDER and DONATELLA VERSACE.

title: The Blizzard's Blessings
description: It seems there was much more going on during the Blizzard of 1996 than shoveling driveways. The Associated Press reported yesterday that nine months after the huge snowstorm socked the Northeast, Pennsylvania and New Jersey delivery rooms are preparing for a deluge of Blizzard Babies. Hospitals do not know exactly how many women will be giving birth this month and next. But administrators at hospitals in both states say they are taking their cue from the number of projected due dates -- which are up as much as 50 percent from last year.

title: In North Carolina, a Battle of 2 Conservatives
description: Many Democrats are trying to sound as conservative as Republicans these days. But here in the Seventh Congressional District of North Carolina, it is the other way around.

title: Everyone Has Heard Yanks' Wake-Up Call
description: The Yankees never realized just how many sleeping giants existed in baseball until their inconsistent play and losing ways started sounding in the American League like so many reveille calls.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Fed Governor Sees Risk Of Inflation in Job Gains

title: Leonard Katzman, 69, Producer, Director and Writer for 'Dallas'
description: Leonard Katzman, a television producer, director and writer who produced more than 350 episodes of ''Dallas,'' one of the most popular series in television history, died on Thursday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 69.

title: Support Ethanol
description: To the Editor:

title: From One Woman to Another, Ogilvy & Mather Is Making History
description: Madison Avenue is marking a milestone as Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide changes chief executives: For the first time, those duties at a giant advertising agency company are being passed from one woman to another.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Hundley's Record Homer Is Hit to Just the Right Spot
description: When Todd Hundley's towering rainbow landed in the 24th row of Section 125 of Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium, Marty Wannemacher was there waiting to fulfill the fantasy he has carried since his childhood, when he watched countless games at Shea Stadium.

title: Workfare Cuts Costs but Tracking New Jobs Poses Problems
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has often described his workfare program -- by far the largest in the nation -- as ''saving the lives'' of people on welfare by putting them to work. But while the program has helped New York City slash its welfare spending, it has not demonstrated that it can rebuild the futures of men and women on welfare.

title: 5 Years Later, Baghdad Army Gets on Its Feet
description: The deployment of Iraqi armed forces in northern Iraq since last week to back a Kurdish faction signals that President Saddam Hussein, five years after the debacle of the Persian Gulf war, has revived his conventional ground forces to the point where they are capable of embarking on major military offensives, diplomats and military analysts say.

title: Inmates Tried Hunger Strike, but Hunger Struck
description: Inmates at the Suffolk County jail staged a one-day hunger strike last week to protest a new policy barring them from wearing high-priced sneakers, which officials say can be used to hide drugs, weapons and other contraband.

title: Stocks Gain in Japan
description: Stocks were traded somewhat higher here today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 94.25 points -- slightly less than one-half of 1 percent -- to 20,246.78. On Friday, the Nikkei index lost 227.29 points.

title: A Brighter Economy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dark Clouds Following Jets Finally Let Loose
description: Even the elements are conspiring against the Jets. A strong thunderstorm raced through northern New Jersey early in the fourth quarter of the Jets' game against the Colts yesterday afternoon, dumping buckets of rain and displaying brilliant flashes of lightning over Giants Stadium.

title: No Carrot, No Stick
description: Bosnia, its wounds unhealed, is about to suffer another bitter twist of fate. This one will legitimize the nationalist fanatics who savaged the country, intensify ethnic cleansing and deprive the international community of crucial leverage to prevent further outrages.

title: Okinawans Send Message to Tokyo and U.S. to Cut Bases
description: In a referendum aimed at sending a message to Washington and Tokyo, citizens of Okinawa voted today by an overwhelming ratio of 10 to 1 in favor of a reduction in the American military bases on this island in the south of Japan.

title: A Century's Worth of Styles, Without Getting Cluttered
description: After presenting the members of his 16-piece band on Saturday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, Lyle Lovett introduced himself as ''the guy who sits next to you and reads the newspaper.'' The line was a clear indicator of his modesty and sense of humor, but it also pointed to more.

title: On Eve of Meeting With Netanyahu, U.S. Asks Israel for 'Concrete Steps' With Palestinians
description: A day before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is to meet President Clinton in Washington, the United States called on Israel today to take more ''concrete steps'' to improve relations with the Palestinians.

title: In Westchester, Welfare Meets Managed Care
description: When Isabel Briceno showed up with her feverish 1-year-old, Selena, and a Medicaid card at the emergency room of St. Joseph's Medical Center, she got two surprises.

title: The Chechen War in Moscow
description: For Aleksandr Lebed, Russia's security chief, it has been harder to make peace in Moscow than to end the fighting in Chechnya. In Moscow, the retired general faces not one but three adversaries, each potentially more deadly to his aspirations than any Chechen force.

title: Perils of Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Arda C. Bowser, Pro Football Pioneer, 97
description: Arda C. Bowser, the last surviving member of the first National Football League championship team, the Canton Bulldogs, and the originator of the kicking tee died on Saturday. He was 97.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: In its first brand-identity campaign in a decade, Novell will try to take the 'No' out of its name.
description: AN assertive advertising blitz that begins today will try to take the ''No'' out of Novell.

title: Fujitsu PC Names CKS Partners
description: The Fujitsu PC Corporation in Milpitas, Calif., has named CKS Partners in Cupertino, Calif., to handle its integrated marketing account, with billings estimated at $20 million. The account had been handled by LVL Communications in Santa Clara, Calif. The decision came after a review that had been narrowed to CKS Partners, a unit of the CKS Group, and two other finalists: LVL and FCB Technologies in San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications.

title: Mercedes-Benz Reports 10% Rise in Car Sales
description: Mercedes-Benz A.G. said yesterday that its car sales rose 10 percent in the first eight months of 1996 as the company, the car and truck-making unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., introduced its new passenger mini-van. Car sales reached 423,000 units in January through August, amid strong sales in Germany and the United States, the Mercedes chief executive, Helmut Werner, said at a news conference to introduce the V-class mini-van.

title: Study Ties Teen-Age Drug Use To Parents' Marijuana Smoking
description: Teen-agers whose baby-boom parents smoked marijuana regularly a generation ago are more likely to use drugs than other teen-agers, a national study released today has found.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: From Here and Abroad, Desire and High Anxiety
description: Dancers from several nations gathered together on Sunday night for ''Moves II,'' a program at the Merce Cunningham Studio that was notable for the seriousness of its choreographic aspirations. But high-mindedness was not always accompanied by imagination.

title: North Carolina Women No Sure Bet
description: Women's soccer has enjoyed such an unprecedented rate of growth and popularity at the college level that the number of women's programs has this season surpassed the number of men's programs at Division I schools.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD REPLACES EXECUTIVE WITH TEAM
description: The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, a builder of single-family homes, said yesterday that Roger Menard had resigned as executive vice president and president of its United States operations, and would be replaced by a regional management structure. Glen Barnard will be regional general manager for the central region; Mr. Barnard will continue as president of the Colorado division, and Lisa Kalmbach will head the Northern California region and remain president of the South Bay Division. Albert Praw, a senior vice president, will oversee Southern California, Nevada and Mexico operations, as well as the multihousing group. Kaufman & Broad said Mr. Menard would be a consultant with the company. Kaufman shares rose 25 cents, to $12.125, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Hate the Government? Let Us Count the Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: FACTION OF KURDS SUPPORTED BY IRAQ TAKES RIVAL'S CITY
description: As thousands of its residents trudged into barren mountains in an anxious exodus, this city in northern Iraq fell tonight to the Kurdish faction backed by President Saddam Hussein after being all but abandoned by its defenders.

title: U.S. Trying to Help Trapped Iraqi Dissidents
description: President Clinton said today that the United States was doing ''everything we can'' to help American-supported Iraqi dissidents trapped by the fighting between Kurdish factions in northern Iraq and hunted by President Saddam Hussein's security forces.

title: Accounts
description: Europay International, Waterloo, Belgium, to McCann-Erickson Worldwide, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as the first agency to handle advertising in 10 European countries for the payment service provider; McCann's office in Prague will serve as the lead agency. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Q&A
description: Tanning Your Hide

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS INSURANCE GROUP LTD., Chicago, an insurance holding company, has been bought by its president, John A. Dore, and the investment group Castle Harlan Partners 2, a partnership managed by New York-based merchant bank Castle Harlan Inc., for $54 million.

title: A Tale of Love and Murder in a Small Town
description: It is one murder, a police detective in Texas says, with two teen-age suspects and three motives: ''his guilt, her anger and their passion for each other.''

title: For Fall, a Touch of Velvet
description: This is the autumn to have something velvet -- a jacket, a dress, a scarf or a pair of gloves.

title: Chess
description: Veselin Topalov came up as a brilliant tactician and got into the inner circle of possible challengers for the world championship with many glittering games. But having arrived at such a high status as one of the top 10 players, the 21-year-old Bulgarian grandmaster seems clearly to be aiming for something besides tournament first prizes and brilliancy prizes. Without tarnishing his bright, adventurous approach, he is honing his positional skills.

title: 2 Face Ethics Charges by Nader Unit
description: A self-styled Congressional reform organization founded by Ralph Nader has filed charges of ethical violations against two senior House Republicans, Tom DeLay, the majority whip, and Bud Shuster, chairman of the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.

title: New York City Primary Choices
description: This list summarizes our recommendations for certain legislative and judicial primary races in New York City today where the outcome is tantamount to election and the race is closely contested. As always, our most important recommendation is nonpartisan: It is to urge you to vote. Poll hours in the city are 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: In L.I. Pine Barrens, Ecologists Learn From Scars of '95 Blaze
description: The charred trees were still smoldering in late August last year, when a handful of scientists got down on their hands and knees in the heart of the pine barrens in Westhampton, L.I., to study the regeneration of the dwarf pitch pine.

title: Summertime Blues ('the Truth') Lingers in a Lot
description: Football season is going into its third week, school buses are rolling, and the night winds carry the chilly feel of fall. But in one struggling neighborhood here, summer is never over until the music stops.

title: I.B.M. and Big Banks in Home Service Deal
description: I.B.M. and a group of big banks said yesterday that they had formed a venture that the banks hoped would improve their ability to offer services through home computers and other devices.

title: Olivetti Shares Plunge After a 2-Day Halt
description: The shares of Olivetti S.p.A. plunged 19.5 percent yesterday on their first day of trading since a former top executive resigned on Wednesday after questioning the first-half results reported by the company. Shares fell 146 lire, to 603 lire (40 cents) yesterday, their lowest closing price ever. The start of trading was delayed an hour and there were numerous halts for excessive declines after trading began. Trading in the stock had been suspended on Thursday and Friday.

title: Pilot's Fatal Venture
description: Robert S. Golabek loved flying his 1971 Piper Cherokee so much that during the summer, he and his wife would move into a trailer at the Sussex Airport in Wantage, officials there said. A thick fog hovered over the airport on Saturday evening, but that did not stop Mr. Golabek, 59, of Allentown, Pa., from taking off. Yesterday, two hikers along the Appalachian Trail found his body amid the charred wreckage of the single-engine plane near Sunrise Mountain in Stokes State Forest in Sandyston Township.

title: A Sporting Gesture, but City Is Weary of Charity
description: Aljo Hadic turned his head toward Trebevic Mountain today when he heard the first sharp report of the starter pistol that sent a half-dozen international athletes racing down the spanking new red track in Kosevo Stadium here.

title: Toshiba Is Entering American Home Computer Market Today
description: The Toshiba Corporation will enter the American market for home computers today with machines that represent a further step in trying to make personal computers look and operate more like consumer appliances.

title: SUDBURY REJECTS BID BY PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES
description: Sudbury Inc. said yesterday that its board had rejected an unsolicited offer of $170 million by Park-Ohio Industries for the company, calling the bid inadequate. Sudbury, a maker of industrial machine parts, reiterated that it intended to maximize stockholder value. The company said it would continue to pursue talks with potential bidders but added it had not decided that a takeover would be in the best interests of its stockholders. Last week, Park-Ohio proposed a cash merger valued at $11 a share. Shares of Sudbury slipped 12.5 cents a share, to $12.625, and Park-Ohio rose 37.5 cents a share, to $15.

title: INSIDE
description: Deciphering Welfare

title: The Lessons Of Attica, 25 Years Later
description: IT is the sort of thing that could easily be overlooked, so those of you with long memories -- and, better yet, those with short ones -- might want to note that this week is the 25th anniversary of the inmate uprising at the state prison in Attica, N.Y.

title: Robitaille Looking Beyond Gretzky Feud
description: Neither player cares to talk about it too much. When asked today if there was still any bad blood between him and Wayne Gretzky, Luc Robitaille said, ''I think there's been a lot of water under the bridge.''

title: Eurotunnel Says Loss Narrowed in First Half
description: Eurotunnel said yesterday that it had narrowed its loss for the first half as its revenue doubled and traffic picked up. Eurotunnel, which operates the Channel Tunnel linking England and France, lost $:371.7 million ($577.6 million) in the first half of 1996 after losing $:464.5 million a year earlier. Revenue for the six months that ended on June 30 came to $:223.7 million ($347.6 million), up from $:104.5 million a year earlier.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was a challenge for the 11 winners of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, this country's highest civilian honor, to get to the White House for the ceremony yesterday. But they all managed to make it except ROSA PARKS, the civil rights pioneer, and MORRIS K. UDALL, the former Arizona Representative.

title: Critics Assail a Group's Control Of Towns' Audits in New Jersey
description: Since the Depression, a small group of accountants has controlled the annual audits of all the towns and counties in New Jersey, using a system of antiquated and arcane rules that are laid out in books and loose-leaf notebooks stored in their offices and passed on to a select few.

title: Yankees Add Sluggers But Lose Some Spark
description: The baseball cards with his glossy picture arrived through the mail cut in half, little pieces of Cecil Fielder.

title: Man Dies Attempting Rescue
description: A good Samaritan died yesterday while trying to rescue a woman caught in a riptide, The Associated Press reported. The 46-year-old woman was struggling near Stockton Avenue when the 54-year-old man jumped into the Atlantic to help her, witnesses told the police. The woman managed to float on her back until she was rescued by someone else, the police said. Neither person was identified by the police.

title: 5-Year Term for Ex-Officer in Harlem Scandal
description: A former New York City police officer caught in the sweeping scandal at the 30th Precinct in Harlem was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison for dealing drugs, evading taxes and breaking into property without a search warrant.

title: Hours for Voting
description: Primary elections will be held in New York State today. Polling places will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deal Is Struck on Plan To Reduce Fees by S.E.C.

title: A Visit From Gingrich Gets a Rare Welcome
description: Across the country, Democrats are trying to tar their Republican opponents by linking them with Newt Gingrich and his opposition to raising the minimum wage, his support for cuts in Medicare spending and his efforts to lift environmental regulations.

title: Dole Focuses On Georgia And Florida, Talking Taxes
description: With bolts of lightning jabbing the air around him, Bob Dole's effort at showcasing his personal side here today was short-circuited by an electrical storm. But before the charcoal skies opened up and drenched the 300 people who had gathered at a backyard fish fry to hear him, he asserted he was excited about the Presidential race.

title: Kemp Praises Farrakhan For His Focus on Family
description: Pressing his message of inclusion and his outreach to black voters, Jack Kemp has praised the Nation of Islam leader, Louis Farrakhan, for emphasizing black self-reliance and family values.

title: Monastery in Spain Catches Manuscript Thieves Red-Handed
description: After thieves posing as researchers stole nine rare manuscripts from a Benedictine monastery library near Barcelona last July, the monks did more than pray. When the prime suspects came back unexpectedly last week, led by a man who said he was a rabbi, the monks helped police lay a trap to capture the group.

title: Elizabeth Eyre de Lanux, 102, Art Deco Designer
description: Elizabeth Eyre de Lanux, an American artist, writer and designer of 1920's Art Deco furnishings whose works were rediscovered in the late 1980's, died on Sunday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 102.

title: Plotting a Mission to Retrieve Rocks From Mars
description: WHILE scientists at several laboratories examine a dark piece of rock to see if it indeed holds evidence of early life on Mars, NASA officials are weighing a wide assortment of ideas for revamping and accelerating current plans for exploring the red planet. The focus is on how and when to secure what scientists covet most: an indisputable sample of Martian rock and soil, preferably from a relatively warm, wet place where microbes might have arisen long ago.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Composer Tells Dole To Hold the 'Soul'
description: The owners of the 1960's Motown hit ''Soul Man'' have told Bob Dole in an onimous-sounding letter that a version of the song being played at his campaign rallies -- sporting the reprise ''I'm a Dole Man'' -- is a violation of copyright law that is ''tantamount to theft.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Lehman Brothers Settles Suit on Trading
description: Lehman Brothers Inc. said today that it had settled a lawsuit over trading debts with the China National United Petroleum and Chemicals Company. Lehman Brothers said terms of the settlement would not be disclosed.

title: Chancellor Considering Offer of Catholic Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he was willing to consider a plan to move 1,000 failing students from the New York City public schools to Catholic schools, provided no tax money is involved.

title: Figuring Out the O. J. Simpson Trial
description: THE RUN OF HIS LIFE

title: Primer on Internet-Wise Spycraft
description: SPIES have sneaked into our imaginations for eons. While the fascination with espionage is enduring, the business of spying has been transformed completely in recent years by the microchip. Cloaks and daggers have given way to computers and hackers.

title: Mayor's New Theme: Personal Responsibility
description: Responding to days of questions about the needs of the city's children, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began to sound a new theme last week on the relationship between New Yorkers and their government. It is time, he argued with exasperation, that individuals, families and neighborhoods assume more responsibility for the city's well-being.

title: Primary Races in New York City End in a Flurry of Spending and Ballot Changes
description: With a flurry of television and radio advertisements, campaign rallies and that staple of New York City campaigning, handshakes at subway stops, the primary campaigning for scores of local posts in New York State wound down yesterday.

title: Agreement Reached on Plan To Cut Fees Charged by S.E.C.
description: Congressional negotiators agreed yesterday on a plan to reduce fees charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission, settling one of the issues that has stalled a bill to reduce regulation of financial markets, a Congressional official, who insisted on anonymity, said.

title: BTR of Britain to Sell Taiwan Polymer Stake
description: The British industrial conglomerate BTR P.L.C. said yesterday that it was selling its 51 percent stake in Polymer Group of Taiwan for $300 million. BTR said two Taiwan companies -- the USI Far East Corporation and the Union Petrochemical Corporation -- were joining to buy the stake. BTR will receive $120 million on completion of the sale and two subsequent annual payments of $90 million. (AP)

title: A Thing for Oysters And for Solving Crimes
description: The name of the police detective hero in ''Dark Angel'' is D'Arcangelo. Get it? Too much of this ''Fox Tuesday Night Movie'' is just as obvious. There is, however, one solid asset. The detective is played by Eric Roberts, making a neat leap to seductive leading man from being the king of creepoville in B-television movies for far too long.

title: Hate the Government? Let Us Count the Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: How Johnny Cash Is Keeping Current
description: Even patriarchs can learn new tricks. Johnny Cash, performing on Saturday night at Irving Plaza as part of the CMJ Music Marathon, started his set with hits from his 40-year career: songs that are haunted by death and that long for redemption, like ''Folsom Prison Blues.'' Dressed as always in black and backed by his longtime band, the Tennessee Three, plus a keyboardist, Earl Ball, he could have simply done reprises of rock and country cornerstones like ''Big River'' and ''I Walk the Line.'' But he drew startled cheers from the collegiate audience when he previewed his next album, ''Unchained'' (American), due Nov. 5.

title: Daily News Settles a Suit Over Housing Ads
description: The Daily News agreed yesterday to a tentative settlement of a Federal lawsuit charging that the newspaper violated fair housing laws by running ads stating owners' preference for tenants without children or of a specific sex.

title: 'Three Strikes' Rarely Invoked In Courtrooms
description: Despite widespread publicity as 24 states and the Federal Government rushed to pass tough ''three strikes and you're out'' laws in the last three years, the statutes have rarely been used and they have had little effect on crime rates, according to two new studies and interviews with prison officials.

title: Yanks Must Rely on a Pitcher With Problems of His Own
description: The ghost of Ed Whitson is materializing in Kenny Rogers's body. Maybe it has already taken over his arm and his mind. If it has, the Yankees might have no hope of salvaging the ghost of their once huge division lead.

title: Of Liberty and Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d Trial in Robbery Death
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the second felony murder trial stemming from the botched robbery in March 1995 of a Franklin Township jewelry store in which the owner fatally shot his wife. The defendant, Robert L. Williams, is the first of four Missouri men to be tried for the failed robbery, which led to the death of Brenda Wolf. In June, jurors were unable to reach a verdict in the trial of Harry Insabella, a Franklin Park dentist accused of helping plan the robbery. Jeffrey Wolf, the store owner, is expected to testify against Mr. Williams, said A. Peter DeMarco, an assistant Somerset County prosecutor.

title: Who Needs Offense With Chiefs' Defense?
description: The Chiefs have the type of defense that can carry an offense. The Chiefs have the type of defense that can propel Kansas City into Super Bowl XXXI.

title: Longtime General Partner Plans To Retire at Goldman, Sachs
description: David M. Silfen, 50, co-head of Goldman, Sachs & Company's equities business, said yesterday that he would retire as a general partner on Nov. 30, the end of the company's fiscal year, after 28 years with the Wall Street firm.

title: Miscellany
description: The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, Daytona Beach, Fla., will open an office in New York to handle duties like sponsorship sales, marketing and licensing.

title: Daewoo Expects to Buy Thomson Multimedia
description: The Daewoo Electronics Company, South Korea's third-largest electronics maker, said yesterday that it would probably buy Thomson Multimedia, the consumer electronics arm of the state-owned French company Thomson S.A. by the end of this year. ''We are in negotiations with the French Government and expect to reach an agreement by the end of this month,'' said Chung Jae Hyun, a Daewoo spokesman.

title: Central Bankers' Group Admits 9 Members : China and Russia Join World's Economic Elite
description: PARIS  The organization that brings together the world's most powerful central banks announced Monday that it was expanding to include China, Russia and a handful of fast-growing, emerging economies from Asia and Latin America.

title: De Benedetti Said to Seek Sale of His Company
description: The shares of Cerus S.A. rose yesterday in Paris as a newspaper reported that Cerus, a holding company controlled by the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti, was in talks to be bought by CGIP, a French financial and industrial company. Both companies declined to comment.

title: Central Bankers' Group Adding to Ranks
description: The Bank for International Settlements will admit nine new members, including China and Russia, as it expands beyond the industrial West to include central banks in the world's fastest-growing economies.

title: War in Chechnya Costs Moscow Billions
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 at Commerzbank Included in Tax Inquiry
description: The chief executive of Commerzbank A.G., Martin Kohlhaussen, and three other bank officials have been included in an investigation of tax evasion by the bank, Frankfurt prosecutors said yesterday. The senior prosecutor in Frankfurt said the others under investigation were Walter Seipp, chairman of the supervisory board and former chief executive; Kurt Hochheuser, a member of the management board, and Wolfgang Hoenig, head of the tax and accounting department.

title: On Clinton's Watch
description: Almost four years after President Clinton assumed responsibility for dealing with Iraq, its armies are far stronger than when he took office, its network of arms factories is rebuilt and fully operating, its secret programs for weapons of mass destruction are clicking along, and Saddam Hussein's prestige in the Mideast and even Europe are higher than ever.

title: Chinese Aide, Released From Prison, Is Still Held in Isolation
description: Bao Tong's family says he would like to learn to play classical music on the piano and, at the age of 63, receive a thorough medical examination before getting on with his life after seven years in prison.

title: Perot Attacks Political Process as 'Destructive'
description: Beleaguered by low standings in public opinion polls, Ross Perot blasted American politics today as ''negative, bitter, mean-spirited and destructive.''

title: Retailers dress up menswear campaigns as flip and hip.
description: IF contestants on ''Family Feud'' were asked to name the favorite fall activity for men, few would rank shopping for clothes ahead of watching football, checking out the new cars or maybe even raking leaves. But as more men begin to follow fashion, retailers are moving to exploit that growing interest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a software programmer who works for the Netscape Communications Corporation included two misplaced passages in some copies. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: The Leap From Stage To Album
description: The original cast albums of Broadway musicals have always had such a decisive effect on the shows' future reputations that it is easy to fool oneself into believing that a recording, augmented with photographs and descriptive liner notes, can distill the essence of a production. But as the original cast albums of ''Rent'' (DreamWorks) and ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk'' (RCA Victor) both illustrate, a cast album often leaves a strikingly different impression from that of the stage event.

title: Parents' Group Doesn't Represent All at Lycee
description: To the Editor:

title: British Air Disputes Report of Job Cuts
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that a report that it planned to cut 10,000 jobs was speculation, though the airline did emphasize that it needed to cut costs to stay competitive. A report in the newspaper The Independent said British Air would shed at least 10,000 of its 55,000 jobs by selling businesses like baggage handling, engineering and maintenance, and information technology.

title: Reeves Heads to Drawing Board After Giants Draw a Blank
description: The Giants' 27-0 loss to the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday has put them in an introspective mode. Like a prophet searching the desert for the meaning of life, Giants Coach Dan Reeves, as well as his assistants and the players, are searching for the meaning of, well, anything at this point, including simply running a play that works.

title: Bonds Rise; 30-Year Yield Slips to 7.07%
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose for the second consecutive session yesterday, even as the market shifted its focus to reports on inflation and retail sales scheduled for release this week.

title: Sampras and Graf Follow Grueling Paths to Greatness
description: It was just four months ago that Pete Sampras could not bear to set foot on a tennis court: tennis reminded him of the death of his coach.

title: Young Broadcasting to Buy Shares Back
description: Young Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back the Walt Disney Company's stake in the company, which consists of 1.5 million class C common shares valued at about $49.9 million and a warrant to buy 750,000 class C shares.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Clinton Adviser Disputes Tabloid Account About White House Files
description: Dick Morris, who resigned as President Clinton's campaign strategist after a supermarket tabloid reported that he had a relationship with a Washington prostitute, today disputed the woman's account that he had told her Hillary Rodham Clinton was behind the White House's improper acquisition of as many as 900 confidential F.B.I. files.

title: Europeans Agonize Over the Mall
