description: J. Byrne Murphy vividly remembers how eager many French cities seemed when he arrived here, in April 1993, to build the kind of suburban shopping centers that helped revolutionize retailing in America.

title: Assault Suspect Booked After Contest
description: ALLEN E. ADAMS was a bust kicking a football. Then he was busted. Adams was arrested Sunday during halftime of the Steelers' 31-17 victory over the Baltimore Ravens at Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh. He was held at the Allegheny County Jail.

title: Facing Death Penalty in Murder, Two Opt for Life
description: Faced with a possible death sentence if convicted under a new Federal death penalty statute, two reputed members of a Chinese gang opted yesterday for a mandatory life sentence without parole, pleading guilty to charges that they had kidnapped, tortured and killed an immigrant Chinese woman in a ransom plot.

title: Gingrich Comes to Dinner (but Others Sent Regrets)
description: Representative Gary A. Franks did something today that few of his Republican colleagues in the Northeast are doing: he had House Speaker Newt Gingrich campaign for him.

title: Leave It to Heaven
description: For bad taste it's hard to beat the statesmen Clinton and Dole waxing sentimental over family values. Dole is divorced, and Clinton, as all viewers of ''60 Minutes'' can attest, is a philanderer.

title: Patterns
description: A Change in Bryant Park

title: ITT Says Weak Casino Results Will Curb Quarterly Profits
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it expected lower revenue from its two casinos in Las Vegas, Nev., to hurt its earnings for the third quarter.

title: Italians Contemplate Beauty in a Caribbean Brow
description: Can a black woman, a Caribbean immigrant who has lived in Italy for four years, be a symbol of Italian female beauty?

title: Canada's Rangers Expected to Play
description: Mark Messier practiced for only about 10 minutes yesterday in Philadelphia, then headed for Team Canada's training room for treatment of sore groin muscles.

title: Judge Rules in Favor of Athlete
description: A Federal judge in Chicago ruled yesterday that Northwestern must give NICK KNAPP a chance to play college basketball, even though his heart once stopped during a pickup game. United States District Judge JAMES ZAGEL said Knapp's risk of injury or death related to the cardiac arrest he suffered two years ago was not enough to warrant barring the 6-foot-5-inch guard from playing.

title: Sounding Like the Beatles, And Acting More Popular
description: What Oasis has done in Britain, unifying an entire country under the banner of a single pop act, a band could no longer accomplish in a country that has become as culturally splintered as the United States. While the members of Oasis, which performed at Jones Beach on Sunday night, are superstars only to a niche pop audience here, in Britain the band reigns unchallenged as the most popular act since the Beatles. There is an Oasis CD in roughly one of every three homes there; last month, the band drew 250,000 people to Knebworth, north of London, for the biggest outdoor concerts in the country's history; The group's battling brothers, Liam and Noel Gallagher, appear as regularly as royalty on tabloid covers.

title: Starved Girl's Burial Touches Neighbors Used to Hardship
description: The people had come with toys and prayers for Nadine Lockwood, the 4-year-old child who would be buried this day. Not permitted into Trumbo's Funeral Chapel in Harlem, they waited, under a searing sun, mothers with strollers and grandmothers with graying hair.

title: Matchmaker, Matchmaker
description: After a long search, Ross Perot is scheduled to name his Reform Party running mate tonight. Some political experts offered their own ideas of whom he should name.

title: 2 Steamship Companies To Join Container Units
description: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company and the Royal Nedlloyd Group said yesterday that they would merge their container businesses to create one of the world's largest shipping companies. Nedlloyd is to make a $175 million payment to P.& O. and the business, P & O Nedlloyd Container Line, will be equally owned by both companies.

title: In Storm-Struck North Carolina, Normal Is Still Days Away
description: Four days after Hurricane Fran crashed ashore in the Cape Fear region of North Carolina, everything on the barrier islands leaned, everything inland was disheveled and a semblance of normal life still seemed several days away.

title: Criticism of State Audits
description: Since the Depression, a small group of accountants has controlled the annual audits of all the towns and counties in New Jersey, using a system of antiquated and arcane rules that is unique to New Jersey. Critics say it is not serving the state well. Some New Jersey municipalities are paying audit fees twice those paid by cities of similar size in nearby states. The biggest criticism, however, is that the inch-thick audit reports these accountants produce give so little useful information that taxpayers, and even local elected officials, have little hope of learning exactly how a town spends its money. $(Page A1.$)

title: Stocks Climb, With Dow Up 73.98 Points
description: Stocks shot sharply higher yesterday, as the lure of moderate earnings, economic growth and restrained inflation all gave investors some new confidence, analysts said.

title: BEN & JERRY'S PREDICTS LOWER QUARTERLY EARNINGS
description: Shares of Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. fell 7 percent today after the ice cream company said its third-quarter earnings would be lower than anticipated. The company, based in South Burlington, cited high dairy costs and lower-than-expected sales. Ben & Jerry's did not estimate earnings for the period that ends Sept. 30, saying only that earnings would be below the $2.5 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with last year. According to a survey by First Call Inc., analysts had expected earnings of 39 cents a share in the latest period. Ben & Jerry's had sales of $45.4 million in the third quarter of 1995. The company could not be reached for comment. Shares of Ben & Jerry's fell $1 to close at $13.375 each in Nasdaq trading.

title: No Headline
description: Criminals don't think about what kind of punishment they are going to get before they act. I don't get a lot of rational people coming in here. -- CHASE RIVELAND, Washington State prison official, on repeat-offender laws. $(D23:3.$)

title: Sentencing in Credit Suisse Embezzlement
description: A former Credit Suisse executive in New York who was to have become head of the company's North American operations, has been sentenced to one year and one day in prison for embezzling $331,000 from the bank. But the former executive, Peter Nardin, 49, will not have to pay a criminal fine for his conviction, Federal District Judge John Keenan said in sentencing him on Friday.

title: Adelphi Chief Vowed War, Ex-Dean Says
description: When opposition grew last year to Adelphi University's president, he vowed to retaliate with all-out campus warfare, a former dean testified yesterday.

title: Daka Shares Fall 35% on Poor Earnings Report
description: Shares of Daka International Inc., a food-service company that also runs the Fuddrucker and Champps restaurant chains, plunged 35 percent today after it posted falling earnings and said it was renegotiating a deal with the Kmart Corporation to operate 1,850 restaurants in its stores.

title: Security Chief: Games Were 'Too Big'
description: The Atlanta Olympics were marred by behind-the-scenes management problems because they were simply too big to handle, the security chief for the Summer Games said yesterday. The security operation, for example, was stuck with filthy dormitories for officers, a severe shortage of two-way radios and some volunteers so disgruntled that they might have quit if not given souvenir watches, BILL RATHBURN, the security chief, said.

title: Summer's Big Bangs Yield to Thoughts Of Oscars
description: The mantra among studio executives is that too many movies are getting made; it seems like two or three open every weekend. But the real issue roiling Hollywood is not so much the quantity of movies but the quality. With two-thirds of 1996 gone, many here are hard-pressed to find a single shoo-in for an Academy Award nomination.

title: Bill Monroe Dies at 84; Fused Musical Roots Into Bluegrass
description: Bill Monroe, who helped lay the foundation of country music as the universally recognized father of bluegrass, died yesterday in a nursing home in Springfield, Tenn. He was 84. He had suffered a stroke earlier this year, said his booking agent, Tony Conway.

title: Hate the Government? Let Us Count the Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: Robert C. Erwin was named to the new position of president of GTFH Advertising, New York, a unit of Grey Advertising. He had been executive vice president and chief operating officer at Robert A. Becker/Euro RSCG, New York, a unit of Havas Advertising.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE PLANS PURCHASES
description: The Northwestern Public Service Company of Huron S.D., said yesterday that its Northwestern Growth unit would buy two propane distributors. Northwestern plans to acquire the Empire Energy Corporation, the eighth-largest United States retail propane distributor, for $120 million, expanding Northwestern's propane business into the Southeast. The closely held Empire, based in Lebanon, Mo., has 130,000 customers in 10 states. Northwestern said it had also agreed to buy CGI Holdings, the parent company of a California-based propane distributor. Northwestern said it would pay $10 million for CGI's preferred stock. The companies have not agreed on terms for the common stock of CGI, which has 75,000 customers in seven Western states.

title: Consumers Continued Pace Of Borrowing During July
description: Consumer borrowing, on the rise for three years, continued to grow in July as credit card use outpaced auto borrowing, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: Radio Days Are Here, but Not on Broadway
description: THERE are plenty of things you can find in New York and nowhere else, but reasonably priced access to the World Wide Web over the airwaves is not one of them. For that, at the moment, you pretty much have to visit the selected enclaves of the West Coast where Metricom Inc. offers its Ricochet service at prices rivaling those of Internet providers who just answer the phone.

title: Frazier Sidelined With Pneumonia
description: TOMMIE FRAZIER, who led Nebraska to consecutive national championships and is the backup quarterback for the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, is sidelined indefinitely while he recovers from pneumonia.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: New Faces

title: A Parting of the Ways On Cigarette Account
description: Trone Advertising in Greensboro, N.C., and the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings in Winston-Salem, N.C., said yesterday that they had mutually agreed to end their relationship on brands including Salem menthol cigarettes. As a result, the Salem account, with billings last year estimated at $3 million, will be handled by agencies that had been working with Trone on that brand on a project basis.

title: Scientists Growing Livers to Order In Hope of Successful Transplants
description: WHEN Dr. Linda Griffith-Cima arrived at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1988 to begin her postdoctoral work in chemical engineering, a research colleague did two things to introduce her to the project she would be working on. First, as a transplant surgeon, he persuaded her to quit riding her motorcycle around Boston. ''He said, 'Do you know who most of our organs donors are?' '' she recalled. '' 'That's not how I want you to contribute to this project.' ''

title: Corporate Insurer to Cover Cost of Spin Doctors
description: For political candidates, hiring a shrewd image consultant is sometimes likened to taking out an insurance policy. For corporate executives, hiring one can now actually be part of an insurance policy.

title: 2 Armanis on Madison
description: A workman putting some final touches on the third floor of the new Giorgio Armani boutique at 760 Madison Avenue, at 65th Street, was singing ''Parlami d'amore, Mariu'' as the designer whose name is on the door was mounting the stairs yesterday. He jumped a bit when Mr. Armani chimed in, forming a robust Italian duet. But that's the mood right now on Madison Avenue, where on Thursday Mr. Armani will open two 16,000-square-foot stores, Giorgio Armani and Emporio Armani at 601 Madison Avenue (57th Street).

title: Reid Signs With French Team
description: The free-agent forward J. R. REID, who finished last season with the Knicks, will play in France next year for about a third of the money he made in the National Basketball Association. The move is an effort to increase his future value to N.B.A. teams, his agent said yesterday.

title: Seeking to Avoid Judgments
description: Stung by recent large court verdicts against the Atlantic City Police Department, officials announced new policies yesterday aimed at preventing future judgments. Police officers have begun sensitivity training, a new police legal unit is being set up, and a Washington-based consultant will be brought in to see if further changes are needed, said Louis Toscano, a senior policy adviser to Mayor James Whelan. In February, Sgt. Donna Hurley won $1.3 million in a sexual harassment suit against the department. Five months later, a veteran police detective, Gary Sutley, who exposed a cocaine ring within the department, won a $3.1 million wrongful termination suit. TERRY PRISTIN

title: U.N. Debate On Test Ban Is Low-Key
description: A special session of the General Assembly began an unexpectedly smooth debate today on a treaty banning nuclear weapons tests.

title: Susan McDougal Goes to Jail For Not Testifying on Clinton
description: Susan McDougal was sent to jail in Arkansas today as she continued to defy a Federal judge who had ordered her to answer prosecutors' questions before a grand jury about her former Whitewater partner Bill Clinton.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: Approve the Test-Ban Treaty
description: Australia deserves the world's gratitude for leading a last-minute diplomatic rescue of the nuclear test-ban treaty. The treaty, which is likely to be voted on in the United Nations General Assembly today, can thwart the development of new generations of dangerous weapons, encourage further reductions of nuclear weapons stockpiles and spare the environment the shock of further underground nuclear blasts.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Oh, what lessons he can teach . . . TERRY ANDERSON, the newsman who was held hostage in Lebanon for almost seven years before being freed in 1991, is joining the faculty at the Columbia University School of Journalism, where he will teach two courses this year. One is on basic reporting and writing, and the other is on international journalism.

title: Agency's Report Supports Treasury's Debt Maneuvers
description: Months after Republican leaders accused the Clinton Administration of ''raiding'' Government funds while trying to outmaneuver Congress during the budget showdown, the General Accounting Office has concluded that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin acted legally.

title: Martha Phillips, 98, a Force In Luxury Fashion Retailing
description: Martha Phillips, a notable force in luxury fashion retailing for more than 60 years and an early supporter of many of today's leading designers, died on Saturday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 98.

title: They've Got The World On a String
description: Every other year since 1992, the International Festival of Puppet Theater has brought to New York an enticing array of handheld artistry, from puppets on a shoestring to satiric extravaganzas. Sponsored by the Jim Henson Foundation, this time with a budget of $1 million, the biennial promises this year to be the largest and the most diverse of the three festivals.

title: Cost Studies Skew Focus of Airline Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: New Hampshire

title: Favre's Packers Looking Super
description: The Packers spent much of the preseason talking about being good enough to win the Super Bowl. It had become a mantra for quarterback Brett Favre. Coach Mike Holmgren told his team to stop using the S-word during the regular season.

title: Club Snubs a Former Champion
description: GARDNAR MULLOY, 82, once America's top tennis player, is an honorary member of the world's finest clubs -- from Wimbledon to Forest Hills. But he got the boot from the Country Club of Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Answers to School Crowding
description: The reports of overcrowding in New York City's public schools last week sounded like a sudden disaster -- classes in locker rooms and projection booths, guidance counselors working in closets, and first grades packed with well over 40 children. This year's back-to-school horrors, however, were simply a repeat of what happened last September, when schools in neighborhoods with high immigrant populations were inundated with new enrollees and wound up holding classes in auditoriums, shower rooms, even lavatories. The situation is less a sudden crisis than a long-term failure to provide children with educational basics.

title: Hate the Government? Let Us Count the Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Paging Network Taps J. Walter Thompson
description: Paging Network Inc., a wireless messaging company in Plano, Tex., said yesterday that it had selected the Chicago office of the J. Walter Thompson Company to handle its account, which had been handled by Larkin, Meeder & Schweidel in Dallas since June 1994. Billings were estimated at more than $10 million.

title: VALLICORP SHARES RISE ON MERGER TALKS
description: Vallicorp Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it was in preliminary talks for a possible merger with an undisclosed banking company. Vallicorp, a banking company based in Fresno, Calif., which has $1.3 billion in assets, said its board was evaluating all options, including remaining an independent company. It said it could not predict the terms or timing of any possible transaction or whether current discussions would result in a deal. The company's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $18.25; earlier in the day the stock had reached $19.25, a 52-week high.

title: A father and son are cited in a stock manipulation case.
description: WHEN you have a lot of questionable stock to sell, it is good to have a son in the securities business.

title: Netanyahu Needs Arafat as a Partner
description: The next time President Clinton and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu meet -- as they did yesterday in Washington -- Yasir Arafat should be present. The partnership for peace must be forged.

title: CLINTON SUGGESTS AN ARRAY OF STEPS TO FOIL TERRORISM
description: President Clinton challenged Congress today to find more than $1 billion a year to finance a catch-all collection of anti-terrorism measures, including sweeping new airline security equipment and procedures to use computerized records to single out some passengers for extra scrutiny.

title: State Welfare Chiefs Ask For More U.S. Guidance
description: After seeking more authority over welfare policy for 15 years, state officials said today that they needed more Federal guidance on how to carry out the new welfare law.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BARNEY'S INC., New York, said its president and co-chief operating officer, Charles Bunstine 2d, had resigned. John Brincko, a co-chief operating officer, will replace Mr. Bunstine. The reason for Mr. Bunstine's resignation was not disclosed. He will now serve as a consultant to the executive committee of the company's board.

title: Discount Chains And Drugstores In Merger Deals
description: The recent wave of consolidations in the retailing industry continued yesterday as two regional discount chains announced plans to merge and a big drugstore chain began an unsolicited bid for a much smaller competitor in the Southeast.

title: Migrant Geese Face Cloudy Future
description: THE Canada goose, once a solely migratory bird whose majestic V-formations filled the autumn skies, in recent years has become an all-too-familiar year-round resident of Middle Atlantic suburbs and farms, including those of the New York region. There, as the goose population has doubled every five years of late, the big honkers have become pests in the eyes of many people.

title: A Nightclub's Return
description: Maxwell's, a nightclub that made a name for itself by spotting promising musical talent like Bruce Springsteen and R.E.M., closed last week after a fire in its kitchen. But its owner said yesterday that performances would resume on Monday. The club's kitchen was destroyed in Wednesday's fire, which apparently occurred after a heat regulator in the fryer malfunctioned, said Lieut. Robert Falco of the Hoboken Fire Department. The kitchen is not expected to reopen for a month, said William Sutton, who bought Maxwell's in December. Mr. Sutton has had to delay plans to open a microbrewery at the club until the end of the month.

title: Woman Saved After Bridge Jump
description: A Greenwich, Conn., woman jumped 140 feet off the Tappan Zee Bridge yesterday during rush hour, but was rescued by a volunteer firefighter who jumped in to save her, officials said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: A Standing U.N. Army Would Require Consent
description: To the Editor:

title: Parts of T.W.A. Fuel Tank Are Retrieved
description: As the waves and clouds of silt subsided yesterday over the crash site of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the flow of wreckage from the sea floor to investigators ashore resumed in earnest, including two pieces of the much-sought center fuel tank, crash investigators said.

title: Aid for Exporters
description: With Secretary of Commerce Mickey Kantor on hand, a new office was opened yesterday that is intended to help companies market and export their products abroad. The new District Export Assistance Center is at One Gateway Center, near Pennsylvania Station. A similar export office in Newark was relocated to Trenton about 12 years ago.

title: Johnson Hits 200th; Wilson In a Groove
description: They provide a maddening contrast to this strange Mets season. Lance Johnson has been a model of consistency all year, churning out hits to the point where he reached a coveted milestone last night by collecting his 200th of the season. Then there is pitcher Paul Wilson, whose rookie year has been foiled by numerous bad outings and poor performances.

title: Executive Promoted At Ammirati Puris
description: Helayne Spivak, vice chairwoman and chief creative officer at the New York office of Ammirati Puris Lintas, is being promoted, effective next month, to worldwide creative director for multinational accounts.

title: G.O.P. Goes to Harlem
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Hostage Wants U.S. Warnings About Dangers in Ecuador
description: John Heidema, a New Jersey computer scientist, was vacationing in Ecuador in late July with his 18-year-old daughter, Sarah, when he was taken hostage by a group of armed bandits during a hiking trip through the jungle.

title: Welfare as Japan Knows It: A Family Affair
description: Genially welcoming a visitor into his ''home,'' the piece of cardboard on which he sleeps in the Shinjuku train station here, Katsuo Kawagoe drew deeply on a cigarette and recalled the times he had applied for public assistance from the Government.

title: A Prodigy Awaits Call From Above
description: THERE comes a point in a game, in a season, in life -- when the crush of circumstances forces coaches, fans and people to see things as they really are and not as they would like them to be.

title: Danka to Buy Part of Kodak Copier Unit for $684 Million
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and Danka Business Systems P.L.C. announced yesterday that Danka would acquire the sales, marketing and equipment service operations of Kodak's office copier business for $684 million in cash.

title: Love of Numbers Leads To Chromosome 17
description: IN the career of Dr. Eric Steven Lander, as in the new branch of biology known as genomics, the life of numbers and the numbers in life have come together.

title: Judge Upholds Charges in Oklahoma Bombing
description: A Federal judge in Denver yesterday upheld the indictments against Timothy J. McVeigh and Terry L. Nichols, which charged them with conspiracy to use ''a weapon of mass destruction'' in the bombing of the Federal building in Oklahoma City.

title: Designers Discover Small Is Beautiful
description: If Robert Danes sells 10 dresses a month when he opens his Broome Street boutique, he'll have made his rent, paid the help and covered production. After that, as the saying goes, it's all gravy.

title: What Does a Coach Do After His Team Starts 0-2?
description: Rich Kotite wasn't sitting in his office today brooding about his 0-2 Jets, his 3-15 record as their head coach or the nasty way they lost still another game on Sunday.

title: Familiar Faces Marooned in a Familiar Format
description: Twenty minutes into Sunday night's Emmy Awards show, viewers saw a clip from one of the season's best episodes of ''Frasier,'' in which the lovelorn Dr. Niles Crane and Daphne, the woman he longs for, did a slick, stylish tango. Then the actors who portray them showed up on the Emmy stage and danced their way to the podium.

title: Tyson Fights Are No Bargain on Pay-Per-Second
description: For a pay-per-view fight to be worth $45, it should last longer than a boxer's walk to the ring. Saturday's Mike Tyson-Bruce Seldon bout failed the viewer value test. Tyson needed 2 minutes 5 seconds to walk in, Seldon 2:37. The fight lasted 1:49. More measures of bad value: the one-named singer Desi's national anthem required 2:20. The ring announcer Jimmy Lennon Jr.'s introductions needed 1:52.

title: Are Lightning Balls Spheres of Plasma?
description: AT least since the time of the ancient Greeks, people have been startled from time to time by ethereal globes of light that appear from nowhere, float through the air for a second or two and then disappear abruptly, sometimes with a pop. Nearly all lightning experts agree that these objects, known as ball lightning, are real. But no one knows what they are.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Aug. 30 with a review of the Gin Blossoms band misidentified the musician standing next to the singer Robin Wilson at Webster Hall in the East Village. He was the bass player Bill Leen, not the guitarist Scott Johnson.

title: Gephardt Takes Off Gloves For Iowa House Candidates
description: On a hot, hazy morning at a community center here, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, is giving 30 elderly Iowans his chilling rendition of what will happen to their Medicare insurance if the Republicans keep control of Congress this November.

title: Pepsico Is Set Back On Coke Sanctions
description: Pepsico Inc. has been denied its request for additional sanctions against its former bottler and the Coca-Cola Company by Venezuela's Antimonopoly Commission.

title: Cost Studies Skew Focus of Airline Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Friends Are Not Surprised Man Jumped to Stop a Suicide
description: Strange as it seems, it would have surprised most people who know Daniel J. Santos if he had not jumped off the Tappan Zee Bridge to save a despondent woman who tried to commit suicide during rush hour on Monday.

title: Judge Blocks Rail Link
description: New Jersey Transit's plan to run a commuter rail link through a historic, predominantly black neighborhood has been blocked by a Federal judge. The judge, William G. Bassler, ruled in Newark on Monday that New Jersey Transit had not provided enough evidence that the proposed route of the Montclair Connection, which would displace two dozen families, was the best one. The link would give commuters on two lines direct rail service to Manhattan. Montclair had claimed that the route violated Federal preservation and civil rights laws. Ken Miller, a spokesman for the agency, said it would produce a more detailed analysis of its decision.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Pressure Spot at Fox
description: When Peter Roth becomes Fox network's chief of entertainment programming next week, he'll be taking over a job that hasn't had much longevity.

title: Drug Clinics Laud Alternative to Methadone
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: John W. Glascott was named senior vice president for corporate marketing and sales at the Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corp., New York. He succeeds Mark Goldschmidt, who moves to the new position of senior vice president for advertising and marketing at Hearst Magazines International. Mr. Glascott had been a partner at Meigher Communications, New York, and publisher at Smart Health, a Meigher custom publishing unit.

title: New Study Data Add to Concerns About Calcium Channel Blockers
description: UNEXPECTED findings from a new study being reported today add to concerns about possible dangers of calcium channel blockers, the most widely prescribed class of medications in this country.

title: Here to Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: At Rosh ha-Shanah, Poignant Memories of Holidays Past
description: ROSH HA-SHANAH, the Jewish New Year, which begins Friday evening, is a time for prayer and reflection, and for the familiar aromas of traditional recipes. This year, the holiday's poignancy and sense of history are enhanced with the publication of ''In Memory's Kitchen: A Legacy From the Women of Terezin.''

title: Olympic Star to Retire
description: FU MINGXIA, the Chinese diver who at age 17 captured two gold medals for China at the Atlanta Olympics, said in yesterday's editions of The China Youth Daily that she wanted to end her athletic career and enroll in college.

title: How's the Jets' Lowery? Well, He Can't Kick
description: How long can Nick Lowery wait?

title: Guns That Kill and Art That Hurts
description: This is not art that pleases the eye, here in this tiny gallery on Magazine Street. It is art that takes aim between the eyes, and drills deep inside.

title: Renault Says Earnings Sank 89% in First Half
description: Renault S.A., the second-largest French automobile maker, said yesterday that its first-half net income plunged 89 percent, to 158 million francs ($31.6 million), as results were hurt by poor car sales and lower margins. In the corresponding period last year, Renault posted a profit of 1.75 billion francs. The company had an operating loss of 225 million francs in the first half, compared with an operating profit of 1.52 billion francs a year earlier.

title: Fairfield Team Cooked From Scratch
description: It was one of the worst blizzards to hit the Northeast, but to the new Fairfield University football coach, Kevin Kiesel, the storm that hit early last January was an unexpected recruiting tool.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. Presents Offer In Labor Negotiations

title: UNION PACIFIC TO ISSUE STOCK FOR SOUTHERN PACIFIC
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that holders of more than 60 percent of the shares of the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation elected to receive stock in Union Pacific's $5.4 billion acquisition of Southern Pacific. The railroad company said that as a result, all Southern Pacific shareholders who elected to receive stock would receive Union Pacific shares and cash according to a proration formula that will be determined by Friday. Those Southern Pacific shareholders who did not submit their choices or shares on a timely basis before Monday's deadline will receive $25.

title: Jones Scores A Knockout
description: Junior Jones of Brooklyn, the former World Boxing Association bantamweight champion, showed no sign of a damaged right hand last night, using it to pummel Tommy Parks for five rounds en route to a victory by knockout in their featherweight battle at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan.

title: Pulsipher Going Home Early
description: Bill Pulsipher will attend his final Mets game of the season this afternoon when New York plays the Marlins at Shea Stadium. Tomorrow, Pulsipher will travel to his off-season home in Port St. Lucie, Fla., to avoid the temptation that led to the recent recurrence of soreness in his surgically repaired left elbow.

title: Corporations are spending travel dollars cautiously these days.
description: AFTER the usual summer slowdown, business travelers will soon be back in force at airports, hotels and rental-car offices -- but apparently not in the record numbers that have marked business and leisure travel throughout 1996. Business travel this fall is projected to drop to its lowest level in at least five years, according to a forecast from the Travel Industry Association of America, based on a telephone survey of 1,500 adults in the United States.

title: Dole and Caesar
description: To the Editor:

title: Nothing Says Kosher Like Chicken Livers in the Tandoor
description: GLATT kosher tandoori chicken livers have come to Forest Hills, Queens. They are just one among dozens of kosher dishes now served at Bombay Kitchen.

title: Woman Betrayed by Loved Ones Mourns a Double Loss
description: Just around the corner from the Kassindja family compound lives another young woman who ran away from home -- but too late to escape having her genitals sliced off against her will.

title: MetroStars Win, but May Lose Their Coach
description: The MetroStars are in danger of losing Coach Carlos Queiroz.

title: Ex-Officer at Zenith Joins On-line Group
description: J. William Grimes, who announced a week ago that he would leave Zenith Media Worldwide, the media services unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York, has joined the Netcast Communications Corporation in New York in the new position of chairman. At Netcast, an on-line entertainment network, Mr. Grimes, 55, will be responsible for strategic planning and partnerships; Jim Butterworth, president and chief executive, continues to oversee day-to-day operations. Mr. Grimes left Zenith, where he had been president and chief executive of United States operations, after his two-year contract expired.

title: Israeli Prime Minister Pays Visit, and a Political Debt
description: The new Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, paid back a crucial political debt in New York City yesterday when he visited the grave of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the Lubavitch leader whose followers in Israel worked diligently toward Mr. Netanyahu's narrow victory in late May.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP., Madison, N.J., the drug maker, plans to sell 10 nonprescription products with total yearly sales of about $25 million to closely held Medtech Products Inc. of Jackson Hole, Wyo., for an undisclosed amount.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GISELE MASSON, the ailing founder of La Grenouille restaurant, has filed a $2.2 million lawsuit to stop the management of her cooperative apartment building from evicting her because of her two dogs, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Legal Graffiti? The Police Voice Dissent
description: VERNON BELTRAN likes seeing his alias, OVIE/KD, emblazoned in ''wild style'' on walls. He's a graffiti artist, so he sometimes sees his real name in unintended places, like a rap sheet. In his medium, the portrait of the artist as a young man is often rendered in mug shots.

title: Russian Power Shift For Yeltsin's Surgery
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, preparing for his heart surgery, formally handed over authority for national security and law enforcement to his Prime Minister. Mr. Yeltsin will still keep control of the nuclear button.

title: Fearful Kurds Huddle at Iran's Closed Door
description: Within sight of a poster of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Paiman Mohammed gritted her teeth this afternoon against the blowing dust and the plight that had brought her back to Iraq's border with Iran.

title: Executive Changes
description: EDMARK CORP., Redmond, Wash., a maker of educational multimedia software, said its chairman and chief executive, Sally Narodick, had resigned because of stress-related health problems. Donna Stanger, vice president for product development, will assume the chief executive's duties on an interim basis.

title: Scrappy Mets Survive Only to Fall in the 12th
description: It seemed like a sentence to death row for the Mets. As if their season wasn't going bad enough, they had the rotten luck of facing a virtual Dream Team of National League pitchers during a four-game span. John Smoltz on Saturday, Greg Maddux on Sunday, Kevin Brown on Monday and Al Leiter last night.

title: In Mr. Yeltsin's Absence
description: After all the dodging and deception about Boris Yeltsin's health, it is refreshing to get some candor from the Russian leader. He announced last week that he needs heart surgery and plans an operation later this month. Yesterday Mr. Yeltsin applied some of the same openness and decisiveness to the question of how Russia will be ruled in his absence, whether that turns out to be a brief or extended period. But too much still remains unclear.

title: Green Cross of Japan Settles AIDS Lawsuits
description: The Green Cross Corporation of Japan said yesterday that it would pay 1.3 billion yen ($11 million) in 109 lawsuits settled between Aug. 10 and Sept. 3 over blood products tainted with the AIDS-causing virus. The company, Japan's largest maker of blood plasma products, said it hoped to settle 52 more lawsuits by paying a total of 700 million yen for the same period.

title: Yeltsin, Preparing for Surgery, Yields Authority to Premier
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin, on vacation and resting up for heart surgery, formally handed over authority today for national security and law enforcement to his Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.

title: San Francisco Opera Turns an Unsuitable Hall Into a Creative Opportunity
description: The most unsettling aftershock of this city's 1989 earthquake struck the ebullient general director of the San Francisco Opera, Lotfi Mansouri, about two years after the first tremor, at a meeting of the company's board.

title: Heinz's Reorganization Plans Follow Slight Earnings Gains
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that it would sell businesses in the United States and abroad as part of a plan to jettison flagging operations and reduce debt.

title: Gas Tax Could Help Our Cities
description: A decade ago, in response to the abysmal state of New York City's public school buildings, the Municipal Assistance Corporation, with the support of Mayor Edward I. Koch and Gov. Mario Cuomo, committed $400 million of its surplus funds to creating a new School Construction Authority. This became the cornerstone of a five-year, $4.5 billion construction program aimed at providing decent schools and allowing for increasing enrollments over the next few years.

title: Correction
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter published on Monday from Ivan Z. Misic, deputy permanent representative of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the United Nations, misstated the position of President Alija Izetbegovic on the return of displaced and expelled people to their homes in that country. The sentence should have read: ''If Mr. Izetbegovic agreed not to allow the expelled to return to their homes, he would in fact accept the division of Bosnia and Herzegovina along ethnic lines.'' (It did not say ''agreed now.'')

title: George B. Mead, 94, Conductor, Organist And a Translator
description: George B. Mead, a conductor, composer and opera translator who was the organist and choirmaster at Trinity Church for 27 years and was associated with several churches, schools and choral groups in New York City, died on Sept. 2 at the Andover Nursing Center in Andover, N.J. He was 94 and lived in Brooklyn Heights and Stillwater, N.J.

title: Nibbling Beneath the Harvest Moon
description: THE farmers at the Union Square Greenmarket usually pack up their produce trucks by late afternoon.

title: Stalling on Ethics
description: Crowning two years of partisan gridlock, the House Ethics Committee seems determined to sacrifice whatever little is left of its credibility by letting Congress adjourn without resolving any of the pending ethics complaints against Speaker Newt Gingrich. The committee's present plans do not even call for making public the lengthy report filed last month by James Cole, the special counsel belatedly hired by the committee to look into tax law charges against the Speaker.

title: On-the-Job Training Tough for Giant Rookie
description: Cedric Jones was so highly prized in April's National Football League draft that a noted connoisseur of defensive players, Coach Bill Parcells of the New England Patriots, tried desperately to trade up to get him.

title: Campbell Soup Sets Terms for Buyback
description: The Campbell Soup Company set a price range of $69 to $80 a share today for its ''Dutch auction,'' which starts on Thursday.

title: Kemp Lines Up Solidly Behind Netanyahu
description: Speaking for the Republican Presidential ticket and drawing stark parallels to the Clinton Administration, Jack Kemp pledged nearly carte blanche support last night for the policies of Israel's new Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Saratoga Backstretch
description: To the Editor:

title: Editor of Village Voice Resigns
description: Karen Durbin, who became editor in chief of The Village Voice two and a half years ago, vowing to rescue it from its midlife crisis, announced yesterday that she was resigning over differences with its publisher.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER BEARD, the fashion and wildlife photographer, was seriously injured on Monday, when an elephant charged and trampled him while he was on safari in Kenya.

title: Clinton and Dole Accept Plan For Campaign Time on Fox TV
description: President Clinton and Bob Dole have said they would participate in the Fox television network's plan to broadcast 10 one-minute campaign statements from the major Presidential candidates, in prime time, in the weeks leading up to the election. Fox has decided to go ahead with that plan regardless of what the other networks decide to do.

title: Arthur Leff, 88, Agency Judge Who Ruled in Labor Disputes
description: Arthur Leff, who rendered some of the first interpretations of the National Labor Relations Act and the Taft-Hartley law as an administrative law judge for the National Labor Relations Board, died on Sunday at the Medbridge-Wheaton Nursing Home in Wheaton, Md., a suburb of Washington. He was 88.

title: Food Notes
description: Variety for Rosh ha-Shanah

title: Flatley Begins His Ranger Metamorphosis
description: For 13 seasons, Patrick Flatley was an Islander mainstay. Toward the end, some might say he was the Islanders. In all that time, from his rookie season through his maturation into a respected veteran, Flatley was conditioned to despise the sight of a Rangers uniform.

title: Packers Aiming to Get Stronger One Opponent at a Time
description: They were billed during the preseason as a serious Super Bowl contender, another team that was finally on a par with the San Francisco 49ers and the Dallas Cowboys. Now that the Green Bay Packers have completely dismantled two opponents in the first two weeks of the National Football League season, it might be time to start believing the hype.

title: A Watershed Agreement
description: The formal agreement announced yesterday to clean up the 2,000-square-mile watershed that supplies New York City with its drinking water is a triumph of good sense over seemingly insurmountable grievances. The agreement ends years of upstate-downstate hostility, and if all goes well it will spare the city the need to build a $6 billion filtration system it can ill afford.

title: Reject Perot Comment About Puerto Rico
description: To the Editor:

title: Yzerman's Overtime Goal Hands the Americans Their First Loss
description: The Canadians were offside, United States Coach Ron Wilson said, and their winning goal should not have counted. Mike Richter, the American goalie, said he saw the shot and played it well but the puck bounced off his arm and over the goal line.

title: Big Canadian Merger Plan For Developer
description: Two years after rescuing the Trizec Corporation Ltd., one of North America's largest real estate companies, from bankruptcy, the Toronto-based Horsham Corporation announced today that it planned to merge with Trizec.

title: Olivetti Shares Off Again As Regulators Seek Data
description: The shares of Olivetti S.p.A. fell 6 percent yesterday after falling 20 percent on Monday, as Italian regulators asked the company to elaborate on its first-half results. After the market closed on Monday, the regulatory agency Consob said Olivetti must provide the additional information. Managers of the money-losing computer and office products company will be questioned by the end of the week. Olivetti's shares closed down 35 lire, at 568, a record low.

title: WAL-MART EXPECTS $464 MILLION FROM SALE OF PLANTS
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that it expected about $464 million from its sale of six photo-finishing plants to Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. and a long-term agreement the companies reached. Wal-Mart expects the sale, first announced July 8, to close in its current fiscal quarter, the company said in a quarterly report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The world's largest retailer did not say previously how much money it expected from the sale. Analysts estimated at the time that Wal-Mart could realize $200 million from the sale.

title: Sweet Send-Off for Summer's Harvest
description: As the season of the very best tomatoes and the sweetest corn winds down, it is time to make the most of them. This recipe calls for pork, but if you prefer, substitute an equal amount of boneless, skinless chicken breast.

title: For 3d Time in 21 Years, Saddam Hussein's Foes Pay Price for a Foiled U.S. Plot
description: For the third time in a generation, a C.I.A. program aimed against Iraq has sent the enemies of Saddam Hussein to prison or the grave.

title: Amstrad of Britain Posts A Loss for the Year
description: Amstrad P.L.C., a British technology company, said yesterday that deteriorating trade conditions and revamping charges contributed to a pretax loss of $:14.9 million ($23.2 million) for the year ended June 30.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: High-tech features bring a turnaround to a downtown building, after five vacant years.
description: A LITTLE more than a year after the Rudin Management Company began spending $15 million to renovate a vacant 400,000-square-foot office building at 55 Broad Street, installing the latest telecommunications equipment, more than 60 percent of the downtown building, now known as the New York Information Technology Center, is spoken for.

title: Gooden's Arm May Be 'Dead,' but Yankees Aren't
description: Dwight Gooden stood as rigid as a pole outside the Tiger Stadium clubhouse with a helpless look on his face and a confused tone to his voice. Gooden conceded he had no answers for his chronic self-destruction, wondered about his tenuous future in the rotation and even compared himself to Fred Flintstone. Fred Flintstone?

title: How to Define a Genre: Any Way You Dare
description: Just as the Minimalists of the 1970's gradually formed a wall against the previous generation, the downtown experimental composers of today are casting about for their own defining esthetic. At the moment, they're finding one direction in turntables and samplers. At the Ohio Theater on Saturday and Sunday, this tendency was on display in two all-day events called ''Swirled Music,'' with disk jockeys, video projections and several different schools of musicians, some of them visual artists on busman's holiday. It was more environment than concert: with the musicians organized against the side walls of the gallery, you could walk right through it.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: No Headline
description: ''People don't want to go too far on changing marriage and traditional relationships. But the feeling is when someone wants to work someplace, they ought to be able to get a job.''

title: U.N. Endorses a Treaty to Halt All Nuclear Testing
description: By a large majority, the General Assembly endorsed a treaty today that would end nuclear weapons testing, reviving hopes that a voluntary test ban now observed by most of the world's nuclear nations may become an international obligation.

title: Korea's Romeos and Juliets, Cursed by Their Name
description: It should be a time of celebration. K. H. Lee and his girlfriend have fallen in love and want to get married soon to start a new life together.

title: Personal Health
description: THE owner of a New Hampshire resort knew her dog did not like children. But she decided to ''introduce'' her pet to several cottagers under 12. Without so much as a warning growl, the dog lunged at an 11-year-old, Lindsey Flook, who then joined an estimated 4.7 million Americans -- mostly children -- who were bitten by a dog in 1994.

title: Nation's Capital Ponders A Broken School System
description: The problems of the District of Columbia's school system mirror those of Washington itself, which is struggling to overcome a fiscal crisis created by poor management and its dependence on Federal financing. And the school system is mired in investigations of poor management and potential mismanagement.

title: A Refugee's Body Is Intact but Her Family Is Torn
description: Hajia Zuwera Kassindja bowed her head to the patriarch of her dead husband's family on a recent steamy morning, her face a cryptic mask of sorrow. She had come to beg his forgiveness for having helped her daughter Fauziya run away to America to escape having her genitals cut off.

title: Don't Forget Electric Side of Fish Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGHER FUEL COSTS TO REDUCE AMERICAN AIRLINES EARNINGS
description: Robert L. Crandall, the chief executive of the AMR Corporation, said yesterday that higher costs for fuel and security would cut the third-quarter earnings of American Airlines. Mr. Crandall told analysts he expected costs to rise 4 percent in the three months ending Sept. 30, with about half of the increase from higher fuel prices. He said that flight cancellations in July and August stemming from a work slowdown by the pilots' union also added to costs. American reached a tentative agreement with its pilots last week. Mr. Crandall also said American, the main operating unit of AMR, which is based in Fort Worth, does not expect much growth in its domestic-flights business. Shares of AMR rose 75 cents, to $79.75.

title: Bond Prices Fall as Yield Hits 7.11%
description: Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday after comments by Federal Reserve officials led to heightened anxiety over how much the Fed is likely to increase rates.

title: Outside One Okinawa Base, a Less Raucous Atmosphere Now
description: If there is a conspicuous example of the changing relationship between Okinawans and the American military bases here, it is a graffiti-splotched concrete wall that stretches for more than a mile along the ocean's edge outside Kadena Air Base.

title: Mayor Says Businesses Offer to Aid in Plan to Use Parochial Schools
description: Private businesses have offered to pay the parochial-school tuition for hundreds of failing public-school students, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday, allowing the city to sidestep the legal prohibition against paying for religious education.

title: Perot Chooses An Economist For His Ticket
description: For the second time in four years, Ross Perot has chosen a political unknown -- this time, Pat Choate, a Washington-based economist and author -- as his running mate, preparing for what is emerging as a far more difficult bid for the Presidency than Mr. Perot's first race of 1992.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: A Restaurant Revival Takes Root in Harlem
description: ON a cool summer Saturday evening uptown, the well-dressed diners who were crowded into Londel's suspended their animated conversations each time a waitress emerged from the kitchen. They were hoping that she was bringing their order of sauteed spinach, spicy crab cakes or parsley-tinged red potatoes. The satisfying scene made the restaurant's owner, Londel C. Davis, a happy man.

title: The Real Piltdown Man Stands Up
description: UNRAVELING PILTDOWN

title: The Bessies, Somber and Merry
description: Antic comedy mingled with earnest idealism on Monday night when Dance Theater Workshop presented its 12th annual New York Dance and Performance Awards, the Bessies. The awards, presented at the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts in Manhattan, honored achievements in dance and performance art in the 1995-96 season.

title: School Financing Deadline
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday gave the Legislature and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman until the end of the year to come up with a school financing plan. Legislators have said for months that they would not be able to pass their version of the Governor's plan by the original Sept. 30 deadline. The state is under a court order to close the gap in financing between rich and poor school districts.

title: For Earnhardt, Shot at Title Is a Stretch
description: With seven races left in the Winston Cup season, Dale Earnhardt's chances of winning a record eighth championship do not seem bright. Besides nursing a broken collarbone and sternum, he is trying to recover from a 218-point deficit to the leader, Terry Labonte.

title: John L. Burns, 87, Former Head of Boys Club
description: John Lawrence Burns, the former chairman and chief volunteer officer of the Boys Clubs of America, died on Sunday at the Greenwich Woods Health Care Center in Greenwich, Conn. He was 87.

title: Did Soccer Set Example For Meadow?
description: ONE of these years it will all be a bad dream the hideous green carpet laid over concrete, the dizzying maze of lines and numbers painted on the field, the aches and pains and downright injuries attributed to the artificial turf.

title: Wealthy Ally for Dissidents in the Drug War
description: Across the country, the scattered dissidents who denounce the whole idea of a war on drugs have found an unexpected ally: George Soros, the currency-market Croesus who is known for donating hundreds of millions of dollars each year to shore up democracy in the former Soviet bloc.

title: Tax Money Flowing Again, California Pares Class Size
description: While overcrowding in classrooms has characterized the start of the school year across the country, California is bucking the trend by rushing to pare class size by next semester.

title: Ex-Reagan Economic Aide Criticizes Dole Plan to Cut Taxes
description: A major architect and defender of Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax cuts broke ranks with Republicans and warned today against the much smaller reductions proposed by Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee.

title: Fumes Sicken Plant Workers
description: A toxic reaction at a clothing dye plant sent one nauseated worker to the hospital, forced the evacuation of 30 others and shuttered homes and businesses in Nutley and neighboring Clifton for nearly four hours yesterday morning, officials said. A vat containing cyanuric chloride overheated at the Crompton and Knowles Dyeing Corporation, Nutley officials said, and water from a sprinkler mixed with the substance to produce cyanide and other fumes.

title: America's Olympic Alchemist
description: Olympic silver medalists often fade away. Matt Ghaffari won't. He is the unofficial Mayor of Olympic Land, the Greco-Roman wrestler with the shaved head who wept on the medal stand in Atlanta, a 6-foot-4-inch, 286-pound schmoozer and emotional charmer, a Junior Achievement acolyte, an Iranian-born American who spoke to the Republican national convention last month. But he won't let you touch his medal.

title: European Deal Would Limit Budget Deficits After Union
description: European Union monetary officials are edging closer to agreement on a deal limiting national budget deficits after monetary union, one of the biggest issues to be resolved before a single currency can be put into effect, the officials said today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Trade Bans Are Boomerangs, U.S. Companies Say
description: Corporate America is beginning to grumble. Allied Signal Inc. says the latest sanctions against Iran are costing it several million dollars a year in lost sales of aircraft parts. Caterpillar Inc. is circulating a map that spotlights countries where, it says, American sanctions throw up obstacles to the sale of Caterpillar's yellow tractors and earth-moving vehicles.

title: Camby Gets a Contract
description: MARCUS CAMBY has agreed to a three-year contract with the Toronto Raptors. Under terms of the N.B.A's rookie salary scale, Camby will make $8.4 million, including the allowable 20 percent increases over the base pay of just over $7 million. (AP)

title: 2 Fronts in Tobacco Battle
description: New Jersey became the 15th state to sue the tobacco industry yesterday, claiming it has cost the state millions of dollars to treat tobacco-related illnesses in poor residents. The suit, filed in Superior Court in Middlesex County, accuses the industry of misinformation and concealing the risks of smoking.

title: Applauding a Man of Movement in the Musical World
description: Cut loose reluctantly from its longtime moorings at the 92d Street Y, the New York Chamber Symphony makes its debut tonight as an independent orchestra with a 20th-anniversary tribute to its popular co-founder, Omus Hirshbein.

title: Economist With a Passion for Policy -- Pat Choate
description: Dr. Pat Choate, whom Ross Perot named yesterday to be his running mate, is more accustomed to being the behind-the-scenes adviser whose briefcase is crammed with position papers, whose Rolodex is crammed with important names and numbers and whose job it is to tutor V.I.P.'s on ideas. His ideas.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Roth Wins Surrogate's Race; DiCarlo Loses
description: Renee R. Roth, the Manhattan Surrogate, won her Democratic primary fight yesterday against Karen S. Burstein, a former family court judge who had drawn strong support in New York City in her failed bid two years ago to become State Attorney General.

title: Nets Sign Massenburg To a One-Year Deal
description: The Nets grabbed another player left out of the free-agency sweepstakes yesterday by signing TONY MASSENBURG to a one-year deal believed to be worth the National Basketball Association minimum of $247,000.

title: Consultants' Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Drafts Plan to Extend Its Mission in Bosnia by Two Years
description: Senior NATO officials, convinced that Bosnia will remain carved into ethnic enclaves for the foreseeable future, say they are drafting plans to prolong the NATO presence here by at least two years to prevent a resumption of fighting.

title: Roth Survives Burstein's Challenge in Surrogate Race
description: Renee R. Roth, the Manhattan surrogate who found herself facing an unusually high-profile challenge, won the Democratic primary yesterday. She defeated Karen S. Burstein, a former family court judge who drew strong support in New York City in her failed bid two years ago to become State Attorney General

title: Primary Voting in Brooklyn Disrupted by Lack of Machines
description: Voters who turned up for a bitterly contested primary in Brooklyn yesterday were turned away from scores of polling places, because election workers had failed to deliver the voting machines in time. The problem persisted into the afternoon in many neighborhoods, raising the prospect that the election would have to be held again.

title: The New Clinton Health Panel
description: President Clinton had a transparent political motive in announcing that he would appoint a commission to examine how well modern health-care plans treat patients. Florida, where he made the announcement, is full of elderly voters nervous about what health-care reforms mean for them. But whatever the President's motive, the commission is a constructive idea.

title: Talks Fortify Rumors Of Deal for Cerus Unit
description: The French holding company CGIPconfirmed yesterday that there had been contact between its chairman and Carlo de Benedetti, the head of Cerus S.A., fanning speculation of a deal to buy Cerus's stake in the auto parts maker Valeo. Valeo's stock, which was up sharply last week on the speculation, rose 3.9 percent yesterday in Paris.

title: Zell, in a Bid To Buy REIT, Says Managers Have a Conflict
description: Mobile-home parks have become the unlikely stage for the latest tussle over corporate governance, and the outcome could have a big impact on the stock price of many of the largest publicly traded real estate investment trusts.

title: ACKLANDS TO SELL ITS INDUSTRIAL SUPPLIES UNIT
description: Acklands Ltd. agreed yesterday to sell its industrial supplies division to W. W. Grainger Inc. for about $350 million (Canadian), or about $255 million (United States), in cash and stock. Acklands, a Toronto distributor of safety and automotive parts, expects to receive $155 million (Canadian) in cash, with the remainder in an as-yet-undetermined number of Grainger shares. Grainger, based in Chicago, distributes motors, power tools and other equipment.

title: Officer Kills Woman
description: A New Brunswick police officer shot and killed a woman yesterday when she bit his finger and reached for his gun as he tried to arrest her on a prostitution charge, prosecutors told The Associated Press. The woman, Carolyn Adams, 39, of New Brunswick, was killed when a bullet from the gun of Officer James Consalvo pierced her heart, said Robert W. Gluck, the Middlesex County Prosecutor.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Aug. 27 about the Urban Artworks program at the Pace Downtown Theater misspelled the surname of a composer of the score for Diane Vivona's ''Goldfish Variations.'' He is Michael Wiese, not Wiesse.

title: Japan's Machine Orders Surge in Sign of Recovery
description: Private industry machine orders, Japan's leading indicator of capital investment, surged 13.6 percent in July from June, flying in the face of concern that the economic recovery had stalled. Auto makers led all industries in the pace of capital spending, with investment soaring 75.2 percent. The auto makers increased production of recreational vehicles and new passenger car models for release this month, the Economic Planning Agency said.

title: Papers Show Party Leaders Pressed Vacco On Hiring
description: On repeated occasions last year, State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco hired lawyers for his staff whose resumes had been forwarded to him by top Republican Party officials and who, in some cases, were considered only marginally qualified by his own aides, documents filed in civil suits against Mr. Vacco show.

title: Time Warp to the 50's, In Playing and Program
description: It may be early in the school year for a conservatory orchestra to test its mettle in public, but the faculty of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia apparently has great confidence in its students, and on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, the school's chamber orchestra showed that this confidence is not misplaced. Conducted by Mischa Santora, a 24-year-old Curtis student who has won several international prizes, the ensemble gave robust and remarkably warm-toned performances of works by Mozart, Tartini, Dvorak and Matthias Truniger.

title: Iraq Repairing Air-Defense Sites Hit by Missiles, Pentagon Says
description: The Pentagon said today that Iraq had defied the United States by continuing to repair air-defense sites damaged in American missile attacks on southern Iraq and threatened another strike to knock out the sites once and for all.

title: Problem in Brooklyn Clouds Primary Vote
description: Would-be voters in yesterday's primary were turned away from scores of polling places in Brooklyn because voting machines were delivered too late, raising the prospect that the results would be challenged.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about ethics charges filed against two senior Republicans in Congress, Representatives Tom Delay and Bud Shuster, misstated the home state of Thomas M. Barrett, a Democratwho brought the complaint. He is from Wisconsin.

title: Out of the Rat Race and Into the Kitchen
description: AS a foreign equity trader at a Wall Street firm, Laurie Bloom often worked until 4 A.M. in the international markets. Today, as an apprentice at the Ryland Inn, an acclaimed restaurant in Whitehouse, N.J., she is learning how to cut onions.

title: Jailing of Clinton's Ex-Partner Stalls Case Involving Zubin Mehta
description: The decision to send Susan McDougal to jail for refusing to testify about her former Whitewater partner, Bill Clinton, has added new complications to a separate case in which Mrs. McDougal has been accused by California authorities of stealing more than $150,000 from the conductor Zubin Mehta and his wife, Nancy.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend on Friday about the MTV Video Music Awards misidentified the member of the rock group Van Halen who is to have a hip replacement. He is Eddie Van Halen, not David Lee Roth.

title: Ratings Victory for ABC
description: Riding some increases for ''Monday Night Football'' and the Emmy Awards, ABC managed to win overall in the weekly ratings competition, and it was the first time the network had won among the 18-to-49-year-old audience, most prized by advertisers, in more than 40 weeks.

title: Hit Man With a Heart
description: The form letters Kevin Higgins sent to Michael J. Berthelot and 10 other corporate executives had the hyperbolic ring of a junk mail solicitation: ''I have some very valuable information that will save your life.'' Mr. Higgins's offer was different, though. He told Mr. Berthelot, chief executive of Trans Technology Corporation in Liberty Corner, that he had been offered $10,000 to kill him but was willing to spare him for $2,500. Mr. Higgins admitted in Federal court yesterday that the letters had been a hoax, and a failed one: no one sent money to the address on the letter, a Maryland prison where Mr. Higgins is serving 35 years for robbery, rape and assault. He faces five more years on yesterday's fraud plea. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Colombia Vice President Announces Resignation
description: Colombia's Vice President, Humberto de la Calle, announced today that he would resign and repeated his previous calls for President Ernesto Samper, who has been accused of taking drug money for his campaign, to do likewise.

title: Campaign Finance
description: To the Editor:

title: The World Gets Even Smaller for the Agency Business
description: Two European agency companies, one based in France and the other in Britain, are expanding further in North America in separate deals that exemplify the growing globalization of the advertising industry.

title: Wine Talk
description: WINE prices have been rising for several years. Shortages of fine grapes, a succession of poor harvests in Europe, vineyard diseases in California and a steadily increasing demand for fine wine have all combined to put unusual pressure on costs and, of course, to drive them up.

title: An Asthma Link to Women's Cycle
description: SOME women with asthma find that they seem more likely to have attacks around the time that their menstrual periods begin. But even though the possibility of such a link was first reported in a medical journal in 1931, it has never been proved or studied extensively.

title: Hong Kong Ends Impasse on Port
description: Hong Kong port companies have broken a deadlock over expanding the British colony's container port and will present their plan to the next meeting of a Chinese-British panel, a Hong Kong Government official said today.

title: For R.E.M., Adventures On the Run
description: For most of its 16-year career, R.E.M. has been a band in transition. Each album has chronicled the changing interests, attitudes and moods of the Georgia group as it cut its own path through the brambles of music, with an ever-growing audience watching it take the easy routes and the hard ones, the shortcuts and the circuitous paths. R.E.M.'s 12th album, ''New Adventures in Hi-Fi,'' released yesterday on Warner Brothers, captures R.E.M. in a transformation significant even for a band constantly in flux.

title: All Six Friends Are Back
description: Nobody has agreed to sign new contracts yet, but NBC's hit comedy ''Friends'' will begin its new season as scheduled a week from Thursday with all six of its stars intact.

title: Bronx Officer Is to Request Nonjury Trial In Strangling
description: A Bronx police officer accused in the choking death of a man during a confrontation over an impromptu football game will go to trial today, and he is expected to make an unusual request: he will waive his right to a jury trial and ask the judge to decide his future.

title: Rethinking Iran Policy
description: This is a true story. I was checking in at Dulles Airport for a KLM flight. The airport was packed; security was tight. Two agents were operating the X-ray machine, others were hand-searching suitcases before they were loaded onto the conveyer belt for the plane. A bevy of other security people milled around. As I went over my ticket with the counter agent I took my eye off my suitcase. When I went to hand it to the agent, it was gone. A man standing in line behind me said he saw another passenger put it through the X-ray machine with his wife's luggage and the security men mistakenly loaded it on the conveyor belt for the flight -- even though it had no destination tag and had not been hand-searched as required. And guess where I was going? On the KLM connection to Iran! I was going to TEHERAN, IRAN, and security agents let some yo-yo load my suitcase without a tag or a search. On top of that, I look like Ramzi Yousef's twin brother!

title: U.S. Control in Camden
description: Amid mounting criticism of Camden's government, a committee headed by the Secretary for Housing and Urban Development, Henry G. Cisneros, took control yesterday of all Federal housing funds spent there. The committee, which also includes local officials, will oversee the spending of more than $83 million. Mr. Cisneros said it was the first time that control of all HUD money had been removed from a local government. Recent HUD reports criticized Camden's use of Federal housing funds. Camden is also one of six cities nationwide selected for Federal grants as urban ''empowerment zones,'' but has lagged in implementing its program.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Artist Transforms Bleak Bridge Walk Into Urban Dream
description: When Chris Doyle wiped his forehead in the noon sunshine yesterday, the flecks of gold leaf on his fingers sparkled like glitter. Beneath his feet, the corroded pedestrian stairway on the Manhattan side of the Williamsburg Bridge gleamed, with the fruit of his labor, like the vault at Fort Knox. A steady stream of pedestrians, many carrying bicycles over their shoulders, made their way up or down, most of them visibly nonplused to be walking a gilded ladder.

title: Iran Will Get Moderate Leader, but Not a Mullah
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Talks of Welfare and Family Leave
description: President Clinton brought his campaign caravan to the Show Me State today to show off an experimental program that helps former welfare recipients move into work and to defend the Federal law that lets families take time off from work for medical emergencies.

title: HURRICANE SLAMS INTO PUERTO RICO
description: What began as an on-again, off-again tropical storm that would skirt Puerto Rico today turned into a full-force hurricane that pelted the island with up to 18 inches of rain leaving eight people dead and four missing.

title: Moss/Dragoti Quits Quincy's Account
description: Moss/Dragoti in New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, said yesterday that it had resigned the broadcast creative account of Quincy's Family Steakhouse, which the agency had handled for only a year. As a result, the account, with billings estimated at $8 million, will be placed in review.

title: Agent Is Arrested
description: LEIGH STEINBERG, the sports agent who recently added the Olympic gymnast KERRI STRUG to his star-studded client list, was arrested over the weekend for investigation of driving under the influence of alcohol, the Newport Beach, Calif., police said yesterday.

title: Separating Gay and 'Transgender' Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Searching for Way to Heal
description: You won't find the rap song ''My Homie Red'' on any top 20 charts. But the University of Miami Hurricane football team can't hear enough of it. The players play it on the bus en route to a game, as they are warming up, during the game and in the locker room afterward.

title: TEXTRON SELECTS AT&T UNIT FOR COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM
description: The AT&T Corporation has beat out British Telecommunications P.L.C. for a $1.1 billion, 10-year contract from Textron Inc. to upgrade its communications system worldwide. Textron, the maker of Bell Helicopters, E-Z-GO golf carts and Cessna planes, hired the AT&T Solutions unit to link the company's 25 divisions through phones and computers. It is the first so-called network outsourcing contract of more than $1 billion, the companies said. Textron expects to save more than $125 million over 10 years by using AT&T to run the system.

title: Abortion-Rights Stance Helps Incumbent Win in Primary Battle for Congress
description: Representative Sue Kelly, a freshman, survived a serious challenge yesterday in the Republican primary, which usually decides the election in the 19th Congressional District.

title: When Space Seemed A Whole Lot Bigger
description: Doomsday predictions have been dogging ''Star Trek'' ever since it made its debut on NBC in September 1966. There are an awful lot of ''Trek'' detractors who found themselves fending off a diagnosis of what a typical script would call ''severe neural damage.'' But now, at 30 years, the extraordinary ''Star Trek'' franchise seems to have entered an unmistakable fizzle quadrant. Tonight's episode of ''Star Trek: Voyager'' (at 9 on UPN, Channel 9 in New York) is but the latest piece of evidence.

title: Dole Campaign Says It Has Hardly Begun to Fight as Clinton Storms the Airwaves
description: The broadcast advertising war between the two major Presidential campaigns is looking more and more lopsided.

title: Pataki Puts Off Calling Session on Welfare Law
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would wait until after the November elections to call a special session of the Legislature to deal with the impact of the new Federal welfare law on New York's programs for the poor.

title: 2 Companies Plan to Merge Gas and Electric Marketing
description: The Coastal Corporation and Westcoast Energy Inc. said yesterday that they would combine their natural gas and electricity marketing operations, joining the industry trend toward consolidation.

title: No Winning Design for Prado
description: An international architectural competition has failed to solve the riddle of how to expand the Prado Museum.

title: Lee Gannon, 36, A Composer Inspired By His Own Struggle
description: Lee Gannon, a prize-winning composer who wrote in an accessible, eclectic style, died on Sept. 2 in Nashville, where he lived. He was 36.

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Supports Test Ban

title: Germans Sentence Six Generals in Border Killings
description: Six onetime East German generals were sentenced to prison today for ordering the shooting of fugitives across the Berlin wall and the former border between East and West Germany.

title: France Says Economy Failed to Add Jobs
description: French companies shed 2,200 jobs in the second quarter as layoffs in construction and manufacturing outstripped job growth in services, the national statistics office said yesterday, revising its August estimate. Overall payrolls were little changed at 14.66 million jobs. It was the third quarter in a row that a sluggish economy failed to add jobs.

title: Not Perfect, but Right
description: This Saturday, the people of Bosnia will go to the polls to elect their national representatives. These elections are an essential step in bringing democracy to Bosnia. They are what the people want, and what Bosnia needs, to help its hard-won peace endure.

title: Galindo Turns Pro
description: RUDY GALINDO, who stunned the figure skating world by winning the United States championship in January, turned pro yesterday.

title: Missile Was Not Threat
description: A missile spotted by the pilot of an American Airlines 757 late last month was flying in its authorized area and did not pose a threat to the plane, a preliminary investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board has found, according to a spokesman, Peter Goelz.

title: SENATORS REJECT BOTH JOB-BIAS BAN AND GAY MARRIAGE
description: The Senate voted overwhelming today to deny Federal benefits to married people of the same sex and to permit states to ignore such marriages sanctioned in other states. The bill now goes to the White House for President Clinton's promised signature.

title: Excerpt From Writings of Nominee
description: Following is an excerpt from a 1990 article by Pat Choate in the Harvard Business Review. The article was based on Dr. Choate's book, ''Agents of Influence'' (Knopf, 1990).

title: G.M. Makes Offer to Union as Ford and Chrysler Continue Talks
description: The General Motors Corporation made its first comprehensive contract offer to the United Automobile Workers today, as national labor contract negotiations continued at all three Detroit auto makers.

title: Roenick Seeks a Trade
description: The Phoenix Coyotes are confident that they will sign center JEREMY ROENICK, although his agent, NEIL ABBOTT, is pushing for a trade. Roenick, acquired in an Aug. 16 trade with Chicago, is reportedly seeking a five-year contract worth $4.5 million to $6 million a season. (AP)

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the theft of rare manuscripts from a monastery in Spain misattributed one estimate of their value. While Lieut. Pedro Pizarro of the Civil Guard said they could be worth at least $160,000, it was Jose Luis Sotoca, a rare-book expert at a Madrid auction house -- not the lieutenant -- who said the lot might sell for $11,000.

title: Kinnear: To the Big Screen
description: Greg Kinnear, who at one time was supposed to be the threat to Conan O'Brien on NBC's late-night lineup, is leaving his NBC show ''Later'' for the movies.
