title: The Winner Says He'd Play His Baghdad Card Again
description: As his forces roared through this city and beyond in a jubilant parade, the faction leader who now controls the Kurdish region of northern Iraq said today that he wanted the protected zone to become ''a castle of freedom and democracy.''

title: A Youthful Hall of Famer Says He's Just Begun to Sail
description: The reaction by Russell Coutts to his induction into the America's Cup Hall of Fame hints at the unusual nature of that invitation. Given that he is 34 and still at the prime of his profession, Coutts is both delighted and somewhat puzzled at being selected so young.

title: Watershed Protection Agreement Is Praised
description: Federal officials yesterday strongly endorsed a comprehensive water-protection agreement reached by New York City, the state, and dozens of communities ringing the city's upstate reservoirs, saying the agreement would put off until at least 2002 a threatened Federal order to build a multibillion-dollar filtration plant.

title: Dole Is Moving To Add Spark To Campaign
description: Bob Dole moved on three fronts today to reignite his campaign, scheduling a meeting to pacify Congressional Republicans who are fearful of losing their majority, trying new ways to present his economic message and enlisting Colin L. Powell in a new push on the character issue.

title: The Sound of Whitewater Silence:A Deep Legal Puzzle
description: WASHINGTON  The determined stance of Susan McDougal, a former business partner of Bill Clinton's, to go to jail rather than testify about his role in the Whitewater case, has puzzled legal experts and analysts.

title: Separating Gay and 'Transgender' Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Bad Chapter Is Added to a Storybook Comeback
description: In the late 70's, early in George Steinbrenner's regime, the owner summoned a reporter to his office at Yankee Stadium during a game with Kansas City and said, ''Ask me about Ken Clay.''

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Eating Well
description: THE San Francisco Bay area has long been known for its stylish cooking.

title: People
description: Lori Burgess, associate publisher at Seventeen magazine, New York, which is owned by the K-III Communications Corp., was promoted to publisher, succeeding Janice Grossman, who was promoted in January to president for advertising and marketing for K-III Consumer Magazines.

title: Dole Visits Connecticut, Despite Gap in Polls
description: In a sign that Republicans think that Connecticut could still go either way in the Presidential election, Bob Dole today paid his fourth visit to the state in a year and hammered away at the issues of tax cuts and character.

title: As Dole Trails, G.O.P. Turnout Becomes Concern
description: For the first time in 40 years, the contests to control the Senate and the House are in more doubt than the Presidential election. Republicans, while positioned to retain control of both houses, are in greater danger of losing them than President Clinton is of losing the White House.

title: When Discrimination Fastens on a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: In T.W.A. Crash Inquiry, Caution Is Byword for Investigators and Their Findings
description: Since the night Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded in midair, Federal law enforcement investigators have pursued a strong hunch that the Boeing 747 was destroyed by a vicious criminal act, most likely a bomb. And in the seven weeks since the crash, which killed 230 people, none of the evidence uncovered has shaken that belief.

title: Price Is Lowered On Leap Offering
description: The Leap Group in Chicago, which owns the Leap Partnership and interactive marketing units, has lowered the price a share at which the agency expects to sell stock in an initial public offering.

title: Renault's Head Says It Will Post 1996 Loss
description: The chairman of Renault S.A., Louis Schweitzer, said yesterday that the auto maker expects to report a net loss for 1996, confirming analyst forecasts following its first-half results, which were announced on Tuesday. Asked in an interview with the newspaper Le Monde whether the company expects a 1996 loss, Mr. Schweitzer said, ''That is our central assumption, considering our forecasts for the market.''

title: When Jimmy Breslin's Life, Columns and Books Passed Before His Eyes
description: I WANT TO THANK MY BRAIN FOR REMEMBERING ME

title: L.I. Garbage Hauler Faces Federal Charges
description: In an indictment that suggests how hard it is to oust the Mafia from the garbage hauling business, a reputed mob associate was charged yesterday with using ''front companies'' to retain his Islip, L.I., routes after the town barred his company because of its role in a bribery scheme.

title: Owners' Negotiator Sees a Path to Progress
description: The process that led to the threshold of a new labor agreement a month ago survived a meeting of baseball's executive council today, but the owners' chief negotiator will have to await additional council discussions before trying to finish what he started. The possibility even arose that owners opposed to the prospective deal could still scuttle it.

title: Business Districts Require Check on Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Mattingly Keeping Decision a Secret
description: DON MATTINGLY said yesterday that he and his family are 90 percent decided on whether he will return to baseball, but he is only dropping hints that he actually plans to come back. Mattingly, 35, left the Yankees last year after playing with them since 1982. He is willing to play first base, left field or right field.

title: Nathan Safir, 83, Spanish-Radio Pioneer, Dies
description: Nathan Safir, a pioneer in Spanish-language broadcasting in the United States, died on Saturday at his home in San Antonio, Tex. He was 83.

title: Rabin Killer and 2 Others Guilty of Related Plots Against Leader
description: An Israeli court today convicted Yitzhak Rabin's assassin, the assassin's brother and a third Jewish nationalist of conspiring to kill the Prime Minister and to attack Palestinian Arabs.

title: Crew Won't Aid Parochial School Plan
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew announced yesterday that the school system's central headquarters would not assist Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in his plan to move 1,000 failing public school students to parochial schools.

title: Bond Prices Unchanged; Data Awaited
description: Prices of Treasury securities were virtually unchanged yesterday, as investors remain defensive about two unknowns: inflationary pressure building in the economy and the size of the next interest-rate increase.

title: Reducing Doctors' Income Won't Improve Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Crew Won't Aid Mayor On Catholic Schooling
description: Chancellor Rudy Crew said the school system's headquarters would not assist Mayor Giuliani's plan to move 1,000 failing public school students to parochial schools, a decision that appeared to remove a possible constitutional objection to the plan.

title: Vacco Admits Politics Played Role in Hiring
description: State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco acknowledged today for the first time that politics played a role in how he chose to hire lawyers for his office.

title: Buyback at Georgia Gulf
description: The Georgia Gulf Corporation said today that it planned to buy back as many as 3.5 million shares of its common stock. Under a recent stock-repurchase plan, Georgia Gulf acquired 3.8 million of its common shares at a cost of $123.6 million over about a year. The chemical maker, which is based in Atlanta, said the additional authorization would enable it to purchase about 10 percent of the remaining shares outstanding by the end of 1997. Georgia Gulf's stock rose 62.5 cents today, to $31.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Coaches Don't Mince Words in Lambasting Giants for Blunders
description: The Giants players certainly didn't expect to be kissed on the cheek after the way they were blown out against Dallas, but some of them were still woozy today after being lambasted by the coaches in their Monday evening meetings.

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: California

title: Radical Swings in Clean Air Plan in Los Angeles Area
description: Flash back to 1992, when hundreds of business executives and union officials joined in a candlelight vigil on the steps of Southern California's pollution-control agency to protest air-quality standards that they said were strangling the economy and killing jobs. Their rare show of unity helped prod the agency to roll back some of the nation's strictest environmental regulations.

title: Children's Health Is to Guide E.P.A.
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it would start focusing all environmental protection standards on the risks that pollution poses to the health of children.

title: Burning of Amazon Picks Up Pace, With Vast Areas Lost
description: After years of Brazilian Government claims that stricter environmental laws had slowed destruction of the Amazon rain forest, newly issued figures show that deforestation has actually increased sharply since the 1992 Earth Summit was held here, with fires and logging consuming rain forest the size of Denmark in just a few years.

title: Clinton Won't Appeal Court Rebuff on Workers
description: The Clinton Administration has announced that it will not appeal a Federal appeals court decision that overturned a Presidential order barring Government contractors from using permanent replacement workers.

title: Planned Parenthood to Participate in a Test of Abortion Drugs
description: The Planned Parenthood Federation of America announced yesterday that it would give some women seeking early abortions the option of taking medication to induce abortion as part of a clinical trial approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Serbian Warlord's New Way: Politics
description: Of all the warlords who have allegedly become rich by turning the Balkans into a slaughterhouse in the name of nationalism, the most dreaded name, Arkan, belongs to the baby-faced man who commanded the stage at a campaign rally here.

title: The Man In the Mirror
description: Bill Clinton is always in love with the sentence he hasn't yet spoken. The prolix President, chasing restlessly from thought to thought at a fund-raising dinner here on Tuesday night, at last fell into his Commander-in-Grief groove, musing about the ''crystallizing'' value of seeing ''people in their hour of greatest pain.''

title: The Art and Craftiness of TV Scheduling
description: Now comes the new television season, filled not only with the onslaught of 40 new prime-time shows but also with stunting, shuffling, substituting and scheming as the networks maneuver for best position in the Nielsen ratings pack.

title: CORPORATE EXPRESS TO ACQUIRE UNITED TRANSNET
description: Corporate Express Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire United Transnet Inc. in a stock transaction valued about $138 million. Each common share of United Transnet will be exchanged for 0.45 share of Corporate Express. Corporate Express is the largest provider of same-day delivery of office supplies to corporations. The company, based in Broomfield, Colo., said it planned to consolidate some facilities and administrative positions and combine national marketing programs. After the acquisition, Corporate Express said it would operate in 90 percent of the nation's 100 largest metropolitan markets. Shares of Corporate Express rose $1.875, to $34.625, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of United Transnet, based in Roswell, Ga., fell 50 cents, to $15.

title: The Internet's Gatekeeper May Cash In on Its Role
description: The private company that the Government put in charge of registering Internet and World Wide Web addresses is now considering cashing in on its gatekeeper role.

title: Clinton Aides Believe Morris Misled Them About Book
description: White House aides said today that it was now apparent that Dick Morris, President Clinton's former strategist and pollster, had deliberately deceived Mr. Clinton about his plans to write a book on his role as a Presidential adviser.

title: Brooklyn Union to Lower, Then Freeze, Service Rates for Gas
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company said yesterday that it would lower its service rates for natural gas use next year for many of its 1.1 million customers and then keep the rates unchanged for five years.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of a performance on Monday by the chamber orchestra of the Curtis Institute of Music at Merkin Concert Hall misspelled the surname of the guest violin soloist. As noted in the review, he was Aaron Rosand, not Rosard.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about plans by two energy companies, the Coastal Corporation and Westcoast Energy Inc., to merge their natural gas and electricity marketing operations, referred incorrectly to a payment to be made by one company. It is Westcoast that will make an initial payment of $50 million and a possible future payment of $10 million, to Coastal -- not the other way around.

title: 'Immediate Action' Demanded to End Territorial 'Outrage' : China Warns Japan on Islands
description: HONG KONG  In a formal protest delivered by its ambassador in Tokyo, China formally told Japan on Wednesday that it was outraged by rightist activists' recent efforts to assert Japan's sovereignty over a small group of disputed islands in the seas east of China.

title: Xerox and Kohlberg Kravis Call Off Planned Sale
description: The Xerox Corporation and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said today that they were calling off the planned $2.7 billion sale of Xerox's insurance units to Kohlberg Kravis.

title: Kemp Says Clinton's Policy On Iraq Emboldens Hussein
description: Jack Kemp, the Republican candidate for Vice President, accused President Clinton today of vacillating on his policy on Iraq and said that the Administration's ''vague and uncertain'' foreign policy goals had contributed to the current state of unrest in that country.

title: Steelmakers plan to polish their product's image to compete with aluminum and plastics makers.
description: IT IS high-tech. It is recyclable. It is light and clean.

title: Bridge
description: It is generally assumed that young players bid aggressively and become more conservative as they grow older. By that measure, Steve Stanton of Stuart, Fla., has yet to grow old, although he is, at 88, the country's second-oldest active male duplicate director. He was playing in a club game with Sallie Harris, also of Stuart, who is a mere 82.

title: Reeves? Kotite? Shula?
description: IF the Giants and the Jets keep losing (and chances are each's record will be 0-3 before each's resistible force meets the other's movable object a week from Sunday), how long will Dan Reeves and Rich Kotite keep their jobs? More important, how long should they keep their jobs?

title: U.S. Seeks To End Direct Aid For Kurds
description: With the allied relief effort in northern Iraq in disarray, the Clinton Administration is looking for ways to end its direct role in providing food, shelter and other aid to the Kurds, leaving it instead to relief groups and international organizations like the United Nations, Administration officials said today.

title: TRON STOCK PLUNGES ON PROJECTION OF LOSS
description: The stock of Itron Inc. slid nearly 28 percent yesterday after the company, a provider of power-utility products and services, said it expected to post a loss for its third quarter. Analysts surveyed by First Call Inc. had predicted profits of 20 cents a share for the period ending on Sept. 30, compared with 20 cents a year earlier. The company, based in Spokane, Wash., also said it expected revenue to be significantly lower than forecast. A year earlier, the company had revenue of $39 million. The company blamed an industrywide slowdown in orders for automated meter readers for the loss. Itron's stock fell $8 to close at $21 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Foul-Ups Bring Calls for New Elections
description: A day after one of New York City's most widespread election foul-ups in recent decades, several candidates defeated in primaries urged the city's Board of Elections yesterday to conduct new elections in Brooklyn, while others said they would seek to invalidate the results in the courts.

title: Face Lift at the Ziegfeld: New Seats and New Z's
description: The Ziegfeld Theater, Manhattan's most grandiose movie house, will close for a three-week, $500,000 face lift after the last showing of ''Independence Day'' today. The theater, on 54th Street near the Avenue of the Americas, is to reopen on Oct. 4 with a newly restored version of Alfred Hitchcock's ''Vertigo'' as part of a benefit for the Walter Reade Theater. On Oct. 6, the theater will resume normal operations, presenting ''Vertigo'' in a commercial run.

title: Women on the Verge Of a Renewed Awakening
description: The Raincoats, from London, and the Bush Tetras, from New York, share a similar history. Both bands released debut records in 1980, when punk's wrecking ball had done its work and pop seemed up for grabs, open for the first time to intellectually self-determining women. In different ways, their songs were miniatures, with self-contained riffs bound by bewitching dub-reggae bass lines. Both carried on until the New Wave going on around them entered its formal, mannerist period; the Raincoats disbanded in 1984, the Bush Tetras in 1983. Recently, both bands re-formed, and in a Monday night double bill at Brownie's, their music made sense once again in pop's vast new landscape.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Painful Time For Yanks
description: As Dwight Gooden spoke about whether he should skip his next start because his right arm has been so lifeless, it was difficult not to notice the scene unraveling about 10 feet away. Wade Boggs grimaced as he pulled on a pair of jeans two hours before the scheduled game with the Tigers and prepared to return to New York for medical tests on his back.

title: Irish Group Living by Its Tunes
description: The Cranberries, who performed on Monday night at the PNC Bank Arts Center here, are like a big, beautifully wrapped present that one opens only to find it completely empty. There can be a beauty in simplicity and hollowness, and this was true at times of the Cranberries' first two albums. But on their latest, ''To the Faithful Departed'' (Island), the band invites the listener into the emptiness beneath the surface, trying to tackle big social and political issues in the lyrics. The result is an album best summarized by the title of an earlier Cranberries song, ''Ridiculous Thoughts.''

title: Robert Nisbet, 82, Sociologist And Conservative Champion
description: Robert A. Nisbet, a scholar who plumbed the history of ideas and found none more appealing than the pure strain of conservative thought that he illuminated and championed in more than a dozen books, died on Monday at his home in Washington. He was 82.

title: Private Program for Troubled Students Echoes Catholic School Plan
description: Two years ago, Sean Kendell Winn was the kind of student who is at the heart of the plan advocated this week by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to send some public school students to Roman Catholic schools.

title: At a Festival in the Catskills, the Blues Go Kosher
description: The blues fans rolled in by car. They came by motorcycle. They even came by Oink Express -- and that could have been a problem.

title: Oil Jumps to Five-Month High As Iraqi Tensions Heighten
description: Crude oil futures prices soared yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after Iraq fired a missile at American fighter planes in northern Iraq, heightening concern that military conflict could disrupt oil supplies from the Persian Gulf.

title: With Heart, African Design Melts Into the Mainstream
description: THE intersection of 116th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem bears the familiar wounds of urban neglect: trash, graffiti and rundown storefronts.

title: Veto of 'Prevailing Wage' Bill Is Overridden by City Council
description: Drawing a clear distinction between its labor and business philosophies and those of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council yesterday voted overwhelmingly to override the Mayor's veto of a bill that would require some city contractors to pay their workers more than double the minimum wage.

title: Ross Perot's Soul Mate
description: Ross Perot's choice of Pat Choate as his running mate does little to increase his meager Presidential prospects. At least in theory, a Vice-Presidential candidate should be qualified to assume the Presidency. Both Al Gore and Jack Kemp meet that test. But ''President Choate''? The words do not ring with plausibility. He was in fact the flinty Texan's fourth choice for the ticket, after three others with broader experience -- a former Senator and two members of the House -- said no.

title: U.S. Has Vital Interest in Stopping Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Fabric (Oops!) Stain-Free
description: PATRICIA McKEOGH, a lawyer from Katonah, N.Y., can tell you all about the marvels of upholstery fabric protectors. Just days after her new blue-and-white checked chair arrived from Bloomingdale's, a guest spilled a glass of red wine all over it. But the wine mopped up easily and left no stain.

title: Timeless Melodies Of Devotion
description: The Jewish holidays about to begin are rich in music that is both introspective and public. The cantor, entrusted to express the contrition of the entire congregation before God, must also move his human listeners to sincere thoughts of repentance. His power to achieve this lies partly in a mastery of ancient forms, partly in a continuing tradition of composition that combines a melismatic Middle Eastern vocal style with elements of Western tonality, and partly in the improvisation inherent in choices of vocal color and ornamentation.

title: U.S. IS PREPARING BIGGER AIR STRIKES ON TARGETS IN IRAQ
description: The United States dispatched F-117 stealth fighters to Kuwait today and moved four B-52 bombers closer to the Middle East to prepare for an attack on Iraq that Pentagon officials said would very likely be larger and more destructive than the two American strikes last week.

title: A Hollywood Production: Political Money
description: For President Clinton, Thursday evening will be a memorable one. Barbra Streisand will serenade him under the stars, Maya Angelou will read him poetry, and he will mingle with Hollywood's corporate elite, all this at a breathtaking Mediterranean-style estate overlooking Beverly Hills.

title: AMF UNIT TO BUY BOWLING COMPANY
description: AMF Bowling Centers, a unit of AMF Group Inc., said yesterday that it would buy the Bowling Corporation of America from the closely held Charan Industries. Stephen Hare, AMF Group's chief financial officer, said the price was about $104 million. AMF said it would acquire 50 bowling centers in 14 states from the Bowling Corporation. AMF operates 287 bowling centers worldwide. Based in Richmond, AMF makes bowling equipment and operates bowling centers internationally. Charan, based in Garden City, L.I., owns and operates bowling centers and owns and manages commercial real estate.

title: Singapore Comments Called Insulting : In Malaysia, Mistrust
description: SINGAPORE  When Singapore was expelled from the Malaysian federation in 1965 for campaigning for racial equality and meritocracy, the action left a legacy of mistrust and misunderstanding that both countries have found hard to dispel.

title: New England Life to Announce Stake in Meca Software
description: Hoping to head off rapidly growing competition from banks and technology companies, the New England Life Insurance Company has bought a substantial stake in a company that produces computer software for managing personal finance, company officials plan to announce today.

title: Health Care Lagging Among Blacks and Poor
description: Even when people are covered by Medicare, the type of care they receive and their overall mortality are influenced by race and income, according to results of a large Federal study.

title: Guilty Plea by a Judge
description: A retired Somerset County Superior Court judge who had previously admitted embezzling $173,000 from his former real estate partners pleaded guilty yesterday to evading taxes on nearly $50,000 of that sum, Federal prosecutors said. The former judge, Michael Imbriani, 67, who was sentenced to five years' probation for the embezzlement conviction, faces up to five years in jail and a $250,000 fine, said Robert Ernst, an assistant United States attorney.

title: No Parole in Police Murders
description: Flanked by 150 police officers, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill yesterday that would prohibit the granting of parole to anyone convicted of murdering an on-duty law enforcement officer. The new law will force suspects accused of sticking another person with a hypodermic needle to submit to an AIDS test and will eliminate liability for officers who assist at the scene of an accident or emergency. The ceremony was filmed by the Republican State Committee in case Mrs. Whitman decides to use it in her re-election campaign, said Tom Wilson, executive director of the Republican State Committee.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TALBOTS INC., Hingham, Mass., a retailer of women's clothing, expects to open 39 stores in the second half of its fiscal year, giving it a total of 75 new stores opening this year.

title: Ascent's Bid for Spectravision Is Approved
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today approved a plan by Spectravision Inc. to be purchased by the On Command Video Corporation for $225 million in stock, warrants and assumed debt.

title: A Clamor to Return Nazi Booty to Holocaust Victims
description: The revelation in Britain that Switzerland may have held onto billions of dollars worth of German gold after World War II provided fresh ammunition Wednesday for organizations still seeking compensation for victims of the Nazi Holocaust and their heirs.

title: Gross Domestic Product Rises for Europe Union
description: The economy of the European Union expanded in the first quarter, after a fourth-quarter decline in 1995, amid rising exports and consumer spending, the European Union's statistics office said yesterday. Gross domestic product rose 0.49 percent in real terms in the three months ended March 31, compared with a 0.24 percent decline in the previous quarter.

title: Human and Humanoid (And Also Half and Half)
description: Brilliant puppetry and an enigmatic, wickedly funny tale of obsessive love and murder most foul are combined in ''The Repugnant Story of Clotario Demoniax,'' which opened the International Festival of Puppet Theater on Tuesday night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.

title: Dole Draws on a Personal Victory to Assure His G.O.P. Colleagues of Political Victory
description: Bob Dole returned to Capitol Hill today to reassure those he called ''the faint-hearted'' that he had the determination to raise himself from the political near-dead because he had once raised himself from the literal near-dead.

title: F.T.C. Is Said to Have Cleared Time Warner Deal for Turner
description: The Federal Trade Commission plans to announce today that it has officially approved Time Warner's $6.5 billion merger with the Turner Broadcasting System, according to people familiar with the decision.

title: The Case Against a Rate Rise Attracts a Respectable Crowd
description: With unemployment falling to just 5.1 percent and the pace of economic growth this year easily outstripping the sustainable long-term growth rate, the Federal Reserve looks to be on the verge of stepping on the brakes. ''The only question left is how much the Fed will raise interest rates,'' said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch.

title: INSIDE
description: Anti-Terrorism Questions

title: New York's Warped Election Process
description: This week's primary-election fiasco in Brooklyn demonstrates how dysfunctional New York City's electoral process has become. Courts ordered three candidates added to the ballot on the Friday before the primary, and subtracted another just hours before the polls were to open. As a result, some polling places did not open until the middle of the afternoon. In others, voters had to be warned that some of the candidates on the ballot were no longer really candidates.

title: Motorola Warns Quarterly Profits Will Shrink
description: Motorola Inc. warned Wall Street today that disappointing sales of semiconductors, cellular phones, and paging products were taking a much bigger toll on its earnings than analysts had been projecting for the third quarter.

title: He Likes Couture When It Sizzles
description: FUTURE fashion archeologists take note: the first dress that John Galliano ever designed is probably hanging in a closet at his sister's house in England.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: WPIX in Yank Finale Today?
description: Will today's game against the Tigers be the final Yankee telecast on WPIX-TV/Channel 11? There may be no more birthday wishes or Scooter Pie references by Phil Rizzuto if WPIX cannot make a deal with the MSG Network.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about NATO's plan to extend the stay of its peacekeeping force in Bosnia by at least two years misstated the whereabouts of the United States Defense Secretary, William J. Perry. He was in Washington, not in Sarajevo.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Japan Corporate Profits Surged in 2d Quarter
description: Japan's corporate profits soared an average of 34.4 percent in the April-June quarter, while sales rose 5.5 percent, the smallest increase in a year, the Ministry of Finance said yesterday. Capital investment rose 7.3 percent from the corresponding period last year, according to the ministry's quarterly survey of corporate profits.

title: Canada Auto Pact Talks
description: Chrysler Canada Ltd.'s latest contract offer does not adequately address outsourcing, the most contentious issue in union bargaining, the Canadian Auto Workers said today. The Canadian union wants better job security for its members and is demanding that rules for contracting out be detailed in the contract. The Canadian union, which has chosen Chrysler as the target of its contract talks, has set a strike deadline for next Tuesday. Chrysler's initial wage offer is expected Thursday.

title: Punish Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: Harrah's Entertainment, Memphis, and Players International, Atlantic City, to TBWA Chiat/Day, St. Louis, a unit of the Omnicom Group, as the first agency to handle advertising for a joint venture, the Riverport Casino Center. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Canadians Get Most Out of Old, Tested Legs
description: Canadian fans concerned about their nation's World Cup hockey team often mention age. By building around players like Wayne Gretzky, Mark Messier and Paul Coffey, some worried that Glen Sather, the coach and general manager, was trying to relive the glory days of the 1980's, when they were all together in Edmonton for the Stanley Cup dynasty of the Oilers.

title: HEALTHSOUTH AGREES TO ACQUIRE READICARE
description: The Healthsouth Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Readicare Inc., based in Sunnyvale, Calif., an operator of workers' compensation medical centers, for about $70 million of stock. Readicare's stockholders will receive 0.2425 Healthsouth common share for each share held. The exchange ratio will be adjusted if Healthsouth's average share price rises above $38.30 or falls below $30.60 during a certain measuring period. Readicare shares soared more than 50 percent yesterday, or $2.84375, to $7.96875, on the Nasdaq market. Healthsouth shares were down 12.5 cents, at $35.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Healthsouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., provides outpatient surgery and rehabilitative care.

title: Giuliani to Sue Over Provision On Welfare
description: Calling it ''inhumane and indecent,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said today that he would sue the Federal Government to block a previously overlooked provision of the new welfare law that allows city employees to turn in illegal immigrants who seek services like police protection, hospital care and public education.

title: A Renewed Challenge From Iraq
description: With the Pentagon reinforcing United States air power in the Persian Gulf, events in Iraq seem to be moving toward an escalation in American military operations. Though Saddam Hussein started the latest conflict, President Clinton owes Americans a clear explanation of how he means to deal with the complex political and military equation in the Persian Gulf before sending more forces into combat. He has not yet made a convincing case for intensified air strikes against Iraq.

title: Behind Rally, an Optimism That Mystifies
description: The Dow Jones industrial average jumped more than 27 points yesterday, bringing it within a whisker of its record close of 5,778 on May 22 and nearly completing a recovery that wiped out its 6.7 percent decline in July.

title: If the Ax Falls, Watson Will Not Run for Cover
description: As the dreary losses have mounted and the Yankees' once-imposing 12-game lead has shriveled to two and a half games, the Yankee owner, George Steinbrenner, has intensified his scrutiny of General Manager Bob Watson. Watson conceded today that there have been ''tense'' moments with the owner, and shockingly said today that he and Manager Joe Torre deserve to be dismissed if the Yankees continue to plummet and fall out of first place.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Back in the good old days of journalism, when reporters wrote on typewriters and editors edited with pencils, the number ''30'' was used to signify an article's end.

title: Burstein Says Primary Defeat Could Be Her Last Campaign
description: Karen S. Burstein said yesterday she should have listened to her mother.

title: U.S. Has Vital Interest in Stopping Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Zabriski Wins Elusive Title
description: Bruce Zabriski, who said he never felt any pressure to win the one local major golf title that has escaped him in an outstanding career as a club pro, finally attained that title today when he captured the Izod/Cadillac Met PGA Championship at the Piping Rock Club.

title: Puerto Rico Asks for U.S. Aid To Recover From Hurricane
description: Preliminary damage estimates from Hurricane Hortense topped $200 million today, and Gov. Pedro J. Rossello urged Federal officials to approve emergency aid to help residents rebuild.

title: Orioles Stay on Yank Heels
description: The Baltimore Orioles have to be of two minds these days. One that believes a division title is still possible as they hotly pursue the Yankees. And one that pushes the Orioles to keep the other avenue to the post-season open by beating back all teams still thinking about a wild-card berth.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JUDY CARMICHAEL, who has been playing jazz piano for more than 20 years and has established a considerable reputation among the cognoscenti, made her singing debut Tuesday night. She is appearing with STEVE ROSS, the singer and pianist, in an engagement that continues at Tavern on the Green through Sunday.

title: Turnpike Repairs to Begin
description: Six weeks of repairs that will leave only a single lane open on sections of the Newark Bay-Hudson County Extension of the New Jersey Turnpike will begin Friday at 8 P.M. and last through Oct. 31, officials said yesterday. The repairs will begin near Exit 14 in Newark between Jersey Avenue and the Holland Tunnel in Jersey City.

title: Building Grace Into A House
description: READERS often write letters to their favorite magazines -- and they generally offer praise. But Jeanette Podlogar, a Country Home subscriber who lives in Dunbar, Pa., did not write to give the magazine a pat on the back. Instead, she asked its editors to put on their thinking caps: How can you build a brand-new house that feels like an antique?

title: Voice-Recognition Software Being Introduced by I.B.M.
description: The long-sought goal of being able to speak directly to a computer rather than type on a keyboard will take a step closer to reality today, when I.B.M. will announce new software that enables radiologists to dictate their reports directly into a personal computer.

title: Moschino's New Store: Down the Rabbit Hole
description: MOST stores fall short of the retailing dictum that is spouted with numbing regularity these days -- that shopping should be fun.

title: Fed Report Finds Growth Still Modest
description: Wages are rising as the economy across most of the nation continues to grow at a moderate pace, but there is little evidence yet of inflation taking root, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Shift in Standard For Environmental Rules

title: City Schools Learn Harsh Economic Lessons
description: The point is made early and often in ''Children in America's Schools'': Poor children's schools are worse in every respect, or disrespect, than the schools of the well-to-do.

title: Paying for Government
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''Politicians and movie stars spring from the same DNA. Both hope for applause, both read from a script and both hope to persuade audiences.''

title: SPRINT PLANS SALES THROUGH RADIO SHACK
description: The Sprint Corporation and its Sprint Spectrum wireless venture are teaming up with the Tandy Corporation's Radio Shack unit to sell phones and services through its 6,800 United States retail stores, the companies said yesterday. The move is Sprint's latest push to offer consumers convenience, following the popularity of its dime-a-minute calling plan. Sprint will sell a range of products from cellular and paging services to traditional local and long-distance calling through Sprint stores inside Radio Shacks.

title: Clinton Mines for Votes in Goldwater Land
description: From the high plains of Colorado to this desert retirement colony, President Clinton prospected for votes today in territory not typically hospitable to Democrats, proposing tighter drug screening for prison inmates and vowing to protect Medicare and other programs for the elderly.

title: Chief of Perot Systems Steps Aside as Part of Expansion
description: Morton Meyerson, Ross Perot's business lieutenant since the 1970's, stepped aside as chief executive of the Perot Systems Corporation today and promoted James A. Cannavino, the company president, to take his place. The switch comes as Perot Systems undertakes a rapid expansion and transformation that even includes discussions of dropping Perot from the company's name.

title: Swedish Bank Plans A Stock Buyback
description: Nordbanken A.B., Sweden's fourth-largest bank by assets, said yesterday that it wanted to buy back shares worth 5 billion kronor, about $758 million, or between 15 percent and 18 percent of outstanding shares, to raise its share value before possible acquisitions. The Swedish state is committed to selling as many of its Nordbanken shares as possible; it now holds a 65.5 percent stake. Since the offer is more favorable for the state than for other shareholders, it may cut the state's stake to a minimum 58 percent, Nordbanken said. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: U.S. Accuses 2 Miami Officials of Corruption
description: Miami's longtime city manager was charged today with conspiring to steal public money in a Federal corruption case that also snared a city commissioner and a lobbyist.

title: Dow Up 27.74 Points, Aided by Oil Stocks
description: Stocks rose yesterday as heightened tensions in the Middle East drove up the price of crude oil and the shares of oil companies like Exxon and Texaco.

title: British Unemployment Hits 5 1/2-Year Low
description: Britain's unemployment rate fell to a five-and-a-half-year low of 7.5 percent in August as jobless ranks fell by 15,600, to 2.11 million, which was also the lowest level since March 1991, the Office for National Statistics said yesterday. The jobless rate was 7.6 percent in July.

title: Beside the Autobahn, a Cold-War Memory Lane
description: Ever since Germany was reunified in October 1990, the hundreds of billions of dollars injected by a wealthy West into a crumpled East have seemed aimed at one particular target: to conjure so much prosperity that no trace of four decades of Communist dictatorship is left.

title: Morris vs. Clinton
description: Dick Morris is hopping mad. Not so much at ''yellow journalism'' or the woman who gave prostitution a bad name, but at the vindictive bunch in the Clinton White House who have been violating his privacy with leaks from his confidential file.

title: Foreign Investment Agency Is Rebuffed in House Vote
description: The House dealt a sharp blow today to a Federal agency that provides insurance and loan guarantees to American companies that invest in developing nations.

title: No Contract Extension for Switzer
description: JERRY JONES, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, said his decision not to extend Coach BARRY SWITZER's contract, as he has done the last two years, is strictly good business. When he hired Switzer in 1994, Jones gave him a five-year contract with a rollover option, meaning it could continue to be a five-year deal as long as the National Football League team wanted.

title: Advertising Alliance Of Children's Groups
description: The publishing divisions of the Boy Scouts of America and the Children's Television Workshop have formed an advertising sales alliance.

title: Look Who's in Control: Isringhausen Lifts Mets
description: He was like a piece of furniture in a summer home, unseen for a whole year. And then someone pulled the sheet off Jason Isringhausen.

title: Election Over, A Loser Bets On History
description: IN this city, where Mickey Mantle was often booed, where Walt Whitman was tossed out of his newspaper job, Shimon Peres became the latest casualty of a harsh truth: New Yorkers are front-runners and, as the old blues song goes, nobody knows you when you're down and out.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Repotting Hibiscus

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: In Search of a Beat, but Not of a Home
description: Rumors that Bradley's is closing have been rife lately. But a show by the pianist George Cables on Tuesday night, along with a pointed notice in the club's window from its owner, Wendy Cunningham, made it clear that Bradley's is still with us, which is a good thing. Mr. Cables's show -- which will be running through Saturday -- underscored how important the club is to New York. Without it this little group probably wouldn't have a home in Manhattan.

title: POCO PETROLEUMS SEEKS TO ACQUIRE A RIVAL
description: Poco Petroleums Ltd. said yesterday that it planned to make a cash-and-stock offer currently valued at $225 million (Canadian), or $164.2 million (United States), to acquire a rival, Gardiner Oil and Gas Ltd. Poco will offer $5 (Canadian) in cash and 0.6 Poco common share for each common share of Gardiner. The offer is subject to the acceptance by at least 90 percent of Gardiner's shares. Poco said shareholders who own or control about 74 percent of the shares outstanding had agreed to tender their shares. Gardiner's shares were up $2.20 (Canadian) yesterday, to $11.50, on the Toronto Stock Exchange, while Poco slipped 15 cents (Canadian), to $11.20. Poco said Gardiner's 250,000 net acres of undeveloped land were within Poco's core areas of operation in western Alberta.

title: Explaining a 15 Percent Tax Cut, in 30 Seconds
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Dole campaign began broadcasting yesterday in a dozen states.

title: Calendar: Crafts, Antiques, Lectures
description: Architecture and Folk Images

title: The Weekend Starts Now for Cigar
description: It was 6:45 on an overcast morning at Belmont Park when the first shots were fired in the battles of Woodward Week, the grandest weekend so far in New York's racing year: One month after his winning streak was halted at 16, the champion Cigar took the track for his final workout before resuming his career.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline yesterday about the Senate's action on two gay rights measures cited one vote incorrectly in some editions. The senators passed a bill defining marriage as between people of opposite sexes and declaring that states are not obliged to recognize gay marriages performed elsewhere; they did not reject a bill on the subject of gay marriage.

title: Misguided Missiles
description: Prominent Republicans, while endorsing President Clinton's decision to launch cruise missiles against Iraq, have caustically noted the President's failure to hold together the coalition of the Persian Gulf war. That failure, they say, reflects a growing lack of confidence in Washington's, or more precisely, Mr. Clinton's leadership.

title: U.S. Has Vital Interest in Stopping Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO CLINTON AIDES RESIGN TO PROTEST NEW WELFARE LAW
description: Two of the Clinton Administration's senior officials on welfare policy resigned today in protest of the law President Clinton signed last month ending the Federal guarantee of cash assistance to the nation's poorest children.

title: U.S. Has Vital Interest in Stopping Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole's Secret Weapon?
description: Next week, the Commission on Presidential Debates is scheduled to decide whether Ross Perot should be included in the television debates.

title: U.S. Aid to World Birth-Control Efforts Faces Cuts
description: Three years after the Clinton Administration lifted a ban on aid for international birth control efforts that include abortion and abortion counseling, the House, the Senate and the White House are at loggerheads over Republican attempts to revive the ban, a dispute that could block passage of the $12 billion foreign aid bill.

title: Met Planning to Add 20th-Century Operas
description: The Metropolitan Opera plans to expand its commitment to 20th-century opera as the century comes to an end, the company announced yesterday at a news conference at the opera house.

title: Airlines and Others Question Aspects of Anti-Terrorism Plan
description: Airline representatives, airport operators and members of Congress expressed reservations today about the Clinton Administration's plans for preventing terrorism. They said they favored re-evaluating aviation security, but raised questions about the cost, practicality and usefulness of many of the proposed steps.

title: When It Comes to Trade, U.S. Now Has No Favorites
description: For years Congress has tied itself into knots every summer over whether to declare China a ''most favored nation,'' entitled to a host of trade benefits almost every other country in the world gets from Washington.

title: Bergdorf Men's Store
description: To the Editor:

title: Start of Something Big For Johnson and Jets?
description: The little guy officially made way for the big guy today when the Jets made Keyshawn Johnson their starting flanker.

title: GRUMMAN WILL HIRE MORE THAN 500 WORKERS
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation is hiring more than 900 workers at its five commercial aircraft-parts factories because of surging orders for planes. Northrop is the biggest subcontractor for the Boeing Company, which has more than 400 firm orders for jets this year, making this its best year since 1990. At its Dallas plant, Northrop expects to add 500 positions by year's end, a spokeswoman, Georgia Engle, said. Northrop also is recalling or hiring new workers at its factories in Hawthorne, Calif.; Stuart, Fla., and Perry and Milledgeville, Ga., Ms. Engle said.

title: Crenshaw to Join CBS as Analyst
description: The two-time Masters champion BEN CRENSHAW will join CBS Sports as an analyst for at least 10 golfing events next year. Crenshaw will also serve as studio analyst for CBS's coverage of the Presidents Cup this weekend. (Bloomberg News Service)

title: Reuters Plans Bonus For Its Investors
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said yesterday it would distribute $:613 million, or $950 million, to investors over three years. Reuters stock gained 14 pence a share to 764 on the London Stock Exchange yesterday; its American depository receipts rose $1.25 to $71.25 in Nasdaq trading.

title: Al Gore Speaks in Montclair
description: Jack Kemp visited New Jersey on Tuesday. Yesterday, it was Vice President Al Gore's turn to stump for New Jersey's 15 electoral votes. Speaking at Montclair State University before a supportive audience of about 3,000, most of them students, Mr. Gore underscored the Administration's support of higher education and criticized Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential candidate, for vowing to eliminate the Department of Education and to reduce student loans and education grants.

title: Nasdaq Trades Found to Cost Institutions More
description: As criticism mounted against the Nasdaq Stock Market in recent years, the cry was that individual investors had gotten a raw deal there compared with the way they were treated on the stock exchanges. But many assumed that institutional investors, who were better able to negotiate deals and more savvy about trading rules, could do equally well on any market.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Hurricanes Come to Rutgers
description: A walk-on baseball player, a senior who played briefly for Tennessee two years ago, will be the starting quarterback for Rutgers tonight when the Scarlet Knights take on unbeaten Miami at Rutgers Stadium in Piscataway, N.J. The task for Mark Stephans, from Morristown, N.J., will be to jump-start the Rutgers offense, moribund in the team's first two games -- a victory over Villanova and a loss to Navy.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about George Soros, the currency-market power, misstated the purpose of the nearly $15 million Mr. Soros has donated or pledged to groups exploring alternatives to the United States' drug policies. It is to be used to broaden the debate and foster changes in those policies. Mr. Soros has made smaller, personal donations to initiatives that would specifically legalize the medical use of marijuana.

title: Bosnia's Candidate 'in Absentia' Still Has a Following
description: On a dirt road that winds through rolling fields and forests, four strong men, aged 34 to 51, were taking a break from cutting firewood for a neighbor on a late summer day.

title: United States Has Its Fed Cup Team
description: MONICA SELES, LINDSAY DAVENPORT, MARY JOE FERNANDEZ and LINDA WILD will be on the American tennis team that will face Spain in the Fed Cup finals Sept. 28-29 in Atlantic City, while the doubles specialist GIGI FERNANDEZ will stay home.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Perot's Running Mate Says He'll Address Wide Range of Issues in Campaign
description: Ross Perot's running mate, Pat Choate, said today that he should not be regarded as a single-issue candidate because of his reputation as an outspoken critic of United States trade policies, including the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Giuliani Assails Rule On Reporting Aliens
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani warned that ''chaos'' would result from an element of the Federal welfare bill that would allow city employees to report to immigration authorities illegal immigrants who seek services like police protection, hospital care and public education.

title: Sierra, of All People, Helps the Yankees Stay on Pace
description: The chronically unhappy Ruben Sierra desperately wanted to help the Yankees advance to the post-season, but they traded him to the Tigers in July. Guess what? Sierra might have achieved his wish tonight anyway.

title: Study Finds Lasting Damage From Prenatal PCB Exposure
description: Exposure before birth to relatively small amounts of PCB's, a kind of industrial pollutant, can result in long-lasting deficits in a child's intellectual development, a new study has shown.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Saturday about Jack Kemp's campaign visit to Harlem misidentified the person seated between him and Representative Charles B. Rangel. He was the Rev. Thaddeus Garrett Jr., board chairman of Howard University and an adviser to the Dole campaign.

title: Workers for Con Ed Puncture Steam Pipe
description: Consolidated Edison workers doing routine maintenance on an underground steam pipe last night accidentally punctured the line, scattering a small amount of debris across a sidewalk on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, a company spokesman said.

title: First-Half Profit Rose For Prudential of Britain
description: The Prudential Corporation P.L.C., the British insurance and asset management giant, said yesterday that it had an 8 percent rise in first-half profit to $:421 million, or $655 million. The report was better than analysts had forecast for Prudential, which is not related to the United States company with the same name.

title: Diesel Buses to Be Replaced In Big Anti-Pollution Switch
description: After years of lobbying by environmentalists, and under pressure from Gov. George E. Pataki, the Transit Authority has agreed to replace about 500 diesel buses with ones that use natural gas or electricity in what supporters say may be the biggest anti-pollution measure the authority has ever taken.

title: Prudential, Outbid, Loses $4 Billion of A.A.R.P. Work
description: Outbidding the Prudential Insurance Company, the United Healthcare Corporation has won the huge health insurance business of the American Association of Retired Persons.

title: A Crime-Cartel Indictment
description: Four organized crime families formed a cartel to control a multimillion-dollar bootleg gasoline scheme that was conducted by Russian immigrants, Federal prosecutors said yesterday. An indictment was unsealed yesterday charging three men, including Daniel Pagano, a high-ranking member of the Genovese crime family, with helping to run the cartel. Calling itself the Association, the group included representatives from the Genovese, Gambino, Lucchese and Columbo crime families and showed a level of cooperation that prosecutors described as reminiscent of the New York organized crime Commission of the 1980's. The Association set prices for the bootleggers, assigned territories and collected a ''mob tax'' from the other gangs, according to the indictment.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in some editions of the Business Digest yesterday referred erroneously to an article about a donation to Harvard University. The article is planned for a future issue.

title: Alien Beings Abduct Pop Culture
description: ANYONE stopping in for a game of pool and a Rolling Rock at the Hudson Grill in SoHo is greeted by an E.T.-like figure waving from the window.

title: Orioles' Best Moves Are Moves Not Made
description: No one knows yet how far the strategies of summer will carry contending teams such as the Baltimore Orioles or the Yankees this fall.

title: Heavyweight Brawl on Lightweight Airport
description: A lot of people in this city of political junkies and armchair Machiavellians are scratching their heads these days.

title: Ban on Neon Signs Defied
description: A municipal judge ruled last week that Long Hill Township has the right to ban neon signs for aesthetic reasons. But two restaurateurs said yesterday that they will continue to defy the ordinance while they appeal Judge James D. Bride's ruling. Laura Krueger, owner of Diane's Country Kitchen, said she has turned off her ''catering'' and ''deli'' signs but will keep her ''open'' sign lit. Anthony Giardino, the owner of Calabria II pizzeria, said he will follow suit. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Mason Believes Ewing May Have Forced Him Out
description: Anthony Mason and Patrick Ewing are no longer teammates, and that is probably a good thing.

title: Trial of Officer in a Fatal Arrest Begins
description: In a Bronx courtroom filled with off-duty police officers and the teary-eyed relatives of the victim, the trial of a police officer charged in the choking death of a man he was trying to arrest began yesterday with no jury and with palpable animosity between the two sides.

title: Saratoga Extends '97 Season
description: The racing season at Saratoga next summer will be increased, as expected, by two days. The days will be added to the start of the meeting to stretch it to six full weeks from July 23 through Labor Day, Sept. 1. The trustees of the New York Racing Association, at their monthly meeting yesterday at Belmont Park, accepted the proposal of Kenny Noe Jr., chairman and president of the association, who said: ''Labor Day weekend was very successful in Saratoga. Certainly, it was much stronger than business would have been at Belmont Park.''

title: More P.S.E.&G. Harassment
description: In 1992, Public Service Electric & Gas harassed and intimidated two engineers who had raised safety concerns at the company's Salem nuclear power plant, regulators found. Now, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission says that P.S.E.&G. has again harassed one of the whistleblowers, along with a supervisor who stood up for him. The regulators said that after the utility was fined $80,000 for the earlier violations, the utility transferred the engineer, Paul Craig, to a job for which he was unqualified, hurting his chances for promotion, said Diane Screnci, a spokeswoman for the agency. His supervisor, William Cianfrani, was given a negative performance review. The N.R.C. met with company officials yesterday and will decide within 30 days whether to fine the company a minimum of $50,000, Ms. Screnci said.

title: Foreman Tells Fans Not to Pay Freight
description: GEORGE FOREMAN has some advice for boxing fans who plunk down big money for pay-per-view events like last Saturday night's 109-second MIKE TYSON-BRUCE SELDON heavyweight fight. Don't do it.

title: King Forced to Step In / Pedophile Scandal Just One of Many : Belgium's Confidence Crisis Is Deepening
description: CHARLEROI, Belgium  As law-enforcement teams move deeper into what appears to be a network of pedophiles, prostitution traffickers and car thieves based around this decaying city, fresh evidence is emerging of a substantially broader crisis in Belgian society. Many Belgians now wonder if an undercurrent of mafia-style criminality and corruption has been governing their society.

title: Council Approves Restrictions on Beggars
description: The New York City Council approved a bill yesterday that would allow the police to arrest squeegee men, beggars at automatic teller machines and other aggressive panhandlers.

title: Sun Is Willing to Offer Cash for Chateau Properties
description: Sun Communities Inc., one of the three publicly traded mobile home park operators currently wooing shareholders of Chateau Properties Inc., said yesterday that it was willing to offer cash for Chateau shares.

title: Photographers Look Inward, and Discover Self-Doubt
description: The annual gathering of photojournalists in this southern French city is called a festival. In fact, it resembles a convention, with some 2,000 photographers, photo editors and photo agents from all over the world evidently less interested in displaying their wares to the public than in meeting one another, doing business and reflecting on the state of their profession.

title: Youth Shot Outside School
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager standing outside Canarsie High School was shot in the right leg and buttocks yesterday morning by two people who fled in a car, the police said.

title: Adelphi Provost Defends Officials at Regents Hearing, Telling of a 'Survival Mission'
description: Adelphi University was barely muddling along a decade ago, poorly organized and in need of revitalization, a top official of the university testified yesterday.

title: A Friendship In Tatters Over Policy
description: After receiving national acclaim for a speech at her Wellesley commencement, Hillary Rodham was invited to address The League of Women Voters' 1970 convention in Colorado Springs as a ''young leader of the future.''

title: Ex-Mayor in Bribery Case to Be Freed on Bail
description: A Federal court in Bridgeport ruled yesterday that former Mayor Joseph J. Santopietro of Waterbury and the former Republican chairman in the city, Perry A. Piscotti, should be freed on bond while they pursue appeals of their 1992 convictions on Federal corruption charges.

title: Cigar 2-5 in Field of Six for Woodward Tomorrow
description: Only five horses were entered yesterday to test the great Cigar when he makes his first New York appearance in nearly a year in the Woodward Stakes tomorrow at Belmont Park.

title: Clinton Sows a Little and Reaps a Lot in California
description: President Clinton swooped down on California today both bearing and seeking gifts, offering a daytime dollop of new Federal money to help communities start innovative schools and raising a nighttime nest egg for the Democratic Party with a little help from the stars.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about American threats to mount a new military strike against Iraq misstated the scope of a restricted zone in southern Iraq in which Iraqi ground troops are prohibited from massing. That zone extends only up to the 32d parallel, and was not expanded northward to the 33d parallel last week along with the so-called no-flight zone, from which Iraqi military planes are barred.

title: From the Court Jews' Uneasy Heyday
description: WHO could forget the sight of the old Jewish cemetery in Prague on a misty autumn night? Behind high walls, hundreds of tombstones tilt and lean like a host of spirits in conversation, at the heart of an ancient city that once held the world's largest Jewish population and some of Europe's greatest shuls and yeshivas.

title: Domecq Importers Adds Weiss, Whitten
description: Domecq Importers, a unit of Allied Domecq P.L.C., said yesterday that it had added Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano in New York to its roster by naming that shop as the first agency to handle advertising in the United States for Tres Generaciones, a so-called superpremium brand of tequila. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Conservatives Out of Sidelines As Religious Coalition Gathers
description: A month after the Republican Party showcased prominent moderates at its convention in San Diego, the Christian Coalition, a powerfully influential force on Republicans, will provide a forum for full-throated conservatism when it opens its ''Road to Victory'' conference today in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a hearing on airline security before the House Transportation Aviation Subcommittee misspelled the name of the panel's ranking Democrat. He is William O. Lipinski.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-12

title: Shouting's Over. Now, Bosnians Vote.
description: On a week of warm late-summer days, with the colors beginning to turn in this leafy city, crowds have gathered here for a flurry of political rallies. One afternoon, the platform was occupied by an infamous warlord and his party; a few hours later, it belonged to an even more extremist nationalist party.

title: Divers Searching to the West Find No New Crash Clues
description: When investigators looking for wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 pushed the search another half mile west two weeks ago, they hoped they would finally find the critical missing pieces that would explain what blasted the jumbo jet from the sky.

title: Deane Malott, 98, Educator Who Ran Two Universities
description: Deane W. Malott, a business-minded educator who led the University of Kansas and Cornell University through periods of significant growth, died on Wednesday at his home at Cornell in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 98.

title: Blair Walliser, 87, Director of Radio Serials
description: Blair Walliser, a director and writer who was a pioneer in radio drama during radio's golden age, died on Aug. 31 in New York Hospital. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: If Clinton Sees Votes in South, He's Not Just Whistling Dixie
description: The most remarkable thing about Bob Dole's visit to Tennessee this week, his third in the last month, was that he had to come here at all.

title: Pitino Not a Defendant
description: A judge dismissed Kentucky Coach RICK PITINO and Athletic Director C. M. NEWTON as defendants yesterday in a discrimination lawsuit filed by a former men's basketball trainer, JoANN HAUSER.

title: August Producer Price Report Shows Inflation in Check
description: Inflation fundamentally remained in check last month, even though hefty increases for food and energy drove producer prices up three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the second-biggest rise this year, a Labor Department report showed today.

title: Culture and Commerce Live Side by Side in SoHo
description: It's back. The downtown art scene shifted into gear last week with three frenzied nights of gallery openings in Chelsea and SoHo. Especially SoHo. There, the end of summer was signaled by the uneven cultural melange that is the fourth annual SoHo Arts Festival.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Blood Baths and Bad Men
description: Gunshot by gunshot, symbol by symbol, Michael Covert's satirical film ''American Strays'' pounds you over the head so relentlessly with its allegorical pretensions that it leaves you irritatedly wondering, what hath Quentin Tarantino wrought? As this leaden spoof of American violence (and the films that exalt it) follows an assortment of gun-packing movie stereotypes down a highway in the Mojave Desert, it is only a matter of time before they converge on a last-chance eatery named Red's Desert Oasis. No sooner have they arrived than their collective frustrations explode in an orgiastic shootout.

title: Pytka Receives Top Honors Again
description: For the fourth consecutive year, Pytka, the commercial production company in Venice, Calif., led by the director Joe Pytka, has taken top honors at the fourth annual Cresta International Advertising Awards.

title: Another C.I.A. Disaster
description: The spectacle of the Central Intelligence Agency's officers fleeing their base in northern Iraq this month, abandoning their Kurdish agents, is but another dark chapter in the annals of C.I.A. covert operations.

title: Paddling Down the Hudson, Slowly
description: WE launched at Catskill, N.Y., from a public park just below the Rip Van Winkle Bridge, in the dense, warm air of a fog lifting at dawn. There, about 30 miles south of Albany, the Hudson River, its sleepy girth about 1,000 yards across, moved lazily southward, and we were grateful for its laziness, neither of us (I had solicited the aid of a friend for the occasion) having been in a canoe in some years. The water was bath warm, and we were grateful for that, too.

title: Victim of Bounty Hunters Wins $1 Million
description: A Federal jury awarded a woman $1.15 million yesterday for an ordeal that began on a warm night two summers ago, when she was handcuffed in front of her Manhattan home and told that she was someone else.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Buzz Enterprises Promotes Four
description: Buzz Enterprises in Los Angeles, which publishes Buzz magazine and Buzz Weekly, announced top-level executive changes yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Chief Wrote Clinton Aide Who Amassed Personal Files
description: Letters obtained by Congressional investigators show that Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. wrote to Craig Livingstone, the dismissed White House security chief, five times in the months during which Mr. Livingstone and other Presidential aides were obtaining hundreds of background files from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Art in Review
description: Yeong Gill Kim

title: Growth Factor: It's a Force of Will
description: These days, when the glamorous nut case Norma Desmond announces, ''I am big'' early in the Broadway musical ''Sunset Boulevard,'' the audience starts laughing even before she reaches her famous tag line: ''It's the pictures that got small.'' That's because Miss Desmond is now being portrayed by Elaine Paige, the celebrated English musical actress, who has taken over from Betty Buckley and who stands at under five feet.

title: Buick's new campaign hopes families will feel safe and secure in their full-size LeSabres.
description: THE rubber hits the road for the new marketing methods of the General Motors Corporation with the introduction of the 1997 models. Those watching for the changes need look no further than the Buick division.

title: Norman, Els Join All the Presidents' Men
description: Because of its proximity to the Civil War battlefields of Manassas, it seems fitting to analyze the second biennial playing of the Presidents Cup in military terms. The International team, badly outmanned and outgunned by the United States team two years ago in the first battle of Manassas -- Bull Run for all you Yankees -- has come to the second staging this year with some reinforcements that could change the entire face of this golfing conflict.

title: Boyhood Dream Builds More Than a Mountain
description: A poor boy with grand dreams, John VanBarriger was 15 years old when he tried to run away from flat Illinois to the mountains of the American West. The authorities caught him just 20 miles down the road, and he ended up going to Boys Town instead.

title: KANSAS CITY UTILITY IS REBUFFED ON PURCHASE
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said yesterday that a preliminary count of proxy votes indicated that its shareholders had rejected a plan to buy Utilicorp United Inc., a victory for a rival Kansas utility, Western Resources Inc., which is pursuing a hostile bid for Kansas City Power. Western Resources, based in Topeka, Kan., had said last month that the Kansas City Power shareholders had rejected the Utilicorp deal. Kansas City Power said, however, that the apparent defeat of the Utilicorp plan did not mean that shareholders would accept the $1.9 billion offer from Western Resources. Kansas City Power, like Utilicorp, is based in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Short Course in Judaism, Especially for New Year
description: It was an unusual sight two days before Rosh ha-Shanah, an Orthodox rabbi in the library of a Reform synagogue, talking about God to an audience that included skeptics and the unaffiliated.

title: Bond Prices Up Modestly On Price Data
description: Bond prices rose modestly yesterday, following the release of data that showed a decline in last month's core wholesale prices. The decline in the core rate served to reinforce the market's perceptions that inflation was not accelerating.

title: Appreciations and Agendas
description: The grand scale of Avery Fisher Hall was appropriate for the 20th-anniversary gala concert of the New York Chamber Symphony on Wednesday evening. There were far too many tributes, agendas and, in Richard Danielpour's ''Canticle of Peace,'' performers to fit comfortably on the stage of either the orchestra's old home, the 92d Street Y, or its new one, Alice Tully Hall.

title: Watson's Remarks Confound Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner sounded bemused and exasperated today while reacting to General Manager Bob Watson's surprising contention that both he and Manager Joe Torre should be dismissed if the Yankees collapse and mishandle what was once a brawny 12-game bulge in the American League East. The owner who would enact the dismissals is not ready to dispense any. Yet.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: One Fine Day at the Brill Building
description: A lovely moment in Allison Anders's ''Grace of My Heart'' finds Denise Waverly (Illeana Douglas) and Howard Cazsatt (Eric Stoltz), her lover and songwriting partner, in the legendary Brill Building on Broadway, sitting at the piano discussing a number about teen-age romance.

title: In Zaire, They Finally Ask, Who Follows Mobutu?
description: From the time he seized power in 1965 with covert Western support, through 31 years of one-man rule, President Mobutu Sese Seko has boasted of being the only person capable of holding Africa's third largest country together.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Federal District Court Judge HAROLD BAER JR. presided over his first naturalization ceremony last Friday and decided that more pageantry was needed.

title: Thunder on El Salvador's Right
description: The peace accords that ended El Salvador's 12-year civil war in 1992 are helping Salvadorans address problems through political institutions instead of violence. But recent upheavals in El Salvador's right-wing Arena party threaten this peace dividend and the country's democratic future.

title: In City Opera's 'Falstaff,' A Comic Sherrill Milnes
description: Attach no symbols to Wednesday night's ''Falstaff'' at the New York City Opera. The production is borrowed, the featured performer a brief visitor from the Metropolitan Opera next door. But take a little courage as well. Verdi's last opera -- a work of racehorse momentum and intricate musical machinery -- is not the kind of piece the City Opera has ever had time to be good at. But it was good at it here. If this unusual evening speaks to the essence of Paul Kellogg's new regime or if it is simply accidental to it, ''Falstaff'' generated pleasure.

title: The City's Right Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Court Gives Wife the Right to Her Embryos
description: In a landmark decision on reproductive rights, Israel's Supreme Court ruled today that a childless woman estranged from her husband could have their frozen embyros implanted in a surrogate against the husband's wishes.

title: People
description: * Paul Bonington, publisher of Web Week and Web Developer magazines, Westport, Conn., owned by the Mecklermedia Corp., was promoted to senior vice president and group publisher of the Mecklermedia magazine group. He assumes responsibilities from David Egan, the group's president and chief operating officer, who resigned.

title: A Sweet, Funny Dad. What's Not to Love?
description: And still another stand-up comic ventures into sitcom land. Tonight on CBS, Ray Romano comes to network prime time in ''Everybody Loves Raymond.'' And why not? Ray is a likable guy, as can easily be discerned in the ''Half-Hour Comedy'' special rattling around HBO's schedule. (HBO is a producer of this new series, and is evidently determined to make the most of its pioneeering stand-up specials and its aspiring stars, as, say, Roseanne Barr was way back when.)

title: $25 and Under
description: Tsampa seems to be a peaceful place, as might be expected of a Tibetan restaurant. The spare interior of polished wood and brick, the handmade rugs hanging from the walls and the window niche in the rear, where a smiling Buddha sits before an ivied trellis, make Tsampa calm and restful, almost ripe for meditation.

title: Where Khmer Rouge Stroll In for a Can of Soda
description: Every morning, a Khmer Rouge guerrilla walks out of the Cambodian jungle, calls a greeting to the lone Thai border guard and buys three newspapers -- in Thai, Khmer and English -- that are delivered to this remote village especially for him.

title: World Heritage List Poses No Threat to U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole Accuses Clinton of Character Bashing
description: Bob Dole today lashed out at President Clinton for waging what he described as a ''character assassination'' by television advertising, even as Mr. Dole's aides disclosed that they were preparing to escalate their own advertising campaign against Mr. Clinton in both scope and tone.

title: Keep Vendetta Out of Gingrich Ethics Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Sends Another Carrier To Bolster Mideast Forces
description: The Pentagon dispatched a second aircraft carrier to the Middle East today, expanding American firepower in the region as the United States prepared for a new attack on Iraq.

title: $500 Million Offer for Poor
description: Fleet Financial Group announced yesterday that it will lend $500 million in poor neighborhoods in New Jersey to mollify community groups that object to its acquisition of NatWest Bancorp. Fleet, which is based in Boston, agreed to make loans to businesses and homeowners over a three-year period after lengthy talks with several groups that accused it of neglecting the poor, Bloomberg Business News reported. One group, New Jersey Citizen Action, had rejected an offer by Fleet to make $475 million in loans over six years.

title: Art in Review
description: Leonardo Drew

title: Children Need Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Xerox loses sale of its insurance units, and the market trembles.
description: FOR several years now, the Xerox Corporation has been telling Wall Street to ignore the insurance operations it so unwisely bought in 1983 and to judge it as a document-processing company alone.

title: Nation of Islam Guards Ordered to Leave Housing Project
description: The Pataki administration has ordered the managers of a state-financed housing project in Brooklyn to break a contract with a security group associated with the Nation of Islam, responding to complaints that the group has been passing out anti-Semitic literature.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about widespread confusion in the primary elections in Brooklyn included an incorrect given name in some editions for the winner of the Republican primary in the 23d State Senatorial district. He is John M. Gangemi, not Robert.

title: Hawks Sign Corbin and Burton
description: The Atlanta Hawks signed the veteran forwards TYRONE CORBIN, who played with the team during the 1994-95 season, and WILLIE BURTON to contracts yesterday. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Out of Kilter in a Predatory Society
description: SUSPECTS

title: INSIDE
description: Yeltsin Doctors Seek Advice

title: Shedding Light on Drug Use in Pro Football
description: Motivated partly by the Michael Irvin and the Bam Morris criminal drug cases and Brett Favre's rehabilitation for abusing painkillers, ESPN's ''N.F.L. Countdown,'' HBO's ''Real Sports'' and CBS's ''60 Minutes'' have made drug use in the National Football League a ripe topic for their examination.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: New Jersey Auditors Must Meet Test
description: To the Editor:

title: New York's Newest Invaders: Tree-Eating Beetles From Asia
description: Strange, large aliens with long antennae and big appetites have appeared and begun to chew their way through trees in New York City.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City tomorrow and Sunday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Leading From Weakness
