description: One year ago NATO aircraft bombed the Bosnian Serb leaders into ending their genocidal aggression. Faced for the first time with a determined use of force by the West, they called off their campaign of terror and mass murder.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Make Way for Goslings
description: The tender beauty of Carroll Ballard's ''Fly Away Home'' goes well beyond what might be expected from a movie about things that hatch. Rekindling the delicacy and invigorating naturalness he brought to ''The Black Stallion,'' and again helped immensely by the radiant cinematography of Caleb Deschanel, Mr. Ballard turns a potentially treacly children's film into an exhilarating 90's fable. It concerns family, ecology, adolescence and, above all (quite literally), geese. See it and you will never look at a down comforter in quite the same way.

title: Immigration Excuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Declines to Penalize Principal for an Illicit Gym
description: Suggesting that the case had not been worth prosecuting, a judge in Brooklyn refused yesterday to impose a penalty on a former school principal convicted of diverting $2,200 in school money to set up a weight-lifting and exercise room at his school for himself and his teachers.

title: Berkshire Gives a Vote of Confidence to Salomon
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment firm controlled by Warren E. Buffett, said late yesterday that it expected to convert 140,000 preferred shares into the common stock of Salomon Inc. this year, raising its holding to almost 10 percent of the big Wall Street firm.

title: Yeltsin Team For Surgery Seeks Advice From Abroad
description: American and other foreign doctors will help evaluate President Boris N. Yeltsin's heart condition and may assist in the planned surgery, Russian officials disclosed today.

title: Inside Photography
description: People in the business of looking after photographs know that negatives need to be stored in cool, dry, reasonably dust-free places. It so happens that one of the world's largest and oldest photographic archives has been sitting in a hot and dusty attic for a century. Not any old attic, mind you. This one, called the ''high attic'' because of its 36-foot ceilings, is above the three domes in the Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: For Children
description: Appalachian Trail

title: Morris Loses Another Client
description: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president who is expected to run for mayor next year, said yesterday that he had severed his professional relationship with Dick Morris, the political consultant who resigned from President Clinton's campaign after a tabloid reported that he had had a relationship with a prostitute.

title: For Would-Be Bookworms, A Lineup of Greatest Hits
description: It's a wall-to-wall book weekend on the Learning Channel. Beginning at 9 A.M. tomorrow and stretching into the early hours of Monday, you can immerse yourself in the Western canon, from ''The Odyssey'' and Plato's ''Republic'' to ''The Scarlet Letter'' and ''Moby-Dick'' to ''Native Son'' and ''Catch-22.''

title: British Aerospace Says First-Half Profit Jumped
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose strongly in the first half because of productivity gains that yielded stronger profits from military work and lower commercial plane losses.

title: A New Program to Fix Up the Eyesore on the Block
description: In a block of historic brownstones, their cast-iron balustrades freshly painted, their front gardens beautifully manicured, the house at 198 McDonough Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn stands out.

title: Art in Review
description: Kathleen Gilje

title: America Behind Fences
description: The Presidential commission on aviation security turned in a report that was carefully thought out, presented 60 proposals for protecting American passengers against terrorism and began with the critical message: Antiterrorism rests on a policy of pursuing terrorists and punishing not only them but the nations that sponsor them.

title: On a Noir and Stormy Night
description: Is Josie Potenza really the dumbsel in distress she appears to be?

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Berlin Philharmonic did not object to performing with a substitute conductor, but PAUL SCOFIELD, the British actor, astonished London theatergoers last week when he refused to perform with an understudy.

title: Victim's Kin Testify At Trial Of Officer
description: It was their last night together before some returned to Florida for Christmas with their families: four brothers playing touch football at midnight outside their childhood home in the Bronx. Two hours later, one, Anthony Baez, lay face down and motionless on the concrete and two others sat handcuffed in the back of a police car.

title: Art in Review
description: 'La Toilette de Venus'

title: With Loss of A.A.R.P. Work, Many Think Prudential Will Be Reshaped
description: Following the Prudential Insurance Company's loss of a roughly $4 billion health insurance contract, Prudential executives and industry analysts said yesterday that they expected a major restructuring of the 120-year-old company's health care business.

title: BTR of Britain Plans Sale of Power Unit
description: BTR P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its electric power unit, Hawker Siddeley Electric Power, to FKI P.L.C. for $:182.5 million, or $283.8 million, in cash, continuing a string of asset sales. The unit, which includes a group of companies that make transformers, generators, motors and other electrical equipment, had operating profit before charges last year of $:19.7 million on sales of $:252.9 million.

title: A Treaty That Deserved to Die
description: An extraordinary thing happened in the Senate yesterday. The proponents of the Chemical Weapons Convention surprisingly pulled the plug on their effort to obtain immediate Senate approval of the treaty's ratification.

title: The Riddler of Modernism
description: IS there a stranger case among the great artists of the 20th century than Giorgio de Chirico? The images he painted at the start of his career, in the 1910's, have been so completely absorbed into our visual subconscious that it's actually difficult to see what made them startling in the first place. You can't imagine Atget or Hitchcock or Bunuel, much less their innumerable progeny, without de Chirico's empty piazzas and weird combinations of objects. At the same time, it's hard to be shocked by his Surreal images, which are cliches by now.

title: Two in Family Are Slain In Shooting In Chappaqua
description: A domestic dispute turned deadly on Wednesday night as three members of a family were shot, two of them fatally, here in one of Westchester's toniest suburbs.

title: ORACLE'S FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS BELOW EXPECTATIONS
description: The Oracle Corporation reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings were short of expectations as software sales increased more slowly than analysts had predicted. Net income rose to $113 million, or 17 cents a share, from $54 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter ended Aug. 31 rose 36 percent, to $1.05 billion. The earnings were a penny below the 18-cent average estimate of 19 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Oracle, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., announced the earnings after the close of the markets. In after-hours trading, the company's shares first fell, then rose to $38, up 50 cents from the closing price of $37.50.

title: U.S. Said to Tell Archer It May Face Charges Soon
description: It's white-knuckle time at the Archer Daniels Midland Company.

title: Home Video
description: Still Waiting for Digital Disks

title: Ratso Rizzo's Long-Lost Son
description: RATSO RIZZO, Dustin Hoffman's down-and-out character in ''Midnight Cowboy,'' may have died on a bus trip from New York to Florida, but his ghost haunts David Mamet's dankly effective adaptation of his 1975 play ''American Buffalo.'' It is not a happy picture. In the film, directed by Michael Corrente, Mr. Hoffman gnaws at the role of Teach, a motor-mouthed small-time hustler and spiritual descendant of Ratso with a fussy, beady-eyed avidity that is as repellent as it is creepily fascinating.

title: Williams's Grand Display Lights Up Scoreboard
description: The lasers and liners caromed around cozy Tiger Stadium this afternoon, turning it into a neighborhood batting cage. The nagging problem for the Yankees was that David Cone, and not a mechanical pitching machine, was offering up the fat pitches and absorbing the unsettling abuse. Cone and Bernie Williams made sure that changed in drastic and dramatic fashion.

title: Bomb Judge Bars Meeting By Prosecutor
description: Frederic Whitehurst, a chemist who was the F.B.I.'s leading bomb-residue expert at the time of the Oklahoma City bombing, has contended that critical evidence in the case was mishandled and wants to tell about it to prosecution and defense lawyers at the same time.

title: Feast of San Gennaro Returns, a Lot Saintlier, Officials Say
description: By early yesterday afternoon, the bronze-and-silver statue of the patron saint of Naples was already festooned with dollar bills, his right hand raised as if to bless the start of New York City's oldest and grandest street fair, the Feast of San Gennaro.

title: Injuries Put Two New Faces in the Jets Defense: Chalenski and Cascadden
description: One used to experiment on sheeps' hearts; the other used to take a beating in the boxing ring from his college roommate.

title: ABC Lines Up 'Lion King' and Spike Lee
description: The Walt Disney-owned ABC television network announced yesterday that ABC would show the wildly successful Disney movie ''The Lion King'' in November, the first time one of Disney's modern-era animated feature films has been shown on broadcast television.

title: Apple and Hewlett In Printer Talks
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it had entered discussions with the Hewlett-Packard Company to collaborate on the development of ink-jet printers.

title: The Undrafted Ellsworth Is Being Noticed by Giants
description: When Percy Ellsworth signed with the Giants, his bonus was about $10,000. To many professional athletes, that's pocket change. To get an idea where that ranks in the bonus standing, compare that with the $4 million lump sum that Dave Brown received when the Giants' quarterback recently signed his new deal.

title: Restaurants
description: Nova Grill fooled me.

title: Ernesto Geisel, 88, Is Dead; Eased Military Rule in Brazil
description: Former President Ernesto Geisel, the Brazilian military dictator associated with the gradual reopening of Brazil to the outside world, died in a Rio clinic today. He was 88.

title: Metra of Finland to Buy Diesel Operations in Italy
description: Metra Oy, a Finnish maker of diesel engines, said yesterday that it would acquire the diesel-engine operations of Fincantieri Cantieri Navali Italiani S.p.A. of Italy in a transaction valued at about $1.4 billion. After the acquisition, a new company will be formed by merging several diesel engine operations that Metra owns, including operations in Finland and Switzerland, with 40 percent of Fincantieri's motor division, Grandi Motori.

title: Tudor Investment Agrees to S.E.C. Fines
description: The Tudor Investment Corporation, headed by Paul Tudor Jones 2d, has agreed to pay $800,000 in fines after a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation uncovered trades that could be construed as an attempt to manipulate the market.

title: Don't Start New York on School Vouchers Path
description: To the Editor:

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP EXPANDS IN FLORIDA
description: Colonial Bancgroup Inc. of Montgomery, Ala., said yesterday that it would acquire Jefferson Bancorp Inc. of Miami Beach for about $76 million in stock, expanding its Florida network. In the deal, Colonial Bancgroup is getting nine offices in South Florida, $440 million in assets and $200 million in trust accounts under management. Colonial said it would pay $18.90 a share for Jefferson Bancorp. Jefferson's shares closed yesterday at $17.375, up $2.125. When the cost of buying outstanding options on Jefferson stock is included, the total purchase price would be about $76 million. Colonial had assets of $4.7 billion, and 132 branches. Colonial shares closed unchanged at $35.

title: Oasis Abruptly Cancels Rest of Its U.S. Tour
description: Oasis, the top British pop band, which performed last weekend at Jones Beach, pulled out of the remainder of its American tour Wednesday night. The band's manager, Marcus Russell, issued a statement citing ''internal difficulties.''

title: Immigrants' Anxieties Spur A Surge in Naturalizations
description: At the George R. Brown Convention Center here today, more than 6,000 people from 80 countries stood and took the oath to become citizens of the United States. Next Tuesday at Texas Stadium, where the Dallas Cowboys play their home games, 10,000 people will do so.

title: Dole's Immigration Stance Splits G.O.P.
description: A bill that would crack down on illegal immigration has exposed deep divisions among House and Senate Republicans, many of whom calculate that the best course for them might not serve the best interests of Bob Dole's struggling Presidential campaign.

title: Writer's Block On Mound
description: YANKEE fans are in a panic.

title: Putting Some Zip into a Zone
description: Officials of the state Commerce Department say Camden has enlivened its planning for an Urban Enterprise Zone. Three months after they attacked Camden's plans as less than aggressive and cut off state funding for the program, they have decided to lift the freeze. On Wednesday, state officials approved a $4.3 million plan, to be financed by sales taxes, that will include the expansion of a shopping center and create a job-training center and an industrial park. In enterprise zones, merchants are allowed to charge a sales tax of 3 percent instead of 6 percent.

title: Gillette to Buy Duracell for $7 Billion
description: In a transaction that combines two of the world's best-known names in consumer products, the Gillette Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Duracell International Inc. for approximately $7 billion in stock.

title: 2 Big French Banks Report Strong Earnings
description: Two of the biggest banks in France reported double-digit first-half earnings growth yesterday. Banque Nationale de Paris S.A., France's fourth-largest bank in terms of assets, said profit rose a greater-than-expected 80 percent during the period to 1.735 billion francs ($336.7 million). And Credit Commercial de France, which ranks among the country's most profitable lenders, said first-half earnings rose 12 percent, to 669 million francs.

title: Joanne Dru, 74, a Star of Movie Westerns
description: Joanne Dru, who starred opposite John Wayne in the westerns ''Red River'' and ''She Wore a Yellow Ribbon,'' died on Tuesday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 74.

title: Stock Prices Post Strong Increases
description: Stocks rose yesterday as a Government report showed scant signs of inflation amid surprisingly strong economic growth and corporate profits. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day up 17.02, to 5,771.94, within 7 points of 5,778, its best finish ever.

title: For Fallen Clinton Aide, Forum for Ethics Lecture
description: How the fallen have risen.

title: Here Comes the Bride, Fleeing Thugs
description: 1. A Quentin Tarantino cameo.

title: The Major Networks Lead Emmy Awards for News
description: The major broadcast networks won most of the news and documentary Emmy Awards for programs shown in 1995, handed out last night in Manhattan. ABC and NBC won 10 Emmys apiece, while CBS and PBS won 7 each, of 47 awards given by the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

title: Bosnia's Vote: Anarchic Democracy
description: Prospects for a smooth election on Saturday did not look good today.

title: 'Mondo Cane' Via Internet
description: What do virtual reality, digital imaging, cosmetic surgery, Las Vegas theme hotels, Prozac, cryogenics, space exploration and intelligence-enhancing drinks have in common? In Iara Lee's smart, entertaining, occasionally scary documentary film, ''Synthetic Pleasures,'' they are all shown to be expressions of the human struggle for omnipotence and ultimately for immortality.

title: U.S. TO HELP FREE REFUGEES IN IRAQ
description: The Clinton Administration said today that the United States would help evacuate more than 2,000 refugees who had worked with its military and relief operations in northern Iraq and grant many of them asylum.

title: NEWBRIDGE BUYING A STAKE IN BROADBAND NETWORKS
description: The Newbridge Networks Corporation said yesterday that it would increase its presence in the wireless communications market by buying 15 percent of Broadband Networks Inc. for an undisclosed price. In recent months, Newbridge has increasingly focused on developing hardware for wireless communications in addition to its traditional business of making switching systems for fixed voice and data networks. Newbridge, which is based in Ottawa, and Broadband Networks, which is based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, intend to develop switching products for an emerging wireless technology that allows computer users to log onto the Internet, make long-distance phone calls or watch cable television through a satellite dish that catches and beams signals from a computer converting unit.

title: SENATE PERSUADED BY DOLE TO SHELVE POISON GAS TREATY
description: Just three months after he resigned from the Senate, Bob Dole reached back today into the legislative process to kill a treaty banning the production of poison gas and to try to derail an immigration bill that he feared President Clinton would claim as his own.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Advance Strongly On Producer-Prices Report

title: Avoiding the Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: STONE CONTAINER SELLS FOREST PRODUCTS UNITS
description: The Stone Container Corporation said yesterday that it had sold most of its forest products operations to U.S. Forest Industries, a new corporation formed by management of the division and an investment group. Stone said it expected to take an after-tax charge estimated at $10 million against third-quarter earnings as a result of the sale. Sales of these assets, along with the previously announced liquidation of certain other forest products assets, are expected to provide proceeds of more than $100 million, mostly in cash, Stone said. The businesses being sold had revenues of $100 million in 1995. Stone's fiber procurement operations, which provide raw materials for the company's paper mills, were not sold.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a company's plan to capitalize on the high demand for Internet addresses omitted part of the name of the federally financed research center where World Wide Web browser software was developed. It was the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign.

title: J.C. PENNEY SAYS IT PLANS TO OPEN 100 NEW STORES
description: The J.C. Penney Company plans to open 100 stores by 1998, spending $700 million to build the new outlets and modernize existing ones, the company's president said yesterday. The president, W. Barger Tygart, said the retailer had been updating its private label offerings and planned to broaden its men's clothing line. J.C. Penney, which is based in Plano, Texas, now has 1,250 stores.

title: Courts Will Balk
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: French Twist

title: Acts of Principle
description: Wendell Primus, a Deputy Assistant Secretary at the Department of Health and Human Services, resigned last month because he could not serve an Administration that had approved a welfare bill that, by his own calculations, would throw more than a million children into poverty.

title: No Headline
description: ''Everybody says that maybe now is a good time to become a citizen. If you're not, they're coming after you.''

title: Jamestown Fort, 'Birthplace' Of America in 1607, Is Found
description: On May 13, 1607, the first successful English settlement in what is now the United States got off to an unsteady start at a swampy island in a broad tidal river. The 104 settlers of the Virginia Company named the place James Fort, later Jamestown, after the sovereign for whom more than half would die in a few wretched months.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: A $5-a-Day Campaign

title: No Assault. Mayor Wins.
description: Sometimes a picture is worth a lot less than a thousand words. In June 1995, Mayor Anthony Russo of Hoboken was accused of assaulting a political rival who tried to photograph him inside a polling place, then stomping on the man's disposable camera. The rival, Francis Przygoda, whose wife was running for City Council, was even able to salvage photos that he claimed showed the mayor advancing on him.

title: Surgery for Randy Johnson
description: The Seattle Mariners' ace, RANDY JOHNSON, is expected to make a full recovery after undergoing surgery yesterday for a protruded disk.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS FOR WEEK THREE
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Mayor Moves an Ally to Schools Post
description: Howard Wilson, the city's Commissioner of Investigation for two and a half years, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to an unpaid position as chairman of the School Construction Authority, resigning a key position in which his watchdog agency forged the closest relationship with City Hall in two decades.

title: Whitaker Pumped For Rivera Rematch
description: Pernell Whitaker is convinced that he is still the best boxer, pound for pound, in the world. So after a sub-par performance in April, Whitaker (38-1-1) is eager for his rematch against Wilfredo Rivera (23-1-1), next Friday in Miami, for the World Boxing Council welterweight championship.

title: Education Panel Sees Deep Flaws In Training of Nation's Teachers
description: More than a quarter of newly hired teachers enter their classrooms with inadequate teaching skills or training in their subjects, according to a new report issued today by a nonpartisan national education panel.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: August

title: NESTLE AND HEINZ SUBSIDIARIES IN CANADA IN DEAL
description: Nestle Canada Inc. said this week that it had agreed to sell its Libby's canned beans and canned pasta business to the H. J. Heinz Company of Canada for an undisclosed amount. Included in the sale are a factory in Wallaceburg, Ontario, and products like Deep-Browned Beans, Alpha-Getti and Zoodles. Heinz will also receive a license to use the Libby's trademark for these products. Nestle Canada, a unit of the giant Swiss food processing concern Nestle S.A., said it would use proceeds from the sale to invest in ''strategic areas'' of growth, including its culinary category. H. J. Heinz of Canada is a unit of the H. J. Heinz Company of Pittsburgh.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Birdcage

title: Brenda Forbes, 87; Played Quirky Characters
description: Brenda Forbes, a character actress who gave vital support onstage to Katharine Cornell, Alfred Lunt, Lynn Fontanne and other stars during a career that lasted more than 60 years, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Lowly Rutgers No Match for Miami
description: A season expected to be a grim one for Rutgers is right on schedule. The Scarlet Knights lost their first Big East contest tonight, to Miami, 33-0, as the West Coast offense of their new coach, Terry Shea, again failed to go up and down the field.

title: New Yorkers, All
description: To the Editor:

title: Iverson and Sixers Agree
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have reached contract terms with ALLEN IVERSON, the No. 1 pick in the National Basketball Association draft and the player the team hopes will lead its revival.

title: Official Is Asked to Resign
description: Two longtime legislative critics of the state's psychiatric hospitals -- both Democrats -- yesterday urged the director of state mental health services to resign. The call for Alan J. Kaufman to step down as head of the agency that oversees operations of the state hospitals came one week after a patient at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital in Parsippany committed suicide. State Senators Richard J. Codey of West Orange and Gordon A. MacInnes of Denville said the mental health system was failing the most vulnerable citizens. But Human Services Commissioner William Waldman accused the two lawmakers of overreacting to the suicide.

title: A Hard Line Softened for Time Warner And Turner
description: When Robert Pitofsky won jurisdiction over Time Warner's proposed merger with the Turner Broadcasting System last year, consumer advocates and legal experts predicted the case would give the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission a ready-made platform for a new hard line on media mergers.

title: Demolition Derby Survives on Long Island And So Do Participants, Despite Themselves
description: Call it sport, spectacle or travesty, but demolition derby has indisputably claimed an ear-splitting, bargain-basement cranny of the American imagination since the first one crashed into existence at a Long Island track almost 40 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Ross Perot's choice of Pat Choate as his Vice-Presidential running mate referred imprecisely to Mr. Perot's relationship with Electronic Data Systems. He sold the company in 1984 and has had no role in it since 1986.

title: Ethnologists' Data Turn Out to Be Art
description: LITTLE-KNOWN fact of the week: the Brooklyn Museum established the first photographic department in an American museum in 1889, some 51 years before the Museum of Modern Art (which ordinarily gets the credit) had a department of its own. Brooklyn, however, was primarily a museum of natural history and anthropology, where you were as likely to see butterflies and bones as paintings of the American West. The Department of Photography, rich in ethnographic material, was blissfully unaware of art. In 1974, Barbara Head Millstein, the present curator, discovered a closet that had been locked since 1957; inside was the photographic collection, a good deal of which had been magically transformed into art in the interval by changing tastes and markets.

title: Kurds Wary of the Hidden Price of Turning On the Lights in Dohuk
description: In this Kurdish city, every bulb is lighted with power supplied by the central Government of Iraq, testament to years of rule by Massoud Barzani, a master of the deal.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Seven years after he first held a baton in his hand, DANIEL HARDING, 21, found himself conducting one of the world's best-known orchestras, the Berlin Philharmonic, on Wednesday .

title: Iraqi Rebels Fear They Are at Great Risk
description: The Iraqi opposition figures who fled to their headquarters building here after a Kurdish faction leader forged a partnership with the Iraqi Government said today that they believed their lives would be at risk unless they were evacuated quickly.

title: New Appetite Suppressor Is Found in Brain
description: A hormone recently discovered in the brains of both humans and rats acts as a powerful appetite suppressant in the rodents, scientists are reporting today.

title: LeClair's Pair Help U.S. Even Series and Force a Deciding Game
description: The World Cup of Hockey will be decided with a climactic match here Saturday night, the traditional hockey night in Canada, with Canadian pride, Canadian will and Canadian national identity at stake.

title: After a Shooting, a Protest
description: Joined by the Rev. Al Sharpton, the family of a woman who was killed during a struggle with a police officer, Wednesday denounced the shooting as an unjustified use of deadly force. ''I have not heard anyone come near to justifying this use of force,'' The Associated Press quoted Mr. Sharpton as telling about 75 people gathered near the site where Carolyn Adams was shot Tuesday. The authorities have said that Patrolman James Consalvo was trying to arrest Ms. Adams for solicitation when she bit his finger. The officer said he shot her when she refused to let go of his finger and tried to grab his gun, according to Robert Gluck, the Middlesex County prosecutor. On Wednesday,9/11 more than 200 people protested the shooting at police headquarters. TERRY PRISTIN

title: The Little Hitter Who Could
description: It began in the playgrounds of Cincinnati. That's where someone first told Lance Johnson he was too small to compete with the best. It continued at Princeton High School and at South Alabama, where he was selected to the All-Sun Belt Conference team as an outfielder. A lot of heart and desire, they said. Too bad he's so small.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FM PROPERTIES INC., New Orleans, a real estate company, agreed to sell the assets of its Circle C Land Corp. subsidiary to an unidentified investor group for $34 million.

title: Misery, Grime, Despair and the Next Stop, Incest
description: Adapted from a best-selling Austrian novel, Joseph Vilsmaier's ''Brother of Sleep'' tells the tale of a tormented musical prodigy. But this film unfolds far from the realm of royal patrons and powdered wigs. Set at the turn of the 19th century in a miserably unhappy Alpine village, it explores the suffering of Elias Johannes Alder (Andre Eisermann), who has an uncanny gift for playing the church organ. Both his talent and his agony are heightened by his mystical sensitivity to the sounds of the natural world.

title: Gillette and Duracell In $7 Billion Deal
description: In a deal that joins two household names, Gillette agreed to acquire Duracell, the world's leading producer of alkaline batteries, for about $7 billion in stock. The agreement, which the companies announced jointly, ends a five-year search by Gillette for what Alfred M. Zeien, its chairman and chief executive, has called a ''new leg'' acquisition, one that would take the company that makes everything from razors to toothbrushes to pens into a new product category.

title: Resignations Won't Disrupt Welfare Plans, Officials Say
description: Federal and state officials said today that the resignation of three Federal welfare officials would not significantly disrupt or delay work on the new welfare law signed last month by President Clinton because most of the important action had already shifted to the states.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: No Trick to Filling the Seats

title: Accounts
description: * Southern Tourism Society, Atlanta, to Austin Kelley Advertising, Atlanta, to develop an international campaign. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: UNION PACIFIC ANNOUNCES TERMS OF SPINOFF
description: The Union Pacific Corporation announced the terms yesterday for its previously announced spinoff to shareholders of its 83 percent stake in Union Pacific Resources, a natural gas and crude oil production company. Union Pacific plans to issue as a special dividend about 0.847 share of Union Pacific Resources for each share of Union Pacific stock. Union Pacific announced the spinoff, which included an initial offering of 17 percent of the subsidiary, in August 1995. The spinoff will occur on Oct. 15 to shareholders of record on Sept. 26.

title: City to Simplify Parking Signs (But Not Rules)
description: They are New York City's totem poles: stacks of cryptic symbols piled one atop another, often so bewildering and contradictory that even the initiated find them impossible to decipher.

title: Officials Consider Busing to Ease Overcrowding in Schools
description: Faced with the most severe overcrowding in decades, New York City school officials said yesterday that they were exploring ways to bus some children from the most crowded districts to schools in other areas of the city.

title: New Hope for Addicts?
description: Doctors and neighborhood groups responded positively this week when New York State cleared the way for a longer-lasting replacement to methadone, which heroin addicts take to stave off the symptoms of withdrawal. The new drug, called Orlaam, is taken three days a week, while methadone must be taken daily.

title: Messier Is Sick, Not Injured
description: Mark Messier, the Rangers' captain, did not play tonight for Team Canada when it faced the United States in Game 2 of the World Cup of Hockey tournament. Neil Smith, president and general manager of the Rangers, said Messier had the flu.

title: Kemp and Farrakhan
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Greig, 93, Fly-Fishing Expert And Sport Innovator
description: Elizabeth Greig, one of the country's most accomplished women at tying fly-fishing lures who was known for her adeptness and her unusual technique, died last Saturday at Highlands Lake Center-Genesis Eldercare in Lakeland, Fla. She was 93.

title: U.A.W. Is Just Trying to Hold Its Ground With Detroit
description: For decades after World War II, the Big Three auto makers' negotiations with the United Automobile Workers were the biggest show in labor relations. The highly ritualized spectacle was watched closely by executives and union leaders in other industries because the U.A.W. had a history of winning big concessions, like automatic cost-of-living adjustments and fully paid health care for retired workers, that soon spread to other businesses.

title: County Panel Makes a Hard Choice: Charity Over Prisons
description: It was a zero-sum choice that the Los Angeles County powers-that-be faced today: Spend $19 million on the poor or on the prisons.

title: The Senate's Votes on Gay Rights
description: The Senate came unexpectedly close this week to passing a long-overdue bill that would ban discrimination against homosexuals in the workplace. The measure failed by just a single vote, and the outcome could easily have gone the other way. One Democrat who might have voted in favor of the bill, David Pryor of Arkansas, was absent because of his son's cancer surgery, and Vice President Gore would have cast the deciding yes vote in the event of the tie.

title: $5 Billion Fund By Kohlberg Seen
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company is expected to raise $5 billion for its latest corporate buyout fund by next month, pension fund managers said yesterday.

title: Nasdaq Head Says He'll Stress Service
description: The ''next hundred years'' are going away.

title: Don't Siphon Gas Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking the Tower Elsewhere
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has decided to be a good neighbor and come up with a new site for a communication tower in Edison, a spokeswoman said yesterday. Many residents were opposed to the initial site because it was just 450 feet away from a school and a residential neighborhood.

title: An All-American Debut For a Washington Era
description: When Leonard Slatkin appeared onstage at the Kennedy Center on Thursday night to begin his first season as music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, the brass section greeted him with an impromptu fanfare and the audience gave him a prolonged standing ovation.

title: No Way to Go but On
description: About two million readers, if the mail is any indication, mistakenly think I am down on the good old days. Pshaw! The one subject guaranteed to leave me moist-eyed and garrulous after the second martini is ''The Good Old Days.''

title: Torre Running Out Of Options
description: JOE TORRE loves to tell the story of how a Milwaukee Braves team on which he played went into Philadelphia to play a Phillies team that held a three-and-a-half-game lead in the National League in the dying days of the 1964 season.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and Sunday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL SET TO PURCHASE MIDLAND BANCORP
description: Valley National Bancorp said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Midland Bancorp for about $96.3 million in stock. Midland Bancorp is the holding company for Midland Bank, based in Paramus, N.J., which has 13 branches and $405 million in assets. Valley National Bank, the principal unit of Valley National Bancorp of Wayne, N.J., has $4.6 billion in assets and 80 branches in New Jersey. Valley plans to exchange 30 of its shares for each the 125,294 Midland common shares. Valley's stock closed at $25.625 a share yesterday, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: If Nonwhites Need a Label, Give It Some Color
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Feels The Pressure Of Expectation
description: The players of Team Canada sat in the Montreal Canadiens dressing room, speaking in subdued voices. Above their lockers were the photographed faces of ancient, serious Habs and the printed words: ''To you from failing hands we throw the torch. Be yours to hold it high.''

title: Park Bomb Suspect May See Part of Files
description: A Federal magistrate ruled today that Richard A. Jewell, the security guard being investigated in the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park, could view parts of the documents used by Federal agents to justify searches of his property. But the magistrate prohibited Mr. Jewell or his lawyers from disclosing to the public anything about the documents.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a dispute in Congress over United States support for international population control efforts referred incorrectly to the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a research center. It receives some of its financing from Planned Parenthood, but since 1977 it has been independent.

title: Turks' Chief Surprisingly Silent on Iraq
description: For years before he came to power in June, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan preached the gospel of Muslim solidarity and promised that his Islamic-based Welfare Party would build a mighty alliance uniting Turkey with Iran, Iraq, Syria and other nearby countries.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Sony Ousts The Chairman Of Its Studios
description: Mark Canton, the head of the Sony studios, which have been hit by a string of box-office failures, was ousted today and replaced by Lucy Fisher, his second-in-command.

title: Annual City Rite: Kindergartners Wait for Seats
description: As the first full week of school drew to a close, elementary-school principals in New York City continued to struggle with a problem that plagues them each fall: finding seats for dozens of kindergarten students who show up unannounced on the first day of school.

title: City Police Open a Hot Line For Quality-of-Life Violations
description: In the city's latest attempt to crack down on so-called quality-of-life violations, the Police Department has started a toll-free telephone line allowing residents to report loud radios, aggressive panhandlers and other nonemergency violations of law or city ordinances.

title: Japan Says Its Economy Shrank for First Time Since '94
description: Japan's economy contracted in the second quarter, the first time economic output has declined since 1994's final quarter, but the Government said the nation's recovery was continuing.

title: On Eve of Election in Bosnia, Peace Is a Last Resort
description: With most of its villages in ruins, its forests and fields saturated with land mines, its infrastructure so devastated that an entire generation can expect little more than a life of drudgery and poverty, and its people plagued by memories of slaughter and loss, Bosnia can hardly be considered at peace.

title: R.P. Bunge, Spinal-Injury Expert, Dies at 64
description: Dr. Richard Paul Bunge, whose research advanced knowledge of the mechanisms of spinal cord injury in hopes of helping paralyzed people, died on Tuesday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 64.

title: Braves Get Soaked By Mets After Delay
description: It seems the longer the season goes on, the higher Bernard Gilkey drives up his market value.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Sept. 4 about American policy toward Iraq misspelled the given name of an expert on Iraq at the National Defense University. She is Phebe Marr, not Phoebe.

title: Mexico's Army Out of the Barracks
description: After a round of attacks by a newly emerged guerrilla organization, Mexico's armed forces have mobilized to hunt for the group in half a dozen states, assuming the highest public profile the military has had in half a century.

title: INSIDE
description: Politics in Tobacco Country

title: Remains of 2 More Crash Victims Found
description: Divers have found the remains of two more victims of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Suffolk County medical investigators said today. Of the 230 people who flew on the plane, the remains of 213 have now been found.

title: A Cultivator of Jazz Talent Who Operates on the Edge
description: On any given night, Mitchell Borden can usually be found on one of the 16 steps that lead down to his club, Smalls. Occasionally, if the weather's too humid, or he's bored, Mr. Borden rouses himself, leaves behind his paperback version of ''Bartlett's Quotations'' and a heavily underlined copy of the complete Keats, and hangs around on the sidewalk by the door. A compact man with a shaved head and Buster Keaton eyes, he seems an unlikely club owner. As the file of entering customers ignores him, he yells: ''Hey! The cover's $10.''

title: Plan to Cut TV Channel Angers Women's Groups
description: Plans by the nation's largest cable television company, Tele-Communications Inc., to drop the Lifetime Channel, a service aimed at women, from cable systems in several areas of the country have prompted an unusually angry, well-organized protest from women's groups and many prominent political figures, who call the decision a blow against the interests of women.

title: If Nonwhites Need a Label, Give It Some Color
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow at a Record 5,838.52; Bonds and the Dollar Rally

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES OF TOP TEAMS

title: U.S. Charges to a Big Lead in Presidents Cup
description: After two years' worth of additions and subtractions, after all the shake-ups and the firings designed to improve the International team, nothing has really changed at the Presidents Cup.

title: Haselrig Is Arrested in Kansas
description: Officials in Topeka, Kan., have arrested the former Pro Bowl offensive lineman CARLTON HASELRIG as a fugitive from justice. Haselrig, who has a history of alcohol-related arrests, was to be extradited to Pennsylvania to face charges of drunken driving and violating probation.

title: Cigar Bids to Stoke Up New Streak at Belmont
description: ''If Cigar runs his race,'' Bill Mott said, ''they can't beat him.''

title: The Baltimore Bombers Keep Heat on Full Blast
description: For the last three days the visiting clubhouse at Tiger Stadium had been the tense home of the Yankees, who left town Thursday thankful for a sweep that kept a sliver of space between them and the surging Baltimore Orioles.

title: UNIVERSAL OUTDOOR UNIT TO BUY TANNER-PECK
description: Universal Outdoor Holdings Inc. said yesterday that its Universal Outdoor Inc. unit had agreed to buy the closely held Tanner-Peck L.L.C. and TOA Enterprises L.P. for about $74.1 million in cash and stock. Tanner-Peck, based in Memphis, operates about 2,000 outdoor advertising displays in that area, including some in Tunica, Miss. Under terms of the agreement, the Chicago-based Universal Holdings will pay about $70.8 million in cash and 100,000 shares of its common stock, valued at $3.28 million, based on Thursday's closing price of $32.75. Universal Outdoor's shares rose $2.50, to $35.25, their highest point since the initial public offering of 6.2 million shares at $14.50 in July.

title: Watershed Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCESS HEALTH SHARES CLIMB ON EXPANSION OF SERVICES
description: The shares of Access Health Inc. rose 18 percent yesterday after the company said it would provide health information services to one million Florida Blue Cross and Blue Shield members in the next 15 months. Access Health shares rose $7.6875, to $50.50, in Nasdaq trading. Access Health, based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., gives customers access to a broad range of health information and counseling services through the phone, the Internet, fax, printed materials or cable television.

title: In Tobacco Country, a Democratic Candidate Is Running Against the President
description: After months of foraging for publicity with the opportunistic abandon of all serious politicians, Joe Wright hit on something close to his heart this week: He took his tobacco cutter's knife over to a fellow farmer who needed a hand and harvested tobacco for three hours, his neat swipe-and-spear cutter's motion attracting television news crews interested in a man-fights-demonization story.

title: SENATE RACE TIGHT IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Pam Perry, an independent who tends to vote Democrat, was at a picnic in the nearby town of Malden, awaiting the arrival of the popular Republican Governor, William F. Weld, and talking about why she might vote for him for senator.

title: Bird Healer and State Officials at Odds Over Release of Falcons
description: No one doubts that Dona Tracy loves birds. It's just that some people believe she loves them too well.

title: Samsung to Study Deal For Fokker Business
description: The Samsung Group of South Korea has been given exclusive rights to investigate the possibility of taking over the aircraft manufacturing operation of the bankrupt Dutch company Fokker N.V., officials said yesterday. Receivers appointed to run Fokker after the company collapsed in March said Samsung's study would determine how Stork N.V., which has already taken over much of Fokker's business, would fit in. A Stork spokesman, Koos Huurdeman, said his company would probably provide maintenance and service for Fokker aircraft.

title: City Prohibits Borrowing By Improvement Districts
description: The Giuliani administration restricted the power of the city's business improvement districts yesterday for the first time, announcing that it would prohibit them from borrowing money to pay for big projects.

title: L.I. Veto Kills Bill to Require Use of English
description: Rejecting what he called ''a message of intolerance,'' the Suffolk County Executive vetoed a measure yesterday to make English the county's official language. It was the latest sign that the Northeast is resisting the English-only movement spreading through much of the country.

title: The Meetings Aren't Necessary, Yet
description: Giants safety Jason Sehorn was asked about last year, when it seemed as if there were players-only meetings every week.

title: Okinawan Ends Battle Over Leases On U.S. Bases
description: The Governor of Okinawa retreated today from a long legal battle over leases for American military bases, making it easier to renew the leases and easing an irritant in relations with the United States.

title: The Tax Man's Booty Stocks a Bargain Store
description: The hottest store in Moscow now is suitably named Arrears.

title: Opposition Grows in Brazil To High Domestic Air Fares
description: As Brazil moves slowly toward selling off state companies and trimming government's regulatory role, its airlines have become an anomaly: an industry forced to bear high costs and tight regulation while still charging high domestic fares that most Brazilians cannot afford.

title: The Pulse of America
description: To the Editor:

title: Kurds Scramble for Safety
description: In northern Iraq, Kurds who have worked for the American military since the Persian Gulf war are desperate to be evacuated. Page 3.

title: Argentina Settles Lawsuit By a Victim of Torture
description: The trial of the Argentine Government never took place. But the long and harrowing trial of Jose Siderman finally came to an end today, more than 20 years after soldiers abducted him from his home in northern Argentina, tortured him for days and then forced him into exile.

title: The Blues: Here More, There Less
description: The blues resists definition. It doesn't always fit the well-known three-chord, 12-bar structure, or any other one. It does involve blue notes, and a tone that can be despairing, stoic, wry, lusty, sullen and resilient, all at once. Yet even if it can't be precisely delineated, the blues means something, despite the tendency to apply the term to any American music that's not trying to be trendy.

title: Messier Plans to Play
description: Mark Messier, Team Canada's emotional leader, showed the effects of the flu at practice today but will be in the lineup for Saturday night's decisive game. ''I just had some kind of upper respiratory infection,'' said Messier, who sat out Canada's 5-2 loss to the United States.

title: Charles Norman, 92, Poet and Biographer
description: Charles Norman, a poet and the author of biographies of E. E. Cummings, Ezra Pound and other literary figures, died on Tuesday at Newport Hospital in Newport, R.I. He was 92 and lived in Newport.

title: Garden Could Soon Run SportsChannel
description: Cablevision Systems, which became a partner with ITT in Madison Square Garden without putting up an equal payment, will repay a $250 million loan from ITT with cash and half ownership of SportsChannel. The type of repayment came when ITT recently exercised an option in their partnership deal.

title: New Case Against Sergeant
description: A Palisades Park Police sergeant stole $85,000 while responding to a burglar alarm at a home in July 1994, the Federal authorities said yesterday. The borough suffered a spate of burglaries around that time, and the state and Federal authorities are investigating whether a burglary ring operated out of the Police Department, said Lisa Russell-Charles, an assistant United States attorney. The sergeant, Edward Shirley, has been suspended without pay since he was indicted by a Superior Court grand jury in August 1995 in connection with the theft. But those charges were dropped yesterday after he was accused by a Federal grand jury of violating the homeowners' civil rights by breaking in and stealing the money.

title: WESTERN NATIONAL SELLS STOCK TO AMERICAN GENERAL
description: The Western National Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell another $130 million of its stock to the American General Corporation, increasing American General's stake in the company to 46.2 percent from 40 percent. Western National will issue 7.3 million shares of a newly created preferred stock priced at $17.92 a share. The company will use proceeds from the sale to increase the capital base of its principal operating unit, the Western National Life Insurance Company, by about 30 percent. American General is an insurer based in Houston.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: In His Joking Words
description: AL GORE

title: Robbery Victim Plays Dead
description: After two men broke into his home yesterday and shot him, a Scotch Plains man pretended to be dead while the intruders ransacked his home, the authorities said. The victim, who received a superficial head wound, used his own gun to fire several shots at his assailants as they drove off in his car, said Edward M. Neafsey, Acting Prosecutor for Union County. The suspects, Gerard Watkins of Newark and Deandre McKenzie of Hillside, were caught after the Hillside police spotted them in a car that had been taken from an 82-year-old Hillside man on Thursday, Mr. Neafsey said.

title: More Information Released On the President's Health
description: Prodded for weeks by the Dole campaign to make public President Clinton's medical records, the White House tonight released an 11-page sheaf of doctors' statements about the President's medical history.

title: Double the Fun? Or Just the Bodies?
description: On the theory that two of anything must be twice as good, the martial arts star Jean-Claude Van Damme has been drawing lately on remembrance of thunks past.

title: Spraying Is Ordered to Combat Deadly Mosquito-Borne Disease
description: Public health officials in Connecticut, Rhode Island and Long Island are growing increasingly concerned about the spread of mosquitoes carrying Eastern equine encephalitis, a virus that can be deadly to humans.

title: The City Opera's Harsh, Early Version of 'Butterfly'
description: In ''Madama Butterfly,'' Puccini set out to depict a multicultural catastrophe: a Japanese woman cast aside by a supremely thoughtless American adventurer. But his conflict of cultures had to pass through the modifying haze of Italian verismo, with added smatterings of French Impressionism and Wagner. The raw, dark quality of the original story is often lost in Puccini's gorgeous mishmash, but it comes intriguingly close to the surface again in the New York City Opera's production of the original 1904 version of the opera, which returned on Thursday night.

title: In Israel, Help for Ethiopian Huddled Masses
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Publisher Arrested on Tax Fraud Charge
description: The police arrested the owner of one of Mexico's biggest newspapers today on charges of criminal tax fraud and evasion, generating accusations from the daily, El Universal, that the Government is cracking down on dissent in the press.

title: For Gore, the Emphasis Is on the Positive, Mostly
description: With the Clinton-Gore ticket sailing comfortably along on a double-digit lead in most national polls, one of Vice President Al Gore's unstated campaign strategies seems ever apparent: do no harm.

title: Fiat Plans Layoffs And Production Cuts
description: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian car maker, said yesterday that it would cut production by 9,400 automobiles in October and lay off thousands of workers temporarily. The company plans to lay off about 15,000 workers in the third and fourth weeks of October, followed by 8,500 workers the week after. A continuing slowdown in car sales in Italy was cited for the layoffs. (AP)

title: Doctors Clear Holyfield for Tyson Bout
description: Armed with a clean bill of health from the Mayo Clinic, EVANDER HOLYFIELD won approval from Nevada boxing officials yesterday to fight MIKE TYSON for the World Boxing Association heavyweight title on Nov. 9 at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. Boxing commissioners dismissed concerns about the condition of Holyfield's heart after a complete medical exam done at the clinic in Rochester, Minn., turned up nothing to indicate there was any heart problem.

title: Complaints Against Doctor
description: A Princeton doctor whose license was suspended in July after he was accused of malpractice has continued to see patients, the State Attorney General's office said yesterday. Dr. Eric Braverman has treated at least four patients in an inappropriate or unsafe manner, the Consumer Affairs Division said in an amended complaint filed as part of its civil suit against the doctor. Dr. Braverman promoted alternative medicine on a weekly radio show on WOR-AM until his contract was canceled in June. He said yesterday that he has treated patients only in New York, where his license was not suspended.

title: Msgr. James Kelley, 94, a President of Seton Hall
description: Msgr. James F. Kelley, who became president of Seton Hall College at age 33 and guided its transformation from a tiny liberal arts college to a large university, died on Tuesday at the Medical Center of Ocean County in Brick, N.J. He was 94.

title: Native Hawaiian Vote Favors Sovereignty
description: The more than 30,000 descendants of Hawaii's original Polynesians who mailed in ballots this summer in a state-sponsored plebiscite voted nearly 3 to 1 in favor of creating some sort of native Hawaiian government, election officials said yesterday.

title: Attacking Patronage In New York Schools
description: State legislative leaders have agreed to avoid a full-scale reorganization of the New York City school system and instead focus on eliminating corruption in the community school boards. Both Democrats and Republicans agree that they want to take away almost all hiring authority from the elected local boards as a way of reducing patronage and mismanagement. But they disagree over who should get those powers.

title: Listless Gooden Will Skip His Next Start
description: Because Dwight Gooden's right arm has turned lifeless, because his earned run average has ballooned and because the Yankees are involved in a tense pennant race, the sputtering right-hander has officially been removed from the rotation for at least one turn and will not start Sunday against the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Mexicans Send Dollars Home and U.S. Companies Profit
description: Where billions of dollars flow can Wall Street be far behind?

title: Bibi Besch, 54, Dies; TV and Film Actress And a Force in Guild
description: Bibi Besch, an actress who appeared on many of television's most popular shows and was on the board of the Screen Actors Guild, died last Saturday at the Daniel Freeman Hospital in Los Angeles. Ms. Besch, who lived in Los Angeles, was 54.

title: Not All Japanese Hear the Same Drummer
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Agrees to Attack Patronage in City Schools
description: Reopening long-stalled negotiations on a plan to revamp the way New York City's schools are governed, state legislative leaders have tacitly agreed to avoid a full-scale restructuring of the system and instead focus on eliminating a major obstacle to improving education: corruption in the community school boards.

title: Judge Lifts Peter Graf's Arrest Warrant
description: In a surprise move yesterday, the presiding judge at the tax evasion trial of STEFFI GRAF's father in Mannheim, Germany, lifted the arrest warrant that has kept PETER GRAF in prison for 13 months. Chief Judge JOACHIM PLASS also lifted the arrest warrant of the former Graf family tax adviser, JOACHIM ECKARDT. Both men remained in custody while a higher state court considers prosecutors' objections to the judge's ruling. Plass provided no details on why he lifted the arrest warrants. Plass said that Peter Graf, 58, could be freed after posting a $2 million bond, while Eckardt's bond was set at $200,000. The two must report to authorities twice a week and are banned from leaving the country, Plass said. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday about a campaign to improve the image of steel referred incompletely to TBWA Chiat/Day, an agency that participated in a review for the account of the Steel Alliance Task Force. The agency withdrew before the selection of the winning agency, GSD&M.

title: Political Evangelists
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Policy as Character Issue
description: After several false starts, the Republicans have begun criticizing President Clinton for his recent handling of Iraq. The new strategy is risky, not least because the initial missile raids ordered by Mr. Clinton have won widespread public approval. After suggesting that vacillation by the President had encouraged Saddam Hussein to consolidate his power in northern Iraq, Bob Dole pulled back as his aides worried that he would seem unpatriotic, leaving the criticism to surrogates.

title: Dole Campaign Agrees to Change Its Tune
description: The latest skirmish in the war between Bob Dole and Hollywood is over, and this time Hollywood triumphed.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: No More Malls
description: To the Editor:

title: Winning the West, or Stealing or Losing It
description: PBS sets off on another expedition into American history tomorrow night. The 12 1/2-hour trek through ''The West'' covers two million square miles and four centuries of exploration and exploitation, dreams and daring, massacres and miracles, all part of a nation-building, nations-annihilating epic. So hitch up for a long adventure-packed journey.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONTINENTAL AMERICAN TRANSPORTATION INC., Calhoun, Ga., a trucking and logistics management company, will merge with Country Wide Transport Services Inc. of Corona, Calif., a provider of temperature-controlled transportation of goods.

title: Federal Audit Faults F.A.A. On Tests of Airport Security
description: A newly issued Government audit on the Federal Aviation Administration's inspections of airport security says that in some cases F.A.A. agents overstated how well airports performed and made efforts to help airlines do well on the inspections.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Crude Oil Prices Drop Sharply On Easing of U.S.-Iraq Tensions
description: Futures prices for crude oil plunged yesterday after Iraq said it would stop firing missiles at American warplanes, signaling an easing of the tensions in the Persian Gulf that had pushed prices to five-month highs this week.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: Alvaleta Guess Actress, 41
description: Alvaleta Guess, an actress who appeared in the musical ''Swinging on a Star'' last season on Broadway, died on Sept. 2 at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. She was 41 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Steeple's Fall Leaves a Hole In Many Lives
description: THE slender green steeple of Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church rises like an unofficial landmark above the buildings clustered around the Hub, the teeming shopping district along Third Avenue in the South Bronx. For 109 years, the sight of ''Immaculate'' has guided thousands of travelers lost in spirit, as well as more than a few lost in cars and on foot. You can see it from the Major Deegan Expressway, from far up Webster Avenue and, even, from Harlem.

title: Judge's Efforts Gain a Reprieve for Farberware Factory in the Bronx
description: Under pressure from a state judge, the company that closed the Farberware plant in the Bronx eight days ago agreed yesterday to reopen it temporarily to give government officials more time to find someone to buy and operate it permanently.

title: Pataki Names Close Adviser to Judicial Screening Panel
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has appointed his closest legal adviser to the commission that recommends candidates to the state's highest court, a move that prompted criticism from leaders of bar groups.

title: Howl About New York
description: When conservationists were conducting their successful campaign to return wolves to Yellowstone National Park, their opponents often said the overwhelming public support for the plan came mostly from Easterners who didn't have to have wolves in their backyards. If it's such a great idea, they said, why not put the wolves in New York?

title: No Crowds Here: One District Is Begging for Pupils
description: While thousands of New York City's public-school children are learning their multiplication tables in oversized closets and locker rooms, teachers on the Lower East Side of Manhattan are so anxious to fill the empty desks in their classrooms that they are plastering colorful fliers all over the neighborhood, hoping to grab the attention of prospective students and their parents.

title: Yes, Personal Ethics of Politicians Are Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: RESURGENT STOCKS HIT RECORD HIGHS ON LOW INFLATION
description: The stock market surged to record highs yesterday, continuing one of the greatest bull markets in history and erasing a midsummer downturn that only recently had many analysts predicting the end of good times on Wall Street.

title: From Murderer Most Foul To Victim of the System
description: How many trials of the century can one century have? So far the 20th century has had at least two. The kidnapping and murder of Charles Lindbergh's baby son in 1932 was quickly labeled ''the crime of the century.'' With Walter Winchell leading a pack of journalists, the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the murder became a media circus to rival O. J. Simpson's so-called ''trial of the century.'' (At Hauptmann's trial, miniature ladders, replicas of the one used by the kidnappers, were sold as souvenirs.) Both cases left a trail of nagging issues: about the distance between legal evidence and real-life truth; about how crimes that touch celebrities exert an irresistible hold on the public imagination.

title: Pettitte Throws Through Pain as Yanks Hold Lead
description: The grisly sight of Andy Pettitte's left knee serving as a target for a scorching line drive, and the pitcher then collapsing to the dirt mound like a goalie who forgot to wear equipment, frightened the Yankees and placed their post-season aspirations in limbo for a few moments. No Pettitte would be no pleasure for this teetering team.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the Woodward Stakes misidentified Belmont Park's linemaker, who sets the odds listed in the program. He is Mike Watchmaker; Mike Lakow is the racing secretary.

title: Consumer Price Index Barely Rises, Easing Inflation Fears
description: Consumer prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in August, the Labor Department disclosed today, a better performance than expected and one that economists regarded as solid confirmation that inflation remains in check.

title: International Shift By Swiss Bank Seen
description: Journal de Geneve, a newspaper in Geneva, reported yesterday that the Swiss Bank Corporation, the third-largest bank in Switzerland, would focus its global operations on London and Chicago. The bank would not comment on the report, which said that Swiss Bank would announce a revamping next Wednesday.

title: Airport Security Windfall?
description: President Clinton's $1 billion antiterrorism proposal could be good news for a New Jersey company. Barringer Instruments Inc. makes the Ionscan 400, a detector of drugs and explosives used at airports around the world. Barringer has only about 30 employees at its New Providence plant, but the work force could grow to 200 employees as the demand for the product increases, Ken Wood, the company's president, said yesterday. Only a handful of companies make similar devices, he said.

title: IRAQ ORDERS HALT TO MISSILE STRIKES ON AMERICAN JETS
description: The Iraqi Government abruptly announced today that it would no longer shoot at American jets enforcing the flight-exclusion zones in northern and southern Iraq, leading Clinton Administration policymakers to reconsider plans to attack Iraq.

title: No Headline
description: ''We have a county that is ethnically and racially diverse, and we value that, and we cannot send the message that these people are not welcome.''

title: Deliveryman Cleared in Killing; 3 Are Accused of Robbing Him
description: In a case that raised tensions between black residents and Chinese restaurant operators in East Flatbush, a Brooklyn grand jury has decided that no charges should be filed against a restaurant deliveryman in the stabbing death of a black teen-ager, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: If a declarer offers a tempting ruff, it may be wise to decline and keep him guessing.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Public and Private Responsibility
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was right on target when he argued that individuals, families and neighborhoods must take more responsibility for New York City's well-being and the safety of its children. True, the Mayor was trying to deflect criticism that the city bore the blame for allowing 4-year-old Nadine Lockwood to be starved to death despite an official investigation of her home. But Mr. Giuliani's contention that Nadine's family and neighbors bear heavy responsibility for her death was echoed by the angry, grief-stricken mourners who thronged to the child's funeral. The crowd of grandparents, mothers with strollers and young fathers berated Nadine's family, particularly her father, demanding to know where he had been while Nadine's mother was starving her.

title: Yes, Personal Ethics of Politicians Are Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: Julia Morton, 84, an Expert On Florida's Poisonous Plants
description: Julia Morton, a self-taught expert on the uses of medicinal and toxic plants and a ''Dear Abby'' for Floridians concerned about poisonous greenery, died on Tuesday at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. She was 84 and lived in Homestead, Fla.

title: House Report on Travel Office Attacks Clinton
description: A report by a Republican-led House committee has concluded that President Clinton forced the dismissal of seven employees of the White House travel office three years ago so that a Hollywood friend of his could take over the travel operation.

title: A Rabbi With All Varieties of Jewish Experience
description: At its most compelling, personal religious experience seldom follows a straight line or fits neatly under a denominational label. But how often does one come across an individual who combines, in her life and work, four distinct streams of a single faith?

title: The Sound of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: The Trouble With Environment Bonds
description: Gov. George Pataki's $1.75 billion environmental bond act, which will be voted on in a referendum in November, proposes to preserve New York's open spaces, clean up contaminated industrial sites and improve waste-water treatment.

title: Battle Begins for Israeli Labor Party Leadership
description: Though it has been less than four months since the Labor Party lost the Israeli election, the battle to succeed Shimon Peres as the party's leader has broken wide open. Two candidates already have their hats in the ring, and at least two more are taking aim.

title: Gretzky Isn't So Sure Of Las Vegas Gamble
description: Neil Smith, president and general manager of the Rangers, has been telling people that Wayne Gretzky will make his debut as a Ranger next Saturday when the team plays an exhibition game in Las Vegas, Nev., against the Anaheim Mighty Ducks.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the contests to control the Senate and the House misidentified the college at which one political scientist, Prof. John Pitney, teaches. Professor Pitney, who pointed to the Republicans' slim majorities as a risk factor, teaches at Claremont McKenna College, one of the Claremont Colleges.

title: Neck and Neck in a Poll
description: A new poll shows that Representatives Richard A. Zimmer and Robert G. Torricelli, who are seeking to replace Bill Bradley in the Senate, are running about even among voters ''very likely'' to go to the polls, The Asbury Park Press reported yesterday. Thirty-five percent of the people surveyed favored Mr. Zimmer, the Republican; 34 percent favored Mr. Torricelli, the Democrat, and 31 percent were undecided, the newspaper said. Jeff Isay, a spokesman for Mr. Torricelli, said the results were skewed because the survey was conducted last week while Mr. Zimmer was running a new ad. Andrea Hofelich, a spokeswoman for Mr. Zimmer, said the results were consistent with a survey by The Record of Hackensack in early August giving her candidate a three-point lead. The poll had a margin of error of 3.9 percentage points, the newspaper said.

title: The Next Infomercials
description: Now that the Oprahfied, pre-scripted, content-free political conventions are history, what can the substance-starved American voter look forward to? The Oprahfied, pre-scripted, content-free Presidential debates -- what else? As tout Washington is debating who should debate, almost no one questions why we bother with these sham exercises at all.

title: Profiles to Spot Airline Bombers
description: As part of its antiterrorism strategy, the Clinton Administration is asking the nation's airlines to increase the use of passenger profiles to help separate ordinary travelers from potential bombers. Trained airport security personnel would match what the airline knows about the passenger against an abstract profile consisting of various factors that warn of possible danger. A close match would prompt authorities to screen the passenger and his luggage more carefully, using the most sophisticated bomb detectors and perhaps search teams.

title: Desperate Kurds Find No Way Out of Iraq
description: Outside the military headquarters abandoned by American and allied officers here two weeks ago, desperate Kurdish men dug into their pockets today to produce what they said were tickets to evacuation.

title: Cuban Star Rebuffed In Miami
description: In recent years, Miami has become a center for Hispanic show business, home to the likes of the singer Gloria Estefan and a magnet for artists from all over Latin America. But this entertainment capital does not have room for performers like Rosita Fornes, a 73-year-old singer, actress and dancer who lives in Cuba.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Aug. 30 about Manhattan's labor history misidentified the woman who used her Madison Avenue mansion in 1909 as collateral to raise bail for striking garment workers. It was Mrs. O. H. P. Belmont, not Mrs. August Belmont.

title: Tupac Shakur, 25, Rap Performer Who Personified Violence, Dies
description: Tupac Shakur, a rapper and actor who built a career on controversy, died of wounds yesterday from a drive-by shooting last Saturday. He was 25 years old.

title: Fund Buys Stake In Mobile Systems
description: Mobile Systems International P.L.C., a provider of mobile communication software and service, said yesterday that General Atlantic Partners, an American investment fund, would buy 20 percent of the company, valuing it at $:180 million, or $280 million.

title: Everen to Trim Operations
description: Everen Securities Inc. said this week that it would close municipal bond operations in New York and Boston amid declining sales and shrinking profit margins. It will maintain offices in Chicago, Denver and San Francisco.

title: By Fits and Starts, Dole Explains His Tax Cut
description: Bob Dole tried three times today to give a new and simpler explanation of his economic plan, but it did not prove to be easy.

title: Compuserve Retracts Official's Prediction of a Profit for the Year
description: The Compuserve Corporation retracted remarks made earlier today by a company official who said the troubled on-line service would make a profit this year.

title: Cleaning Up a Casino
description: Starting Oct. 1, beards will be banned for employees of the Tropicana Casino and Resort. Mustaches will be permitted, but only if they are neatly trimmed, said Susan M. Kotzen, a spokeswoman for the hotel. The restrictions will apply to all workers, she said, adding that Will Espin, Tropicana's vice president of poker and simulcasting, shaved his beard of 17 years to comply. TERRY PRISTIN

title: More Information On Olivetti Is Sought
description: Consob, the Italian stock market regulatory agency, said late Thursday that it was asking Olivetti S.p.A., the maker of computers and office equipment, to provide further information about its financial situation. Consob said it was seeking more information about the company's half-year results as well as assurances of the comparability of this information with results from the period a year earlier.

title: Dog Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''Brother of Sleep,'' based on a novel about a musical prodigy, referred to two characters incorrectly. Elsbeth is not related to the main character, Elias.

title: Flare-up of Gang Gunfire Vexes, Gary, Ind.
description: This faded steel town, which has had stubbornly high crime statistics for years, had a quiet summer and a 34 percent drop in its murder rate for the year so far, primarily, city officials say, because of increased anti-gang efforts.

title: High-Spirited Johnson Won't Change
description: Keyshawn Johnson is headed for Miami determined to be Keyshawn Johnson, and if that means smiling and spiking the ball against the Dolphins on Sunday, then so be it.

title: Off the Bus, Into Custody
description: When Schardrac Falaise, 20, stepped off the bus from Florida on Thursday, he was wearing a bulletproof vest and carrying two duffel bags filled with 35 handguns, Federal agents said. Mr. Falaise bought the guns in a store near Fort Lauderdale, using a fake identification card, and planned to sell the guns to street gangs in Elizabeth, Irvington and Newark, according to agents at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. He was charged with illegal trafficking of handguns.

title: Minimizing the Wage Damage
description: WITH the Federal minimum wage set to rise 50 cents, to $4.75 an hour, on Oct. 1 and then to $5.15 next Sept. 1, many economists believe that there will be an accompanying increase in unemployment. But few are asking if anything can be done to counter such a result.

title: Traveling to the Polls Is Difficult for Many
description: Wearing a suit, black cardigan and white shirt and tie, Hivzo Burazezovic and his wife, Nusreta, in a patterned dress, walked with dignity into a war-damaged house in this rural village at 9 A.M. today to cast their votes in the Bosnian election.

title: Incentives Are Luring Buyers to Bucks County
description: DEVELOPERS in a fast-growing, competitive market for single-family homes have started using time-tested car dealer tactics like financial incentives and short-term promotions to lure move-up buyers to Bucks County, a 40-minute drive northwest from downtown Philadelphia.

title: Students And Safety Nets
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Rebuts G.O.P. Attacks On Iraqi Policy
description: Facing mounting Republican criticism, President Clinton said today that American air strikes against Iraq ''tightened the strategic straitjacket'' around President Saddam Hussein and ''advanced America's fundamental interests in the region.''

title: Young Man's Obsession: The American Chestnut
description: Timothy Van Vliet is one of those intense 17-year-olds who's madly in love. But it's the American chestnut that captured his heart.

title: In Programming, Orchestras Play to Win
description: THE NEW YORK philharmonic opens its season on Wednesday with a winning program. And make no mistake, concert programs are designed to win. As orchestra managements ponder how to fill seats and keep them filled for two hours at a time, programming becomes a combination of field strategy, mass psychiatry and games of cat-and-mouse.

title: In His Own Words
description: JACK KEMP

title: Canada Geese: Growing Nuisance Defies Solution
description: YEARS ago the United States Fish and Wildlife Service developed a program to reduce the population of Canada geese on Long Island.

title: Federal Proposals Cast Costly Security Net
description: Two months has not been long enough for investigators to determine why Trans World Airlines Flight 800 crashed, but it has been long enough for a White House commission to devise counterterrorism recommendations and for Congress and the aviation industry to argue over them.

title: A Low-Risk Plan to Counter Iraq: Fly, Don't Drive
