description: AS the United States approached another military showdown with Iraq last week, nobody, but nobody at the Defense Department talked publicly about the possibility of sending American ground troops back to war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: Ms. Pontrelli, Mr. Porterfield
description: Gina Giulietta Pontrelli, the daughter of Verna and Michael Pontrelli of Hermosa Beach, Calif., was married last evening to Christopher Brown Porterfield, a son of Stephanie Brown Porterfield and Christopher Porterfield of New York. Dr. Robert A. Ringler, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Beach Club in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Christine Harkins, Craig T. Hosay
description: Christine Mary Harkins, the daughter of Stella L. Davison of Yardley, Pa., and Dr. Michael J. Harkins of Haddonfield,, N.J., was married yesterday to Craig Thomas Hosay, a son of Lois T. Hosay and Dr. John J. Hosay of Montclair, N.J. Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia officiated at the Fleisher Art Memorial, a gallery in Philadelphia.

title: Jessica Mitford's Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Richter Saves Day Yet Again
description: Sitting in front of his locker as Gatorade flew through the air and a celebration swirled around him, Team USA goalie Mike Richter looked anything but shellshocked.

title: As We Know It
description: ''ENDING THE I.R.S. as we know it'' was a centerpiece of Bob Dole's economic plan, later driven home in his acceptance address with ''You will have a President who will end the I.R.S. as we know it.''

title: Investing in a Candidate
description: JAMES CARVILLE, BILL Clinton's 1992 campaign strategist, made a discovery during that campaign: there was a powerful force that had to be appeased, even though technically it did not vote. ''The damned bond market,'' said the counselor. ''Who the hell knew it was so powerful? If if gets nervous, everybody has to calm it down. If I'm ever reincarnated, I want to come back as the bond market. Then everybody will be afraid of me and have to do what I say.''

title: Assessing the Dunlap Way
description: To the Editor:

title: In North Carolina, Clinton Hears About Storm
description: Nine days after Hurricane Fran swept into North Carolina, President Clinton did the same today, getting an update on the storm cleanup and displaying Democratic hopes that the state, which voted Republican in the last three Presidential elections, could be within his reach this year.

title: Company Agrees to Delay Logging in a Virgin Redwood Forest
description: After three days of intense negotiations, a California timber company agreed on Friday night to postpone logging on 3,000 acres of virgin redwood forest for two more weeks while discussions continue about the state and Federal governments' acquiring the land.

title: The Changing Voice of Local Radio
description: LONGTIME listeners to the Norwalk radio station WNLK got a rude awakening of sorts when they tuned in to the David Smith morning show on July 30. Not only did they not hear Mr. Smith; they also did not, in a sense, hear WNLK.

title: More Orchard Beach Than Elaine's
description: QUESTION: If you were the cause celebre of the New York literati, given gobs of money for your first collection of short stories and a novel you hadn't even started and anointed one of Newsweek's ''new faces of '96,'' how would you spend a sticky summer Sunday?

title: When It's Time to Do Your Math
description: AS your child struggles with her application for admission to a well-known boarding school, you get to apply for financial aid. What can you expect?

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: OUR LADY OF BABYLON

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Mr. Truman's War

title: BEST SELLERS: September 15, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Fiction 1 1 3 EXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) Vice President Jack Ryan has problems after the deaths of the President and most of the Cabinet, Congress, the Joint Chiefs and the Supreme Court. 2 2 5 SERVANT OF THE BONES, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $26.) A dark angel seeking redemption makes a perilous journey from ancient Babylon to modern Manhattan. 3 3 16 the RUNAWAY JURY, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $26.95.) A woman in a Mississippi Gulf Coast town sues a tobacco company for causing her husband's death. 4 4 6 THE LAST DON, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $25.95.) The aging head of a Mafia family makes plans for his heirs' activities in Hollywood and Las Vegas. 5 5 9 CAUSE OF DEATH, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $25.95.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta investigates the mysterious death of a reporter. 6 6 133 THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life. (+) 7 7 15 FALLING UP, by Shel Silverstein. (HarperCollins, $16.95.) Poems and drawings, for children and grown-ups, celebrating strange characters and experiences. 8 8 19 THE TENTH INSIGHT, by James Redfield. (Warner, $19.95.) A journey through the Appalachian Mountains provides answers to life's enigmas. (+) 9 9 18 HOW STELLA GOT HER GROOVE BACK, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $23.95.) A divorced black woman finds romance on a Jamaican holiday. 10 1 OUT OF SIGHT, by Elmore Leonard. (Delacorte, $22.95.) A deputy United States marshal is abducted by an escaped bank robber when she stops to serve a summons at a Florida prison. 11 11 7 THE WEDDING, by Julie Garwood. (Pocket, $23.) A 12th-century Scottish laird captures and marries an English lady. 12 10 12 GODS AND GENERALS, by Jeff Shaara. (Ballantine, $25.) The progress of four military leaders on their way to Gettysburg; a prequel to ''The Killer Angels.'' 13* 12 9 LILY WHITE, by Susan Isaacs. (HarperCollins, $25.) A defense lawyer takes on the case of a con man charged with murder, whose true motives mystify her. 14* 13 10 EXCLUSIVE, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $22.95.) Should a television reporter broadcast the secrets confided to her by the First Lady? 15 1 THE BURNING MAN, by Phillip Margolin. (Doubleday, $23.95.) The President states his vision for America in the 21st century. (+) 4 11 2 ALL TOO HUMAN, by Edward Klein. (Pocket, $23.) The courtship and marriage of John and Jacqueline Kennedy. 5* 4 124 MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga. (+) 6* 3 28 UNDAUNTED COURAGE, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The story of how Thomas Jefferson sponsored Lewis and Clark's exploration of the American West. (+) 7 6 4 BARE KNUCKLES AND BACK ROOMS, by Ed Rollins with Tom DeFrank. (Broadway Books, $27.50.) A political consultant recalls his 30 years behind the scenes. 8 5 18 BAD AS I WANNA BE, by Dennis Rodman with Tim Keown. (Delacorte, $22.95.) The memoirs of the flamboyant basketball player. 9 19 IT TAKES A VILLAGE, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon & Schuster, $20.) The First Lady's quest for ways to help create a better society for children. (+) 10* 8 50 EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE, by Daniel Goleman. (Bantam, $23.95.) Factors other than I.Q. that contribute to a successful and happy life. (+) 11 10 6 DOMINIQUE MOCEANU: AN AMERICAN CHAMPION, by Dominique Moceanu as told to Steve Woodward. (Bantam, $14.95.) The autobiography of the 14-year-old Olympic gymnast. (+) 12 9 10 THE CHOICE, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) Self-indulgent morality, and ways to overcome it. (+) 14 7 13 OUTRAGE, by Vincent Bugliosi. (Norton, $25.) The reasons, according to the former Los Angeles County prosecutor, that O. J. Simpson was found not guilty. (+) 137 15 13 7 DRINKING: A LOVE STORY, by Caroline Knapp. (Dial, $22.95.) A journalist recalls her 20-year addiction to alcohol. Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 173 MEN ARE FROM MARS, WOMEN ARE FROM VENUS, by John Gray. (HarperCollins, $23.) Improving communication and relationships. (+) 2 1 26 THE ZONE, by Barry Sears with Bill Lawren. (Regan Books/HarperCollins, $23.) Diets to prevent disease and enhance mental health. (+) 3 3 24 SIMPLE ABUNDANCE, by Sarah Ban Breathnach. (Warner, $17.95.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+) 4 1 THE CELESTINE PROPHECY: A POCKET GUIDE TO THE NINE INSIGHTS, by James Redfield. (Warner Treasures, $6.95.) Lessons derived from the novel.

title: The British Weather Channel: Better Than a Yule Log
description: BRITONS have never been blessed with particularly interesting weather. They seem to spend most of their waking hours under a grim blanket of clouds.

title: HONEY, WHAT'S YOUR NAME AGAIN?
description: I found myself groping for words, too, as I slid into my early 40's (Lives: ''Honey, What's Your Name Again?'' by Letty Cottin Pogrebin, Aug. 25). When I asked a doctor about this, she calmed my anxieties by telling me that now and then we all forget where the keys are placed. With Alzheimer's, we forget what keys are for.

title: Back to School With Overcrowding And Budget Deficits
description: FOR many of the county's schoolchildren who returned to classes last week, back to school meant close encounters with newly installed computers, crowded quarters and more demanding teacher expectations. In many schools, where veteran teachers had taken advantage of retirement incentives at the end of the last academic year, these students are also facing new teachers. Several schools have new leadership, with new principals learning the ropes along with the children.

title: Tiffany Doggett, John F. Lynch
description: Tiffany Allen Doggett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Kirk Doggett Jr., of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to John Francis Lynch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Lynch of New York. The Rev. Marston Price performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans, Mass.

title: City of Money
description: FLORENCEA Portrait.By Michael Levey.Illustrated. 498 pp. Cambridge, Mass:Harvard University Press. $35.

title: New York's Upcoming Non-Elections
description: New Yorkers are generally unaware of how much power the state government has over their lives. Otherwise they would be angrier at how little say they have over who runs it.

title: Inspector Returns, Privately
description: As commander of the 19th Precinct on the Upper East Side, Deputy Inspector Peter Buccino was known in the neighborhood as an effective, personable law-enforcement official. On his watch, from 1992 to 1994, the number of burglaries declined, and sometimes he took to the streets in plainclothes and made an arrest, like that of the prostitution suspect who had no inkling she was soliciting a man who ran one of the city's high-profile police precincts.

title: Lucent May Be AT&T's Creation, but Its Stock Is a Different Beast
description: ON Friday, AT&T shareholders got the chance to begin selling their shares in Lucent Technologies Inc., the phone company's high-tech spinoff, even before receiving them.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: An Island Out of Time

title: Murray Is In
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Denounced in Italy
description: Out of sheer self-defense, foreigners living in Italy are likely to begin reading the fine print on invoices and contracts. And they will soon notice that they are permitted, on occasion, to indulge in what is called a denunzia tempestiva. I know, this sounds therapeutic. The day you receive your first wildly dubious phone bill -- itemized, as is the rule -- a tempestuous denunciation is just what you'll probably want to make. Unfortunately, the phrase denunzia temp-estiva merely means something like ''timely notification,'' and who needs that? They can take their ''timely.'' They can have their ''notification.''

title: Managing the Shore: The Debate Continues
description: New Jersey officials and environmental planners have argued for years over whether beaches and shoreline buildings should be protected or whether nature should be allowed to run its course. The argument promises to heat up again this fall as a new coastal management plan is debated at hearings starting in a week.

title: At UConn, $1 Billion Plan and a New Chief
description: Philip E. Austin was quite content doing what he had been doing the last seven years as Chancellor of the University of Alabama, overseeing three different campuses, 43,000 students and a budget of $1.1 billion.

title: Test-Ban Monitoring Need Not Wait for India
description: To the Editor:

title: Doris Rosenblum, 71, Activist and Neighbor
description: The shock has subsided and the memorial is being planned, but around the Upper West Side, the loss of Doris Rosenblum is still keenly felt.

title: Can a State Go Too Far In Courting Business?
description: ''O Governor, Won't You Buy Me a Mercedes Plant?'' (Sept. 1), by Allen R. Myerson, examined the debate over how Alabama attracted the German auto maker and 1,500 new jobs at a cost approaching $300 million in tax breaks and other subsidies. The article drew these responses from readers:

title: Mr. Dole Bumps a Good Treaty
description: It is not uncommon for election-year politics to contaminate Congressional lawmaking, but a vitally important international treaty should not be cynically sacrificed for political advantage. That is what happened last week when Bob Dole reached back into the Senate to block the expected approval of an agreement banning the development, production, stockpiling, sale and use of chemical weapons.

title: Noreen McCann, Peter B. Healey
description: Noreen Anne McCann, a daughter of Noreen C. McCann of the Bronx and the late Edward J. McCann, was married yesterday to Peter Bannan Healey, the son of Angela and Robert Healey of Newport, R.I. The Rev. Peter F. Bannan, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Frances de Chantal Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx.

title: Under Growing Criticism, Hunters Discuss Ethics to Restore Their Image
description: For the last several years, hunters have been subjected to a campaign by animal rights advocates that depicts them as wanton, unfeeling killers.

title: New Yorkers Bring Storm Aid to Puerto Rico
description: An emergency team from New York City was in Puerto Rico yesterday, bringing electric generators and water and helping local officials restore power and clean up the devastation left by Hurricane Hortense, which has left 24 people dead.

title: Its identity is in cloistered courts of brick and stone
description: A town where scholars and students have lived in unbroken succession for nearly 800 years is a town full of ghosts, and the ghost that any former student meets upon returning is his own.

title: More Method Than Madness in North Korea
description: THE FIRST THING I DID IN NORTH KOREA IS what every visitor does; I presented a bouquet of flowers -- carried in my hand luggage on the Air Koryo flight from Beijing -- before the huge bronze statue of the Great Leader, the late President Kim Il Sung, in downtown Pyongyang.

title: The Super Snow Dome
description: Only the most ardent kitschophobe could not love a snow dome. But for kitschophiles, these silly objects, available wherever souvenirs are sold, can be addictive. (A Washington collector had 6,000 at last count.) Snow domes, however, take up space and themselves collect dust. Herewith, the only snow dome you'll ever really need. Paste it on cardboard, prop it on your mantle, and you'll never dust again.

title: Pink Think
description: I thought feminizing would be civilizing.

title: Next Stop for Bill Bradley
description: Bill Bradley will soon be retiring from the United States Senate. What advice would you offer on how he can best serve New Jersey and the country as a private citizen?

title: Bermuda, Martinique Stage Fall Jazz Festivals
description: Two island events for music lovers are scheduled this fall: Bermuda Jazzscape, in Bermuda from Oct. 11 to 13, and the 12th International Guitar Festival, a biennial event, on Martinique from Nov. 30 to Dec. 8.

title: The 'Big Hair' State? Not Anymore
description: ON behalf of Jersey girls of all ages, the following is the Jersey column's response to the Hawaii-based sunglasses company that ran humorous national ads depicting two helmet-haired ladies as representing ''all these women in Jersey'' who are ''using so much hair spray'' that the earth's ozone layer is being destroyed:

title: Six Flags Wants to March Into Tourist Territory
description: WITH six of the state's seven top tourist attractions already in place, one about to open and another on its way, southeastern Connecticut may get still more destinations and millions of visitors if proposals for two entertainment complexes are realized.

title: It's a Love-Hate Thing
description: At the corner of the former U.S. embassy in Teheran now sits a small shop called ''The Center for Publication of the U.S. Espionage Den's Documents'' -- a bookstore of sorts, selling dusty paperbacks containing the secret documents found when the embassy was stormed by Iranian students in the revolutionary days of 1979. The man behind the counter couldn't quite recall when someone last came in to buy a book. His languid demeanor, though, his three-day-old stubble and the broken air-conditioning all suggested that this was not Barnes & Noble, and that his shop had long ago seen its last real customer. But like much of Iran's anti-U.S. rhetoric today, the shop stays open -- partly on inertia, partly because America-bashing is useful for the regime and partly because Iran's leaders have long forgotten what a normal relationship with the U.S. is like.

title: San Francisco With a Twist
description: Recently I took an impromptu trip from New York City to California with a singular intention: to sample martini cocktails in the bars at each of a dozen or so of the swankest hotels in San Francisco, and then make some sort of definitive judgment about them.

title: Susan Medgyesy, Preston Grandin
description: Helen Susan Medgyesy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Peter Medgyesy of Attleboro, Mass, was married yesterday to Preston Breckinridge Grandin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Livingston Grandin of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Hal Tilghman performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: The Wild Frontier
description: Wagons, ho! The American West gets a series as big as Montana when PBS begins broadcasting THE WEST - SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on CHANNEL 13. The eight-par documentary, directed by Stephen Ives, runs 12 1/2 hours, tracing the history of the vast territory that has always embodied open spaces, new beginnings and limited possibility.

title: Not Enough Time in a Day? Meet the Master Jugglers
description: Sure, sure. We know. There's just not enough time in the day, the month, the whole year, for that matter. You would love to exercise, plow through books, play an instrument, learn a foreign language. You'd even floss your teeth if you had more time. But hey, there is only one of you. You have a demanding job, a busy schedule and you've got to sleep sometime, right?

title: F.Y.I.
description: Getting to the Source

title: East Village: The Hip, The Rowdy, the Cozy
description: AGROTIKON ++

title: Public Furor Over Nursing Baby in a Car
description: DINA TANTIMONACO, a new mother, could make herself dizzy figuring out the dos and dont's of a baby. But she never doubted she would breast-feed.

title: Lisa Menegon, Edward Lovejoy
description: Lisa Ann Menegon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benito A. Menegon of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Edward Winchester Lovejoy, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Lovejoy Jr. The Rev. Gary W. Smith performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Branford, Conn.

title: WORK
description: The author has the temerity to tell those of us who do work how we have to function in order to get the unproductive members of society out of their beds and off their duffs. Then, to top it off, we have to bring the jobs to them.

title: Protect the Children? Not With These Gates
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking a Page From Their Book
description: DURING THE FESTIVITIES THIS TUESDAY celebrating Ismail Merchant and James Ivory's 35th anniversary, you won't see Helena Bonham Carter worrying that recent activities in the garden have engendered a kerfuffle, and Emma Thompson will not pause on a staircase to process a small, complicated emotion. Instead, a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall will feature the music of Richard Robbins, Merchant-Ivory's composer, and then on Sept. 20 and Oct. 9 Warner Brothers will release two new films, respectively: ''Surviving Picasso,'' Ivory's take on the philandering titan, and ''The Proprietor,'' directed by Merchant, usually the production half of the team.

title: Who Is He? Why Is He Here? Perot's Nominee Speaks
description: James B. Stockdale posed the question best, four years ago, when he found himself on stage with Al Gore and Dan Quayle at the Vice-Presidential debate. ''Who am I?'' he asked. ''Why am I here?'' Today, Ross Perot's 1992 running mate is a Bob Dole delegate.

title: Pictures of Faith
description: It isn't God but faith that is in the details of Thomas Roma's dramatic, honest photographs of services in black Brooklyn churches in COME SUNDAY (Museum of Modern Art/Abrams, $35). Tapping every shade of gray between starch white and stark black, Mr. Roma's photographs gracefully capture countless details: the shine on an exposed tooth, the precise thickness of a braid, a hand's tight clutch on a Bible. Mr. Roma is particularly skilled at portraying texture, finding and exploiting contrasts among the corduroys, silks, polyesters and wools of Sunday-best suits and dresses. Between walls of plywood paneling and stucco, in pews and in folding chairs, Mr. Roma's subjects chat, crack smiles, doze, read, weep and cheer. But mostly they pray, and in his introductory essay Henry Louis Gates Jr., the chairman of Harvard University's Afro-American studies department, writes that the intensity of their prayers is linked to earthly hardships. ''Roma's worshipers are figures of transcendence, paradoxically all-too-rooted in this world by the burdens of unemployment and underemployment, ghetto housing and crime-infested neighborhoods,'' he writes. Mr. Gates is of course correct. However, ''Come Sunday'' is not primarily concerned with belief itself; if one sensibility pervades the praying faces of Mr. Roma's subjects, it is absolute trust -- perhaps the most dramatic evidence of faith available. Alexandra Hall

title: Fresh Starts, Anniversaries And Tributes
description: A whirl of parties, dripping in chic, honor fashion designers' new endeavors and the return of a magazine. Meanwhile, lower Manhattan goes plaid.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Playing in the Neighborhood column last Sunday about an exhibition of photographs of the beat generation by Larry Keenan misstated the date that one of Mr. Keenan's best-known photos, ''The Last Gathering of Beat Poets and Artists, City Lights Books,'' was taken. It was 1965.

title: The Packaging Of a Perpetrator
description: THE perp walk got a new look in Arkansas last week, when a mini-skirted Susan McDougal was led from the United States Courthouse and Post Office Building in Little Rock in chains and leg irons for vowing to maintain her silence about her former partner in the Whitewater venture, Bill Clinton.

title: Northern Illinois No Match for Penn State
description: On the opening drive of the game, Northern Illinois looked as if maybe, just maybe, it belonged on the same football field as No. 6 Penn State.

title: I'M NO HOWARD STERN, YOU DUMMY
description: I'd like to add a note to Alex Witchel's warm piece on Don Rickles, from the perspective of a working stiff (''I'm No Howard Stern, You Dummy,'' Aug. 25). While studying for my doctorate in English at Arizona State University, I played trombone professionally in the Phoenix area. One of the better venues was always Buster Bonoff's Star Theater, where Liberace, Robert Goulet and others -- including Don Rickles -- headlined. Performers traditionally sent the house band some liquid refreshment as a thank-you at the end of a gig. Liberace, I recall, sent a couple of bottles of warm (domestic) champagne. But Rickles sent the band a nice assortment of premium liquors to celebrate the run.

title: Another Round of 'Applause' at Paper Mill
description: THE babble in the New Jersey theater at the moment is all about ''Applause.'' What will become of the new production that is opening the Paper Mill Playhouse season?

title: In Pataki Bond Measure, Cleaning Money for Everyone
description: It looked like a war zone that nature was fast reclaiming. The abandoned pig-iron plant on Lake Erie had been overrun by wildflowers and implacable weeds, its blast furnace reduced to a mound of slag and crumbled brick.

title: Where Students Gasp for Learning
description: For the recent immigrants studying English at Liberty High School in Chelsea, new vocabulary words might include ''oxygen deprivation'' and ''emergency evacuation.'' Over the last two years, students have been hustled out of the school 10 times when toxic fumes or high temperatures made the five-story building at 18th Street and Eighth Avenue unbearable.

title: Finding 'Chi' In the Eye Of the Traffic
description: It is just before sunrise, and at the East River Pavilion off 60th Street the rush-hour cacophony is hard to ignore. Cars and construction workers clang away on the Queensboro Bridge above, and traffic roars by on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive below. Sanitation trucks wheeze into the depot on the south side, while the helicopters are almost deafening as they land at the heliport to the north.

title: For Yachtless, Public Sailing Finds a Berth
description: Bob Roistacher had been staring at the Hudson River for years. A veteran of Columbia University's sailing team, which plies the river by the Dyckman boathouse in Inwood, he never lost the desire to go sailing.

title: Can a State Go Too Far In Courting Business?
description: ''O Governor, Won't You Buy Me a Mercedes Plant?'' (Sept. 1), by Allen R. Myerson, examined the debate over how Alabama attracted the German auto maker and 1,500 new jobs at a cost approaching $300 million in tax breaks and other subsidies. The article drew these responses from readers:

title: Pears, Apples and Plums Sweeten Dessert Menus in the Fall
description: AS autumn approaches, the focus of the dessert menu shifts. Apples, pears and Italian prune plums replace summer's nectarines, blueberries and cherries.

title: New Orlean: A Panoply of People and Pleasures
description: New Orleans may be the only city in the world with a continuous multimedia soundtrack. Walking through the French Quarter from one street to another at any hour of the day or night is like surfing on a ''Greatest Hits'' CD -- there's the lemon-blended cacophony of jazz and Zydeco slithering out of the open doorways of countless bars, of course, but that's only the beginning. There's the rush of the Mississippi making its improbable half-moon turns. There's the clamor of voices, talking, singing, arguing, laughing, the accents Cajun and French and Southern.

title: Disaster Is Imminent, So Plan Ahead
description: OUR SECRET CENTURY

title: Dig He Must, for Stones and Bones
description: SINCE 1988 Dr. Nicholas F. Bellantoni has been Connecticut's state archeologist. He combs the state for historic sites while educating the public about their importance.

title: Dole Promises to Announce His Proposal on Drugs and Crime
description: Bob Dole said in his weekly radio address today that on Monday he would announce a proposal to control drug use and thereby limit violent crime.

title: How The West Was Lost (As a Staple Of TV)
description: VERY NEAR THE END OF ''THE WEST,'' an epic documentary about how the American frontier was settled and how its myths took shape, there is a brief but extraordinary piece of early film: actual scenes from Buffalo Bill's Wild West show. Here are glimpses of the fabulously successful entertainment that the Western scout and showman Buffalo Bill Cody staged for 30 years. In the middle of an arena, Indians with elaborate headdresses ride wildly after soldiers and around tepees, recreating the Battle of the Little Big Horn. A cowboy shoots at several massive buffaloes as enthralled schoolchildren cheer from the bleachers. Buffalo Bill himself, white hair flowing, rides into view carrying the American flag and takes a bow.

title: Valerie Miller, Ludovic Candon
description: Valerie Fullerton Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert G. Miller of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Ludovic Paul Jean Candon, a son of Jean-Louis Candon and Mrs. Andre Vidal, both of Paris. The Rev. Clinton A. Lunt performed the ceremony at the Community Methodist Church in East Norwich, L.I.

title: Moscow Move Casts Doubt On Accord In Chechnya
description: Challenging a key provision of the peace accord for Chechnya, the Kremlin warned today that the southern republic must remain part of Russia.

title: Two Are Charged In Shooting Spree
description: Two members of a Brooklyn street gang were arrested on murder charges yesterday in connection with a drive-by shooting that left one man dead and five wounded on the Fourth of July, the police said.

title: Hail Rosemary
description: IF YOU COULD DISTILL THE AROMA THAT hovers above the shore in Maine, in the Pacific Northwest and all around the Mediterranean, it would be essence of rosemary. Rosemary is the aromatic sum of restless sea and imperturbable woodland. It is what you smell along a wooded path when water is near. Derived from the Latin word for sea dew, it is a simple, reassuring aroma. In the kitchen, it always reminds me of a smart tide on a cold, foggy day.

title: David Tudor Memorial
description: A memorial for the composer David Tudor, who died on Aug. 13, is to be held on Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South, Greenwich Village. Composers Inside Electronics will perform Mr. Tudor's ''Rainforest,'' and a video installation by Molly Davies will document the creation of Mr. Tudor's score for ''Ocean,'' a collaboration with John Cage and Merce Cunningham. Information: (212) 941-8911.

title: Deep Bench, Quick Hook, Torre Wins
description: THEY squeeze together in the clubhouse as if it were the first week of spring training. The mob on the bullpen bench looks like starlings clustered on a telephone wire. The other night in Detroit, the players spilled out of the antiquated Tiger Stadium dugout, sitting on milk crates at the edge of the stands.

title: Walking in the Footsteps Of Prehistoric Ancestors
description: FEW places in Europe are as wild and spectacular as the Pyrenees mountains dividing France and Spain. It was here that the early Europeans lived in large numbers, and few places have as many imprints of their presence.

title: Jefferson's Vision Finally Bears Fruit
description: VIRGINIA'S emergence as a center for viniculture has been anticipated -- repeatedly -- for almost 400 years. It is only in the last decade, though, that Virginia wines have established themselves as wines of choice, not of default. Close to 50 wineries around the state now produce a broad spectrum of satisfactory to terrific wines, many of which are made from vinifera grapes.

title: New Jersey Gamblers Get Cash on the Table
description: Starting tomorrow, gamblers in New Jersey casinos won't have to leave the table to replenish their money supplies. Under a new regulation adopted by the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, players may use A.T.M. cards or credit cards to get cash while continuing to play.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: TRAVEL CD PIRANHA PACK

title: Can't Sleep? Check Out the Polka
description: WHAT national news program informs its audience that the weather in Austin, Minn., is ''Spammy''? Has its own resident polka player? Sends cryptic messages to viewers via screen saver?

title: E. de Carvalho, Composer, Conductor And Teacher
description: Eleazar de Carvalho, the Brazilian conductor, composer and teacher who enjoyed long associations with major American symphony orchestras and music schools, died on Thursday night at his home in Sao Paulo. He died of cancer, said his wife, Sonia Muniz. He was 84.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Benilde Little
description: Benilde Little's first novel, ''Good Hair,'' will be published next month by Simon & Schuster.

title: Here Comes the Bride
description: I was in Kerala, in southwest India, for the summer holidays. How old was I then? Eight perhaps, or 9. I sat on a wet plank in a small wooden boat rocking in a canal. My ayah was next to me, a covered dish in her lap. It held paysam, a fragrant concoction: sweet rice and thickened milk, cardamom, cloves, a sprinkling of saffron. We planned to visit my great-aunt's sister-in-law who lived in a neighboring village and were taking her the paysam for lunch.

title: From the Streets to the Classroom
description: When William Carter started doctoral classes last week at Columbia University's School of Social Work, it was hard to imagine that not so many years ago he was homeless and slept on subway platforms and park benches.

title: AIDS Patients Slipping Through Safety Net
description: William Krantz, a 29-year-old chef who lives in Indianapolis, has AIDS and no health insurance. Early this year, as his medical bills began to mount, he applied for a program that was supposed to help people like him get medications. He is still waiting.

title: Majestic Prancing Steeds, Actors All
description: UNDERSTANDABLY PERHAPS, THE WIRY 39-year-old Frenchman who runs the Zingaro Equestrian and Musical Theater feels the need to deny that his troupe is a circus. After all, there are obvious similarities. The company's members live and occasionally travel in caravans, their permanent home outside Paris is a circular wooden theater that resembles a big top, and their shows involve trained horses and skilled acrobats.

title: The Test of German Tolerance
description: IT is virtually impossible these days to take a stroll along Hamburg's Steindamm thoroughfare without being accosted by men who offer an introduction to Scientology with all the breeziness of a used Chevy dealer.

description: With only minor incidents of violence, hundreds of thousands of Bosnians voted today in elections that the United States and its allies hope are a major step toward democracy and ethnic integration in a country bitterly divided by war.

title: Kelly Defeats DioGuardi In Republican Primary
description: ONCE again, Joseph J. DioGuardi has been rejected by the majority of voters in his effort to return to Congress, this time in last week's Republican primary against the incumbent, Sue Kelly. And once again, Mr. DioGuardi has declined to throw in the towel.

title: U.N. Is Pressed to Name a Woman to an Afghan Peace Mission
description: Rukhsana Sarwar, a professor of English at Kabul University in Afghanistan, had survived coups and a Soviet invasion. Then, in 1992, she had to flee fighting among Afghan factions that left her neighborhood in ruins and the fate of the women of Afghanistan in the hands of Islamic militants determined to deny them a place in civic life.

title: Julia Kuskin and Joel Bell

Kuskin of Manhattan, is to be married at her mother's house today to Joel Ian Bell, a son of Tina Torrance of Rancho Mirage, Calif., and Seattle, and William L. Bell Jr. of Arlington, Va. Cantor William R. Walton is to officiate.

title: Atlanta Sued Over Its Law On Benefits To the Unwed
description: Just days after Mayor Bill Campbell signed into law a measure to grant health and other benefits to domestic partners of unmarried city employees, opponents filed a lawsuit challenging it as fiscally irresponsible and at odds with the state's recently passed ban on same-sex marriage.

title: Disputes With A Contractor
description: To the Editor:

title: Women at War
description: The white-hot enmity between two frontier rancher women, unexplored and unexplained, is at the center of JOHNNY GUITAR (1954), Nicholas Ray's blazingly Freudian western quite unlike any other. Joan Crawford (above) and Mercedes McCambridge are the two women. The picture opened, critics played cool, but the public flocked. Why? Production stories abounded of the outright feuding between the stars. The film makes no attempt to explain why the women are at war except to show two strong people who are greedy for more land and power. It makes for an eyeful - like two rattlesnakes coiled in a deadly tango. This is bony, stark stuff, obviously not for everybody - FRI. at 2:30 P.M. and FRI.-SAT. at 4 A.M. on MAC.

title: Hewitt and Army Trample Ohio U.
description: At the beginning the Cadets did not know what they were doing. Bewilderment and confusion were rampant as their season-opening opponent, Ohio University, scored on its first two possessions to take a 14-0 lead.

title: Annie Oakley's Home, Rich in History
description: WITH stories of a speakeasy, a slave jail, artists and the sharpshooter Annie Oakley, the tiny township of Nutley in New Jersey's Essex County is steeped in its colorful past.

title: Flirting With Suicide
description: Mark Ebenhoch has on his ''command'' voice: the voice of fearless authority he learned during 12 years in the Marines. A fearless voice hardly seems appropriate now, in my hotel room, talking about sex; he wants to get rid of it, but it keeps re-emerging. If he had the money, he'd also like to get rid of the tattoos: the one on his left arm that reads ''U.S.M.C. and damn proud'' and the one on his chest, the so-called meat patch, with his Social Security number and blood type: B-positive. Which could be his catch phrase. Be positive.

description: THE first thing the television news director Paula Walker did when she got to the top of Bear Mountain on a hiking trip recently was catch her breath, pull out her cell phone and call her office.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about General Motors' lineup of new cars misstated the relative size of the G.M. work force and that of the United States Postal Service. G.M.'s work force of more than 700,000 employees is slightly smaller than that of the Postal Service, not twice as big.

title: Giants See Redskins as a Vulnerable Foe
description: Like a general who sees that he is about to be surrounded on all sides, Giants Coach Dan Reeves has done just about everything he can to win and is fighting to get the most out of his players. It is either do what you can to survive or be obliterated.

title: Boggs's Back Is Back In Time for the Orioles
description: The look on Wade Boggs's face this morning was not necessarily one of contentment. But it was free of worry. And that was what mattered most to Boggs.

title: Some Tips For Buying New Houses
description: BUYING a used house is a little like buying a used car -- you can kick the tires all you want but you usually don't know what you've got until it's too late to change your mind. Some people avoid most of the problems associated with used cars by buying new ones instead. Shouldn't the same be true for houses?

title: Laura Pickens, Anthony Cannon
description: Laura Katherine Pickens, a daughter of Loretta and Thomas Pickens of Berwyn, Pa., was married yesterday to Anthony James Cannon, a son of Anne and James Cannon of Wyckoff, N.J. The Rev. Donal Kehew performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church on Block Island, R.I.

title: For the Helmsley Building, Restoration at the Top
description: ALTHOUGH among the fanciest of New York's fancy-dress skyscrapers, the Helmsley Building at 230 Park Avenue was built for no-nonsense reasons -- to make money and speed traffic. Now the lantern of the 1929 tower, originally the New York Central Building, is about to undergo a restoration.

title: Cringing Over Football's Worst Fear
description: IT was the scariest moment of the National Football League season. So far.

title: New Hands Take Reins at Big Manhattan Properties
description: TROUBLE breeds opportunity in the real estate business. Troubles descended forcefully in the early 90's on many owners who had placed mortgages in the 80's on offices, apartment houses and other income-producing properties based on rent projections that could not be achieved.

title: Chartering Your Yacht: Rowboat-Size Returns?
description: BREATHES there a sailor who has not heard the siren song of the charter programs? ''Get paid for owning a boat,'' the ads read, quite a temptation for anyone contemplating the purchase of a yacht. But like any offer that sounds too good to be true, these programs require careful scrutiny.

title: Easy Choices for the Right Insulation
description: CHOOSING home insulation is not a complicated task once you are aware of the materials available and have some understanding of how they are put together. Insulating materials can be grouped into three categories: materials made from living or natural resources, materials made from mineral resources and materials made from chemical synthesis.

title: Remaking the Dolphins
description: In the tell-it-like-it-is world of Jimmy Johnson, where perform or else is the standard, there is no room for malcontents, for cutting corners or for showboating without producing. Johnson has a remedy for players, for trainers, for secretaries, for ball boys -- really, for everyone and anyone around his football team who is lazy and saps the energy from others and makes the experience less fun.

title: Call in the C.I.A. and Cross Your Fingers
description: WHEN the President tells the Central Intelligence Agency to discreetly make a foreign leader disappear, the agency's job is to salute smartly, skulk back to headquarters and try to figure out how in the world to do it. The assignment came last January: topple Saddam Hussein.

title: Nicholas Wahl, 68, Scholar of French Politics
description: Nicholas Wahl, an American political scientist who turned his Institute of French Studies at New York University into a magnet for droves of French political scholars, French journalists and French politicians, died yesterday at a hospital in London, where he had been living during a sabbatical. He was 68 and lived on Washington Square.

title: INSIDE
description: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 5/

title: Que Pasa, Miss Italy?
description: Are national beauty pageants about beauty or about national notions of beauty? Italians were debating this and other questions after the Miss Italy 1996 jury last weekend awarded the crown to Denny Mendez, an 18-year-old Dominican-born contestant who moved to Italy four years ago, and who is black.

title: And So Is Waiting for New Judges to Fill Empty Benches
description: It takes Robert Vetra 20 minutes to drive from his law office in Mount Laurel to the Burlington County Courthouse in Mount Holly, where he makes frequent appearances in Superior Court. But several times this year, Mr. Vetra has ended up driving much farther for court dates, with files, clients and witnesses in tow.

title: Does Decency Equal Religion?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Congress and the Issues
description: The West

title: They Call It Luddite Love
description: Laura Woodswalker -- a pseudonym for a 45-year-old Pennsylvania woman who would only ''speak'' to us via the Internet -- admits to feeling a strong ''emotional identification'' with Theodore Kaczynski, the Unabom suspect, but denies she's in love. ''My interest is purely platonic,'' she writes. O.K., but it sounds fairly torrid. Woodswalker, who agrees with many of the Unabomber's anti-industrial-society views (even though, like many Unabuffs, she's a computer user), has written short stories about Kaczynski and has sent him several letters with self-addressed stamped envelopes. (No reply.) Her husband isn't pleased. ''$(He$) resents me spending my time writing Internet postings,'' she admits, ''that 'glorify a serial killer.' ''

title: Elaine Clayton, Simon Boughton
description: Helen Elaine Clayton and Simon Boughton were married yesterday at Pronto Cena, a restaurant in Jersey City. Canon Ashton Jacinto Brooks performed the ceremony.

title: The Stadium We Deserve
description: The guiding spirits behind our proposal for a New Yankee Superstadium (left) are two famously assertive New Yorkers: George Steinbrenner and the late Robert Moses. As Yankee fans know, Steinbrenner intends to jilt the Bronx and build a new ball park elsewhere, but he has been vague about how fans might benefit from this gut-wrenching move. the N.Y.S.S.T. vision (henceforth, ''Nisty'') answers this question with the classic Gotham response: Big Is Best. In so doing, it borrows a page from Moses, the fabled master builder who scoffed at mere human-scale structures. Indeed, if Moses still controlled the city's map, he would want the new pin-stripe palace to be clearly visible from Mars. Nisty isn't quite that grandoise, but it does, we believe, match the grandeur, scale and - yes, arbitrariness, eccentricity and even madness - of the Yankees, their owner and their fans.

title: Newly Minted Americans
description: Last week 6,000 people from 80 countries became citizens in Houston. On Tuesday 10,000 will take the oath outside Dallas; on Wednesday, 12,000 to 15,000 in San Jose, Calif. In unprecedented numbers, in mass swearings-in, newly minted citizens are renouncing their native lands for a country caught up in a fever of anti-immigrant laws and xenophobic sentiment. Changes in immigration policy have also enabled more naturalizations. By the end of the this month, 1.1 million immigrants will have become citizens; last year 445,853 were sworn in, shattering a record set in 1944.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19

title: 'Some Day I'll Be In Out of the Rain'
description: ANGELA'S ASHESA Memoir.By Frank McCourt.364 pp. New York:Scribner. $24.

title: Madam President
description: DREAMS OF THE HEART

title: The Healing Poets' Society
description: Dark, heavy thoughts overload Carl Herr's mind like a sagging plastic grocery bag straining a shopper's hand. Relief from his psychosis often comes with his daily dosages of medication, but sometimes even his pills don't help.

title: R.A. Pfeiffer Jr., 69; Rebuilt Covenant House
description: Ralph A. Pfeiffer Jr., a retired chairman of the IBM World Trade Corporation who helped revive Covenant House after the shelter was tarnished by scandal, died on Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 69.

title: Curing Stress, Creatively
description: Dr. Sanford L. Klein, chief of anesthesiology at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital here, has found one rather unusual way of relieving stress. He makes steel knives.

title: Painter Depicts Love of Strays in Portraits
description: MENTION dog portraits and most people probably envision aristocratic-looking spaniels on velvet cushions, pointers and setters in the English countryside or pampered poodles on their owners' laps.

title: Brooke Donahoe, John Roberts
description: Brooke Bradley Donahoe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Donahoe 3d of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married there yesterday to John Brinton Roberts, the son of Camilla von Bergen and Henry B. Roberts Jr., both of Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Spaulding, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at John Gardner's Tennis Ranch.

title: Study Finds Flaws In Emergency Care
description: IF your child is having difficulty breathing or suffering from other life-threatening emergencies, the worse place to take him or her may be your pediatrician's office.

title: Natural History at Unnatural Prices
description: For the person who has almost everything, how about a 6-by-5-foot plaster cast of the jaws of an extinct great white shark, complete with more than 100 real fossilized teeth? It sold last year for $32,200.

title: Rethinking Injuries in the Workplace
description: A WOMAN who works in graphic design at a small newspaper in Connecticut was suffering excruciating pain in her arm, particularly her shoulder and wrist. Her doctor proposed surgery to repair muscle and tendon damage, but first he referred her to the ergonomics center at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington.

title: Fate of a Derelict Mill Clouds Patchogue's Future
description: THE first thing that visitors from the west see as they enter this South Shore village is a complex of dilapidated red-brick factory buildings, which many say is a prime cause of the community's deteriorating fortunes.

title: The Meeting of Minds in a Legendary Union
description: ASK WORKING JAZZ MUSICIANS what question they're most often asked, and they will probably say something like, ''Do you guys just make up this stuff on the spot?'' The notion that the solos, if not entire performances, are improvisations created out of nowhere is a long-held misconception. It belies the fact that jazz playing can be a highly disciplined art of theme and variation. From the beginning, jazz composers have struggled to integrate improvisation with written music. In the hands of masters like Jelly Roll Morton, Duke Ellington, Charles Mingus and John Lewis, the two elements enhance each other.

title: After Unbuttoning Its Image, a Retailing Legend Comes to Market
description: THE new-stock offering of Abercrombie & Fitch is a deal that Teddy Roosevelt and Ernest Hemingway might have liked. After all, Abercrombie remains a successful purveyor of upscale casual apparel, just as it was in the days when it outfitted Roosevelt and Hemingway for safari.

title: Same Pass, No Catch: Michigan Gets Chance to Rewrite History
description: Two seasons later, the Michigan Wolverines turned their nightmare into a celebration.

title: Teach, Take Bath, Cook Pasta and Fret Over a Man (on Stage)
description: MICHAEL GAMBON'S American stage debut may be the obvious event of ''Skylight,'' but David Hare's play is no one-person show. Mr. Gambon's co-star, Lia Williams, is pictured on the front of the published English text, her long, straight hair blowing in some unfelt wind. In London, at least, it was Ms. Williams who emerged last for her bow. And why not, since she never once leaves the stage during a draining two and a half hours?

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: In this age when almost anything goes, manners is the unlikely subject that unifies the four fine films that highlight this week's schedule.

title: Philharmonic Facing Double Duty
description: AUDIENCE size is not an obsession with the Westchester Philharmonic, said Paul Lustig Dunkel, founding music director of the ensemble. ''We honestly feel we represent art to the public. We're to Westchester what most ball teams are to their city. We will continue our outreach to all county residents and break down cultural barriers of all types.''

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 25 about access to county government on the Internet misstated the E-mail address for County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. It is:

title: Class in Defeat
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shotgun Weddings
description: I DON'T have a car. I don't want a car. If I forget to water my scheflerra, how could I possibly take care of a car? ''Gas me, polish me, check my oil,'' it would whine. Why do I need a car when so many of my dazzling friends have cars?

title: At Belmont, Cigar Starts A New Streak at One
description: Cigar lives. Cigar wins. Cigar reigns.

title: Going After the Old and Rare, Sometimes the Very Strange
description: TOM JOHNSON of Sandy Hook loves antique furniture, but his wife, Connie, prefers new furniture, albeit pieces that look antique.

title: Africa Outgrows A Magazine From Paris
description: From its birth 36 years ago as a tiny newsmagazine under a Tunisian publisher whose unfettered voice spoke for the emergence of Africa's newly independent countries, Jeune Afrique aimed to be indispensable weekly reading for an entire continent.

title: Some Images Stick. Some Don't. Why?
description: IMAGINE, for a moment, if Bob Dole, on three occasions this year, had responded to reporters' questions with red-faced outbursts.

title: In Praise of Haydn, Father of an Art Form
description: THE days of our years are three score and ten,'' reads the 90th Psalm, ''or by reason of strength, four score.'' Before this century, most composers were not lucky enough to attain that life span. Bach, Beethoven and Brahms didn't make it, and Mozart, Schubert, Mendelssohn, Purcell, Bizet, Bellini, Chopin and Gershwin all died in their 30's.

title: A Challenger in Flatbush Loses Despite an Appeal to Race
description: Despite running in a district that is three-quarters black and Hispanic, a Caribbean immigrant could not unseat a wite incumbent in last Tuesday's Democratic Assembly primary in Flatbush.

title: Every President's Child Could Use a Good Buddy
description: The Crow: City of Angels

title: What Was in It for Them?
description: THE LOGIC OF EVIL

title: Huskies' Defense Stops B.Y.U.
description: Washington 29

title: Bedford Seeks Retailers to Speed Growth
description: BEING just another pretty-faced hamlet is not enough for Bedford. Her merchants want her to go out and earn. But has her time passed?

title: Lighthouse Beckons Vacationer, Come and Work
description: It took all of Charlotte Johnson's creativity 12 years ago to help save the Rose Island Lighthouse, a beacon in Newport Harbor, from extinction.

title: From Finistere To the Wester Isles
description: Up in our bare, whitewashed room-with-a-view over a creperie in Le Conquet, a village at the tip of Brittany, my husband, Max, and I are planning our tour of the three westernmost islands in France. It is midafternoon, and, in the old port below, the tide is out. Stubby-sterned fishing boats lean in muddy shallows or stand on crutches. A squadron of oyster catchers divebombs the shore. The day, which began in brilliant, late October sun, is now all pale, translucent gray. To the left stands a pint-size chateau, once the property of a 16th-century cartographer in the days when Le Conquet made maps for the entire Western world. Its small, sinister-looking towers seem ideal for imprisoning miniature medieval maidens.

title: Alison Haynie, David Byron-Brown
description: Alison Dittemore Haynie, a vice president at J. P. Morgan Securities in Manhattan, was married yesterday to David Paul Byron-Brown, a senior banking-software consultant based in Manhattan. The Rev. Paul Woodrum, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Society of Ethical Culture in Brooklyn.

title: American Gothic
description: FIRST LOVE

title: Few Strings With Big Gift For Harvard
description: A gift of $22 million may seem like a drop in the bucket to Harvard University, which has an endowment of $8.6 billion, but the gift is the kind that development officers dream about, because most of it comes with no strings attached.

title: Complexity of Form In a World of Books
description: ARTISTS often make books, small editions incorporating aspects of their style and subject matter. But few are full-fledged book artists in the way Ken Campbell is.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: A FLING WITH A DEMON LOVERBy Kelvin Christopher James.HarperCollins, $22.

title: Friends, Have I 'Gone Hollywood?'
description: Dear Suzy,

title: THE 00'S
description: Why look to the past to name the next decade (On Language: ''The 00's,'' by Jack Rosenthal, Aug. 18)? I suggest that the year 2000 should be called Deux Mille, pronounced ''da-mill.'' It's metric and Hollywood. The class of Deux Mille -- cool. The class of 2001 will no doubt be described by the full name. Arthur Clarke saw to that. The first decade of the 21st century might be the ''digital decade,'' not only for its single-digit numerals but for the portending dominance of the computer.

title: East Harlem's Sentiments Do Not Represent 'Nimby'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Decides Not To Play Favorites in Trade
description: China rarely ranks very high when American politicians list their their favorite nations. Chinese leaders are regularly excoriated in Congress, by Democrats and Republicans alike, for imprisoning dissidents, shipping missile parts to Pakistan and pirating ''Pocahantas'' videos. Yet every year, with lots of hand-wringing but without fail, China is re-certified for its ''most favored nation'' trading status. Its goods then get the same low-tariff treatment as every other country. But try explaining that in a television sound bite.

title: Wall Street's Masters of Disaster
description: AS hurricanes approach, some people buy candles and hunker down. Others send money to the Red Cross. And some people try to figure out ways to make a buck.

title: Town-House Renovation Becomes a Family Affair
description: AROUND the corner on First Avenue, an old neighborhood institution, Billy's 1870 steak house, survives. But across the street, a fancy bakery now lists ''eggs en cocotte'' on its breakfast menu and lets its clientele admire its patisseries from rattan armchairs.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: LOST IN PLACE: Growing Up Absurd in Suburbia

title: Survivors of the Street Became Champions of the Ring
description: The Spanakos twins still get stares when they visit the old Red Hook places -- the once-sturdy pier that now noses into the water, the bodega that had been a boxing gym and before that a brothel.

title: Director For a Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Psst! Here's What Party Girls Are Really Like
description: ''PARTY GIRL,'' a new sitcom on the Fox network, is supposed to appeal to the 14- to 24-year-old audience that made ''Melrose Place'' a hot show. But ''Party Girl'' does not show how party girls party in New York. At least not the ones I know, and knew during private school on the Upper East Side before graduating last year. There is more sophistication, audacity and rule-bending in New York than on the show. Here are some other ways that ''Party Girl'' misses the party:

title: Hundley's 41st Puts Him in Record Books
description: In a season when Mets fans have not had a lot to cheer about, there has always been Todd Hundley. He came into his fifth full year with the Mets hoping to stay healthy enough to establish himself as one of the game's most dependable catchers. He will end it with a piece of baseball history -- a record that had stood for 43 years.

title: Quaint customs have nothing to do with what matters
description: A portrait of President Clinton by R. B. Kitaj has recently been hung in the dining hall of University College, Oxford, joining those of other famous alumni, such as the former British Prime Minister Clement Attlee. The writer V.S. Naipaul was at the same college. I mention this simply to indicate the breadth and complexity of the net that Oxford spreads. There could hardly be two men whose concerns and vision are more polarized than those of President Clinton and V.S. Naipaul, but both of them carry in their heads the same set of images: the glow of limestone buildings in the autumn sun, the stack of bicycles outside college entrances, punts and eights on the river. Tens of thousands of people share the same freight of reference, with a different significance for each.

title: Private Glimpses Of a Private Man
description: WHEN BERNARD B. JACOBS, one of the most powerful men in the American theater, died on Aug. 27 at the age of 80, he left endless questions about the future of the Shubert Organization, the largest theater owner on Broadway. And despite the fact that Mr. Jacobs, who headed the Shubert Organization with Gerald Schoenfeld, was a famously private man, he also left personal memories among friends and colleagues. Here are a few. WILLIAM HARRIS

title: Taped Advice In Taxis Has Angry Drivers Pulling Plug
description: The recorded message -- in a variety of accents, from Brooklynese to Yiddish to generic -- advises departing passengers to take along their things and to ask for a receipt. But for thousands of taxi drivers, the Voice is simply haunting.

title: A Who's Who in Art At Island Cemetery
description: There are many cemeteries on Long Island, some historic, some devoted only to families, and at least one, in East Northport, preserved within the parking lot of a shopping center. In addition to those devoted to people of one religious faith, there are two national cemeteries that honor those who fell in combat for the United States.

title: Susan Addiss, Brendan Hemingway
description: BEARDED and bearlike, Brendan Hemingway looks remarkably like his grandfather Ernest Hemingway. He resembles him in other ways as well. He is athletic, well traveled (he grew up in England and went to boarding school in Ireland) and does almost everything in a larger-than-life way.

title: An American in Paris
description: Some Remarkable Men

title: Ms. Whitehead And Mr. Mobley
description: Patricia Twells Whitehead, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Whitehead of Chalfont, Pa., was married yesterday to Nathan Mobley 3d, a son of Ellen Scranton Conway of Greenwich, Conn., and Nathan Mobley Jr. of San Francisco. The Rev. Matthew Creighton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: The War at the Shore
description: THE oil spots that washed up on the Jersey Shore from various spills and leaks this summer worried environmentalists and doubtless annoyed many bathers. But they brought me back to a time when oil on the beach meant something else altogether.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: The Twilight of an Ivy League Institution
description: For Yale's Carmen Cozza, this season, his 32d, will be his last as head football coach. His teams have won 177 of 293 games and 10 Ivy League titles, and his players numerous awards. ''A record of achievement Yale will never see again,'' said Fred Leone, the 1981 captain. Cozza, a native of Parma, Ohio, who had never traveled east of Pittsburgh, came to Yale as an assistant coach in 1962 from his alma mater, Miami of Ohio. Here are comments he made in a conversation with William N. Wallace of The Times's sports staff.

title: Returning to Newark to Remember the Dead
description: For 364 days a year, the Grove Street Cemeteries are a desolate, dangerous place. Crack vials and tiny plastic dope pouches litter the cemetery grounds. Headstones are toppled, domino-like, with the utmost disrespect.

title: Campaign Trail
description: DEMOCRACY IN AMERICA '96 is a series that focuses on issues facing voters and wouldbe leaders on the eve of a Presidential election. Judy Woodruff and Bernard Shaw are commentators for the seven hour long documentaries, beginning with ''My Child, My Fear'' - SUNDAY at 9 P.M. on CNN. In it Ms. Woodruff looks at public education and the impact of changes in family structure (fatherlessness, working parents) on American children. Later programs are about a ''toxic culture'' of violence, AIDS, drugs and the like; job issues, and a growing cynicism toward government and the media. The series concludes with the role of the First Lady and the candidates themselves.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ALICE ON STAGE

title: Revisiting a 19th-Century Company Town
description: WHEN the townspeople of Canton turn out for the second annual Sam Collins Day next Saturday, they will be paying homage to one of the more unusual and resourceful entrepreneurial industrialists of 19th-century America.

title: And the Foundation, Where the Money Comes From
description: THE R. in the name of the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation stands for Rockefeller. In the 1920's, Geraldine Dodge -- daughter of William Rockefeller, president of the Standard Oil Company -- and her husband, Hartley, heir to the Remington arms fortune, were the richest young couple in the country. When Mrs. Dodge, who lived in Madison, died in the early 1970's, she left part of her fortune to create the New Jersey-based foundation.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Pretty Baby Moves On to Prime Time
description: GORGEOUS, gorgeous, gorgeous. The adjective has followed Brooke Shields around for so long that she could put it on her resume and no one would accuse her of boasting. In movies, in magazines, in Calvins, she has been type-cast in a role from which genetics has offered her no escape.

title: Behind North Korea's Barbed Wire: Capitalism
description: In the lobby of the Sonbong House of Culture is a huge oil painting of the late ''Great Leader,'' Kim Il Sung, and his son, and current leader, Kim Jong Il. But in the alcoves, North Koreans wearing their Kim Il Sung buttons on business suits are wheeling and dealing with foreign entrepreneurs and investment bankers about potential joint ventures and marketing tie-ins.

title: Shorter Days, Winding Down to Winter
description: THE days getting shorter may mean the end of summer fun and the beginning of school but the phenomenon is also a major signal for plants.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: PROF TALK
description: After kicking English professors, those prime practitioners of postmodernist writing (some of which is very good, by the way) at their laptops, Stephen G. Bloom and James L. Wunsch, who teach journalism and history respectively, pat themselves on the head (On Language: ''Prof Talk,'' Aug. 25). But the wide public understanding that they claim for journalistic writing is hardly proof of its veracity. There are times when the ''plain talk'' that Bloom and Wunsch advocate distorts the truth through a deliberate avoidance of complexity.

title: Purdue Cannot Touch Notre Dame's Offense
description: The weather was in midseason form today, but Notre Dame and Purdue decidedly were not as the Irish prevailed by 35-0 in a game every bit as dreary as the cold, rainy Midwestern afternoon.

title: A Matter Of Mechanics
description: To the Editor:

title: BAD SPORTS
description: To deny that golf has a spiritual side because of bad writers on the subject is like condemning romance because of Robert James Waller (Culture Zone: ''Bad Sports,'' by Michiko Kakutani, Aug. 25). In decrying the idea of Zen golf because it ''takes sport out of the lovely pure realm of the physical,'' she recreates the very mind-body dichotomy that Zen seeks to subvert.

title: Science Fiction
description: Science fiction novels, like detective novels, tend to beget sequels, which, if successful, beget long-running series. But while each book in the typical series starring a popular detective can be read on its own, many science fiction series are actually multivolume narratives whose later volumes are all but unintelligible if read out of order.

title: Time-Share Sales At Midtown Condo
description: With its opening still seven months away, the Manhattan Club, the first major time-share condominium in New York City, has sold its first 135 shares, according to the club's developer, Ian Bruce Eichner. Each share represents the right to occupy a room or suite for a week a year.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Every President's Child Could Use a Good Buddy
description: Bogus

title: Giuliani Says School Overcrowding Is Overstated
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday there were misconceptions about school overcrowding in New York City, suggesting that the Board of Education had not addressed the problem properly and had provided confusing information about the situation to the public.

title: Miss Travers, Mr. Stettinius
description: Regina Marie Sarah Travers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter George Travers of Farmington, Conn., was married yesterday to Joseph Stettinius Jr., a son of Mrs. Michael Ballentine and Mr. Stettinius, both of Richmond. The Rev. Ned W. Edwards Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ Congregational in Farmington.

title: The Schools Need $7 Billion
description: When I was appointed chairman of a commission on school maintenance in March 1994, I had not been inside a New York City public school since I graduated from the Bronx High School of Science in 1970.

title: Ms. Zekavat, Dr. Nourbakhsh
description: Susan Zekavat, the daughter of Drs. Pouran and Hassan Zekavat of Moorestown, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Mohsen Nourbakhsh, a son of Farzaneh Nourbakhsh and Dr. Ahmad Nourbakhsh of Monkton, Md.

title: Turow? Thoreau? No, Theroux.
description: My Other Life

title: INSIDE
description: Capitalism in North Korea

title: Counseling the Poor, But Now One by One
description: When Congressional Republicans barred Federally financed lawyers three months ago from suing the Government on behalf of large groups of poor clients, both the lawyers and their opponents predicted stark consequences.

title: Boats in Friendship Race
description: More than 200 sailboats are expected to compete today in the Stamford Denmark Friendship Race on Long Island Sound.

title: Magazines As a Way Of Life
description: MAGAZINE publishing in New York is like the movie industry in Los Angeles. In a city where publishers are as feared as studio bosses, and editors are treated like stars, it wasn't surprising that the party Tuesday for the $40 million revival of House and Garden at the Four Seasons was as packed as Spago for the Academy Awards.

title: Look, but Don't Buy: A New Kind of Window-Shopping at the Mall
description: NEW JERSEY'S shopping malls are known for offering almost anything. These days, that includes something unexpected and without a price tag: the chance to contemplate fine art.

title: Agreement On Lilco Is Reported Nearer
description: AFTER months of secret negotiations, the Long Island Lighting Company and the Long Island Power Authority are nearing agreement on a revised state plan to lower electric rates, officials involved in the talks said last week.

title: With a Victory, Dominicans Flex A Growing Muscle
description: When John Brian Murtaugh was first elected to the State Assembly 16 years ago, Hispanic residents made up just over half of the population of his district, which takes in Washington Heights and Inwood. Today, 80 percent of the 72d District's residents are Hispanic, most immigrants from the Dominican Republic. In last Tuesday's Democratic primary, that demographic reality helped elect Adriano D. Espaillat, 41, a Dominican who defied the pundits by beating Mr. Murtaugh by just 196 votes.

title: An Asian Billionaire Tries to Fly by the New Rules
description: EARLIER this summer, the largest tax evasion case on the planet landed in the lap of the Supreme Court of the Philippines. Lucio Tan, one of the country's richest men, stood accused of evading more than $1 billion in taxes.

title: U.S. Companies Can Live With Trade Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Lydia P. Arnold, Terry Turnipseed
description: Lydia Palmer Arnold, a daughter of Gale Palmer Arnold of Washington and Chief Judge Richard Sheppard Arnold of Little Rock, Ark., was married yesterday to Terry Lynn Turnipseed, a son of Dr. Jorja Turnipseed of Starkville, Miss., and the late J. Larry Turnipseed. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

title: Simple Dry Whites Offer Excellent Value
description: BASED on recent samplings and a survey of retail outlets, those simple, straightforward dry whites known collectively as Macon blanc offer excellent value, particularly as accompaniment to light seasonal fare, and many stores are stocking at least a few of the most popular brands.

title: A Timely Tale, With Endings Unforewarned
description: TO THE MOVIEGOING PUBLIC he was just beginning to reach, Russ Hexter was an unknown. But he did not come out of nowhere. Here, then, are some salient facts about him.

title: Texas Bar Sends a Warning To Its Overzealous Lawyers
description: Prompted by complaints about lawyers' trolling for business after major disasters, bar groups are trying to clamp down on the solicitation of clients.

title: County by County, Cellblock Overflow Is Still the Norm
description: At a groundbreaking ceremony this month for a $50 million expansion of the Bergen County Jail, Governor Whitman told state and local officials that the event could serve as a cautionary message to criminals. ''There is,'' she said, ''always room for one more.''

title: At Rockleigh School, a Student Finds Calm and a Second Chance
description: With its 270 residents nestled in the northeast corner of Bergen County, the borough of Rockleigh seems an unlikely candidate to have the highest violent crime rate in the state. But for years it did.

title: A Souvenir That's Worth a Detour From the Boardwalk
description: That the macaroon is the most frequently smuggled dessert from Atlantic City's casino buffets is no accident. Until the casinos came to town, Tripician's Macaroons were one of Atlantic City's most famous names, along with two saltwater taffy makers, Fralinger's and James, when it came to Boardwalk souvenir sweets.

title: Minding Your Mouth
description: It was the only time in four trips to India that I have come home unwell; I am vigilant -- usually -- about what I eat and drink.

title: UP IN SMOKE
description: Tobacco farmers see the end of an era coming (''Up in Smoke,'' by Luisita Lopez Torregrosa, Aug. 25). I see the beginning of a new day when those farmers will prosper, growing vegetables for the Eastern market. Decades earlier, we decided to provide extensive Federal subsidies to Western agribusiness -- in a deal that eventually forced unsubsidized Eastern producers off their farms, even though they provided a better and cheaper product. Agribusiness got Federally subsidized water to grow food in the desert, immigration policies to provide cheap labor and a Federal highway network to haul the produce across the continent. Meanwhile, in the East, there is adequate rainfall and nearby markets, and subsidies are not needed.

title: 6 Ways of Saving a Blackbird (or a Hawk, a Robin or an Owl)
description: The Raptor Trust offers these suggestions for helping birds avoid injury. More information is available by calling (908) 647-2353.

title: Who's the Real Enemy Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: Like Parent, Like Teen-Ager?
description: Teen-agers whose parents once puffed marijuana regularly are more likely to use it than other teen-agers, a new study found.

title: Buy Me Some Peanuts and Photographs . . .
description: FROM CARDS TO AUTOGRAPHED jerseys, bats and balls, everything relating to baseball seems to be a collectible today. The exception is photographs of baseball heroes, especially those without a player's signature.

title: Where Style Is Made in the Shades
description: Some things a newcomer learns quickly upon arrival in Los Angeles: Those motorists you see babbling to themselves on the freeway are not schizophrenics; they are so sane they installed speaker phones so they could drive with both hands. A tank top is perfectly suitable for dining in a fancy restaurant. And when someone says he is writing a screenplay, you must not ask, ''About what?'' because he will think you want to steal his idea.

title: The Voice of Women in Politics
description: SHE was considered a trailblazer, one of a tough new breed of women breaking ground in politics. She edged into the old boys' network, cut deals in smoked-filled rooms and promoted the economic and social causes affecting women. Recently, though, Cecile D. Singer, 66, looked back at the generation of female politicians coming up in the ranks and said that, contrary to what she had hoped for, there was no thundering herd following in her footsteps.

title: Some Days, the Rabbi Wears Blue
description: RABBI ALVIN KASS had settled into his first pulpit, in Astoria, when he got a call from the New York Board of Rabbis to interview for the part-time job of Jewish police chaplain. Rabbi Kass had never even been inside a police station. What got him the job, he thinks, was his answer to a question about the counseling of cops. He said that ''a rabbi has to know when to go to higher authority.'' Commissioner Howard Leary and the other top cops nodded at each other; it was clear Rabbi Kass was not talking about God.

title: Leah C. Johnson, Gerrard P. Bushell
description: Leah Colette Johnson, the press secretary for New York City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, and Gerrard Patrick Bushell, the director of intergovernmental relations for New York State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, are to be married today. Fred A. Davie Jr., the Deputy Borough President of Manhattan who is a Presbyterian minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Hotel Westbury in Manhattan.

title: When Quitting Is Un-American
description: WHEN two prominent officials in the Department of Health and Human Services resigned in protest last week over President Clinton's welfare policy, it represented an unusual twist in American politics.

title: Out of Season, Off Track
description: If you're traveling out of season, make sure you know when the season begins.

title: The Patience of Joe
description: MANAGER JOE TORRE OF THE NEW YORK YANKEES sits in the California Angels' visiting manager's office eyeing a Peruvian good-luck charm that has just been presented to him by a sportswriter. Torre is wearing a blue T-shirt that reads, ''We play tonight, we win tonight.'' Wishful thinking. The Yankees haven't been winning many games these past late-summer nights. Before the All-Star Game in July, they led the American League East by 12 games. Since then, they've had trouble winning half the time.

title: Where Jobs Have No Collars
description: I'M a milker and ''cowperson'' on a 660-head Holstein dairy in King Ferry in upstate New York, between Ithaca and Auburn. I'm an invisible worker to much of America, which reports employment data in terms of nonagricultural jobs, as if people like me don't exist. Seen as a caste below, agricultural and domestic labor is governed by separate laws concerning wages, overtime, unemployment benefits and work conditions.

title: HAS ANYBODY SEEN THE DEMOCRATIC PARTY?
description: Richard N. Goodwin's ''Has Anybody Seen the Democratic Party?'' (Aug. 25) was inspiring enough to make me abandon the rightward-charging Republicans -- my party for 20 years -- and register this week as a Democrat. He has helped me locate the better angel of my nature (to borrow from that greatest Republican, Abraham Lincoln).

title: After 2 Games, Bengals Are Running on Empty
description: The season started with so much promise for Bengals running back Ki-Jana Carter. But after two games, it has already turned sour.

title: Rafe's Progress
description: DR. NERUDA'S CURE FOR EVILBy Rafael Yglesias.694 pp. New York:Warner Books. $24.95.

title: Men Take The Plunge
description: Plunging necklines for men, associated with the hot designer Tom Ford for Gucci, may remind some people of the unbuttoned sports shirts worn without jackets by Hollywood's Rat Pack in the 1950's and 60's.
