Today, the shirts are dress shirts, and the collars usually spread like wings over black suit jackets for day and evening. Necklines have long been a focus of women's fashion (left). The men's plunge, though still timid compared to women's, reflects the interest in men's wear as fashion. With more men frequenting health clubs, the shirt is a frame for the erogenous zone of the sculptured chest.

title: Simon Times Four
description: Combine the playwright Neil Simon with an all-star cast and the stage is set for LONDON SUITE. The stories, told in a series of interwoven vignettes, take place in an elegant London hotel and follow a day in the life of our couples involved in varying degrees of mischief and romance. Sidney and Diana Nichols (Patricia Clarkson and Kelsey Grammer, above) meet after being divorced for eight years only to discover they are still in love. Mark and Annie Ferris (Michael Richards and Julie Hagerty) are in town for Wimbledon and have mislaid their tickets. Debra Dolby (Julie-Louis Dreyfus) on her honeymoon loses her husband; and Sharon Semple (Madeline Kahn) on a shop-till-she drops spree meets a merry widower. SUNDAY at 9 P.M. on NBC.

title: The Yanks Are Seeing The Magic Reappear
description: The luck is back.

title: Every President's Child Could Use a Good Buddy
description: Bulletproof

title: Once Upon a Model
description: Madeleine, my 4-year-old niece, is the well-dressed child of well-dressed parents. She prefers visiting Barneys to watching Barney videos and is the only girl with a black tutu in her ballet class. Although her nursery-school principal recommends that she wear sneakers, Madeleine refuses. The shoes defining her moment right now are Italian moss-colored suede, very back-to-school. Her other shoes, the black patent-leather ones, are for special occasions only, like the three or four dozen birthday parties she attends each season.

title: Fashion as Art. Or Maybe Not.
description: WHEN Ingrid Sischy first visited the controversial, microbe-size place where fashion meets art, it was 1982, on the cover of Artforum magazine, where she was the 30-year-old editor. An Issey Miyake nylon polyester jacket and skirt with a rattan bodice adorned an issue dedicated not to fashion as art but to the question of just why fashion wasn't considered art. She still hasn't heard the end of it. Most people have probably forgotten that the issue posed the same question about record covers, pulp-fiction book jackets, newspaper photos, magazine covers, jukeboxes, comics and street posters.

title: Things Are Looking Up -- And Going Up
description: FINALLY. After several years of spotty performance, replete with optimistic predictions and disappointed hopes, builders, brokers and industry advisers agree that the commercial real estate market in the New York area seems on a path of steady, if slow, improvement.

title: Square Pegs Stay Out Of School In Japan
description: Chihiro Sato hated the morning and evening Mass in the Catholic school she attended in first grade and felt ostracized by other students when she switched to a public school for second grade. She began suffering headaches and nausea when it came time to go to school.

title: Taking Up a Tennis Racquet to Fight Cancer
description: ALTHOUGH the summer festivities have ended and year-round residents are breathing a sigh of relief as the crowds dissipate, the frenetic fund-raising season in the Hamptons still has not yet drawn to a close.

title: Young Lust
description: Nicky Wertheim is only 10 years old, but the merest sight of Julia Turrell, nine years his senior, fills him with an emotion he can't even name. It's lust. And what would be passing puppy love for anyone else becomes for Nicky pure unbridled infatuation. He and Julia are destined to cross paths again and again, in a series of encounters that brings them both sheer joy and abject misery. In his first novel, SNAKEBITE SONNET (Little, Brown, $22.95), Max Phillips uses darkly comedic tones to draw a bead on the sweet agonies of passion and sex. Part coming-of-age story, part social commentary, Mr. Phillips's novel maneuvers Nicky through his childhood in suburban New Jersey and his college years at Cornell, then follows him to the East Village punk and art worlds of the early 1980's. With deft satiric wit, Mr. Phillips explores the confused emotions of adolescent romance and the even more convoluted world of adult attraction. Ultimately, of course, Nicky finds that perceptions of love and the real thing are often at odds, and that reconciling the two can be just as hard as sorting them out in the first place. Scott Martelle

title: On Tour, the Real Life of Actors
description: IN the matter-of-fact world between superstars for all seasons and stars of the week, real actors work. And travel.

title: Deaf Man Triumphs In a Speaking World
description: IF one meets George Oberlander Jr. and does not realize he is deaf, there's no reason to feel bad. He fooled his mother until he was 5. He fooled his pediatrician, too.

title: The Poetry Crowd Goes Wild
description: COMPARED with music, art exhibitions, novels and movies, even obscure ones, poetry has few followers and fewer practitioners. It is widely regarded as uncomfortably highbrow and not much fun.

title: Juliet Prowse Is Dead at 59; Leggy Star of Musicals, Clubs
description: Juliet Prowse, the tall, leggy dancer with the sultry smile and the bee-sting lips who became a tabloid celebrity when she offended Khrushchev and captivated Frank Sinatra, died yesterday at her home in the Holmby Hills section of Los Angeles. She was 59 and had been a staple of Las Vegas nightclub acts, television specials and touring musicals for more than 30 years.

title: Cadets' Love Triangle
description: Two 18-year-old honors students who had just entered the nation's top military colleges are under arrest in the brutal slaying last December of Adrianne Jones, 16, a high-school sophomore from their home town of Mansfield, Tex.

title: The High Cost Of County's Home Page
description: After reading ''Entering the Age of Cyberspace On Line'' on Aug. 25, I understand more clearly why Westchester County government is so costly and my taxes so much higher than they need be.

title: Cornelia Wise, Robert Conklin Jr.
description: Cornelia Stevens Wise, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Tower Wise 2d of Irvington, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Henry Conklin Jr., a son of Lorraine Conklin Towey, also of Irvington. The Rev. Dr. Charles R. Colwell performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Barnabas in Irvington.

title: The Fatal Attraction of Book Publishing
description: Screen occupations move in and out of vogue with Concorde quickness. For a while there, every Tom (Hanks), Dick and Harry was an architect (''Sleepless in Seattle,'' ''The River Wild,'' ''Jungle Fever''). There was a period when the job du jour was psychiatry (''The Prince of Tides,'' ''The Silence of the Lambs,'' ''Final Analysis''). But the publishing industry has not been slighted. Book editors have been key figures in several movies and television shows over the past few years: Woody Allen in ''Manhattan Murder Mystery,'' Goldie Hawn in ''Deceived,'' Brian Benben in HBO's long-running series ''Dream On,'' Mary McDonnell in the recently departed CBS series ''High Society'' and, most notably, Glenn Close in ''Fatal Attraction,'' Sharon Stone in ''Sliver'' and Jack Nicholson in ''Wolf.'' This fall, Brooke Shields plays a book editor in the NBC series ''Suddenly Susan.''

title: WORK
description: As one who reached maturity in the Great Depression, I remember well the accomplishments of the W.P.A. and feel strongly that something of that nature is what we need today.

title: Drug Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Smoke. Please. Pretty Please.
description: THIS may be an unhappy time to be a regulator, but hardly anyone except the cigarette companies had a critical word to say last month when President Clinton announced new steps by the Food and Drug Administration to limit the marketing of tobacco to minors.

title: Christian Coalition Offers Dole Both Cheers and Sharp Prodding
description: Bob Dole made a brief and unscheduled appearance at a Christian Coalition conference today, bringing cheers from the rank and file of the politically powerful religious conservatives but barbs from some of their most outspoken leaders.

title: The Galapagos, Caravansary of the Sea
description: ''The late Charles Darwin would have quit legislating his gentle jungle had he tried some limited scuba diving.''

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: Jobs Gone, We'll Be a Nation of Cooks
description: To the Editor:

title: Exodus a Threat to Relief for Iraqi Kurds
description: As local employees of United States military and relief agencies prepared today to leave northern Iraq, aid workers who will remain behind warned that the exodus will severely disrupt their efforts here.

title: The New World of (Skilled) Factory Jobs
description: THE myth is that manufacturing in Connecticut is dead. The fact is that while large military contractors and older, heavy industries have lost thousands of jobs, small and medium-sized manufacturing companies are growing. In fact, their growth is being held back by a shortage of skilled workers, according to the Connecticut Skilled Trades Coalition, which represents small and medium-sized manufacturers.

title: Kate Brennan and John A. Crotty
description: Katherine Elizabeth Brennan, the daughter of Alice M. Brennan of Allentown, Pa., and Francis X. Brennan of Hallandale, Fla., was married yesterday in New York to John Austin Crotty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Crotty of New York. The Rev. Gerald McMahon, a Roman Catholic priest who is the bridegroom's great-uncle, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Evangelicals Lobby for Oppressed Christians
description: Frustrated by what they consider inaction in Washington, evangelical Christians are redoubling their efforts to mobilize support for persecuted Christians around the world.

title: Pharaohs' Treasures in Houston
description: More than 200 objects from the Egyptian collection of Pelizaeus Museum in Hildesheim, Germany, will be on view at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston from Sept. 22 to March 30. The show, ''Splendors of Ancient Egypt,'' traces 4,500 years of pharaonic history, from the close of the pre-dynastic period to the first century A.D. This is the first time the Pelizaeus Museum has permitted such an extensive selection of its objects to be shown outside Germany.

title: Hot Pickles and Smart Bombs
description: THE PINBALL EFFECT

title: Boaters Made a Federal Case Out of It, and Marina Is Saved
description: Edwin Radetsky, a retired teacher and current recreational mariner, spent the summer worried that he would be a man without a port.

title: Founder and Mentor, Debating a Definition
description: THOMAS N. MATHERS, founder of the mutual fund that bears his name, is a growth investor with a cast-iron stomach. ''When you think the world is going to open up and swallow your stocks, it's time to buy,'' he said.

title: Mapping the Life of the Upper West Side
description: Between 56th Street and Avenue of the Americas on the south, 121st Street and Lenox Avenue on the north and the Hudson River on the west there are 5,591 residential buildings, 648 institutional buildings, 336 industrial buildings, 189 retail buildings, 37 office buildings, 25 hotels, 366 parking lots and 137 vacant lots. At least according to the makers of the Identity ''living'' map of the Upper West Side.

title: A Pitiable Disservice To Great Pianists
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Under the Black FlagThe Romance and the Reality of Life Among the Pirates.By David Cordingly.Random House, $25.

title: Forget Ecstasy. Get the Prozac!
description: TO my relief, two of Peter Gatien's notorious nightclubs -- the Tunnel and Limelight -- are padlocked again, perhaps for good. These institutions were responsible, at least in part, for many of my friends' current consumption of drugs. Not the cocaine and Ecstasy, a mildly hallucinogenic relative of amphetamines, that the city says were freely sold in the clubs. I mean prescription antidepressants and tranquilizers that were used to soothe many a bruised psyche at the end of a Tunnel evening.

title: IN SOHO, ART AND FASHION ARE ON THE OUTS
description: THE love affair between art and fashion that was born and bred on the cobblestone streets of SoHo seemed like a match made in heaven.

title: A Rival Is Getting New Teeth
description: WHILE the Dodge Viper GTS assumes the mantle of America's fastest production automobile, whither goest the deposed king?

title: U.S. Companies Can Live With Trade Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Parts
description: The WellspringPoems.By Sharon Olds.88 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf.Cloth, $21. Paper, $13.

title: Seeds of Success
description: THE SOUL'S CODE

title: Gone Fishing
description: LIGHT YEARSA Memoir.By Le Anne Schreiber.Illustrated. 152 pp. New York:Lyons & Burford. $20.

title: Not a Political Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he hoped Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential candidate, did not involve himself in the controversy over the idea of using parochial schools to ease overcrowding in public schools.

title: The International Team Is Showing Signs of Life
description: Once they were nearly dead. Now they are nearly dead even. Wielding different putters, new attitudes and their old golf games, the 12 angry men on the International team roared back to life in the Presidents Cup today, coming from 5 points down when the morning began to 1 point away, 10 1/2-9 1/2.

title: Nancy B. Carey, DeWitt Brown 3d
description: Nancy Bunting Carey and Dr. DeWitt Clinton Brown 3d were married yesterday at the Salem United Methodist Church in Selbyville, Del. The Rev. Patricia A. Long, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ecumenical ceremony.

title: Fighting for Nurses, and Quality Care
description: IN the late 1980's and early 90's, nurses could almost write their own tickets. They were in such short supply that hospitals, in desperation, increased their salaries, recruited actively and hired per diem nurses who worked the hours of their choice.

title: Civil Rights Dance Lesson: The Tiny Step Forward
description: TWO bills. Two votes. Two defeats for gay rights advocates. And one edifying lesson on how far they have taken their movement for equality -- and how far they have to go.

title: Street Artists Endure Harassment That's Illegal
description: To the Editor:

title: Foxy Ladies
description: The Gangster of Love

title: Lorraine Saunders, Henry White 3d
description: Lorraine Liddell Saunders, a group manager at ADP Benefit Services, and Henry Martin White 3d, the owner of HM White Site Architects, both in New York, were married yesterday in Weekapaug, R.I. The Rev. Susan A. Moran, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Weekapaug Chapel.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: TASTING FOOD, TASTING FREEDOMExcursions Into Eating, Culture, and the Past.By Sidney W. Mintz.Beacon, $22.

title: Melissa Crowley, Penry Price 2d
description: Melissa Andree Crowley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Crowley of Wayland, Mass., was married yesterday to Penry Williams Price 2d, a son of Marianna Jackson Price of Barrington, R.I., and David A. Price of New York. The Rev. Lawrence J. Drennan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Mary's, Our Lady of the Isle on Nantucket, Mass.

title: After Emigres Began Fuel Scheme, Traditional Mob Families Moved In, Officials Say
description: In an elaborate scheme involving shell companies and tax dodges, prosecutors say a group of Russian emigres made millions of dollars selling bootleg gasoline and diesel fuel in New York and New Jersey. But their success quickly drew the unwanted attention of New York's more established organized crime families, which formed a cartel to take over the lucrative operation.

title: 2 Long Islanders Find an Outlet for Films
description: AT first blush, it may seem that David Nesenoff and Michael Markowitz have nothing in common. Mr. Nesenoff is the rabbi at the Oyster Bay Jewish Center and the chairman of the Town of Oyster Bay anti-bias task force. Michael Markowitz, a 1986 graduate of Half Hollow Hills East High School, now lives in Los Angeles and is a researcher for Disney home videos.

title: Upstairs, Downstairs; Serious Desserts
description: THE attractive, ivy-covered stone house in Greenwich now occupied by the Ivy Restaurant and Bar has seen its share of fine restaurants over the past 20 years. If the Ivy's beginnings are any clue, this operation should last for a good long time. Despite the name, ownership and kitchen changes, the actual space is still much the same. There is a new pastoral mural on the wall leading to the upstairs, more formal, carpeted dining room. In the noisy Rufus Porter Room on the ground level, with its wood floor, handsome close-together cherrywood tables and tiger maple chairs are new additions, as is the wall-long bar in the room across from the entry. Conversation here borders on impossible; upstairs is quieter.

title: Photo-Finish Race In Astoria Leaves Bitterness
description: Two years ago, when Kimon C. Thermos lost the Democratic primary in Assembly District 36 in Astoria and Long Island City, he put in a congratulatory phone call to his opponent, Denis J. Butler, who had won by 2,000 votes. This year, though, Mr. Thermos told his crowd of supporters on election night that he wanted a recount. He had lost to Mr. Butler by only 210 votes -- 3,284 to 3,074, a margin Mr. Thermos described as ''too close to call.''

title: What 'Affordable' Can Mean in Westchester's Housing Market
description: AFFORDABLE adj.: capable of bearing the expense of -- as in buying a house -- means different things in different parts of the country.

title: Homegrown Pleasure
description: COME September, newspapers swell with stories about ''great meals I ate'' in this or that Tuscan farmhouse. Homegrown meals, however, are less expensive and easier to procure in parts of New Jersey.

title: A Country Horse Auction
description: TRAVELERS to northeast Iowa can drop in next month on what is probably the only marketplace in the world where Walt Disney goes head to head with Amish farmers.

title: Growing a Garden, and Good Citizenship
description: WILLIAM BELLE, 13, was checking out the vegetables -- big green ones waiting to be picked and eaten. ''These peppers are looking good,'' he said. ''See that dill over there? I planted that. That's my dill.''

title: WORK
description: William Julius Wilson's article ''Work'' (Aug. 18) reminded me of Belfast and Londonderry, Northern Ireland. When I was there in the 1980's, I saw entire neighborhoods that had no adult male role models who went off to work in the morning. In one house, a grandfather, father and teen-age son lived together, and none had ever held a steady job.

title: In Harrison, a Place for Portuguese Fare
description: COLORFUL Portuguese tiles, a tank of lobsters and, on weekends, a display of fish mark the entrance to this cheerful dining room, which on weekend evenings overflows with diners enthusiastic for the rich flavors of Portuguese (and Brazilian) cuisine. But popularity exacts a price. On those evenings -- particularly when a large group has booked the adjoining party room -- the success of dishes varies. Faced with accommodating the demands of so many customers, both kitchen and service seem to falter. To savor Aquario at its attentive best, go on a quiet night.

title: Three on a Match
description: The latest in synchronized fashion.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WOE IS IThe Grammarphobe's Guide to Better English in Plain English.By Patricia T. O'Conner.Grosset/Putnam, $16.95.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Sal ick Health Care's entry into cancer-treatment services in the New York region misstated the position formerly held by Dr. Ronald Blum, who will head the company's new clinic at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was deputy director of New York University's cancer center, not its head.

title: Oksanna Zanft, Patrick Butler
description: Oksanna Iona Zanft, a daughter of Natalia and Robert Zanft of Clinton, N.J., was married yesterday to Patrick Brendan Butler, a son of Carrie Anderson Butler and John R. Butler 2d of Ridgewood, N.J. Canon Roy D. Green performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I.

title: The Korean Oprah
description: ON the Friday before Labor Day, with moments to go before show time, Miseon Chang of WZRC-Radio Korea New York (1480 AM) flipped through the mainstream tabloids one last time and made a few hasty notes on the letters she would read on her morning Korean-language talk show.

title: Stephanie Payton, Mark A. McMillan
description: Stephanie Michelle Payton, the daughter of Nancy Gray Jefferson of Baldwin, L.I., and David R. Payton of Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Adam McMillan, a son of Alicia D. McMillan of St. Albans, Queens, and the late Samuel H. McMillan. The Rev. Cecily P. Broderick y Guerra officiated at Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing last Sunday about a production of the Noel Coward play ''Present Laughter'' that is to open on Broadway in November misidentified the costume designer. She is Ann Roth, not Jane Greenwood.

title: Corrections
description: A 1927 photograph of the Equitable Building last Sunday, with the Streetscapes column, carried an erroneous credit. It was from the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: BIG PICTURE

title: Staff Turmoil Seems a Staple Of Dole's Management Style
description: Fifteen years ago, when Bob Dole was chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, a newly hired aide showed up at a Capitol Hill meeting and discovered that the topic of conversation was his job. Aides to other senators were taking bets on how long he would last. The high bet was five months, the low was six weeks. The aide actually managed to beat his own odds, hanging on for seven months.

title: A Rich Family Life Amid Extraordinary Circumstances
description: IN a suburban land where swimming pools and three-car houses are as abundant as stop signs, there are still people who become excited over owning a lawn mower.

title: Q and A
description: Climbing the Aconcagua

title: Sabina Gioia, Brooke Furst
description: Sabina Arabella Gioia, a daughter of Iris Gioia of London and Emilio Gioia of Monaco, was married yesterday to Robert Brooke Furst, a son of Judith and Robert Furst of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. Stan Moseley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: So Many Stocks, So Little Time: Software Can Narrow the Field
description: DO you sometimes have nagging doubts about your broker? (''Why did she recommend Acme Buggywhips? Isn't there something more likely to grow?'') Do you wish you knew some intelligent questions to ask when he calls to recommend a stock? (''So XYZ's earnings are growing rapidly?'') If so, a new computer program from Value Line may be right for you.

title: Stalemates Can Help A Place Like Bosnia
description: TO those who watch from a distance, there seem to be some places in the world where conflict is chronic, embedded in the folk music, the mythologies, the tales of martyrdom told to children. War sometimes seems a part of the human condition in these places, alive in memory and always possible at some future random moment. Bosnia can look like that.

title: A Hyperbolic Feat
description: Politicians frequently get carried away when extolling the virtues of wherever they happen to appear (''home of the most beautiful women in the South,'' ''where they make the best barbecue,'' ''where Democrats/Republicans always know they get the best welcome'').

title: It's Bienvenue for a French Newcomer
description: THE opening of a French restaurant on Long Island is news, and when it boasts a chef with a distinguished pedigree lovers of French food have reason to shout ''c'est bon.''

title: In 2002, Where Will All the Garbage Go?
description: The Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island is a ribbon of verdant mounds hugging the West Shore Expressway that is largely veiled in grass but immediately recognizable by its smell. The landfill grows by 13,000 tons every day, but that will end on Dec. 31, 2001, the day Mayor Giuliani has promised to close Fresh Kills, the largest municipal landfill in the world.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Correction
description: Because of a computer entry error, a review on Aug. 18, about a new translation of the Dutch historian Johan Huizinga's ''Autumn of the Middle Ages'' -- a work previously known in translation as ''The Waning of the Middle Ages'' -- omitted 10 words in the final paragraph, reversing the intent of the reviewer, Rosamond McKitterick. The next-to-last sentence of the review should have read, ''Ultimately, however, I read it more as a fascinating piece of cultural history of the earlier 20th century than as a convincing interpretation of the 14th and 15th centuries.''

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: International Show Celebrates Diversity
description: THE Center for Curatorial Studies lies on a grassy incline overlooking the campus of Bard College here. This pink brick building, completed in 1992, has but one story but is long enough to accommodate the center's assets, which include a substantial library, a permanent collection of about 700 works and last but not least a museum. Now on view in this august space are exhibitions that reinforce Bard's reputation as an enclave with a direct line to the international scene as well as a commitment to what passes for the avant-garde on the home front.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on Aug. 4, about a mansion in Far Rockaway, Queens, now demolished, misstated the date of death of one of its owners, Louis A. Heinsheimer. A reader's letter, received last week, pointed out that it was 1910, not 1909.

title: Last Stand
description: THE HEIRESS (1949) is a haunting, bittersweet tale of a lonely, plain young woman; her hostile father, and a deft fortune hunter in old New York. William Wyler's artful film version cracles with life and fire. The screen play, based on the Henry James novel ''Washington Square,'' was written by Ruth and Augustus Goetz from their Broadway drama - FRI at 8 P.M. and FRI.-SAT. at 2 A.M. on AMC. Olivia De Havilland is soft and pliant as Catherine, Ralph Richardson gives a rich and sleek performance as her masterful father and Montgomery Clift brings vitality and romantic charm to the young man. A fine character study and grade A Hollywood - so is the Copland music.

title: Adapting to Downsizing
description: IT was a 10th anniversary get-together for the group, held on a perfect morning in an opulent room in the Gothic-style castle at Manhattanville College. But it was no frivolous party.

title: In 4 Reports Over 10 Years, Issues of Security at J.F.K.
description: For nearly a decade, officials at Kennedy International Airport have been repeatedly told of security problems that made aircraft vulnerable to terrorist attack.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: SHADOW OF ASHLAND

title: Getting a Kick From Champagne
description: QUICK, setting out from Paris, where can one combine great art, stirring history, magnificent scenery, superb food and wine, and still be back in town in time for dinner?

title: Trip Insurance, Minus Strings
description: A STARTLING change in trip cancellation insurance occurred last summer. Most insurers dropped their ban on paying benefits when a policyholder's trip was called off because of a ''pre-existing condition,'' an illness that began before the policy was bought. To get a policy that waived the ban, the companies required clients to buy policies swiftly -- within a day or two -- after making the first deposit on a trip.

title: The Oregon Trail, by Rail
description: IF you're looking for train memorabilia, however arcane, you can find it at Grandpa's Depot Store, on the second floor of the Oxford Hotel annex in Denver, across Wynkoop Street from Union Station. There, amid antique railroad lanterns, Union Pacific martini sets and matchbooks from the old Rio Grande line, you can also find Grandpa John White, who's spent a lifetime watching trains come and go. When I met him on a hot afternoon in late July and told him of my plan to ride Amtrak's Pioneer train all the way from Denver to Portland, Ore., he said, in perfect deadpan, ''The Government runs it, you know. They don't have a timetable anymore. They just post the day the train's expected.''

title: Q. & A.
description: Enforcing A Contract Of Sale

title: Beverly J. Hoch, Michael Steinel
description: Beverly Jean Hoch, a soprano, and Michael Lynn Steinel, a jazz musician and writer, were married yesterday in Weehawken, N.J., at the home of Ardith Grandbouche, a friend of the couple. The Rev. Dr. R. Maurice Boyd, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Kent Miller, a Presbyterian minister, took part.

title: Jennifer Blank, James J. Coster
description: Jennifer Blank, a daughter of Mary Ann Murphy of Newport Beach, Calif., and William Blank of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Justin Coster, a son of Rosemary Coster of Flushing, Queens, and the late John I. Coster. The Rev. Vincent Biagi performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: DIARY
description: WELFARE PROTEST

title: Masterpiece Theater
description: PAUL CEZANNEPortrait of My World.CD-ROM (Windows and Macintosh). Bellevue, Wash.:Corbis. $45.

title: E Pluribus Unum? (Or Something)
description: LA DOLCE VITA in Suffolk County is about to come to an end

title: They're Not James Bond, But Couriers See the World
description: Q. Can one still take trips as an airborne courier?

title: First Families
description: THE NATIVE AMERICANS CD-ROM (Macintosh and Windows).Produced by Image Smith.Atlanta: Turner Publishing. $39.99.

title: With a Late Flurry, U.S. Beats Canada at Its Own Game
description: The United States won the World Cup of Hockey tonight by stunning Canada with four goals in the final four minutes to take a 5-2 victory in a bitter battle that will be discussed and debated for many years.

title: HONEY, WHAT'S YOUR NAME AGAIN?
description: Pogrebin's essay reminded me that when my memory was only 30 years old, it contained half as many people, places and experiences as it does today. I would not trade one of my memories for a younger person's instant recall. An occasional frustration with ''social amnesia'' goes with a broad and bountiful territory.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 1 about the saxophonist Steve Wilson misidentified the composer of the jazz standard ''Moanin'.'' He was Bobby Timmons, not Art Blakey. The article also misspelled the nickname by which Blakey was known. It was Bu, not Boo.

title: In Pataki Bond Act, Cleaning Money for All
description: For Gov. George E. Pataki, much is riding on his $1.75 billion environmental bond act, which New Yorkers will vote on this Nov. 5. Its passage would be a major success of his first term and would strengthen his image as a friend of the environment. And the measure is clearly laden with environmental programs intended to appeal to every region.

title: Mexican and Southwest Fare at a Hideaway
description: SOME restaurants almost seem invisible. No one notices their openings, including reviewers. That happened to the difficult-to-find now-four-year-old Blue Parrot Bar and Grill in East Hampton. Its address is 33A Main Street (324-3609). But it is on an alley across the way from a movie theater.

title: Blameless Above All
description: It wasn't my fault! That was my comfort, and I repeated the thought, maybe annoyingly, several times a day. Usually I choose the holiday and get the blame, but that year my wife, Louise, had read about this hotel down in the heel of Italy, aiming in future at the world's playboys and playgirls, but in that first year content with a more modestly heeled clientele. We were willing guinea pigs.

title: Responding to Dole, Clinton Releases More Health Data
description: By releasing a packet of brief statements from President Clinton's doctors on Friday night, the White House offered a picture of a 50-year-old man in vigorous health and sought to counter accusations by his opponent, Bob Dole, that Mr. Clinton had only partially disclosed information about his medical records.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Ornaments for a Beach . . .

title: Fearful Symmetry
description: ESCHER INTERACTIVEExploring the Art of the Infinite.CD-ROM (Windows).New York: Harry N. Abrams/Byron Preiss Multimedia. $55.

title: Clinton or Dole? You Might Check Your Portfolio
description: IF history is any guide, small stocks have a better chance of shining if Bill Clinton wins a second term than if Bob Dole unseats him, according to a study by the Liberty Financial Companies, a financial services concern in Boston.

title: If You've Paid Already -- Thanks! We'll Never Let You Go!
description: IF you read magazines or even junk mail, it's hard to miss the enticements of Columbia House, the nation's largest marketer of music and videos by mail. Millions of Americans have responded to these ads, sending away for initial shipments of dirt-cheap compact discs, cassettes or videos in return for an agreement to buy more at full price over the next few years.

title: Life in the Toxic Zone
description: Metaphors of death are plentiful in Chester, Pa., a declining factory town on the Delaware River just south of Philadelphia. Once a muscular city of 66,000, Chester lost a third of its population -- and more than 40,000 jobs -- between the end of World War II and the coming of Ronald Reagan. Elected Mayor, the town's leading mortician suggested turning out street lights -- actually letting the city go dark -- to save money. Many streets are desolate. Young prostitutes prowl the doorways of burned-out buildings. In addition to these misfortunes, Chester has become the waste-processing capital of Pennsylvania -- and a national battleground on the issue of environmental justice.

title: Esthetic Alchemy and Surprising Photos
description: ''Winners '96''

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: The Sophisticated Traveler

title: Future Vision: Planners Head in Different Directions
description: It has been discussed for a decade, undergone several incarnations and been led by three different people. Now, leaders of a committee creating a plan for future development along the waterfront in Williamsburg and Greenpoint say they will release a draft plan later this month. ''It will be a blueprint for redevelopment of the Greenpoint-Williamsburg waterfront,'' said Ronald Webster, who heads the 197-A Waterfront Committee. ''When developers come out, they can say this is what the neighborhood wants.''

title: No Headline
description: ''What four years of war created cannot be eliminated in a few months or by elections. You need generations now for the fear to disappear from the souls of the people.''

title: Karl Kortum, 79, Who Founded San Francisco Maritime Museum
description: Karl Crouch Kortum, the founder of what is now the San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park, died on Thursday in San Francisco at the age of 79. The cause was congestive heart failure.

title: 'The Horror!'
description: To the Editor:

title: Kitchens of Doom
description: THE MUPPET CD-ROM

title: Another Serpent With Power to Tempt
description: DURING the week a Viper GTS coupe sat in the company parking lot, my office E-mail chimed steadily. It had become quite the merry contest: who could think up the best vanity license plate for the man so -- fill in the blank here: neglected, needy, neurotic -- as to display himself in Dodge's wanton blue totem of machismo.

title: At Dia, Fresh Wounds and a Fresh Start
description: FOR YEARS, THE DIA CENTER for the Arts in Manhattan had been a quiet and inspired presence, its style reflected in the stripped-down elegance of its main exhibition building on West 22d Street, which has become the anchor of the growing art community in Chelsea. At Dia, the focus has always been on art, not on how that art is packaged or contextualized. The histories of Minimalism, Conceptualism and Earth Art wouldn't be the same without Dia's longtime and unequaled involvement. There is nothing else quite like it.

title: Don't Fence Him In
description: King Victor's MAN WITHOUT A STAR (1955) is vigorous and solid entertainment set in the post-Civil War era. Its sensible, humorous scenario centers on an unreconstructed cow poke (Kirk Douglas) who takes a youngster (William Campbell) under his wing and teaches him all about guns, whisky and women. He's willing to become the strong-arm man for a beautiful cattle owner in distress. The story is full of colorful regional chracters, many of them surprising. Richard Boone, Claire Trevor and Jeanne Crain round out the cast in this surprising western with punch and color - SAT. at 5 P.M. and SAT.-SUN. at 1:30 A.M. on AMC.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: MAVISBy Brenda K. Marshall.Fawcett Columbine, $20.

title: Aileen Hefferren, Charles Harkless
description: Aileen Carol Hefferren, a fund-raising director, and Charles Waller Harkless, a management consultant, both in New York, were married yesterday at Troutbeck, an inn in Amenia, N.Y. The Rev. Elice Higginbotham, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: A Change of Cloths
description: I was so intent on getting to China to adopt a tiny baby girl from a Shanghai orphanage that I did not give enough thought to what I would wear while I was there. ''Shanghai is colder than New York,'' a friend advised. ''This is December, wear your warmest clothes.'' I read a guidebook that cautioned Shanghai would be frigid and the streets would be rough -- I should take hardy hiking boots.

title: Crossing the Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: A Less Than Rural Retreat
description: Some people may not like sharing a cottage with pigs. I absolutely do. I bribed a friend. He found me an ancient farm cottage to rent in Wales. This cottage had five rooms for humans and one room (inaccessible from inside) expressly for piglets. My friend knew I'd have a heavenly time and I did.

title: Be Assured, 'the Great Gambon' Is a Star
description: WHEN ACTORS' EQUITY was asked to give permission for the British actor Michael Gambon to appear in New York in David Hare's ''Skylight,'' the union at first demurred. Was he a big enough name to bypass the usual restrictions on foreign performers? Was he genuinely a star? According to accounts circulating in England, Equity's initial riposte was ''Who is Michael Gambon?''

title: Anselm L. Strauss Dies at 79; Leader in Medical Sociology
description: Anselm L. Strauss, an internationally known sociologist who developed an influential and pragmatic approach to social science studies and used it to examine such subjects as how hospitals deal with dying patients, died on Sept. 5 in San Francisco. He was 79 and lived there.

title: Red Hook's Blueprint Ricochets Between Local Factions and City
description: Initially praised for its farsightedness and self-reliance, the plan for Red Hook's regeneration has undergone major alterations by the City Planning Commission, which has appeared to favor business interests at the expense of residents.

title: Sneakers on the Wires Showed Up Back in 1908
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 More Months to Answer A 20-Year-Old Riddle
description: The State Supreme Court cut the Legislature some slack last week when the justices granted lawmakers a three-month extension to come up with a new school-financing plan.

title: THE 00'S
description: Let's hope that we at least avoid the trap Fibber McGee fell into with the lingering aught: ''Molly's a good kid. I remember once back in nineteen-aught-thirty-four. . . .''

title: Not Yet Brown
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: L.I. VInes
description: MerlotCorey Creek Vineyards, Southold, 1994. About $17.

title: 'Picasso' Brings an Unknown British Beauty Into the Foreground
description: THE LAST TIME Natascha McElhone entered the Cafe de Flore, the clock had been pushed back to 1953 and she was playing Francoise Gilot. With the camera turning, she walked into the legendary Left Bank cafe in search of Pablo Picasso (Anthony Hopkins). Instead she bumped into Dora Maar (Julianne Moore), the woman she had replaced as his mistress. Beware, Maar warned theatrically, Picasso is an evil man.

title: Wisconsin Trip
description: BILLY SUNDAY

title: New Plaque at Statue Endorses No Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Under His Wing
description: HERE in the middle of Morris County, where affluent estates give way to dusty gravel roads and untamed fields, sits a tiny hospital. Like any hospital, it has an operating room, an X-ray machine and signs warning that patients may not eat before undergoing anesthesia.

title: Growing Up in Newark To Be Auxiliary Bishop
description: Nicholas DiMarzio Jr. grew up in the shadow of Newark's Sacred Heart Cathedral, now a basilica.

title: Tara DeLucia, Christopher Johnson
description: Tara Maria DeLucia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vic DeLucia of Glen Cove, L.I., was married there yesterday to Christopher Michael Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael W. Johnson of Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Robert Coyle officiated at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Shostakovich Sketch, Based on Dots
description: THE TORMENTED AND compelling physiognomy of Shostakovich's symphonic works might be roughly traced by connecting the dots of major essays from his precocious maturity to his middle years -- from the youthful bravura of the First Symphony to the humanistic questioning of the Fourth and the world-weary testimony of the Eighth.

title: Forest on the Verge
description: The great redwood forests that once covered two million acres in Northern California are nearly gone. Most of what remains is protected in Redwood National Park and a few isolated state parks.

title: Brussels
description: From Gothic to post-modern, Brussels is a glorious jumble of architectural styles. It started in 1695, when Louis XIV of France bombarded the city center with red-hot cannonballs. The resulting fires destroyed more than 5,000 wooden buildings, including the entire Grand'Place. An exception was the Town Hall, then 200 years old and built of sterner stuff (it's still standing). The Sun King's expansionist plans failed, but the destruction prepared the way for the Grand'Place of today, with Baroque guild-hall gables, gilt ornaments and cozy cafes.

title: Giant Companies Entering Race To Run State Welfare Programs
description: The new welfare law is still a matter of confusion in statehouses and city streets. But to some companies, it already looks like the business opportunity of a lifetime.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: There But For FortuneThe Life of Phil Ochs.By Michael Schumacher.Hyperion, $24.95.

title: What Welfare Research?
description: IN trying to remake the nation's welfare system, members of Congress and President Clinton rarely cite any data or research to support their arguments. And for good reason.

title: Jazz Is Back in Montclair; Now It Comes to Madison
description: To the Editor:

title: Choate on the Cheap: Prep Schools Woo the Middle Class
description: GWEN HALEY teaches at a public high school in Stratford, Conn. Her husband, Ted, is a drug rehabilitation counselor. Together they make a decent income, but not enough to simply say yes when their younger son, Ben, announced he wanted to go to Choate Rosemary Hall, a boarding school with a blue-chip reputation and a price tag of more than $22,000 a year.

title: When Paterson and America Were Robust and Confident
description: To the Editor:

title: And in This Corner
description: A recent survey by the Society for Human Resource Management showed that workplace violence is growing -- with threats, pushing, shoving and fistfights as the most common incidents. Usually it's employee fighting employee, but sometimes the boss is involved, too, the survey said. If a fight has occurred in your office, we want to hear from you. Send your best story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Still Driving To the Basket, But on Skates
description: Sometimes the regular basketball players at Tompkins Square Park would yell at Tom LaGarde when he skated onto the court. Other times they would laugh.

title: Private Donation to Spur Answers in U.S. Drug War
description: George Soros, the currency-market mogul who has donated hundreds of millions of dollars to the former Soviet bloc, is contributing a tiny portion of his fortune closer to home in an effort to broaden the American debate on what to do about drugs. Mr. Soros's foundations have given about $15 million since 1994 to groups studying the issue. This election season he has also offered two personal donations in support of ballot initiatives in California and Arizona that would legalize the medical use of marijuana. But the gifts may not thrill the Clinton Administration, whose drug policy director, Barry McCaffrey, denounced the California initiative last week as ''dangerous and wrong.'' CAREY GOLDBERG

title: Crucial Midwest States Lean Toward Clinton
description: The more Presidential politics changes, the more it stays the same.

title: Kari Torjussen, Martin Waters 3d
description: Kari Winfield Torjussen, a daughter of Harriet and Karl Torjussen of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to Martin Joseph Waters 3d, a son of Helen and Martin Waters Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel R. Sweeney performed the ceremony at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: Jersey City's Waterfront Showing Signs of an Upturn
description: A ROLLER-COASTER office market took the commercial revitalization of the Hudson River waterfront here from the heights of the mid-80's to the depths of the early 90's, when construction ground to a halt. But in the years since, the riverfront has slowly rebounded, rekindling interest in building at the water's edge.

title: The Cape, A Region Renewed
description: WINE-MAKING in South Africa, which has been a tradition for nearly 350 years, is enjoying a new beginning. The political changes that have put the country's wines back on the world's tables are now making the Cape wine region a magnet for tourists from abroad.

title: Gun Play
description: Among the assorted communications that follow my son, Wesley, home from school every day was the following advisory: ''Bringing a weapon to school, using a weapon on school grounds or at a school activity, or having a weapon in your locker, pocket or while you are at school, on the bus or at an after-school activity, is a grave offense and is against school rules and regulations. It is also against the law.'' Among the prohibited items: firearms, switchblades, stilettos or metallic knuckles, nunchaku, shuriken, blackjacks, blowguns, razors, box cutters and ''chains, whips or any other metal object of no academic purpose.''

title: Forgotten Cub
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jessica Hoffman, D.P. Brennan Jr.
description: Jessica Danielle Hoffman, a daughter of Barbara and Daniel Hoffman of Dongan Hills, S.I., was married last evening to Donald Patrick Brennan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brennan of Old Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Edward R. P. Kane performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: A Painting Crew With a Different Angle
description: The tarpaulins were down, dusted with chips of old paint, and Alberto Ojeda was atop a ladder putting a coat of primer on the walls of a bathroom at St. James Catholic School on St. James Place, where Gov. Alfred E. Smith received his only formal education. Jerome Lee, who was overseeing the project, cast a seasoned eye on the paint job from his wheelchair.

title: WORK
description: Wilson informs us that work ''constitutes a framework for daily behavior because it imposes discipline.'' But is someone really employable before he learns discipline, and when is that instilled? I suspect very early in life. We do have data indicating that inner-city black youths who grow up attending church or mosque and/or live in two-parent families do much better statistically in school, are much less likely to commit crimes or use drugs and usually end up gainfully employed. Where do they find jobs? They commute on public transportation to jobs in other sections of the city. How many Americans, even urban dwellers, white or black, have the luxury of walking to work?

title: Environment Bond Issue Is More Than Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Master Who Could Create Poems for the Eye
description: HIS APPROACH WAS CALLED ''tragic realism'' by the film critic Parker Tyler; he called himself ''a director of atmosphere.'' He demanded of his screenwriter a script so real it would capture the body odor of his characters, while providing some of the most poetic visuals in movie history.

title: Festivity in Montreal
description: The moment Phillis and I crossed the Vermont-Canada border into Quebec one sunny morning last fall, we knew that we had not just entered a different country, but an altogether different land. As we drove out of the Green Mountains, the silver church spires of half a dozen Quebecois villages were visible in the broad, flat St. Lawrence River valley. Neat farmhouses painted in pastel pinks, lavenders and yellows, with sharp sloping roofs to shed the snow, crowded right down to the highway on both sides. And the signs, of course, were all in French.

title: Friday The 13th: The Bull's Birthday
description: The movies have it all wrong. There is nothing nicer than Friday the 13th.

title: Jewish Heritage Trips To Philadelphia
description: Seven hotels in Philadelphia are participating in a package designed for visitors interested in Jewish heritage. Available until the end of the year, it includes tickets to museums with relevant exhibitions.

title: Mail-Order Clothing Gets a Whole New Meaning
description: Clothing comes in all sorts of incongruous flavors these days, from Coca-Cola to Marlboro. Now, at that vast Mall of America in Minnesota, incongruity reaches new heights as the Postal Service test-markets clothing with a postal theme. If you try some on, though, make sure no one mails you anywhere.

title: Alternatives to Alternative: What's Next?
description: THE USHER AT ALICE TULLY Hall, gray-haired and motherly, was directing new arrivals. ''Hip-hop to the left,'' she said. ''Heavy metal to the right.'' It was the 16th annual CMJ Music Marathon, which took over Lincoln Center and two dozen clubs earlier this month. The marathon has outlasted its rival, the New Music Seminar, to become the annual New York City convention and showcase for every music-business entity connected to alternative rock, no matter how tenuously.

title: China's Endless Task to Stem Centuries of Floods
description: When the summer of 1996 began, the endless landscape of the Yangtze River valley here was a symphony of labor, where legions of Chinese, buried to the waist in the rich greenery of China's grain belt, were bringing in the summer harvest.

title: No, Not That Pageant
description: LAST year, Miss Perfectly Disgusting, a 280-pound comic drag performer who calls himself Chunky Marinara, didn't win the Miss'd America Pageant.

title: Puppet Caveat: Grown-Ups Only Please
description: AFTER sundown, when the audience for the International Festival of Puppet Theater is tucked in bed, the upstairs space at P.S. 122 opens as the Late Night Puppet Lounge and performers emerge to entertain an audience with pieces that might not play during the light of day. ''There's the possibility of

title: Once an Outsider, a Poet Unravels His Life
description: WE sat among imported evergreens. They were all very stately and gigantic, on an elegant lawn in Old Field.

title: The New Kid on the Opera World's Toughest Block
description: LAST WEDNESDAY, PAUL KELLOGG began his first season as general and artistic director of the New York City Opera much as others have before him: aware of the challenges this scrappy company faces, full of optimism and, above all, determined to make the City Opera an exciting alternative to its Lincoln Center neighbor, the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Top Cops
description: Terry Eastland is the editor of Forbes MediaCritic and a fellow at the Ethics and Public Policy Center in Washington. His latest book is ''Ending Affirmative Action.''

title: How the Gold Group Is Keeping Its Luster
description: GOLD mutual funds seem to have a magical touch in 1996. For the year so far, they hold the lead among all equity funds that have at least $30 million in assets, and the precious-metals group has gained 17.4 percent, on average, nearly twice the 9 percent for the equity funds through Thursday, according to Morningstar Inc. in Chicago.

title: Rebecca Nelson, George Nikias
description: Rebecca Ann Nelson, a daughter of Ilene Nelson of Royal Oak, Mich., and Dr. Randolph Nelson of New Milford, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. George Andrew Nikias, the son of Drs. Mata and Chris Nikias of Fort Lee, N.J. The Rev. Angelo Artemas officiated at the Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church in New York.

title: Debating The Merits Of Wetlands And Stores
description: The proposed Meadowlands Mills mall in Carlstadt promises to be BIG. It would cover 2.4 million square feet, making it the largest shopping center in New Jersey. There would be 2.2 million square feet of office space, 50,000 square feet of restaurants, 1,000 hotel rooms, 150,000 square feet of light industrial space. Not to mention 9,000 new jobs, 17,000 parking spaces and a new exit ramp off the New Jersey Turnpike just so people can get to the mall site, which, at 594 acres, would be almost three quarters of the size of Central Park.

title: Though Reared in Kansas, Dole Finds His 'Home' Almost Anyplace He Happens to Go
description: One thing about having as many home states as Bob Dole claims is that as he campaigns across the country, he can always feel at home. Last week, as the Republican Presidential nominee scoured the South and the Midwest for votes, he pronounced himself home in six important battleground states.

title: In Los Angeles, War of Weeklies Erupts
description: This city's two largest alternative weeklies broke most newspaper rules last week by intentionally publishing the same article.

title: Fred Speaker, 66, a Crusader Against Capital Punishment
description: Fred Speaker, a former Pennsylvania Attorney General who had such a visceral reaction the first time he saw the state's electric chair that he ordered it dismantled and declared the death penalty unconstitutional, died last Tuesday at a hospital in Harrisburg, Pa. He was 66 and lived in nearby Camp Hill.

title: Mayor Seizes Car Insurance As Hot Issue
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken a sudden interest in recent weeks in the policies of automobile insurance companies, a subject not normally within the purview of the city's chief executive. But the Mayor's focus on the companies may have less to do with his interest in the intricacies of their practices and more to do with his effort to keep the spotlight on what he considers perhaps the finest accomplishment of his tenure: lower crime rates.

title: Club Land Vignettes With Lights And Techno
description: Eric Dunlap is a modern-dance choreographer intent on reaching new dancegoers, in this case young audiences who frequent bars, clubs and rock concerts. He and his group Forward, formed with Pony Wilde, a designer, were the opening act for Cyndi Lauper at the Academy last year. And the program presented by Forward on Friday night at the Ohio Theater had very little to do with the kinds of dance being seen these days downtown, though it owed something to the light-and-dance work of Alwin Nikolais.

title: No Headline
description: ''We believe that the goal of Saddam Hussein is to dominate this region and that he has only been prevented from this goal by this containment policy.'' SECRETARY OF DEFENSE WILLIAM J. PERRY $(A6:1$)

title: Roche and Bayer Are Said to Form Joint Venture
description: Bayer A.G. and Roche Holding Ltd. are forming a joint venture in the United States to sell Roche's Aleve analgesic and several other nonprescription drugs, people with knowledge of the deal said last night.

title: Jets Show They Can Lose a Lead, Too
description: It was definitely uncharted territory for the Jets. Here they were with a 14-0 lead, accomplished in part by a 100-yard interception return by cornerback Aaron Glenn midway through the second quarter against a Jimmy Johnson-coached Dolphins team that has been running on high octane since opening day.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER

title: Perot's New Campaign Propels Unanswered Questions Back to Surface
description: Four years after Ross Perot took his first run at the Presidency, a remarkable odyssey that saw him capture nearly one in every five votes cast in the 1992 election, the Texas billionaire is once again a candidate for the White House, atop the ticket of a party he founded and bankrolled.

title: Citibank Expands Links With Lowe
description: The Citibank unit of Citicorp has further expanded its relationship with the Lowe Group by naming that agency as the first to handle the creative advertising assigment for its Citibank credit cards throughout Europe. Though billings were not disclosed, Campaign, the British advertising trade publication, estimated them at $30 million.

title: An Asian Mini-Tempest Over Mini-Island Group
description: In the ocean south of Japan a group of tiny islands peep above the waves, desolate and windswept, home only to sea birds. But the islets are the center of a growing East Asian rivalry.

title: Seoul Arrives At a Difficult Crossroads
description: SEOUL  (Stella Kim, a freelance journalist based in Seoul, contributed to this and several other articlesin this report.)

title: Writing Off the Public Schools
description: The New York City Board of Education is right to resist the proposal, put forth by John Cardinal O'Connor and endorsed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, to send 1,000 failing public school students to parochial schools and to pay for their education with private funds.

title: Maple Leaf Wilts Under Stars & Stripes
description: The headlines in today's local newspaper said ''Woe Canada'' and ''Damn Yankees.'' Wayne Gretzky said his home and native land is ''probably a crushed country.''

title: Behind the Fading of a Onetime Software Star
description: Sally Narodick set impressive goals for herself seven years ago when she left a successful career at Seafirst Bank of Seattle to run a sleepy little educational software company across Lake Washington in suburban Redmond.

title: Park Service Removes Peace Plaque
description: A plaque that was placed in the entryway of the Statue of Liberty by a spiritual group led by Sri Chinmoy has been removed after a review by the National Park Service.

title: A Mini-Retrospective Birthday Party
description: Since the mid-1960's, Larry Austin's work has been the gently accessible face of the electronic music avant-garde. His pieces combine instrumental and electronic sounds, and if his choices of timbre have sometimes been outlandish, he has always maintained a sense of musical syntax and drama that makes his work easily comprehensible. And his inventiveness and catholicity of taste have kept the pieces lively and entertaining, if not always profoundly moving.

title: Gaillard F. Ravenel, 55, Curator Of Design at National Gallery
description: Gaillard F. Ravenel, senior curator of design at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, died on Friday in Georgetown University Hospital. He was 55 and lived in Washington.

title: Preserving Prime Farmland
description: New Jersey's Farmland Preservation program will mark its most valuable acquisition to date at a ceremony tomorrow: nearly a thousand acres of some of the most prime real estate in the state, straddling the border of Hunterdon and Somerset counties. State, county and local governments have teamed up to pay $6 million for the development rights to the Sam Kanach farm, still owned and farmed by the late Mr. Kanach's family. ''In that part of the state, it's a neck-and-neck competition between us and the developers,'' said Donald Applegate, executive director of the program.

title: Executive Steps Up Tobacco Ad Attack
description: David Milenthal, chairman and chief executive at HMS Partners in Columbus, Ohio, is stepping up his battle against tobacco advertising by asking the American Association of Advertising Agencies to form a task force to help curb the sale of tobacco products to minors.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Votes to Go on Strike
description: The musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night voted unanimously to reject the terms of a labor agreement proposed on Friday by management and to strike for the first time since 1966.

title: Rereading the Classics, and Loving It
description: GREAT BOOKS

title: A Pageant of Their Own
description: Not to be upstaged by the festivities in Atlantic City, residents of the Seacrest Village nursing home had their own beauty pageant over the weekend. Marge Devany, 86, edged out a 70-year-old former model, Jackie Macris, to win Seacrest's 2d annual Ms. Senior America pageant on Friday. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday misspelled the surname of the Italian politician who is leading a secessionist movement in northern Italy. His name is Umberto Bossi, not Rossi.

title: Dad's So Grumpy Now: The Cosby Persona Goes Into a New Phase of Life
description: Listen, if the grumpy-old-man concept works so well for Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau, why not for Bill Cosby? CBS, at least, is banking on a positive answer as the network brings back one of the country's cleverest entertainers in ''Cosby,'' an American riff on a British sitcom called ''One Foot in the Grave.''

title: Bosnia Votes
description: Measured against the destructive military conflict still raging less than a year ago, Saturday's national elections in Bosnia marked a clear advance. But measured against the promises of reconciliation and democracy contained in the Dayton peace agreement, the elections were disappointingly deficient. If peace is to be sustained, and the current trend toward authoritarianism and ethnic partition checked, the countries sponsoring Dayton, led by the United States, will have to energize their diplomacy in the weeks and months ahead.

title: West Coast Naval Base Belatedly Stirs Passions
description: This past Wednesday, Patricia Fink went through a routine she had followed for four years, locking the door of her office on the elegant, campuslike naval base here, initialing a form against the back of a sailor who had been waiting in the breezeway, then walking toward her car for the ride home.

title: Party Leader Tests Gears in Brooklyn Machine
description: Days after last week's New York Democratic primary, Clarence Norman Jr. could barely hide his exhilaration. Sipping a soda and smiling broadly while discussing a race for a little-known judicial position, he made it clear that he had been buoyed by the results of his handiwork in a campaign that he hoped would define his stewardship as the leader of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn.

title: Clinton Leads Dole 2 to 1
description: President Clinton appears to be pulling away from Bob Dole in New Jersey and now leads him in the state by nearly two to one, according to a Star-Ledger/Eagleton poll released yesterday. The poll of 627 registered voters, conducted last week, gave Mr. Clinton a 57 percent to 29 percent lead. Even 14 percent of Republicans expressed a preference for Mr. Clinton. A mid-June poll found Mr. Clinton ahead by 53 percent to 34 percent. Ross Perot won 6 percent, and 8 percent were undecided in last week's poll, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.

title: Assembly Takes Up Helmets
description: On its first day back from summer break, the Assembly will consider measures today that would require thousands of young bikers and skaters to wear helmets. One bill before the Law and Public Safety Committee would require children under 14 to wear helmets for in-line skating and skateboarding; another would raise the age under which bicyclists must wear helmets to 18 from 14. The bill for skaters has already passed the Senate.

title: INSIDE
description: Questions on Perot Linger

title: New York Has (a) Too Many Pupils (b) Empty Seats (c) Both
description: It's a matter of simple arithmetic, isn't it?

title: 'Boarder Babies' Languish
description: It has been 10 years since the crack epidemic first flooded nurseries in hospitals around the country with ''boarder babies'' -- infants who lingered in hospitals, unable to go home with their mothers because they had been exposed to drugs or the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Surprise Victory in Futurity for Vanderbilt
description: The fortunes of horse racing shifted on both sides of the border yesterday when Smoke Glacken, the favorite for the Kentucky Derby, ran fifth in the Futurity at Belmont Park, while a 15-1 long shot named Traitor was winning for 84-year-old Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt. In Toronto, the Woodbine Million and, in all likelihood, the 3-year-old championship were won by Skip Away, while Louis Quatorze ran dead last.

title: A Religious Tilt Toward the Left
description: As members of the Christian Coalition strolled outside their convention hotel here this weekend, loud and challenging hymns drifted across their path from a small brick church where other Christians -- politically different Christians -- sang of ''righteousness like a flowing stream.''

title: The Internet as an Influence on Urbanization
description: For years, experts have warned that computer technology could bring the demise of old bricks-and-mortar cities. In ''The Third Wave'' in 1980, the futurist Alvin Toffler sketched out a vision of legions of workers liberated from the traffic and hassle of urban areas by computers and telecommunications. Instead, he predicted, they would work from homes soon to be transformed into far-flung ''electronic cottages.''

title: Seeing Ad Dollars, C-Net Multiplies Web Sites
description: The Internet address is taut and memorable: www.news.com.

title: Make Room in the Kitchen For Yet Another Appliance
description: At last, Velveeta has arrived on the World Wide Web.

title: On-Line Guide to TV Viewing Offered by Upstart Company
description: Maybe the expected convergence of television and the Internet is years away. But there is now another sign that it is likely to occur -- namely, the creation of a personalized on-line television viewing guide.

title: Title Character in 'Ellen' May Come Out as Gay
description: Producers of the ABC sitcom ''Ellen'' are discussing plans to have the main character disclose that she is a lesbian during the 1996-97 television season, several reports and a person familiar with the production say. No one involved with the show would comment on the reports, which appeared on Friday.

title: The Browser Duel
description: An old-fashioned marketing war has broken out in the new and rapidly expanding world of Internet software. Individual computer users could be big winners.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Auto Talks Continue After Contract Expires

title: Flags Flying, North Italian Secession Rally Falls Short
description: Unfurling the banners of the still-mythical state of Padania, Italy's small but flamboyant secessionist movement steamed into this northern lagoon city this evening, stepping up its improbable challenge to Italian unity with a mix of medieval pageantry and political bombast.

title: Bridge
description: The Marlboro International Tournament in Beijing last week proved to be a triumph for the host country and for four American women experts.

title: Iraq Has Not Fully Met Demands, U.S. Says
description: Clinton Administration officials said today that Iraq had still not met all the terms of an American ultimatum delivered to Baghdad this month and that as a result there was still the possibility of a devastating American military strike on Iraq.

title: Immigration Bill Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada's Upscale Influx
description: On Nov. 1, 1995, Sergio Marchi, then Canada's Minister of Immigration, rose in Parliament and denounced the Statue of Liberty. Yes -- the one in New York's harbor, with the torch. Mr. Marchi, a Liberal Party member and an immigrant himself, took particular exception to the plaque affixed to Lady Liberty that welcomes the world's wretched refuse. He stressed indignantly that neither he nor other immigrants to Canada bore any likeness to refuse -- wretched or otherwise.

title: Drug Official Shot to Death In Mexico City
description: The top federal police officer in charge of fighting drug traffickers in the border state of Baja California was gunned down over the weekend in downtown Mexico City.

title: Transsexuals and Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Shots Silence Angry Voice Sharpened by the Streets
description: The news drifted into the Marin Public Housing complex with a chill, like the late afternoon breezes that play over this hillside pocket of poverty a few minutes' drive north of the Golden Gate Bridge. Tupac Amaru Shakur, rap music's bad-boy monarch, whose struggle to stardom left him wealthy and weary, complicated and conflicted, was dead.

title: Temple Emanu-El displays High Holy Days services on the Internet.
description: IT'S the High Holidays,'' proclaims the banner headline. ''Can't Get to the Temple? Get to the Computer.''

title: Public and Catholic School Chiefs Join Forces
description: Obligated to take every child, from the darling to the disruptive, public school officials have tended to dismiss the experiences of Roman Catholic schools, which have a much freer hand, as largely irrelevant.

title: Santa Monica Tries to Curb Charity to Homeless
description: For years, this beach city meant good living to the homeless, a place where the poorest of the poor could beg among the liberal rich, sleep under stars, and be fed from city coffers.

title: Lotus Gears Up To Get a Slice Of Internet Pie
description: Colleen Griffiths, a product developer at the Lotus Development Corporation, had to suppress a laugh recently when an executive at a large bank asked her why he should risk his business on new Lotus Internet software when he could choose ''mature technology'' from the two-year-old Netscape Communications Corporation.

title: David Bowie, Without All the Gadgetry
description: Immediately before David Bowie walked on stage at Roseland on Saturday night for a rare club-sized concert, a dance mix of his new single, ''Telling Lies,'' played on the loudspeakers. His fans had no noticeable reaction; they carried on talking, waiting for the concert to start. At most, only a handful of them had even heard the song before: it is available only on the Internet. It is also the latest example of Mr. Bowie's stubborn forward-thinking: his tireless search for something new and futuristic, no matter what the cost may be to his popularity and his audience.

title: . . . And Edison's Labs
description: The ambitious effort to raise $60 million to restore Thomas Edison's crumbling laboratories begins with a single check today: the newly formed Thomas Alva Edison Preservation Foundation will accept a $1 million donation from the Charles Edison Fund, an endowment set up by the inventor's son. For years, priceless relics of the inventor's work have been slowly deteriorating inside the 22-building Edison Historic Site, plagued by leaks and cracks and mostly unheated. The site has been designated one of the nation's 11 Most Endangered Historic Sites by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: The Giants and Jets Are as Empty as 0-6
description: THE Giants and the Jets deserve each other. And next Sunday they will get each other. Call it the Empty Bowl.

title: A Decade After Massacre, Some Sikhs Find Justice
description: A dismal air pervades the dank residential blocks of Tilak Vihar, a gloom that goes beyond the unpaved lanes turned to swamps by monsoons and the stench of human waste. In this quarter of New Delhi, the degradation common in Indian slums is compounded by a blankness on the faces, a lack of the optimism and vitality that, against all odds, inspirits so many of India's poor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about moves in Congress to control the designation of American parks and other locations as Unesco World Heritage Sites or Biosphere Reserves misstated the position of Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana. His office says that while he supports a House bill, he is not sponsoring it in the Senate.

title: Sun Shines on Fans, But Not on Yankees
description: ''LET God watch a ball game,'' my friend Jason said yesterday as the roof of the Skydome was opened. It is truly one of the marvels of contemporary sport, watching a cavernous domed arena turn into a sun-dappled ball park in 15 minutes.

title: In a Tough Housing Market, Rented Dividers Help Make Ends Meet
description: It took extraordinary vision for four young women to look at a one-bedroom apartment in New York City and see in it their new home, jammed full of their clothes, three computers, four separate phone jacks and a skittish cat. But as the women tell it, the recent spike in Manhattan rents made it inevitable. And a pressurized wall -- a relatively new invention, spoken about with surprising authority by young people in this space-cramped city -- made it possible.

title: Take a Cheaper Flight
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Joining Local Fight On Narcotics
description: In an attack on the booming wholesale narcotics market in Washington Heights, several Federal law enforcement agencies have agreed to join the New York Police Department in an unprecedented effort to break up gangs and deport illegal aliens who deal drugs in the neighborhood, according to law enforcement officials.

title: On Iraq, Republicans Are Following the Pattern
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARLO THOMAS and PAUL NEWMAN are rounding up their friends to pay tribute tonight to DR. HELEN CALDICOTT, the Australian pediatrician who has waged long battles against nuclear weapons and the degradation of the environment. Dr. Caldicott has written an autobiography, ''A Desperate Passion,'' which is being published by W. W. Norton. The book is a look back at her causes -- she founded Physicians for Social Responsibility -- and the heavy personal toll she paid for her crusades. Her husband of 27 years left her and she suffered bouts of depression and spiritual crises.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Pools and Stars

title: Carla Goes to College, but Who'll Educate Whom?
description: We all want different things from education. But Malcolm McDowell, playing a supremely arrogant humanities professor, makes his class an offer hard for anyone to resist. ''Survive this class, and you'll be able to swim in the shark-infested waters of the corporate world, handle French maitre d's, flummox cab drivers and maybe even hold your own with those awful little men who install telephones,'' he promises. Stephen Pynchon says he can turn a freshmen into an intellectual, ''someone who can listen to the 'William Tell' Overture and not think of 'The Lone Ranger.' ''

title: CHRONICLE
description: Lest there be any doubt that the fall book party season is moving into full swing, consider two gatherings taking place this evening.

title: A $78 Song vs. a Lloyd Webber Work
description: Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber's music has been heard in theaters, living rooms, concert halls and churches, delighting millions of listeners. Today, his work will appear in another setting, Federal District Court in Manhattan. And it is a sure bet that one listener, a composer named Ray Repp, will be experiencing many emotions, but delight will not be among them.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: Film Maker's Silent Partner Is Web
description: It was 1:30 A.M. on a recent Sunday in the Roxy, a cavernous downtown Manhattan nightclub, as Iara Lee, in red plastic pants, funky tinted sunglasses and a neon-green Lycra shirt, grabbed a handful of chartreuse brochures and vanished into a mass of sweaty, scantily clad bodies undulating to booming techno music.

title: U.S.-Bound Kurds Glad to Leave Iraq
description: Even as they perched among their suitcases on the way to the Turkish border, the families aboard Bus No. 8 remained reluctant to tell their last names.

title: Pressed by U.S., Haitian President Begins Purge of Guards
description: President Rene Preval of Haiti, under pressure from the United States, has begun a purge of his personal security detail, including several bodyguards suspected by American officials in the recent killings of two political opponents.

title: A Provocateur at Large In the World of Flamenco
description: Joaquin Cortes, a 27-year-old flamenco dancer who is being marketed by his management as the equivalent of a rock star, turns out to be the Michael Clark of Spanish dance.

title: Brush Off the 'Pollbearers'
description: After the New Hampshire primary, the pundit-pollster pack wrote off Bob Dole's candidacy.

title: Flickers of Hope Quickly Fizzle for the Giants
description: There were a number of signs in the Giants' 31-10 loss to the Washington Redskins today that the team is beginning to fall apart. Players arguing with each other. Defensive end Michael Strahan going into the Redskins' huddle and talking trash.

title: Drug War Isn't About Marijuana as Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets' Good Start Goes Up in Smoke
description: We knew the Jets had trouble handling adversity.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Old Pro Gives Woods A Lesson in Patience
description: It was all right there for Tiger Woods today. He held a three-stroke lead after three holes in the final round of the Quad City Classic and he had a long par-4 in front of him, the kind he routinely disposes of with a blinding flash of his driver and a flick of his pitching wedge.

title: How It Happened
