description: When Bosnia declared its independence in April 1992, Serbian paramilitaries poured across the border to kill and terrorize the Muslims of eastern Bosnia. On April 6 the last American Ambassador to Yugoslavia, Warren Zimmermann, protested to the Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Risk of Mosquito-Borne Virus Changes the Routines of Many
description: On the edge of Camp Hero State Park in Montauk, L.I., 27 families live year-round in ranch houses, running fishing boats and catering to the local tourists. It is a sturdy, tight community whose children used to play outside until well after dusk.

title: Presidential Campaign Sets a Costly Farce
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WARNING IRAQ THAT NEW ATTACKS ARE STILL POSSIBLE
description: Secretary of Defense William J. Perry, who is seeking to repair cracks in the coalition arrayed against Saddam Hussein, said here today that further United States attacks on Iraq were ''still a possibility.''

title: Did Someone Say Mendacity? (No, Not That Play)
description: Send in the no-neck monsters.

title: Juliet Prowse Is Dead at 59; Star of Musicals and Clubs
description: Juliet Prowse, the tall, leggy dancer with the sultry smile and the bee-sting lips who became a tabloid celebrity when she offended Khrushchev and captivated Frank Sinatra, died on Saturday at her home in the Holmby Hills section of Los Angeles. She was 59 and had been a staple of Las Vegas nightclub acts, television specials and touring musicals for more than 30 years.

title: Perot, in Video Lecture, Renews Attack on Trade Accord
description: Ross Perot says that when he cocks his ear toward Mexico, he still hears that ''giant sucking sound'' of American jobs headed south of the Rio Grande.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Conde Nast Makes Executive Changes
description: The Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications in New York, which owns magazines like GQ, Glamour, Mademoiselle and Vogue, will make executive changes.

title: Subway Sandwiches Narrows Its Review
description: The Subway Franchise Advertising Board, which oversees ad operations for the Subway chain of sandwich shops, has narrowed a review on its account to 5 agencies from 12. The account, with billings estimated at $85 million, has been handled for four years by Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland in Chicago.

title: In New Jersey, Infants Languish in Hospitals
description: Tiffany, the baby girl in crib No. 8, was ready for a bottle. She fussed until Rose Alston, a 72-year-old hospital volunteer, scooped her up into her arms. The infant looked into Miss Alston's eyes, holding her gaze as if fearing she might lose her attention.

title: Ford and U.A.W. Optimistic On Reaching an Agreement
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company were guardedly optimistic this evening that they could reach a new national labor contract, as work at factories continued despite expiration of the old contract at midnight on Saturday.

title: Is Unicellular Life Worth Living? Mars Knows
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Joseph Rukaj, who is accused of fatally shooting two relatives in Chappaqua, N.Y., misidentified one victim. He was Marc Nikc, the father-in-law of the second victim, Rigaletta Nikc, not her husband, Antonio Nikc.

title: Testing Whether Internet Readers Will Pay
description: After extending its grace periods four times, The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition says it will bar freeloaders from its World Wide Web site beginning Saturday.

title: CBS counterattacks the cable networks, hoping to reclaim its old loyalists.
description: ANOTHER television season starts tonight, but the broadcasting networks' fall party is a bit less grand and glamorous this year, mainly because so many guests have drifted away to that party next door, the one being given by those once-shabby neighbors, the cable channels.

title: Clinton Presses Tax-Cut Issue, Saying His Plan Is Paid For
description: Blending a prairie populist's fervor with a New Democrat's fiscal decorum, President Clinton pledged today that his was a party that could be trusted with people's money and to balance the Federal budget while providing targeted tax cuts to help the middle class.

title: Township Treasurer Charged
description: Last July, when auditors linked Stephen P. Arthur, the veteran treasurer of Mendham Township, to a $23,000 deficit in the township's books, he repaid the money immediately, the authorities said. But that did not keep Mr. Arthur out of trouble. He was charged in Superior Court in Morris County on Friday with official misconduct and misuse of entrusted property. Mr. Arthur is accused of using the township's payroll as his personal bank, taking a total of about $60,000 from 1991 to 1996, said Susan Bielanowski, an assistant Morris County prosecutor. All the money has been returned, she said.

title: Bozell Worldwide joins in a venture to reach black consumers with nontraditional marketing.
description: A GIANT agency has helped form a company that offers marketers a chance to reach black consumers outside the boundaries of conventional advertising.

title: Harold Pryor, 76, Long Island Rail Road Union Chief for 3 Decades
description: Harold J. Pryor, who as a Long Island Rail Road union chief was involved in disruptions of the railroad's operations in the 1950's, 1960's and 1970's, died on Friday in John T. Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 76 and lived in Stony Brook, L.I.

title: People
description: Jack Sansolo was named to the new post of senior vice president for global brand direction at Eddie Bauer Inc., Redmond, Wash., a unit of Spiegel Inc. He had been president at Point A Consulting, Los Angeles, which closed.

title: Noncommunicable Diseases Seen as World Health Challenge
description: In a comprehensive survey of the health of the world's population, an international team of experts says in a book to be published today that noncommunicable diseases and accidents are quickly replacing infectious diseases and malnutrition as leading causes of premature death and disability worldwide.

title: High-Tech Accounts Are Settled
description: Four software and high-tech marketers have made account decisions.

title: A Youthful Ad Agency Pursues an Elusive Group With a Bit of Irreverence
description: Steven Grasse, who at 31 sits precariously on the edge of the demographic group known as Generation X, rather likes the stereotypes that paint the group as a listless and cynical group of losers.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Who first identified a key enzyme in biotech research? Hoffmann-LaRoche has money on it.
description: FIVE years ago, the pharmaceutical giant Hoffmann-LaRoche paid $300 million for a portfolio of patents covering polymerase chain reaction, or P.C.R., a process that has revolutionized biotechnology research.

title: Power Authority Acts to Protect Upstate Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: . . . As Bills Move Slowly
description: Just because a bill is introduced today, don't expect to see it as a law tomorrow. Only 2.7 percent of the bills introduced in the State Legislature so far this year have been signed into law, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The ruling Republicans' bills fared more than twice as well as Democrats', but even they boast only a 4.4 percent success rate. Legislators have submitted 4,161 bills so far this year, more than in all of 1994 and on track to eclipse last year's total of 6,067.

title: 4 Girls and a TV Set. Clearly Not Your Miss America. Or Are They?
description: First, a disclosure: Lisa and Amy Fusick and their friends Kimberly and Allyson Malek once dressed up in lacy nightgowns and lip-synched to Madonna. But that was years ago, and now, watching the Miss America pageant on Saturday night, the foursome could not help recalling their childhood theatrics.

title: Transit Union Refuses to Reopen Contract
description: The head of the union representing most of New York City's transit workers said yesterday that he would not renegotiate the existing contract with the Transit Authority, which has sought spending cuts while threatening thousands of layoffs.

title: Business Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Reeves Be Drawn To Dallas?
description: Despite a contract that runs through 1999, there continues to be talk that Dallas Coach Barry Switzer is on his way out after this season. If Switzer is fired, a surprising name has popped in the Cowboys' coaching picture: Giants Coach Dan Reeves.

title: Puppy Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Alleviate What Ails the Braves
description: There was panic and fear. But the Atlanta Braves had just enough composure to turn the Mets into the shape of a life raft yesterday.

title: Yanks Fall, But Remain Pleased With Trip
description: It has been the road trip on which the Yankees finally righted themselves. Five consecutive victories can do that for a team, especially after the August and early September that this bunch had.

title: Bond Offerings Tentatively Set for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Dole Gets Christian Coalition's Trust and Prodding
description: Minutes after Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, spoke to the Christian Coalition this past weekend in Washington, the organization's founder, Pat Robertson, met him backstage and asked that Mr. Kemp carry a request to Bob Dole, the party's Presidential nominee.

title: Doing Better by Abused Children
description: Just as relatives were burying Nadine Lockwood, the latest tragic victim of child abuse and neglect, the head of New York City's child-welfare agency announced that he was considering decentralizing services to troubled families to prevent more deaths. Any decentralization plan must be carefully thought out. But Nicholas Scoppetta, Commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services, seems to be on the right track. Other cities have tried decentralization, with positive results.

title: The Best Drama This Fall? Yanks' Pennant Race
description: In a sports era in which loyalties are as transient as teams, in which franchises rent out memorable moments by inviting veterans in for a year or two, well-founded rivalries are often obscured or have simply faded away.

title: Westinghouse Offers Big Buyout at Unit
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is offering voluntary buyouts to 4,600 of the 6,600 workers at its slumping nuclear energy systems unit.

title: Presidents of Bosnia and Serbia To Meet Soon at Urging of U.S.
description: As part of a drive to bring Bosnia's former warring factions together as soon as possible after Saturday's nationwide vote, President Alija Izetbegovic will meet President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia in Paris in about three weeks, the American mediator, Richard C. Holbrooke, said today.

title: Remember: It's Just the Beginning
description: As the final second ticked off the clock yesterday, Bobby Mitchell, the Washington Redskins' assistant general manager, spoke compassionately about the defeated Giants as they left the field.

title: Scrappy Surfers Cavort In Space Age Outfits
description: Somewhere beneath the welter of space-race iconography that the band Man or Astroman? (hereafter referred to as M.O.A.) uses for promotional purposes, an estimably scrappy surf-music band exists. The members of the group come from Alabama, though they have told the press that they're really ''vaporous forms'' traveling through space.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Worth More Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Series of Suspects, but Each Is Ruled Out
description: A year after the body of Maria Isabel Alves was found in Central Park, investigators are still seeking the big break they hope will lead them to the man who killed her.

title: America Online, now on the Big Board, has big plans.
description: AFTER watching its stock price drop by about 60 percent since May, America Online Inc. did something about it yesterday. It moved from the Nasdaq market to the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Straight Man as an Imperfect Carbon Copy
description: When in a rough spot, the Smothers Brothers always had a punch line guaranteed to produce laughs: ''Mom always liked you best.'' It was a funny interjection, no matter what context it was used in. But that was almost 30 years ago. Comedy hasn't changed quite as much as other entertainment forms have since then, but the best comics avoid the tried and proven.

title: Shuttle Is Launched To Retrieve Astronaut
description: The space shuttle Atlantis rode into orbit today to retrieve an American astronaut, Dr. Shannon W. Lucid. Her return to Earth from the Russian space station has been delayed more than six weeks by emergency repairs of the shuttle's booster rockets and by a hurricane that disrupted work here at the Kennedy Space Center.

title: Ford Reaches Tentative Pact With Union
description: The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union reached agreement this evening on a new national labor contract intended to protect the jobs of current and future union workers, while providing wage increases modestly exceeding the inflation rate.

title: Laws Won't Let H.M.O.'s Tell Doctors What to Say
description: In a sign of growing concern about the practices of some health maintenance organizations, 16 states have adopted laws this year to nullify efforts by H.M.O.'s to limit what doctors can tell their patients.

title: Ohio Edison Plans to Buy Another Utility For $1.6 Billion
description: In the utility industry's latest merger deal, the Ohio Edison Company said yesterday that it would buy the Centerior Energy Corporation in a $1.61 billion stock swap to create the nation's 11th-largest investor-owned utility, serving 2.1 million customers in Ohio and western Pennsylvania.

title: Kuwait Agrees to Let U.S. Send 3,300 More G.I.'s There
description: After registering its annoyance at not being properly consulted, Kuwait agreed today to allow 3,300 more American troops to be based there to keep up military pressure on Iraq, even as the confrontation with President Saddam Hussein showed signs of easing.

title: Cosmic Ray Sources Sought
description: SCIENTISTS have known since 1938 that the earth is bombarded by particle showers that have energies so high as to defy explanation. On Friday, 19 nations agreed to make a collective effort to find an answer.

title: Nassau County Executive Proposes $17 Million Tax Cut
description: Nassau County residents would see their property taxes drop by $24 to $38 a year under a $2.2 billion budget proposed today by County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta.

title: Former Chicago Prep Star Pleads Guilty
description: The former prep basketball star RONNIE FIELDS and two other men pleaded guilty yesterday in Wheaton, Ill., to charges of sexually abusing a 20-year-old woman in July. The incident happened at the apartment of RON ESKRIDGE, a volunteer coach at Chicago's Farragut Academy, which Fields attended.

title: Inventories Rise as Business Bets on Sales
description: Stockpiles of unsold goods at American businesses soared to the highest level in more than a decade in July, suggesting that businesses were betting that a surge in demand would continue.

title: Key's Comeback Complete
description: A year ago, nobody thought Jimmy Key would return from season-ending shoulder surgery until mid-July of this season. At the earliest.

title: N.R.C. Acts Against a Doctor
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission took what a spokeswoman described as an ''infrequent'' step yesterday when it suspended a physician's license to use radioactive materials. The doctor, Shashi K. Agarwal, had been licensed to use the materials only when monitored by a radiation safety officer, but was caught violating that rule in April, the spokeswoman, Diane Screnci, said. Radioactive isotopes of thalium, barium and other elements are used in nuclear medicine to permit examiners to observe certain tissues and organs. Dr. Agarwal's license to practice medicine was not affected.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Turner Losing Key Executive In Merger Deal
description: Scott Sassa, the executive who led the Turner Broadcasting System's aggressive expansion in the entertainment industry, will resign from the company when the expected merger with Time Warner Inc. is completed next month, executives familiar with Mr. Sassa's plans said yesterday.

title: Joe Elsby Martin, 80, Muhammad Ali's First Boxing Teacher
description: One rainy night in 1954, Joe Elsby Martin, a Louisville, Ky., policeman who ran a local recreation center called the Columbia Gym, saw a skinny 12-year-old boy with tears in his eyes come into the gym seeking him out.

title: Federal Express Profit Off 18%; Foreign-Business Decline Cited
description: The Federal Express Corporation said yesterday that fiscal first-quarter earnings fell 18 percent because of a drop in international business and higher fuel costs.

title: New Republic And Cuban Agree to Settle Libel Lawsuit
description: The leader of the most powerful anti-Castro Cuban exile group in the United States announced yesterday that he had agreed to settle a libel suit against The New Republic for an article in the political weekly magazine that called him a mobster.

title: Intuit Selling Bill-Processing Unit for $227 Million
description: Intuit Inc., the nation's leading seller of personal finance software, announced yesterday that it would sell its electronic bill-payment processing business to its main competitor in that field, the Checkfree Corporation, for $227.6 million in stock.

title: Microcosmic Captive Breeding Project Offers New Hope for Beleaguered Beetle
description: IN a former restroom at the Roger Williams Park Zoo, a dozen or so American burying beetles have just emerged from underground -- well, from the depths of a five-gallon flowerpot -- and are happily munching mealworms in one of the more unusual captive breeding programs in the 23-year history of the Federal Endangered Species Act.

title: Far Out in the Exurbs
description: Burgville is my hometown. It used to be Manhattan. Then I tried to buy a three-bedroom apartment, and the real-estate agent asked me if I was the legal heir of the late Nizam of Hyderabad.

title: James Gulliver, Chairman Of Food Group, Dies at 66
description: James Gerald Gulliver, the son of a grocer who rose to become chairman of the Argyll Group, one of Britain's largest food retailing businesses, died on Thursday. He was 66.

title: When Trust in 'Data' Is Misplaced
description: WE sometimes pretend our computers are helping us with ''mission critical'' endeavors even when those missions are critical largely to our careers. But computers really can be involved in matters of life and death. Less than a year ago, relying on a specialized computer apparently contributed to the death of 159 people.

title: If You Bothered to Vote, Raise Your Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: PEGASUS GOLD AGREES TO BUY DAYTON MINING
description: Pegasus Gold Inc., a mining company based in Spokane, Wash., agreed yesterday to buy the Dayton Mining Corporation in a stock swap worth about $390 million. Pegasus offered three-quarters of a share for each Dayton share. Dayton Mining's stock closed at $7.8125, up 81.25 cents on the American Stock Exchange; Pegasus's stock closed at $11, down 25 cents, also on the Amex. The new company is expected to have a cash flow of $60 million from mining operations in 1997, rising to more than $100 million in 1998. Pegasus also said it would have lower cash costs as a result of its acquisition of the Andacollo gold mine in Chile, Dayton's key asset. Dayton is based in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Chess
description: Alex Yermolinsky won the tightly contested World Open Tournament in Philadelphia this summer by a tiebreak. After the 38-year-old grandmaster of Euclid, Ohio, had tied with his former countryman, grandmaster Aleksandr Goldin of Russia, with a score of 7 1/2-1 1/2 in the regulation games, they played a 10-minute game that Yermolinsky won. That gave him $11,220 in prize money. Goldin was awarded $10,780.

title: Magic's Koncak Is Out for the Season
description: Orlando Magic center JON KONCAK, who underwent surgery Sept. 10 to remove torn cartilage and bone spurs from his left knee, will miss the entire season. Koncak, who has had operations on the same knee three times during his 11-year career, reinjured it during an informal workout on Sept. 9. The Magic had hoped he could help fill the gap left by SHAQUILLE O'NEAL, who signed with the Los Angeles Lakers. The loss of Koncak may force Orlando to rely more than anticipated on FELTON SPENCER at center. (AP)

title: People
description: Daniel Roth, vice president for strategic planning at Western International Media, Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to the new position of executive vice president and chief strategic officer.

title: A New York City Honor for Erving
description: JULIUS ERVING will receive the Trustees' Award at the seventh annual New York City Basketball Hall of Fame awards dinner on Sept. 30 at the Time & Life Building in midtown Manhattan.

title: Dole and the Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Task Force Report Says Technology May Help U.N. Cut Red Tape
description: Technology may do for the United Nations what years of talk have failed to accomplish: slash through its mountains of paperwork and rein in its corps of international frequent flyers, the head of a new efficiency task force said today.

title: Claire Bloom Looks Back in Anger at Philip Roth
description: Few major American novelists have as eagerly breached the boundaries of fact and fiction as Philip Roth. In book after book he has skirted perilously close to autobiography, naming characters ''Philip'' and turning his own life inside out for public inspection and even condemnation. But now Mr. Roth is playing a role in someone else's book, and the portrait is even less flattering than anything he might have written himself.

title: Tough New Warning on Diet Is Issued by Cancer Society
description: Just as martinis and steaks seem to be making a comeback, the American Cancer Society, in guidelines released yesterday, warned that eating red meat and drinking even small amounts of alcohol could contribute to certain cancers.

title: Keeping Demons at Bay, or Almost
description: ''Back From Madness: The Struggle for Sanity'' is a conscientious effort to look into the disturbed minds of four psychiatric patients at Massachusetts General Hospital. That it provides no revelations is not so much a failure of the reporting as a testament to the mysteries of mental illness.

title: Conspiracy Theories Rife On Demise of Flight 800
description: No matter how many times the authorities investigating the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 have tried to dismiss the theory that the airplane was destroyed by a missile from an American military craft, and that the event was being covered up, it has refused to go away.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: U.S. Command Faulted in Blast At Saudi Base
description: American military commanders ignored repeated warnings of terrorist threats to an apartment complex housing American troops in Saudi Arabia that was bombed in June, and later exaggerated the size of the explosion in defending their lack of preparation for the attack, Pentagon investigators said today.

title: Maurice M. Black, 78, an Expert on Breast Cancer
description: Dr. Maurice M. Black, a pathologist who was an expert on breast cancer, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: Strike in Philadelphia: What Stopped the Music
description: The central issues in the strike called by the Philadelphia Orchestra on Sunday are those at the heart of virtually all labor negotiations these days: wages, health benefits and pensions. But the flash point was the orchestra's loss of its recording contract with EMI Records last month, followed by management's wish to reduce a guarantee of recording payments that was in the musicians' most recent contract.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Think the British royal family is alone when it comes to marital woes? The Grimaldis of Monaco may be giving the Windsors some competition.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: I.B.M. Is Said To Prepare A Buyout Plan
description: I.B.M. is preparing to offer buyouts and other inducements to between 3,000 and 5,000 employees either to leave the company or find new jobs at its fastest-growing divisions, people familiar with the company's plans said yesterday.

title: America's Habit of Force in Haiti
description: The 23,000 American troops who landed here two years ago this week to restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and democracy in Haiti have long since gone. But the United States continues to be deeply involved in the day-to-day management of this country -- and reliant on the unilateral application of force to achieve its objectives.

title: Giant Black Diamonds Of Mysterious Origin May Hail From Space
description: THE source of the world's largest diamonds -- black stones known as carbonadoes -- has long been a geological puzzle. Found mostly in Brazil and central Africa, the big stones follow none of the normal rules of diamond mineralogy and inhabit none of the usual haunts. For decades, their formation has baffled scientists, even as geologists have come to understand the origin of the regular diamonds that adorn rings and jewelry.

title: Clerical Workers' Strike at Barnard Ends in Pact
description: After five months on the picket line, clerical workers at Barnard College yesterday ended one of the longest strikes ever at an American college by ratifying a contract in which Barnard gave in to employee demands on health insurance.

title: AGENCY TIGHTENS AIRPORT SECURITY IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Responding to repeated criticisms of the security at Kennedy International Airport after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Port Authority officials announced a series of changes yesterday intended to make it more difficult for anyone to plant a bomb on a plane.

title: Brazilian Whose Daughter Died in Park Ends a Year Without Solace or Answers
description: On Maria Isabel Alves's dresser back home, there is an engraving of Jesus, striking in its ambiguity. Floating in a gray background, the face is earthly and yet unreal. The eyes are either open and brimming with solace, or closed in contemplation. As Ms. Alves's mother, Lydia Pinto Machado, is learning, it is a matter of light and angles, of faith and time.

title: Playing Around With Your Photos on a Zip Drive
description: I FINALLY tried an experiment I have been meaning to do since I got a Zip drive last February. When I wrote about the drive then, I concentrated on problems with the technical support from its manufacturer, the Iomega Corporation of Roy, Utah; (800) 456-5522. I should say now that the Zip drive, with a price of $150 to $200, has become an indispensable part of my old Macintosh Quadra system.

title: After History of Threats, Man Kills Ex-Girlfriend and Himself
description: Slipping past spot-checks by police patrols, a gunman obsessed with a teen-ager barricaded himself in her family's Brooklyn apartment with a dozen hostages yesterday. In a three-hour siege, he shot three captives, pistol-whipped another, then killed his pregnant former girlfriend and himself with bullets to the head as the police stormed in.

title: Mom, Dad, Ex-Spouses And All
description: When it comes to funny, where would you put divorce on the national laugh meter? NBC's ''Something So Right'' offers what the executive producers, Judd Pillot and John Peaslee (both citing ''Coach'' as a credit), see as a look at a true blended family of the 90's.

title: The Orioles Will Have A New Look
description: After rain washed out their chance to slice another game from the Yankees' lead, the Baltimore Bombers left the friendly environment of Camden Yards today and headed for ''the most hostile atmosphere there is.''

title: Some Accused of Insider Trading in Duracell
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday sued unknown buyers of Duracell International Inc. securities, accusing them of engaging in illegal insider trading before it agreed to be sold to the Gillette Company.

title: THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: Texas

title: The Flip Side: Six Teams Are at 3-0
description: Six teams are 3-0 after Week 3, tying a record established in 1966 and tied in 1968, 1979 and 1986. Pittsburgh's victory over Buffalo prevented the Bills from becoming a record seventh undefeated team. There won't be six 4-0 teams, though. That's because all six teams are involved in showdowns with each other this weekend.

title: Joyner-Kersee to Play in Women's League
description: JACKIE JOYNER-KERSEE, who won Olympic gold medals in track and field in 1988 and 1992, will play in the American Basketball League, the new women's league announced yesterday.

title: Former Exchange Chief Barred for Commodity Ruse
description: A former chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange was fined $500,000 and barred from trading on commodities exchanges for five years for his role in a fictitious-trading scheme, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said yesterday.

title: Annual Data Show Where City Falls Short
description: Crime and welfare caseloads continued their steep decline in New York City last year, but budget cutbacks combined with a harsh winter to produce a reduction in several critical city services, according to the self-portrait released by the Giuliani administration yesterday.

title: A New Armani Conquers a New World
description: The most telling moment in Giorgio Armani's assault on New York last week wasn't at the intimate dinner for 35 at the apartment of S.I. Newhouse Jr., when Mr. Newhouse compared Mr. Armani's triumph to Caesar in Asia Minor, saying, ''Veni, vidi, vici.'' It wasn't at the private dinner for 150 on top of the new Giorgio Armani boutique, where a few mere mortals were sprinkled around the celebrity-packed room. It wasn't even at the Emporio Armani concert for 900, when Mr. Armani got up and waved his arms over his head to the Fugees, D'Angelo, Eric Clapton and the Wallflowers.

title: No Headline
description: ''I found it amazing. Doctors told me they could not tell a cancer patient that they felt a bone marrow transplant would be very beneficial, because the H.M.O. doesn't pay for it.''

title: If You Bothered to Vote, Raise Your Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Streeters Test Water Futures
description: The smartly dressed commuters walked down the gangplank for the East River Express yesterday, clutching newspapers and briefcases, flashing a smile as they boarded the ferry, a far cry from the city's crowded subways, where they jostle every day for a seat.

title: Generous Memories of a Poor, Painful Childhood
description: ANGELA'S ASHES

title: Motorola Introducing PC's With Apple System
description: Motorola plans today to introduce a line of personal computers equipped with Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh operating system, as the companies bid to expand the market for such machines at a time when it is threatened by I.B.M.-compatible computers running Microsoft Windows software.

title: A new campaign for Hanes hosiery features the singer Tina Turner and her famous legs.
description: THE owner of what may well be the most glamorous gams since Betty Grable's is the star of an elaborate cross-marketing effort to promote Hanes hosiery.

title: Clinton and Dole Plan Debate Format as Perot Ruling Nears
description: The outline of the debate over the shape of the Presidential debates became clear today, as the Clinton camp said it would push for a tightly spaced series of long sessions that would not begin until October.

title: Coca-Cola Expands An Agency's Role
description: The Coca-Cola Company has further expanded its relationship with Fallon McElligott Berlin in New York by awarding that agency creative duties for Georgia Coffee, a soft drink sold in Japan. Those duties had been handled by the McCann-Erickson Japan unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in Tokyo.

title: Studies Pinpoint Region of Brain Implicated in Tourette's Syndrome
description: SCIENTISTS have found a possible explanation for the severity of tics in Tourette's syndrome, a bizarre neurological disorder characterized by rapid sudden movements or vocalizations that occur repeatedly in the same way.

title: New Zealand Publisher Gets Bid From Ireland
description: Independent Press Communications Ltd., headed by the Irish entrepreneur Anthony F. J. O'Reilly, said yesterday that it would offer $10.50 (New Zealand) each for the shares of the publisher Wilson & Horton Ltd. that it does not already own. The offer values the company at $1.03 billion, or $716 million (United States). Companies controlled by Mr. O'Reilly already own 45.2 percent of Wilson & Horton, which publishes The New Zealand Herald.

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: Raines and Key Put Yankees Three Games Ahead
description: The huge three-game series that may well determine the winner of the American League East won't begin for the Yankees until Tuesday night, in the Bronx, when the division leaders face the rampaging second-place Baltimore Orioles.

title: Jets and Giants With a Mellow Tone
description: With the Jets ahead, 14-0, against Miami on Sunday, I thought, ''Terrific, the Jets won't lose by much now.'' That's how it is in Jetville. This Sunday, when the 0-3 Giants play the 0-3 Jets, what measure of nominal expectations should be employed? Probably the speed at which a satellite dish can be nailed to your roof and you can activate a ''Sunday Ticket'' subscription to watch all other National Football League games kicking around the universe at 1 and 4 P.M.

title: Accounts
description: The Cleveland Clinic to BBDO Chicago, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been handled by Wyse Advertising, Cleveland. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $3 million to $5 million.

title: What Perot Sought and Found in Running Mate
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Intense Efforts by Police Fail to Stop Brooklyn Killing

title: Simpson Trial, Part II, Begins Today in California Civil Court
description: Though his life and liberty have been preserved, O. J. Simpson will on Tuesday again face charges that he is responsible for the deaths of his former wife and her friend.

title: New York's Welfare Challenge
description: With more than two million New Yorkers receiving public assistance, Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature in Albany face one of the toughest challenges ever to confront the state's government. Now that the bitter battle over welfare reform has been settled by President Clinton's signature, critics and advocates of change must work together to fashion a new system that softens the law's harshest blows to the poor without bankrupting the state. They have only about six months to transform welfare as we know it into something other than a nightmare for recipients and government officials alike.

title: Summer Math Camp
description: To the Editor:

title: When Machines Can't Count
description: Even in a town built on fantasy, it was too good to be true. Each time an employee at the Grand Hotel withdrew $20 from a certain automatic teller machine near the casino floor, the device spit out $100 instead. The unusual circumstances were discovered by hotel security personnel on Thursday. The state Division of Gaming Enforcement and the owner of the A.T.M., Midlantic PNC Bank, are investigating, said Sharon Pearce, a spokeswoman for the Grand. And the excess money will have to be returned, she said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Girl, 15, Reports Another Student Raped Her
description: A 15-year-old at Bushwick High School in Brooklyn was raped in the school basement yesterday, the police said, by another student in an incident that reignited a dispute over security in the public schools.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Skaters and Cyclists Argue Against Helmet Laws
description: Roller skaters and bicyclists banded together yesterday to criticize proposed laws that would require them to wear helmets or face $50 fines. The two groups argued that the rules would be virtually unenforceable and would only discourage people from engaging in either activity.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: 'Merger of Equals' Discussion Heats Up for H.M.O.'s in California
description: The Foundation Health Corporation, a provider of managed health care that is based here, said today that it was discussing a possible ''merger of equals.'' The company did not name the other party in the talks, but it said that the deal would value Foundation Health's shares at less than the closing price on Friday.

title: U.S. Flying Out Refugees
description: More than 2,000 refugees who had worked with the American military and relief operation in northern Iraq have crossed safely into Turkey. The United States flew the first of them to Guam today, where they will be considered for eligibility for asylum in the United States.

title: 3D0 to Make Only Entertainment Software
description: The 3DO Company said today that it planned to shift away from video-game systems and make only entertainment software.

title: C.I.A. Laughs Last
description: To the Editor:

title: President Nearly Loses Fox TV Spot
description: The fledgling effort by Rupert Murdoch's Fox television network to help right what is wrong with Presidential election campaigning faltered over the issue of a blue backdrop yesterday, but a last-minute conference call saved it.

title: Queiroz Quitting Stars
description: The MetroStars are looking for a new coach. In a move that was expected, Carlos Queiroz informed the team late Sunday night that he had accepted a $2 million offer to coach in Japan. Queiroz will leave the MetroStars at the end of the Major League Soccer season.

title: Hoechst Weighs Sale Of Chemical Unit Stake
description: Hoechst A.G. said yesterday that it was considering selling a stake in its chemical business as part of a reorganization into a ''strategic holding company.'' Hoechst said it wanted the chemicals, drugs and agricultural operations to be separate businesses, in hopes of making them more attractive to investors.

title: Evelyne V. Johnson, A Philanthropist
description: Evelyne V. Johnson, widow of Gen. Robert Wood Johnson, the philanthropist and chairman of Johnson & Johnson, died on Tuesday at Longleat, her estate in Princeton, N.J.

title: Clinton Enters Utah Battle Over Fate of Wilderness Area
description: Following a path taken by Teddy Roosevelt in 1908, President Clinton will go to the Grand Canyon on Wednesday, where he is expected to declare as a national monument a big stretch of much-fought-over Federal land in southern Utah.

title: Making Women Swoon And Boyfriends Sulk
description: The Mexican singer Juan Gabriel, whose shows sold out two nights at Radio City over the weekend, knows his audience. Toward the end of his performance on Sunday, surrounded by a mariachi band and in the middle of a set of rancheras -- rural morality tales put to song -- he sang one of his latest hits, ''Cancion 187.''

title: Correction
description: An article in Weekend on Sept. 6 about Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn and some of the families buried there misstated the site of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. It is in Boston, not Cambridge, Mass.

title: The Best Pennant Race Money Can Buy
description: The New York Yankees have tumbled since mid-July, depressing their fans and delighting their enemies. The happy result is a delectable three-game September showdown with the Baltimore Orioles this week at Yankee Stadium. While the Yankees were slumping, the Orioles were winning. As the weeks passed the Yankee lead over the Orioles in the American League Eastern Division dwindled from a July high of 12 games to just 3 as of this morning.

title: Devils (1-0) to Suspend Absent Holik
description: The Devils will suspend Bobby Holik, effective today, Lou Lamoriello, the team's president and general manager, said last night.

title: Goldman, Sachs Profit Advanced 39% in the 3d Quarter
description: Continuing one of its strongest years ever, Goldman, Sachs & Company had pretax profit of $589 million for the three months ended Aug. 30, John A. Thain, the firm's chief financial officer said yesterday.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANKERS TRUST CORP., New York, named Kevin B. Ferrell as managing director and head of its risk management advisory business.

title: Omnicom Group Revamps Ross Roy
description: A year after acquiring Ross Roy Communications, the Omnicom Group has made changes that include a revamping of management.

title: Bosnia Election Results Are Delayed for a Day
description: Preliminary results of the national elections held on Saturday in Bosnia are expected on Tuesday, a day later than originally announced.

title: Mickelson and Norman on Dunhill Teams
description: PHIL MICKELSON, a four-time winner who tops the PGA Tour money list with $1,574,799, will join MARK O'MEARA and STEVE STRICKER on the United States team for the Alfred Dunhill Cup next month in St. Andrews, Scotland. Tournament organizers also said yesterday that GREG NORMAN would represent Australia with STEVE ELKINGTON and CRAIG PARRY. The 16-country competition is scheduled for Oct. 10-13 at the Old Course. (AP)

title: Big Day Nears in a Life Lived for Saturday Afternoon
description: The smell of a Saturday morning began to help define Peyton Manning's life long before the game ever did. From his vantage point in a football household in the South he was forever trying to understand how Saturdays worked, but always with an appreciation of what they represented -- an experience linked to distant generations, larger than any individual.

title: Patron Saint Of Street Fairs Marches In
description: NO denying, there was a familiar hubbub on Mulberry Street as the feast honoring San Gennaro, patron saint of Naples, enjoyed what the Mayor assures us was its first mob-free weekend in a long time. But con tutto rispetto, as they would say in Naples, with all respect, the annual street fair had that look of faded grandeur Neapolitans know all too well.

title: Girl Drawn Into Angry Man's World
description: Danielle DiMedici was not yet 17 and still in high school when she and James Parker, six years her senior, began to date. But it took almost no time, law enforcement officials said yesterday, before the teen-ager virtually disappeared from her family and into his world.

title: Giuliani's Flirtation With G.O.P. Ticket
description: Repeatedly over the last few weeks, Rudolph W. Giuliani has praised Bob Dole's selection of Jack Kemp as his running mate. Last night, the Mayor went so far as to meet with Mr. Kemp at Gracie Mansion, and stood by smiling as the candidate criticized the Clinton Administration's urban policies.

title: Dole Attacks on Crime, but Clinton Is Ready
description: The 1996 Presidential campaign abruptly shifted from the economy to crime today. Bob Dole maintained that President Clinton had presided over an epidemic of juvenile drug use and crime, and Mr. Clinton appeared amid an ocean of blue uniforms to receive the support of the nation's largest police union.

title: QNA
description: The Rain Barrel

title: Charge Against Warriors' Smith Dismissed
description: A judge in Chesapeake, Va., dismissed a malicious wounding charge yesterday against Golden State Warriors forward JOE SMITH, who had been accused of striking a male dancer with a beer bottle in a bar. Smith broke into tears after the decision was announced by General District Judge S. BERNARD GOODWYN.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The march of Britons into commanding positions at American magazines is continuing unabated, it seems.

title: Seeking to Muzzle Planes
description: Members of Congress from New Jersey and Staten Island have joined forces on a measure to require the Federal Aviation Administration to reduce aircraft noise over New Jersey by six decibels, so that normal conversation can be heard over the aircraft. (The bill would require a 25 percent reduction in noise over Staten Island.) The bill, to be introduced in the House of Representatives today, is co-sponsored by several members of the New Jersey delegation as well as Representative Susan Molinari, Republican of Staten Island. The bill does not specify how the noise reduction would be accomplished.

title: Agnes Mongan, 91, Curator and Director At Fogg Art Museum
description: Agnes Mongan, the first woman to be a curator and then the first to be a director at the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., died on Sunday at a hospital in Cambridge. She was 91 and lived in Cambridge.

title: Voters Are Seeing a 3-in-1 Campaign
description: Vice President Al Gore campaigned today in his home state of Tennessee for the ninth time this year, another dutiful call to help reverse the Democratic fortunes of 1994, when the party lost both Senate seats, two House seats and the governor's office to Republicans.

title: Braves Sink the Mets
description: There was a game, too, one the Mets were losing as usual. But forgive them for feeling pretty good about certain moments while being beaten, 5-2, by the Braves last night at Shea Stadium.

title: F.A.A. Agrees to Buy New Computers to Control Air Traffic
description: The Federal Aviation Administration signed a contract today for installation of a new generation of computers and software to modernize hundreds of civilian and military air traffic control offices that handle planes within 50 miles of airports.

title: GLENAYRE SHARES DIVE 39 PERCENT ON POOR OUTLOOK
description: The shares of Glenayre Technologies Inc. plunged 39 percent yesterday to a 52-week low after the company, a maker of telecommunications equipment, said that slowing orders and higher costs would keep third-quarter earnings as much as 45 percent below estimates. Glenayre shares dropped $13.25, to $20, in Nasdaq trading of more than 19.5 million shares, making it the day's most actively traded issue. The earnings forecast surprised analysts, who said that the company, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., had not been forthcoming with details on why orders were slowing.

title: Patterns
description: A Suit, a Shave or a Cigar?

title: Marshall Creates Scholarship at UConn
description: DONYELL MARSHALL, a former University of Connecticut standout now playing for the Golden State Warriors, will return to campus Thursday as the school recognizes his establishment of a basketball endowment. Marshall, the fourth player picked in the 1994 draft, donated $100,000 to the school's Athletic Development Fund, which will be matched by the UConn 2000 upgrade campaign. (AP)

title: Seasoned Envoys Debate, and the Language Is Diplomatic
description: Two women who could be Secretary of State faced off last night in a preview of the foreign policy portions of this fall's Presidential debates.

title: Teacher Union's Ads Return Dole's Fire
description: New York City's largest teachers' union, the United Federation of Teachers, has decided to strike back against Bob Dole.

title: CAROLCO PICTURES FILES REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: Carolco Pictures Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan to liquidate its assets and distribute proceeds valued at $90 million to creditors. The plan, filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles, would cancel all Carolco equity securities, including convertible debt. Securities holders would not be entitled to distributions, the company said. The $90 million from asset sales and Internal Revenue Service claims that were smaller than expected would leave bondholders who bought Carolco's $58 million in outstanding bonds with big profits, Daily Variety, the entertainment trade newspaper, reported last week. Carolco sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in November.

title: Before Jamestown
description: To the Editor:

title: An Assassin For Apartheid Recalls Trade, And Trauma
description: When he was a young police officer sent off to fight South Africa's secret border war with Angola in the late 1970's, Eugene de Kock once captured a group of prisoners and brought them back to camp.

title: Speaking Softly to Nigeria
description: The world was outraged when the regime of the Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha executed Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other environmental and human rights activists last November. Clinton Administration officials spoke of strong sanctions to force Mr. Abacha to move toward democratic elections and stop the abuses. Unhappily, the repression has remained but the threats have disappeared.

title: Alsthom and Matra Make Bids for Thomson
description: Alcatel Alsthom S.A. and Matra S.A. said yesterday that they had submitted bids for Thomson S.A., the debt-ridden military and electronics company that the French Government has put on the block. Analysts said Alsthom, a telecommunications and transportation company, appeared to be the front-runner although a decision was not scheduled before mid-October. Matra is the military arm of Lagardere Groupe.

title: Two Directors of Archer Not Running for Re-election
description: In the latest response to criticism of insider domination of the company's board, the Archer Daniels Midland Company said yesterday that two former officers of the company would step down as directors.

title: Dole's Elegant Solution
description: With an exquisite sense of timing, Bob Dole has thrown his full political power behind an idea for easing overcrowding in American schools that is elegant in its simplicity: Take some of the brats and throw them out on their grimy ears.

title: Mercedes Buses in China
description: Mercedes-Benz A.G. of Germany said today that it had completed an agreement to form a joint venture to manufacture touring buses in China. The venture, Yazing-Benz Ltd., will turn out around 7,000 coaches annually and 5,000 bus chassis for the Mercedes partner, Yangzhou Motor Coach General. The plant is scheduled to start operating early next year. Mercedes, the luxury car and commercial truck division of Daimler-Benz A.G., will hold a 50 percent stake in the $60 million bus plant.

title: Hundley Recognizes His Place in History
description: Todd Hundley would appreciate the place. It is just a room, a 20-by-20 safe-deposit box of sorts, a place Roxie Campanella had built for her husband, Roy, in their Los Angeles home years ago. It was filled with everything Roy Campanella had achieved, every award, every championship moment, every record he valued.

title: McGeorge Bundy Dies at 77; Top Adviser in Vietnam Era
description: McGeorge Bundy, an influential foreign policy adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson who was a forceful advocate of expanding American involvement in the Vietnam War, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 77 and lived in Manchester-by-the-Sea, north of Boston.

title: Building Layers of Scar Tissue
description: THERE is no antidote for Pennant Fever. Even if you play professional football.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COOPER INDUSTRIES, Houston, said it was considering the sale of its drapery hardware division as part of its plan to focus on industrial systems and power generation.

title: Another Steep Decline For Olivetti's Shares
description: The stock of the troubled office-products company Olivetti S.p.A. slumped further yesterday as its chief executive, Francesco Caio, faced questioning by magistrates on the company's finances. Mr. Caio, who has headed the company for 10 weeks, is to be questioned soon in a preliminary inquiry into Olivetti's accounts by magistrates in Ivrea, near Turin, people close to the judiciary said.

title: Service for Dr. Baltzell
description: A service for Dr. E. Digby Baltzell, a sociologist known for his writings about his fellow white Anglo-Saxon Protestants, or WASP's, will be held at 3 P.M. today in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. A professor emeritus at the University of Pennsylvania, he had a doctorate in sociology from Columbia. Dr. Baltzell died on Aug. 17.

title: Expanding Visitation Rights
description: As lawmakers returned to work yesterday after their summer break, the Assembly Community Services Committee approved a bill that would allow aunts and uncles to sue for visitation rights for their nieces and nephews when access has been cut off because of a death or divorce. The measure now goes to the full Assembly. The sponsor of the bill, Assemblywoman Marion Crecco, Republican of Bloomfield, said it resembled an existing law in Washington State.

title: Wrestling as Fun, Not Sport
description: After concluding that professional wrestling is a form of entertainment, not a sport, an Assembly committee voted yesterday to deregulate the industry. Under the bill approved by the Senior Issues, Tourism and Gaming Committee, the state's Athletic Control Board would no longer oversee professional wrestling. The measure would also eliminate a special tax on pay-per-view professional wrestling events taped in the state, The Associated Press reported. The tax -- unique to New Jersey -- has stopped the World Wrestling Federation from holding pay-per-view events in the state since 1990, said Douglas G. Sages, an executive vice president of Titan Sports, which owns the federation.

title: Amorous Intrigue in Turn-of-the-Century Vienna
description: Given the New York City Opera's desire to maintain an identity distinct from that of the Metropolitan Opera, the company's decision to present Strauss's ''Rosenkavalier'' might seem a miscalculation. Great orchestras have played this score famously, and major singers have given legendary portrayals of its characters.

title: U.S. Starts Trial of Reputed Mexico Drug Boss
description: The reputed drug trafficker who is accused of having transformed Mexico's drug trade from a backwoods marijuana operation into a $4 billion cocaine industry went on trial here today, eight months after he was arrested in Mexico and expelled to the United States.

title: Giuliani and Crew Weigh Year-Round Classes to Ease Overcrowding
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that they would consider keeping the school system open all year to lessen overcrowding, suggesting that such a move would allow the city to make better use of buildings that are mostly empty in the summer.

title: Season of Discontent Flares Up on the Field
description: When a team begins to break apart, sometimes it happens in small steps that may not be noticeable to everyone.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: New Defenses

title: Down and Out in Paris, in a Not-So-Lavish Setting
description: At its best, the New York City Opera's intimate, honest production of Puccini's ''Boheme,'' which was introduced last season to commemorate the opera's 100th anniversary, offers a refreshing alternative to the proscenium-filling excess of Franco Zeffirelli's production for the Metropolitan Opera. This seemed especially true on Saturday afternoon when the production, the work of the former soprano Graziella Sciutti, returned to the company with a youthful, engaging cast and some supple playing from the orchestra, conducted by Robert Duerr.

title: Turnpike Reprieve Expires
description: Drivers who use the Newark Bay-Hudson County Extension of the New Jersey Turnpike got a reprieve last weekend, when extensive repairs to the bridge deck from exit 14 to 14C were postponed for a week. The work will begin this Friday instead, the turnpike authority said. Inclement weather was blamed for the delay.

title: U.S. Knew in 1953 North Koreans Held American P.O.W.'s
description: Newly declassified documents show that the United States knew immediately after the Korean War that North Korea had failed to turn over hundreds of American prisoners known to be alive at the end of the war, adding to growing speculation that American prisoners might still be alive and in custody there.

title: Who Keeps the Burmese in Step? Ask the Generals
description: There are fighter planes and rifles and artillery shells in the new military museum here, but there are also displays of textile mills, power plants, resort hotels, supermarkets, bus lines and dancing shoes.

title: A Model Case of Risks and Rewards in Small Business
description: It isn't all crinoline dresses and cute blinky blue eyes in the doll business.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in thin trading yesterday, as the day's statistics, -- July business inventories -- had little impact on the market, where traders are looking ahead to the Fed's monetary policy meeting next week.

title: Misreading the Gender Gap
description: LOS ANGELES  Do you know about the gender gap in paranormal beliefs? Women are more likely than men to believe in horoscopes and psychics. People who are unsympathetic to women say it's because women are more gullible or dumber than men; those who are sympathetic to women say it's because women are more open-minded or spiritual than men.

title: Fort Hood G.I.'s Pack And Wait for the Word
description: The crowd at the First Cavalry Division Memorial Chapel was sparse at the Protestant services on Sunday morning. About 30 worshipers, instead of the usual 70 or so, were in the pews to hear words of encouragement from the chaplain, Capt. Steven Maglio.

title: Samsung Declares Intent To Buy Fokker Unit
description: Samsung Aerospace Industries of South Korea said yesterday that it had sent a letter of intent to acquire the bankrupt aircraft production arm of Fokker N.V. of the Netherlands. ''We sent the letter to Fokker on Sept. 3,'' Kang Shin Woo, a official of the company, said. ''But we have not finalized the deal yet. We are still negotiating.'' (Bloomberg Business News)

title: A Blast From the Past Is Man of the Moment
description: That chortling you heard when the Yankees deprived the Baltimore Orioles of Darryl Strawberry, then acquired Cecil Fielder, is almost a whimper now. And the sobering up of a team heady with notions that the Orioles had been foiled has occurred because a bargain-basement transaction, not by the Yankees but by Baltimore, rivals anything George Steinbrenner and his millions have managed to bring about the last two months.

title: Warner Executive Hired by Paramount
description: Robert G. Friedman, a top film marketing executive at Warner Brothers, was hired yesterday as vice chairman of the motion picture group of Paramount Pictures in Los Angeles. He succeeds Barry London, 48, who resigned last week.

title: Jets Call The Doctor And Cross Fingers
description: They clutched their X-rays in brown envelopes, while Dr. Stephen Nicholas waited outside the Jets' complex today, as if looking to see what kind of future would be reflected in those black-and-white pictures.

title: Dollar Falters as Doubts Grow Concerning Rate Rise by Fed
description: The dollar fell yesterday against other leading currencies as doubts grew about the prospect for a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase next week.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Theater in Review
description: A Platform From Which Shaw

title: Theater in Review
description: Making the Predictable

title: Decision on Graf's Release Due Next Week
description: An appeals court in Mannheim, Germany, will decide next week whether to free STEFFI GRAF's father on bail after more than 13 months in prison on of tax evasion charges, a court spokesman said yesterday. PETER GRAF, 58, has been jailed since Aug. 2, 1995. He is accused of not paying about $13.3 million in taxes on $28 million of his daughter's earnings between 1989 and 1993. (AP)

title: Rogers and Pettitte Are O.K.
description: Two days ago, the Yankee rotation was on the brink of falling apart heading into the team's biggest series of the season: three games against the Baltimore Orioles beginning Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium. Today Manager Joe Torre's biggest worry was the forecast of rain.

title: SUPERIOR NATIONAL OFFERS $54 MILLION FOR PAC RIM
description: Superior National Insurance Group Inc., a subsidiary of the Superior National Corporation, said yesterday that it had offered $54 million in cash to acquire the Pac Rim Holding Corporation in a transaction expected to yield about $3 a share to stockholders. Pac Rim, of Woodland Hills, Calif., sells workers' compensation insurance and had net premiums earned of $76 million last year. Pac Rim executives were not immediately available to comment on the offer, which also includes cash to retire Pac Rim debt and warrants. A spokesman for Superior National, of Calabasas, Calif., said that the exact amount of cash was still under discussion. Pac Rim's shares fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $2.625, and Superior National's shares rose 50 cents, to $8.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: CHRONICLE
description: American authors seem to have no monopoly on creative -- and sometimes infuriating -- ways to promote their books.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Dow Rises 50, To Still Another Record

title: Girding the Wrists
description: The sleek matte jerseys and stretch velvets that promise to be popular this fall call for bold modern jewelry, like the wide cuff bracelets Ralph Lauren and Tom Ford used as accessories in their shows. The bracelets, in shiny gold or silver, make an especially dramatic statement when worn one on each wrist.

title: The City Hall Doctor, Forever on Call
description: The fate of ABC's ''Spin City,'' linchpin in the network's campaign to halt NBC's ratings juggernaut, could very well depend on what the American public thinks about Dick Morris, the Clinton spinmeister caught with his family values around his ankles.

title: Duff Has Different Idea: Rehabilitating Alone
description: An interesting situation has developed with one of the Giants' best young prospects, defensive lineman Jamal Duff, who has raised some eyebrows in the organization by leaving the team to rehabilitate his injured foot in California.

title: Movie History Emerges From a Basement
description: A film that archivists believe to be the oldest complete American feature, a 1912 version of Shakespeare's ''Richard III,'' has been been turned over to the American Film Institute in near-perfect condition. The print had been stored for more than 30 years in the basement of a onetime theater projectionist in Portland, Ore.

title: OCEAN REEF WITHDRAWS ITS BID TO BUY BEST PRODUCTS
description: The Best Products Company said yesterday that Ocean Reef Management had withdrawn its unsolicited offer to buy the company for $2 a share, or a total of $63.2 million. Best Products said that Ocean Reef had concluded the takeover would require greater resources than originally thought. But it said that Ocean Reef wanted to continue talks in the hopes of reaching an alternative proposal. Best Products' stock plummeted more than 58 percent on the news, falling 62.5 cents a share to close at 43.75 cents in Nasdaq trading. Best Products, a catalogue retailer based in Richmond, emerged from bankruptcy-court protection in 1994. Ocean Reef is a closely held investment concern based in Miami.

title: Take Another Look at Environmental Threats
description: To the Editor:

title: Isles' Arbour Named to Hall
description: Al Arbour, who coached the Islanders to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships in the 1980's, will be inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto on Nov. 25.

title: Net Off at General Mills; Cereal Prices Cited
description: General Mills Inc. said today that fiscal first-quarter earnings fell, as expected, because of lower breakfast cereal prices announced in June.

title: Giuliani Has Kemp to Dinner. Is It Just a Flirtation?
description: A remarkable thing happened last night on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's front porch. Without raising an eyebrow of protest -- in fact, while actually grinning -- the Mayor allowed a national political candidate to make a partisan statement at his side.

title: D.M.V. Secures Information
description: The State Division of Motor Vehicles, under pressure to keep information about drivers out of the hands of stalkers and other criminals, announced regulations yesterday to make records harder to get. Access will be limited to people with good reasons for requesting it -- an employer checking on a job applicant, for example, or a driver seeking information about the other party in an auto accident.

title: Morris and Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Drugs Surge as Campaign Issue, But All the Talk Clarifies Little
description: Shortly after he took office in 1993, President Clinton gutted the drug policy staff that he inherited from President George Bush, cutting it to 25 employees from 146, to fulfill his campaign pledge to run a smaller White House.

title: Fierce Debate Erupts Over Degree of Peril Facing Ocean Species
description: FOR the first time, some scientists are saying that some species of ocean fish and invertebrates are reaching the perilously low levels where extinction becomes a real possibility. Their contention is prompting a fierce scientific debate, which could intensify with the addition next month of more than 100 species of oceanic fish to the World Conservation Union's influential ''red list'' of creatures whose existence is in some degree endangered.

title: Patrols to Fight Anti-Semitic Graffiti
description: The authorities promised stepped-up police patrols here today after anti-Semitic messages were scrawled on two homes in a Jewish neighborhood over the weekend, just as the High Holy Days were beginning.

title: Intel Sees Revenues Climbing, Sign of a Spurt for PC Growth
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it expected third-quarter revenues to be above previous estimates, sending Wall Street a strong signal that personal computer sales had entered a new growth spurt.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: 'Truth' Is Not Stranger Than Fiction: It Is Fiction
description: Who was it who cautioned, believe half of what you see and none of what you hear? If the dispenser of that advice were to see Russ Hexter's ''Dadetown,'' the cynic would be entitled to a good I-told-you-so chortle.

title: American Express Scrambles to Remake Its Credit Unit
description: The American Express Company is doing just what it said it would to reclaim the glory days of its card business -- but that may not be enough.

title: Family Planning Aid Is Worth Our Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: A Closer Look at 'Ellen'
description: When ''Ellen'' makes its third-season debut tonight, the ABC sitcom is likely to get much closer scrutiny than usual. Viewers will be looking for some indication of whether the show's lead character, Ellen Morgan, played by Ellen DeGeneres, is going to become a lesbian.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: White House Acts to Deflect Criticism of Its Iraq Policy
description: President Clinton defended his actions against Iraq today and vowed to continue taking steps ''to keep Saddam Hussein in a box,'' moving on several fronts to quell grumbling by Republicans in Congress that the United States had not done enough and to rally support among allies concerned that it had done too much.

title: Zaire Struggles to Keep Neglected Region in Fold
description: Ask nearly anyone in this scruffy mining town for an explanation of the hardships residents here have had to endure through 36 years of independence, and the answer is likely to be something like: ''making things difficult for us is the policy of Zaire.''

title: People
description: Susan Mendelsohn was named strategic planning director at Griffin Bacal, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group. She had been associate director for worldwide consumer research at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, part of the MacManus Group.

title: Happy New Year?
description: It's a dirty job, but some Jew's got to do it.

title: Fixing the Presidential Debates
description: The Commission on Presidential Debates was established in the late 1980's as a nonpartisan group with the sole purpose of sponsoring debates among the major Presidential candidates. But by deciding yesterday to exclude Ross Perot from this year's debates, the commission proved itself to be a tool of the two dominant parties rather than a guardian of the public interest. This commission has no legal standing to monopolize debates, and it is time for some more fair-minded group to get into the business of sponsoring these important events.

title: NORWEST EXPANDING INTO TEXAS WITH ACQUISITION
description: The Norwest Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Central Bancorporation, the largest bank in the Dallas-Fort Worth region and fourth-largest in Texas. The closely held Central Bancorporation, based in Fort Worth, has $1.1 billion in assets and operates 24 branches through its Central Bank and Trust subsidiary. Norwest, based in Minneapolis and the 12th-largest bank in the United States with $77.8 billion in assets, has expanded its banking, investments and insurance franchise in the Midwest. It set its sights on Texas in the last year as part of its national expansion plans. Norwest's shares fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $39.625. The price of the purchase was not disclosed.

title: Philharmonic Appoints Its New Chairman
description: Paul B. Guenther, the former president of the Paine Webber Group, was appointed chairman of the New York Philharmonic at a board meeting yesterday, the orchestra announced. Mr. Guenther, 56, joined the board in 1994 and has been on its finance and development committees. He succeeds Stephen Stamas, who gave up the unsalaried post in June after seven years.

title: Tribute to Martha Hill
description: Dancers from the companies of Jose Limon, Martha Graham and Paul Taylor will perform with dancers and choreographers from the Juilliard School in a tribute to Martha Hill on Sept. 30 at 6:30 P.M. at the Juilliard Theater. Ms. Hill, who died last year, was the founding director of the dance division at Juilliard and a leading figure in modern dance and dance education. A photo exhibition and symposium on Ms. Hill's life are scheduled for that day at the school. All events are free; remaining tickets will be available on a standby basis from 6 P.M. on that day. Information: (212) 769-7406.

title: A New and Needed National Monument
description: President Clinton is expected today to invoke a 1906 law known as the Antiquities Act to set aside 1.8 million acres of southeastern Utah's splendid canyonlands as a national monument, thus placing the area off limits to development. There is an element of politics here. The President is actively if belatedly polishing his credentials with environmentalists, a constituency Bob Dole has largely ignored. Still, this is a bold and praiseworthy move that at one stroke should neutralize both the Utah Congressional delegation and a big European mining company whose commercial ambitions threaten an irreplaceable wilderness.

title: Memorabilia Goes on Sale for $40 Million
description: For 50 years, Barry Halper has built a baseball memorabilia empire so vast that his 984 historic uniforms move on dry cleaning racks for viewing in his New Jersey house. He has tens of thousands of items, including a baseball signed by Joe and Norma Jean DiMaggio, the contract that sold Babe Ruth from the Red Sox to the Yankees, an autographed 1936 Lou Gehrig uniform, two rare Honus Wagner tobacco cards and Shoeless Joe Jackson's 1919 White Sox uniform.

title: For the Panel, The Debate Is Over Scope
description: From its creation nearly a decade ago, the Commission on Presidential Debates has been involved in a debate of its own about whether to include third-party candidates.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday, about several banking mergers including the proposed acquisition of First Federal Bancshares of Eau Claire Inc. by the Mutual Savings Bank of Milwaukee, referred incorrectly in some editions to Mutual Savings' shares. The stock is not publicly traded; the price given was for the Mutual Savings Bank of Bay City, Mich.

title: Simpson's Civil Trial Opens on Tight Rein
description: Signaling that he would run a tougher courtroom than his criminal trial predecessor, a Santa Monica judge opened O. J. Simpson's civil trial today with several rulings crimping the defense strategies that helped win Mr. Simpson an acquittal last year.

title: Personal Health
description: MANY dog lovers act on impulse when they acquire canine companions. They may find an appealing stray on the street and take it in ''temporarily.'' Or they may fall in love with an adorable puppy in the local pound or pet store. Either way, little thought is given to the nature of the beast and how well it will fit into the household and lives of its owners.

title: An Amnesty In Cambodia
description: ''Do I have remorse? No,'' said Ieng Sary, the breakaway Khmer Rouge leader who is implicated in the killings of huge numbers of his fellow Cambodians in the 1970's. ''I have no regrets because this was not my responsibility.''

title: Irving J. Lewis, 78, An Expert on Policy For Public Health
description: Irving J. Lewis, an expert in public health policy who became a professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 78.

title: A Dance Festival Marches to a Different Drummer
description: Famous in France for being undemonstrative, aloof and even a tad stuffy, the people of Lyons were struck by a tropical storm this weekend in the form of 550 Brazilians who landed here for the seventh Lyons Dance Biennial. In no time, the Brazilians brought carnival to the streets of this city and had over 100,000 local people jumping, clapping and singing as if it were second nature.

title: Lottery Executive on Trial
description: Opening statements began yesterday in the Federal trial of a former lottery company executive who is accused of defrauding his employer by taking kickbacks from a New Jersey consulting firm.

title: Shanghai Eases Rules For Foreign Investment
description: The municipal government of Shanghai, aiming to stimulate foreign investment, introduced rules that will cut the time for overseas projects to obtain approval. The rules, will be effective on Oct. 1.

title: Experts Are at Odds on How Best to Tackle Rise in Teen-Agers' Drug Use
description: As drug use among teen-agers begins to rise sharply after years of decline, experts in drug abuse say there is an opportunity to halt the incipient epidemic in its tracks. But they disagree on the right remedy.

title: Emmerling Post Expands Operations
description: Emmerling Post Advertising in New York said yesterday that it had acquired an agency in Rochester and started a public relations division.

title: Courts, Not Congress, Will Protect Gay Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER
description: In Search of a Life

title: No Headline
description: ''Participation is not extended to candidates because they might prove interesting or entertaining.''

title: How Schedule Has Worked Elsewhere
description: As he seeks to test a year-round calendar in at least one New York City school district next year, Chancellor Rudy Crew can look to any number of examples nationwide: 2,368 schools, in 39 states, have already adopted a similar schedule, most within the last decade, according to the National Association for Year-Round Education.

title: Criticized for Casting Votes, and for Not Voting at All
description: BACKGROUND: The Republican National Committee started broadcasting this 30-second commercial on Friday in the New Jersey area, where Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, is facing a Republican Congressman, Richard A. Zimmer, for an open Senate seat. Called ''More,'' this spot is an example of ''issue oriented'' advertising. To prevent the cost of the ad from counting against the federally imposed limit on the amount of money the national party can donate to Mr. Zimmer's campaign, the commercial makes no mention of an election or of Mr. Zimmer. The Republican Party officially describes the ad as party-building and educational, even though it just happens to attack the Democratic candidate in the weeks leading up to Election Day.

title: Wine Talk
description: IN this country, any list of recommended white wines could easily begin and end with chardonnay. America's infatuation with the chardonnay grape has to be one of the great love stories of the late 20th century. Last year, California shipped 21.1 million cases of chardonnay. The nearest contender among white wines was sauvignon blanc, at 5.4 million cases. The leading red was cabernet sauvignon, with only 10 million cases. Merlot, a current darling, came to 3.8 million cases.

title: Today's Fish: Straight From The Farm
description: CAN the day be far off when diners speak lovingly of fish that swim freely in the sea, just as they do now of free-range chickens?

title: Doctors Said Stop, but Anderson Said Go
description: Rafael Palmeiro was asked if he thought his Baltimore teammate Brady Anderson was crazy.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: U.S. Policy on Iran Must Address Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Denies Tribal Status, Foiling Plans For a Casino
description: An Indian tribe that had sued to reclaim what it says are tribal lands in downtown Bridgeport and surrounding suburbs has been denied Federal recognition by the Department of the Interior.

title: Three More Years for Stockton
description: JOHN STOCKTON has agreed to sign a three-year, $15 million contract with the Utah Jazz. Stockton is to sign the contract when he arrives in Utah for the start of training on Oct. 5.

title: Giant Squash Turns Briefly Into Belle of the Harvest Ball
description: THIS is tennerumi time, that brief season when the long green runners of the cucuzze squash -- and the squash itself -- come to market. Or at least to the two New York City Greenmarkets where Ken Migliorelli, as in years past, is selling them.

title: Report Sets Off Questions On Police Patrol Strength
description: Among the least welcome duties that nearly all New York City police commanders face is handling the inevitable complaints at neighborhood meetings that there are not enough uniformed police officers on the beat -- even in times like these when crime is declining.

title: Men Will Be Boys, And Slobs and Dogs
