description: With a title as juicy as ''Men Behaving Badly,'' you almost don't need a show to go with it. Fortunately, the series behind the title is a blithely funny and sharp, though often impolite, battle-of-the-sexes comedy.

title: Executive Changes
description: ITT HARTFORD GROUP INC., Hartford, promoted Ramani Ayer, who has been president and chief operating officer of the company's worldwide property-casualty operations since 1991, to chairman, president and chief executive, effective Feb. 1. The insurance company said Mr. Ayer would succeed Donald R. Frahm, who will retire effective Jan. 31. Mr. Frahm, who will be 65 in January, will continue as director. The company also named Lon A. Smith vice chairman, also effective Feb. 1. .

title: Making Ravioli As a Party Game
description: Making ravioli by hand is so tactile -- mixing and rolling the pasta, squeezing the filling from a pastry bag, running a rolling pin over the top of the molds -- that it fairly begs for a child's hands.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 7 about Rose Williams, sister of the playwright Tennessee Williams, misstated the year of her birth. It was 1909, not 1919.

title: Attack Ads in New Jersey Senate Race Tiptoe Around Campaign Spending Rules
description: The Republican National Committee is broadcasting advertisements denouncing Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for Senate in New Jersey, as ''liberal and wrong.'' The ads make no mention of the Republican candidate, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, or the November election, and that is no accident.

title: Spiro T. Agnew, Ex-Vice President, Dies at 77
description: Spiro T. Agnew, who was forced to resign as the 39th Vice President of the United States in 1973 when he pleaded no contest to a charge of income-tax evasion, died yesterday in Berlin, Md. He was 77 years old.

title: Dole Carries Crime Theme to a Tent Jail
description: Bob Dole brought the law-and-order theme of his Presidential campaign to the Arizona desert today, inspecting a field of 42 army surplus tents that serve as an outdoor jail run by a sheriff who has built a reputation on promoting chain gangs and prohibiting prisoners from partaking in cigarettes, coffee, hot lunches or pornography.

title: Push at Fed For Rate Rise Is Reported
description: A report that inflation hawks within the Federal Reserve are pressing for a rate increase took some of the wind out of the financial markets today and provided more evidence of the conflicting pressures buffeting the Fed as it prepares for a key policy-making meeting next Tuesday.

title: Food Notes
description: Just Like Mexico

title: EXISTING LEADERS OF ETHNIC GROUPS WIN BOSNIAN VOTE
description: Bosnian voters handed power to the existing leaders of the country's three major ethnic groups, election returns indicated tonight, giving the former enemies the task of cooperating in a three-member presidency to govern a restructured nation.

title: Market-in-a-Truck Goes to the Capital
description: On most Saturday mornings, two New Morning Farm trucks can be found parked in northwest Washington, with their owners, Jim Crawford and his wife, Moie Kimbal, urging browsers to shop.

title: Graham to Start for Cardinals
description: The Arizona Cardinals added another starting quarterback to the list yesterday when Coach VINCE TOBIN moved KENT GRAHAM to the first unit and dropped BOOMER ESIASON as the starter.

title: KIDS MART TO CLOSE 97 STORES AND REDUCE WORKERS
description: Kids Mart Inc. said yesterday that it would close 97 stores and cut an unspecified number of workers in an effort to reverse its losses. Another 10 stores, which sell infants' and children's apparel, could be added to the list of pending closures, Kids Mart said. Expenses from the cuts are expected to reduce its results by $5.4 million in the third quarter ending Oct. 31. Most of that expense is related to rents, closing costs and severance pay. Also, Kids Mart said it was seeking interim financing to buy inventory for the 1996 holiday season. The company, based in City of Industry, Calif., said it expects to violate some of its borrowing agreements and is seeking ways to refinance its debt.

title: Gore Brings Campaign Back to New York, and to the Usual Party Supporters
description: A midtown Manhattan skyscraper and a Government-subsidized housing development near Union Square provided the backdrops today for Vice President Al Gore as he campaigned before two groups that Democrats are counting on for major support in the Presidential election.

title: Don't Umps Check Out Forecasts?
description: ALL day long, the forecasters kept saying New York was in for a brutal night of wind and rain, but the news went right past the night watchman who runs baseball.

title: The Oedipus Message, Unvarnished, as It Used to Be
description: Like Christianity itself, ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' the reworking of Sophocles' ''Oedipus at Colonus'' as a Pentecostal church service, has spread from a humble beginning to institutionalization, along the way altering the delivery of its message, attracting a growing number of followers and occasionally claiming persecution (chiefly from critics).

title: DANCE
description: Growing Love Between Women,

title: Parole Fight in 1963 Murders
description: As a defense lawyer pleaded with an appeals court yesterday to free his client after 32 years in prison, Andrew Voto was outside the courthouse, exhorting about 30 police officers to continue a 16-year campaign against the convicted murderer, Thomas Trantino. Mr. Voto, the retired Lodi police chief, is the brother of a police sergeant, Peter Voto, who was killed along with a probationary patrolman, Gary Tedesco, by Mr. Trantino in 1963.

title: New York's Schools Are Planning a Test Of All-Year Classes
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that to cut class size in some schools, the Board of Education will begin testing a year-round school calendar in one of New York City's overcrowded districts next fall.

title: Pork, Mediterranean Style
description: Pork and potatoes with coriander and wine comes from the Mediterranean. Its richness is beautifully balanced by another Mediterranean-style dish: yogurt with carrots and cucumber.

title: Cosby Leads the Way
description: CBS had so much riding on Bill Cosby and his new comedy that the network's executives said they could not sleep Monday night just after the show had its premiere, because they were so anxious to find out how it fared in the ratings. After all, CBS, which has in recent years languished in prime-time ratings, had committed about $44 million to secure Mr. Cosby and had made his the lead-off show on Monday, the network's strongest night.

title: Term-Limits Ballot Proposal Shortened but Still Criticized
description: The organizers of a referendum that would alter New York City's term-limits law announced yesterday that they had shortened the ballot question in response to criticism that they had deliberately used complicated language to confuse people.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Germans Are Not So Quick To Judge 'Papa Merciless'
description: The windowless courtroom in Mannheim's State Courthouse seems an unlikely setting for drama. There is no live television. The accusations revolve around endless rows of figures. The prime celebrity who has delighted tennis crowds the world over is conspicuously absent.

title: Trainer Is Suing Tyson
description: KEVIN ROONEY, MIKE TYSON's former trainer, is suing the heavyweight for $10 million, alleging breach of contract. The suit was filed eight years ago, but jury selection didn't take place until yesterday in United States District Court in Albany. Opening arguments were scheduled for this morning.

title: G.O.P. Seems Ready to Drop Political Fight
description: House and Senate Republican leaders today appeared to be on the brink of dropping a controversial provision that has been the major stumbling block for a bill cracking down on illegal immigrants.

title: A Technology for the Virtual Marketplace
description: Electronic commerce on the Internet has not yet reached critical mass, and there is little wonder why. Finding, buying and paying for merchandise on the Internet without having to worry about theft or fraud is a complicated and convoluted process -- one that can sometimes make even the most determined shoppers weep. Some call it ''debt by a thousand clicks.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: Next stop for CONNIE CHUNG, the newswoman who was deposed as co-anchor of the CBS Evening News last year is Harvard University.

title: Agents Posing as 'Fences' Arrest 60 in Thefts of Cargo
description: In what they called their largest undercover operation to recover stolen property, F.B.I. officials said today that they had arrested more than 60 people and recovered $38 million in merchandise stolen from trucks and warehouses in the New York City region.

title: Feminist Awakenings
description: To the Editor:

title: North Koreans Slip Into South In Submarine
description: A group of North Korean troops landed on a South Korean beach, entering the country and setting off a vast manhunt, South Korean television reported this morning.

title: Joyner-Kersee Makes Switch
description: JACKIE JOYNER-KERSEE is switching from the heptathlon to basketball. The Olympic track and field great said yesterday that she signed a one-year contract with a one-year option with the Richmond Rage in the new all-women's American Basketball League.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: A Cart That Says, 'Attention, Shoppers'
description: THE Elon shopping cart is so perky that some people stop cart pushers on the street to ask where they can buy one. The lightweight, folding, two-wheel cart, made of plastic, has a mesh bag that can hold about four packed grocery bags -- or a week's worth of laundry. Closed, it can be carried like a handbag; opened, it is 35 inches high.

title: Milbury, at Impasse With Green, Is Weighing His Trade Options
description: After watching his offensively challenged team get shut out by the Devils in its first preseason game, 2-0, Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury went on the offensive himself after the game.

title: Officials Find Plenty of Blame to Cast in Fatal Siege in Borough Park
description: Police officials failed to inform the Brooklyn District Attorney's office last week that they were ending round-the-clock protection for an 18-year-old woman whose former boyfriend, after repeated attacks and threats, burst into her Borough Park home on Monday and killed her. Prosecutors said that if they had known the police protection was being removed, they would have taken emergency steps to relocate the woman for her safety.

title: Whack! Whack! Whack! Reborn Punch Pounded
description: Punch, the weekly magazine of satire, cartoons and reviews that was once a British cultural icon, has just been brought back from the dead. It has been greeted with a lively reaction that is just as rich a British tradition -- brisk expressions of disdain, scorn, derision, contempt and character assassination.

title: 3 Leaders of New Bosnia: Pulling in 3 Directions
description: Momcilo Krajisnik, an ethnic Serb, and Alija Izetbegovic, a Muslim, both powerful players in prewar Bosnian politics, once enjoyed a warm relationship.

title: C.R. BARD COMPLETES $143.2 MILLION ACQUISITION OF IMPRA
description: C. R. Bard Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Impra Inc., a maker of vascular grafts used for blood vessel replacement surgery, for $143.2 million. C. R. Bard, which is based in Murray Hill, N.J., said it planned to consolidate its current vascular graft product line with the Impra products and keep the new subsidiary, Bard Impra, in Tempe, Ariz. Impra, which is privately held, had sales of $48.8 million in its latest year. With 1995 sales of $1.1 billion, C. R. Bard develops and manufactures health care products.

title: SHARES OF SHOWBOAT RISE 12% AMID SPECULATION
description: The shares of Showboat Inc. rose 12 percent yesterday amid speculation that Kerry Packer, the Australian financier, might acquire a stake in Showboat, which owns part of a Sydney casino as well as casinos in Atlantic City and Las Vegas. Shares of Showboat, which owns a 26 percent stake in the Sydney Harbor Casino Ltd., rose $2.375, to close at $22.375. Showboat shares rose after Consolidated Press Holdings Ltd., Mr. Packer's private company, sold a 15 percent stake in a rival Australian casino operator, Crown Ltd., for the equivalent of $160 million. The move sparked speculation among investors that Mr. Packer might use the cash to buy either Sydney Harbor or invest in Showboat, which is based in Las Vegas.

title: Denver Extends Health Coverage to Partners of Gay City Employees
description: On Wednesday, Mayor Wellington Webb will sign an ordinance extending health insurance to gay partners of city workers in an action that will echo far beyond this city.

title: Wine Tasters, Yes. Wine Snobs, No.
description: AFTER nearly 15 years, the Boors are still going strong. In fact, the Bronx Order of Oenological Recidivists is stronger than ever. The club's core of 14 members has grown to 24, and they still gather six times a year without fail to celebrate the grape and punch holes in wine snobbery.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When RICHARD H. JENRETTE, the former chairman and chief executive of the Equitable Companies, made his first trip to Paris about 35 years ago, he retraced Thomas Jefferson's steps. He became fascinated with a building called the Hotel de Salm on the Left Bank, which Jefferson used as a model for Monticello.

title: Broadening 'Megan's Law'
description: A group of Republican lawmakers want to broaden ''Megan's Law'' by requiring convicted child molesters to take a lie test twice a year at their own expense.

title: Nascar Fines Three Drivers
description: The Nascar drivers JIMMY SPENCER, MICHAEL WALTRIP and KYLE PETTY were fined a total of $17,000 yesterday after nearly coming to blows in a race Sunday at Dover, Del.

title: City Business Districts Are Held to Account
description: To the Editor:

title: Gusty Wind and Heavy Rain Cut Power and Delay Flights
description: Gusty winds and heavy rain toppled trees and disabled electric wires throughout the region yesterday, resulting in power failures for thousands of people in Queens, Westchester County and on Long Island. The storms also delayed flights at all three major airports.

title: Hold Your Horses: Rain Washes Out a Showdown
description: The much-anticipated September showdown between the Yankees and the Orioles turned into a soggy sitdown after less than one exasperating inning last night. So much for the duel between David Cone and Mike Mussina. So much for George Steinbrenner's restraint.

title: THEATER
description: Night Is When the Nuts

title: Ex-Wives of the Rich and Famous See a Film and Pronounce It Fact
description: LAURA HUNT well remembers the times soon after she divorced Ward Hunt, a scion of the Texas Hunt dynasty. ''Friends would call and say: 'I feel so sorry for Ward. We had him over for dinner the other night, and he was so sad.' ''

title: Some companies are making it a lot easier to use a cellular telephone overseas.
description: EXECUTIVES accustomed to the convenience of using a cellular phone while traveling domestically now can easily do the same overseas.

title: Arrest in Deptford Mall Case
description: A Camden man wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a fatal shootout on Aug. 5 at the Deptford Mall was arrested last night in Brooklyn, The Associated Press reported.

title: Dangerous Heartbeats On Monday and Friday
description: DANGEROUS abnormalities in heart rhythm are more likely to occur on Mondays and Fridays than on other days of the week, scientists have concluded from a study of patients being treated for heart disease.

title: U.A.W.'s Pact At Ford Aims At Downsizing
description: The Ford Motor Company's new three-year labor contract with the United Automobile Workers union addresses two issues that have haunted organized labor for more than a decade: layoffs and moves by companies to rely more on outside suppliers.

title: Redefining Spending In Tight Senate Races
description: By not mentioning the Republican candidate in the New Jersey Senate race, ads assailing the Democratic candidate, Robert G. Torricelli, do not come under the spending limits set by the Federal Election Commission. Such advertising -- paid for by the national party -- have become common in tight Senate races throughout the nation.

title: To Contain Cow Disease, Swiss Plan to Destroy 230,000 Cattle
description: Seeking a decisive measure that will allay consumer concerns about the safety of Swiss beef, the Swiss authorities have announced plans to destroy 230,000 cattle, which would cut its national herd by one eighth.

title: INSIDE
description: Simpson Civil Trial Opens

title: Commercials but No Breaks
description: So just how do you broadcast an hour of commercial television without any commercial interruptions?

title: Oil Price Rebounds on Denial Of Plan for Saudi Output Rise
description: The price of crude oil rebounded yesterday from its biggest drop in more than four years on the New York Mercantile Exchange after the United States denied a report that it had asked Saudi Arabia to increase oil output.

title: David Beretta, 68; Served at Uniroyal As Chief Executive
description: David Beretta Jr., former chief executive of Uniroyal, the rubber and chemical products company, died on Monday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 68 and lived in Jamestown, R.I., near Newport.

title: Soon Brooklyn Union won't be just a staid utility investment.
description: SINCE it was founded a century ago, Brooklyn Union Gas has grown steadily as it focused on serving its 1.1 million customers in Brooklyn, Staten Island and Queens. The utility has raised its dividend in each of the last 19 years.

title: Morgan Stanley Closes a Private Fund at $800 Million
description: The Morgan Stanley Group is closing to further investment its Princes Gate Investors II L.P., a private equity partnership with $800 million in capital.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Hurricanes Suspend Safety
description: Miami Hurricanes safety TREMAIN MACK was suspended indefinitely yesterday and blamed a drinking problem for his sixth arrest in four years. Mack, honored Monday as Big East Conference defensive player of the week, was arrested last weekend and charged with driving under the influence of alcohol. It was his third alcohol-related arrest in two years.

title: DANCE
description: A Quiet Harmony

title: KANSAS CITY POWER SHAREHOLDERS REJECT MERGER
description: Shareholders of the Kansas City Power & Light Company rejected a proposal to buy Utilicorp United Inc., clearing the way for Western Resources Inc. to pursue its $1.9 billion plan to acquire Kansas City Power, according to results of the voting released yesterday. About 38 percent of Kansas City Power shareholders voted for the Utilicorp accord, Western Resources said, citing the count certified by an independent tabulator. The Utilicorp proposal needed a two-thirds approval to proceed. Almost 83 percent of Kansas City Power's shares were represented in the vote, and less than 46 percent of the shares were voted to approve the plan. If Western succeeds in acquiring Kansas City, it would be the first hostile takeover of an electric utility.

title: Army Moves By Syrians Leave Israel Guessing
description: The movement of crack Syrian commandos toward Israeli listening posts on Mount Hermon and other unusual Syrian military deployments in Lebanon in recent weeks have left Israel and the United States nervous and somewhat baffled.

title: Pistons Get a Bargain in Smith
description: KENNY SMITH, a nine-year N.B.A. veteran who was part of two championship teams with the Houston Rockets, signed a one-year contract with the Detroit Pistons yesterday.

title: With Little Fanfare and Facing Crisis, U.N. Starts a New Year
description: Its difficult 50th birthday party over, the United Nations opened the 51st session of the General Assembly today without ceremony, in financial crisis and with no idea who its Secretary General will be when this session ends on Dec. 23.

title: 2 Presidents At Shubert, But Just One Chairman
description: The board that oversees the largest theater chain on Broadway announced yesterday that it was dividing the two jobs that had been held by Bernard B. Jacobs, the powerful Shubert theater executive who died last month at the age of 80.

title: Dole Aide Has Part-Time Harvard Job
description: Sheila Burke, who was Bob Dole's chief of staff in his Senate office for the last decade, is now working part time at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard while continuing to work for Mr. Dole's Presidential campaign.

title: Entrepreneur Sets His Sights on Gingrich
description: In a year when candidates are wearing their biographies on their sleeves, none may have a more compelling story to tell than Michael J. Coles, the Georgia cookie entrepreneur who hopes to oust Speaker Newt Gingrich from the House of Representatives.

title: Clinton Announces Steps For More Portable Pensions
description: Finding campaign fodder in an arcane place, President Clinton today announced steps taken by the Treasury Department to enhance workers' ability to save for retirement even as they move between jobs.

title: New Needs of Society Bring Back A Medical Dinosaur: House Calls
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, a Manhattan resident called a doctor he did not know to say that he was worried about his 83-year-old homebound aunt. She had no doctor of her own (in fact she had not even seen a doctor in 40 years), but she had recently lost a lot of weight. Would he kindly make a house call?

title: THEATER
description: Bawdy Bits of Shakespeare

title: Ballet Master to Move
description: Terrence Orr, longtime ballet master at American Ballet Theater, has been appointed artistic director of the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, effective in September next year. Mr. Orr succeeds Patricia Wilde, who announced two years ago that she would retire in 1997.

title: No Place for Perot
description: Ross Perot played an important role in the 1992 Presidential debates, hammering relentlessly on the need to balance the budget and reduce the influence of lobbyists in government. But Mr. Perot is a different candidate in 1996. He is better known, but he also has less support. The Commission on Presidential Debates made the right decision yesterday in keeping him out of the debates this year.

title: WEATHERFORD ENTERRA PLANS TO SELL FOUR BUSINESSES
description: Weatherford Enterra Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its pipeline services, cranes, automatic welding and engineering services divisions for an undisclosed amount and use the proceeds to reduce debt. The Houston company said it would sell the four businesses because they are cyclical and have not been consistently strong performers. The divisions have annual revenue of $140 million. Weatherford Enterra officials declined to place a value on the divisions. The company's stock fell 75 cents yesterday, to $28.25.

title: Gene Nelson Is Dead at 76; Athletic Hollywood Dancer
description: Gene Nelson, who played Will Parker, the blond, boyish, high-stepping lasso dancer in the 1955 film version of ''Oklahoma!,'' died on Monday at a hospital in Calabasas, Calif. He was 76 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: 3DO SHARES FALL ANOTHER 15% AFTER ANALYST CUTS RATING
description: The shares of the 3DO Company fell another 15 percent yesterday to an all-time low after an analyst cut his rating on the company, which had announced plans to sell all or part of its video-game hardware unit. Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. analyst Steven L. Eskenazi cut the rating to ''buy'' from ''strong buy.'' Alex. Brown helped to underwrite the company's public offering in May 1993. 3DO shares fell $1, to $5.75, on trading of almost 1.8 million shares. The company, based in Redwood City, Calif., has lost 29 percent of its market value since saying on Monday that it planned to sell its hardware unit, or place it in a joint venture, by the end of the year. 3DO said it would cut 150 of its 450 jobs and focus on making entertainment software.

title: Take the Focus Off Gender Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: $75 Million in Casino Aid
description: Financial aid might seem like the last thing Atlantic City's booming gambling industry needs. Yet on Monday, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a measure that will set aside $75 million collected by the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority for the construction of new hotel rooms.

title: Hollywood and Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole's Tax Message Heard, Not Heeded, in Midwest City
description: Only a day after Bob Dole's ''Citizen's Ship'' had whisked the Republican Presidential candidate in and out of this once-battered industrial corner of Michigan, it seemed as if everyone in Saginaw had seen the image the Dole campaign wanted them to see: Mr. Dole, in a gesture of Reaganesque simplicity, holding a nickel aloft to symbolize how he would go about cutting the Federal budget.

title: SUNBEAM SECURES $500 MILLION CREDIT FACILITY
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said yesterday that it had secured a $500 million credit facility with 15 banks that would be used in the company's turnaround efforts. The company's chief executive, Albert J. Dunlap, said in a statement that the money would support plans to develop a growth strategy. The facility's agent is Chase Manhattan Bank. The other banks were not named. Sunbeam, a maker of blenders, toasters and other small appliances, has missed analysts' earnings forecasts for two years.

title: Clinton, in Midwest, Takes Page From Reagan's 'Morning in America' Drive
description: Eighteen months ago, President Clinton's election strategists sat down and studied Ronald Reagan's ''Morning in America'' campaign of 1984 to learn how one of the few recent incumbent Presidents to win a second term had used mood and imagery to sail to a landslide victory.

title: Large Drop in Violent Crime Is Reported
description: In a further confirmation that the nation's crime problem has begun to recede, the Department of Justice reported yesterday that violent crime fell more than 9 percent last year, a very large drop that criminologists consider statistically important.

title: A Poet Warns About a Waste Of Black Rage
description: TUPAC SHAKUR'S swaggering image, ''Thug Life'' tattoo and all, flickered on the muted television set near Umar Bin Hassan, who contemplated the electronic eternal flame of modern celebrity. Mr. Hassan, a poet, provided his own soundtrack to the quick cuts of slick gangsta rappers and ashen-faced fans.

title: Shades of Toulouse-Lautrec and Piaf
description: When Liliane Montevecchi swivels down the aisle of the Martin Kaufman Theater, flashing a saucy Cheshire cat smile, flirting with the audience and singing ''Je Cherche un Millionaire,'' she resuscitates an archetype that has never really gone out of style: the eternal gamin. To be sure, her version of that archetype is more hard-boiled material woman than dewy-eyed ingenue. But since Ms. Montevecchi is pushing 60, how could it be otherwise?

title: Pentagon Negligence
description: The Pentagon's commendably candid report on this summer's terrorist bombing in Saudi Arabia induces a disquieting sense of deja vu. Once again, the Defense Department has proved more adept at investigating its security lapses than in preventing them. Many lives would have been saved if the Pentagon had learned from its previous failures to safeguard American forces stationed in the Middle East, including the 1983 Marine barracks bombing in Beirut that killed 241 people.

title: Troubled Olivetti Sees Shares Tumble Again
description: The shares of Olivetti S.p.A. tumbled 10 percent again yesterday after Italian regulators demanded more information on the company's inventories, debts and credits. In a two-week-long investigation into the company's 440 billion lire ($293 million) first-half losses, Consob, the market regulator, asked Olivetti about 16 matters in its financial reports.

title: Too Crowded to Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: More Children Are Killed by Air Bags, and Parents Are Blamed
description: As passenger-side automobile air bags become more common, more children are being killed by them, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Princeton Among Sports Elite Too
description: In the academic year just beginning, the varsity teams from Princeton will be challenged to equal or exceed the record of their immediate predecessors. These won more championships than any other member had ever captured before in the 40-year history of the Ivy League and raised a question among the others -- how does Princeton do it?

title: Bonds Drop As Fed Rate Rise Is Feared
description: Bond investors reacted with alarm yesterday to a report that regional officials of the Federal Reserve were pushing for an increase in interest rates.

title: Inexorably Turning Foolish Good Into True Evil
description: A FRENCH TRAGEDY

title: Lunches Imported From Brooklyn Add Insult to Injury
description: All the frustration in this city over the state takeover of its troubled schools, all the resentment for the New Yorker hired to be superintendent and all the anger over the Superintendent's layoffs of hundreds of school employees this summer, came down to this in the first week of the school year:

title: Behind Dance Rhythms, A Cuban Sings the Blues
description: The singer Issac Delgado spent his second set at S.O.B.'s on Monday night singing three songs. The set lasted an hour. Mr. Delgado built the tunes out of fragments, singing chants that slowly changed and were sung back at him by his chorus. He motioned the band, Seis del Solar, to stop playing, and sang against the driving ostinatos of his pianist, Melon. He signaled the horns to play alone, and sang backed by drums, or the choir. Mr. Delgado improvised, but he also was thinking structurally: the compositions took on the narrative quality of suites, and their complexities as well.

title: Staying on Sidelines In Presidential Race, N.R.A. Snubs Dole
description: The National Rifle Association is not endorsing anyone for President this year, choosing to denounce President Clinton for his support of the ban on assault weapons and remain silent about Bob Dole, an erstwhile friend.

title: Holding The Bag In the Gulf
description: On ''Meet the Press'' on Sunday, House Speaker Newt Gingrich criticized the Clinton Administration for using $1.2 million cruise missiles ''to do $60,000 of damage in radar equipment that takes three days to fix.'' While it is debatable whether launching million-dollar cruise missiles at Iraqi targets is less cost-effective than dropping thousand-dollar bombs from million-dollar airplanes, Mr. Gingrich's specific criticism raised a more important issue: How much should the United States spend to protect its interests in the Persian Gulf?

title: Court Overturns Suspension of Bronx Student With Handgun
description: In a ruling that drew sharp criticism from city officials, a state appeals court said yesterday that a student should not have been suspended for carrying a loaded weapon to a Bronx school since the gun was found during an illegal search.

title: Three hotel projects are in the works for downtown Chicago, the first in five years.
description: AFTER a drought of almost five years in new hotel construction, downtown Chicago now has three projects under way.

title: After Bitter Debate, Amity on Way to Implement Welfare Law
description: While generally supporting the new welfare law, state officials asked Congress today to give them more latitude and a bit more money to care for poor people and create jobs for welfare recipients.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARC de COSTER, a luminary among the hair stylists of New York, and a tonsorial client, GRACE VANCE, took two strangers to lunch yesterday at the Carlyle. The purpose: to express their gratitude for good deeds.

title: Play in Rain? That's No Way to Run a Pennant Race
description: In an era when even the National Football League halts games because of menacing weather, the umpires decided to play a baseball game at Yankee Stadium last night. Their ball-strike and safe-out calls should never suffer from such highly questionable judgment.

title: Smashing Pumpkins, Changed and Charging
description: Billy Corgan of the Smashing Pumpkins apologized for ''the delay'' between the band's scheduled appearance at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on July 14, and the band's show there on Monday night. ''Not really our fault, but . . . ,'' he said with a shrug.

title: Italian Cooking In the Cornfields
description: Past rolling fields of corn, oats and soy beans, and 13 miles from the nearest stoplight, lies the anomaly of a new Italian restaurant in Scandinavian country. Terrace, Minn., 120 miles northwest of the Twin Cities, is the size of a rhubarb patch. It has a handful of houses, a historic mill, a repair shop and now the Terrace Store Company, which seats 72 -- more than triple the year-round population of 23.

title: After Years at DDB, GTE Is in Review
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it had begun a review on the bulk of its account, with billings estimated at $80 million.

title: Defense Gets 'E' for Effort and Exhaustion
description: In the 1980's, the Giants had enough top-rate linebackers to stock a league. There were Brad Van Pelt and Harry Carson, then Lawrence Taylor, then Carl Banks and Pepper Johnson.

title: Reeve Directing Film
description: Christopher Reeve's new career as a director began this week when he gathered Glenn Close, Whoopi Goldberg, Bridget Fonda, Robert Sean Leonard and David Strathairn for rehearsals for a movie he is directing for HBO.

title: Societe de Belgique Buying Tractebel Stake
description: Societe Generale de Belgique S.A., Belgium's biggest holding company, said yesterday that it was buying a 24.5 percent stake in Tractebel, a Belgian energy holding company, from the Groupe Bruxelles de Lambert S.A. unit Electrafina S.A. and Royale Belge S.A.

title: $3.1 Billion In Stock Bid by Funeral Chain For Prime Rival
description: Service Corporation International, the world's largest chain of funeral homes, announced a $3.1 billion stock offer yesterday for the Loewen Group, its prime domestic competitor.

title: Party Battle on Education Aid Takes Politics to Classrooms
description: Senate business stalled today for the second time in a week as Republicans tried to prevent Democrats from introducing a politically popular amendment, in this case to soften cuts in money for education.

title: Flood Relief for China
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep It Simple
description: When trying to assess the long-term implications of Saddam Hussein's recent ''victory'' in northern Iraq, keep in mind the following fact: The Kurds whom Saddam wooed away from the U.S., and forged a partnership with in an effort to reassert his authority in northern Iraq, are the same Kurds whom Saddam bombarded with mustard gas and cyanide in 1988. This is not a relationship with a long future. The relationship between Saddam and the Barzani Kurdish faction has about the same shelf life as an Elizabeth Taylor marriage.

title: An Even Faster Crowd Arrives at Las Vegas Speedway
description: From Ramses to Steve Wynn, the desert has always brought out man's urge to build monuments to himself. On the northern frontier of Las Vegas, the newest temple is rising: Richie Clyne's Las Vegas Motor Speedway.

title: No More of Tables for Two at the Top of the Sixes
description: One of New York City's quirkier culinary institutions died this week in a real estate transaction full of poignancy and paradox.

title: Indians Win Division For 2d Straight Year
description: Indians 9, White Sox 4

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Labor Contract Goes Against Big 3 Trend

title: Safety of Catheter Into the Heart Is Questioned, Startling Doctors
description: A standard procedure used more than a million times a year on seriously ill patients in this country offers no benefit and may kill some people, according to a new study that is causing consternation among many doctors.

title: Fans Keep Eye on the Sky
description: The forecast called for nonstop rain, but with the prospect of the first September to remember in years, no one riding the ferry from the South Street Seaport to Yankee Stadium last night was willing to take the chance that the Yankees-Orioles game just might go on.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SHOO HALE of Sandisfield, Mass., was walking along Central Park West when a city bus came to an unscheduled stop and double-parked, blocking a lane of traffic. The driver jumped out and hurried to the nearest telephone.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THEATER
description: These Puppets Make

title: TCI to Buy Jones Unit
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable system operator, has agreed to buy Jones Intercable Inc.'s Jones cable systems for an undisclosed amount of cash. TCI said it would acquire Jones Cable Income Fund 1-B/C venture, which serves customers in Colorado, and Jones Spacelink Fund 4 Ltd., which serves customers in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg, Tex.

title: Rap Star's Death Highlights Harsher Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Deutsche Telekom Says Profits Sagged
description: Deutsche Telekom, the German telecommunications giant, reported yesterday that its profit for the first half dropped 96 percent, mostly because of the costs of laying off workers. The company plans to lay off 60,000 in the next four years in preparation for privatization.

title: Mets Have Reason to Envy the Expos
description: The Mets hoped they would be what the Montreal Expos are, a young team with a low payroll playing a meaningful September with realistic hopes for post-season participation.

title: Sleeping, Fitfully, Where Lizzie Did
description: IT might have been the photographs of the skulls. Or the yellowed tag reading ''Mr. Borden's stomach.'' Or the red gobs on the tag that turned out to be sealing wax, not blood after all.

title: Time Warner Says Turner Will Run Cable Networks
description: Ted Turner now has a job description to go along with his vice chairman's title at Time Warner.

title: Panel on Debates Bars Perot, Calling Him Unelectable
description: The Commission on Presidential Debates announced today that it believed that Ross Perot had no realistic chance of winning the Presidential election and that he would therefore not be invited to join President Clinton and Bob Dole in this year's debates.

title: Jets May Be Encountering Right Foe at the Right Time
description: When will the wayward Jets finally break out the offense that seemed so intriguing before the season but so far has only disappointed the team's followers?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PATRIOT AMERICAN HOSPITALITY INC., Dallas, a real estate investment trust, said its joint venture with Doubletree Corp. of Phoenix had agreed to buy three Holiday Inn hotels in Tallahassee, Fla., Miami and Chicago for a total of $32 million.

title: Panels Moving to Bar Data Sampling for Census
description: Expressing concern about methodology and legality, two Congressional panels are moving to bar the Census Bureau from using statistical sampling to supplement the national head count in 2000.

title: New Software Aids Officials In Flagging Welfare Fraud
description: New computer software led officials to two welfare-fraud schemes in which low-level city employees helped obtain benefits for relatives and others, costing the city more than $120,000. Two city workers and 20 welfare recipients were accused in the schemes, in indictments unsealed yesterday.

title: No Interest Proves Costly
description: Two consumer electronics giants, Comp USA and Tandy (the parent company of Radio Shack), agreed to pay the state $25,000 each and to stop running ads claiming ''zero percent financing,'' the state Division of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: Merck & Co., Whitehouse Station, N.J., to Lowe Direct, New York, a unit of the Lowe Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle consumer direct marketing for Fosamax, a treatment for osteoporosis. Those duties had been handled by FCB Direct, New York, a unit of True North Communications. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Of Pumpkins and Parades
description: A Federal audit has found that city officials misspent or mismanaged about $2.2 million in Federal grants and housing funds, using some of the money to pay for Halloween pumpkins and Christmas parade floats, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Are Actors All Related? Or Is It Just Kevin Bacon?
description: Three years ago, three students at Albright College in Reading, Pa., were watching ''Footloose'' on television, and began naming dozens of other movies featuring the actor Kevin Bacon. On the spot, they decided that he was the center of the entertainment universe -- and the game was afoot.

title: Plane Hits Ocean; 2 Saved
description: The pilot and only passenger of a single-engine plane escaped serious injury yesterday afternoon when the aircraft skidded off a runway while trying to land at Bader Field Airport and plunged into the Atlantic Ocean, officials said. Police rescuers pulled the pair from the water, said Sgt. Ernest Jubilee of the Atlantic City Police.

title: SANTA FE ENERGY RESOURCES TO SPIN OFF DIVISION
description: Santa Fe Energy Resources Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell as much as 17 percent of its Monterey Resources unit to the public and spin off the rest to its shareholders. Monterey, based in Bakersfield, Calif., would assume substantially all the assets and liabilities of Santa Fe's Western division, which operates oilfields primarily in the San Joaquin Valley of California. The company expects to complete the spinoff by June 1997 and said it would use the proceeds to pay down debt. After the public offering of Monterey stock, Santa Fe plans to distribute its Monterey stock to Santa Fe shareholders.

title: Russia's Mir And a Shuttle Are Flawless In Space Link
description: The shuttle Atlantis and the Russian space station Mir completed a long orbital waltz last night by linking up high above Earth, a prelude to bringing home an American astronaut who has spent half a year aboard the Russian outpost.

title: Insider Muddle Seems Headed for the High Court
description: A group of 11 judges in the Midwest is being asked to decide whether it is legal to buy the stock of a takeover target with inside knowledge of a secret takeover offer, as long as that information did not come from the target itself.

title: Gun Decision Raises Furor In the Schools
description: Teachers, principals and school safety aides in New York City said yesterday that they would continue to search students aggressively for guns and other weapons, despite a state appeals court ruling this week that a 15-year-old student caught with a loaded gun should not have been suspended because he was searched illegally.

title: Perot's Loss of Debate Slot Is Democracy's Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARES OF RHODES DIVE ON REPORT OF ACQUISITION
description: The shares of Rhodes Inc. plunged yesterday after the Heilig-Meyers Company agreed to buy the Atlanta-based furniture company for about $69 million in stock and the assumption of $106 million in debt. Rhodes's shares fell $3.125, or 29 percent, to $7.50. Under the deal, Rhodes's shareholders will receive one Heilig-Meyers share for every two Rhodes shares. Rhodes has 9.15 million shares outstanding. Shares of Heilig-Meyers rose 87.5 cents, to $15.125. The acquisition would create a retail furniture company with 824 stores and annual sales of $1.5 billion.

title: On Tour With Spiro Agnew
description: Some of yesterday's obituaries about Spiro T. Agnew conveyed the impression that he was little more than a surrogate for Richard Nixon's darker instincts, giving outrageous voice to feelings that President Nixon shared but could not vent. They also left the impression that Mr. Agnew left no real mark on American political history.

title: Export Data Nudge Dow 11.47 Lower
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday for a second day as computer issues like Intel and Microsoft again reached record highs, helping offset weakness in machinery and retail shares.

title: Chief of McDonald's Defends Arch Deluxe to Franchisees
description: In an unusual move, the head of the McDonald's Corporation has sent a memorandum to the company's 2,700 United States franchisees defending the introduction of the Arch Deluxe, saying that the sandwich was ''never intended to be a silver bullet.''

title: PILL FOR ABORTION CLEARS BIG HURDLE TO ITS SALE IN U.S.
description: An abortion-inducing drug has cleared the last major obstacle to marketing in the United States by receiving conditional approval from the Food and Drug Administration, the drug's sponsor announced yesterday.

title: An Anchor and an Archway for Times Sq.
description: In the latest new development planned for the Times Square area, executives said yesterday that the northeast corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue would be anchored by a multiplex movie house, a huge phalanx of neon signs and a Las Vegas-theme restaurant, complete with entertainers but without the gambling.

title: A Dangerous Immigration Bill
description: As the White House and members of Congress make final decisions this week about a severely flawed immigration bill, they seem more concerned with protecting their political interests than the national interest. The bill should be killed.

title: New York Bond Act Stems Environmental Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets See Giants Game As the Biggest Test Yet
description: It's not for a playoff, or even bragging rights. It's to stay alive, to validate the 1996 Jets as something more than another team of failed promise.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Marlene Dietrich and Liberace made their London debuts at the Cafe de Paris on Coventry Street. Frank Sinatra and Noel Coward sang there, and Princess Margaret is said to have smoked in public for the first time there.

title: When Strategy Goes Awry: Orioles Can't Spell Relief
description: For much of the season, Davey Johnson did not have the luxury of a relief corps loaded with effective pitchers. But as corps members such as Armando Benitez and Alan Mills became healthy and effective, the Baltimore manager began using them freely. At times, he even had them relieve the Orioles' crack closer, Randy Myers, to hold a last-inning lead.

title: Size Is in the Eye of the Architect
description: MR. EXTRA-LARGE has done something very small for his first project in the United States.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Young Nomads Need Furniture With Legs ...
description: THEIR nests are empty, too.

title: World Bank Focusing on Areas Shunned by Western Business
description: The International Monetary Fund is likely to sell some of its gold reserves to finance two new initiatives to help the world's poorest countries, high-ranking officials of the agency said tonight.

title: Six Weeks Away
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Laidlaw Waste Units To Be Sold for $1.34 Billion

title: Reinventing a Home
description: To The Home Section:

title: Yankees' Small Ball Wins in a Big Way
description: Excuse the Yankees if their hitters feel a tad overlooked in their series with the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Times Books Head Leaving to Start a New Imprint
description: Peter Osnos, the head of Times Books and the publisher of Presidents from Clinton to Yeltsin, yesterday announced his resignation from the Random House imprint to work with the Twentieth Century Fund to create a new publishing line.

title: Money Matters to Miller
description: With Reggie Miller still unsigned, Donnie Walsh is not certain that a deal will be completed before the Indiana Pacers open training camp Oct. 4.

title: Regulators Turn Spotlight on Cybermoney
description: As concerns grow about electronic money laundering, cybercounterfeiting and bank runs on the Internet, regulators in the United States and around the world are scurrying to catch up with the rapid development of electronic money.

title: Shift That Male Image
description: To The Home Section:

title: CHRONICLE
description: CARL BERNSTEIN, the writer, had more than one reason to celebrate at a party given in his honor last night at Elaine's on the Upper East Side.

title: Worthy Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a bipartisan commission's decision to exclude Ross Perot from this year's Presidential election debates misidentified the newspaper whose Washington bureau chief declined to take part in a survey about Mr. Perot's electability. It is The Boston Globe, not a Baltimore paper.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: F.T.C. Adopts New Procedures to Speed Up Action
description: The Federal Trade Commission has approved new procedures designed to speed up agency trials and decisions in challenges to corporate mergers, in antitrust complaints and in consumer protection disputes.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL CHIEF EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: The struggling Federal-Mogul Corporation announced yesterday the resignation of its chairman and chief executive, Dennis J. Gormley, and said its 1996 earnings from operations would exceed last year's but would not match analysts' expectations of $1.24 a share. The company, which makes parts for the automotive, farm and construction industries, did not disclose the reason for Mr. Gormley's resignation. Roderick M. Hills, a director, will succeed Mr. Gormley as chairman. Robert S. Miller Jr., also a director, will serve as the acting chief executive and will lead the search for new chief executive. The company's stock rose $1.125 to close at $19.875.

title: U.S. Says Man Helped Brother Flee in Trade Center Bombing
description: The brother of one of the four men convicted of bombing the World Trade Center has been indicted on charges that he helped his brother flee the United States days after the 1993 terrorist attack, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: How One Small Ball Holds the Whole Universe
description: GOLF DREAMS

title: Kenneth Warren, 67, Tropical Disease Expert
description: Dr. Kenneth S. Warren, a former director of health sciences at the Rockefeller Foundation and a prominent researcher of tropical diseases, died yesterday at his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 67.

title: What It Was Like in Everest's Maw
description: Nature must abhor mountain climbers. What else can explain the beating it inflicts periodically on those with the audacity to challenge the elements way up there in the Himalayas?

title: G.O.P. Tries Hard to Win Black Votes, but Recent History Works Against It
description: In a number of ways, the Republican Party has sought to make this the year it would break the Democratic hammerlock on the votes of black Americans.

title: W. R. Grace-Fresenius Deal Is Cleared
description: Shareholders of W. R. Grace & Company and Fresenius USA Inc. have approved the $4.4 billion merger of their dialysis businesses to create Fresenius Medical Care A.G.

title: Should Journalists Be Perot Judges?
description: In delivering its verdict that Ross Perot could not win the election and thus should not be invited to this year's debates, the Commission on Presidential Debates said it relied in part on the ''professional opinions of the Washington bureau chiefs of major newspapers, news magazines and broadcast networks.''

title: Drugs, Glamour and Despair in 2 Films
description: Whether the films ''Pulp Fiction'' or ''Trainspotting'' glorify the use of drugs is finally in the eye of the beholder. Any movie that portrays sexy, rebellious characters acting out antisocial behavior risks glamorizing that behavior, no matter how disastrous the consequences. Both films show the risks and consequences of heroin use, but ''Trainspotting'' is far more explicit.

title: Latest Chapter in a Photographer's Worldwide Project
description: It's hard to get away from the guest list.

title: Troupe Emerges in Eclectic Identity
description: British ballet had two founding mothers: Ninette de Valois, who established what is now the Royal Ballet, and Marie Rambert, who in 1926 founded the Ballet Club, which became Ballet Rambert and then the Rambert Dance Company.

title: MetroStars Win Game and a Playoff Spot
description: The MetroStars achieved their main objective in the inaugural season in Major League Soccer tonight when they clinched a playoff berth by beating the Columbus Crew, 1-0.

title: The days of playing in the mud are over for the GMC Jimmy, whose image is being cleaned up.
description: STARTING Sunday, television viewers will see a fresh approach to selling the GMC Jimmy, a sport utility vehicle designed to attract upscale buyers.

title: South Koreans Hunt Last of Infiltrators From Sub
description: Thousands of South Korean troops backed by helicopters and tracker dogs searched a mountainous area today for the last survivors of a group of North Korean commandos who apparently sneaked into South Korea from a submarine before dawn on Wednesday.

title: Reeves vs. Kotite: The Outcome Will Be Most Unforgiving for One
description: A recipe to cook coaches, brought to you not by Martha Stewart but by the National Football League. Take two coaches, put them in the glaring heat of New York. Add media. Mix with $70 million worth of free agents and draft picks. Throw in one cup of attitude, especially for the coach who does not get along with management. Spice with a combined 0-6 record, let simmer.

title: Stop Laughing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Difference Is in the Flash
description: PETER MARINO, the Manhattan architect, has a signature style. It's opulent and spare -- and, invariably, the perfect shade of cream. What, then, separates two of his most recent designs -- the Giorgio Armani store, which opened last week, and the Valentino boutique, which opened on Tuesday. The stores are cater-corner, at 65th Street and Madison Avenue. Both incorporate limestone (on facade or floors) and cream-colored interiors. The difference is that old intangible: sex appeal. ''Armani's is tranquil and calm, but Valentino's is sexier and glamorous,'' said Mr. Marino, below left, with Valentino.

title: Underdog Gators Shoot Off Their Mouths
description: Are the Florida Gators forfeiting their edge?

title: De La Hoya Fight Postponed
description: OSCAR DE LA HOYA's defense of his World Boxing Council superlightweight title will be postponed because he has tendinitis in his left shoulder. TODD DUBOEF, a spokesman for the promoter, Top Rank, said yesterday that the Oct. 12 fight with MIGUEL ANGEL GONZALEZ would probably be delayed until January. (AP)

title: After 44 Years, a Chain-Gang Fugitive Is Told He Can Stop Running
description: Eddie Brown began running in a Florida swamp in 1952, and yesterday, in a Brooklyn courtroom, he reached his goal: freedom.

title: Four A's Applauds Pataki Tax Decision
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies is hailing a decision by Gov. George E. Pataki of New York to sign legislation that will modify and eventually eliminate a ''vice presidents'' tax, which affects agencies as well as the securities and insurance industries.

title: The Fed Should Keep Its Head
description: How low would inflation have to be to calm the economic doomsayers? Right now, it is virtually zero. Consumer prices rose by a mere one-tenth of 1 percent last month, and producer prices are practically unchanged. Nevertheless, inflation hawks at the Federal Reserve are pressing for a rise in the most basic short-term interest rate when a Fed policy-making group meets on Tuesday.

title: In T.W.A. 800 Crash, Don't Discount Meteor
description: To the Editor:

title: GLIMCHER REALTY TRUST GETS $1 BILLION INVESTMENT
description: Glimcher Realty Trust said yesterday that it would build four shopping malls, using $1 billion in financing from the Nomura Asset Corporation, the United States unit of the Nomura Securities Company. Glimcher plans to open malls in Kansas City, Mo., in 1997; in Elizabeth, N.J., in 1998, and in Los Angeles and Carson, Calif., in 1999. The real estate investment trust, based in Columbus, Ohio, said Nomura would provide as much as $135 million of equity in the projects. The rest of Nomura's investment will include mortgage and construction loans. Glimcher said it expected to arrange another $750 million in financing. The company plans to develop, lease and manage each property.

title: 1991 BLAST IN IRAQ MAY HAVE EXPOSED 5,000 G.I.'S TO GAS
description: The Defense Department announced tonight that more than 5,000 American troops might have been exposed to deadly chemical weapons when a battalion of American soldiers blew up an Iraqi ammunition depot days after the end of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Weekend of Rallies and Rebirths
description: The events of last weekend in golf illustrated many of the abiding truths of the game, particularly the immutable one about never, ever counting anyone out until the final hole is played.

title: Allied Agrees to Purchase Laidlaw's Waste Operation
description: Furthering a wave of consolidation in the solid waste management business, Allied Waste Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the solid waste management operations of Laidlaw Inc. for $1.34 billion in cash and stock.

title: Accounts
description: Omnipoint Communications, Mountain Lakes, N.J., to Grace & Rothschild, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the personal communications company. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Ticket Plan for Rainout Fans
description: The Yankees, who lost a lucrative date at the gate in the wake of Tuesday night's rainout, announced plans yesterday for those ticket-holders who lost out as well.

title: Week After a 'Mild' Hurricane, Hard Times Remain in Parts of Puerto Rico
description: The waters have receded and the bodies have been buried, yet neighbors here are still coming to see the house where a river claimed four members of the same family.

title: Takeover Fight for Mobile Home Operator Intensifies
description: Chateau Properties Inc., an operator of mobile home parks that has been the unlikely object of an intense takeover fight, yesterday rejected two unsolicited bids and said it had slightly altered the merger agreement it already had with ROC Communities Inc.

title: Fund Manager Dismissed By Morgan Grenfell
description: Morgan Grenfell Asset Management said yesterday that it had dismissed a fund manager, Peter Young, for ''gross misconduct'' amid an investigation into improper trading in three mutual funds. Mr. Young, 38, was suspended after the company, a subsidiary of Deutsche Bank A.G., froze trading in three funds two weeks ago because of questions about the value of certain unlisted securities.

title: Payne Attacks Media Coverage
description: BILLY PAYNE spoke out yesterday about the Atlanta Games and criticized the coverage provided by some of the news media. ''These were the greatest Games,'' said Payne, the chief organizer, in a speech to Atlanta's business community.

title: Torre Knows 'Small Print' Of the Job
description: IN 1976 Joe Torre would hit .306 as the Mets' third baseman, but late that season Joe McDonald, then the Mets' general manager, took him aside to ask a question.

title: Jacques Minkus, 94, Dies; Brought Stamps to Masses
description: Jacques Minkus, the Polish-born entrepreneur who gave the once-patrician hobby of stamp collecting its mass-market reach, died on Tuesday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 94 and had operated his stamp shop, the nation's largest, at the old Gimbels department store for more than 50 years.

title: Torrent at Stadium Shows Cracks Above
description: With one of the largest turnouts at Yankee Stadium this year on hand for what turned out to be a rainout Tuesday night, a section of the stadium's roof was leaking so badly that water cascaded like a waterfall, tumbling over the edge of the upper deck onto a concrete walkway and on down upon a back row of premium seats near the field.

title: Bridge
description: The oldest person in the world to acquire a first computer and put it to serious use may be Muriel Brigham of Newport, Wash. She is believed to be the oldest game director in the world, and she recently introduced computer scoring into her weekly duplicate. Last week she celebrated her 98th birthday by playing bridge in a game held in her honor, and the president of the American Contract Bridge League, Dudley Brown of Grandview, Wash., drove 500 miles to be her partner.

title: A New Method of Internet Sabotage Is Spreading
description: A new type of Internet sabotage reported recently by a small New York-based service provider is spreading and has now occurred at least a dozen other World Wide Web sites around the nation.

title: Kuwaitis Seek to Sell Allies on U.S. Buildup
description: With more American troops and military hardware headed here, Kuwait is trying to persuade its skeptical Persian Gulf neighbors that there is cause for the latest United States buildup aimed at Iraq.

title: Where to Find It
description: JUST as with unhappy families, unhappy sofas and chairs may need a little therapy. The person to call is a furniture restorer, who can reglue a side chair, remove cat scratchings from a table leg, reproduce missing marquetry from vintage woods or even rebuild joinery as it was done centuries ago.

title: After 10 Innings, Breathing Room for Yanks
description: Real baseball returned to Yankee Stadium last night after a controversial hiatus because of wet weather, and the Yankees and Orioles played the intense game everyone expected to see on Tuesday night. It took an extra day for the September showdown to begin, but the delay was worth the wait.

title: Photo Error Is Blamed For Defeat In Primary
description: All newspapers make mistakes at times, and apologize for them, but the correction and apology that The Star Tribune of Minneapolis put out after a computer glitch placed a picture of John Derus in the wrong article last week on the day of a primary election is not good enough for Gov. Arne Carlson of Minnesota. He thinks The Star Tribune should pay for a new election.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Purchase Planned In France by Cordiant
description: Cordiant P.L.C. in London, which owns agencies including Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Bates Worldwide, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the remaining 47 percent of the French operations of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising that it did not already own. The interest in the French agency, with offices in Paris, is being acquired from current and former employees and directors for $33.2 million. Nicolas Moniaux will continue as chairman.

title: FIELDCREST CANNON STOCK DROPS ON EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: The shares of Fieldcrest Cannon Inc. fell 12 percent yesterday after the company, a textile concern, said it expected third-quarter earnings to drop because of reduced sales and the closings of two plants. Shares fell $2.25, to $16. The company, which makes towels, blankets and furniture coverings, operating results to range between a break-even level and a loss of 25 cents a share. Last year, the company, based in Eden N.C., earned $4.7 million, or 40 cents, for the quarter. After charges, the company had a loss of 13 cents in the comparable 1995 quarter. The average estimate of six analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for 48 cents a share in the quarter.

title: Sundstrom Is Eager to Start, But Rangers Get Out of the Blocks Slowly
description: It took only a week for Niklas Sundstrom to come down from the high of the World Cup. There was a trip home to Sweden, a visit with a few friends and then it was back to work.

title: Christopher Sees U.S. Exit From Bosnia On Schedule
description: Declaring the elections in Bosnia ''a major victory for the democratic process,'' Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that the United States would now be able to withdraw its peacekeeping troops from Bosnia by the end of the year as President Clinton promised.

title: No Headline
description: ''She says she wants to eat junk food and drink diet Cokes and be cross at us. She said it's a lot of work to stay in a good mood all the time.''

title: Tinton Falls Murder on TV
description: Last night's episode of the television series ''Law & Order'' borrowed heavily from a carjacking and the murder last March of Kathleen Weinstein, a special education teacher from Tinton Falls. The victim in the episode is also a teacher, and her taped conversation with her assailant leads to his arrest.

title: Panel's Report On Dismissals Is Released; Dispute Stays
description: Republicans and Democrats on the House committee investigating the White House's dismissal of seven travel office employees traded bitter accusations of partisanship today as the panel formally released a report that concluded that President Clinton had misused his office and improperly forced the dismissal of the travel staff three years ago.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Bee Gees, Enshrined

title: Transit Union Agrees to Allow Workfare Plan
description: Leaders of New York City's transit workers' union agreed yesterday to let thousands of welfare recipients clean subways and buses, in return for a guarantee that no union workers would be laid off through 1999. The deal, officials said, would produce cost savings and a transit system cleaner than it has been in generations.

title: Misgivings Over a Media Merger
description: The Federal Trade Commission's approval of the acquisition of Turner Broadcasting by Time Warner will offer consumers no major benefit and could in fact harm them. Under narrow antitrust law, the commission may have had little choice but to approve the takeover. That is unfortunate, because the merger might well lead to higher cable prices and a smaller choice of programs.

title: Lush Odes to the Art Of Two Film Makers
description: Who is Richard Robbins? On Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, a packed house paid as much as $500 a seat for a performance that consisted mostly of his music. Chances are that most spectators hadn't even heard of him before. They had, however, heard of Hugh Grant, Sharon Stone, Vanessa Redgrave, Christopher Reeve, Goldie Hawn, Joanne Woodward and Jeanne Moreau, who spoke and read between compositions.

title: Fuel Tank Crucial to All Crash Theories
description: No matter which theory they pursue, investigators looking for the cause of the explosion that destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800 cannot get away from the giant jet's center fuel tank.

title: A Hankering for Home
description: When she gets back home and back in shape, Dr. Shannon W. Lucid, a 53-year-old biochemist who has been in space longer than any other American and longer than any woman of any nation, plans to ride her bike, visit a bookstore and go rollerblading with her daughter.

title: Islanders and Palffy Close on Contract
description: ZIGMUND PALFFY, a restricted free agent, appears close to a new contract agreement with the Islanders. ''I'm optimistic,'' PAUL KRAUS, Palffy's agent, said yesterday from Edmonton, Alberta. ''There is reason to believe when we're talking.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: House Set for Abortion Vote Amid a Furor Over Just How Rare a Late-Term Method Is
description: On the eve of a hotly contested House vote to enact a ban on a kind of late-term abortion, advocates on each side today held dueling news conferences, previewed new television advertisements and predicted that the issue would be decided by a handful of votes.

title: New Focus on Malfunctions In Inquiry on T.W.A. Crash
description: Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board, saying they are convinced that none of the physical evidence recovered from T.W.A. Flight 800 proves that a bomb brought down the plane, plan tests intended to show that the explosion could have been caused by a mechanical failure alone.

title: Saddam Hussein Plays the Odds
description: Early in his presidency, Saddam Hussein summoned an auditorium full of senior Baath Party officials to deliver his glowing assessment of the military's performance in the first year of the war against Iran.

title: Yankee Stadium Fans Get No Rain Check From Roof
description: The raindrops falling on the heads of Yankees fans on Tuesday night were not just coming from the skies. A section of the stadium's roof was leaking so badly that water cascaded like a waterfall, tumbling over the edge of the upper deck onto a concrete walkway and on down upon a back row of premium seats near the field.

title: A Mahler Who Roars and Swirls
description: ''Soviet musicians and music lovers are wildly enthusiastic about Mahler's works,'' Dmitri Shostakovich wrote in 1964.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONSOLIDATED STORES CORP., Columbus, Ohio, a toy and close-out merchandise retailer, received $29.7 million from Melville Corp. as a price adjustment on Consolidated's purchase of Kay-Bee Toys. The final purchase price of the toy retailer was $285.3 million.

title: When Life Turns Goofy, Glamour Is a Real Asset
description: In the first episode of ''Suddenly Susan,'' Brooke Shields smokes a cigar, sings karaoke, slides to the floor behind a bar and accidentally clobbers herself on the head with her television's remote control. She relies on an ancient concept: a glamorous woman taking a pratfall is inherently funny. Ms. Shields is no Carole Lombard, but she reveals a genuine flair for physical comedy and a game attitude. Now all she needs is a character and a show to go with them.

title: These Handles Are Handled With Care
description: DOORKNOBS and drawer pulls can be both ornamental and functional, particularly those made of handblown glass or sculptured metal. Several years ago, Carl Martinez, who was an apprentice to Ted Muehling, the Manhattan jewelry designer, was in Rome, where he saw centuries-old Venetian glass knobs and chandeliers. He started designing his own hardware last year, and it is now being introduced. In the designs, the technique is ancient, the silhouettes modern. ''I always gravitate to utter simplicity,'' said Mr. Martinez, 34, who lives in Manhattan.

title: One Hero's Pretending, the Other's Just Acting
description: Enough already of the one-liner zapping. The new season switches tonight from its sitcom glut to two hourlong dramas. NBC gives ''The Pretender,'' which will settle into a Saturday-at-9 slot, a send-off in the Thursday-at-10 slot normally occupied by the ultra-successful ''E.R.'' And CBS, not overburdened with ultra-successful series, is bringing ''Moloney'' straight into what the network hopes will be a long run on Thursdays at 9. Hope, of course, springs eternal in television land.

title: The Owner Gives Torre A Vote of Confidence
description: George Steinbrenner asked reporters to gather round in the clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, before last night's 3-2 victory in 10 innings over the Baltimore Orioles, and then made the stunning and amusing announcement that Joe Torre would return as the Yankees' manager in 1997.

title: Weekend Heartbeats
description: To the Editor:

title: British Airways to Cut 10% of Its Work Force
description: British Airways P.L.C. intends to cut 5,000 jobs in Britain as part of a $1.55 billion reorganization, its chief executive said yesterday. The cuts represent about 10 percent of the airline's work force. The carrier's chief executive, Bob Ayling, said that the company hoped to make the cuts in 18 months largely through retirement and voluntary resignation. They will be widespread, from pilots to ground crews.

title: Democrats Press Ethics Panel to Release Report on Gingrich
description: House Democrats moved today to force the ethics committee to release its counsel's report on complaints about Speaker Newt Gingrich, and to make Republicans in shaky races risk accusations of a cover-up if they vote to keep it secret.

title: Abortion Lobbyists Battle
description: On the eve of a House vote on enforcing a ban on a form of late-term abortion, lobbyists are waging tough public campaigns. Page B12.

title: PEROT DENOUNCES SET-UP OF DEBATES
description: Ross Perot today denounced the decision to exclude him from Presidential debates as ''a blatant display of power by the Republicans and the large donors who fund their campaigns.''

title: Asian Sexuality
description: To The Home Section:

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Shifting Gears, Beijing Reins In Anti-Japanese Campaign
description: After months of whipping up nationalist sentiment against Japan, Britain and the United States, China's Communist Party leadership suddenly seems to have realized that nationalism could spin out of control.

title: Democrats Fight Hard In Key Midwest Races
description: In their first two debates here this week, Senator Paul Wellstone repeatedly called his Republican opponent, former Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a ''cheerleader for the Gingrich agenda.''

title: Spiro T. Agnew, Point Man for Nixon Who Resigned Vice Presidency, Dies at 77
description: Spiro T. Agnew, the tart-tongued political combatant who fired up the American electorate but then had to resign as Richard M. Nixon's Vice President in the face of a kickback scandal, died on Tuesday at the age of 77.

title: Narrow Range For Bonds On Rate Fears
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed but stayed in a narrow range yesterday, as the market continued to be weighed down by concerns of an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.

title: Panthers' Collins Out With Injury
description: Four days before the biggest game in the franchise's brief history, the Carolina Panthers learned yesterday that KERRY COLLINS won't be their starting quarterback because of an injury.

title: Thousands of Gulf Fish Die; Red Tide Is Probable Cause
description: Tens of thousands of dead fish have been washing ashore on Mustang Island near the Texas Gulf Coast, the apparent victims of red tide.

title: Low Inventories Of Heating Oil Signal Higher Prices Ahead
description: Consumers in the Northeast could see heating-oil prices soar further -- especially if there is an unusually cold winter -- because inventories are extremely low.

title: Root, Root, Root for What Home Team?
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Spiro Agnew Dead at 77

title: Officer Wins, Mayor Quits
description: Mayor Robert W. Shoey of Matawan resigned in protest Tuesday, when the Borough Council voted to settle a discrimination lawsuit. The Council, which the Mayor described as ''spineless,'' approved paying $360,000 to Sgt. James M. Alston, the Police Department's only black member.

title: Trenton to Add 120 Child Social Workers
description: Under criticism that social workers responsible for protecting children were being assigned too many cases, the Whitman administration acknowledged today that caseloads had reached unacceptably high levels and that 120 new caseworkers would be hired immediately.

title: Earning Their Salt, Doing What the Romans Did
description: These mornings, as the sun and the wind burnish the marshlands on the Brittany coast, Andre Halgand can be found practicing one of the world's oldest professions. He is harvesting salt from the sea.

title: Swiss Bank Is Planning to Cut 1,700 Jobs and Shut Branches
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation said today that it would cut 1,700 jobs, close a quarter of its Swiss branches and take a $2.65 billion charge in an attempt to raise earnings at its domestic operation.

title: An Agency Switch By Virginia Lottery
description: The Virginia Lottery has awarded Arnold Finnegan Martin in Richmond a two-and-a-half-year contract to handle its account, which had been handled by the Richmond office of Earle Palmer Brown. Billings were estimated at $15 million annually.

title: A Heartbeat Away
description: In 1973, Edward Bennett Williams's law partner, Paul Connolly, gave me my first news tip as a neophyte New York Times columnist: that Vice President Spiro T. Agnew was the target of a grand jury inquiry for being on the take while Governor of Maryland.

title: Big Insurer Promotes President To Chief
description: Seven years ago when Seymour Sternberg was recruited to join the New York Life Insurance Company he figured he might have a shot at some day running it.

title: Moment of Perception
description: Next week, Congress is expected to consider overriding President Clinton's veto of a bill that would ban a type of third-trimester abortion. The anti-abortion forces will again display horrible pictures of the technique, which they call partial-birth abortion. Although few in the abortion-rights movement take this approach seriously, it has emotional resonance and erodes public support for all abortions. And the pro-choice movement is partly to blame for its opponents' success.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Winter Aconite

title: Airline Makes Waiting Easier for Children
description: AIR FRANCE understands that children do not like to sit still. So in June, it officially opened Pla nete Bleue, a 900-square-foot lounge for passengers 2 to 12 at its Kennedy International Airport terminal. Children can watch television, play in a biplane, right, or just squirm (so far this summer, 3,000 have used the area, which is supervised). It was designed by Greenfield, Sawicki, Tarella Architects of Manhattan.

title: Man Is Slain by Officer After Brandishing a Gun
description: A police officer searching for a man wanted on an arrest warrant shot and killed another young man who pulled a gun when the officer confronted him early yesterday, investigators said.

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON

title: North Korea Opens the Door, a Crack, to Capitalism
description: When a three-day conference aimed at luring foreign investors drew to a close on Sunday, Kim Jong U, a senior North Korean official, proudly announced his biggest catch. The Emperor International Holdings group of Hong Kong had agreed to spend $180 million to build a five-star hotel and casino along the picturesque coast north of town.

title: Title for Honour and Glory?
description: For the second time in a week, Belmont Park may serve as the championship stage for a clinching on Saturday when the 3-year-old colt Honour and Glory races to pre-empt the role of America's leading sprinter. He will still have to complete the year in the Breeders' Cup Sprint at Toronto on Oct. 26, but he can stake an almost unshakable claim to the title when he meets seven other speedballs in the $200,000 Vosburgh, a Grade I race that is the major prep for the Breeders' Cup.

title: Student at Center of Case Is Nowhere to Be Found
