description: The 15-year-old Bronx student known as Juan C. was supposed to be in class at William H. Taft High School in the Soundview section four years ago when school employees caught him wandering the halls with a loaded handgun in his pocket.

title: Japan Inc., so resilient in the past, can't find its footing.
description: REMEMBER Japan Inc., the unstoppable juggernaut? The juggernaut stalled in the early 1990's with the near-collapse of the Japanese real estate and stock markets. Now it appears that the Government's sputtering effort to rekindle growth is once more failing: after a big first quarter, the economy actually shrank at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the second quarter.

title: INTERNATIONAL NETWORK SHARES SOAR IN PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Shares of International Network Services soared more than 90 percent above its offering price of $16 a share yesterday, in its first day of trading. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., provides computer networking services to big telecommunications companies including the AT&T Corporation, the Sprint Corporation and Cable and Wireless P.L.C. The 2.5 million shares that were offered began trading at $28.50 on the Nasdaq and closed at $30.75. The company plans to use proceeds from the stock offering to pay debts and for other general corporate purposes.

title: James F. Bonner, 86; Studied Gene Regulation
description: James F. Bonner, a molecular biologist whose interests ranged from the intricacies of gene regulation to ways in which agriculture could better provide for the world's needs, died on Friday at a nursing home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 86 and lived in South Pasadena.

title: Storm's Toll Included Turtles
description: The last few stormy weeks have brought more than waves onto New Jersey's beaches. At least 15 dead sea turtles, ranging up to four feet in diameter and weighing as much as 400 pounds, have washed ashore since Sept. 1, according to the Marine Mammal Stranding Center.

title: Cone Is Ready to Pitch Doubleheader Nightcap
description: For the thousands who were disappointed at seeing less than an inning of the David Cone-Mike Mussina matchup Tuesday night, there will be no return engagement at Yankee Stadium today.

title: Data Shows School Crime Is Dropping
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that reports of assault, robbery, weapons possession and other violent crimes in the New York City schools fell during the last school year. But he said the degree of improvement was not entirely clear because of changes in the way the Board of Education collected such statistics.

title: Help in Saving Sterling Forest
description: With the Congressional session about to end, proponents of preserving Sterling Forest got a renewed commitment yesterday from House Speaker Newt Gingrich, according to a spokesman for Rep. Marge Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood.

title: ... And a New House Bends to a Family's Needs
description: IF design awards were given for political correctness, ''The Next Home,'' an experimental four-story house designed to be affordable for nontraditional families, could be a contender.

title: Hussein's Gamble
description: The Iraqi President seems to have wagered that even a military loss to the allied forces patrolling over northern and southern Iraq could strengthen his political prestige at home, and there are many Iraqis who say Mr. Hussein has won his bet.

title: Some Serious Business At Philharmonic Opener
description: The New York Philharmonic conducted by Kurt Masur opened its season last night with an honest accounting of what it is and what it does. Indeed, dressed-up patrons, primed by cocktail parties and anticipating the late-evening banquet to come, were halted in mid-swing and pointedly reminded that music is serious business.

title: Child Pornography?
description: To The Home Section:

title: Deformed Welfare System Raises First Alarms
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday listing some provisions of the tentative labor contract between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union misstated the sources of the information. They were people close to the union and other sources, not company officials.

title: Dole Delivers a No-No to the Glory Days of Brooklyn
description: Bob Dole was in the right place at the right time and trying to hitch his fortunes to the right championship baseball team today. The only thing he got wrong was the city -- by 39 years and nearly 3,000 miles.

title: Deficit Soared In U.S. Trade During July
description: The trade deficit surged in July to its highest level in at least four and a half years, the Government said today, undermining the Clinton Administration's claim to an improving trade performance but reducing the chances of inflation infecting the economy.

title: S.E.C. Argues Against Prudential Claimants
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday asked a Federal District judge to reject accusations that Prudential Securities Inc. miscalculated settlement payments to thousands of people who had been fraudulently sold investments.

title: President Designates A Monument Across Utah
description: With the striated pink cliffs and the purple depths of the Grand Canyon behind him, President Clinton today designated nearly two million acres of the red rock country of Utah as a national monument, calling it ''some of the most remarkable land in the world.''

title: Apartheid Killer Points a Finger at Superiors
description: After three days on the stand, the commander of a notorious apartheid-era police assassination squad has offered a grisly picture of the way his unit eliminated the political enemies of this country's former apartheid government.

title: Despite Strongman's Vow, Burundi Strife Grows
description: When Maj. Pierre Buyoya seized power in Burundi in July, he said his aim was to end the ethnic bloodshed between Hutu and Tutsi that has taken 150,000 lives since October 1993.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: Attacking Drugs, Dole Takes On Entertainment Industry
description: Bob Dole today denounced what he termed the glorification of heroin and other drugs by the entertainment industry and led a high school gym filled with teen-agers in chanting a new slogan that he presented as the center of his drug-fighting strategy: ''Just don't do it.''

title: Soul of Continuity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rebels' Call to Arms Echoes in Rural Mexico
description: At first glance, this village in the pine ridges of Mexico's southern sierra seems tranquil and unchanging, with its stone streets and colonial church tower with a bell that tolls mournfully through the mist.

title: Murray's 500th to Be Sold for $500,000
description: EDDIE MURRAY wanted to put it in a display case for his daughter. The man who runs the Psychic Friends Network wants to put it on display in his hotel.

title: Perry Accepts The Blame In Saudi Blast, But Not All
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that he was to blame for any ''failure of leadership'' in the Defense Department that may have resulted in the terrorist bombing in Saudi Arabia in June that killed 19 American airmen.

title: Alcatel Would Hold All Units of Thomson
description: Two days after submitting an offer to buy Thomson S.A., Alcatel Alsthom S.A. said yesterday that it would hold onto all units of the state-owned military and electronics company -- including its unprofitable Thomson Multimedia unit -- if the bid succeeds. Alcatel's chairman, Serge Tchuruk, said that taking over Thomson and its debt of 25 billion French francs, or $5 billion, would neither increase Alcatel's indebtedness nor dilute shareholder equity.

title: T.W.A. PREDICTS EARNINGS BELOW EXPECTATIONS
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it expected its third-quarter earnings before interest, taxes and other items to fall short of the $45.8 million it earned before charges in the third quarter of 1995. The airline said it lost international bookings after its Flight 800 crashed in July, killing all 230 passengers and crew. T.W.A. stock closed at $10.50, down 12.5 cents. A year ago, the company had a third-quarter loss of $82 million, after $299.7 million of pretax charges related to its reorganization. T.W.A. had been expected to post earnings of $1.13 a share in the quarter, according to the average estimate of four analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.

title: Agency Search Begun By GO-JO Division
description: The Purell brand consumer products division of GO-JO Industries Inc. in Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, said yesterday that it was in the preliminary stages of a search for an agency to introduce Purell Brand Instant Hand Sanitizer to the consumer market. Billings were estimated at $15 million. Lorraine S. Rojek, president of the Rojek Marketing Group in Cleveland, which is managing the review, said that 8 to 10 agencies would be invited to participate. She said a decision would be made by mid-November.

title: Gilkey and Mets Can't Agree on the Term
description: Negotiations on a multiyear contract for Bernard Gilkey have reached an impasse that is heightening the probability that the Mets outfielder won't re-sign with the team before the end of the season.

title: Magical World of Man and Beast
description: Which of us hasn't been deeply instilled with the circus and Wild West imagery of human beings proudly ''taming'' animals? By training them to perform simple stunts and to execute feats of hard labor, we demonstrate our superiority in the food chain along with a tenuous control over a brutal natural world. Presented under a tent, these man-conquers-beast displays usually represent the glitzy, least common denominator of show business.

title: Events: Plants, Antiques and Design
description: Garden Open House

title: Paints In Crayon Hues
description: CALL it paintbrush diplomacy. Parents tired of scraping Crayola smears off the walls of children's rooms can stop fighting and join the fun. Benjamin Moore has translated 40 Crayola colors into paint colors, from Purple Passion to Schoolbus Yellow, adding 112 midtone and pastel shades. ''If a child loves Razzmatazz, but a parent is afraid of putting shocking pink all over the wall, they can use it as an accent and do the rest of the room in midtones,'' said Leslie Harrington, manager of new business for Benjamin Moore. Black chalkboard paint allows you to use, and erase, chalk. Paints are about $25 a gallon. For dealers, (800) 972-4685.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Gemina of Italy Returns to Profit
description: Gemina S.p.A., an Italian holding company, said yesterday that it had returned to profit in the first half as earnings at its clothing companies rose and losses at its publishing unit were reduced. Its profit was 115.1 billion lire, or $75 million, compared with a net loss of 409.2 billion lire in the first half of 1995.

title: In His Own Words
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON

title: Accord Is Signed On Improvements To Casino Roads
description: Ending an impasse over the details of the project, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has signed an agreement with Mirage Resorts that confirms the Las Vegas-based gaming company's plans to participate in the construction of a $405 million roadway and tunnel project for Atlantic City.

title: Sale Planned for Shares in Florida Panthers
description: The billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga plans to sell almost half the ownership of the Florida Panthers hockey franchise to the public, cutting back his stake in a team that wins games but loses money.

title: The Artless Dodger
description: The Brooklyn Dodgers never had a pitcher named Nomo.

title: Jong Helps Barnard Help Others Start Writing
description: Erica Jong takes her passions seriously. Zipless sex is the one she is best known for, chronicled in her first best seller, ''Fear of Flying.''

title: TRANSAMERICAN WASTE DROPS ITS PURCHASE EFFORT
description: TransAmerican Waste Industries said yesterday that it had ended plans to acquire Waste Industries after failing to negotiate a lower price. TransAmerican had offered in July to buy Waste Industries, based in Raleigh, N.C., for $209 million in stock. It revised that proposal to $150 million yesterday, including $50 million in cash, 25 million shares of stock and another $50 million if certain earnings targets could be met. TransAmerican, a Houston waste management company, said Waste Industries officials had rejected the lower bid. Waste Industries officials did not respond to requests for comment.

title: Girth and Real Estate  To the Editor:
description: Re Russell Baker's Sept. 17 column on being forced out of Manhattan because of real estate prices and moving to Burgville, Va.: Alas, Mr. Baker has got the wrong rich man. His ''fat man whose people gave him his weight'' -- not in rubies and pearls but in gold and diamonds -- was not the Nizam of Hyderabad but Aga Khan, father of Prince Aly Khan, who married Rita Hayworth.

title: German Economy Shows A Gradual Strengthening
description: The German economy is continuing to improve gradually, with reports showing business confidence jumping to a nine-month high and the money supply growing faster than expected. There is evidence that the recovery that started in the second quarter is on track, the Economics Ministry said yesterday in a summary of its monthly report.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a review of two performances by the comedians Jason and Randy Sklar reversed their names. Randy was on the left and Jason on the right.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about trading on the Tokyo stock market referred incorrectly in some editions to the market's movement on Tuesday. The Nikkei index of 225 leading Japanese issues rose 467.95 points; it did not fall by that amount.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: If Lucy Fell

title: A Leap Out of Bed, and the Guns Start Blazing Away
description: John Smith (Bruce Willis), a samurai in a business suit, wanders into a tough guy's dreamland when he hits the dusty little ghost town called Jericho. The set belongs to a western, but Jericho has been taken over by rival gangs of Depression-era bootleggers.

title: Important French Rate Is Trimmed 0.10 Point
description: The Bank of France trimmed a significant interest rate yesterday in an apparent sign of its approval of the Government's 1997 budget.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16

title: It's Our Land, Isn't It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotel's Garage Reopens
description: The $27 million parking garage at the Claridge Casino Hotel will reopen today, two months after two elderly women were killed when their car plunged off the fourth floor of the new structure.

title: Bad Weather Doesn't Still Enthusiasm For the Trail
description: Under gray skies, drizzle and an occasional downpour, the Clintons and Gores rolled their trademark campaign buses along the byways of the Pacific Northwest today, bashing the Republicans in town after town and calling for Democrats to be elected to Congress.

title: Restaurants
description: Never trust a recommendation when it comes from someone living or working within five blocks of the restaurant.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Hit Record Level on Big Board
description: In a separate report, the American Stock Exchange said short interest rose 5.2 percent in the period, to 125.1 million shares. That was below the record of 126.7 million shares set in the mid-May to mid-June.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Developments of rental apartments are being planned at an old factory site in Hoboken.
description: A HUDDLE of manufacturing buildings is being torn down to make way for what is to become the first new rental complex in a decade in the northwestern sector of this Hudson County city.

title: 7 Held in Abduction as Feud Follows Dance
description: It began as an underground party featuring hip disk jockeys, hundreds of young people dancing in a New Jersey warehouse and the slogan ''Share the warmth. Feel the love.''

title: Subtle Ploy: Dole Cites Beloved Bums
description: BOB DOLE is probably going to take more heat than even Hideo Nomo can deliver for that peculiar slip the other day about the pitcher's having thrown a no-hitter for the Brooklyn Dodgers. Few seem to realize that this was no gaffe, reinforcing the notion that the 70-something candidate is out of touch. It was nothing less than a calculated strategy to do what pundits and polls say is impossible: snatch the New York vote from Bill Clinton.

title: Fears About Winter Inventory Drive Up Natural-Gas Prices
description: Natural-gas prices rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as concern grew that inventories were lagging behind last year's levels and could be uncomfortably low this winter.

title: Simpson-Case Fatigue Mixes With Obsession
description: As jury selection began this week in the civil-suit sequel to the murder trial of the decade, the prospect of another national spell of obsession with O. J. Simpson was bringing a sigh from many a resistant viewer, reader and coffee-shop debater across the nation: ''Not again.''

title: INSIDE
description: 7 North Korean Agents Slain

title: Fleeing the Fleas
description: Nearly 100 workers in the Hudson County administration building have been routed from their offices by a flea infestation that health officials said could take weeks to be eradicated.

title: No Argentine Loopholes
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Couples Arrested on Charges Of Sexual Abuse of Teen-Agers
description: For the last two months, a Long Island man and his wife and another couple sexually abused at least a dozen teen-agers under the pretense of playing games, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: 2 Sides Meet; No Deal Yet
description: Still awaiting authorization from Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, to try to conclude a labor agreement, Randy Levine met with Donald Fehr yesterday before both negotiators headed out of town for the weekend.

title: Jets Hope Elliott Shakes Seasonlong Injury Label
description: John Elliott weighs about 310 pounds, is nicknamed Jumbo, is 6 feet 7 inches tall -- and was the first symbol of the Jets' off-season commitment to become a contender.

title: TORO TO ACQUIRE IRRIGATION PRODUCTS SUPPLIER
description: The Toro Company, the lawn-care products concern, said yesterday that it would acquire James Hardie Irrigation Group, a unit of James Hardie Industries Ltd. of Australia, for $130 million. James Hardie Irrigation, based in Laguna Niguel, Calif., provides irrigation products to residential and commercial customers. In addition to its lawn mowers and snow blowers, Toro makes irrigation sprinkler heads. Toro, based in Minneapolis, said the price could be adjusted based on a final review of the unit's balance sheet. The company said that it expected the acquisition would reduce its per-share earnings slightly in the first year after the transaction was completed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about the actor Gene Nelson referred incorrectly to his performance in the 1971 Broadway production of ''Follies.'' He was nominated for a Tony Award; he did not win.

title: Florida State Routs Wolfpack
description: Florida State has achieved the best winning percentage in college football during the 1990's (.880) primarily on the strength of a creative, explosive offense. But tonight against North Carolina State, it was Coach Bobby Bowden's defense that dominated as the third-ranked Seminoles slogged to a 51-17 victory.

title: Photographers Help Save Dole
description: The Reuters photographer captured a picture of Bob Dole lying on the ground after his four-foot fall from a campaign speakers' platform in Chico, Calif., his face drawn into a pained grimace, while the photographers from The Associated Press and Agence France-Presse had no pictures to speak of.

title: HOST MARRIOTT BUYS 3 RITZ-CARLTON HOTELS
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said yesterday that it had bought three Ritz-Carlton hotels for $331 million. Host Marriott, a hotel operator based in Bethesda, Md., said it had bought a majority stake in a partnership that owns a 463-room hotel in Naples, Fla., and a 553-room hotel in Atlanta. The company also bought a 447-room hotel in downtown Atlanta. The hotels -- which will generate an estimated $41 million in earnings before taxes this year -- will continue to be operated by Ritz-Carlton, which is a subsidiary of Four Seasons Hotels Inc. Host Marriott owns 71 hotels primarily under the Marriott brand name.

title: Borejko Leibler Changes Its Name
description: Borejko Leibler has changed its name to reflect the addition of one partner and the exit of another.

title: Albany Is Confident on Welfare Quotas
description: In its first official response to the new Federal welfare law, the Pataki administration said today that the state was well on its way to meeting strict new work requirements for welfare recipients in the coming year.

title: Kelly Injures Hamstring And Is Likely to Sit Out
description: JIM KELLY will probably miss Sunday's game against the Dallas Cowboys after the Buffalo Bills quarterback sustained a hamstring injury in practice yesterday.

title: Inside Art
description: A Gallery's Changing Faces

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Before and After

title: Kemp Accuses the President of Lacking Strategy to Deal With Inner City
description: Trying to undercut one of the Democrats' political pillars, Jack Kemp today attacked President Clinton's urban policies.

title: A War So Long Its Origins Are Dimmed
description: In retrospect, the civil war in Guatemala now seems ''an absurd conflict,'' as one of the country's leading businessmen called it just last month.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sumitomo Estimate of Loss Grows in Copper Scandal

title: At Drug Trial, Mexican Suspect Faces Accuser
description: They carried on an extraordinary 18-month correspondence, by phone, by letter and by messenger. But until Tuesday, Juan Garcia Abrego, the reputed Mexican drug boss, had never actually met Claude de la O, the F.B.I. agent who did him in.

title: Audit of School Janitors Finds Criminal Records
description: For months or even years, 21 janitors who had been convicted or accused of crimes that included rape, robbery or drug-dealing worked in New York City public schools, according to an audit released yesterday that fanned a long-running dispute over control of school buildings.

title: Jews and Coalition
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Venice/Venice

title: A Vote on Princeton Merger
description: Residents of Princeton Borough and Princeton Township will be able to vote this November on whether to merge, a judge ruled yesterday. Judge Philip S. Carchman of Mercer County decided that the county clerk had erred when she said officials of the municipalities had missed the filing deadline.

title: Giuliani Attacks Transit Workfare Accord and Threatens to Scuttle Union Deal
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the transit system's plan to use welfare recipients to clean subways and buses would undermine the city's own agreements with its unions over workfare, and threatened to scuttle the deal.

title: Scary Puppets and Artist in a Deadly Tango
description: In ''Twin Houses,'' presented by Compagnie Nicole Mossoux and Patrick Bonte on Wednesday night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, a woman shares the dark stage with puppet heads and upper torsos that sprout from her shoulder. They might be alter egos or an artist's visions of work at hand. Some seem like figures from the past, remembered on the dark, nearly empty stage.

title: Cool, Hip and Proud to Be Selling Harm?
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Jailed Dad Is Freed, Ordered to Get a Job And Pay Support
description: Jeffrey A. Nichols, the ''deadbeat dad'' who has been imprisoned twice for failing to pay $640,000 in child support, was released yesterday after three months in jail and ordered, also for the second time, to get a job.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the naming of Paul B. Guenther as chairman of the New York Philharmonic misspelled the surname of the chairman of the orchestra's search committee. He is J. Carter Bacot, not Bascot.

title: House Rejects Bid to Force Release of Ethics Report on Gingrich
description: Without debate, the House voted today to quash a Democratic move to force the ethics committee to make public its counsel's preliminary report on charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Just Don't Say It

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS FOR WEEK FOUR
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALASKA AIR GROUP INC. Seattle, the holding company for Alaska Airlines Inc. and Horizon Air Industries, said it had ordered 12 Boeing 737-400 aircraft, with the option to acquire up to 12 more in a deal worth $540 million.

title: Chinese Shooter Hurt
description: WANG YIFU, the Chinese air pistol sharpshooter who collapsed during the Atlanta Olympics, has been hospitalized for 20 days with a neck injury, the Xinhua News Agency said yesterday.

title: Of a Woman and Her Donor
description: ''A Modern Affair,'' a wispy romantic comedy that wobbles away from the mark, may be the first movie to provide a guided tour of an upscale New York City sperm bank. As a perky Germanic physician with a Dr. Ruth accent (Robert Joy) shepherds the film's main character, Grace (Lisa Eichhorn), through his clinic, we peer through a microscope at the frisky organisms that fertilize human eggs and visit ''the cupping room,'' an office equipped with a television receiver and X-rated videos.

title: A case where a billion dollars really wasn't a lot of money
description: THE men who ran Comparator Systems -- the small company with no successful products that somehow became valued at a billion dollars and served as an example of ridiculous stock market valuations -- won't be running any more companies. And the accountant who signed off on Comparator's books won't be auditing any more public companies.

title: Perot Hasn't Earned A Chance to Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCO EXPANDS PARTNERSHIP WITH RUSSIA'S LUKOIL
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it had expanded a partnership with AO Lukoil Holding, Russia's largest oil company, by signing a $5 billion venture to jointly develop projects in the former Soviet Union. The agreement replaces an earlier plan that called for the United States oil company to team up with Lukoil for $3 billion in projects over 10 years. Atlantic Richfield, also known as ARCO, said the new venture could last 18 years, and Lukoil said it would be financed largely by ARCO. For Lukoil, the partnership brings a ready supply of cash and the Western technology that it needs to expand outside Russia. Like many of Russia's formerly government-owned companies, Lukoil is resource rich and cash poor.

title: Work Starts 100 Feet Above Grand Central Commuters
description: It was a tall order: how to clean and restore the ornate, 100-foot-high, grime-encrusted sky ceiling in the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal without disrupting the flow of the roughly 500,000 people who walk through each day.

title: Longing to Connect, But Out of Reach
description: IT'S only an old sock, after all: a stiff, shabby sock in which a key is put before it's thrown out the window to callers at a run-down apartment building in northwest London. But in the remarkable hands of Michael Gambon and Lia Williams -- the stars of David Hare's absolutely splendid ''Skylight,'' which opened last night at the Royale Theater -- that sock acquires, with a few casual-seeming gestures, as many shades of meaning as Desdemona's handkerchief.

title: As the Pope Pays a Visit, 'Secular France' Bristles Just a Bit
description: Arriving here on a trip that has stirred old passions about the role of the Roman Catholic Church in French society, Pope John Paul II tried to dampen the debate today with an appeal to compassion and tolerance ''regardless of religious beliefs.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: What can you give a woman for her 107th birthday? AMY HILL HEARTH, the writer who collaborated with the Delany sisters on their best-selling book ''Having Our Say: The Delany Sisters' First 100 Years'' was determined to find just the right gift for SARAH L. DELANY, better known as Sadie, who turned 107 yesterday. Her sister, A. Elizabeth Delany, who was known as Bessie, died last September at 104.

title: War, Peace and Stubborn Faith in a Family of Nations
description: An allegory inspired by the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, vignettes inspired by Bob Dylan and an animated but oblique meditation on the human condition: the sum makes up the Rambert Dance Company's second program at the Joyce Theater, the best seen so far.

title: Hughes Deal For Panamsat Is Reported To Be Complete
description: After weeks of tangled negotiations, the Hughes Electronics Corporation plans to announce today that it will acquire Panamsat in a deal worth $3 billion, according to people with knowledge of the talks.

title: Art in Review
description: Richard Tuttle

title: COMPUTER MAKER OFFERS SOME EMPLOYEES BUYOUTS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that as expected it had offered some of its United States employees a buyout plan if they leave the company by the end of the year. I.B.M. would not disclose how many employees were affected. The company said that employees who have at least five years of service would be eligible and that the plan was being offered to a select group of its 110,000 United States employees. Eligible workers, if accepted into the program, will receive one week's pay for every six months of service, up to a maximum of 26 weeks. Health benefits will be extended for six months.

title: $11.2 Million for Chinese Furniture
description: A sale yesterday at Christie's of more than 100 pieces of Chinese furniture brought a total of $11.2 million.

title: No Headline
description: ''I am a product of welfare, and not ashamed. The reason I am where I am is because someone gave me a chance. I feel a duty to pass that on.''

title: Sand, Sea Breezes And Victoriana
description: THERE are no primary colors in Cape May, N.J. It's a town of mauves and chartreuses, ochres and pinks, the colors of hundreds of Victorian-era summer cottages that have made Cape May a national landmark. It's a seaside town, too, bordered by pale fine sand and green-gray waves.

title: Seles's Shoulder Woes
description: The ailing shoulder that has hampered her all year ''hasn't gotten better or worse,'' MONICA SELES said yesterday.

title: Stalking the Urban Wildlife In Night's Darkest Corners
description: There are those who will not want to miss ''Hustler White'' for its scene in which a male prostitute removes his prosthetic leg extension to service a client who has been shown devouring a publication called Amputee Times. There are many, many more who will want to make sure to miss it.

title: Terms of Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Dodgers Rip Valenzuela To Take 1 1/2-Game Edge
description: In a sense, Fernando Valenzuela is still pitching for Los Angeles.

title: SONY AND SHARP FORM FLAT SCREEN VENTURE
description: The Sony Corporation and the Sharp Corporation said yesterday that they would jointly develop a new type of flat panel display for use in computers and in television sets that can hang on a wall like a picture. The collaboration, to last three years, aims to produce a 40-inch screen using an approach developed by Tektronix Inc. of Wilsonville, Ore., that combines liquid crystal and plasma technologies. Sony and Sharp, which did not disclose any financial terms of the alliance, said they hoped to begin shipping samples by the fall of next year.

title: Justice Dept. In New Inquiry Into Microsoft
description: The Justice Department is opening a new phase of its long-running investigation of the Microsoft Corporation by examining the company's sales practices in the fast-growing market for the software used to browse the Internet.

title: Rap's Positive Message
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: All types of classes for children are beginning in the next few weeks, and the breadth is daunting. Here are details about classes offered by two large institutions in New York City.

title: Art in Review
description: Larry Bell

title: Holik and the Devils Patch Up Differences
description: The Devils and Bobby Holik have apparently resolved their differences. The center reported and practiced with the team yesterday at Continental Arena after meeting with Lou Lamoriello, the team's president and general manager.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Hofstra

title: Lured Into Picasso's Web, and Not the Only One
description: When Francoise Gilot, who deemed herself ''a seasoned philosopher disguised as a young girl,'' paid a fateful visit in 1944 to Pablo Picasso's studio in Paris, she wore a black velvet gown with a white lace collar and styled her hair after a painting of the Infanta by Velazquez. Imagine what the Merchant-Ivory-Jhabvala team could do with an image like that, not to mention their vigorously inventive homage to Picasso's own work, and you have a hint of their new film's visual splendor.

title: Clinton Errs in Designating Utah Monument
description: To the Editor:

title: Dark Beauty and Austerity
description: The New York Philharmonic conducted by Kurt Masur opened its season Wednesday night with an honest accounting of what it is and what it does. Indeed, dressed-up patrons, primed by cocktail parties and anticipating the late-evening banquet to come, were halted in mid-swing and pointedly reminded that music is serious business.

title: Bonn Accuses Paris of 'Window Dressing' : Germany Assails France Over Budget Maneuvers
description: BONN  Senior government officials in Germany on Thursday sharply criticized what they called "window dressing" used by France this week when it presented a 1997 budget that Paris asserted would meet the conditions for Europe's single currency.

title: Vote for Abortion Ban
description: The House voted to override President Clinton's veto of a ban on a form of late-term abortion. But the Senate is expected to uphold the veto. Republicans, who plan to turn the veto into an election issue, were gleeful about their narrow victory in the House, describing it as a turning point in the debate over abortion.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Pitch Timer Whose Time Hasn't Quite Come
description: During the 1991 World Series, CBS Sports used a technology called Super Vision to track the speed and movement of a ball graphically from a pitcher's release to home plate. The fascination with the system reached its acme when a pitch from the Twins' Jack Morris left his hand at 94 miles per hour and arrived at the plate at the same speed. It astounded CBS's Tim McCarver and Jim Kaat, even as it rebuked physics.

title: In School, But Not Learning
description: For three years I taught in New York City's public schools, and before I began in 1991, I tried to picture what my school year would be like. My hopes weren't particularly extravagant. I was realistic enough to expect overcrowded classes, dilapidated buildings and scant supplies.

title: The Trains Are Leaving
description: You cannot ride a train from Dallas to Houston or from Cincinnati to Cleveland. Those trains have left, and across a land originally stitched together with railroad tracks, passenger service is in a downward spiral of neglect, curtailment, customer estrangement and route cancellations. America could wake up in the 21st century to find only freight on its tracks while its highways choke with traffic.

title: Gap Narrows For Rogers And Torre
description: WHEN George Steinbrenner said he needed to reassure Joe Torre that the 1997 portion of the manager's contract would be honored so as to make Torre relax, everyone laughed. For if Torre were any more at ease, he would fall asleep.

title: Rangers Reserves Are Taking a Fall
description: The Rangers' five best players have yet to join the team in this exhibition season, which has given several lesser players increased opportunities to fill out the roster spots still up for grabs before the regular season begins in three weeks.

title: CELLULAR INDUSTRY REJECTS U.S. PLAN FOR SURVEILLANCE
description: In a showdown with the Justice Department, the wireless communications industry voted yesterday to reject Government-backed technology that would make it possible for law enforcement agencies to keep closer tabs on cellular phone users.

title: U.S. Changes Policy on Polio Inoculation, Recommending Salk Vaccine for First Doses
description: Inactivated polio vaccine, familiar to millions in the 1950's and 60's as the Salk vaccine, was reinstated on Wednesday as part of the Federal Government's recommended schedule of childhood immunizations.

title: Dole Appears to Be More at Ease As Election Going Gets Tougher
description: As Bob Dole's plane rumbled over California on Wednesday night, the Republican candidate strolled uncharacteristically to the back of his aircraft in search of the news photographers on board.

title: British Call Halt to Cow Slaughter Demanded by European Union
description: The British Government announced tonight that it was calling a halt to the slaughter of cattle that it had agreed to this summer. The slaughter was a condition for a gradual lifting of the ban on British beef exports by the European Union.

title: Barney's Acts to End Isetan Licensing Pact
description: Barney's Inc., the parent company of Barneys New York, which filed for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy protection last January, said yesterday that it was seeking to terminate a licensing agreement with its Asian partner, the Isetan Company.

title: Love's Revenge, or, Spite Is a Many-Splendored Thing
description: With a mink and a drink, middle-aged Cynthia Griffin (Stockard Channing in an unbilled cameo) stands on her Fifth Avenue terrace, wondering whether she should leap. Just then, she glances toward an adjoining building to see a pretty young blonde on an exercise machine. The blonde waves cheerfully and that's it for Cynthia. The last straw. Over and out.

title: Spain Honors Lewis
description: CARL LEWIS was awarded one of Spain's prestigious Prince of Asturias prizes yesterday for his contribution to sport and the battle against drugs in track. With the award goes $40,000 and a sculpture. (AP)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Drugs, Guns and Vigilante Justice in South Africa
description: It is past midnight and a steady drizzle is falling on the crowd of almost 2,000 people, including women in chadors and children. The alleys of the downtown Muslim neighborhood of Schotches Kloof have turned to muddy streams, but the crowd pushes on toward a known drug dealer's house, chanting: ''Kill the merchant! Kill!''

title: A Reopening And a Carnival Of Graphics
description: ONE day, somebody up there will realize that New York does not need a monument to Andrew Carnegie's taste for dark, carved wood. It needs a clean, well-lighted place for Cooper-Hewitt, the National Design Museum, resident since 1976 in Carnegie's upper Fifth Avenue mansion. Until that day arrives, however, visitors to this institution can expect to see two shows in one: a changing exhibition housed within a permanent display of ponderous Edwardian gloom.

title: A Golden Girl Escaping Into Infinity
description: IF ever an artist started out right, it was Sonja Sekula (1918-1963). Born in Switzerland, the only child of well-to-do parents, she moved to New York City with them in 1936, and in the family's Park Avenue apartment met a wide range of European artists and writers exiled by the war.

title: Nomura to Bail Out Its Finance Arm
description: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's biggest brokerage house, said yesterday that it would provide assistance of 371 billion yen ($3.4 billion) to its cash-short affiliate Nomura Finance.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg Business News on Tuesday about a Government report on business inventories in July referred incorrectly to the significance of a figure exceeding $1 trillion. That was the total reached in July for the first time since the Government began collecting inventory data in 1982. It was not the inventory figure for 1982.

title: Treasury Securities Drop in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday after a strong housing report alarmed investors and a Government report on manufacturing sent mixed signals to a market already sharply divided over the possibility of a rise in interest rates.

title: Here We Go Again
description: The double standard about the Middle East lives on in the foreign offices and press of the world -- on and on and on. To examine and understand the latest specimen, suppose the following supposes.

title: Oldest (1850) Street Photo Survives Scrutiny
description: If only every street-paving project turned out to be so important.

title: Profits and Pride Are at Stake for Ailing Olivetti
description: If Carlo de Benedetti proved anything Wednesday night, it was that he was not about to surrender control of Olivetti S.p.A., after resigning two weeks ago as chairman of the big Italian electronics group he guided for the previous 18 years.

title: S.E.C. Is Said to Plan Fraud Case Against Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has been told by Federal regulators that it will be charged with securities fraud in connection with the 1994 bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., Bloomberg Business News reported today, citing unidentified lawyers involved with the investigation.

title: Elizabeth B. Noyce, 65, Benefactor of Maine With Vast Settlement From Her Divorce
description: Elizabeth Bottomley Noyce, a microchip millionaire's scorned first wife who showed as much imagination and verve in deploying her half of his Silicon Valley fortune as he had in making it, died on Tuesday at her seaside home in Bremen, Me. She was 65 and had been the state's premier philanthropist and most innovative investor for two decades.

title: Gulf War Veterans in Navy Unit Tell of an Iraqi Chemical Attack
description: While the Pentagon continues to insist that it has no evidence that American troops were made sick from exposure to Iraqi chemical weapons during the Persian Gulf war in 1991, more than 150 veterans of a Naval reserve battalion have come forward with details of what many of them describe as an Iraqi chemical attack that has left them seriously ill.

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY QUARTERLY EARNINGS PLUMMET
description: Micron Technology Inc.'s fourth-quarter earnings fell 93 percent, reflecting the plunge in computer memory chip prices. The decline was less severe than some analysts had expected. Net income for the three months that ended on Aug. 29 fell to $18.6 million, or 9 cents a share, from $281 million, or $1.30 a share in the corresponding period last year. Sales fell 32 percent, to $700 million. The average estimate of 16 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for a loss of 3 cents a share. Shares of Micron rose $2, to $27.375. The company released the results after the close of trading.

title: Lutheran Treasurer in Connecticut Accused of Stealing From Church
description: A former treasurer of the Lutheran Church's governing body in New England was arrested yesterday on charges that he embezzled $800,000 from the church to finance a life style that included resort trips and vacation homes on Cape Cod and in Vermont.

title: To Expand West Bank Settlements, Israelis Plan 4,000 Homes
description: The Israeli authorities have approved plans to build nearly 4,000 homes in Jewish settlements in the West Bank, putting into practice a Government decision to end restrictions on expanding settlements there and in the Gaza Strip.

title: Chernomyrdin to Control 'Nuclear Button' for Yeltsin's Surgery
description: Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin will control Russia's nuclear arsenal during President Boris N. Yeltsin's heart operation, the Kremlin announced today. The date of the operation, which is planned for late September or early October, has not been fixed.

title: Hell and Hatred in a Country Town
description: ''Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 26. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street west of Fifth Avenue, Greenwich Village.

title: 10 Accused In Drug Sales And Killings
description: For 10 years, a gang known as the Raysor Organization dominated the crack trade in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, ready to burn down a building or shoot a rival or witness to keep its lucrative operation going, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Abortion Pill Will Galvanize the Opposition
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans Plan To Return Refugees To Bosnia
description: Less than a week after Bosnia's elections and despite the protests of relief workers, senior officials resolved today that 320,000 Bosnian refugees in Germany should begin going home on Oct. 1.

title: How Much Is Too Much? Torre Learns the Hard Way
description: The American League East championship was in their grasp. Sure, 10 more games remained on the schedule, and mathematically the Baltimore Bombers could still have caught them. But the Yankees were four innings away from effectively ending the race last night, four innings away from a sweep of a doubleheader with the Orioles that would have crushed them emotionally and maybe even crippled their quest for the A.L. wild-card spot.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Carried Away

title: Backlash of Intolerance Stirring Fear in Iran
description: With inflation raging around 50 percent, the capital choked by air pollution, the prodigious carpet-weaving industry in the doldrums, and the Government infested with embezzlement scandals, one of the most vociferous debates gripping Iran is whether women should be permitted to ride bicycles.

title: Schools Lose Admission Fight
description: A Superior Court judge in Jersey City issued an emergency order yesterday blocking the Union City schools from denying admission to children who could not prove that they lived in an apartment that met city code standards.

title: Franco Wonders if Mets Really Want Him Back
description: John Franco has been the good soldier.

title: Home Video
description: Offbeat Titles From Abroad

title: Accounts
description: * McDonald's Operators Association, San Jose, Calif., to Hoffman/ Lewis, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the San Francisco and Monterey Bay markets. Those duties, with billings estimated at $9 million, had been handled by Davis, Ball & Colombatto, San Francisco. Also to Hoffman/Lewis, Golden Gate University, San Francisco, to handle its account, which had been in-house; billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Dole Inside Out
description: Bob Dole had one main thing going for him as a candidate for President: He was a man of steadiness, of responsibility, of character. With him, there would not be the flip-flops of Bill Clinton's White House. You might not share his ideology, but you knew where you stood with Bob Dole. You could trust him.

title: A Much Wilder West Than It Ever Was
description: BEING a performance artist isn't easy and probably no one knows this better than Paul McCarthy, whose exhibition at the Luhring Augustine Gallery in SoHo is among the season's more notable openers.

title: Why People Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: School Janitors Found To Have Criminal Pasts
description: For months or even years, 21 janitors who had been convicted or accused of crimes that included rape, robbery or drug dealing worked in New York City public schools, according to an audit released yesterday that fanned a long-running dispute over whether custodians have too much control over school buildings.

title: Irving Ben Cooper, New York and U.S. Judge for 51 Years, Dies at 94
description: Irving Ben Cooper, who upheld organized baseball's exemption from antitrust laws, granted Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis relief from a relentless photographer and presided over hundreds of civil and criminal cases in more than 30 years as a Federal judge in New York, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Images Engraved In History's Heart
description: TO get a feel for David Seymour, the photographer known as Chim, you might begin not with his own pictures but with one of him by Elliott Erwitt that shows him playing with Erwitt's son. In the photograph, Chim is a small man in a three-piece suit and thick glasses, a cigarette dangling from his mouth, his head partly turned from the camera because he is facing the child, who happily pursues him with a stick. At 44, Chim looks older than he was, but also a little mischievous, which is the case in photographs of him at 34 and 24. This one was taken in 1956, the year he died covering the conflict in the Suez.

title: Networks Are Fine-Tuning The Art of Self-Promotion
description: A marketing blitz to promote fall television programming, estimated at a record $400 million to $500 million, has been inundating America with a barrage of branding.

title: Princeton Settles Suit Over a Former Name
description: Now everybody take notes.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Inside/Out'

title: A Union Chief Whose Life Led to His Workfare Deal
description: Willie James, the leader of New York City's transit workers' union, had made the grim decision to let the Transit Authority put welfare recipients to work cleaning subways and buses for the first time even as it eliminated 500 union jobs. But as contract talks wound down this week, he wanted something in return.

title: Japan-U.S. Talks On Insurance Sputter
description: Trade negotiators have failed to make progress toward settling American objections to steps Japan plans to take on Oct. 1 that would remove some of its insurance business from foreign companies.

title: Ryder Selling Truck Unit To Questor
description: Questor Partners Fund L.P. agreed today to buy the consumer truck rental division of Ryder System Inc. for about $575 million in cash, allowing Ryder to focus on its other businesses.

title: Clinton Aides Suggest Commission, Not Perot, May Have to Go
description: Fervently hoping to shoehorn Ross Perot into at least one of the planned debates, senior aides to President Clinton said today that they were considering forsaking the Commission on Presidential Debates and finding a different sponsor, one that would invite Mr. Perot.

title: Containing Iraq Has Made Kuwait Duty Old Hat for G.I.'s
description: To some American soldiers, at least, arrival here has come to feel almost routine.

title: Orioles Claw Back From Precipice
description: After four innings of last night's doubleheader nightcap, the Baltimore Orioles were staring at a five-run deficit. They were in danger of being swept out of the Bronx, out of the American League East race and right into the tight scramble for the wild card.

title: The Legend of Evita as Latin Gothic
description: SANTA EVITA

title: Edberg Joins Cup Team
description: STEFAN EDBERG said yesterday that he would join Sweden's Davis Cup squad, increasing the favorite's chances in the weekend's semifinals against the Czech Republic in Prague. (AP)

title: GGT to Pay $163 Million For BDDP
description: The global stampede of acquisitions involving advertising agency companies continued yesterday with a twist: the buyer is much smaller than the seller.

title: No Penalty Set In Lehman Case
description: The United States Treasury will take no disciplinary action against Lehman Brothers Holding Inc. for violations in 1994 and 1995 of laws governing Treasury auctions, the department said today.

title: Sumitomo Increases Size of Copper-Trade Loss to $2.6 Billion
description: The Sumitomo Corporation announced today that the staggering losses incurred by its former star copper trader had soared to $2.6 billion, $800 million higher than its earlier estimate, and that it would seek criminal charges against the trader.

title: Whitaker Aiming to Silence Critics
description: Pernell Whitaker sat in his hotel suite this morning, with a picturesque view of Miami and the ocean outside his window. The view from the top looked magnificent.

title: Art in Review
description: Margarett Sargent

title: Forest Fire Bill Gains
description: The Assembly Judiciary Committee approved a bill yesterday to increase penalties for starting a forest fire from six months to as much as 10 years in prison. The new measure was inspired by an April 1995 fire started by an arsonist that destroyed 20,000 acres of the Pine Barrens. Existing statutes define arson as the intentional burning of a structure.

title: Excerpts From Giuliani on Transit Plan
description: Following is an excerpt from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's remarks yesterday about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its workfare proposal as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Suffolk Executive Seeks 3.3% Tax Increase
description: Citing the unexpected costs of the T.W.A. Flight 800 disaster, the snowiest winter on record and the wildfires that devastated the East End last year, the Suffolk County Executive today proposed a $1.7 billion budget that includes a small tax increase.

title: SOFTWARE PROVIDER SAYS EXECUTIVES ARE LEAVING
description: The communications software provider General Magic Inc. said yesterday that its founder, Marc Porat, would step down as chief executive and that its president, Robert Kelsch, would resign. The company said the posts of president, chief executive and chairman would be combined into a single position held by Steve Markman, who was previously executive vice president and general manager of Novell Products Group. General Magic recently posted a widened loss of $11.6 million, or 45 cents a share, for its second quarter, as it continued to invest in unproven products. In June, it announced plans to focus on Internet business.

title: Art in Review
description: Anton van Dalen

title: Solheim Cup Begins Today
description: It shares the Ryder Cup's compelling plot line: the best European golfers against the best Americans. It shares the Ryder Cup's biennial, three-day, match-play format. What the Solheim Cup lacks is the Ryder Cup's history, not to mention its historically hard edge.

title: Campbell Soup to Offer Mail-Order Health Meals
description: In a first for the world's largest soup maker, the Campbell Soup Company will begin selling frozen mail-order meals that are designed to combat high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes.

title: Guatemala and Guerrillas Sign Accord to End 35-Year Conflict
description: Moving decisively toward ending the longest guerrilla conflict in the Western Hemisphere, the Government of Guatemala and the leftist rebels there signed an ambitious peace accord here today.

title: After Showdown, the Yankees Like Their Chances
description: The memorable afternoon featured the unexpected as Kenny Rogers twirled the game of his enigmatic Yankee career. The memorable evening eventually focused on the unexpected as well because the gritty David Cone could not protect a five-run lead, the amazing Mariano Rivera was trampled in a tie game and a critical sweep evaporated for the Yankees. The memorable result of the Yankees and Orioles sharing the doubleheader is that the pennant race is still percolating. Just barely, but it is alive.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Named Top Investigator
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani nominated a former special state prosecutor yesterday to become commissioner of the city's Department of Investigation, an agency that has faced criticism in recent months for its close ties to the Mayor.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decision by a New York State appeals court that struck down the suspension of a student caught with a gun reversed the identities of two law-enforcement agencies. In an unrelated case cited in the decision, a state police trooper was arrested by the Buffalo police for marijuana possession; a Buffalo policeman was not arrested by state troopers.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: $25 and Under
description: For a new restaurant, Pascalou looks awfully familiar. Its interior, with cherished objects, faded tiles and not-so-fresh coats of paint, looks like any well-worn family restaurant in southwestern France.

title: CIA Chief Says Saddam Is Stronger After Showdown With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Saddam Hussein has emerged strengthened from his recent confrontation with the United States, the CIA director, John Deutch, said Thursday.

title: Morrison Plans One More Fight Despite His H.I.V. Diagnosis
description: Tommy Morrison has seldom proceeded with caution, always one to go after what he wanted -- headfirst, at times.

title: The Spin on 'Spin City'
description: The first TV show about politics I can remember seeing was an episode of ''Night Stalker,'' a 70's precursor of ''The X-Files.'' The plot involved a candidate who sold his soul to the Devil to get elected to the State Senate. Since then, I have never nurtured any great expectations about what happens when you cross American government with regularly scheduled network programming.

title: Diner's Journal
description: If you sit outside on the lawn you can hear the crickets singing at Aquamarine, and if you are facing the water you can see the boats making their way up the Hudson.

title: Johnson's Big Talk Bothers the Giants Less Than His Big Plays
description: When Herman Moore, Detroit's Pro Bowl receiver and all-round good guy, was asked about Keyshawn Johnson, his voice fluctuated between concern and admonishment.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: A Chorus of Critics in Thailand Is Trying to Oust Premier
description: ''I used to strut the streets in foreign countries, so proud to be Thai,'' said Chatichai Choonhavan, a former Prime Minister who is now an opposition member of Parliament. ''Now I hate to tell people where I'm from.''

title: Next Moves in Bosnia
description: Bosnia's national elections last weekend were only a first, flawed step toward creating new democratic institutions in that war-torn country. Numerous problems could still disrupt the launching of a newly elected parliament and three-man presidency, particularly a turn toward secession by the victorious Serbian and Croatian nationalist parties.

title: Till Assassination Do Us Part
description: If you're going to use an alias like Smith, you'd better have an original story behind it. ''Mr. and Mrs. Smith,'' a new romantic-action-detective series, is so banal it makes life-threatening espionage combined with sexual tension seem dull.

title: 'Gidget' Redux, or Maybe 'Emma'
description: On ABC's T.G.I.F. schedule tonight, the one night of the week when this network flexes its rating muscles, is ''Clueless,'' based on the movie that was supposedly based on Jane Austen's ''Emma.'' If you stand on your tippy toes and listen really carefully, you might, indeed, detect a faint echo of Ms. Austen. Don't strain.

title: Middle of Road Beckons In Drive to Overtake G.O.P.
description: With the battle for the House now considered to be extremely competitive, the Democrats have a sensitive task over the next seven weeks: preparing for the possibility of power, and assuring the voters that this would be a Democratic House very different from the one they rejected in the 1994 elections.

title: Koreans Kill 7 Northern Infiltrators as Manhunt Widens
description: South Korean troops shot and killed seven North Korean commandos on Thursday, but at least one of the group remained at large and the target of a vast manhunt.

title: Orwellian Sleuths
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON MORE COVERAGE FOR HEALTH CARE
description: House and Senate leaders announced agreement today on two major health insurance proposals, directing insurance companies to offer comparable coverage for mental and physical illnesses and to guarantee new mothers coverage for at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Auto Racing

title: Gay Partners of I.B.M. Workers to Get Benefits
description: A steady march by corporate America toward providing benefits for the partners of lesbian and gay employees took its largest step forward yesterday when the International Business Machines Corporation announced that it would do so for its domestic work force beginning in January.

title: About Honor, Integrity And a Memorable Meal
description: ''Big Night'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 29. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: House Votes to Override Clinton's Veto of Abortion Bill
description: After eight million postcards, a five-month delay and two hours of blistering debate, the House today narrowly voted to override the President's veto of a ban on a form of late-term abortion.

title: Opposing a Blood Test
description: The blood test for syphilis administered to people seeking a marriage license is an anachronism, a state health official told an Assembly committee yesterday. Dr. Elin Gursky, senior assistant commissioner with the Department of Health and Senior Services, was testifying in behalf of a bill to eliminate the law, which was enacted more than 50 years ago when syphilis was incurable. Today, the tests are conducted on newborn babies and are recommended for people at risk of contracting sexually transmitted diseases.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Partnership Revived

title: Temporary Walls Are Lasting Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d Conviction in '94 Murder
description: An 18-year-old man was convicted yesterday of firing the bullet that killed a clothing-store owner after a July 1994 carjacking outside her East Orange home. The authorities said Tony Frazier of Newark and two accomplices grabbed Sandra McKnight in her driveway while she was loading groceries and took her on a four-hour ride before killing her.

title: Underwater T.W.A. Search Resumes
description: After three weeks of delays caused by rough seas, efforts to recover the remaining sunken wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 returned to high gear yesterday, with at least two more days of calm conditions in the offing, Navy officials said.

title: As 2 Shows Come Down, Museums Take Stock
description: The crowds that jammed West 53d Street for the last five months are gone, and the cavalcade of cars angling for a space in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's parking lot will soon disappear too. As two of the city's major museum shows end this week -- ''Picasso and Portraiture: Representation and Transformation'' at the Museum of Modern Art, and ''Winslow Homer'' at the Metropolitan -- both institutions are taking stock of how they did.

title: Foreign Aid for Family Planning
description: As the House and Senate rush toward a long election recess, they are in danger of shortchanging an important foreign aid program dealing with family planning. The Senate has been more reasonable on the issue, and the House should follow its lead as a bill is prepared for final action.

title: British School's New Boy Is the Other Boris Yeltsin
description: It was over the summer vacation that Emlyn Evans, a 17-year-old in his final year at the Millfield School here, heard about the new student preparing to enroll this fall.

title: Mother Always Says ...
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Archer Sues Ex-Executive Who Became U.S. Informer
description: The yearlong battle between the Archer Daniels Midland Company and the former executive who worked as an informant for the Government against the company is headed for an American courtroom.

title: Loewen Buys Big Cemetery, And Its Suitor Criticizes Deal
description: Executives of the Service Corporation, the world's largest funeral home chain, say their $3.1 billion offer this week for their chief rival, the Loewen Group, is a friendly one. Loewen executives say they will seriously consider it, in due course

title: INSIDE
description: Scrutiny of Swiss Banking

title: Perot Is Given No Sympathy Over Debates
description: When Ross Perot fumes that ''two registered puppies'' are shutting ''this cur dog'' out of the Presidential debates, some people here remember that two months ago it was Mr. Perot who was keeping an underdog out of televised debates.

title: School Plan Forces the G.O.P. Into a Dilemma
description: As House and Senate Republicans struggle to salvage a bill cracking down on illegal immigration that President Clinton will sign, they are reluctantly conceding that what serves their own interests may hurt Bob Dole's Presidential campaign.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS IN DEAL TO BUY SOLVAY
description: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Solvay S.A.'s animal health unit for about $450 million to expand overseas, making it one of the world's biggest producers of pharmaceuticals for livestock and pets. The transaction catapults American Home to the top ranks of an $8 billion market, after Pfizer Inc. and Merck & Company. It will gain swine and poultry vaccines, growth products in an industry expanding about 10 percent annually, thanks largely to demand in eastern Asia. Solvay, Belgium's biggest chemical company, said it would concentrate its drug business on human health. American Home Products' stock was unchanged yesterday at $62.75.

title: No Headline
description: ''One of the purposes of his coming here is to be treated like an ordinary boy.''

title: G.M. Is Ready To Give Up Hughes Unit
description: General Motors no longer believes that it must control Hughes Electronics to benefit from its technology, although no decision has been made yet to sell the satellite communication, aerospace and auto electronics company, top G.M. and Hughes executives said today.

title: Year-Round Schooling: Forget About It
description: To the Editor:

title: Honesty in Banking
description: House and Senate negotiators will decide soon whether to gut an important protection for bank customers. The 1991 Truth in Savings Act requires banks to advertise yields on deposit accounts in identical fashion so that customers can instantly compare one bank's offering with another. The provision forces banks to compete honestly for customers by offering attractive interest rates. Consumers Union estimates that the law will be worth $300 million this year to depositors.

title: Drug Agency Proposes New Guidelines on Animal Transplants
description: Federal health officials yesterday proposed new guidelines for transplants of animal organs and tissues into humans, responding to concerns about their potential for causing outbreaks of new and previously known diseases.

title: DIARIES DISCLOSED IN UNABOM HEARING
description: A Federal prosecutor disclosed yesterday that Theodore Kaczynski, the hermit-like former math professor accused of being the Unabomber, had kept detailed journals in his Montana cabin with entries the likes of ''I mailed that bomb,'' and ''I sent that bomb.''

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL
description: KEY GAMES

title: Extra Safety for Road Crews
description: Road crews working at night will be given extra protective gear to make them more visible from the side, the Department of Transportation said yesterday. The move came in response to the death on Aug. 8 of a private contractor who was killed by a car as he crouched alongside the Palisades Interstate Parkway.

title: Clinton Signs Bill Denying Gay Couples U.S. Benefits
description: President Clinton announced tonight that he was signing a bill to deny Federal benefits to married people of the same sex and to permit states to ignore such marriages sanctioned in other states.

title: Tennessee Faces Its Annual Day of Reckoning
description: There is not enough Gator meat the special of the day -- to satisfy the appetite of this town and this state. There are not enough tickets, not even in expanded, 102,544-seat Neyland Stadium, where a standing-room crowd could be the largest to see any college football game in 66 years. For the followers in Tennessee orange and white, there is still not enough time to analyze Saturday's meeting with Florida. Or to savor the possibilities. Or to worry about the consequences.

title: Red Sox Enjoying A Rebirth
description: They knew they were good. And maybe that was the problem. The Boston Red Sox could not handle losing, leading to a tension that splintered the clubhouse and only made things worse.

title: Objections Aside, Transit Officials Predict Mayoral Support on Workfare
description: A day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened to scuttle a plan to use thousands of welfare recipients to clean subways and buses, transit officials said they were determined to avoid a public feud with him and were confident he would eventually agree to the plan.

title: Bomb Security Test On Jet May Explain Trace of Explosives
description: Adding another twist to the investigation of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Federal officials said yesterday that the jetliner was used during a test of a bomb-detecting dog five weeks before the crash, which they said could explain the traces of explosives found in the wreckage.

title: Grand Central Chaos When Train Derails
description: A train derailed at a switch point outside Grand Central Terminal yesterday, blocking 11 tracks and scores of Metro-North Commuter Railroad trains during the morning rush. No one was hurt, but as the chaos of delays from the derailment began to subside, a bomb scare emptied the cavernous terminal. The incidents led to a domino-tumble of reroutings, cancellations and delays.

title: St. John's Conducts Review Of Athletes' Las Vegas Trip
description: Officials at St. John's University are trying to determine who paid for a trip its two best basketball players took this summer to Las Vegas, Nev.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: BATON BROADCASTING IS ADDING BUSINESS OF ELECTROHOME
description: Baton Broadcasting Inc. said late on Thursday that it would acquire the broadcasting business of Electrohome Ltd. in a stock-and-cash transaction valued at almost $79 million. For Baton, the acquisition solidifies its position as the single largest shareholder in Canada's No. 2 national television network, CTV. Baton's stake in CTV will rise to 42.9 percent from 28.6 percent. State-owned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation operates the largest TV network in the country. Baton will issue 8.3 million common shares to Electrohome and $35 million (Canadian) in cash less the cost of buying back one million of its shares. At yesterday's closing price of $10 (Canadian), up 20 cents, the 8.3 million Baton shares are worth $83 million (Canadian).

title: 28 Derailments in 13 Years, But Nearly All Are Minor
description: In its 13-year history, Metro-North Commuter Railroad has had 28 derailments, Federal officials said yesterday, after a train derailed as it approached Grand Central Terminal.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Chronicle column in some editions yesterday about the 30th reunion of journalists from The New York Herald Tribune included a name incorrectly on the list of former Tribune staff members who attended. Seymour Krim, an arts critic, died in 1989.

title: Isringhausen Needs Surgery On Right Arm
description: What was supposed to be the foundation for the Mets future is starting to become quicksand. Instead of being something the franchise can build on, the Mets pitching staff is sinking deeper into uncertainty.

title: Surviving a Scandal By Just Doing Her Job
description: Not long after her husband, Dick Morris, had become the talk of the country, Eileen McGann gathered a few other lawyers for a strategy session that went late into the night.

title: Republicans to Seek Ouster of F.B.I.'s Counsel in Files Matter
description: House Republicans who have been investigating for months how the Clinton White House improperly acquired as many as 900 confidential F.B.I. files plan to call for the resignation of the bureau's general counsel, Howard Shapiro, over his role in the matter.

title: Sunday's Stupor Bowl
description: The press is having a wonderful time with tomorrow's game between the New York Jets and the New York Giants, two allegedly professional football teams with a combined record of 0-6. One headline writer called it the ''Loser's Bowl.'' The fans are even more derisive. ''This game is a dead heat,'' said Walter Becker of Massapequa, L.I., ''with the key word being dead.'' Another predicted that if one of the two teams failed to show up, the other would surely score in the first five minutes.

title: An Attack in Black and White on Clinton's Drug Policy
description: This is a 30-second television commercial called ''School,'' released yesterday by the Dole/Kemp campaign committee. It will be broadcast today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a crackdown on morals in Iran misspelled the given name of an Iranian newspaper editor, and gave him a religious title incorrectly. The editor is Ataollah Muhajerani; he is not a clergyman with the rank of ayatollah.

title: Veterans of Army Film Center in Queens Plan Reunion
description: It wasn't exactly ''Gone With the Wind,'' a film Lester Binger had watched dozens of times as he marched up and down the aisles of the old Loew's Kings movie palace in Brooklyn as an usher. In 1943, Mr. Binger, whose plan to open his own movie house was thwarted by World War II, found himself in the film library at Camp Stewart, Ga., booking a 20th run of ''Kill or Be Killed.''

title: Oilers Sign Lowe
description: The Edmonton Oilers, seeking to re-establish their winning ways of the 1980's, have signed defenseman KEVIN LOWE, an integral part of the franchise's five Stanley Cup victories.

title: Inquiries Into Report That Contra Rebels Sold Cocaine in U.S.
description: Two Government agencies have opened investigations into a newspaper's reports that the contra rebels supported by the C.I.A. had sold drugs in Los Angeles in the 1980's and used the profits in their war against Nicaragua's Communist Government.

title: Hard Calculus: Nazi Gold vs. Swiss Bank's Secrets
description: In these woeful times, spare a thought for the Swiss banker.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: Yeltsin's Ailments May Complicate Surgery
description: President Boris N. Yelstin has serious noncardiac medical problems that may complicate his coming heart operation, the head of the Kremlin medical center acknowledged today.

title: Battle Shifts to Character Issue as Clinton and Dole Ads Duel Over Drug Abuse
description: The Presidential campaign battle shifted to character yesterday, as the Dole and Clinton camps used the issue of teen-age drug abuse to deliver a broader message about their opponents.

title: Annabella, 86, Film Actress Known for Playing Gamines
description: Annabella, a film star with flashing eyes who became the toast of France in the 1930's, died on Wednesday at her home in Neuilly-sur-Seine, a suburb of Paris. She was 86.

title: Seemly Vs. Sexy On Screen
description: ''Sex and the Silver Screen'' is a six-hour account of the decades-long battle between permissiveness and censuriousness, or between prurience and primness, or between the artist and the bluestocking, or between the exploiter and the upholder of standards. However described, it is generous with flesh-and-frolic scenes from movies that were greeted with finger-shaking by some and lip-licking by others.

title: Songs From the Roots Of a 19-Year-Old Soul
description: When Fiona Apple performed her songs on Tuesday night at the Fez, she talked about being lonely at a new high school, about being treated as ''weird'' because she was quiet, about guilt after toying with someone's affections. ''I make art out of my anger and I make art out of my pain,'' she said. Explaining herself, she sounded her age: 19 years old. With her full lips and long hair, wearing a tank top knotted to reveal her pierced navel, she looked like song writing's answer to Liv Tyler.

title: Congress Plays Divorce Court
description: On Wednesday, our pro-family-values Congress passed a bill that sends this message to parents in the District of Columbia: If you lose a battle in a custody case, just snatch the child and take her abroad for at least two years. The court order will become void, and you will be forever immune from punishment for violating the court order.

title: U.S. Airlines Told to Stop Routing Flights Over Iran
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has issued an emergency order barring flights by United States airlines over Iran because, it said, the Iranian military installed antiaircraft missiles on the Iranian-Turkish border this month.

title: Chavez Bout Is Set
description: JULIO CESAR CHAVEZ will return to the ring for the first time since his loss to OSCAR DE LA HOYA when he fights Oct. 12 in Anaheim, Calif.

title: Commuter Chaos: Derailment, Then a Bomb Scare
description: After months of relatively smooth riding, with memories of last winter's blizzard-related breakdowns fading, 50,000 Metro-North commuters rode into another day of misery yesterday. A train derailed at a crucial switch point just outside Grand Central Terminal, blocking 11 tracks and scores of trains during the morning rush, and then a bomb scare emptied the cavernous terminal.

title: Year-Round Schooling: Forget About It
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Dole at Paramus
description: The candidates (or their surrogates) keep coming. Elizabeth Dole will make her first campaign stop in New Jersey since the Republican National Convention when she attends a rally at the Paramus Mall this afternoon. And on Tuesday, President Clinton is scheduled to attend a rally in Monmouth County. The site has not been selected, said Kathy Ellis, a spokeswoman for the Democratic State Committee. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Country Club Equality Bill
description: At some country clubs, women are barred from teeing off during certain hours and are kept out of all-male grills. Legislation that would forbid clubs from granting special privileges to men was approved Thursday by the Assembly Judiciary Committee and will be taken up by the full Assembly, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Masur the Modernist Gets To Show His Preferences
