description: Planners at the New York Philharmonic could not have anticipated all the consequences of the orchestra's grand commissioning project for its 150th anniversary, in 1992.

title: Don't Just Not Vote. Do Something About It.
description: To the Editor:

title: Townie Brings A Tale of Faith To a Seminary
description: OSCAR HIJUELOS grew up in Morningside Heights on a street surrounded by colleges and seminaries that never quite connected to the rest of the area. The Union Theological Seminary seemed to him like this ''big place that was there,'' where serious-minded folks pondered the world at a safe distance behind thick stone walls.

title: Dr. Kenneth Warren, 67, Expert On a Parasitic Tropical Disease
description: Dr. Kenneth S. Warren, a former director of health sciences at the Rockefeller Foundation and a prominent researcher of tropical diseases, died on Wednesday at his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 67.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arrival of reinforcements for the American garrison in Kuwait misidentified one unit deployed. It is the Second Battalion, 12th Cavalry, not the 212th Cavalry.

title: Shield the Taxpayers In New Welfare System
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Species Extinct
description: The old-fashioned political reporter is going the way of the chestnut tree. Nowadays the only political reporting that gets any attention -- including attention from old-fashioned political reporters -- is public opinion polls.

title: A Never-Ending Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Shifting World View
description: Bob Dole offered criticism, then limited support and, finally, more criticism of President Clinton for his response to Saddam Hussein earlier this month.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deal on Mental Health May Affect Employers

title: Snapping Decision Done for Defense
description: The Giants made a minor shake-up on special teams today, demoting the long snapper, Moses Regular.

title: Company Briefs
description: EPIC DESIGN TECHNOLOGY INC., Sunnyvale, Calif., which develops simulation and analysis software tools, agreed to acquire Cida Technology, also based in Sunnyvale, a developer of layout verification tools, for $3.75 million in cash and 810,000 Epic Design shares, worth $18.9 million at yesterday's closing price.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: EXPERTS FORESEE HEALTH PLAN SHIFT FOR MENTAL CARE
description: Experts on employee benefits said today that Congress's decision to expand health insurance coverage for the mentally ill would prompt tens of thousands of businesses to revise their health plans in ways that go far beyond what is required by Congress.

title: Fox Reacts Angrily to Move By Time Warner on Cable
description: Time Warner's cable television company has decided to carry NBC's new news channel and not one being started by the News Corporation's Fox Inc. The move enraged Fox executives, who yesterday accused the Time Warner chairman, Gerald Levin, of breaking a fully negotiated agreement.

title: Showcase High School Delays Opening to Make Repairs
description: The High School for Cooperative Technical Education was to begin classes next Tuesday in a newly renovated building on East 96th Street -- a multimillion-dollar showcase with the latest technology in vocational education. Instead, the Board of Education yesterday ordered that the opening be delayed after an inspection by the United Federation of Teachers found numerous building violations it deemed dangerous to teachers and students.

title: America Online Wins Appeal on Mail
description: America Online Inc. won a Federal court appeal today giving it the right to resume blocking electronic junk mail to its subscribers from Cyber Promotions Inc., at least for now.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ACQUISITION REPORT ADVANCES LEHMAN BROTHERS STOCK
description: Shares of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. rose yesterday after Business Week reported that the firm was in talks to be acquired by a New York bank. Shares of the New York-based investment bank, the nation's fourth-largest securities firm, closed at $22.75, up $1.125, on trading of 1.8 million shares. The takeover talks were reported in Business Week's ''Inside Wall Street'' column, which cited an anonymous investment banker. Lehman's shares would be worth $40 in a buyout, the banker said. A senior Lehman executive denied that the firm was in takeover discussions.

title: Payback Time on Student Loans
description: In Chicago, President Clinton set the nation's sights high when he declared that ''by the year 2000, the single most critical thing we can do is to give every single American who wants it the chance to go to college.'' To make that possible, it is essential that we take steps to preserve the integrity of the Federal student loan program, which has issued about 90 million loans since 1965.

title: For Gooden, It's a Matter Of Faith
description: DWIGHT Gooden last night offered an assessment of yet another significant outing on his comeback trail.

title: Yankees Waste an Encouraging Outing by Gooden
description: Even if it was just for one night, even if it was just a tease, even if it was just so his inspiring story would not finish abruptly in September, Dwight Gooden's weary right arm came back to life for five innings. Gooden saved what is left of his season with a gutsy performance last night that assured him of pitching again.

title: F.T.C. Drop Case Against Big Publishers
description: Seventeen years after starting an antitrust investigation, the Federal Trade Commission quietly closed a case yesterday involving six major book publishers without deciding if they discriminated against independent bookstores by selling discounted books to major chains.

title: An Italian Celebration
description: To the Editor:

title: Quiet in the Kitchen! Jazz Is Being Recorded
description: When the bassist Charlie Haden and the pianist Kenny Barron took the stage at Iridium for Wednesday night's late set, they locked into the changes of an unrecognizable piece, taking on a subdued, intense manner. The duo is getting ready to record a live album for Verve records: the tape recorders will be rolling through the weekend at the club.

title: Clinton's Backers Perceive A Variety of Sides to Him
description: Bill Clinton is a force for change, and he is a guardian against change. He is a sophisticate in global affairs, and he is a good ol' boy out of ''The Dukes of Hazzard.'' He is courageous and sincere, and he is poll-driven and slippery but effective.

title: In Australia, Signs of Artists Who Predate Homo Sapiens
description: Out in the remote tropics of northwestern Australia, where a 130-foot-high sandstone monolith rises starkly above the wooded plains, archeologists say they have found the rock face and many surrounding boulders engraved with thousands of circles, the work of people some 75,000 years ago.

title: Keeping Guns Out of School
description: Once again, New York judges have created a legal and political tangle over the contentious Fourth Amendment issue of when to throw out evidence on the ground that it was obtained by an illegal search. The setting this time is a New York City public school. A state appeals court ruled this week that a 15-year-old student should not have been suspended in 1992 for carrying a loaded weapon to a Bronx high school, since the gun was found during an illegal search. The case is important for New York, and for other cities plagued with school violence. The pressing need is for a higher court to clear up the muddle in a way that is legally sound, respectful of student rights and, most important, supportive of the authority of school officials.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: P.S.A.L.

title: Americans Lead Solheim Cup
description: The weather shifted from blustery and foreboding to still and soothing -- and so did the momentum.

title: Beliefs
description: Marco Politi, a professional Pope-watcher, was in New York for about 48 hours this week. He had come from traveling with the Pope in Hungary and was heading back to travel with the Pope in France. He was in New York for the publication of a book about, you guessed it, the Pope.

title: COKE SHARES FALL AFTER 3D-QUARTER FORECAST
description: The shares of the Coca-Cola Company fell yesterday in heavy trading after the company said third-quarter sales would fall short of expectations, mainly because of sluggish sales in Europe. Coke, the world's largest beverage maker, said it expects case sales of its soft drinks would rise 6 percent to 7 percent in the third quarter, less than the 7 percent to 8 percent range analysts had expected. The Atlanta-based company said it still expected to match Wall Street's third-quarter earnings forecast of 38 cents a share, based on the average estimate from 14 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Coca-Cola shares fell 87.5 cents, to $51.125, in trading of 7.7 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Happy 75th Birthday, Jon Hendricks
description: To open its season, Jazz at Lincoln Center created a show that was uncharacteristically aimed at jazz's pop side. A celebration of the singer Jon Hendricks's 75th birthday, the concert hustled to the stage singers who work in the area between pop and jazz, including Manhattan Transfer, Bobby McFerrin and Al Jarreau. Tony Bennett made a short appearance, and the whole performance, overseen by Mr. Hendricks, was a reminder that vaudeville and jazz were once good friends.

title: Regents' Vote Turns Aside Voucher Plan
description: The New York State Board of Regents yesterday rejected, at least for now, an experimental voucher program under which parents could remove their children from the worst public schools and send them to parochial schools.

title: Lewis Replaces Primis as President of Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that its 50-year-old president and chief operating officer, Lance R. Primis, had resigned. He will be replaced by Russell T. Lewis, the president and general manager of The New York Times newspaper.

title: North Korea Infiltrators Still Elude Search
description: Thousands of South Korean troops combed rugged hillsides for a third day today for the survivors from a group of North Korean commandos who infiltrated the country on Wednesday. But they proved elusive, and the authorities warned that most of them are probably disguised in South Korean military uniforms.

title: Blue Cross Questions Purchase Of Ohio Plan by Columbia-HCA
description: The national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association suggested yesterday that Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield was not getting full value for the main business lines that it has agreed to sell to the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation for $299.5 million.

title: The Prisoner of Japan's Great Expectations
description: The train carrying Japan's most famous young couple chugs into the station and out comes Princess Masako, all charm and elegance in a pale-green suit, waving to her picture-snapping fans and walking briskly, two steps behind the Crown Prince.

title: Stepfather Held in Death of Bronx Girl
description: The police yesterday arrested the stepfather of a 2-year-old Bronx girl who had been beaten to death and charged him with murder and manslaughter.

title: Gold Off on Possible I.M.F. Sale Of Supply to Aid Poor Countries
description: Gold prices fell yesterday on the Comex Division of the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concern that the International Monetary Fund would officially announce a plan to sell five million ounces of gold to help pay debts of the world's poorest countries.

title: SEAGRAM PLANNING TO BUY BACK UP TO 3% OF STOCK
description: The Seagram Company, the beverage and entertainment powerhouse, said yesterday that it would buy back up to 11.1 million shares, or 3 percent of the company's outstanding stock. The shares will be purchased in open-market transactions over the next 12 months beginning Sept. 27, the Canadian company said. Seagram's previous stock buyback program ends Sept. 26. Under that plan, the company bought back 4.9 million shares as of Sept. 13 at an average price of $32.62 each. On the New York Stock Exchange, Seagram shares were up 50 cents yesterday, at $35.25.

title: 3 Doses Of Paranoia In One Evening
description: Getting into an ''X-Files'' groove, NBC has reshaped its Saturday night lineup with three new hourlong dramas exploring, in very different ways, the parameters of contemporary paranoia.

title: Tillman Faces Charges
description: HENRY TILLMAN, a former heavyweight boxer and 1984 Olympic gold medalist, was returned to Los Angeles from state prison yesterday to face murder charges. Tillman, 36, was awaiting trial on credit-card fraud charges when he allegedly shot Terreance Thomas to death on Jan. 10 outside a Westchester, Calif., nightclub. Tillman was charged with murder and attempted murder late Thursday. (AP)

title: Jets Opt for the Patience That Paid Off in 1981
description: The Jets' president was too patient, screamed the fans and the back pages, with his underachieving team.

title: Democrat Says G.O.P. Buries Report on Gingrich
description: The senior Democrat on the House ethics committee today accused the Republicans who control it of burying charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paul Draper, Aristocrat of Tap Dancing, Is Dead at 86
description: Paul Draper, whose stylish tap dancing to classical music made him an international star in the 1930's and 40's, died yesterday at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 86.

title: Video May Lead to a Case Against Kevorkian
description: A woman who died last month, ostensibly of natural causes, has unexpectedly turned up on one of the videotapes that Dr. Jack Kevorkian routinely records with those whom he is about to help commit suicide.

title: QUEST CAPITAL IN DEAL TO BUY CODY ENERGY CANADA
description: The Quest Capital Corporation said yesterday that it agreed to buy Cody Energy Canada Inc., a private oil and gas company, for about $70.8 million. Quest Capital, a merchant bank in Vancouver, British Columbia, said the transaction was scheduled to close on Oct. 31. Cody is based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Review of Youths' Jailing
description: The Ocean County Prosecutor's office will review an incident in which two 16-year-old soccer players from Pinelands High School in Little Egg Harbor were placed in a juvenile detention center overnight after a fight at a soccer match, officials said yesterday.

title: Legless Man Faces Charges For Killing A 'Bully'
description: A 67-year-old double amputee was charged with two counts of second- degree murder yesterday in the shooting of a man who was bullying residents of an Upper West Side neighborhood, a spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office said.

title: Judge Attacks Ballot System's Failures
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that the widespread foul-ups in last week's primary elections in Brooklyn had interfered with many people's right to vote, and he assailed the system that led to the failures.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with the film review of ''Surviving Picasso'' misidentified the actress shown with Anthony Hopkins. She was Diane Venora, not Natascha McElhone.

title: Dole Offering Book on His Economic Plan
description: Hoping to jump-start public interest in the centerpiece issue of their campaign, Bob Dole and Jack Kemp today released a book on their economic plan.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Jobless Rate Holds Steady
description: The unemployment rate in New Jersey remained at 6.1 percent in August for the fourth straight month, but still remained one percentage point above the national rate, the state Department of Labor said yesterday. The private sector gained 5,400 new jobs, said Kevin Smith, a spokesman for the department, but that gain was partially offset by the loss of 2,900 government jobs, he said.

title: Greek Orthodox Prelate Enthroned Today
description: A new era for Greek Orthodox Christians in the United States begins today, when Archbishop Spyridon, the first American-born prelate appointed to lead them, is enthroned in New York City.

title: Bond Prices Little Changed Ahead of Fed Policy Session
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly higher yesterday as dealers and traders squared positions ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting next week to consider interest rates.

title: Ethics Panel Clears Senator In Stock Deal
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today that the Senate Ethics Committee had cleared him of wrongdoing for any special treatment he may have received from a Long Island brokerage firm that earned him a $37,125 profit in a stock trade in one day in 1993.

title: For Bosnian Serbs, Room for Dissent Appears to Be Opening Up
description: Among the hundreds of recently discharged soldiers gathered with their dates at the regional headquarters of the Bosnian Serb army here, the news that opponents of the Serbian ruling party have done surprisingly well in Bosnia's elections brought a good deal of optimism.

title: A Ford Is Seen As Candidate For Chairman Of Auto Maker
description: The Ford Motor Company's board has decided that Alexander J. Trotman, the chairman and chief executive, will remain for at least a year after he turns 65 in July 1998, and is considering a Ford family member to replace him then as chairman, people close to the company said today.

title: A Banished Kingdom
description: What makes the theater thrilling and what makes it so poignant are one and the same. The performance you see tonight is unique, but once it is over it is gone forever, to live in the memory of its audience, then slowly die.

title: Don't Forsake the Kurdish Refugees
description: The collapse of the safe haven in northern Iraq has once again left the Kurds facing betrayal and peril. Although the United States has evacuated more than 2,000 people directly associated with the American Government, its moral obligations in the region are not over. There are still others whose lives are in danger, including tens of thousands of Kurdish refugees and hundreds of Kurdish employees of private humanitarian groups.

title: Bridge
description: Four decades ago, a young insurance executive and an even younger professor of mathematics began making a mark on the national scene. From 1958 to 1966, Leonard Harmon, the executive, and Ivar Stakgold, the professor, twice represented the United States in world championship play and won four major national titles, the Vanderbilt Teams, the Spingold Teams, the Board-a-Match Teams and the Open Pairs.

title: Louisiana Primary Aids Democrat
description: One leading candidate for the United States Senate is accused of using campaign money to buy Napoleonic-era documents to decorate his office. Another has gained notoriety by brandishing plastic fetuses as part of the abortion debates in the Louisiana Legislature. A third has maintained her front-runner status in most polls despite being called a liberal.

title: Panel Faults A-Plant Staff For Inaction On Problems
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that managers at the Millstone Point 3 nuclear plant in Waterford, Conn., were fairly good at identifying problems but ineffective at correcting them. The commission's conclusion, issued in a report, is another indication that the reactor's problems are still deep and that six months after it was closed, it is still months away from reopening.

title: Bernard King Named To Sports Authority
description: BERNARD KING, whose 16-year career in the National Basketball Association was marked by one scoring championship and stops with both the Nets and the Knicks, was appointed to the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority yesterday.

title: Whitaker Dispatches Rivera, and Doubters
description: It was a rematch, but for Pernell Whitaker, it was redemption.

title: Salo and Isles Blank Devils
description: Jason Holland, Chris Taylor and Craig Fisher scored as the Islanders defeated the Devils by 3-0 in an exhibition game tonight. Tommy Salo earned the shutout on 20 saves.

title: Convicted in Student Murder
description: Cindy Del Carmen Villalba, a senior at Rutgers University, had just returned from a six-week trip to Costa Rica and was out for the evening with a friend when, prosecutors say, a 17-year-old youth leaned into their car and demanded money. When the students said they had none, the youth, Corey Miller, of Teaneck, fired a shot that struck Ms. Villalba in the heart.

title: As a Tax Break Closes, Some See Dire Consequences
description: The floodwaters left behind by Hurricane Hortense will recede soon, but it may take years for Puerto Rico to recover from the storm that scoured the United States commonwealth's economic landscape just weeks before.

title: Mosquitoes With Virus Are Found In Old Lyme
description: Mosquitoes that carry the potentially fatal Eastern equine encephalitis virus and that feed on humans have been found in two Connecticut communities, Gov. John G. Rowland announced today.

title: Turks, Opposing U.S., Urge Iraq To Take Control of Kurdish Area
description: Determined to crack down on Turkish Kurds who are waging a guerrilla war from camps in northern Iraq, Turkey is urging President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to impose his authority there.

title: A Paradise (and Hell) Regained
description: After seven years of restoration work, this craggy Umbrian hill town is about to unveil the most glorious of its artworks, the vast depiction of the Last Judgment by Luca Signorelli.

title: Dole's View of the World: Complex and Idiosyncratic
description: Early this month, Bob Dole accused President Clinton of ''weak leadership'' in failing to curb Saddam Hussein in northern Iraq. After Mr. Clinton took military action against the Iraqi leader, Mr. Dole backed away, saying, ''In matters like this, all of us think not as Republicans or Democrats, but as Americans.''

title: My Left Earlobe
description: I HAD come down to New York on the early-morning bus to deliver an overdue book manuscript to an editor.

title: The Shrewdest Team in the West
description: Doug Melvin, general manager of the Texas Rangers, answered the telephone in his hotel room in Anaheim, Calif., Friday but quickly hung up. ''I'm on the other phone,'' he said. ''We're flipping a coin for a possible playoff.''

title: Way Out West
description: In Robert Parrish's SADDLE THE WIND (1958), an intelligent little western about two brothers, John Cassavetes is a trigger happy extrovert and Robert Taylor, a gunfighter turned solid citizen. With his probing expressions Taylor (above with Julie London), in one of his final screen protrayals, makes us realize what a good restrained actor he was, although reviewers often ignored it. There's a grim showdown and the emphasis is on talk. Rod Serling's dislogue is excellent - blunt, thoughful and scathing, and the movie is admirably compact and well played, from the three stars to the affecting performance by Royal Dano in a sequence so strong that is almost cuts the picture in two - THURSDAY at 4 P.M. on TNT.

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Budapest
description: Budapest is a splendid city set on the Danube, so I like to start my day walking along the river embankment to Margaret Island. There, among the plane trees, is Central Europe's best year-round outdoor pool, the Hajos Alfred Nemzeit Sport Uszoda. Heated in winter, with steam rising from the clean blue water, this is where Hungary's swimming and water polo champs train, but the public is welcome. After a workout, stop at the kiosk in the newly tiled lobby for some Hungarian breakfast pastry and a hot lemon tea.

title: Liability Costs Curb Recreation At Town Parks
description: WHEN Amy Conway, a high school tennis player, twisted her knee in a match in Wilton 10 years ago, she touched off a protracted legal battle that now has municipal officials across the state worried that the liability costs of public recreation may skyrocket.

title: John W. Hunter 3d and Pia Babusis
description: Pia Babusis, a daughter of Grazina and Edas Babusis of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to John William Hunter 3d, a son of Marianne Lockwood of New York and the late Mr. Hunter Jr. Franklyn J. Engel, the town justice of Woodstock, N.Y., officiated at Mrs. Lockwood's house in Catskill, N.Y.

title: When Fact Is Stranger Than Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Boom And Boast
description: GEORGE BUSH'S re-election chances took a dive on July 30, 1992. That was the day the Government announced the economy had grown an anemic 1.4 percent in the second quarter of that election year, a statistic that played straight into Bill Clinton's argument that the nation was underperforming.

title: Sex Club Lives On in State's Cellar
description: New York State owns prisons, parks and bridges. Now add to its property manifest the Vault, which bills itself as the city's ''premier fetish-fantasy, safe-sex club.''

title: Dump Toxic Waste in Affluent Backyards
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Spot Escapes Auction Hammer
description: In July, it appeared the final chapter had been written on Augie's, a popular Upper West Side jazz club that had closed after it was seized by the State Department of Taxation and Finance for failure to pay $30,000 in outstanding warrants.

title: Missiles Aimed at Iraq Are Armed With Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline McCrady, John A. Rudolf
description: Caroline Field McCrady, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Duff McCrady of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to John Anthony Rudolf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Robert Rudolf of Sewickley, Pa. The Rev. Calvin Wilson performed the ceremony at the Shadyside Presbyterian Church.

title: Home Buyers Move Cautiously Back Into the Market
description: AS the economy and job market improve so does New Jersey's housing outlook as once-hesitant buyers tiptoe back into the residential market, which had fallen into the doldrums last winter.

title: Now Is the Time for Fresh Beans to Enliven Soups or Gratins
description: LATE summer is a peak time for fresh beans of all kinds. Shell beans -- cranberry beans, black-eyed peas, cannellini and lima beans -- are now available at farmers' markets, and they are wonderful in gratins, cooked in soups, made into purees or tossed in salads.

title: PEROT, ALONE
description: INVITED ONLY A WEEK EARLIER BY THE LEADERS OF ROSS PEROT'S fledgling Reform Party, Richard Lamm received a rousing reception for his June 1 speech at the California State party gathering. Afterward, a reporter asked the former three-term Colorado governor if he had thought of running for President. He hesitated, then said he would consider it ''under the right circumstances.''

title: Just Do . . . Whatever
description: Got to feel sorry for Bob Dole.

title: Grim Reminders of a War
description: For years, the Pentagon said only a few hundred troops had been exposed to toxic chemical agents during the demolition of an Iraqi ammunition depot days after the end of the 1991 gulf war. But last week, it announced in a report that more than 5,000 American troops might have been exposed. The report, which suggested that two plumes of chemical agents wafted over troop positions, some 25 miles from the demolition site, is of interest to thousands of veterans who say they suffer lingering health problems. Researchers have suggested that low-level exposure to Iraqi chemical or biological weapons may be to blame, but the Defense Department has said it has no evidence of such a link.

title: Joanne Giasullo, M.R. Santangelo
description: Joanne Giasullo, a daughter of Johanna and Anthony Giasullo of Maplewood, N.J., is to be married today to Michael Richard Santangelo, a son of Ann Santangelo of East Hanover, N.J, and the late Dr. Richard G. Santangelo. Bishop Charles J. McDonnell of Newark is to perform the ceremony at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in South Orange, N.J.

title: Add Color and Mix
description: Since the 1950's, dressing dark has meant dressing hip. Now there is a bright alternative to the monochromatic look, with colorful shirts, sweaters and ties enlivening somber jackets and suits.

title: Parochial School Mystique
description: IN the 1950's and 60's, Roman Catholic schools were known as places where all students had to wear uniforms and bad students got their knuckles rapped or their ears pulled by nuns. Except for a handful of institutions, particularly Jesuit schools, they were not regarded as academically superior to public schools.

title: Before Supermarkets and Shopping Malls, a Simpler Life
description: ''Does it tickle the sheep when you give it a haircut?'' That's the kind of question that comes up as 20th-century families get a lesson on 19th-century life at Historic Cold Spring Village.

title: In the World of Fashion, Leather Is Indestructible
description: THE leather dress sheathed the body like the proverbial glove. At strategic places, it was inset with lace panels that offered a glimpse of flesh.

title: Vicki S. Weiner, Joseph T. Koelbel
description: Vicki Suzanne Weiner, the executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation, and Joseph Thomas Koelbel, an architect with Goshow Associates in New York, were married yesterday on East 50th Street in Manhattan, overlooking the East River. Judge Jeffry H. Gallet, a Federal bankruptcy judge in the Southern District of New York, officiated.

title: The Fed Can Wait
description: The Federal Reserve is coming under enormous pressure, from inside and out, to raise interest rates when it meets Tuesday. It should resist. The economy is performing better than nearly any economist, until recently, would have predicted. Yet there is barely a whiff of the dreaded monster, inflation, that the Fed is responsible for slaying. The only supposedly ''troubling'' sign is that wages have begun to outstrip prices -- but that is actually a wondrous turnaround after decades of wage stagnation. Before the Fed clamps down, it ought to have a better reason than the fact that workers are, finally, enjoying fatter paychecks.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: TOURS

title: This Year, Old Favorites Mingle With the New
description: IT'S more than a $2 million leap from the Passage Theater in Trenton (this season's production budget: $99,000) to the McCarter in Princeton ($2.2 million). If the McCarter is the esthetic equivalent of a first-class ticket to a wellspring of civilization, Passage represents the eternal struggle of theater professionals to make do while making art.

title: Heather Castile, Tomas Krasuski
description: Heather Rain Castile, a daughter of Sondra and Rand Castile of Eastport, Me., was married yesterday to Tomas Louis Krasuski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Krasuski of Buffalo. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Greenoch Church, St. Andrews by the Sea, New Brunswick.

title: Warrior's Wardrobe
description: War brings out the best and the worst in men, not only in character but in battle garb. Few would argue that there is something about a man in a uniform. Unfortunately, impeccable tailoring and a trim fit don't always mean he is ready for combat, as the smartly attired British redcoats discovered. Often, uniforms were designed as much to frighten as to function on the field -- witness the armored knight or the samurai warrior. Then there's the kilt, an odd choice for fighting, even if the Romans did conquer the world in a paneled leather skirt.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'ANNIE' IS BACK

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 8 with an article about hotels in San Francisco misidentified one. It was the Milano, not the A.N.A. San Francisco.

title: Greyhound Cuts Fares For Long Distances
description: Greyhound Lines has significantly lowered fares for trips of more than 1,000 miles from more than 75 cities around the country. For example, a round trip between New York and Dallas has been lowered from $179 to $149. The fare between Chicago and Seattle was $290 round-trip, and is now $179; Minneapolis to Los Angeles one-way used to cost $139, and is now $99.

title: Goodbye, Ozzie and Harriet
description: SHE WORKS/HE WORKS

title: Tradition and Change as a Way of Life
description: AT a time when religious issues are often garbed political controversy, Rabbi Richard L. Eisenberg of Congregation B'nai Jacob in Woodbridge offers a new way of looking at Conservative Judaism.

title: Drugstores Go Marble for Marble
description: Six months ago, Bashir A. Suba, whose pharmacy and surgical supplies store sits at 104th Street and Broadway, was sure he would be out of business soon. Rite Aid was moving in diagonally across Broadway. The drugstore megalith, the largest in the country, even offered to buy him out and to hire him as the pharmacist.

title: Edward P. Lee and Susan S. Pease
description: Susan Sheldon Pease, a daughter of Mrs. Robert S. Yates and Walter F. Pease Jr., both of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Edward Pinckney Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Lee of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Lidabell Hunt Pollard performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of New Canaan, with the Rev. Vernon D. Miller, a retired Presbyterian minister who is the godfather of the bridegroom.

title: Sagaponack General Store Returns as a Cafe
description: A CHARACTER in ''Virgil the Frogboy Still Lives,'' a recent play at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor, asks, ''At the restaurant are there going to be real people like me, you know year rounders.'' A few miles down the pike is the Sagaponack General Store's cafe in Bridgehampton where life is imitating art.

title: Primers in Urbanism, Written in Cast Iron
description: THIS IS A TALE OF TWO BUILDINGS, OR OF two corporations, or of two attitudes, but definitely of one city. One building is old and may disappear; the other is new, so new that it has not yet been built. Both are (or will be) in lower Manhattan, and together their very different stories tell us all we might ever want to know about this moment in historic preservation.

title: Imaginary Friends
description: DANGEROUS PILGRIMAGESTransatlantic Mythologies and the Novel.By Malcolm Bradbury.515 pp. New York:Viking. $32.95.

title: Measuring Athletes' Level of Aggression
description: THE growing list of professional and former professional athletes who have run afoul of the law because of violent outbreaks does not surprise Dr. J. Morrow, a professor of psychology at Iona College who also serves as the Gaels' sports psychologist.

title: Valerie L. Ullman, Scott T. Taylor
description: Valerie Leah Ullman, a daughter of Katharine M. and Leo S. Ullman of Sands Point, L.I., was married last evening to Scott Thomas Taylor, a son of Barbara A. Desser of Bridgeport, Conn., and Charles T. Taylor of Miami. Edmund F. Bolella, a leader in the Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Hudson Theater in New York.

title: Putting In for Overtime: Cornell Stuns Princeton
description: Cornell 33, Princeton 27

title: Vera B. Lawrence, 87, Pianist And American Music Historian
description: Vera Brodsky Lawrence, a pianist, editor and historian of American music whose research helped bring the works of Scott Joplin and Louis Moreau Gottschalk to the attention of contemporary performers, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

title: Calling Betty Crocker
description: NAN WAS FEELING RECKLESS AND FOR ONCE, it wasn't the evening breeze ruffling her feathers. Usually a cool wind makes Nan shiver, and shivering makes her fret. But there she was on this cool September night, acting perfectly composed.

title: Dole Has to Make The Decided Think Twice
description: POINTING to a map of the United States on the wall of his office here, Scott Reed, Bob Dole's campaign manager, noted last week what he said were Bill Clinton's weak spots and summed up how his boss would capture the White House. ''Clinton is soft,'' he said gamely, ''and when he starts to fall, he's going to fall like a deck of cards.''

title: Child Alone
description: To the Editor: Thank you for your very useful article ''Sending a Child Alone on Flights'' (Practical Traveler, Aug. 4).

title: Max Manus, 81, Dies; Fought Nazis in Occupied Norway
description: Max Manus, a Norwegian resistance leader whose Oslo Gang sank so many German warships, blew up so many German planes and kept Norwegian spirits so high during the Nazi occupation in World War II that he became a national hero, died on Friday, The Associated Press reported. He was 81.

title: Managers May Change; What About Principles?
description: THE founders and managers of the Pax World fund, the country's oldest and largest socially responsible mutual fund, have decided to cash out, selling the company that manages the fund's $500 million of assets.

title: A 7th Ave. Campaign Goes to Washington
description: All week, trunks arrived from New York slated for unpacking at the National Building Museum. Tissue and tape, gaggles of models like Kate Moss and Amber Valetta, mounds of accessories and setup crews were a thunderous advance for the arrival of designers like Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan, Calvin Klein, Isaac Mizrahi, Linda Allard and Oscar de la Renta.

title: Hilary Robbins, William Goodman
description: Hilary Gilmour Robbins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Robbins Jr. of Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to William Louis Goodman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Louis Goodman of Montville, Conn. The Rev. Dr. David St. George performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Gag Order
description: The Irony of Free Speech

title: Signing Up a New Voter Here and a New Voter There
description: At the N.A.A.C.P. of the Oranges, even the cleaning man wasn't safe. He walked into the office and was promptly asked if he was registered to vote. He wasn't.

title: As Snow Falls in Tetons, Elk Temperatures Rise
description: The first snows of the year have fallen in the mountains that dramatically surround this luxury resort town, bringing summer to an abrupt halt and signaling the onset of autumn.

title: Festive Weekend, Sibelius to Chuck Berry
description: LEIF BJALAND, music director of the Waterbury Symphony, opens the season with a festival weekend at the Fine Arts Center.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: U.S. Eases Caution On Visiting Guatemala
description: The State Department has lifted its two-year-long warning against travel to Guatemala, but is still cautioning Americans about the possibility of violence.

title: An Old Wall Street Pro's Voice in the Campaign
description: A FEW years ago President Clinton's political advisers were fuming about Robert E. Rubin's relentless focus on satisfying America's bond markets, fearing that his insistence on cutting the Federal deficit would prove politically disastrous for his boss. But history gets rewritten quickly in Washington. And now some of those same advisers, rejoicing in the latest poll results, argue that the bond markets were in fact a proxy for a majority of American voters, who seem to have decided, in the last weeks of the campaign, that Bill Clinton deserves credit for his handling of the economy.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LYING ON THE COUCHBy Irvin D. Yalom.Basic Books, $25.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Manual for Terror

title: Roy Innis Defines Himself and Politics
description: Roy Innis is against school busing, affirmative action and gun control. He says ''political correctness'' is an extremely dangerous philosophy, and he defines himself as the biggest hawk on crime in America today.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: Blowing Away Homeless Blues
description: IT might be argued that the last thing Orette Ennis and Dovon Jones needed was trumpet lessons, living as they did in a homeless shelter. But the brothers, who are 9 and 14, respectively, might disagree. Especially after hearing original Louis Armstrong recordings from the 1920's, attending a Herbie Hancock concert in Greenwich Village and learning something about music theory and the history of jazz.

title: A Riverboat Jamboree For Iowa's Birthday
description: Eleven historic riverboats, including the Delta Queen, will converge along the Missis

title: The Memories Of a Dazed G.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: Michelle Korn, Christopher Mulshine
description: Michelle Christine Korn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard C. Korn of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Haigh Mulshine, a son of Kathleen Saxon of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Robert A. Mulshine of New York. Msgr. William A. Genuario performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: Craps 101 (a Noncredit Class)
description: THE dice tumbled and lay still. ''A 9 for the shooter! Shooter makes his point!'' Brian Guiliani called out like a peppy sports announcer.

title: When Scaffolding Covers a Cityscape
description: THE Buettner and Breslin families are not commonly ranked among New York's leading builders. Yet 300 or more of their structures are standing today around the city. Their businesses have spanned many decades. And countless sidewalks.

title: Who Says They're the Heavens If There's No Junk Food?
description: ''I miss things like potato chips and junk food,'' the astronaut confessed before being picked up late Wednesday by the space shuttle Atlantis from a Russian space outpost where she stayed for a half year -- seven weeks longer than planned, her return delayed by shuttle troubles and hurricane winds down below.

title: Fight Over Surgery for Girl Pits Family Against Courts
description: Three weeks ago, after doctors once again told Steve Stout that his 10-year-old daughter, Rachel, could die unless her severely ulcerated colon was removed, Mr. Stout told the nurses on duty at Children's Hospital that he wanted to take his sick child downstairs to watch the model train that whooshes through the lobby.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Pina Bausch Goes West to Prospect for Imagery
description: IT DOESN'T HAPPEN TOO OFTEN, but Pina Bausch managed to name her newest work, her first American commission, before its premiere in Germany last May. With a nod to the production's origins, the artistic director of the Pina Bausch Tanztheater Wuppertal dubbed the work ''Nur Du,'' the German translation for the title of the Platters' 1955 hit ''Only You.''

title: Bills Are Feeling Pain Of Kelly's Leg Injury
description: John Butler, the Buffalo Bills' general manager, was watching when quarterback Jim Kelly went down with a strained hamstring in practice on Thursday. He saw Kelly take the snap, fake a handoff, roll out, throw across his body, then crumple to the ground in pain.

title: Solicitations Rising for Costlier Galas
description: WITH government financing declining and competition for private charitable contributions on the rise, Long Island's nonprofit institutions are stepping up their fund-raising activities.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HEART AND SOULBy Liz Rosenberg.213 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace & Company.Cloth, $11. Paper, $5. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Don't Blame Jazzmobile For Post-Concert Troubles
description: To The Editor:

title: Academic Integrity And Animal Rights
description: Whereas I agree with Suzanne E. Roy's statement $(Letters, ''N.Y.U. Fined in Animal Research,'' July 28$) that the settlement agreement with New York University is by far the largest in the history of the Agriculture Department, the statement in Ms. Roy's letter that I acknowledged that ''politics'' prevented the Department of Agriculture from upholding the law is erroneous. Such a statement was never acknowledged or made by me. In fact, the letter that I sent to Dr. Jan Moor-Jankowski stated very clearly why the case was being closed. After review of all the evidence, we concluded that the evidence did not support a complaint for a violation of section 2.32 (c) (4) of the Animal Welfare Act regulations, e.g., retaliation for reported violations of the act.

title: Together Again: Two Women With a Multiplicity of Messages
description: HOLLY NEAR thought it would be nice if she and Ronnie Gilbert made another little concert tour after all these years. The idea came when Ms. Gilbert was about to turn 70, and for the occasion, Ms. Near, 46, arranged for the two folk singers to give an informal private concert with their two favorite pianists. It was recorded live, and then, presto! It turned into a 12-city tour based on the CD, titled ''This Train Still Runs.''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about investing in natural-history objects referred incorrectly to a recent purchase by the curator of the meteorite collections sold at the Phillips International Auctioneers and Valuers in New York City, and misspelled his given name. The curator is Darryl Pitt, not Daryl.

title: A Time To Applaud Creativity
description: Celebrating two new books, two film makers, a publishing house and the worlds of music and fashion.

title: Laura K. Werden, Michael D. Keller
description: Laura Katherine Werden, a daughter of Margaret Farrar of Collinsville, Conn., and Peter W. Werden of Avon, Conn., was married last evening to Michael Davis Keller, a son of Jacqueline and Dr. Barnes Keller of East Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. Robert A. MacDonald, a Methodist minister, officiated with Rabbi Evan Radler at the Ethel Walker School Chapel in Simsbury, Conn.

title: In One Death, Mirrors Of Our Times . . .
description: TUPAC SHAKUR'S DEATH -- FROM A drive-by shooting while he was on the way to an antiviolence-charity event in Las Vegas -- has confirmed everyone's biases. For those who think gangster rap sows violence, Shakur will prove that in hip-hop there's no gap between fantasy and reality, even among those constructing the fantasy. For those who see racism as an overwhelming force, his story can demonstrate that a successful, defiant black man faces insurmountable odds. In the entertainment business, he'll provide another parable about a performer trying to live up to his image. To young fans, he could become hip-hop's Kurt Cobain, killed by the torments he described.

title: Ted's Kids
description: Autumn's here. Time for children to ponder nature's eternal questions. Why do leaves fall? Why do geese fly south? And: After you drive an arrow into the side of an eight-point buck, what do you do next?

title: Downsizing The I.R.S.: A Net Loss
description: BOB DOLE'S recent campaign promise to downsize the Internal Revenue Service, and his support for reducing the number of I.R.S. ''bureaucrats'' by 30 percent by 1999, would seem to gladden the hearts of all us John Q. Taxpayers.

title: THE DO-IT-YOURSELF DEALERS
description: So, facing a desperation not unlike that of college graduates, with their degrees and resumes, looking for work, the baby-boomed art marketeers choose the bohemian survival route (''The Do-It-Yourself Dealers,'' by Ellen Pall, Sept. 1). But one does not see any refreshing art to go along with their inventive enterprise. Your cover of neo-dealers parades neo-Dada yet again, with its Coney Island/magic shop/ stage props/video games/ comic strip variation on predictable Warholism. The striking thing is the utter conformity of the radicalism presented.

title: Dynamite in the Can, But No Explosion
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Heat of Passion, What Will the Fed Do With Rates on Tuesday?
description: IN Tuesday, the seven governors of the Federal Reserve and the presidents of the Fed's 12 regional banks will gather in the board room at the central bank's Washington headquarters.

title: Where Have You Gone, Ted Williams?
description: Full House

title: Balloons and Baskets, Riders on the Wind
description: IT was another miserable morning in Plainville. The fog was thick and close to the ground. At Norton Park, several hundred sleepy-eyed spectators watched anxiously as a score of gaudily-colored canvas mastodons stood motionless, waiting for the sky to clear.

title: Crime Rates May Be Down, but the Problem Stays Hot With Politicians, and Voters
description: There is nothing unusual in Tampa about Ed W. Block's belief that crime is just about the biggest problem around.

title: One Faithful Rider Still on Brown Bandwagon
description: Tommy Hodson was bleeding from the chin, and his forearm was bruised and purple from being hit more than a dozen times. The year was 1990, and Hodson was the backup quarterback of the New England Patriots, a team that would crash to a 1-15 record and become known as one of the worst National Football League teams ever. In a rare moment of public frustration after yet another loss, Hodson shook his head and blurted to a reporter, ''All I want is a chance.''

title: Notre Dame's Late Kick Leaves Texas Deflated
description: The kid dubbed ''Foul Ball'' by his coach because he misses so many field goals in practice -- became a hero today.

title: Madeleine Albright's Audition
description: Under a warm late-afternoon sun, two middle-aged American women in smart pants suits slip out of their Prague hotel and stroll across Old Town Square. Trailed at a discreet distance by Secret Service agents, they study the clock on the 15th-century Town Hall, do some window shopping and walk into Wenceslas Square, where a protest rally in 1989 sparked the country's Velvet Revolution and the fall of Communism. They talk about their children, the professors they had at Wellesley College, walking, eating and vitamins. Madeleine Korbel Albright and Hillary Rodham Clinton are clearly having a good time.

title: Denial and Taboo Blinding India To the Horror of Its AIDS Scourge
description: The giant tamarind trees spread a lush umbrella across the highway here, 75 miles from Calcutta on the main road between India and Bangladesh. The shade is the only forgiving thing about Petrapole, where grimy trucks stretch fender to fender for miles, often waiting a week or more before moving across the Broken Boat River to Bangladesh.

title: On an Island, Barely, in Greece
description: THE word Poros, which means ''passage,'' is an apt name for that little Greek island, which is separated from the mainland by only 800 feet of water.

title: Classical Briefs
description: MAHLER: SYMPHONY NO. 6

title: WHEN CLOTHES BECOME YOU
description: There is, as in all things fashion-related, good news and bad news regarding that latest trend in men's clothes: the uniform.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Paradise Recycled
description: BUSHWHACKING YOUR WAY THROUGH THE COSMETICS section of your favorite department store, you can't help but notice a profusion of shampoos and lotions made with rain-forest ingredients. At the dawn of this century, when Joseph Conrad wrote ''Heart of Darkness,'' a rain forest was a jungle full of disease and dark doings where ''vegetation rioted on the earth and the big trees were kings.'' Immense and robust, it was a fitting metaphor for the primitive forces in man's own nature. But in less than 100 years, having destroyed over half of it, the rain forest is now seen as a fragile thing, not menacing but nurturing and cuddly. By drawing a macaw and an orchid on a label and assigning an appropriately jungle-sounding name, cosmetics companies are tapping into warm, fuzzy feelings about rain forests and a variety of ambient myths.

title: Kathleen Murphy And John Gisondi
description: Kathleen Maura Murphy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Murphy of Churchville, Pa., was married yesterday to John Carroll Gisondi, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John G. Gisondi of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Laurence D. Ryan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Philadelphia.

title: Kimberly J. Stolz, Randall J. Irwin
description: Kimberly Jayne Stolz, the daughter of Ann A. Glew and the stepdaughter of David R. Glew of New York, was married yesterday to Randall Jay Irwin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Irwin of Seattle. The Rev. Stephen Bauman, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Christ Church in New York.

title: Growing Up Just Means Having More Expensive Toys
description: THERE are guys out there who would vote for two cars in every garage, if one of the cars was a Porsche. But some of these guys, having graduated to more generously cut suits and fatter wallets, now crave costly, complicated playthings like penthouses, wine cellars, airplanes and helicopters. Porsches, too. Though Jaguars will do.

title: Two Ways to Belong in America
description: This is a tale of two sisters from Calcutta, Mira and Bharati, who have lived in the United States for some 35 years, but who find themselves on different sides in the current debate over the status of immigrants. I am an American citizen and she is not. I am moved that thousands of long-term residents are finally taking the oath of citizenship. She is not.

title: North Korean Dangers
description: North Korea, secretive and belligerent, persists in menacing its South Korean neighbor and mystifying the rest of the world. Washington has wisely sought to entice Pyongyang out of its dangerous isolation in recent years. But those attempts have now been complicated by reports that some American prisoners of war captured during the Korean War may not have been returned as promised after the 1953 armistice and by a reckless and provocative North Korean attempt to infiltrate armed commandos into South Korea by submarine.

title: Running a 'Master Charity' of Donors
description: WHEN a former F.B.I. agent from Scarsdale, dying of cancer, wanted to set up a fund to support nursing scholarships, he turned to the Westchester Community Foundation. When a Westchester family sought to set up a fund in memory of their 20-year-old daughter who died eight years ago in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, they also turned to the foundation. And so, too, each year do a number of other donors who are looking to set up something permanent.

title: Why Are We in Korea?
description: TRIPWIRE

title: English Only Wouldn't Have Helped Anyone
description: County Executive Robert J. Gaffney's veto of the bill $(''E Pluribus Unum? (or Something),'' Sept. 15$) that sought to establish English as the official language of the County of Suffolk was a victory for human rights and for all of Suffolk's residents. Mr. Gaffney should be commended for sending this strong message of welcome and inclusion to all of Suffolk's residents by his veto of this legislation. Clearly, English is the language of our nation. It is the language of our governments, courts, schools and businesses. The adoption of the ''English Only'' resolution would not have increased the English proficiency of even one person. To the contrary, by enacting such legislation, the legitimacy of bilingual assistance, aids upon which many Hispanics and Asians depend and aids that have long been supported by the Jewish community, would have been called into question. The ''English Only'' legislation would have placed unnecessary restrictions on Suffolk County activities and on its citizens, and was a divisive force that would have served to further polarize our community.

title: An Ordinary Bigot
description: ABOUT SCHMIDT

title: Punmeister
description: ''I COULD NEVER watch 'The Wizard of Oz' in toto,'' writes Gary Muldoon of Rochester to the would-be global punmeister, adding an apologetic postscript: ''Sari.''

title: Dole Sees Symbol in the Failed Health Plan of the President
description: Bob Dole today invoked President Clinton's failed effort to overhaul the nation's health care system as the ''defining moment'' of his Presidency, saying it symbolized Mr. Clinton's dedication to big and expensive Government programs.

title: HAS ANYBODY SEEN THE DEMOCRATIC PARTY?
description: As a Canadian citizen, I was intrigued by Richard N. Goodwin's ''Has Anybody Seen the Democratic Party?'' (Aug. 25). I agree with him that the party has shown considerable flexibility in what some consider a move to the right, but I disagree with his unflattering conclusion that it represents a false step. Flexibility and moderation -- on the part of conservatives and liberals alike -- are the qualities that will enable us to meet today's social and economic challenges.

title: Traveling by Ferry, Once Common in New York Harbor, May Be Again
description: There was a time when the air was filled with the whistles and toots of more than a hundred ferries crisscrossing New York Harbor. Men and women still dressed for dinner. People wrote with fountain pens and rode trolleys to work. With the advent of bridges and tunnels, however, the ferries all but disappeared.

title: How Long Can Rap Survive?
description: When he was gunned down in Las Vegas, the rap star Tupac Shakur was under contract to Death Row Records, the West Coast juggernaut that pioneered gangster rap, a wildly successful music made up of misogyny, hypermaterialism and open celebration of murder. If this sounds like a description of the ''Godfather'' trilogy, that's because it is; gangster rappers view the Corleone saga with biblical reverence. They have outstripped Mario Puzo by bringing their own legends to life -- recreating the street wars in song, music videos and especially in the way they live.

title: . . . In Another, a Reminder of Our Roots
description: ''IF I CAN'T PLAY IT, NOBODY can.'' With this terse retort, the rugged gentleman on a rural stage in a business suit and a cowboy hat, clutching a battered old Gibson F-5 mandolin, dispatched a persistent heckler one afternoon in 1961. He also recruited a new, awestruck, teen-age fan, me. On Sept. 9, legions of admirers around the world felt the great loss of that gentleman on stage, Bill Monroe, the 84-year-old father of bluegrass music.

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Moscow
description: Moscow has first-rate art museums, many good, if expensive, restaurants and more than its share of architectural wonders.

title: Immigrants' Daughter Who Embraced Malcolm X Keeps a Radical Flame Alive
description: In Yuri Kochiyama's most prized scrapbook, the copy of a Life magazine photograph shows the frenzy after Malcolm X was gunned down. As he lay on the Audubon Ballroom's stage, his white shirt turned red, a face stood out among the people surrounding him: the face of a woman in her 40's with the black, thick-framed glasses of the era, a face unmistakably Asian.

title: Heirs and Elders Out in the Cold
description: AFFLUENT Americans who are part of the so-called ''sandwich generation'' are concerned about estate planning and providing for adult children or aging parents, but are doing very little about it, according to a recent survey conducted for Massachusetts Financial Services.

title: Symphonists, Native and Fervent
description: IN THE American Centennial year 1876, the 21-year-old composer George Whitefield Chadwick heard the Symphony No. 1 by his fellow Bostonian John Knowles Paine and marveled that an American could have composed something so beautiful. ''It proved we could have a great musician and that he could get a hearing,'' Chadwick later recalled. ''To me there was something Godlike in the very name of Symphony.''

title: Pier Dog Run Draws Snarls of 'Anathema!'
description: West Village dog owners have long bemoaned the lack of open space where their pets can roam free.

title: Officials Received Threat to New York Aviation Last Fall
description: Several hours after a Federal jury convicted Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman last Oct. 1 of conspiring to bomb the United Nations building and other New York landmarks, American intelligence officials received an anonymous but pointed threat: a New York area airport or jetliner would be attacked as retribution for prosecution of the sheik.

title: On Canal Routes, the Mules Are Long Gone, but Not the Memories
description: A hundred and fifty years ago, a pair of canals crossed New Jersey from west to east. Mule teams pulled canal boats carrying loads up to 70 tons on trips that took up to five days.

title: Jill W. Alpert, Evan I. Seigerman
description: Jill Wendy Alpert, a daughter of Susan Sloan of Old Tappan, N.J., and Jeffrey Alpert of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to Evan Ira Seigerman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Seigerman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Matthew Hoffman officiated at the Marriott at Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Bluefish May Be Tasty, But They're Not Abundant
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra J. Shin, John P. Nabagiez
description: Dr. Sandra Jean Shin, the daughter of Dr. Young Soon Suh and Ki Ha Shin of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. John Paul Nabagiez, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Vladimir A. Nabagiez of Walden, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. James Bell performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: The American Chapter of the Jewish Saga
description: JEWS LIKE ME ARE FOND OF saying that any time three Jews get together you get four different opinions in one room. That in-joke with its own little edge is actually not very exclusive. Has anyone noticed a uniformity of opinion among Catholics? Or the Irish? Or blacks? Or Kurds?

title: The Woman in Their Lives
description: Wystan and Chester

title: Trash Ruling Affects 2 Counties' Bond Ratings
description: The recent Federal court decision that opened New Jersey's trash market to competition is taking its toll on the county agencies that handle garbage. On Wednesday, Standard & Poor's downgraded the bonds of the Union County Utilities Authority and the Camden County Pollution Control Financing Authority to BB, from A- and BBB+ respectively.

title: Southern Exposure
description: The Distance from the Heart of Things

title: Stanford White And His Life Under Scrutiny Of Descendant
description: Stanford White, the architect of the Gilded Age who was celebrated in life and notorious after death, is not as famous as he used to be.

title: Purchase College, the 25-Year-Old Experiment
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago this month, Purchase College officially opened during a downpour. The rain prevented 10 portable classrooms from being delivered to the unfinished campus, and the first entering class -- 170 third-year students who had transferred from other schools -- met under a tent.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HOPE'S CADILLACBy Patricia Page.Norton, $25.

title: Bosnia Holds Elections And Washington Exhales
description: The biggest surprise in Bosnia's election last weekend was what didn't happen. As expected, voters handed power to the existing leaders of Bosnia's three ethnic groups, creating a three-headed presidency -- one Muslim, one Croat, one Serb -- that must now govern together after four years of war. The election, however, passed with almost none of the violence that many had feared.

title: Bookshelf
description: WHEN I WAS YOUR AGE: Original Stories About Growing Up. Edited by Amy Ehrlich. Candlewick. $15.99. (Ages 9 to 14) In answer to the plea ''Tell me about when you were young,'' 10 distinguished writers -- including Katherine Paterson, Walter Dean Myers and Francesca Lia Block -- contributed tales true to the time and place of their own childhoods, if not necessarily absolutely factual. Rich and rewarding.

title: Newcomer Relishes Political Life
description: DR. RICHARD KLEIN felt like the forgotten man this summer, as two Republicans fought each other for the right to run against him for Congress in the 19th District.

title: No Headline
description: ''We were burned during the Civil War and shelled by the Union. We'll endure this, too.''

title: Little-Noticed Cut Imperils Safety Net for the Poor
description: A little-noticed provision in the nation's new welfare law that will immediately cut Federal money for safety-net services like soup kitchens and child protection programs has set off a struggle by state officials to preserve what they can.

title: Hollywood Blue
description: From the moment Thomas Edison shocked the public with May Irwin's unabashed kiss, the movie industry has become a battlefield for audiences who can't get enough of a good thing - and critics who believe some things are better left behind closed doors. SEX, CENSORSHIP AND THE SILVER SCREEN, a six-part documentary written and directed by Frank Martin - SUNDAYS at 8 P.M. on SHOWTIME - traces the evolution of sexuality in America film, from the silent-film vamp Theda Bara to Elizabeth Taylor (above) to the temptresses of ''Showgirls.'' Harrison Ford, Melanie Griffith, Marisa Tomei and Daryl Hannah recreate the voices of Hollywood lengends to chronicle the continuing clash between screen sexuality and censorship. Raquel Welch - who else? - is the host.

title: For Archie Manning, The Big Game Is Still the Big Game
description: Lickety-splitting the byways and bayous outside town, bound for Hammond, La., smack in the middle of it all last Thursday, Archie Manning said that even after all these years he could still feel and smell and taste it: Big Game Week.

title: Staples Isn't the Only Hot Trend in Selling Office Supplies
description: WHEN Staples recently announced a $3.4 billion stock swap to acquire Office Depot, many investors cheered. But if they turn their attention to another, far less familiar part of the $125 billion office-supply market, they may find something equally enticing -- the section of the industry that does for companies what Staples and Office Depot do for the retail trade.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CLOWN

title: In the Driver's Seat
description: If you had superpowers and could change one thing -- and one thing only -- about how people drive in New Jersey, what would it be?

title: Blending Flavors From Tropical Islands
description: VSITORS to the New Britain Museum of American Art (which has a fine collection from the 1740's to the present) or the American Clock and Watch Museum (another intriguing stop for its collection of 5,000 or more timepieces) in nearby Bristol may be looking for a place to have lunch. Following are a few in the vicinity worth visitors' attention.

title: Charlotte Alston And John A. Legg
description: Charlotte Hunter Alston, a daughter of Dr. Alice Sanders Alston and the Rev. Dr. Wallace M. Alston Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Castine, Me., was married yesterday to John Anthony Legg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Legg of Brewster, Mass. The bride's father, a former senior minister of the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, performed the ceremony at St. Cuthbert's Chapel on MacMahan Island, Me.

title: Paintings Stolen in Queens
description: More than $100,000 in artwork was stolen from a Queens home during a burglary early yesterday, the police said. Officers from the 111th Precinct in Douglaston responded to a burglary call about 1 A.M., the police said, after an alarm system notified neighbors of a break-in. The owners of the home, on Horatio Parkway, told detectives that several paintings had been taken. Carmen Melendez, a police spokeswoman, said the homeowners estimated that the paintings were valued at more than $100,000.

title: Balkan Sorrows
description: IN THE HOLD

title: A Good Driving Instructor Made Surprise Appearance
description: To The Editor:

title: Miss Vanderslice And Mr. Duffy
description: Mary Elizabeth Vanderslice, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James T. Vanderslice of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to Sean Peter Duffy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Duffy of Waccabuc, N.Y. The Rev. Michael C. Palmer performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Renewing Broadway's Legendary Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Hammond, Mr. Lauterborn
description: Jennifer Ann Hammond, the daughter of Angela and John Hammond of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Theodore Lauterborn Jr., the son of Karen Lombardo and Mr. Lauterborn Sr., both of College Point, Queens. The Rev. Thomas O'Rourke performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Housing for Elderly Draws Developers and Buyers
description: IT has been exactly 10 years since the Town of Hempstead first began offering tax abatements in projects that provide moderately priced for-sale housing for older residents.

title: Midwood Gets Past Truman in Overtime
description: P.S.A.L.

title: Penny McLoughlin, David Deming
description: Marianne Penny McLoughlin, a daughter of Julia Anne McLoughlin of Garden City, L.I., and the late James Vincent McLoughlin, was married yesterday to David Riley Deming, the son of Dorothy Hill Deming of Menlo Park, Calif., and Willis Riley Deming of Oakland, Calif. The Rev. Frederick D. Hoesli performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Who'd Expect Such Blossoms From an Onion?
description: One of the loveliest flowers in the late spring garden is the one that arises from the overlooked leek.

title: Taking a Look Beneath The Greasepaint
description: NOEL COWARD'S red silk dressing gown, with monogram, hangs not far from the ballroom gown Julie Andrews wore in ''My Fair Lady'' in 1958. Around a corner and down the hall, a makeup artist is about to turn a teen-age girl into a wrinkled old woman. And when her transformation is complete, racks of flamboyant costumes await her on a nearby stage for an improvisational performance. All this can be found in a place that captures the essence of London's many theaters: the Theater Museum in Covent Garden.

title: Autumn of the Patriarchs
description: FALL is always a frenetic season for the State Legislature, but this year, its members face an especially daunting task. Both houses are supposed to put the finishing touches on a court-ordered plan to equalize spending in New Jersey's poorest and wealthiest school districts. And they must work fast.

title: Confessions of Father Pete
description: IT was the kind of weather tailor-made for a wake. As lightning streaked the night sky and sheets of rain turned Ninth Avenue into a muck-filled canal, the Rev. Peter Colapietro climbed the stairs of a funeral home in Hell's Kitchen, knelt before an open casket and whispered comforting words in the ear of an elderly Croatian woman burying her son, her only child.

title: The Population Of Woodmere
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOLARSHIPS FOR THE RICH
description: If there is a problem with need-based student financial aid, it is because tuition at some private colleges has reached levels that make even words like ''astronomical'' seem inadequate. A cynic might suspect that the tuition at some elite private colleges has nothing to do with costs. Like the price of many luxury goods, the cost of an Ivy League education has become part of its cachet.

title: Allow Disaster Victims a Lawyer-Free Interval
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WRINKLE ROOM
description: With the graying of the gay population, New York City has an increasing number of established ''wrinkle rooms.'' The GH Club, Regent's, Town House, Pegasus and Oscar Wilde come to mind. Had Holleran not wallowed in self-pity but explored these generally friendly bars, he would have discovered the ''gero'' phenomenon. Somebody -- actually, hordes of attractive young men -- seems to love you when you are old and gay!

title: News Summary
description: International 3-10

title: Love Story
description: Blue ItalianBy Rita Ciresi.287 pp. Hopewell, N.J.:The Ecco Press. $22.

title: Movies Much More at Home on the Small Screen
description: HOLLYWOOD WON'T NOTICE, but for a large chunk of the movie-watching public an event of no small significance is about to take place. On Oct. 1, ''Fargo'' will be released on videocassette.

title: New Life Insurance Isn't Always the Best Policy
description: IN a small auditorium in lower Manhattan last week, the New York State Insurance Department held its final hearing on a new regulation intended to combat deceptive practices in the selling of life insurance policies, a longstanding problem that has cost consumers millions of dollars.

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Making the most of a short stay
description: Amsterdam

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Geneva
description: Leave the blue-green lake, Geneva's glory, for the early afternoon when the autumn light is best, and start your sightseeing day in the Old Town. It is among the best-preserved ancient neighborhoods in all of Europe even though art galleries, boutiques and fake-English pubs are now ensconced in medieval and Renaissance buildings. Walk behind the haughty banking citadels on the Rhone embankment where the river rushes out of the lake and up the narrow, sloping Grand-Rue. A plaque at No. 40 marks the birthplace of Rousseau in 1712.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today:

title: The Only Place to Go Is Up (but Only One Can Go)
description: Finally, a team the Jets think they can beat. Or else.

title: Thai Premier Agrees to Quit After Debate In Parliament
description: Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa capitulated today to three days of battering in a parliamentary debate on a confidence motion and said he would resign within seven days.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 22, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Fiction 1 1 4 EXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) Vice President Jack Ryan has problems after the deaths of the President and most of the Cabinet, Congress, the Joint Chiefs and the Supreme Court. 2 2 6 SERVANT OF THE BONES, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $26.) A dark angel seeking redemption makes a perilous journey from ancient Babylon to modern Manhattan. 3 3 17 THE RUNAWAY JURY, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $26.95.) A woman in a Mississippi Gulf Coast town sues a tobacco company for causing her husband's death. 4 4 7 THE LAST DON, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $25.95.) The aging head of a Mafia family makes plans for his heirs' activities in Hollywood and Las Vegas. 5 1 JACK AND JILL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Alex Cross on the trail of serial killers at large in Washington. 6 5 10 CAUSE OF DEATH, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $25.95.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta investigates the mysterious death of a reporter. 7 7 16 FALLING UP, by Shel Silverstein. (HarperCollins, $16.95.) A young doctor encounters greed, corruption and medical miracles when she goes to work in a Boston hospital. 14* 1 THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN, by Jacquelyn Mitchard. (Viking, $23.95.) The courtship and marriage of John and Jacqueline Kennedy. 4 6 29 UNDAUNTED COURAGE, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The story of how Thomas Jefferson sponsored Lewis and Clark's exploration of the American West. (+) 5 5 125 MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga. (+) 6 11 7 DOMINIQUE MOCEANU: AN AMERICAN CHAMPION, by Dominique Moceanu as told to Steve Woodward. (Bantam, $14.95.) Factors other than I.Q. that contribute to a successful and happy life. (+) 10 14 14 OUTRAGE, by Vincent Bugliosi. (Norton, $25.) The reasons, according to the former Los Angeles County prosecutor, that O. J. Simpson was found not guilty. (+) 11 13 33 HOW COULD YOU DO THAT?! by Laura Schlessinger. (HarperCollins, $22.) Self-indulgent morality, and ways to overcome it. (+) 12* 12 11 THE CHOICE, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A behind-the-scenes account of Bill Clinton's and Bob Dole's activities over the past two years. (+) 13 9 20 IT TAKES A VILLAGE, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon & Schuster, $20.) The First Lady's quest for ways to help create a better society for children. (+) 14 3 2 BETWEEN HOPE AND HISTORY, by Bill Clinton. (Times Books/Random House, $16.95.) The President states his vision for America in the 21st century. 15 1 ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $24.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood amid the miseries of Limerick.
