Diets to prevent disease and enhance mental health. (+) 2 1 174 MEN ARE FROM MARS, WOMEN ARE FROM VENUS, by John Gray. (HarperCollins, $23.) Improving communication and relationships. (+) 3 3 25 SIMPLE ABUNDANCE, by Sarah Ban Breathnach. (Warner, $17.95.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+) 4 71 THE SEVEN SPIRITUAL LAWS OF SUCCESS, by Deepak Chopra. (Amber-Allen/New World Library, $14.) How to ''generate wealth in all its forms.'' (+)

title: Europeans Survive Americans And Wasp
description: It was early morning at the St. Pierre Golf and Country Club when a wasp struck the first major blow of the golfing day.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: To Track This Budget, You Need a Tape Measure
description: To the Editor:

title: Riding in Ireland
description: To the Editor: Hats off to you and Roxana Robinson, the author of ''Horses of Another Color'' (July 21), about the riding school near Adare in Ireland. I have visited and can easily picture the activities in the story.

title: Tax Amnesty Would Help Pay For Dole's Economic Plan
description: THE debate is under way as to whether the nation can pay for Bob Dole's proposed 15 percent across-the-board tax cut. But one important aspect of his economic plan that would help assure its success has gone virtually unnoticed -- a Federal tax amnesty program.

title: Private Property
description: SHAMANS, SOFTWARE, AND SPLEENSLaw and the Construction of the Information Society.By James Boyle.270 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:Harvard University Press. $35.

title: Red Sox and Yankees Wear a Path to Mound
description: From the sanctity of the Yankees' bullpen, far beyond the protection of the wall in left-center field, John Wetteland spent the better part of his Saturday afternoon watching a veritable hit parade of pitchers trot in -- and get bounced out -- of what would eventually become a 4-hour-45-minute track meet of a ball game.

title: Battling McPaper
description: THE CHAIN GANGOne Newspaper Versus the Gannett Empire.By Richard McCord.290 pp. Columbia:University of Missouri Press. $24.95.

title: Patchogue and Landlords at Odds Over Crackdown
description: THE State Attorney General's office is investigating a dispute between Patchogue and landlords in the village. The lawyer for a landlords' group, Robert Accomando, said the issue arose when the village took landlords to court over violations of the building code, and the landlords realized that they were being treated differently from other landowners.

title: Vanessa Montag, David S. Brosgol
description: Vanessa Emily Montag and David Scott Brosgol, associates at law firms in New York, were married last evening at the St. Regis Hotel in New York. Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler performed the ceremony.

title: Struggling Toward The Big Time
description: Correction Appended

title: Pink Walls, Greenbacks
description: WHEN Erik Grossman bought his condominium on East 65th Street, it had pink walls.

title: Police Officers. (Quick, Which Food Comes to Mind?)
description: IN an episode of ''The Simpsons,'' Police Chief Wiggum hears over the car radio that there has been an incident at a local restaurant. When his partner reminds him of the great doughnuts served at the establishment, the chief replies, ''Let's roll!''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Sept. 8 about the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art misstated the nationality of its designer, Mario Botta. As the article noted, he is Swiss, not Italian.

title: Asian Investment Is on the Rise in Los Angeles
description: JAPANESE investment in the top hotels and office towers in Los Angeles soared during the 1980's and then crashed with the real estate market in the early 1990's. Now, Asian investment is once again increasing, mainly from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Indonesia, driven partly by bargain real estate prices here and political uncertainty at home.

title: Cross of Steel
Arts Council Finds Internet Spot
description: AN inquiry from a college student seeking a summer job gave the Westchester Arts Council a vivid presence on the Internet. Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the Arts Council, said the group's 30-page site on the World Wide Web was largely the work of a summer intern, Candace Rand, a junior majoring in theater studies at Yale University.

title: Looking at Voters' Wallets, and the Candidates' Fingers
description: IF the polls are any indication, the old saw that people vote their pocketbooks remains valid. To help such readers, the October issues of three personal-finance magazines -- Money, Worth and Mutual Funds -- have articles examining the stances of Bob Dole and President Clinton on the economy.

title: The Lifeguards Are Gone, But Summer Lingers On
description: Most people may think summer is officially over, but the State Division of Travel and Tourism is trying to draw people to the Jersey Shore for a few more weeks. A spot check of authorities along the coast shows beaches will be unguarded but probably open to swimming.

title: Riding a Business Crest by Making Products Tamper Proof
description: EVER since the Tylenol tampering incident in 1982, consumers have been more aware of tamper-proof packaging. For Sharon Lobel, who had been working in the packaging industry since 1980, the well-publicized incident prompted her to research methods that would make it difficult to tamper with packaging.

title: A Film Puts the Spotlight on Hirschfeld and His Singing, Dancing Pen
description: A STUNNING AND (if you happen to be a cartoonist) personally demoralizing montage occurs in ''The Line King,'' the new documentary on the veteran caricaturist Al Hirschfeld. The film opens on Friday.

title: Ethics Code Stirs Question of Balance
description: TO Westchester's former Health Commissioner, it was simply a matter of moving from one job helping people to another. But to the County Board of Legislators, the question was whether Dr. Mark Rapoport had used a public-sector position to obtain a lucrative private-sector job with a company doing business with Westchester. In the end, it was determined that there was no breach of ethics on the Health Commissioner's part. What failed to pass muster was an outdated ethics code, which government leaders now agree needs to be overhauled.

title: Elizabeth S. Treanor, C.P. Conniff
description: Elizabeth Samantha Treanor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Treanor 3d of Washington, was married yesterday to Christopher Paul Conniff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Conniff of Brooklyn. Msgr. James F. Montgomery performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Washington.

title: The Truth About Gentle Ben
description: BENJAMIN FRANKLIN AND HIS ENEMIES

title: Mosquito Controls Returning
description: STATE legislators and Gov. John G. Rowland are promising the restoration of the state's mosquito-control program in the 1997 General Assembly session. But southeastern Connecticut residents are living with the risk of contracting a fatal or debilitating mosquito-borne disease, Eastern equine encephalitis, until the first frost.

title: Q. & A.
description: Removing A Lien on Property

title: All-Day Kindergarten Makes Inroads but Has Far to Go
description: In the early afternoon, the 5-year-olds at the Ridge Street Early Childhood Center haul out soft blue mats and doze for a spell. Napping, it seems, remains as essential to the kindergarten experience as singing, painting and story time.

title: Promises, Promises From Olin, But Its Stock May Deliver Yet
description: WALL STREET'S fabled impatience may spell a solid opportunity for investors in the Olin Corporation, the well-known maker of chemicals, brass and ammunition.

title: THE DO-IT-YOURSELF DEALERS
description: A business tip for the art dealer Kenny Schachter: After you have promoted a set of used tampons, a dismantled bed, a video recording and a painted shower curtain as works with a claim on the highest human faculties, it doesn't look good to complain that ''everyone in this country hates art.''

title: Persian Gulf Dividends
description: To the Editor:

title: Ivy Emerging Growth
description: SMALL stocks took a beating in June and July, leaving many investors unnerved. Still, these stocks are the choice of many long-term investors because smaller issues have tended to outperform bigger ones over time.

title: Victoria Miller, Gregory Smith
description: Victoria Hopkins Miller, the daughter of Mrs. Ross Arnold Miller of Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Miller, was married yesterday to Gregory Campbell Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Phillip Smith of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The Rev. Dr. James A. Kowalski performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: The Panthers' Plan Is Working
description: The owner (Jerry Richardson) wanted a first-class operation that would compete annually for the Super Bowl. The president (Mike McCormick) wanted a team with strong ties to the community. The general manager (Bill Polian) wanted a physical team that could make big plays and prevent them. The coach (Dom Capers) wanted a united, close, character-filled unit. The players, like all players, wanted to get paid, and to win.

title: A Spot for Sushi Lovers in White Plains
description: AJIYOSHI'S recently doubled and refurbished dining room and sushi counter attracts a clientele that keeps the place bustling from the hour the doors open to the moment they close. In the past the restraurant has been criticized for rude service, but these days the welcome could not be warmer. And the painfully sparse waiting staff of the reopening's early days is now in full complement, needing only somewhat better direction for smooth operation.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Gifts for the Dog or Cat Who Has Almost Everything

title: Academics and Labor Leaders Pulling in Tandem Once More
description: After a 30-year estrangement in which union leaders shunned academics as too far to the left and the liberal intelligentsia scorned big labor as part of the establishment, the two sides have begun efforts to forge a new alliance.

title: A Wretched New Class of Infected Untouchables
description: Tucked away in a corner of the Calcutta Medical College is what Indian doctors have described as the only AIDS ward in India -- a bleak, isolated place where, not long ago, two male patients were lying unattended atop iron beds on a concrete floor.

title: LiRon Anderson, Glenn Bell
description: LiRon Kenyatta Anderson, the daughter of Elizabeth Borden Anderson of Jamaica, Queens, and Kenneth R. Anderson of Elmont, L.I., was married yesterday to Glenn Evan Bell, the son of Vivian L. and Norris E. Bell of Westwood, N.J. The Rev. Odella B. Williamson performed the ceremony at Embury United Methodist Church in Queens Village, Queens.

title: Below the Beltway
description: The capital quaked at the news.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SHIPWRECKSBy Akira Yoshimura.Harcourt Brace, $21.

title: A London Sketchbook
description: Al Hirschfeld took a theater-lover's holiday in London last month, and of course he took along his sketch pad to capture his impressions of the scene. Shakespeare's fabled Globe Theater burned down 350 years ago; the reconstructed version, above, opened in August and was overrun by the press. Cameron Macintosh's $6 million-musical ''Martin Guerre,'' above right, which opened in July to mixed reviews, features Iain Glen (with sword) as the false Martin Guerre and Matt Rawle as the real one. Joanna Riding, right, plays Anne Egerman in ''A Little Night Music,'' by Stephen Sondheim, a smash hit for a year. As for classics: Eileen Atkins, below left, Vanessa Redgrave and Paul Scofield star in Ibsen's ''John Gabriel Borkman.''

title: Store Owners Catch Suspects And Say, 'Smile'
description: When Jean Valjean, the downtrodden protagonist of Victor Hugo's novel ''Les Miserables,'' was caught stealing a loaf of bread, he wound up serving 19 years hard labor in a dingy Parisian jail. Simon Michael, 25, an East Harlem resident who was recently accused of shoplifting several cans of infant formula, was a lot luckier. When employees at the Associated Supermarket at 103d Street and Madison Avenue discovered the cans under Mr. Michael's coat, he was made to stand with his back against a wall, forced to hold up the merchandise and told to smile for the camera.

title: The Accidental Revolutionist
description: NOT SO LONG AGO, PUBLISHERS REGULARLY put out books with titles like ''The New Music,'' ''Modern Music'' or ''Twentieth-Century Music.'' These were 150- or 200-page guides to what their authors believed to be the essential components of 20th-century music. They described the decay of the tonal system, the crisis of tonality in Wagner, the experiments of Debussy, the atonal revolution of Schoenberg and Stravinsky, Stravinsky's later Neo-Classical reaction and the eventual triumph of Serialism and the avant-garde after World War II.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: A UNIFORM VIEW
description: This season designers are paying homage to the handsome, functional uniforms of the armed forces, past and present. Olive and khaki jackets, trenches and topcoats display oversize pockets, metal buttons and epaulettes. In keeping with military guidelines, a trim fit is de rigueur for these highly tailored coats. But there is also a casual side to uniform dressing, seen in everything from peacoats and arctic parkas to flight jackets and fatigue pants. And what better place to photograph military style than West Point, with its strict sense of order and smartly dressed cadets?

title: North Carolina Picks Up After the Hurricane
description: ''IT'S kind of ironic -- water damage to a scuba store,'' said Terry D. Kennedy, owner of the Visionquest Dive Center in Sneads Ferry, N.C., an area heavily damaged by Hurricane Fran.

title: Are We Feeling Punchy?
description: We know that the office can be a volatile place -- so volatile, in fact, that punches can be thrown. Companies are reporting an increase in workplace violence, including pushing, shoving and fistfights. Has there been a fight in your office? Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

description: ALIEN IMPACT

description: To the Editor:

description: Correction Appended

title: Bethany Yarrow and Sebastian Ossa
description: EVER since Bethany Yarrow could walk, she has marched for peace, a family tradition.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Geography of the Heart

title: The Silencers
description: GIVING OFFENSE

title: Calvinism
description: To the Editor: Eric Weinberger's otherwise excellent and informative article (''A Dutch Tour by Bike,'' July 21) stirred my ire because of his lack of sensitivity and respect for the Calvinist tradition, which is pervasive in the part of the Netherlands he rode through. I have traveled a great deal in the area and came to have a high regard for the beauty of the buildings and landscape and for the industry and ingenuity of the people.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 4 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Roundabout Theater revival of the Tennessee Williams play ''Summer and Smoke,'' directed by David Warren, misidentifies the play that Mr. Warren directed on Broadway last season. It was Philip Barry's ''Holiday,'' not his ''Philadelphia Story.''

title: Poets Report to Society, Not Just to Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Racism Abroad
description: To the Editor: I've just spent a month traveling with my husband in Java and Northern Sumatra. My husband and I found that Indonesia was one of the most inhospitable countries we have ever been to, because of my race. I am an African-American of Haitian origin. My husband is white, of Dutch nationality.

title: Star Power Lights Up London
description: WITH Diana Rigg, Albert Finney, Tom Courtenay, Gene Wilder, Jessica Lange and a score of less celebrated but comparably accomplished performers descending on the London theater this fall, it looks as if we critics will have little time to escape to our dachas and engage in Chekhovian reverie. Indeed, were we to do so, we would very likely miss two of the finest revivals of the great Russian's work that Britain has seen in recent years. Chekhov's ''Uncle Vanya'' has just arrived at the Albery Theater, with Derek Jacobi in top form as the dilapidated title character, and in mid-November it will be replaced by the equally lustrous production of Chekhov's ''Cherry Orchard'' that the Royal Shakespeare Company first staged at Stratford last year.

title: Special Time: Loss of Memory
description: BAD things do happen to good people, even law-abiding citizens who pay their taxes, cut their lawns and respect the HOV lanes. One morning last week I switched on the computer and saw the dreaded words HARD DISK FAILURE.

title: At This Party, Pedigree Was Crucial
description: Not one guest at this Upper East Side soiree was ashamed to arrive wearing fur.

title: Michelle Tucker, Marc Kritzer
description: Michelle Leslie Tucker, a daughter of Jane S. and Larry H. Tucker of Saddle River, N.J., was married last evening to Marc Allen Kritzer, the son of Sylvia Kritzer Baumwald of Atlanta and the late Walter R. Kritzer. Rabbi Nathaniel D. Benjamin performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Transit Divisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Didn't Anyone Plan For Influx of the Elderly?
description: To the Editor:

title: Science of the Heart
description: EINSTEIN, HISTORY, AND OTHER PASSIONSThe Rebellion Against Science at the End of the Twentieth Century.By Gerald Holton.Illustrated. 240 pp. Reading, Mass.:Addison-Wesley Publishing Company.Paper, $14.

title: BORN IN THE COUNTRY, BRED FOR TOWN
description: This fall designers have brought those tweedy country classics up to date, with cleaner lines and trimmer shapes just right for the city. Yet the earthy color palette and richly textured fabrics have lost none of their masculine appeal. Camel, that most traditional of men's-wear hues, is the season's favorite, along with a broad range of browns now used in everything from plush corduroy and tweed to brushed alpaca, suede and shearling. For a more contemporary look, try a red or burgundy turtleneck sweater with this warm mix of colors.

title: Wilson Makes Timely Adjustment
description: The progress Paul Wilson has made has not been measured in victories and losses but by more subtle evidence, such as posture, demeanor and the ability to survive when the pitches aren't as crisp as they should be.

title: Sigmund on the Couch
description: WITTGENSTEIN READS FREUD

title: They Decide Which Sports Get Headlines
description: How do women's sports get to be big time? A large part of the answer lies in which sports the news media decide to cover. Two sports editors were asked how the decisions are made.

title: Southwestern Surprises
description: DO YOU want my opinion as a picky or an enthusiastic eater?'' one of my companions asks after sampling the black bean, vegetable and white cheddar tart at Mojave Grille.

title: Museum Hopping Made Easy
description: Visiting museums in Washington has been made easier with the addition of the Museum Bus, a service introduced in July by the Cultural Alliance of Greater Washington.

title: If K.F.C. Can Do It, So Can TCNJ
description: CHANGING the name of this college was an outrageous act of elitism,'' said Prof. Joseph V. Ellis, who grew up in South Philadelphia and isn't coy about saying what he thinks.

title: Those Sweet Summers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front-page article in the New Jersey section today about intercollegiate women's sports omits a line from the continuation on page 10. The affected sentence should read, ''But the women have an added burden: fighting endlessly for respect even as they have tried to ward off bitterness and keep their ambitions intact -- to be a good coach, to put together a winning team.''

title: Setback in T.W.A. Crash Inquiry Adds Urgency to the Search for Evidence of a Bomb
description: The discovery that the Trans World Airlines Flight 800 jumbo jet was used to train a bomb-sniffing dog just five weeks before it crashed heightens the importance and urgency of the deep-sea hunt for physical evidence of the precise location of the explosion, investigators said yesterday.

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Paris
description: Just one day in Paris is a sin, but you can atone for that. Get yourself to the Place du Pantheon, the domed mausoleum for famous men (and Marie Curie) on the Mont-Ste.-Genevieve above the Sorbonne, and walk around behind it to one of the least known architectural jewels of the city, the Eglise St.-Etienne-du-Mont.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: IN the pairing of actors, in the concoction of plots, chemistry is crucial, as four choice movies prove this week in the realms of high adventure, troubled love and wild comedy.

title: Art From High End to Low End on East End
description: WHAT began as a community art show on East End Avenue has developed into an outdoor gallery with an international reputation. Again next weekend, East End from 84th to 87th Streets will be closed to traffic and opened to artists and art aficionados in the 26th Annual Gracie Square Art Show. Nearly 100 artists will offer their art for sale at the show of original artwork, which draws participants from all over the country vying for space to exhibit paintings, prints, sculptures and photographs.

title: Beautiful and Damned
description: Cheap Ticket to HeavenBy Charlie Smith.286 pp. New York:Henry Holt & Company. $25.

title: Party Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Envisioning Electra Anew, as a Heroic Figure
description: THE GREEK TRAGEDIES, those hoary tales of incest, murder and betrayal, were the soap operas of the ancient world. Long-running and with recurrent characters, they were rites of mass culture that provided audiences with an almost visceral release.

title: Juilliard Ensemble Opens Friends' Season
description: IN 1954, a group of music lovers formed an organization to bring concerts to the county, and not being able to afford big-name performers, they invited a promising young ensemble, the Juilliard String Quartet, to give the inaugural recital. The group called itself Friends of Music, the young ensemble was the Juilliard String Quartet, and the rest, as they say, is history.

title: Cezanne
description: To the Editor: ''Cezanne Gives a Boost to Philadelphia Tourism'' (Correspondent's Report, Aug. 25) leaves out much of the story.

title: Birnur Siren, Kurt Z. Itil
description: Birnur Siren, the daughter of Cigdem Artunkal of Istanbul, Turkey, was married yesterday to Kurt Z. Itil, the son of Eleonore and Dr. Turan Itil of Nyack, N.Y. Mayor Terry Hekker of Nyack officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Casting a New Iran in the Old Role of a Friend
description: UNEXPECTEDLY, the crisis with Iraq has revived a debate on a taboo subject: whether, after all these years, America needs better relations with Iran in order to pursue its interests in the Persian Gulf.

title: North Korea's Mission Failed, but at What?
description: WITH North Korea seeking investments and food assistance from South Korea and Western countries, it may seem a bit odd for the North to press its case by sneaking a 325-ton submarine into South Korean waters with a boatload of armed commandos.

title: An Abortion Pill Is Approved
description: An abortion-inducing pill that has been at the center of a tempestuous debate between foes of abortion and abortion-rights groups received preliminary approval for marketing from the Food and Drug Administration last week.

title: Trophies For Tourists
description: For an influx of Asian tourists, the shopping parade route is on Fifth Avenue from 50th Street (Saks Fifth Avenue) to 58th Street (Bergdorf Goodman), with a detour east on 57th Street. And when their day's buying is done, they are loaded down with shopping bags bearing prestige labels. The shopping is a bonanza for both stores and tourists, whose currencies, in most cases, are strong compared to the dollar. That can mean prices 50 percent cheaper than in cities like Tokyo and Hong Kong. Then again, there is the airfare.

title: Stockholm's Sparkling Cuisine
description: THERE is more to Swedish food than herring and meatballs, as I discovered during a recent stay in Stockholm. I arrived gastronomically apprehensive and departed captivated.

title: Forest Service Tries to Gain an Urban Foothold in Baltimore
description: For two years the United States Forest Service, steward of 192 million acres of nature reserves, mainly in the West, has been trying to cultivate barren city streets on the East Coast.

title: Dodgers Now Look South for Their Biggest Rivals
description: The National League West will be won or lost by ''Brooklyn'' or by Barry Bonds. It will be won or lost by a pitcher who speaks English behind closed doors, by a slugger with a deck of cards or by a Hall of Famer who can not even get on deck. It will be won or lost in a stadium full of palm trees or a stadium in a ravine. It will be won or lost without Brett Butler and without Tommy Lasorda, and it will be won or lost with T-shirts in the stands that say, ''I hate the Macarena.''

title: Smoke Free
description: To the Editor: I did not recognize the ''smoke free'' Amtrak described by Adam Bryant in ''On the Ground, a Few Chances to Light Up'' (June 30). On a recent trip from Minneapolis to Ardmore, Pa., I found that the Empire Builder, Capitol Limited and Three Rivers trains were actually quite smoky in certain places. The observation car on the first two trains contained two designated smoking sections, partitioned only by narrow plexiglass strips on either side of the aisle that allowed plenty of smoke to circulate throughout the nonsmoking section sandwiched between them. The Three Rivers train had no observation car, so the cafe car contained the smoking section, which had no partitions to divide it from the nonsmoking section.

title: Sian F. Miller, Nicholas S. Wurf
description: Sian Frances Miller, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Clarence A. Miller of Houston, was married yesterday to Nicholas Sigmund Wurf, the son of Mildred Wurf of Washington and the late Jerry Wurf, the labor leader. The Rev. Mary Cushman, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at St. James's Church in New York.

title: Capital Gains Change Could Be Bonanza for Homeowners
description: LIKE many other empty-nesters and people nearing retirement, Becky Goldenberg of Easton, Pa., would like to trade down -- by selling her four-bedroom Victorian home in the historic College Hill section of town and moving into something smaller, perhaps even a rental. There is just one hurdle: capital gains taxes.

title: Faith Meets The Secular SportsWorld
description: Five major faiths will be in conflict today as the Giants play the Jets, the Yankees play the Red Sox, and Yom Kippur, the holiest day of the Jewish calendar, begins at sundown. How some fans observe these rituals will offer commentary on the old line that sports is America's religion and religion is America's sport.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Coins Unreturned

title: Perseverance Pays Off for Developer in Mamaroneck
description: THE Westchester County landscape is littered with the detritus of failed development projects, both residential and commercial. Some have fallen due to the financial collapse, for whatever reason, of the developer. But several have never gotten off the ground due to vociferous local opposition.

title: An Original Who Plumbs the Ordinary
description: STRANGE CHAP, MIKE LEIGH. HE QUITE bristles at the suggestion that his latest and most acclaimed movie to date is less bleak and disturbing than most of his previous work. Well, sorry, Mike, ''Secrets and Lies,'' which opens the New York Film Festival on Friday, is a positive film, and it is funny and moving, too. But that, apparently, is not the point. The 53-year-old Englishman likes to quote Jean Renoir's dictum that every director keeps reshooting the same film. So, he contends, while his mood may change, his fundamental vision of life does not.

title: Amy Weingartner, Michael Culhane
description: Amy Elizabeth Weingartner, a Marvel Comics editor, and Michael Noel Culhane, a marketing representative for DC Comics, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Rochester. The Rev. John L. O'Connor performed the ceremony.

title: Penn State Comes Out Pounding, And Temple Crumbles in Defeat
description: Penn State is a Big Ten heavyweight, ranked fifth in the nation in the Associated Press weekly poll. Temple is a Big East also-ran.

title: Bosnia's Nationalist Parties Dominate Election Results
description: The nationalist political parties that plunged Bosnia into war four years ago dominated the federal and regional legislative races, further jeopardizing hopes for unity, according to nearly complete returns made public today from the Sept. 14 national election.

title: An Overtime Interception Wins It for Lions
description: Overtime came to the Ivy League yesterday, and at Columbia's Wien Stadium, the extra period brought the Lions a 20-13 victory over Harvard.

title: Confronting Death With Poetry, One Letter at a Time
description: Her arms and legs are paralyzed from Lou Gehrig's disease but Josie Mendoza Guzman's spirit is unchained. Three years ago, she learned that she had the illness, formally known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, that progressively destroys the nervous system and often means a life expectancy of three years. Ms. Guzman, now 26 years old, has confronted the imminence of death by writing poetry. In the Washington Heights apartment where her parents, brother and sisters care for her, she has tapped out several hundred poems on her computer, using a blink of the eye to select the letters as they are displayed, one after the other, on an electronic board. A 20-line poem can take the better part of a day. ''Sometimes when I get really inspired I can go up to five hours at a time,'' she says. ''But I get very tired.'' Her writing may reflect the darkness of a terminal illness but, she says, ''It's an escape from reality, letting my imagination run wild.''

title: A Signal From Damascus
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria does not like being threatened or taken for granted.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: CENTRAL PARK

title: Old U.S. Army Manuals for Latin Officers Urged Rights Abuses
description: Training manuals used by the United States Army's special school for Latin American military and police officers in the 1980's recommended bribery, blackmail, threats and torture against insurgents, according to documents made public by the Pentagon late Friday.

title: Sharpton Announcing Run for Mayor, as Democrat
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who twice sought a seat in the United States Senate, will announce today that he will run in next year's Democratic primary for mayor, his office said yesterday.

title: The Ghetto or the Global Village?
description: When Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, visited the U.S. a few weeks ago, he took a side trip between meetings at Wall Street and the White House to drive to the Montefiore Cemetery in Queens. There, he lit a yellow candle, recited a psalm and stood in silent meditation to pay his respects at the gravesite of the renowned Lubavitcher Rebbe, Rabbi Menachem Schneerson.

title: No-Pet Rule: A Bone of Contention
description: IF Gisele Masson didn't own one of New York City's best-known French restaurants, her ongoing dispute with the board of her Manhattan co-op would probably have received little attention. As it turns out, however, Ms. Masson's fight to keep her two dogs in her apartment -- despite the board's insistence that the co-op's rules require that she evict one of them -- has been reported in several newspapers and featured on at least one television news program.

title: New Concerns After Alert On Mosquitoes With Virus
description: The discovery in Stonington and Old Lyme this week of the deadly Eastern equine encephalitis virus in mosquitoes that predominantly bite humans has raised the level of concern among officials and residents alike.

title: Sojourner's World
description: Sojourner Truth

title: California or New York, Coastal Styles
description: TAKING sides used to be mandatory: either New York or California. Especially in the 1980's the two coasts' contrasting life styles meant different values.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in the Travel section today about the Spanish town that is the site of the Santa Maria la Mayor church and fort misspells its name in some copies. It is Valderrobres, not Valderobles.

title: Leslie M. VanDerzee, John T. Marvin
description: Leslie Morgan VanDerzee and John Turnbull Marvin, banking executives in New York, were married on Thursday at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of the Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Need of a Net Does Not a Gender Gap Make
description: To the Editor:

title: Tourist-Office Toll
description: To the Editor: In October my wife and I are taking a seven-day cruise on the Rhone River, ending up in Paris via T.G.V. high-speed train from Lyons.

title: Rooting for the Red Sox, but Doing It All Alone
description: In the past, I'd have looked forward all year to a weekend such as this, when my beloved Red Sox are at Yankee Stadium. I moved to New York City 30 years ago but like many a transplanted Bay Stater, I saw these rare visits as a chance to root for what would ever be my hometown team.

title: Langfuhr Steals the Show In Breeders' Cup Rehearsal
description: If that was the dress rehearsal for the Breeders' Cup Sprint that they staged in the Vosburgh at Belmont Park yesterday, then a 4-year-old horse from Canada named Langfuhr gave a rave performance. He also gave notice that he will be the horse to beat for the championship when the same cast reassembles in five weeks at Woodbine in Toronto.

title: How to Make a Ph.D. Matter
description: THE DEBATE OVER THE present and future condition of the American university is consistently reduced to a debate over ideology.The troubled relations between academics and the rest of the society get explained as the consequence of political and philosophical differences: if professors weren't so left-wing or multiculturalist or theoretical, if they could only start to think like the rest of us, the university's social standing would be restored. This manner of posing the issue is good for polemicists, but it is not much good for anyone else. For the real problem has nothing to do with politics and philosophy and everything to do with economics and structure.

title: London
description: Autumn is London's season. The customary cloudy, cool weather -- so disappointing in the summer, so oppressive in the winter -- feels suitable for the city's post-August return to seriousness, and as temperatures dip into the 50's and 60's and days shorten, London's night life, theater, opera, music and dance swing into full gear. It is a perfect time for shopping and sightseeing, and for organized or peripatetic strolls.

title: Pope's Gentler Message for France: Kindness and Forgiveness
description: As the French engaged in a furious debate on church-state relations before Pope John Paul II arrived here on Thursday, detractors depicted him as a Christian Ayatollah at war with modern reality while loyal supporters hailed him as the only clear moral voice in a troubled world.

title: Impressive Cadets Top Duke
description: No one will ever compare this year's Army football team to the squads led by Glenn Davis and Doc Blanchard 50 years ago. But this could be the best and most exciting Army team in years, as the Cadets demonstrated today in beating Duke, 35-17, before a crowd of 36,049 at sun-drenched Michie Stadium.

title: Literary Sachet
description: The announcement that Parfums Fragonard would produce a fragrance called ''A Year in Provence,'' inspired by and named after Peter Mayle's best-selling book of the same name, has prompted a rush to sign up the olfactory rights to other literary properties. . . .

title: Bedford Panel Considers Tougher Tree Law
description: THE first round in a clash of cultures between tree huggers and farmers has ended in a tangle.

title: Help Abroad In Emergencies
description: IT'S scary enough to be robbed, become ill or get arrested while traveling in the United States, but for the 45 million Americans who travel abroad each year, similar emergencies can trigger a daunting array of problems. Although trip insurance can offer some protection, travelers can also contact United States embassies and consulates throughout the world for a variety of emergency, and a few nonemergency, services.

title: Three Buildings Join City's Landmarks List
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission last week designated three new landmarks: The Potter Building, a 19th century testament to terra cotta, at 35-38 Park Row across from City Hall Park; the Manhasset, a Beaux-Arts-style apartment building at 301 West 108th Street; and both the interior and exterior of the Bowery Savings Bank Building at 110-120 East 42d Street, facing Grand Central Terminal.

title: Mannequins Come to Life For Designer
description: Barneys, beware. The modest store windows of a Fulton Street boutique have caused bus drivers to slow down and wave, befuddled schoolchildren and stopped passers-by in their tracks.

title: BOTH PARTIES SEE LEGISLATIVE RACES AS OPPORTUNITIES
description: At a time when Congress is giving the states expanded control over welfare, health care and other social programs, fierce battles are being waged in state legislative races here and across the country. Republicans are trying to cement the victories of their 1994 landslide and Democrats are fighting aggressively to regain the majorities they lost.

title: A Death by Gunplay
description: In a national exhalation of mixed emotions, America last week said goodbye to Tupac Shakur, the 25-year-old rapper who died on Sept. 13 from gunshot wounds he received in a Las Vegas shooting six days earlier.

title: A Virtuoso Who Plays It Safe
description: IN 1959, Itzhak Perlman bought a high-quality Hill & Sons violin bow for $125. Today, he figures, it is worth about $7,000. ''Let's see, that means it has appreciated probably as much as the market,'' he said.

title: THE DO-IT-YOURSELF DEALERS
description: It was refreshing to read about new-wave art dealers like Kenny Schachter and about alternative places to show art. They are surely a departure from arrogant galleries and cliquey art centers that are often too traditional, political and oppressive.

title: Ann K. Eldred, Robert Johnson
description: Dr. Ann Katherine Eldred and Dr. Robert Bruce Johnson were married yesterday in the Crossroads Church at the Farmer's Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y. The Rev. Rod Johnson, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Details Reveal A Prim Heroine's Lifetime Longings
description: Correction Appended

title: Sarah K. Sutter, Christian Glazar
description: Sarah Katherine Sutter, a daughter of Mary T. Funsch of Princeton, N.J., and John R. Sutter of Oriental, N.C., was married yesterday to Christian Todd Glazar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Glazar of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Leslie Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Princeton.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Between Hope and History

title: Seeing Religion Where None Exists
description: To the Editor:

title: Rita L. Roberts, Oliver L. Hill
description: Rita Lemons Roberts and Oliver Lee Hill were married yesterday. The Rev. W. Franklyn Richardson performed the ceremony at Grace Baptist Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: A Loss in the Family Led to a Bill on Visiting
description: Assemblywoman Marion Crecco, a Bloomfield Republican, knows how it feels to be prevented from seeing a close relative grow up. After her sister died, it took her family years to re-establish contact with that sister's daughter. When the niece was found, she was an adult.

title: An Olympian Injustice
description: BY THE TIME YOU read these words, Richard Jewell may be fully cleared or finally implicated in the explosion of a pipe bomb in Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta last July. Or he may still be dangling in the hellish limbo to which a media lynch mob consigned him nearly eight weeks ago.

title: Pull Up a Chair Where Peru Meets China
description: Two things about the chairs at Jaimito's, an otherwise unassuming-looking Chino-Peruvian storefront restaurant. One is that they resemble twisted miniature surfboards covered in leopard skin. The other is that they are almost sinfully comfortable. ''Once you sit in them you don't want to stand up,'' the owner, Jaime Lam, says with an air of mystery.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: TOUCHEDBy Carolyn Haines.Dutton, $23.95.

title: Berliners
description: COUPLINGS

title: The Studio, A Place Of Legends
description: First things first: ''Inside the Actors Studio'' is not taped inside the Actors Studio. The Bravo cable series originates in an auditorium at the New School for Social Research in Greenwich Village, blocks and blocks from the Studio's well-worn home in the theater district in midtown Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: The New & Noteworthy Paperbacks column on page 40 of The Times Book Review today lists two books prematurely. The Penguin editions of ''A Shooting Star'' and ''Remembering Laughter,'' both by Wallace Stegner, are not scheduled to be available in stores until Nov. 12.

title: W.Jost Michelsen, Martha Leonard
description: Martha Reed Leonard and Dr. W. Jost Michelsen were married last evening at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx. Dr. Laurence H. Rubinstein, a rabbi, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: How Land Was Used, How People Lived
description: THIS summer people started working -- often with dental tools -- in holes in the ground at Mystic Seaport. Visitors began stopping by the holes, even in the rain, to learn about past decades along the Mystic River and current work in the dirt.

title: Julia C. Powell, James K. O'Brien
description: Julia Clayton Powell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Brentnall Powell Jr. of Baltimore, was married yesterday to James Kenneth O'Brien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Robert O'Brien of East Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Thomas L. Culbertson performed the ceremony at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Baltimore. The Rev. Peter Daly, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Three Painters Add a Human Touch to Abstraction
description: THE painters whose work is on display at the Ben Shahn Galleries of William Paterson College here display different strategies for defining a memorable individual signature while incorporating various elements of what are by now, after all, the familiar traditions of abstract art.

title: Florida Stuns 107,608 in 20 Explosive Minutes
description: Defying convention, the laws of etiquette and the largest crowd to see a college football game in 66 years, the Florida Gators streaked to 35 consecutive points in the first 19 minutes 54 seconds on the way to a convincing, if misleadingly narrow, 35-29 victory over Tennessee.

title: In an Arena Of Faithful, Joyful Noise And Prayer
description: All at once yesterday morning, hundreds of men rose from their seats in Shea Stadium and gave each other jubilant high-fives, the clapping echoing loud and long.

title: Trading Places
description: Leo MelamedEscape to the Futures.By Leo Melamed with Bob Tamarkin.Illustrated. 463 pp. New York:John Wiley & Sons. $27.95.

title: Exploring Streetology (Whatever That Is)
description: The large red-lettered sign outside 867 Marcy Avenue says, ''Street ologist Consultant Firm.'' Inside, Timmie Vincent, youth advocate, basketball coach and former Harlem Globetrotter turned storefront philosopher, has file drawers and scrapbooks labeled ''streetology.'' He has business cards that say ''director of streetology,'' and he can produce a faded sheet of paper from the 1960's spelling out the mission of the movement.

title: What's on the Internet? Here's a Start
description: DEBORAH GILBERT, the host of The Emerging Society, a call-in talk show simulcast on the Fairfield County News Radio, AM 1350, and on the Internet, speaks about cyberspace with sheer reverence. A seasoned talk-show host, she started using the communication tool last fall before starting her program, the first of its kind in Connecticut.

title: Technical Maneuvers
description: Modern, minimalist clothes in high-tech fabrics are designed to function under any conditions -- even underground. Durable quilted outerwear styles are made of matte or shiny-finish synthetics in streamlined silhouettes. Here, only functional details -- such as zippered pockets, snaps and a few hoods -- remain. Beyond basic black, jackets come in brown, forest green and pewter. Underneath, there are close-fitting ribbed knits, with stripes around the chest reminiscent of motocross styles, in colors of gold, burgundy, red and pale green. Trim, plain-front pants complete the picture.

title: What's Looking Up in Collector Cars
description: EACH year, Dave Brownell, the editor of Hemmings Motor News and Special Interest Autos, two publications based here that are ardently read by old-car buffs, draws up a list of collectible cars that he sees as good buys at the moment -- cars with legs, if you will.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a delegation of Afghan women visiting the United Nations misidentified the late husband of one of them, Rukhsana Sarwar. He was a professor of electrical engineering, not a political scientist, and played no part in politics.

title: O'Neill's Family Affair
description: You may feel a little numb from all the verbiage flowing like a river nearing the sea. But the talk is fascinating coming from Eugene O'Neill in LONG DAY'S JOURNEY INTO NIGHT (1962), as he reminisces about his home life with his actor father, his brother and drug addict mother in the Connecticut house, which is the nearest thing the group could call home. We get an unchecked flow of aches, pains and the wakenings within the bosom of a turbulent family that still has room for love. It worked wonderfully well on Broadway. The small cast - Katharine Hepburn, Jason Robards, Ralph Richardson, Dean Stockwell - is exceptional. And Sidney Lumet's direction is brilliant - THURSDAY at 3:30 P.M. and FRIDAY, NOON on BRAVO.

title: Noreen Donovan And Peter T. Roth
description: Noreen Anne Donovan and Peter Thomas Roth were married last evening at the Plaza. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani officiated, and Rabbi Richard S. Chapin took part in the ceremony.

title: Where 'No Trespassing' Signs Are as Numerous as Gnats
description: LITTLE RIVER can barely be made out on a map, and in most places it can be crossed in hip waders. But trout fishermen know it hides an abundance of trout, particularly the stretch from its headwaters in Hampton to the Hanover Reservoir.

title: In the East 50's, Elegance and Elan
description: JUBILEE $S

title: THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: Democrats

title: Paying Tribute To the Music That Never Died
description: IT IS 1958 AT THE START OF THE new film ''Grace of My Heart,'' and the world is on the cusp of the rock-and-roll revolution. The would-be chanteuse Edna Buxton (played by Illeana Douglas) paces backstage at a Philadelphia talent show. Nearby, another contestant, Doris Shelley, warms up with a soulful blues. Doris asks Edna what she'll be performing that evening. ''You'll Never Walk Alone,'' answers the embarrassed Edna; her mother chose the chestnut, from ''Carousel.'' Doris tells Edna she should sing what really moves her. Cut to Edna at the microphone, following Doris's advice.

title: Care Is Required With Roof Repairs
description: THE part of the house that receives the most punishment from the elements is the roof. It is assaulted by rain and snow, baked by the hot sun and buffeted by severe winds. Sooner or later, even the best roof will show signs of wear and tear. Unfortunately, this is also the part of the house that receives the least care because it is relatively inaccessible.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report last Sunday about a telephone service set up by the Neighborhood Cleaners Association to receive complaints about odors emitted at dry cleaning stores misstated the association's working method. The association works with dry cleaners to resolve problems voluntarily; its remedies are not compulsory. The report also misstated the association's membership. There are about 4,000 members -- not 1,500 -- of which 1,100 are in New York City.

title: As Autumn Comes, So Do Craft Shows Of Artists' Wares
description: AS varied as autumn leaves, as sensuous as the changing colors on a hillside, handmade crafts appear each September with the predictability of the equinox. Artists plying textiles, jewelry, glass and wood-carved objects count on the season to fatten the till, while craft shows attract buyers to a wide range of ventures.

title: Suit on Brookhaven Lab Pollution Clears Hurdle
description: IN a decision that may foreshadow years of legal action targeting the Brookhaven National Laboratory, a judge has refused to dismiss contentions that emissions from the laboratory have seriously contaminated neighboring communities.

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Amsterdam
description: Probably no European capital is as compact and intimate, as friendly to pedestrians and hostile to cars as Amsterdam. So our day will be entirely on foot. Never mind the marijuana culture and the beckoning of the city's lazy cannabis cafes. This itinerary will begin at the medieval core, the place where Amsterdam was born.

title: It's Fall. So Aerate, Prune, Fertilize, Plant, Harvest. And Enjoy.
description: Aerate the lawn and rake out thatch. Apply slow-release fertilizer, or top-dress with compost.

title: Swamped
description: SAME PLACE, SAME THINGS

title: Mary F. Merkel And Chip McGee
description: Mary Feiler Merkel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Merkel Jr. of New York, is to be married today to Eric Spencer McGee, the son of Karen B. McGee and Robert E. McGee, both of Cincinnati. The Rev. Stephen Garmey is to perform the ceremony at the Calvary Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Alison B. Shyer, Jonathan R. Laird
description: Alison Brooke Shyer, the daughter of Marlene Fanta Shyer and Robert M. Shyer, both of New York, was married yesterday in Larchmont, N.Y., to Jonathan Robert Laird, the son of Dorothy Laird of Rockland, Mass., and Robert W. Laird of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Richard Martin performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Party Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Dublin
description: In the soft gray autumn days of dear old dirty Dublin, as James Joyce called this energetic capital, the easiest thing to find is the rain. So for a day's outing, carry a light plastic raincoat and start at Marjorie Fitzgibbons's slightly larger-than-life bronze statue of Joyce on O'Connell Street, at the corner of North Earl. Joyce, the most famous Dubliner, spent most of his life abroad and didn't write much about the explosive anti-British politics of his day, but his image looks across to the General Post Office, still bullet-pocked from the 1916 Easter Rising.

title: How West Has Grown, Seen Through Cameras
description: A major photographic exhibition focusing on the American West opens this week at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. ''Crossing the Frontier: Photographs of the Developing West, 1849 to the Present'' includes more than 300 vintage and modern images, many of which come from private collections and from historical societies that have no room to display them.

title: His Bliss Is the Blues, and He Follows It
description: Paul Jones, the lead singer of the popular 60's band Manfred Mann, is not the kind of aging rocker who spends his time jetting between Mustique and Easthampton, doing of-the-moment drugs while reminiscing about his lost glory days. Now 54, the man who made ''Do Wah Diddy Diddy'' popular in the 60's devotes himself to the blues, his first and most enduring musical love.

title: Male Actor Seeks a Female Role, But the Playwright Says No
description: For a few weeks, much of the talk at the P and H Cafe here has centered on a male actor who tried to transform himself into a steel magnolia.

title: Living Dangerously
description: We lived in Providence during the year everyone was worried about electrical waves. As I recall, it didn't matter if the waves came from something big like power lines or small like coffee makers. Waves of any kind were suspect. Even now, I have no reason to play down this threat. I don't know what it is, really. But there was a big gray transformer on a utility pole in front of our house that would buzz and click. It was a fine house in many ways, with a fireplace and skeleton keys. My wife and I had just had a child. ''The sooner we get away from this transformer, the better off we'll be,'' I remember thinking.

title: Robert J. Straub, Dorothy E. Palmer
description: Dorothy Ellen Palmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Guy Palmer 2d of Savannah, Ga., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Jordan Straub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester J. Straub of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. David S. Hoag, the rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the church. Msgr. Anthony Dalla Villa, the rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, took part in the service.

title: Greenburgh Passes School Budget
description: RESIDENTS of the embattled Greenburgh Central 7 school district passed a $33.4 million budget on Sept. 11, one week into the new school term. Two previous budgets, which had proposed a $33.7 million spending plan and would have included a 3.9 percent tax increase, were defeated earlier in the year. The new budget, passed by a vote of 1,359 to 577, does not increase taxes and restores sports and other extracurricular activities to the schools.

title: A Mini-Van on a Diet?
description: Or perhaps a giant bug on wheels? Or an alien lander? No, it's a ''Smart'' mini-car, built by Mercedes and Swatch (yes, Swatch), going through its paces last week on a test track in France. Production is due to start in a year.

title: Agents Find Little to Link Suspect to Olympics Bomb
description: Seven weeks after a deadly bombing at the Atlanta Olympics, Federal law-enforcement officials say they have made little progress in solving the attack and are unable to implicate the security guard who has been the focus of their inquiry.

title: Atop 2 Hudson Piers, a Sense of Tranquil Apartness
description: GREAT ocean-going vessels loom through Maxine Hobson's ''backyard.''

title: The Trickle-Down Theory
description: HAD THE ALIENS in ''Independence Day'' succeeded in their conquest of the Planet Earth and set about investigating the world they'd just destroyed, they might have come to some rather odd conclusions about our pre-millennial culture. They might have concluded that Victor Hugo was the brains behind Quasimodo bubble bath and Medieval Mystery body lotion, that Virginia Woolf was a fashion designer working with Anna Sui, that Michelangelo and Donatello were mutant turtles who practiced martial arts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about investing in Lucent Technologies Inc., the high-technology spinoff of AT&T, misstated the number of Lucent shares sold by AT&T in an initial public offering in April. It was 112 million, not 122 million.

title: THE WRINKLE ROOM
description: When Andrew Holleran, age 50, defines gay men's identity as based, ''more than most people's, on being unwrinkled,'' where does that leave me, age 72, and my contemporaneous gay friends (Lives: ''The Wrinkle Room,'' Sept. 1)? Like everyone, we sowed wild oats, but as the bloom faded, we readjusted our tempo and talents to the inevitable, and did so as individuals.

title: Terry Ann Burke, Sadison E. Weil
description: Terry Ann Burke, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Burke of Saddle River, N.J., was married there yesterday to Sandison Edward Weil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Alan Weil of Washington. The Rev. Vincent Fortunato performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: West Harlem's Architectural Gems
description: ON weekends the sounds of hammers, saws and sanders can be heard for blocks along the side streets of Hamilton Heights in western Harlem. In long-neglected, century-old brownstone, limestone and brick town houses a new generation of upper-class minority families has returned to restore the homes and the neighborhood.

title: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: House

title: Modern Times
description: The clean, simple lines of modern design extend to all areas of fashion, including accessories, where extraneous details are now kept to a minimum. Here and on the following pages are matte stainless steel watches minus the diver dials and buttons; grained- and smooth-leather belts with angular, brushed silver-tone buckles; near-solid, colorful ties with subtle Jacquard patterns, and blunt- or square-toed shoes -- from the very popular loafer to the classic jodhpur boot.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Celebrating the Struggle for Justice
description: CONNECTICUT is a small state with a wealth of people and places that have played a prominent role in America's struggle for justice and equality. To celebrate that fact, the Connecticut Historical Commission and the Amistad Committee are inaugurating the Connecticut Freedom Trail next Saturday.

title: Figuring Out How to Put a Town's Financial House in Order
description: Even before Irvington's new finance director found $5.5 million of unpaid bills tucked away in municipal desk drawers, a discovery that forced the state to seize control of the township's financial affairs, the town was spending millions of dollars more than it had.

title: Lower Fares to Florida From New Unit of Delta
description: Delta Air Lines plans to start a new low-fare division called Delta Express next month to offer low-fare service linking 10 cities in the Northeast and Midwest with five cities in Florida.

title: Dooming the Desert
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Portrait of My Body

title: For the Japan Society, an Expansion
description: The sedate black building housing the Japan Society, at 333 East 47th Street, normally a symbol of serenity, is not very serene these days. Its president, William Clark Jr., calls it a Potemkin village.

title: Scott Fitzgerald Slept Here, Briefly
description: Two years ago, on a brilliant Saturday in September, a marching band paraded down Summit Avenue in St. Paul, followed by open touring cars carrying descendants of F. Scott Fitzgerald, as well as Eugene McCarthy and the novelist J. F. Powers, and by a crowd on foot, including any number of people who looked like authors, and a smattering of high school kids who had been reading ''The Great Gatsby.'' The parade wound down the hill past the cathedral to the old Shubert Theater on Exchange Street, where Fitzgerald had gone to see plays as a boy, and there, after a few speeches, buckets of Mississippi and White Bear Lake water were sloshed on the facade, rechristening the Shubert the Fitzgerald Theater. That evening, it was packed for a five-hour reading of ''Gatsby,'' from Nick Carraway's father's advice to reserve judgment on people who haven't had the advantages you've had, to the famous ending: ''So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.''

title: Another View Of a Store's Fate
description: In reference to your article, (''Pride in State and Family, Trying for a Sound Economic Base,'' Aug. 11):

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: In Search of Nature

title: The Tricky Business Of Keeping Doctors Quiet
description: ADVERTISEMENTS for health maintenance organizations often picture smiling families and flash reassuring messages that conjure up blissful images. One offers ''a lifetime of care.'' Another describes the H.M.O. as ''your health partner for life.'' Another says, ''You'll feel better with us.''

title: THE WRINKLE ROOM
description: Holleran should walk through a shopping mall with his shirt off. He should have included a photo of his 50-year-old self on the jacket of his latest novel. And he should give gay men the credit that they can handle it. People age the same, gay and straight. In both camps, the self-obsessed will have a tough time of it.

title: Asking Questions At Towers Financial
description: To the Editor:

title: Reality Bites for Celebrities' First Wives
description: To the Editor:

title: Ray Coleman, 59, Biographer Of Lennon and McCartney
description: Ray Coleman, a former editor of Melody Maker, the English pop music weekly, and the author of several biographies of rock musicians, died on Sept. 10 at his home in Shepperton, near London. He was 59.

title: The $640,500 Card
description: In the realm of baseball memorabilia, there is only One True Card: it dates from 1910 and bears the homely visage of a long-dead ballplayer named Honus Wagner. Time has relegated Wagner's baseball brilliance to television documentaries and coffee-table books. Yet The Card lives on; yesterday it was sold at Christie's Art Auctioneers for $640,500 to an anonymous buyer.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Cabernet Sauvignon

title: Kathleen M. Nester, Philip R. Schatz
description: Kathleen Mary Nester, a daughter of Patricia and Walter Nester of North Haven, Conn., was married yesterday to Philip Ransom Schatz, a son of Jane Carbines Topley of Marcell, Minn., and Gary Schatz of Minneapolis. The Rev. Denver Hart, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York.

title: Agnew Leaves Legacy Of a Shrill Divisiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada
description: To the Editor: I was happy to see ''Prince Edward Island Idyll'' (Frugal Traveler, Aug. 4). I go to the island every summer to soothe my soul with the peaceful panoramas and delight my earthly side with the equally satisfying lobster dinners at the Fisherman's Wharf.

title: A Joyful Mess
description: Disheveled children scream, laugh, scramble up a chair, run a tricycle over a living-room carpet; a little girl becomes frantic when the black cat she has been teasing bites her on the big toe; another child puffs on a cigarette. The rooms are messy, the ashtrays full, yet the parents, friends and neighbors -- sprawled on brown velvet sofas or sitting on the floor -- enjoy one another's company, along with a smoke, a beer, a cup of tea and ice cream. Such is life for the working poor in the housing project in Nottingham, England, that Nick Waplington documents with remarkable intimacy in THE WEDDING: New Pictures From the Continuing ''Living Room'' Series (Aperture, $40), the successor to a collection he published in 1991. Loosely organized around the union of Janet and Clive, the photographs are boisterous and raw, bursting with color, movement and emotion. Mr. Waplington shot for months and from all angles: a baby's leg occupies the foreground of one image; a solitary beer-sipping guest, slumped between a wall and a television set, is the focus of another. Always, Mr. Waplington celebrates the beauty of the ordinary, and his images constitute an intense representation of the power of love. Christine Schwartz Hartley

title: Dowsing for Dinos
description: Ramal (Ray) Jones, a fossil buff and radiation analyst at the University of Utah, admits that ''people were kind of laughing at me'' when he invented a gadget that sounds like a dowsing rod for dinosaur bones. That was before it helped him unearth fossils buried in the Utah desert, including bones from what could be a previously unknown species -- the Nodosaur, an armored plant-eater depicted above.

title: Proof of Dog Training Took 3 Weeks
description: Using airplanes to test bomb-sniffing dogs is such a routine exercise with so little record-keeping that it took investigators three weeks to figure out that the same Trans World Airlines jetliner that exploded off the coast of Long Island on July 17 was used to test a dog five weeks earlier.

title: Jennifer Filardi, L.M. Waterhouse 3d
description: Jennifer Anne Filardi, a daughter of Anna T. and Edward V. Filardi of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lawrence Michael Waterhouse 3d, a son of Marjorie J. McGahren of Litchfield, Conn., and Mr. Waterhouse Jr., also of Briarcliff Manor. Msgr. Thomas Hartman, a relative of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Russian Surgeons Deliver A Grim Report on Yeltsin
description: In sharp contrast to statements by the Kremlin about the health of President Boris N. Yeltsin, Russian doctors have begun to paint a grim picture of a seriously ill leader.

title: Ernie Banks Would Love This Game
description: NOT to be a spoilsport, but for all their pains, the Red Sox and the Yankees get to play two more games today. They labored for merely 4 hours and 45 minutes yesterday before the Yankees outlasted the Red Sox, 12-11, in the 10th inning.

title: The Mountains of El Cid
description: Correction Appended

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE FORTUNATE FALL

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Canada Won't Rally Round (Costly) Free Flags
description: To help heal some of the wounds to national pride that were left after Quebec nearly pulled out of Canada last year, the federal Government has set out to help Canadians feel better about being Canadian.

title: DIARY
description: PRISONS

title: ENGLISH ACCENTS
description: Here we pay tribute to two of England's celebrated traditions: its distinguished Shakespearean actors and its elegant Savile Row-cut suits. Leaving behind the baggy suits of the early 1990's, designers in Europe and America have rediscovered this uniquely British take on structured style, with its moderately flared jacket, padded, slightly roped shoulders and nipped waist. This flattering model does exactly what suits are supposed to do -- that is, give a man the shape nature hasn't.

title: Sewage Plant: No vs. Maybe
description: On the edge of Newtown Creek, the city is poised to modernize and expand its largest sewage treatment plant -- a more than $1 billion venture that will bring the 30-year-old facility into compliance with Federal clean water laws.

title: A Portrait of the City, Painted by the Numbers
description: The numbers that are the life force of New York City government are born anew each year in the Mayor's Management Report, required by law each September. The reports always draw political fire, and the one that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani issued last week came under particular criticism for its sunny spin on the state of city services.

title: Baseball's Card of Cards Is Auctioned for $640,500
description: In the realm of baseball memorabilia, where autographed balls are encased in glass and tattered uniforms are revered as relics, there is only One True Card: it is in mint condition, dates from 1910, and bears the homely visage of a long-dead ballplayer named Honus Wagner.

title: The Fed Will Act, But Does It Matter?
description: The man at the sandwich shop took an order from one of my colleagues a few days ago, and, after establishing whether mayonnaise or mustard was desired, had one more question. ''Is the Fed going to raise interest rates?'' he asked.

title: 2 Debates Agreed On For Clinton and Dole
description: President Clinton and Bob Dole compromised and agreed to two televised 90-minute debates, a one-on-one debate on Oct. 16, without Ross Perot participating in either one.

title: John W. Tuthill, 85, Career Envoy for U.S.
description: John W. Tuthill, who served as United States Ambassador to the European Economic Community and to Brazil, died on Sept. 9 in a Washington hospital. He was 85 and lived in Washington.

title: After Reviving District, a Citywide Challenge
description: ''There's a little proverb,'' Barbara Byrd-Bennett rattled off in her signature rapid-fire staccato. ''Go to the people, learn from them, serve them, plan with them. Start with what they know and build on what they have. When the current leaders leave, the people will say, 'We have done it ourselves.' ''

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Madrid
description: Time-conscious visitors to Madrid such as President and Mrs. Clinton, on a one-day tour last December, and more recently, my friends from Bound Brook, N.J., made short work of the Velazquez and Goya galleries at the Prado museum, so they could go see the town that the great painters depicted.

title: Minnesota's Plan to Weaken Tenure Leads to Drive to Unionize
description: Minnesota's public university system is exploring revisions to the faculty tenure code that would allow cuts for the first time in professors' salaries for reasons other than financial emergency and would allow the dismissal of professors if their programs were eliminated.

title: Dueling Panthers
description: ''It's a trademark dispute,'' says Fahim Minkah, the man behind a lawsuit filed recently in Dallas. The suit elaborates: ''The Black Panther Party Inc. does not wish to be confused with the 'New Black Panthers,' a group preaching racial division and the inappropriate use of arms to promote social change.''

title: Mesa Air Agrees To Alter Procedures
description: Mesa Air Group has reached a tentative agreement with the Federal Aviation Administration to resolve deficiencies found in the airline's operations and maintenance, the company said this week.

title: What Nan Goldin Saw This Summer
description: TO SAY THAT NAN GOLDIN'S SUBJECT FOR THE past 25 years has been the urban demimonde, the world of drag queens and slum goddesses, of Lower East Side nightclubbers and Tokyo teen-agers in black rubber, is to explain her current fashionable status, but it doesn't say much about what makes her photographs good. It's not just who and where she photographs but how: with rare affection and a melancholic sense for the porcelain fragility of the bonds linking us one to another.

title: Slur by a Nation of Islam Leader Stirs Anger
description: A local leader of the Nation of Islam, a group that has a record of anti-Semitic comments and has been accused of bigotry, called a Brooklyn Assemblyman a ''snotty-nosed Jewish politician'' on the air on Friday, prompting angry retorts from the Governor and Jewish groups.

title: A Memory of McGeorge Bundy
description: IF they were so very smart, how could they have got it so wrong?

title: A Triumph In Triathlon
description: Thwarted by equipment problems at the international triathlon championships in Cleveland a month ago, Jim Quinn of Pleasantville got back on the road to the 2000 Olympics in Sydney, Australia, with a triumph in the final competition of this year's Gatorade Triathlon series last Sunday on Jekyll Island, Ga.

title: Bob Dole's Calculated Pragmatism
description: Until a few weeks ago, the vital question in this Presidential election campaign seemed to be whether it took a village to raise a child. Now we have another question: Why did it take Saddam Hussein to make American foreign policy an issue worthy of discussion in the campaign? Until he sent his troops north against the Kurds, the subject was being comprehensively ignored, and how the strongest country on earth should comport itself abroad was a nonissue.

title: The Space Program's Base in Connecticut
description: WHEN he was 17, Robert Goddard, a founder of modern rocketry, would find solitude sitting on a branch of a cherry tree at his family's home in Worcester, Mass. It was the place that allowed him to dream of space flight at the turn of the century.

title: The Best Days Out On The Town: Rome
description: If all you have is a day to spend in Rome, take a walk through the area that lies betweeen the Tiber River and the Corso Vittorio Emanuele II, bracketed by two bridges, the Ponte Garibaldi and the Ponte Mazzini. These boundaries are purely arbitrary, both geographically and historically: some guidebooks call this area the heart of Renaissance Rome, but it also contains hints of the Middle Ages (the Casa di San Paolo), of ancient Rome (the site of the Theatre of Pompey) and, like other parts of the city, a healthy dose of Baroque. In fact, this small swatch of Rome is not one, but many neighborhoods, a jumble of narrow streets, and a collection of piazzas, big and little, where social classes, and historical periods bump up against each other like happy bedfellows.

title: SCHOLARSHIPS FOR THE RICH
description: The two cases Andrew Delbanco uses to illustrate the impact of financial aid in college admissions oversimplify a complex process (''Scholarships for the Rich,'' Sept. 1).

title: Q. and A.
description: Layover at O'Hare

title: Grandchildren of the New Deal
description: THE INHERITANCE

title: Michio Hoshino Dies While Filming Bears
description: Michio Hoshino, a photographer known for his pictures of bears and other wildlife, was mauled to death by a brown bear last month on the Kamchatka Peninsula in eastern Russia. He was in his mid-40's and lived in Fairbanks, Alaska.

title: 'A Separate Creation'
description: To the Editor:

title: The 40 Years' War
description: INSIDE THE KREMLIN'S COLD WAR

title: Wild Things From Many Times and Cultures
description: MYTHS and legends -- of ancient Greek sun gods, of divine reptiles of old Nigeria, of the creatures under a second-grader's bed -- will be danced this fall on New Jersey stages.

title: The Burglaries Have Stopped; Effects Linger
description: NO one could understand what was happening to Burr Place. This quiet little block of white frame houses had become interesting to burglars. Three homes were hit in one week. And the thieves seemed to know which places were empty when and for how long.

title: No Compromises, Thank You
description: THINK of it as the no-pain, no-gain law of automobiles: Cars that are fun to drive demand more skill, not to mention tolerance for quirks.

title: Hood Ornaments
description: They are vestiages of romance on otherwise modern chassis.

title: Where Autumn's Esoteric Items Draw Serious Shoppers
description: FALL shopping is not usually thought of as an intellectual activity but in this village it just might be. On a recent afternoon it was described repeatedly by residents browsing through boutiques on Palmer Avenue as a haven for the intelligentsia and the artistically inclined; one woman nicknamed the village a ''mini-Upper West Side of Manhattan -- the money is there but it is low key, the people are high achievers but they're casual and 'artsy' rather than formal or ostentatious.''

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/

title: Defiant V.M.I. to Admit Women, But Will Not Ease Rules for Them
description: After defying a Supreme Court order for three months, the governing board of Virginia Military Institute voted 9 to 8 today to admit women, transforming the nation's last single-sex school that is state supported.

title: Meredith Marks, C.K. Sanjenis
description: Meredith M. Marks, the daughter of Peggy D. Peeters of Palm Harbor, Fla., and Donald M. Marks of New York, was married last evening to Christopher Kleiner Sanjenis, the son of Julie Sanjenis and Samuel Kleiner, both of New York. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, the senior minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York, officiated at the Stanhope Hotel.

title: A Move Toward Peace In Guatemala
description: Handshakes were not enough for the Government officials and leftist rebel leaders of Guatemala who signed a peace accord in Mexico City last week that curbs the power of the military and sets the stage for a final armistice to a 35-year war. Government negotiators -- including Gen. Otto Perez Molina, the top military officer in the delegation -- and guerrilla leaders congratulated each other with back-thumping embraces.

title: Today's Tactics for Yesterday's Terror
description: EVEN now, two months after T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded off Long Island, no one knows what to do to prevent a repetition, because no one knows what happened. Officials can look at security and see gaps, but airlines and others can argue about their significance. The aviation industry can examine whiz-bang technical solutions, but not know their effectiveness, let alone which ones to seek first.

title: Nab 'Em While They're Youngish
description: President Clinton's anti-smoking campaign has involved, in part, a prolonged scold of Joe Camel, the illustrated hepcat who has been criticized as a blatant attempt to sell cigarettes to adolescents. Less familiar is R. J. Reynolds's Red Kamel brand, aimed at smoking's next generation: self-consciously hip twentysomethings, who tend to believe they're immune to advertising. A revival of a failed brand introduced in 1913, Red Kamels are often given away in downtown clubs like Nation in Manhattan. Their ads mix Soviet colors, old-style labor imagery and copy that reads like a rejection of ad copy. ''Back for No Good Reason,'' goes the slogan, ''Except They Taste Good.'' Why would this appeal to Generation X? R. J. Reynolds declined to discuss it, so we rounded up our own panel of experts and put the question to them.

title: Unexpected Venice
description: WE had wound our way through the misty, nippy February twilight and Venice's well-worn maze of canals and bridges to the restaurant Da Fiori, and been rewarded with the best seafood in the city. After savoring the local delicacies -- risotto with cuttlefish and its ink, salt cod, razor clams, baby shrimp -- my wife and I, expecting our first child in a few months, felt confirmed in our decision to visit Venice during the post-Carnevale lull, when reservations are easy to come by and, if the Piazza San Marco is flooded, it's with water, not tourists.

title: There's More Where 'Malaguena' Came From
description: THE AMERICAN PIANIST Thomas Tirino is a man with a mission: to bring to light the works of the Cuban composer Ernesto Lecuona. Mr. Tirino's approach to the task is monumental and comprehensive.
