He is recording Lecuona's complete works for solo piano and piano and orchestra as well as selected songs, in six volumes on the Bis label, the third of which has just appeared. He is also supervising the publication of these works and of a catalogue of published scores and recordings.

title: Gretzky in Ranger Uniform
description: Wayne Gretzky greeted his first game as a Ranger with a palpable sense of eagerness.

title: Marathon Comes Early, and Yanks Win It
description: The Yankees were spoiling their fans' weekend, spoiling their own chances to clinch first place quickly, spoiling what had been a comfortable feeling. But it was only the 10th inning on this wacky day, so they had time for redemption. They got it. They are relaxed again.

title: Leaving a Barroom for a Classroom
description: In a town that worships youth and beauty, Rhea Perlman is merely talented. In a profession that rewards egomania and faux family values, she is genuinely self-effacing, and a genuine wife and mother in the generally accepted meaning of those terms.

title: Sunday the Rabbi Watched Football
description: IN my youth, when baseball was still king, the World Series always seemed to coincide with Yom Kippur, the holiest day in the Jewish calendar. In Columbus, Ohio, where my father was a rabbi, my friends and I would take occasional breaks from prayers in synagogue so we could rush to the parking lot, turn on a car radio and get the score, which was then quickly relayed from one male worshiper to another throughout the sanctuary.

title: Academic Integrity And Animal Rights
description: The case of Dr. Jan Moor-Janowski and New York University $(''In the Maelstrom of Animal Medical Studies,'' July 7$) is an extraordinary example of almost inexplicable treatment of a distinguished scientist by an equally distinguished academic institution.

title: SCHOLARSHIPS FOR THE RICH
description: It seems that the ''rich'' (those middle-class families who are going into debt to finance their children's education) are actually underwriting the financial-aid packages given out by many private colleges by paying artificially inflated tuition and room and board prices.

title: The Torre Brothers Wait for a New Heart
description: WHEN he's worrying about whether to bring in a new pitcher or flash the hit-and-run sign, Joe Torre is too busy to think about it. But when he's sitting in the dugout, so dependent on how his Yankee players perform, so helpless in a sense, that's when his brother Frank jumps into his mind.

title: Ivana diTommaso, Scott Gaillard
description: Ivana Sara diTommaso, the daughter of Jana L. Tognoli of Denville, N.J., and Dr. Andrea diTommaso of Detroit, was married yesterday to Roger Scott Gaillard, the son of Laura F. and Roger R. Gaillard of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Melinda M. Keck performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Kent, in Connecticut.

title: Pataki's Support Tops 50% For First Time, a Poll Says
description: Evidently bolstered by his support of a $1.75 billion bond act to improve the environment, Gov. George E. Pataki has the approval of a majority of New York voters for the first time, according to a new poll released today by Quinnipiac College.

title: Benefits
description: For and Among the Roses

title: Preserving a Ruin on Roosevelt Island Proves Costly
description: YOU'D think a ruin would be the all-time low-maintenance structure, but for 30 years the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation has been trying to get the money to stabilize the old Smallpox Hospital at the island's southern end -- a project whose cost is now estimated at $3 million. Now vital repairs to the seawall, a much larger effort, may finally provide funds for the haunting, neo-Gothic shell.

title: Muddling Through the Enlightenment
description: Set in a thriving 17th-century northern European port, Eric Darton's first novel, FREE CITY (Norton, $18), attends the stormy birth of the Enlightenment, when faith vied with reason and science threatened to replace religion in defining human destiny. These differing explanations of the cosmos make it difficult for anyone to come up with a consistent world view; for the unnamed inventor whose fictional journal makes up the novel, this is especially perplexing. Both a surgeon and a mechanical engineer, he oversees the construction of various automatons and an airship, experiments with anesthetics and stimulants, speculates about artificial memory and movies, and dabbles in law and politics. Yet despite all this accomplishment, he finds his prodigious reason nearly equaled by his lover's apparently occult powers, which have been gained, it seems, primarily by instinct. But his real problems are caused by his patron, the mysterious Roberto, a man whose ''ambitions have succeeded all reason,'' to whom he is symbiotically joined -- at least until he realizes that he is being drained of his genius simply to feed the other's devious schemes. Witty and surprising (by far the most thoughtful and morally rigorous character is a talking duck), Mr. Darton's book is an allegorical gambol through a frequently bizarre universe of foible and imperfection. Its conclusion that most things somehow work out in the end -- or, at least, that life goes on -- is fitting, if unsurprising. After all, progress often seems mostly a matter of muddling through. James Polk

title: THE SEANACHIE
description: As a former student of Frank McCourt's at Stuyvesant High School, I have to thank Robert Sullivan for capturing McCourt's humor and directness (''The Seanachie,'' Sept. 1). McCourt watched with pride as many of his students went on to Ivy League colleges and successful careers. Now it's our turn to be proud of him.

title: Long Ago in the Land of Hope and Michael
description: WHEN THE CHARACTER Gary was killed in a car accident on ''Thirtysomething,'' the 1980's television show that became a loved and hated cultural icon of a generation, the cast members gathered, like a stricken family, to watch the episode together. ''It was such a marker,'' says Peter Horton, who played Gary. ''One of us had died.''

title: Aging World, New Wrinkles
description: A CHARACTER in the comic strip Doonesbury once declared: ''This generation is like a great comet, blazing through the firmament, carrying with it a dream as boundless as the universe itself.''

title: Etiquette: Is It Back?
description: LA GOULUE, the elegant bistro at Madison Avenue and 65th Street, is exactly the kind of place where you might expect the patrons to know how to dip a soup spoon or tell the difference between a fish knife and a butter knife or exactly the right time to place the napkin on your lap. There's platinum credit cards in them there Kelly bags.

title: Strollers Are Best Ride For Babies in the Subway
description: To The Editor:

title: Unions Consider Charter Schools of Their Own
description: In the last five years, as more states and parents have embraced the movement to create charter schools, national teachers' unions have often resisted, worrying about how to hold onto the kind of teachers' benefits that some proponents of school choice say limit a charter school's success.

title: DEEPAK'S DAYS IN COURT
description: Your Sunday item ''Deepak's Days in Court'' (Aug. 18) posed some interesting dilemmas for me. How does a public figure protect himself from slander without compromising his spiritual values? It is true that I have suggested in my book ''The Seven Spiritual Laws of Success'' that the best tactic is defenselessness. On the other hand, the American justice system does promise me, at least in principle, the right to seek redress from those who break the law by maliciously vilifying me because they feel threatened by my philosophy or popularity. For the time being, I am choosing to respond directly to these attacks. Perhaps, in the long run, this will prove to be unenlightened. I don't know.

title: It's Never Too Early to Consider Spring Bulbs
description: TULIPS, daffodils and hyacinths. The big three in the bulb world are synonymous with spring. Plant these packages of bloom anytime now until the end of October and spring will be glorious.

title: Helicopters Won't Cut Back Without a Fight
description: Over the summer, the whomp-whomp roar of helicopters and the piercing odor of their fuel were to have eased a bit around the East 34th Street heliport, after the City Council cut the number of flights there by about half. But the relief sought for years by East Side residents never arrived, and it may never arrive if a judge grants National Helicopter, which operates most flights out of East 34th Street, an injunction against the flight curbs.

title: Always a Good Sound Bite: The 'Good Life' Behind Bars
description: Those inmates who can be seen along New Jersey's roadways picking up trash and garbage thrown from the cars of ''law-abiding'' motorists must be having a good time -- working a little by day, banking big bucks, and kicking back at the crib in the evening.

title: Two Win Notice for Guyanese
description: Since they began arriving in southwestern Queens three decades ago, immigrants from Guyana have worked hard for an economic foothold. But they have devoted little effort to local politics, preferring to keep track of politics back home.

title: Karen J. Bruno, Donald A. Jeffrey
description: Karen Jane Bruno and Donald Allan Jeffrey were married yesterday in Wainscott, L.I. The Rev. Thomas J. Parlette, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Wainscott Chapel.

title: THE DO-IT-YOURSELF DEALERS
description: Although artists will always have to find innovative ways to show their work, it's good to read about dealers who are not indifferent to new art and in fact, approach the unknown artist as an exciting issue.

title: Gay Support for Clinton Holds in Middle America
description: Rick Ward, a bartender at Dar's, one of a half-dozen gay night spots in Stark County, opened a long-neck bottle of Budweiser for a customer (''Need a glass? No?''), then considered the political question put to him.

title: New Party Faces For a Spandex A-List
description: THEY aren't all household names yet. But you can tell they've arrived because they're now hot guests at splashy parties. These new party faces (some from New York, some not) are achieving recognition in the media-driven meritocracy that is New York society. Like money, their names are used as currency on invitations and in gossip columns.

title: Joan Viebranz, Robert Lockwood
description: Joan Connor Viebranz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Viebranz of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Anthony Lockwood, the son of Barbara Allyn Jones Lockwood of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. J. Randolph Alexander performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Whitaker Makes His Point in Winning W.B.C. Welterweight Rematch Against Rivera
description: Nearly an hour had passed since his latest victory Friday night, and Pernell Whitaker was still in control. He sat calmly before a group of listeners, explaining his classic performance against Wilfredo Rivera to retain the World Boxing Council welterweight title.

title: Gay Rights Groups Attack Clinton on Midnight Signing
description: Gay rights advocates today denounced President Clinton's midnight signing of a bill to deny Federal recognition and benefits to couples of the same sex who might marry, dismissing it as a ''historical misjudgment'' that endorsed a ''needless and mean-spirited bill.''

title: Cinderella in London
description: Lynn Redgrave's effervescent portrayal of an awkward but curiously endearing creature of her time makes a firm centerpiece for GEORGY GIRL 91966), a gorgeous little Cinderella story rocketing through mod London. With little previous screen experience, Ms. Redgrave delights and charms us as she is caught up in the wake of a worldly couple (Alan Bates and Charlotte Rampling) and finally through good luck becomes the bridge of a millionaire (James Mason). The director, Silvio Narizzano, is wise and unobtrusive, dealing with realism and some tough minded characters, but hope springs forth around most every bend. This is a picture that makes you smile, ponder and chuckle - SATURDAY at 7 A.M. on A&E.

title: A Zesty Musical Love Affair With a City Beyond Words
description: ONE OF THE MYSTERIES OF music is the way it can conjure up the essence of a place more completely than any photograph or written description. Is it absurd to imagine that a city as complicated and changeable as New York has such an essence? Perhaps. But ''Leonard Bernstein's New York,'' a glorious mosaic of the composer's show tunes and orchestral excerpts from his film scores and ballets, presumes to do exactly that. Jauntily hard-boiled one moment, vaultingly romantic the next, this sonic elixir suggests a kaleidoscopic blend of Times Square, Carnegie Hall, Rockefeller Center and Coney Island placed against a star-spangled backdrop of the Manhattan skyline.

title: Elizabeth A. Fox, Kyle F. Keogh
description: Elizabeth Anne Fox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Fox of Buffalo, was married yesterday to Kyle Francis Keogh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Keogh of Pittsford, N.Y. Msgr. Francis Braun performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mark in Buffalo.

title: Who's That in the Oval Office?
description: EXECUTIVE ORDERS

title: What Time It Is in the Nouveau SoHo
description: The trickle of the city's art galleries into western Chelsea has grown to a flood over the last year, astonishing even the most boosterish of the area's champions -- and prompting what amounts to sponsorship from a Swiss watch company.

title: On Reconstructed Columbus, Assessing the Damage
description: Some say the dust is close to settling over the giant undertaking that was the two-year, $65 million Columbus Avenue reconstruction.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Paddling for the Peconic

title: Prancing Beneath Raindrops
description: ON Tuesday, a mighty storm started to drench the opening-night reception for the Brooklyn Academy of Music's 1996 Next Wave Festival. Hundreds of dressed-up people, who had come to Battery Park City for outdoor cocktails before the American premiere of ''Chimere,'' a performance by the Zingaro Equestrian Theater Troupe of France, ran, in vain, for cover.

title: In a Latin Roundup, Breadth and Depth
description: Latin Viewpoints

title: Keeping Valued Employees by Letting Them Go, for a While
description: RICHARD SCHACK has had a lot of turmoil -- mishegoss, as he puts it -- in his life. His companion of nine years died of AIDS in 1992, and since then so have a number of close friends. He desperately longed for a break from his job.

title: Classical Briefs
description: VERDI, TCHAIKOVSKY: ARIAS

title: The Summer of Hate
description: FATHER AND SON

title: The Flames Are Fanning Against Racism
description: ''WHEN people hear I'm from Coney Island, they walk away or they ask to see my gun,'' said Roderick Spivey, 17, who has no gun. ''I'm not comfortable in Coney Island. People are jealous, they want to mess you up and bring you down. Like crabs in the bucket.''

title: At Folk Festival, Roots Are Familial
description: OSCAR BRAND and Jean Ritchie, longtime folk singers, did not set out to turn their sons into musicians. It just happened that way.

title: LeRoy Neiman Looks In the Mirror
description: THE man who is arguably America's best-known artist leaned back in his baronial Central Park West duplex and rested his feet, encased in paint-splattered tennis shoes, on the desk in front of him. Lighted from behind by mid-September sun, LeRoy Neiman was trying to sum up a career spent in a brighter spotlight.

title: 'Like Finding a Rembrandt'
description: Early this year, William Buffum, a 77-year-old retired flour mill manager, and his wife, Margaret, decided to sell their home in Portland, Ore. Mr. Buffum, a part-time movie projectionist who collected old films as a hobby, called the American Film Institute to donate two films he had owned and carefully kept since 1960.

title: Read My Lips: Oral Promises May Bind Employers
description: IF an employer promises the moon but delivers only moondust, he may be headed for court on charges of fraud.

title: A Postrevolutionary Man
description: The President We Deserve

title: 2 Debates Set Between Dole And President
description: President Clinton and Bob Dole agreed through their negotiators tonight that they would meet each other for two televised debates in October and that Ross Perot would not be invited to either event.

title: Two Orchestras Added to List Of Strikers
description: September can be a cruel month for orchestra subscribers, to say nothing of musicians and managements. Because orchestra contracts tend to run out just before the start of each season, negotiations often hang like dark clouds over opening nights.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Dr. Lucy F. Squire, Radiologist And a Longtime Educator, 81
description: Dr. Lucy Frank Squire, a radiologist who became known as a medical educator, died on Sept. 15 at her home on the West Side of Manhattan. She was 81.

title: Democrats Ponder New Clinton Term
description: Bill Clinton could very well be on his way to becoming only the third Democrat in this century to win re-election as President. That feat alone would give him a place in history.

title: Longer Years, Better Schools
description: The idea of year-round public schools is suddenly getting attention in New York City. Putting children on a staggered schedule over 12 months would allow each school to handle up to 25 percent more students. That would reduce much of the overcrowding problem. Money now targeted for new buildings could be used instead for repairs, computers and new science labs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Pope Is Showing Stamina on His French Visit
description: Winding up a trip that was a test of his health and his popular appeal, Pope John Paul II showed today that he still has the stamina to meet the demands of his flock.

title: Panthers' Upset of 49ers Almost Looks Too Easy
description: The Carolina Panthers can no longer be considered a surprise, an underdog or a pleasant novelty. Rather, after the second-year club's 23-7 victory over the San Francisco 49ers today before 72,224 fans at Ericsson Stadium, Carolina has established itself as a solid, disciplined team, and a force in its division.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHEILA KAMERMAN has been at the forefront of children's causes in a different arena -- academia. She has been named the first Compton Foundation Centennial Professor for the Prevention of Children's and Youth Problems at Columbia University.

title: Banks Oppose Bailout of Poor Lands in Crisis
description: A group of the world's largest banks is urging the world's governments and the International Monetary Fund to stop using public money to help developing countries that fall into crises like the one that crippled the Mexican economy in 1994.

title: Case Study: When Busing Works, but Unease Persists
description: The move seemed logical enough.

title: Expanding the Boundaries of E-Mail
description: Even in the unconventional world of Internet business, Jaye Muller does not appear to be a typical entrepreneur. With his tight orange pants and blond-streaked hair, he looks more like a rock musician than the founder of an ambitious young company that wants to change the way business people communicate.

title: Bacon, Meet Erdos
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Showdown Time On 'Murphy Brown'
description: The changes in series returning this season range from significant touch-ups (Lily Tomlin's joining CBS's ''Murphy Brown'') to complete make-overs (''The Jeff Foxworthy Show,'' now on NBC instead of ABC).

title: INSIDE
description: Party Rebellion in Mexico

title: Legacy of Rwanda Violence: The Thousands Born of Rape
description: Some days, when she looks at her round-faced baby boy, Leonille M. feels that she no longer wants to live.

title: 'Ask Not . . .' '. . . Military-Industrial Complex . . .' '. . . but Fear Itself . . .'
description: In winnowing thousands of recorded speeches of this century's American political oratory down to a mere four-hour video of what every voter craves -- excitement, surprise, conflict, leadership -- Parker L. Payson sampled the quadrennial Presidential debates but usually hit the fast-forward button.

title: Huskers Learn What Losing Is Like
description: The Nebraska Cornhuskers seem to lose only once every millennium -- or once every three years -- so Saturday night's 19-0 loss to Arizona State had grown sophomores in tears. Tommie Frazier had put two rings on everybody's finger before leaving this summer for the Canadian border, but, the truth is, no one actually knew he was a one-man team until just this moment.

title: That's Entertainment: Gretzky Makes Debut as a Ranger
description: There was polite applause when he first came on the ice for warm-ups and a big cheer when he came over the boards for his first shift of the game. But the biggest roar Wayne Gretzky received was when the scoreboard flashed a video of Gretzky doing an Elvis Presley parody years ago when he hosted ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 25 about Mayor Dennis W. Archer of Detroit and his role in President Clinton's re-election campaign misstated the number of years Mr. Archer was a member of the Michigan Supreme Court. It was five years, not nine.

title: Perry Says 'Backing Off' By Iraq Eases Need for Ships
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that Iraq was ''backing off'' from its recent military threats and that as a result, the United States could decide as early as next week to remove one of the two aircraft carriers now in the Persian Gulf.

title: Abortion Sensitivity
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Dim Afterglow of the Giants' Victory
description: A post-game news conference to talk about a victory was an unfamiliar situation for Giants quarterback Dave Brown. It was sort of like having enough time to look off the primary receiver and find another target -- OPEN!

title: MOST STATES FIND GOALS ON WELFARE WITHIN EASY REACH
description: State officials are discovering that the work requirements of the new welfare law are much less onerous than they first believed.

title: Companies Reach Investors Via the Net
description: Bell & Howell's management found a new way of getting out information about its annual shareholder meeting last May in Ann Arbor, Mich.: broadcast the proceedings live on the World Wide Web.

title: A Hate-Crime Tale's Surprising Turn
description: In the last year Fort Bragg and this city have been buffeted by racial incidents and suggestions that white supremacist hate groups operate in their midst.

title: Late-Night Dining at Rutgers
description: That staple of college life, the late-night cholesterol fix, may get harder to come by for some New Jersey students. For years, Rutgers University students have ended the night with a visit to one of the all-night food trucks parked just off College Avenue for a gyro or a ''fat cat,'' a submarine sandwich filled with two beef patties, french fries and the works.

title: A Bit of Bluegrass, Blues, Flamenco, Whatever
description: When the mandolinist David Grisman started his quintet 20 years ago, he wisely named the group's instrumental repertory ''dawg music,'' leaving the possibilities wide open. At Town Hall on Saturday night, the quintet touched on bluegrass, bossa nova, swing, flamenco, blues, klezmer, funk and Arabic music. Its genial genre-hopping made it an unmistakable product of Northern California.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the presidential debates reversed the sites in some editions for the two sessions planned by the Dole and Clinton campaigns. The debate on Oct. 6 will be in Hartford, and the one on Oct. 16 in San Diego.

title: 'Pinafore' Sails Past Some Traps
description: The Gilbert and Sullivan operettas were politically incorrect a century before that term was coined. Yet most directors today seem to fear that American audiences will not understand the satire. A result is productions that either treat these audacious works like jolly anachronisms, or else load them up with razzle-dazzle Broadway staging that could not be more inappropriate.

title: This Season Already Unpredictable
description: The only happy people in Knoxville were giggling again. It was past 1:30 in the morning, at the end of Tennessee's somber Saturday night, and Florida Gator fans were still up, watching television screens in disbelief as they watched what was happening in Arizona. On Saturday afternoon they had gaped at the sight of their team racing from the gate by scoring 35 straight points in a bizarre 35-29 victory over Tennessee. Now they were blinking as they watched a season become a race.

title: Why The Cruelty?
description: A government agency with a history of abuse is called to account by the courts. The government's answer is to immunize the agency from legal challenges to its policies and practices.

title: More Users Now Taking Direct Route to the Internet, a Survey Finds
description: A new survey of home computer users has found that for the first time, more people are gaining access to the Internet through direct Internet service providers than through commercial on-line services like America Online or Compuserve, still substantially owned by H & R Block Inc.. But the survey also found that most consumers are not very impressed with the on-line experience.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: Labor Worries About Workfare

title: Perot Steps Up His Complaints On Being Kept Out of Debates
description: Ross Perot intensified his criticism of the Commission on Presidential Debates yesterday, taking his case to be allowed to participate to network news programs and unveiling a 30-second television advertisement that portrays commission members as ''career politicians'' and ends: ''Let Ross speak. The truth never hurt anyone.''

title: Canada's Public TV System Faces Cuts
description: The new fall lineup of prime-time programs has already begun on Canada's public television system, the CBC, but neither viewers nor network executives can be sure what will be on the air in the coming months because of deep budget cuts, thousands of layoffs and a drastic reshuffling of broadcast strategy that will purge all American soap operas and situation comedies from the CBC schedule.

title: Bus Driver Shot in Stomach
description: A New Jersey Transit bus driver was shot in the stomach yesterday by a passenger who then fled the bus, a spokesman for the agency said. The driver, Rich Berger, was en route from Philadelphia to the Burlington Center Mall and had stopped along Route 38 when a man who passengers said had gotten on in Pennsylvania shot him, the spokesman, Steve Coleman, said.

title: Newscast Wins an Emmy
description: Beating out big-budget network affiliates in Philadelphia, New Jersey Network News, a public broadcasting station, won the prize for the best newscast at the Mid-Atlantic Emmy Awards Saturday night.

title: Times of Rejoicing and Lamenting
description: The Rambert Dance Company rejoiced and lamented on Friday night, when it offered the third program of its engagement at the Joyce Theater.

title: Families on the Edge
description: The navy blue sweater of 3-year-old Timothy Dixon was saturated from the steady rain. No one paid much attention. Soggy clothing is one of the hazards of being homeless. Timothy was with his mother, Kim Dixon, his brother, Byron, 10, and his sister, Keisha, 8, in a downpour outside the city's Emergency Assistance Unit, a chaotic place in the Bronx where homeless families go to seek shelter and eventually, they hope, a subsidized apartment.

title: Sensitive Lovers and Exuberant Rag Dolls
description: Theme programs too often are deadly dull or poorly organized. ''In the Company of Men,'' an evening of dance created by men that was presented on Friday at the Pace University Schimmel Center, was an impressive exception.

title: Colombia's Conflict Predates Guatemala's
description: To the Editor:

title: Every Word a Prayer
description: I am third in a family of nine, which means that every year, sometime before sundown on the eve of Rosh ha-Shanah and again before Yom Kippur, I have at least three phone calls to make and six to receive. In the tradition of honoring elders, the younger siblings call the older ones, but it happens that an older sibling gets to the phone first and then there is some joking about who should call whom. It remains important, however, that the children call the parents and not the other way around. In any case, on these two days every member of our family will speak with every other member, and not for a minute or two either. These calls take time.

title: Mets Stumble in the Ninth
description: Butch Huskey hit his 13th home run and two doubles today for the Mets, but it was not enough to prevent the Phillies from earning a 4-3 victory and a split of the four-game series.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FBI Enlisted in Effort To Investigate Leak at Fed

title: We Like House Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: 40 Poems That Eliot Wanted to Hide, Including Some on the Bawdy Side
description: The poet's instructions could not have been more clear. ''I beg you fervently to keep them to yourself and see that they are never printed,'' T. S. Eliot wrote in 1922. He was 34, and he was preparing to sell a notebook full of early poems to a friend named John Quinn, for $140.

title: Winston H. Cox, 55, Ex-Chief Of the Showtime TV Network
description: Winston H. Cox, the former chairman and chief executive of Showtime Network and an outspoken critic of gratuitous violence on television, died on Saturday after collapsing at a Manhattan health club. He was 55.

title: They Call This Dance the Detroit Shuffle
description: From the massive entrance arches to the high, coffered lobby ceilings of Wedgwood blue and gilt, the immense General Motors headquarters here has always looked less like a corporate office building than a seat of government.

title: The Battle of New York, a Sad and Soggy Tale
description: Wayne Rusakks looked out disgustedly from his rain-soaked seat at the 50-yard line and shook his head. If ever there was a day that summed up the state of professional football in New York, this was it.

title: Newspapers increasingly cooperate in the face of growing competition for ads.
description: NEWSPAPER people like to consider themselves as among the most competitive of people, even if their scoops seldom make their papers any richer. There is a clear money logic for Ford's scratching to sell more cars than Chrysler, after all, but breaking the Watergate story didn't directly bring the Washington Post Company any more profits, only more esteem.

title: Dole Takes Note of a Clinton Anniversary
description: Bob Dole noted the three-year anniversary of the introduction of President Clinton's failed health-care overhaul measure today by denouncing it as a symptom of the President's ''liberal agenda.'' He ridiculed ''Liberal Bill Clinton'' as an advocate of higher taxes and bigger government.

title: Couple Sought in Murder
description: A Burlington County couple became the subject of a nationwide search after authorities said they abducted an elderly woman in North Carolina, bludgeoned her to death, dumped her body in Georgia and abandoned her car in Alabama.

title: At a Ceremony for Shakur, Appeals for Peace
description: More than a thousand people, most of them young, black and fans of the slain rap star Tupac Shakur, braved heavy rains yesterday to attend a ceremony in Harlem that was less a memorial and more a lesson in the futility of ''gangsta'' values and the street violence that recently ended the 25-year-old rapper's life.

title: Appalachia Family Reunions on Wane
description: Alma Watts Waddell surveyed her annual family reunion recently with the kind of tender smile she might bestow on an ailing relative.

title: 2 Spirits Marketers Alter Accounts
description: Two marketers of distilled spirits have made changes on their accounts.

title: Visa Expands Ties With Omnicom Unit
description: Visa International in San Mateo, Calif., has expanded its relationship with its United States agency of record, the BBDO New York unit of the Omnicom Group, by awarding that shop the assignment to create projects aimed at presenting a unified world image for the Visa brand.

title: Birds Imperiled by Pollutants
description: Many seabirds off the New Jersey coast have so much lead and mercury in their bodies that their chances for survival are threatened, according to a Rutgers University study reported by The Associated Press yesterday.

title: An invention may help make big, flat screens feasible for TV sets and computers.
description: FUJITSU LTD., the Japanese computer company, has patented a technology for plasma-display panels that it believes will vault the hardware hurdle that has obstructed production of large flat-screen televisions that hang on a wall.

title: People
description: * Peter E. Heymann, managing director at Sukon Marketing Communications, New York, was promoted to the added post of chief executive, succeeding Joseph Harris, who continues as managing director.

title: Remaking Radio as Internet Voice
description: Some broadcast industry executives are betting that the Internet will help radio reinvent itself and solve the medium's biggest shortcomings.

title: Drugs, Guns and Just Don't Do It
description: After dwelling for weeks on the economy, Bob Dole has begun attacking President Clinton on drugs and crime. As a tactical matter, Republicans may be right to try to add to Mr. Dole's central proposal, a 15 percent tax cut that has failed to excite voters. Mr. Clinton, however, has moved shrewdly to pre-empt criticism on these two social issues no less than everywhere else. The Republican candidate's poor gun-control record makes it unlikely that he can reclaim the crime issue for his own. As for drugs, both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole are right to call for more leadership, and right to accuse each other of ignoring the problem until fairly recently.

title: Bond Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week will include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned Wednesday and Thursday.

title: No Headline
description: ''This is the type of game everyone expected to see. Two bad teams playing a 13-6 game in the driving rain.'' SCOTT LINICK, at the Giants-Jets game. $(C5:1$)

title: Americans Bring Solheim Cup Back Home
description: It is a lovely place, this pastoral, prosperous neck of southern Wales, and today, an American visitor could appreciate the view in near silence.

title: Sony and Ogden in Big-Screen Film Venture
description: The Ogden Corporation and the Sony Corporation of America, a division of the Sony Corporation, are planning to co-produce two large-format films a year, beginning with the release of ''Mark Twain's America'' in the fall of 1997.

title: In Service Of Amazon, Composers Of Brazil
description: The Amanakaa Amazon Network, which takes its name from the Tupi Indian word for rain forest, has been raising money to preserve 150,000 square miles of Brazilian rain forest since 1990. One of the network's activities is an annual Amazon Week in New York, the seventh of which began on Saturday evening.

title: Personal-Injury Awards Rise
description: Awards in multimillion-dollar personal-injury cases increased sharply over the last year, the New Jersey Law Journal reported last week, led by the $17.7 million awarded to a Union County man who claimed his broken neck was caused by a defective Chevrolet roof. The 20 biggest verdicts and settlements over the last 12 months averaged $5.6 million, up more than 20 percent from last year's average of $4.7 million.

title: Will This Jets Team Find a Way to Win?
description: THE numbers now identify him as if he were a prisoner in a penitentiary. The numbers are 3 and 24, meaning that in Rich Kotite's last 27 games as the coach of the Jets and earlier as the coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, his record is 3 victories and 24 losses.

title: Foreign Coverage Less Prominent in News Magazines
description: If you solely depended on the three news magazines for information and just happened to glance at the covers of those magazines when they came out on Sept. 9, chances are you might not have realized that the United States had launched a cruise missile attack on Iraq the week before.

title: Comptroller Versus Chief, The Sequel
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took to the airwaves the other day to alert the public to a threat to his great metropolis. His target was not the usual roster of heartless criminals, impudent bureaucrats or other troublemakers. The Mayor, it seemed, was simply fed up with City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.

title: Middle-Relief Corps Is Still Yankees' Bane
description: Forgive Joe Torre if the combination of weather and playoff talk had him feeling a bit like Noah yesterday.

title: Why Pour Money Into Failed Amtrak System?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribute for a Birthday That Never Arrived
description: It was fitting that Friday night's tribute concert to Albert Ayler should take place in a church. One reason is that the tenor saxophonist's short career, utterly original work and mysterious death at 34 (he was found drowned in the East River in 1970) make his life seem almost like a saint's. Another is that his music, based on hymns, carols and anthems, and working up to the most sanctified glossolalia , is one of the few kinds of jazz whose sound befits the aeries and echoes of a place of worship.

title: Sharpton's Candidacy Has Democratic Leaders Stewing Over Strategy
description: As the Rev. Al Sharpton formally announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday, Democratic leaders said that his surprise entry into the race would complicate their efforts to regain City Hall next year.

title: Rise in Interest Rates Won't Curb Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretty soon, a computer control system may be perking your morning coffee.
description: THE Internet may be getting most of the media attention these days, but computer networks of a completely different variety are steadily finding their way into industrial plants, commercial buildings and transportation systems.

title: Wanted: Corporate Name. Must Evoke Speed, Power. Originality Optional.
description: The Internet has afforded software developers many opportunities the last few years -- including the freedom to name your company ''Yahoo,'' if that's what you want.

title: Dead Poets Yield To Stand-Up Routines
description: The only thing that can keep a television critic slogging through 40 new series in a single season is the prospect of a genuine surprise popping up when least expected. Welcome to ''Mr. Rhodes,'' a delightfully off-center sitcom having its premiere on NBC tonight.

title: No Pol Will Tell You
description: Only a couple of months ago, it seemed to be such a political masterstroke.

title: Rural Life Gains New Appeal, Turning Back a Long Decline
description: After graduating from college a few years ago, Marty Beanblossom did something that would once have seemed remarkable for an ambitious young man from this Midwestern prairie town. He came back.

title: The Real North Korea: The Bustle of a Mausoleum
description: If people are starving in North Korea, it is difficult to detect in this remote northeast part of the country, far from the area where floods have ravaged crops for two years in a row. Nor is there any outward sign of the political divisions that are rumored to lurk under the surface of the world's most closed society.

title: Rise in Interest Rates Won't Curb Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Bridge
description: Players and administrators are normally in two different worlds, and to play on an international level while fully occupied in bridge administration is a great rarity. One might think of Bobby Wolff of Dallas, one of the all-time great players who was president of the World Bridge Federation from 1992 to 1994. But that is not a full-time occupation, and his results improved greatly when he no longer had the cares of office to contend with.

title: Fox Said to Be Planning Spinoff Of Its Children's TV Show Unit
description: After months of weighing the benefits, the Fox Broadcasting Company has decided to spin off its Fox Children's Network, combining it with the Saban Entertainment Company -- producers of hit programs like ''Mighty Morphin Power Rangers''-- and create a new company, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

title: In New Canaan, Prominent Residents Fight a Subdivision
description: When a housing developer appeared before the town's Environment Commission here last month, he was armed with a landscape architect, three engineers, two wetland scientists, two lawyers and his own court reporter.

title: If Only Poe Had Succeeded When He Said Nevermore to Drink
description: To the Editor:

title: A Crowded Primary Creates A Classic Battle of Contrasts
description: A classic Louisiana battle of sharp differences shaped up here in the wake of Saturday's Senate primary vote, which saw a conservative Republican and a centrist Democrat win places in the November runoff.

title: Outsiders Bring Islamic Fervor To the Balkans
description: At a sharp bend in the Bosna River this small village, with its white stucco homes topped with terra-cotta roofs, climbs gently up a wooded slope.

title: Envisioning Clinton II
description: Although Bill Clinton could very well be on his way to re-election, there is little agreement on what a second term would bring. Page A13.

title: F.A.A. Weighs Plan to Track Airplanes Used in Bomb Tests
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is considering whether to create a central record of bomb-detection tests run on the nation's aircraft, after the recent discovery that a bomb-detection test could explain the traces of explosive materials found in the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about the purchase of three Ritz-Carlton hotels by the Host Marriott Corporation misstated the ownership of Ritz-Carlton. It is an independent company, not a subsidiary of Four Seasons Hotels Inc.

title: Rank-and-File Mount a Revolt in Mexico's Ruling Party
description: The rank-and-file members of Mexico's governing political party surprised the country this weekend by starting a raucous revolt against the party leadership.

title: Start Spreading the News: The Giants Are 1-3
description: On the Giants' third drive of the first half against the Jets, they scored a touchdown. In the grand scheme of things, this probably rates up there in excitability with infomercials on dog food and tests of the Emergency Broadcast System. But you wouldn't know that from the reaction of Giants tackle Scott Gragg. He was flailing his 300-pound body around on the ground in ecstasy in the end zone after doing something that resembled a cartwheel. He calls it the ''thunder roll.''

title: College Skyboxes Curb Elbow-to-Elbow Democracy
description: College football teams have long relied on marching bands, cheerleaders and winning teams to sell tickets and generate revenue. While nothing will ever take the place of a winning record, colleges across the country are adopting a more reliable, and more controversial, source of cash: those exclusive enclosed seats in the stratosphere of sports stadiums known as skyboxes.

title: Offerings of Equity and Convertible Debt Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Turner Deal a Chance for Time Warner to Fulfill Promises
description: When Gerald M. Levin and Ted Turner hit the road next Monday to sell the merger of Time Warner Inc. and Turner Broadcasting System, they will face a supremely jaded audience. For six and a half years, Time Warner's shareholders have waited in vain for the stock to rouse itself.

title: Sharing a Stage: India's Classical Styles
description: Dance in India has sacred roots, but by the 19th century a once-vital art form had fallen into disrepute. Among those who played a role in the rebirth of classical dance in India in the 1920's and 30's was the dancer Ragini Devi.

title: Rain Must Fall, But Yankees Cover Up Nicely
description: Yellow and orange rain slickers and umbrellas in every imaginable color were scattered throughout a damp and soggy Yankee Stadium. A day game seemed like a night game because the weather was cool and the lights were on before the first pitch. It was the perfect time to watch the Yankees and Red Sox -- from the solitude of your dry living room.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Raines And Jeter Adding Sizzle
description: Tim Raines and Derek Jeter grew up in different times, one a teen-ager in the polyester 70's, the other just now hitting his 20's during the fad's return. But what's old is new. That's the happening trend for the Yankees.

title: F.B.I. to Aid Fed in Inquiry Of Sensitive Rate Data Leak
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has agreed to assist the Federal Reserve in a highly unusual internal inquiry into a leak last week of sensitive information that some members of the Fed were pushing for an increase in interest rates, law enforcement officials said tonight.

title: Peace by Piece in Guatemala
description: The accord on security and justice that representatives of Guatemala's Government and guerrillas signed last week is a long-sought achievement. It is part of a productive peace effort that promises to transform one of the world's most violent and repressive nations. But vigilance by Guatemalans and the outside world will be needed to turn the promise into real change.

title: Health Coverage Gains, but Drug Addicts Lose
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Union Leader Urges Halt to Broadening Workfare
description: Troubled by a plan to have welfare recipients clean New York City subways and buses and by new Federal workfare requirements, the head of New York's largest municipal union has called for a moratorium on expanding the city's workfare program. The demand reflects the growing anxiety of labor leaders nationwide over workfare.

title: They're Singing and Dancing Despite Pain
description: They call it killing the choreography. Dance until you achieve transcendence -- jazz splits, toe stands, ''Russian'' leaps. Dance until you reach an endorphin high, where there is no pain anymore from inflamed iliopsoases (hip muscles) or patella tendons (knees), or hairline fractures of the calcaneus (heelbone).

title: Olivetti Talks With France Telecom
description: PARIS  France Telecom and Italy's Olivetti group are in talks aimed at forging a new strategic alliance that could lead to the French state telephone monopoly's eventually buying an equity stake in the troubled Italian company, according to executives close to the discussions.

title: Dorothy Lamour, 81, Sultry Sidekick in Road Films, Dies
description: Dorothy Lamour, whose sarong-draped charms adorned many films of the late 1930's and 40's, especially the ''road'' pictures she made with Bing Crosby and Bob Hope, died yesterday at her home in North Hollywood, Calif. She was 81 years old.

title: The Omnicom Group is forming a division to specialize in interactive marketing and media.
description: THE OMNICOM GROUP, the world's second-largest advertising agency company, is forming a division to specialize in interactive marketing and media in another strong step by Madison Avenue to become more deeply involved in those realms.

title: Yeltsin's Condition May Delay Heart Surgery Up to 2 Months
description: President Boris N. Yelstin is so ill that his planned heart operation may be delayed as long two months, his surgeon said today.

title: In His Own Words
description: ROSS PEROT

title: Kansas Opponents of Big Rail Merger Say Dole Ignored Them
description: Last March 29, just days after he locked up the Republican Presidential nomination, Bob Dole made an unusual and little-reported statement on the Senate floor announcing that he would play no further role in an issue of intense concern to his home state of Kansas, the merger of the Union Pacific and Southern Pacific railroads.

title: Lloyd's of London Says the Hard Times Are Well Behind It
description: After a brush with near financial ruin this summer, Lloyd's of London, the world's oldest insurance organization, is painting a picture of renewed financial strength and representatives are making an earnest pitch for new business in a tour of the United States.

title: Life of Paul Theroux, Told in Theroux Novel
description: MY OTHER LIFE

title: Henri Nouwen, 64, Dutch Theologian
description: The Rev. Henri J. M. Nouwen, a Dutch theologian who wrote more than 30 books on spiritual themes and taught at American universities before turning to live and work with the mentally disabled, died on Saturday in the Netherlands. He was 64.

title: A Publisher's Trademark: Low Advances and High Prestige
description: At his favorite corner table, Roger W. Straus Jr. greets the world according to habit. A yellow silk foulard is clasped loosely around his neck, a cream handkerchief tucked in his double-breasted jacket. And he is loudly, cheerfully spouting enough profanities to fill all the salt shakers in the Union Square Cafe.

title: An On-Line Service Planning Expansion
description: City Search Inc., which produces community-based on-line information services for the World Wide Web, plans to announce today that it has placed management teams in Austin, Tex., and Salt Lake City in preparation for starting local services in those cities by the end of the year.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: John F. Kennedy Jr. Is Married, Quietly, Reports Say
description: After years of speculation about his romantic life and a weekend flurry of hot rumors, John F. Kennedy Jr. was reported yesterday to have been married on Saturday to Carolyn Bessette, his girlfriend, in a private ceremony at a small resort on a secluded Georgia barrier island.

title: Headliner's Quiet Performance, Overlaid With Charm
description: The headliner was the quietest performer when Joao Bosco topped the bill for the Brazil-New York Jazz Festival '96 at Town Hall on Friday night. Mr. Bosco is from the generation of innovative Brazilian songwriters known as MPB (''Musica Popular Brasileira'') who emerged in the late 1960's and early 70's, They combined urban sophistication with respect for traditional roots and rhythms.

title: Does America Love or Hate the U.N.?
description: How alienated from the United Nations are the American people? That question is on many minds here as the United Nations prepares for a visit on Tuesday by President Clinton.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Boy Painted Swastikas
description: A 13-year-old boy from France has admitted to painting swastikas along a nature trail in Mamaroneck this summer, the police said. But investigators said they do not believe the boy is responsible for several other incidents of anti-Semitic vandalism over the last eight months in the quiet Westchester town.

title: Parties Bicker Among Themselves Over How to Divide Their Money
description: President Clinton's dominance in the polls and the fierce battle for control of Congress have set off tensions between the Presidential campaigns and their political parties over how best to divide a limited financial pie in the crucial last full month of the campaign.

title: Environmental Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Fifty years ago, ELINOR GUGGENHEIMER waged a campaign to persuade New York City to continue paying for the day-care centers it had opened for children whose mothers had gone to work during the war. And she prevailed.

title: British Business For Devon Direct
description: There have been two developments involving direct marketing.

title: Bernard Nath, 97, Civic Leader
description: Bernard Nath, a prominent lawyer and a leader in the Anti-Defamation League who worked to end discrimination, died last Wednesday at Highland Park Hospital in Chicago. He was 97.

title: Lakers Extend Harris's Contract
description: Los Angeles Lakers Coach DEL HARRIS, who originally signed a three-year contract before the 1994-95 season, has signed a two-year extension through 1989-99, the team said yesterday.

title: After New Law, Abortion-Clinic Protests Fall
description: New data show that violent protests at abortion clinics have decreased sharply in the 28 months since Congress made it a Federal crime to obstruct access to clinics.

title: Chairwoman of Adelphi's Board Is Accused of Using Her Double Role to Advantage
description: In the campaign to oust the trustees of Adelphi University here, the dual roles of its board chairwoman, Ernesta G. Procope, have loomed large.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: EXIDE SHARES UP SHARPLY ON AIR FORCE CONTRACT NEWS
description: The shares of Exide Electronics Group Inc. climbed 38 percent yesterday after the company received an Air Force contract that could be worth up to $625 million. The stock rose $3.50, to $12.625, in Nasdaq trading. Exide, based in Raleigh, N.C., makes devices that protect computers and other electronic equipment from electrical power loss. Exide said the three-year contract was worth about $375 million and could be extended two more years.

title: People
description: Joe Norberg was named to the new position of chief operating officer at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston. He had been chief financial officer at AST Research, Irving, Calif.

title: When Designers Hone Ideas for The Mainstream
description: When fashion people look at collections on the runway, they look for creativity and newness. But the rest of the world is often turned off by anything that looks too different, finding it strange and even scary. Which is one reason that high fashion is worn by a microscopically small percentage of women, while the vast majority wait until new styles have been adapted and modified to look more familiar.

title: Inquiry Into Reported Peeping at Police Station
description: Police officials said yesterday that they were investigating accusations that some male officers secretly watched their female counterparts through a two-inch hole at a women's locker room in a Manhattan police station.

title: Hateful Neighbors
description: The recent Bosnian election confirms that the Dayton accord's vision of a multiethnic Bosnia is doomed and that the partition of Bosnia is inevitable. Fierce nationalists won resounding victories at every level in all three communities -- Muslim, Serb and Croat. Two of the leaders elected to the three-person presidency -- Kresimir Zubak, a Croat, and Momcilo Krajisnik, a Serb -- have publicly declared that Bosnia should be partitioned. The people of Bosnia have spoken, saying ''no'' to living together.

title: 2 Oil Refiners In Merger Deal For $1 Billion
description: Diamond Shamrock Inc. and the Ultramar Corporation said yesterday that they planned to merge through an exchange of stock to form the nation's third-largest independent oil refining and marketing company in a deal valued at about $1 billion.

title: CLINTON SIGNS BILL FOR $256.6 BILLION FOR ARMED FORCES
description: In an election-year nod to the popularity of military programs, President Clinton today signed a $256.6 billion spending bill that provides a 3 percent raise for military personnel, even though the bill allows $11.2 billion more for the armed forces than Mr. Clinton requested.

title: Tyson Foods' Ex-Chief Settles S.E.C. Trading Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused Donald J. Tyson, the former chairman of Tyson Foods Inc., of tipping off a friend about Tyson's 1992 acquisition of an Alaskan fishing company.

title: War on Drugs Urged at U.N. By Colombian
description: With the audacity that has made him the scourge of Washington, President Ernesto Samper of Colombia -- minus the American visa he lost in July because the Clinton Administration accused him of having ties to narcotics traffickers -- came to the United Nations today to propose a new global campaign against drugs.

title: Ex-S.E.C. Chief's New Firm
description: The former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Richard C. Breeden, is leaving Coopers & Lybrand L.L.P. to start his own firm. The new firm, to be called Richard C. Breeden & Company, will be established on Oct. 1. Mr. Breeden said the move would give him time to act as bankruptcy trustee of the Bennett Funding Group, an equipment-leasing company in Syracuse that filed for bankruptcy in March after the S.E.C. accused it of defrauding investors of $570 million in securities.

title: August U.S. Deficit Up to $41.83 Billion
description: The Federal Government's total budget deficit widened to $41.83 billion in August from a $33.85 billion deficit last year, the Treasury said today.

title: For Dancing, in the Latin Way
description: The Caribbean still produces some of the world's best dance music, with the relationship between the improvisers on the dance floor and those on the bandstand guaranteeing that the music holds to especially high standards. Ignore the wishes of the dancers and be left behind on the pop junk pile.

title: The Kremlin Power Vacuum
description: Now that his own physicians have disclosed the gravely precarious state of Boris Yeltsin's health, Russia faces a potentially volatile period of political uncertainty. Though less visibly turbulent than earlier crises, including the failed 1991 coup attempt, this period could prove no less important in determining whether Russia makes a successful transition to democracy.

title: Peter Serkin to Replace Pollini at Carnegie Hall
description: The pianist Peter Serkin is to be the soloist with the Berlin Philharmonic, conducted by Claudio Abbado, in the opening concert of Carnegie Hall's 1996-97 season at 7 P.M. on Thursday.

title: From Old New York, Photograph Showed Library
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Plain Folks, White House Style
description: Did you catch the Barbara and Bob and Elizabeth and Bill and Hillary and Barbara shows? On ''20/20'' Friday, Barbara Walters chatted up the First Couple, a week after chatting up the would-be First Couple. ''Open, intimate, off guard,'' promised Hugh Downs, Ms. Walters's right-hand man, of performances that had all the spontaneity of a convention biography: damp goods in a damp campaign season.

title: Speculation of Merger By 2 Swedish Banks
description: Shares in Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken A.B., Sweden's third-largest bank by assets, and Svenska Handelsbanken, Sweden's biggest, rose on speculation yesterday that they were planning a merger that would create Scandinavia's biggest bank. Together they would have a market capitalization of 68.4 billion kronor ($10.4 billion).Both banks refused to comment. Handelsbanken's class A shares were up to as much as 161 kronor ($24.47), a record high, while S-E-Banken rose as high as 61.50 kronor ($9.35), a 30-month high. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Peugeot Says Profit Fell 50% in First Half
description: Peugeot-Citroen said yesterday that its profit fell more than half in the first half of the year because of auto price wars throughout Europe. Profit slumped to 602 million francs ($118 million), from 1.22 billion a year earlier. First-half revenue rose 3 percent, to 89 billion francs ($17.5 billion).

title: Seeing Liberty and Equality as Much Overrated
description: SLOUCHING TOWARDS GOMORRAH

title: Former Fugitive Is Facing New Troubles
description: Alex Kelly, a former high school wrestling star who fled to Europe a decade ago after being accused of raping two girls, faced new charges yesterday, three days after a car crash near his parents' fashionable home in Darien, Conn.

title: Private Research Giant Is Said to Be in Talks for Bellcore
description: The Science Applications International Corporation, the nation's largest privately owned research and engineering company, is said to be negotiating to buy the Bellcore research organization from the regional Bell communications companies for $700 million.

title: Dorothy Lamour, 81, Sultry Star of Road Films, Dies
description: Dorothy Lamour, whose sarong-draped charms adorned many films of the late 1930's and 40's, especially the ''road'' pictures she made with Bing Crosby and Bob Hope, died on Sunday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 81 and lived in North Hollywood, Calif.

title: MOOG TO ACQUIRE UNIT FROM MOTION CONTROL
description: Moog Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Moog Controls Inc. from closely held International Motion Control for $48.6 million in cash. All of Moog Controls' 240 employees will be offered jobs, a company spokesman said. Moog Controls, a maker of industrial controls primarily for United States markets, was spun off by Moog Inc. in 1988 in exchange for stock held by Bill Moog, the company's founder. Moog Inc., based in East Aurora, N.Y., makes controls used in commercial, industrial, aerospace and military applications with sales in the United States and overseas.

title: Giants' Running Game Can't Keep Up With Reputation
description: Something has become crystal clear this season for the Giants. They can no longer dominate the line of scrimmage and run the ball at will as they did in the late 1980's and early 1990's. The era of Giants' smash-mouth football is over.

title: Armenia Chief Faces Protests Over Election
description: The President of Armenia said today that he had won a ''brilliant victory'' in the presidential election on Sunday. But in the face of voting irregularities, thousands of protesters gathered near the presidential palace and demanded that he step down.

title: Paul Weston, 84, Who Wrote And Arranged Big Band Hits
description: Paul Weston, a pop arranger, conductor and composer who was one of the inventors of modern mood music, died on Friday at a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 84.

title: ARCO looks to Russia to fill its vast appetite for oil reserves.
description: WITH its huge fields in decline in Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, ARCO has been looking for new prospects overseas. Among the primary prospects for ARCO and other Western oil companies are Russia and some of the former Soviet republics like Kazakstan and Azerbaijan.

title: Appeal of a Woman's Revenge
description: Movie studios in the 1930's and 40's used to churn out films about oh-so-perfect wives -- often played by Norma Shearer or Margaret Sullavan or Irene Dunne -- whose husbands left them for other women. The theme of wronged women has hardly changed in contemporary Hollywood, but the studios have given it a new twist: anger and revenge.

title: Court Made Right Decision in School Gun Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Gun Matches Old Gun in Duel at the Stadium
description: THEY went to the same junior college in Texas, albeit a decade apart. One of them has won three Cy Young Awards as the best pitcher in his league. The other has not won a single Cy Young Award, at least not yet.

title: Anheuser Ends Czech Talks Over the Budweiser Name
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, which adopted the Budweiser name of a small Czech brewery more than a century ago, said today that it had broken off negotiations with the Czech Government in the decades-long trademark dispute.

title: Drivers Alerted To Clinton Visit
description: The police are warning drivers to avoid the East Side in midtown and lower Manhattan today, when streets will be closed because of the visit of President Clinton, who is to address the United Nations General Assembly.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: THE CAMPAIGNS FOR THE HOUSE
description: The Ad Campaigns

title: Association Selects Young Achievers
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington has elected seven more members to its Hall of Achievement for executives 40 years old or younger.

title: Beach Plan Is Withdrawn
description: Last night, officials were supposed to hold the first public hearing on a proposed shore protection plan that has upset politicians and homeowners along the coast. But the Department of Environmental Protection has canceled the meetings and will draw up an alternative instead.

title: Mrs. Clinton Is Linked to Payments in Deal Under Investigation
description: A new report by Federal regulators says legal work performed by Hillary Rodham Clinton and a law partner was used to facilitate sham payments in a 10-year-old real estate deal that is now a focus of the inquiry by the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Turnpike Speeders Warned
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced a crackdown on speeding yesterday, provoked by an increase in single-vehicle fatal accidents this year. There were 10 single-vehicle fatal accidents during the first eight months of 1996, but 11 all last year, said Lynn Fleeger, a spokeswoman for the authority.

title: Greenwich Air's Shares Fall 9%
description: Shares of Greenwich Air Services Inc. fell 9 percent today after the company said USAir would not renew a five-year contract for Greenwich's CFM56-3 engines.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Differing Views on Muster Walkout
description: THOMAS MUSTER, the world's third-ranked tennis player, got more backing from his native Austria yesterday for his controversial decision to pull out of the Davis Cup match in Brazil. But there were some misgivings, too. Muster accused Brazilian fans of acting ''like animals'' during Saturday's doubles match in which he walked off when he and his partner, UDO PLAMBERGER, trailed, 0-2, 15-30, in the fifth set.

title: Adelphi Critics Charge Conflict of Interest
description: A group that is trying to oust the trustees of Adelphi University on various charges of mismanagement has accused its chairwoman, Ernesta G. Procope, of conflict of interest, since she also owns the brokerage that handles the university's insurance.

title: Questions Raised Over Handling of Yeltsin Medical Case
description: When Boris N. Yeltsin's doctors meet on Wednesday to decide if and when the President should have a heart bypass operation, one of Russia's most renowned heart surgeons will not be there.

title: On Rocky Walls, Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS and specialists in the study of early humans are mystified by the discovery, announced last week, of what appears to be the oldest rock art in the world.

title: Long Lineup for a Downsized Job
description: The election will not be held for a year, and the office carries only a trace of its former grandeur and power. But candidates have already begun hungrily eying the office of Manhattan borough president.

title: Gretzky and Rangers Begin the Blending Process
description: Phase II of the Rangers' training camp began today at Playland Ice Casino, with the entire roster gathering for the first time.

title: Sabina Zlatin Dies at 89; Saved Children From the Nazis
description: Sabina Zlatin, who rescued dozens of Jewish children from the Nazis during World War II, died on Saturday in a Paris hospital. She was 89.

title: For Russia's Cardiac Patients, Little Care and Grim Prognosis
description: Just 60 miles north of the sparkling, world-class medical institute where President Boris N. Yeltsin plans to have his heart surgery, in a shabby city hospital with peeling brown paint and 20-year-old heart monitors, Mariya Chirkova nearly died last week for lack of a heart surgeon.

title: Utica's Leader Relishes His 'Lousy' Job in a 'Lousy' Place
description: One of the inexplicable things Edward A. Hanna did when he was Mayor here 20 years ago was to declare that Utica was ''a lousy place to live.'' Another was to construct the Tower of Hope outside City Hall in honor of Bob Hope, who has no particular connection to Utica.

title: G.O.P. WILL DELETE DISPUTED MEASURE IN IMMIGRANT BILL
description: Republican Congressional leaders have agreed to drop from a stalled immigration bill a divisive provision that would allow states to bar illegal-immigrant children from school.

title: After Guatemalan War, Sorrow and Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: South African Blacks Buy Into Industry
description: It wasn't the usual handshake on a deal. One hand, white, belonged to Nicholas Oppenheimer, scion of the family that controls much of South Africa's gold- and diamond-mining. The other, black, belonged to Cyril Ramaphosa, a prominent foe of the old, white-ruled South Africa and leader of a crippling 1987 miners strike.

title: Clinton Implies He Is Subject Of a Vendetta
description: President Clinton suggested today that it was ''obvious'' that the Whitewater prosecutor was out to get him and his wife, Hillary, whatever the truth of any accusations against them.

title: Presto Chango Evening Bag
description: The Prada bag may be high status, but not everyone can afford one, especially for a seldom-used evening purse. So smart women have been buying Prada cosmetics cases to carry at night.

title: For Kuwaitis, Self-Reliance Proves to Be an Elusive Goal
description: Exultant but also bitter after the Persian Gulf war, Kuwait sought to settle scores, deporting tens of thousands of foreign workers whose leaders had backed Iraq in the conflict. The new Kuwait, its leaders declared, should be run by the Kuwaitis.

title: Love at First Leap, Followed by Reality
description: When Isabel and Leo first meet, it is one of those earth-shaking, once-in-a-lifetime collisions of yin and yang. It doesn't hurt that they are in irresistibly romantic Rome, where Isabel has come to decide whether to marry her staid boyfriend, and Leo has come to celebrate his 26th birthday and decide whether to go to architecture school. Mere seconds after they decide to remain what they call ''traveling buddies,'' they leap into each other's arms.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actress Dorothy Lamour yesterday reversed parts of the name of her second husband in some copies. He was William Ross Howard 3d, not William Howard Ross 3d.

title: Warning About a Loophole
description: If the state cannot close a loophole, one legislator wants to make sure that people are at least warned about it. Assemblywoman Shirley K. Turner announced a bill yesterday to let expecting mothers know if they are not covered by the state law that requires insurers to pay for a 48-hour hospital stay after childbirth.

title: Employing Darth Vader to Take Care of Your Data
description: DESKTOP computers are commodities. The hardware differences between two boxes with similar specifications have become less significant than ever. As prices and profit margins decline, big-name manufacturers try to find clever ways to differentiate their machines from the putty-colored rabble.

title: Separation Anxiety For 0-4 Jets
description: NOW comes the finger pointing.

title: Buying Out a Housing Plan
description: A long-debated plan to build 2,000 town houses atop wetlands may be laid to rest tomorrow, when the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission is expected to vote to buy 186 acres of land from Hartz Mountain Industries for $2.3 million. Hartz had been trying for more than a decade to win approval for its Villages at Mill Creek, but had been opposed by Secaucus officials.

title: Another Bailout Seen For Credit Lyonnais
description: Credit Lyonnais, France's unprofitable state-owned bank, is set to receive its third Government bailout in two years when it reports first-half results on Thursday, a person familiar with the latest rescue plan said yesterday. A Credit Lyonnais spokesman, Olivier Perrain, declined to comment.

title: U.S. Shouldn't Blame Turkey for Turning to Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Seattle Falls to Angels, But Loses No Ground
description: Angels 4, Mariners 3

title: Newark Officers Arrested
description: It has been a difficult few days for the public image of Newark's finest. On Sunday, Hudson County prosecutors say, Officer Ayisha Westry of Newark acted as a lookout while two accomplices tried to steal a Jeep in Bayonne. Ms. Westry, a 22-year-old rookie, was suspended without pay and charged with theft and conspiracy.

title: A Maverick Art Scholar Pursues a Tangled Case
description: To some in Russian art circles, he's an icon of his own, a one-man art police squad ferreting out fakes, a keeper of his homeland's conscience and the books of history. To others, he is a bullying figure who knows less than he boasts and thrives on controversy and self-promotion.

title: Patterns
description: A Contender for Givenchy

title: It's Crying Time Again
description: Coach-firing season may start early this year. There was hardly a sports page in America yesterday morning, for example, that did not have an article suggesting that Rich Kotite, the embattled coach of the winless (0-4) New York Jets, might soon be looking for new employment. Having lost to the previously winless New York Giants, Mr. Kotite now has the distinction of coaching the worst professional team in the Greater Metropolitan Area, which is not a good thing in a Greater Metropolitan Area that can somehow endure crumbling schools but has no patience for lousy ball clubs.

title: Colts' Defense Holds Up
description: There were 60,891 fans in the RCA Dome tonight, the largest crowd here in history. They came expecting to see the Indianapolis Colts -- short-handed or not, healthy or not, lucky or not -- do two things: win, and keep the spirit alive.

title: Goats for Cashmere Promoted in Europe
description: Nora Kravis grabs a goat by the horn, ruffles the coarse hairs on its skin and points to the soft down underneath.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column of the Westchester Weekly on Sunday about the Five-Mile American Heart Walk along the Bronx River Trail misstated the date. It is this Sunday, not Saturday, beginning at 10 A.M. at the County Center Plaza in White Plains.

title: Out of Fantasy's Realm, Tales Told by Movement
description: The Artichoke Dance Company, which performed on Saturday afternoon at the Ohio Theater in SoHo, promises to be a welcome addition to the New York dance scene. The program of seven dances suggested that one aim of the company, which was formed last year by three choreographers who trained at the University of Michigan, is to explore dance based in fantasy and storytelling. That is an unusual preoccupation these days, but such dance requires a much more specific approach than was evident here.

title: When Curie Excelled
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Trek for Boers, to Congo's Greener Grass
description: Standing in the shadow of the three shipping containers that serve as his temporary shelter, Ben Fouche, a South African immigrant, surveyed the junk-strewn clearing that is his new homestead and uttered a pronouncement that was stunning in its optimism.

title: Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov stands for winning, not for fun. He does not mind following the severe discipline of exact play move after move, all day long, if he comes out the winner in the end. He abhors brilliance if it does not rest on the bedrock of soundness. For him that is just error, flashy nothing, not to be part of his game.

title: $5.5 Billion Missing
description: Switzerland decided a half-century ago to return to the Allies of World War II the stolen gold deposited by the Nazis in Swiss banks. But the bankers did not exactly clean out their vaults.

title: Harnisch Is Eager For Winter
description: Pete Harnisch wore a look of disappointment and disgust as he sat in front of his locker at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia on Saturday night. The Mets had just dropped a tight 2-1 decision to the Phillies. Harnisch had pitched well, but still wound up losing his fifth straight decision.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Who Deserves No. 1?

title: Except for the Pentagon
description: The best of all possible headlines for this column is ''Welfare Mom Meets Bottom-Line Guy.'' Unfortunately it's too big for the allotted headline space, so must be buried, wearing type too small for it, in that dull opening sentence.

title: Bidding War To Get Big B Seems Likely
description: Big B Inc. said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected a $330 million takeover bid from Revco D.S. Inc. as financially inadequate, upping the ante in what Wall Street believes may well become a bidding contest for control of the nation's 10th-largest drugstore chain.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DONNA KARAN likes London so much that she has opened a second store there, this one for her designer collection. ''London is the bridge between New York and Europe,'' Ms. Karan said. ''And 50 percent of our business for the collection is abroad, including Europe and Asia.''

title: Playoffs Kick Off in M.L.S. With MetroStars Vs. United
description: Having completed its first regular season with ample success on the field and in the stands, Major League Soccer launches its playoff season tonight with a nationally televised game between the MetroStars and D.C. United at Giants Stadium.

title: New York Needs Environment Bonds Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Nigeria Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Notion of Year-Round Schooling Is Slow to Win Over Los Angeles
description: They have seen lingering confusion and knotted-up schedules. They have been through broken friendships and canceled vacations, dropped classes and abandoned activities, sweltering classrooms and even hassles with the police.

title: Keeping Up With the Phoneses
description: SOME people think you cannot be too rich or too thin. On the Internet, where everyone can pretend to be rich and thin, it is commonly agreed that one cannot have too much bandwidth. Happily, new advances in modem technology promise a significant increase in the bandwidth available to typical Internet users next year, at least in theory.

title: No Jewish Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: Changing World View
description: Bill Clinton came into office talking about the United States sharing the costs and burdens of world leadership. But after crises from Somalia to Haiti to Bosnia to Iraq, President Clinton talks less about relying on the United Nations and is increasingly comfortable with acting alone.

title: Goodness, Without Angels
description: If you're lucky enough to have Della Reese as a guardian angel, it is a good idea to keep her around. ''Promised Land,'' a series spun off ''Touched by an Angel,'' leaves behind the very elements that make that show work: the gimmick of angels who prod people into reforming their lives, and Ms. Reese herself, whose tart delivery makes the otherwise sticky-sweet show palatable.
