title: CHRONICLE
description: Was CAROLYN BESSETTE thumbing her nose at Calvin Klein, her former boss, when she married John F. Kennedy Jr.?

title: The Tubes of Bald Head: Battle on a Barrier Isle
description: Even Hurricane Fran dealt gently with this resort island, a wealthy enclave where sunsets are long and slow and travel is by golf cart. The storm, which devastated 120 miles of beaches and many homes farther up the North Carolina coast, merely brushed Bald Head, shaking loose barely a shingle or two.

title: Perot Files Debate Suit
description: Ross Perot, the Reform Party candidate who is being kept out of this year's Presidential debates, filed a lawsuit in Federal Court in Washington seeking to force his way into the forums. In the complaint, Mr. Perot's lawyers offered a complicated legal assault on the group that voted to exclude him, the Commission on Presidential Debates.

title: Jets Regret Passing On Running Game
description: A day after a 13-6 loss to the Giants became the latest in a steady stream of Jets defeats, confusion lingered over what the Jets wanted to do offensively in the second half and why they abandoned the running game when it was working so effectively.

title: Chocolate: The Stuff Of Shock Absorbers?
description: DRIVERS may one day glide over potholes on a cushion of melted chocolate -- or something with a similar composition.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COASTAL PHYSICIAN GROUP INC., Durham, N.C., a health-care service, hired the investment firm Smith Barney Inc. to advise it on a sale of the company.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: Executive Changes
description: GLOBAL DIRECT MAIL CORP., Port Washington, L.I., named Curt S. Rush to the new position of general counsel.

title: Fear And Shopping In Queens
description: ON the peninsula of two-story houses known as College Point, jutting into the East River, people refer to their part of Queens as their ''town,'' as though it were independent.

title: Amoco Ends India Project
description: The Amoco Corporation has scrapped plans to invest as much as $1 billion in a methane project in eastern India because it could not reach an agreement with the Indian Government. Amoco said the unresolved terms included unclear legal title to the gas and a lack of assurances that the tax structure would be kept stable for the life of the operation. Amoco's decision follows two years of discussions about the project with the Government.

title: Paul Erdos, 83, a Wayfarer In Math's Vanguard, Is Dead
description: Paul Erdos, a legendary mathematician who was so devoted to his subject that he lived as a mathematical pilgrim with no home and no job, died on Friday in Warsaw. He was 83.

title: U.S. and Russia Report Gains in Talks on Anti-Missile Accord
description: The United States and Russia have reached agreement on the first part of an understanding that would allow the United States to proceed with efforts to build defenses against shorter-range missiles, while preserving the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.

title: Stealing G.O.P.'s Thunder, He Reduces Stress on U.N. Role
description: Bill Clinton came into office talking about a standing United Nations rapid deployment force and with aides preaching a policy in which the United States shared the costs and burdens of collective world leadership.

title: Football Player in Coma
description: The captain of the Snyder High School football team remained in a coma yesterday after colliding with an opponent during a game on Friday. The player, Tahid Ramsey, 17, a senior, threw an open-field block on a player from Ferris High School on a kickoff return and fell to the ground, said Robert Murden, Snyder's athletic director. Mr. Ramsey is on life support at Jersey City Medical Center, a hospital spokesman, William Dauster, said.

title: Perot Goes to Court to Try to Get Into the Presidential Debates
description: Ross Perot filed suit in Federal District Court today seeking to force his way into this year's Presidential debates and portraying the process that led to his exclusion as corrupt and unconstitutional.

title: What's the Trendy Word at Co-ops These Days? 'Rejected'
description: Getting into a co-op, an excruciating experience at any time, has recently become even more so, as co-op boards reject more and more applicants in a growing number of neighborhoods and income brackets.

title: No More Hot Horses
description: A veterinarian who treats horses at Meadowlands Race Track may no longer use radioactive materials. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission cited Dr. Roy Sadovsky of Floral Park, L.I., for improperly storing a gold isotope that is implanted in horses' legs to treat tendinitis, and for failing to provide radiation monitoring devices to his workers. His veterinarian's license was not affected.

title: Meteor and Plane Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Christie's to Auction Impressionist Collection
description: A group of 10 Impressionist paintings and drawings, including two Monets and a Picasso, are being sold at auction by Jane Englehard, the philanthropist and longtime board member of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Enthralling or Exasperating: Select One
description: DAVID SLOAN WILSON was a newly minted Ph.D. in his early 20's when he went to visit one of evolutionary biology's leading theorists and tried the intellectual equivalent of selling atheism to the pope.

title: Vaughn Adjusts, and Keeps Boston's Hopes Alive
description: Mo Vaughn likes to play in New York, close to where he grew up, in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Teen-Ager Takes His Life And Everything With It
description: Nothing is more shattering than the death of a child, and it's even more devastating when the reason is suicide. That's the experience sensitively probed in ''After Jimmy,'' tonight's drama on CBS. What is in some ways a typical by-the-numbers television movie, complete with comforting lessons, is given unusual depth and resonance by a fine cast beautifully directed by Glenn Jordan.

title: Bond Prices Are Higher On Thin Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday in lackluster trading as traders prepared for today's meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers.

title: A New Tier Of Executives At Goldman
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, as part of a continuing reorganization of the 127-year-old Wall Street partnership, is planning to create managing director positions, people familiar with the firm said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Sets Record, As Broader Market Slips

title: INSIDE
description: Police Raids in London

title: River in Nevada Helps Its Own Restoration
description: THE trembling leaves of a forest of knee-high cottonwood saplings flash a moving mosaic of light and dark green on the bank of the lower Truckee River. Just two years ago, the riverbank was a barren surface of dry, cracked mud and rocks baking in the hot Nevada sun. But an innovative restoration effort has taken advantage of two winters of abundant snowfall and spring floods to bring hundreds of thousands of trees back to this long-suffering river.

title: GRACE BUYS BACK 10 MILLION OF ITS SHARES
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had completed the repurchase of about 10 million of its common shares. The company, based in Boca Raton, Fla., said the shares were bought at an average price of $73.69 under a program announced in October 1995. Grace stock closed yesterday at $74.125 a share, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Later this month, the company plans to spin off its health care unit, National Medical Care Inc., which will be combined with a German dialysis concern, Fresenius A.G. After the spinoff, Grace said, it planned to buy back up to 20 percent of the shares of the new Grace. The company currently has about 89 million shares outstanding.

title: Anticipating the Fed: Moods Swing With the Data
description: The Federal Reserve's policy makers, who convene this morning to set the short-term interest rate levers they control, appear to be sharply divided. It is their last chance to alter rates before the Presidential election, and several Fed regional presidents are agitating for an increase of at least a quarter point in the closely watched Federal funds rate, the interest rate charged among banks for overnight money.

title: A Once-Crucial Issue Languishes in the Campaign
description: The mini-crisis in United States relations with Iraq in the last few weeks has only emphasized how meager a role foreign policy has played during this long campaign year, especially when compared with past Presidential contests.

title: Al Sharpton's Mayoral Race
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton's announcement that he may run for mayor of New York City has suddenly put the spotlight on an election that will not take place for more than a year. Other Democratic candidates, who struggle mightily to attract any notice at all, have a right to feel chagrined.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a plan by the Campbell Soup Company to sell frozen health meals by mail included one company erroneously among those that sell frozen foods by mail. Freezer Queen Foods of Buffalo does not.

title: Tyson Testifies Rooney Betrayed Him
description: MIKE TYSON, in lengthy testimony in his former trainer's lawsuit against the heavyweight champion, yesterday denied ever offering KEVIN ROONEY a career-long contract.

title: Kidder to Pay $15 Million in Fraud Claim
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company has agreed to pay $15 million to settle claims that it took part in a reported securities fraud by the Bonneville Pacific Corporation, an alternative-energy concern.

title: In the campaign for its new sports utility vehicle, Ford its traveling the young and haughty road.
description: THE Ford Motor Company is using old-fashioned snob appeal in an outdoorsy setting to sell its all-new Expedition, a big brother to its popular Ford Explorer model.

title: Yanks Let Down by Bullpen but Gain on Orioles
description: There are power lunches, places of power and the power of two. Whatever shape or form it comes in, people want it. And Roger Clemens has it.

title: Israel's Orthodox Don't Shun Modernism
description: To the Editor:

title: Gooden's Role Keys on Health
description: It seemed yesterday as if Manager Joe Torre had decided to lean the other way regarding Dwight Gooden's chances of making the Yankees' post-season roster.

title: Gasoline Prices Take Tumble On Outlook for Ample Stocks
description: Gasoline prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, pulled down by expectations that high rates of domestic refinery production and a seasonal drop in demand would keep supplies ample.

title: Protein Linked to 3 Nerve Ailments
description: IN two papers representing the work of 19 researchers, scientists reported last week that they had seen, at a molecular level, the damage to an important protein that is the cause of three genetic nerve disorders.

title: Woods Proves Worthy of the Hype
description: No matter what Tiger Woods does in his next three scheduled appearances on the PGA Tour, he has already assured himself of playing a full Tour schedule next year. By finishing tied for third at the rain-shortened B.C. Open this past weekend and winning $58,000, Woods, 20, vaulted into 128th place on the money list with season earnings of $140,194.

title: North Carolina Media Try to Lead Politics to Issues
description: Several of this state's major newspapers and television and radio stations have agreed on what the real concerns are for residents this year, and, working together, they are trying to force candidates to address them.

title: Mariners Are Laughing and Soaring
description: Ken Griffey, the Seattle Mariner with seven figures on his contract, barged into his manager's office tonight to grab the lineup card.

title: Negotiating A Dispute in 'The Spirit' Of ASEAN
description: SINGAPORE  Shortly before Japanese patrol ships repelled Chinese nationalists from Taiwan and Hong Kong who were trying to land on disputed islands in the East China Sea, Indonesia indicated how another part of Asia has kept nationalism in check.

title: British Police Say Raids Thwart Suspected I.R.A. Bomb Attacks
description: A terrorist suspect was shot dead, five men were arrested and some 10 tons of explosives and weapons were uncovered today in a series of raids before dawn that the police said had forestalled imminent I.R.A. attacks in the British capital.

title: Q&A
description: An Eclipse by Daylight

title: General Motors Gets Deadline For a Strike By Canadians
description: The Canadian Automobile Workers union threatened again today to strike General Motors unless G.M. reversed plans to sell factories, the latest in a series of coordinated moves by the Canadian union and the United Automobile Workers union to derail G.M.'s plans to slim down.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: No Headline
description: The Kuwaiti, he does not like to work. The foreigners have experience that we lack, and they work for lower salaries. This does not mean that the Kuwaiti does not contribute. But this way, the Kuwaiti can stay safe and rested. -- FALAH AL-RASHIDI, a 23-year-old Kuwaiti. $(A1:1.$)

title: STERLING SOFTWARE SAYS BOARD APPROVES SPINOFF
description: Sterling Software Inc. said yesterday that its board had approved a spinoff of its Sterling Commerce unit. Sterling Software currently owns 81.6 percent of Sterling Commerce. The parent sold off about 18 percent of the unit to the public in March at $24 a share. The spinoff will involve distributing special dividends of the remaining 61.2 million shares in the subsidiary that are not publicly owned. The dividends will be payable on Oct. 7 to Sterling Software shareholders of record next Monday. About 1.6 shares of Sterling Commerce will be distributed for each outstanding share of Sterling Software. Its shares fell 75 cents, to $73.50, yesterday. Sterling Commerce shares fell 62.5 cents, to $30.

title: Accounts
description: Hunt-Wesson, Fullerton, Calif., a unit of Conagra Inc., to Berry Brown Advertising, Dallas, as agency of record for its Manwich line of sauces, which had been handled by Suissa Miller Advertising, Santa Monica, Calif. Berry Brown also handles Wolf chili for Hunt-Wesson. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Dole Uses Clinton Health Plan To Portray Him as a Liberal
description: Bob Dole held a chatty session with voters here in this northern Virginia suburb today, dragging out one of the Republicans' most popular props from the 1994 campaign to back up his ridicule of President Clinton as a hopeless liberal.

title: Settlement In a Bias Case Sets a Record
description: The Justice Department announced here today that a housing discrimination case had been settled for $475,000, the largest settlement to arise from a Federal program that sends test applicants to housing complexes that are suspected of discriminating.

title: Shots From a Starter Gun Alert Long Island Police to a Man's Home Arsenal
description: Police officers responding to reports that shots had been fired on a residential street in Woodmere, L.I., said they made a surprising discovery in a two-story house: pipe bombs, machine guns and assorted rifles and explosives in a vast arsenal.

title: Contests Tighten For 2 Accounts
description: Two companies have narrowed reviews on their accounts.

title: In Albany, Talk and Hope About a Raise
description: Although no one has formally proposed the idea, many members of the Legislature say they strongly believe that they will return for a special session after the Nov. 5 elections to give themselves a raise, and a potentially hefty one at that.

title: France Telecom Talking To Olivetti About Deal
description: Olivetti S.p.A. and France Telecom both dismissed a report in The International Herald Tribune yesterday that the companies were negotiating an alliance that could lead to France Telecom's acquiring an equity stake in Olivetti. Both companies said they were actually involved in talks about France Telecom's buying a piece of Olivetti's telecommunications joint venture Infostrada as part of an agreement dating from November 1995. Infostrada is a joint venture with the Bell Atlantic Corporation that provides data transmission and long-distance phone services in competition with Telecom Italia S.p.A. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Dow Up 6.28, to 5,894.74, in Sluggish Trading
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rallied from a 53-point deficit to finish at a record yesterday, but declines in oil and semiconductor shares hurt the broader market.

title: Ranchers Ride to the Defense Of Mountaintop 'Sky Islands'
description: WARNER GLENN's dogs picked up the jaguar's scent when the big spotted cat was almost within sight of the canyon where Geronimo surrendered 110 years ago, here in one of the most unusual landscapes of North America: an archipelago of magnificent mountain forests and grasslands rising from the desert like islands from the sea. They are called sky islands, and they are home to one of the richest panoplies of living creatures on the continent.

title: No Violation of Rights Is Found In Cornell Dorms for Minorities
description: The United States Department of Education has ruled that Cornell University is not in violation of Federal civil rights statutes by maintaining two dormitories that attract mostly minority residents.

title: Trial Begins for Pool Mechanic in a Tennis Star's Death
description: A pool mechanic's failure to install a $1.44 piece of exhaust pipe helped cause the death of the tennis star Vitas Gerulaitis from carbon monoxide exposure, prosecutors charged today as the mechanic went on trial.

title: People
description: Lawrence J. Iannuzzelli was named to the new position of managing partner at Block Advertising and Marketing, Verona, N.J. He had most recently been executive vice president and business unit head at DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: NEW ENGLAND INVESTMENT TO BUY JURIKA & VOYLES
description: The New England Investment Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Jurika & Voyles, an investment management firm, for about $95 million. Boston-based New England Investment manages real estate assets valued at about $86 billion. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company owns 55 percent of New England Investment. Jurika & Voyles, a firm with $5 billion in assets, is based in Oakland, Calif. The deal, expected to close early next year, would give New England $91 billion in assets under management.

title: Blazers Get a Guard
description: ALEKSANDR DJORDJEVIC, a sharpshooting point guard who helped lead Yugoslavia to a silver medal in the Atlanta Olympics, has signed a contract with the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Open Short-Sale Positions Increase by 7.7% on Nasdaq
description: Open positions on short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 7.7 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.

title: Albany Aided Segregation, Court Declares
description: In a groundbreaking decision, a Federal appeals court has ruled that New York State education officials and the State Legislature actively ''encouraged the perpetuation of segregation'' in Yonkers in the 1960's and 1970's and that the state must pay the high costs of remedying the harm done to black and Hispanic children.

title: Kohl Confident On Monetary Union
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany warned yesterday against talk of delaying the proposed European monetary union and expressed confidence that the project would go ahead as planned. European nations are struggling to narrow their deficits to 3 percent of gross domestic product in 1997 to qualify for the 1999 start date.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When the British playwright HAROLD PINTER wrote ''Betrayal,'' the inspiration was autobiographical. The play, which was first presented in 1978, was, a new biography by MICHAEL BILLINGTON reports, inspired by Mr. Pinter's seven-year affair with JOAN BAKEWELL, a British television news broadcaster and journalist.

title: The Secrets of Swiss Bankers
description: The cloistered Swiss banking industry has belatedly and reluctantly agreed to unlock two of its most disturbing secrets. One is its handling of accounts opened by European Jews who were later killed in the Holocaust. The other is the expedient relationship it cultivated with Nazi Germany.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MOTHER TERESA, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, is expected to be discharged today from the Woodlands Nursing Home in Calcutta, where she was hospitalized on Sept. 16 after having fallen from a chair, Reuters reported yesterday.

title: A Toast To the Marriage Of the Web And Wine
description: A WINE lover's discovery of the World Wide Web can feel like a first trip to a thriving city far from home. So many unsuspected intertwined lives! So many busy projects! Who knew that devotion to pleasure on the Internet had flourished to such an extent? Type in the word ''wine'' and the search agent Web Crawler returns 10,419 links (click a button and go); a recent search through Lycos provided access to 31,365 documents.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Chess column in Science Times yesterday about a game between Anatoly Karpov and Oleg Romanishin omitted a passage in some copies. The affected passage should have read:

title: Don't Overplay Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Tooth Fairy Defense Budgets
description: One probably can't expect Presidential candidates to debate what they agree on, which, for President Clinton and Bob Dole, seems to be a lot. Still, someone should tell the voters what's going on in the vital area where the nation's defense and finances intersect. Both candidates are balancing the budget on the back of the Pentagon, and neither is owning up to the implications.

title: U.S. Economy Is Off Track, Dole Declares
description: In an hourlong address today, Bob Dole stepped up his attacks on President Clinton and signaled that he was returning full-bore to his economic message.

title: One Generation's Haunted Reverie Is Another's Pot of Gold
description: UP a lazy river, Hoagy Bix Carmichael watched the brown water slide by and said nothing. While he was at it, he also did nothing, if you think that watching insects dance over the water and following the dimples poked into the surface by feeding trout are nothing.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Ratings Yield Drama: ABC and Fox Faltering As Fall Season Begins
description: The first week of the new television season held more threat than promise for at least two networks, as both ABC and Fox watched their ratings tumble badly. CBS, on the other hand, saw its back-to-basics strategy largely vindicated by viewers last week, while NBC continued to expand its overall leadership of prime time.

title: Medical Kickbacks Admitted
description: The owner of a Fort Lee medical supplies company pleaded guilty yesterday to paying kickbacks to a podiatrist's relative in exchange for orders. Ronald M. Nemeroff, who owned the defunct Palisades Medical Technologies, paid more than $36,000 to the stepfather of a podiatrist, who was not identified, to supply the doctor with lymphedema pumps. Medicare paid nearly $145,000 for the pumps, which are used to treat a rare lymph disorder, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Clinton Pulls For His Party In New Jersey
description: President Clinton traveled to a Republican stronghold in New Jersey today to talk about domestic issues like gun control and tax writeoffs for tuition and to support Democratic Congressional candidates.

title: INSIDE
description: Home Runs by the Bushel

title: Vote on Sex-Offender Prison
description: New Jersey's voters should be given a chance to decide whether to close the state's special prison for sex offenders, two Republican legislators said yesterday. Assemblywoman Rose M. Heck, of Hasbrouck Heights, and Senator Louis F. Kosco, of Paramus, said legislation to be introduced today would include a referendum on whether to phase out the Adult Diagnostic Treatment Center at Avenel. The treatment center has been criticized for years as ineffective.

title: Clean Up Your Land, European Union Tells Ex-Eastern Bloc
description: The public handwringing about the soiled air and water of Central Europe may have subsided, but the countries of the former East bloc have been notified that they will not be welcome in the European Union until they take on their environmental problems more vigorously.

title: Is It the Lighting, or the Angel Glow?
description: You couldn't ask for a more compatible pairing than the singer Barbara Cook and the lyricist Oscar Hammerstein 2d, whom she is honoring in her wonderful new show at the Cafe Carlyle (Madison Avenue at 76th Street). With her gold-trimmed lyric soprano and gift for conveying the rush of emotion in a way that is at once broadly theatrical, deeply personal and without affectation, Ms. Cook is the vocal embodiment of Hammerstein's esthetic of balanced uplift.

title: Victims' Shoes Are a Protest Of Gun Deaths
description: HUNDREDS of shoes -- from scruffy sneakers to spit-shined wingtips -- were piled high on Barbara Hohlt's dining room table on Sunday. Nearby, a dozen people busily rooted through bags and boxes of even more shoes, making her Brooklyn Heights home look like the epicenter of a specialty tag sale.

title: I.R.A. Cache Of Arms Sets Back Ulster Talks
description: The discovery of a huge stock of I.R.A. explosives and weapons by the police in London on Monday has seriously wounded the peace effort in Northern Ireland, but did not kill it, Irish and British officials and independent analysts said today.

title: MetroStars Take Lead in Playoffs
description: The rivalry between the MetroStars and D.C. United that was born this season was heightened tonight in the first playoff game in Major League Soccer history, when the teams engaged in a controversial shootout that went 11 rounds.

title: Honors
description: John Mack Carter, president of the Hearst Magazines Enterprises unit of Hearst Corp., New York, was named to receive the 1996 Silver Medal Award from Advertising Women of New York.

title: More Jail for Ex-Official
description: A former Newark City Council president, already sentenced to 33 months in prison on one corruption conviction, was sentenced to eight more months yesterday for conspiring with an East Orange councilman to extort a campaign contribution. The Council President, Ralph T. Grant Jr., was convicted in May in Federal court of conspiring with Ralph Harris to offer an East Orange contract to a towing company for a $10,700 donation to Mr. Harris's 1993 mayoral campaign. Mr. Grant was convicted last year of soliciting a $25,000 bribe from the same towing company operator, who turned out to be an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Rise in Income Tops Inflation
description: Per-capita income in New Jersey grew faster than inflation last year but slightly slower than the national average, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. The state's per-capita income -- total annual income divided by population -- went up 5.1 percent in 1995, to $29,848. The national rate of per-capita income growth was 5.3 percent. New Jersey's status as the second-wealthiest state (after Connecticut) was unchanged.

title: For the Love of Joni, In Blond Wig and Bonnet
description: Shouts of ''We love you, Joni!'' periodically erupted through the cabaret at the Westbeth Theater Center during a recent performance of ''Paved Paradise,'' John Kelly's alternately worshipful and uproarious tribute to Joni Mitchell. Mr. Kelly, a 42-year-old performance artist, has been doing impersonations of the flaxen-haired folk-pop diva for more than a decade. But ''Paved Paradise,'' which plays at the theater through Saturday (151 Bank Street, West Village) is a full 90-minute show in which he sings more a dozen songs by the queen of confessional singer songwriters.

title: Lawmakers' Shift to Full-Time Politicking Won't Mean a Change in Routine
description: There is serious legislative work going on as Congress hurries to adjourn, but not so much of it that it gets in the way of politicking.

title: Suit Against Fuller Over Death Of Guatemalan Youth Dismissed
description: A Federal judge in St. Paul has dismissed a wrongful death lawsuit filed against the H. B. Fuller Company of St. Paul, a leading adhesive manufacturer, by the family of a Guatemalan teen-ager who died in 1993 from the effects of sniffing glue.

title: Isetan Suit Against Barney's Gets Approval
description: The Isetan Company won approval yesterday to proceed with a lawsuit against the owners of Barney's, the retailer based in New York, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January.

title: The Critics Were Wrong
description: O.K., it's safe to say it now: The 1995 U.S. bailout of Mexico's economy with a $12.5 billion loan worked. Mexico has now repaid $9 billion of that loan, including $1.29 billion in interest, and the Standard & Poor's credit agency just upgraded Mexico's government bonds from ''negative'' to ''stable.'' You may recall the Mexican bailout was fiercely resisted by most of Congress, but a few brave legislators (including Bob Dole) supported President Clinton when he essentially took personal responsibility for the Mexico loan by getting the money from a special Treasury Department fund, instead of Congress. If Mexico had defaulted, Mr. Clinton, and his top Treasury officials Robert Rubin and Larry Summers, would have been skinned alive. But it turns out they were right. Their critics -- Al D'Amato & Co. -- were wrong. So what have we learned?

title: Pollution Stand Criticized
description: In the latest attack on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to relax water-pollution laws, the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group released a study yesterday that found that New Jersey already ranks 12th worst in the nation for toxic chemicals discharged directly into waterways. The study, based on an analysis of data from 1990 to 1994, also found that the Delaware River receives more toxic discharge than all but five other waterways nationwide, and that New Jersey is home to 9 of the 50 companies rated worst for discharging toxic waste to sewage plants.

title: Rebuild Infrastructure
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami's Mean Streets
description: In May, ''Nightline'' on ABC began an ambitious series on race called ''America in Black and White,'' which for five consecutive nights bluntly addressed some sensitive racial topics. This week the series has resumed, addressing race and crime and focusing on Miami. Tonight Ted Koppel, the program's host, will lead a discussion among black and white police officers and several citizens about why Miami has one of the nation's highest crime rates.

title: New Breath Test for Ulcer-Causing Bacterium
description: ALTHOUGH doctors have learned in recent years that most peptic ulcers are caused by a bacterial infection of the stomach, the infection has been hard to detect. The only sure method has required an invasive procedure, endoscopy, in which a tube is passed down the patient's throat and into the stomach to remove a piece of tissue for analysis.

title: EMI Records decides that its musical artists will feel more at home in Midtown South.
description: EMI RECORDS has leased nearly 50,000 square feet -- the third, fourth and fifth floors -- at 304 Park Avenue South, a 13-story, 190,000-square-foot building on the southeast corner of 23d Street in Midtown South. The record company, whose performers include Jon Secada, Queensryche and many rap artists, will be moving from 1290 Avenue of the Americas, a 43-story, 1.9-million-square-foot building at 52d Street.

title: Clinton Unleashes a Fierce Attack on Dole
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Clinton-Gore campaign began running yesterday in 26 states, including California, Florida, Michigan and Ohio. In almost all of its advertisements, the campaign has combined attacks on Bob Dole with praise of Mr. Clinton, but this commercial is pure attack.

title: Mediocrity Revisited
description: A well-trained and accomplished teacher can make a dramatic difference in a child's life. But a new report from a national commission on education shows that adequately trained teachers are increasingly difficult to find. The report, ''What Matters Most: Teaching for America's Future,'' finds an alarming number of teachers who have not studied the subjects they teach or have otherwise failed to meet already lax licensing requirements.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Fishwife Meets Drifter, And All Take a Plunge
description: A simple plot synopsis will not be kind to Robert M. Young's ''Caught,'' a film that eventually gathers more blunt force than it initially promises. The story centers on a Brooklyn fish store, Joe's Fish, and its proprietor, Joe (Edward James Olmos). He is a kindly, simple fellow proud of both his attractive wife, Betty (Maria Conchita Alonso), and his skill at boning shad with a very sharp knife.

title: Balancing Personal Beliefs and the Law
description: Ever since the death penalty was revived in New York State last September, prosecutors and defense lawyers alike assumed the Bronx District Attorney would be the last prosecutor in the city to seek it, and the Brooklyn District Attorney the first.

title: A suit asks: Must advisers treat all clients exactly the same?
description: A TENNESSEE family that made a fortune in coal mining and was burned by the collapse of a stock it owned in a Texas oil company is pursuing an unusual legal strategy to recoup its losses: It has sued its investment advisory firm for not giving all clients the benefit of research conducted for the firm's largest customer.

title: Nothing to Fear in Immigration Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Children, Please Welcome Principal Rudolph Giuliani
description: The name of the new principal at Public School 369, a special education school in downtown Brooklyn, has a tantalizingly familiar ring.

title: The Senate Clears $1 Billion In Subsidies to Shipping Lines
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a new plan for $1 billion in subsidies over 10 years for the nation's private merchant-marine fleet.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS ENDS ACQUISITION TALKS WITH BEC
description: The American Greetings Corporation has ended talks about a possible purchase of the Foster Grant Group from BEC Group Inc., the companies said yesterday. American Greetings, a Cleveland-based maker of greeting cards, said the acquisition would not fit its business objectives. BEC, based in Rye, N.Y., said it was ''unable to agree on philosophies and price'' with American Greetings. BEC has said that it expected a sale of about $45 million for the unit, with another payment of as much as $15 million based on the future performance of Foster Grant, a maker of sunglasses. BEC said it would sell Foster Grant, which has about $90 million in annual sales, to a management group.

title: In New York, Kemp Accepts Support of Police Union and Conservative Party
description: Jack Kemp brought the Republican Presidential campaign to New York yesterday, accepting the endorsement of the city's police union and telling the New York Conservative Party convention that he and Bob Dole would step up their pressure on the Senate to overturn President Clinton's veto of a ban on late-term abortions.

title: Brooklyn Case Is City's First Seeking Death
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney became the first New York City prosecutor to seek the death penalty under the state's new capital punishment law yesterday, saying he would push for the execution of a man charged with murdering his companion and cutting up his body with a saw.

title: Conferees Approve a Tough Immigration Bill
description: House and Senate negotiators today approved an immigration bill that stiffens border enforcement, speeds the deportation of aliens who are criminals and restricts public benefits to legal immigrants.

title: Secondary Rises Above The Giants' Mediocrity
description: On the football field, Jason Sehorn couldn't stand out more. He is the only white starting cornerback in the National Football League. Right now the Guinness people are not calling, and neither is David Letterman. But one of Sehorn's Giants teammates is calling, not caring what color Sehorn is as long as they are both on time for their meeting with the assistant coach Zaven Yaralian.

title: French Revolution in Potatoes Comes to America
description: THE potato prized by many French chefs as one of the finest of all has taken root in America. A small, elongated, sometimes contorted oval, it has smooth, dense golden flesh and a flavor that hints richly of hazelnuts and chestnuts.

title: Corrections
description: An article about an auction of millions of dollars' worth of Impressionist paintings and drawings to be held at Christie's in November misspelled the surname of their owner and of her late husband. She is Jane Engelhard, and her husband was Charles W. Engelhard, the president of the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation.

title: Incidents and Arguments Add to Arab-Israeli Friction
description: Tensions between Arabs and Israelis smoldered on several fronts today, with Israel warning Egypt to curb its taunts and attacks and Palestinians protesting the extension of a tunnel along the ancient man-made plateau in Jerusalem sacred to Muslims and Jews.

title: The Brothers Burns
description: ABC remains busy making deals for shows to fill the holes on its prime-time schedule. The network has signed Ed Burns, the young film maker who made a splash with his first movie, ''The Brothers McMullen,'' and followed that with this year's ''She's the One.'' He will joinwith his brother Brian in creating a new situation comedy for the network.

title: Executive Changes
description: APPLE COMPUTER INC., Cupertino, Calif., named Dale Fuller vice president and general manager of its Powerbook laptop computer division.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the erroneous publication of a candidate's photograph with an article about charity fraud in The Star Tribune of Minneapolis referred incorrectly in some editions to the cause of the error. It resulted from a procedural slip-up by editors in Minneapolis, not from a computer malfunction.

title: At a Symposium, Deep Thoughts and Cheap Thrills
description: The crowd that filled the auditorium on the Upper East Side of Manhattan one evening last week was stellar indeed -- writers, academics, lawyers, publishers, a judge, a Pulitzer Prize winner and assorted other thinkers of big thoughts.

title: Live From Atlantis
description: Shannon Lucid, the 53-year-old astronaut who is finally hurtling back to Earth after unforeseen delays aboard the Russian space station Mir kept her in space for six months, will give the final live television interview from her historic trip today -- to the Sci-Fi Channel.

title: A Young Man Who Yearns to Be Good
description: GOOD EVENING MR. AND MRS. AMERICA, AND ALL THE SHIPS AT SEA

title: In Clear-Cutting Vote, Maine Will Define Itself
description: In Maine this political season, everyone is talking about one thing: The 10 million-acre North Woods, most of it owned by multinational paper companies, that help define the state's economy and its psyche.

title: Clinton Should Stand Up for Perot
description: In their public statements, President Clinton and the Democrats said they wanted Ross Perot to be included in the debates, and they blamed Bob Dole and the Republicans for his exclusion. The President's aides unanimously expressed their disappointment last week that the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates recommended the exclusion of Mr. Perot.

title: Garden Gets '98 All-Star Weekend
description: New York has been selected to be the host for the 1998 National Basketball Association All-Star Game, 30 years after the event was last played at Madison Square Garden.

title: Arrest in Bus-Driver Shooting
description: A man believed responsible for shooting a New Jersey Transit bus driver in the stomach on Sunday dropped his backpack as he fled the crime scene and was identified by passengers through photographs, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Michael W. Moore, 23, of Cherry Hill Township, was charged with attempted murder and robbery, said Greg Reinert, a spokesman for the Camden County Prosecutor's office. The driver, Richard Berger, 51, of Moorestown, was in satisfactory condition yesterday at Cooper Hospital-Medical Center in Camden.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BEST PRODUCTS CO., Richmond, a catalogue showroom retailer, said it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because of a decline in sales and earnings and deteriorating support from vendors.

title: New Deal for Carey
description: JIM CAREY of the Washington Capitals, the Vezina Trophy winner last season as the National Hockey League's top goalie, signed a four-year contract yesterday.

title: Laura Ashley Profits Soared 73% in 6 Months
description: The British retailing company Laura Ashley P.L.C. said yesterday that pretax profits rose 73 percent in the six months ended July 27 despite a drop in sales. The company earned $:5.2 million ($8.1 million) before taxes, compared with $:3 million in the corresponding period a year ago. Sales were $:156.1 million, down 5.2 percent from last year's $:164.6 million. The company attributed the decline on a planned reduction of its mail order and perfume business, and the shedding of its Australian operations in 1995. (Dow Jones)

title: Armenia Leader's Edge in Vote Is Cut; Crowds Call for Resignation
description: President Levon Ter-Petrossian's lead shrank today as more votes were counted in the presidential election, and supporters of his opponent demonstrated before the presidential palace for a second day to demand that he resign.

title: Report of Serb-Croat Pact Worries Muslims
description: The Bosnian Croat and Bosnian Serb political leaders, elected barely a week ago to a new three-member presidency, have mounted a political alliance that could doom the new Bosnian Government before it convenes for the first time, Western diplomats and Bosnian officials say.

title: Miscellany
description: Burger King Corp., Miami, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., agreed to become the worldwide restaurant promotional partner for the summer 1997 release of ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park,'' the sequel to the film ''Jurassic Park.'' The agreement was signed with Amblin Entertainment and the Universal Studios Consumer Products Group division of MCA Inc., which is controlled by the Seagram Co.

title: Blast in Queens Destroys A Church and Two Houses
description: A thunderous explosion, apparently caused by a natural gas leak, tore through a Presbyterian church on a residential street in Queens shortly before dawn yesterday, destroying the church as well as two nearby houses.

title: Rank Buying a Chain Of British Pubs
description: The Rank Organization, the British company that owns the Hard Rock Cafe chain, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the pub company Tom Cobleigh P.L.C. for $:95.6 million ($148.8 million). Rank received an irrevocable contractual promise from company directors, family trusts and a fund that altogether hold 61.5 percent of Tom Cobleigh's shares.

title: Merchandise-Trade Gap Soars in South Korea
description: South Korea's current-account deficit more than quadrupled in August to a monthly record of $3.49 billion, the central bank said yesterday. Imports of consumer goods surged, and shipments of semiconductors plunged, resulting in a sixfold increase in the merchandise-trade gap.

title: Excerpts From the Yonkers Desegregation Decision
description: Following are excerpts from the decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in the Yonkers desegregation case.

title: Trustee Defends Adelphi Chief's Pay
description: Adelphi University's trustees repeatedly raised the school president's salary and benefits because of his devotion to revamping the troubled institution, a former board chairman said yesterday.

title: From the Easel To the Oven: Gingerbread By Grandma Moses
description: GRANDMA MOSES, the American primitive painter, wrote down a recipe for gingerbread in the 1940's in a three-and-a-half page manuscript, along with home remedies for nerves and aching feet. Bruce Gimelson, a dealer from Garrison, N.Y., has put a $5,500 price tag on the manuscript, for sale at the annual Fall Antiques Show, which runs from tomorrow through Sunday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: Jones Loses Some Sleep But Doesn't Miss a Beat
description: The way the Mets' season has gone, it figured. At 3:50 A.M. today they were rousted by an ear-piercing fire alarm at the Westin Galleria Hotel, where they are staying for a three-game series against the Houston Astros.

title: Eating Well
description: MENTION the word ''fiber,'' and the odious oat-bran craze of the late 1980's springs to mind. Those who gagged each morning on a 400-calorie, 20-gram fiber muffin cheered when they learned that oat bran made only a modest impact on cholesterol levels.

title: A Fund for Distressed Companies Goes Awry
description: Among the elite corps of Wall Street financiers who buy into failing companies, probably no one's elbows are sharper -- and no one's tactics so feared and admired -- as those of Mikael Salovaara.

title: Gerstman & Meyers Planning Changes
description: Gerstman & Meyers, a corporate-identity and package-design company in New York, is making changes in top management as Herbert M. Meyers, one of two managing partners, makes plans to retire.

title: Another Storm, Another Washout for Cone
description: For the second time in a week, the showers came a little early for David Cone.

title: AT&T Warns of a Drop in Earnings and Its Stock Plunges
description: The AT&T Corporation stunned Wall Street and sent its stock into a free fall yesterday when it warned that its profits would fall well short of expectations for the rest of the year.

title: The new Pan Am is rolling out an unusual frequent-flier program with an old name.
description: WHEN Pan American World Airways is reborn tomorrow, with a daily nonstop between New York's Kennedy International Airport and Miami, and between Kennedy and Los Angeles, passengers can enroll in an unusual frequent-flier plan, named World Pass.

title: Yanks File Protest as Bad Trade Gets Worse
description: Bob Watson, the beleaguered Yankees general manager, yesterday escalated his assault on the Milwaukee Brewers over a trade he made with them last month by filing a formal complaint with the American League president, Gene Budig.

title: Animal Transplants Extend Medical Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: 3Com Earnings Up 62.2% in First Quarter
description: The 3Com Corporation said today that its earnings had gained 62.2 percent in its first quarter, beating Wall Street estimates.

title: Tumbledown Teams Should Heed the Colts
description: Take solace, Jets. Look upward, Saints. Peek over here, Bucs. You are winless in four games. You are being trampled. Respect? Every National Football League team is glancing over its schedule hoping you are on it -- three or four times, please. Your team is the brunt of ugly jokes. Your franchise is being snickered at by your peers.

title: Career Changers, Beware!
description: To The Living Section:

title: Lake Shore Route
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Immigrants Begin to Lose Food Stamps Under New Law
description: New York and other states this week began the first cuts mandated by the new Federal welfare law, starting to drop some legal immigrants from the food stamps program.

title: Dissidents Plan to Fight Proposed Transit Accord
description: Contending that the transit workers' union should have taken a harder line in contract talks, even if it meant courting widespread layoffs, a major dissident faction in the union announced yesterday that it would campaign aggressively against the proposed contract.

title: $3.1 Billion Offer Rejected By Loewen
description: The Loewen Group, striving to remain independent, rejected a $3.1 billion takeover offer last night from the Service Corporation, the world's largest chain of funeral homes.

title: Killer of 5 Dies After Collapse on Death Row
description: A death row inmate who fashioned himself as an aggrieved ninja warrior and killed five people, including three postal workers, in brutal vendettas, died late Monday in a Trenton hospital, three days after collapsing in his cell, prison officials said. They said there was no sign of foul play.

title: Without Money to Build, Western Colleges Innovate to Handle More Students
description: When American colleges and universities were hit in the late 1960's and 1970's by an avalanche of baby boomers, their best defense was a good edifice.

title: Ludmilla Chiriaeff, 72, Founder Of Ballet Company in Montreal
description: Ludmilla Chiriaeff, the founder of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens of Montreal and a major force in Canadian dance, died on Sunday at a hospital in Montreal. She was 72.

title: Dr. William Clark, 81; Led the March of Dimes in Change of Focus
description: Dr. William S. Clark, a rheumatologist who helped lead the March of Dimes when it switched its focus from polio to birth defects and juvenile arthritis, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Marino to Miss 3-4 Weeks With a Broken Right Ankle
description: The Dolphins' wonderful ride through the early part of the season took a nasty turn in Indianapolis on Monday night when quarterback Dan Marino fractured his right ankle in the first quarter of Miami's 10-6 loss to the Colts. Marino will likely miss the next three or four weeks.

title: The Silent Partners Inside Restaurants
description: IT is morning at Vong and, as she does each day, Rotjana Muensouk is making a special dish. Its simple components -- bits of chicken, a few cubes of potato and prettily fanned-out slices of mango -- look pleasing.

title: U.N. Is Urged To Combat Sex Abuse Of Children
description: On a day when two presidents and about a dozen ministers spoke to the General Assembly, mostly about arms control and other traditional topics of statecraft, Foreign Minister Erik Derycke of Belgium came to the podium today to talk about the sexual exploitation of children.

title: At 0-4, It's Open Season on Kotite
description: Whatever you think of Jets Coach Rich Kotite -- whether you believe his 3-17 record with the team merits his being axed in favor of Jerry Stiller playing Vince Lombardi or you think he'd be better off creating offensive formations for Hess toy trucks -- he is enduring a horrific trial by media fire.

title: Rockies Ski Resorts Send Strip Clubs Packing
description: As fresh snow heralds the start of the ski season next month, Colorado's high mountain resort towns are celebrating their victory over a summer invader from the lowlands: strip joints.

title: Family Leave Act Is Good and Can Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Ravens Make Moves
description: Hoping to add some badly needed punch to a lackluster offense, the Baltimore Ravens signed two former Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday -- tight end ERIC GREEN and the suspended running back BAM MORRIS.

title: In Catholic School, Shared Values Include Rigor and Decorum
description: Along a wall of Sister Mary Scanlon's seventh-grade homeroom at St. Elizabeth School are two bookcases, one for the World Book Encyclopedia, National Geographics and biographies, the other for Bibles, catechisms and the ''Saints Alive'' series.

title: No Headline
description: ''We're not tree huggers. We're not saying don't work the woods. The woods are the lifeblood of Maine. We're just saying work them in a responsible way.''

title: A Reckless Tax Cut
description: Bob Dole wants to cut everyone's income tax rates by 15 percent and throw in an extra $500 cut for every child up to age 18 -- a startling 70 percent reduction for a family with two children earning about $30,000. But, says a group of more than 500 economists, including seven Nobel laureates, the tax gift would be economically reckless -- crowding out valuable public programs and private investment that the economy needs to grow. President Clinton was cornered by Mr. Dole into offering his own tax-cut plan -- for families with young children, for college students and for employers who hire welfare recipients. These tax cuts are also tantalizing, but they too make little economic sense, as some of his own advisers admit in private. Yet there is a major difference between the two plans. The President's is too small to do great harm.

title: Clinton, at U.N., Signs Treaty Banning All Nuclear Testing
description: President Clinton signed a treaty today that would ban all nuclear weapons testing and called on world leaders to take further steps to limit weapons of mass destruction. He also urged them to show ''zero tolerance'' for international drug smuggling and for terrorism.

title: HBO & COMPANY TO ACQUIRE GMIS IN STOCK SWAP
description: HBO & Company, a fast-growing provider of computer systems for hospitals and doctors, said yesterday that it would acquire GMIS Inc. for about $212 million in stock. Shares of GMIS surged $6.1875, or 36 percent, to $23.3125, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of HBO, based in Atlanta, fell $1.25 to $62.50. The agreement calls for shareholders of GMIS, based in Malvern, Pa., to receive 0.42 share of HBO common stock for each GMIS share. GMIS, which had $35.8 million in sales last year, specializes in data bases that help insurers and H.M.O.'s process claims and manage costs. HBO, with $496 million in sales last year, focuses on software for doctors and hospitals.

title: A New Glasnost to Sell Yeltsin as Fit
description: It was only a 40-minute meeting between President Boris N. Yeltsin and his loyal Prime Minister.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE MAKES NO CHANGE IN INTEREST RATES
description: After weeks of speculation that the Federal Reserve would launch a pre-emptive strike against inflation, its monetary-policy officials met today and decided against raising interest rates, apparently in the belief that the economy is likely to cool off enough to keep prices in check.

title: Pennant Race Separates Old Friends
description: GERALD WILLIAMS and Derek Jeter drove up to Yankee Stadium together yesterday. They walked into the Stadium through the familiar gate and descended the stairs.

title: Theater in Review
description: 'Hate Me, Then!'

title: Jets Handle The Glare, Despite Spotlight
description: The Jets and Coach Rich Kotite will once again suffer by comparison this week. But Kotite said today that he was glad his team is on national television Sunday night against a Washington Redskins team that, unlike his own, has turned things around and started to win.

title: Prudential to Pay $410 Million For Misleading Policyholders
description: In the latest chapter in a long-running dispute over the sales practices of the country's largest life insurer, the Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday that it would pay at least $410 million in an attempt to put the matter behind it.

title: Congress's Political Work
description: Although members of Congress are continuing their legislative work during the campaign season, there is plenty of politicking on the House and Senate floors. Page A19.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about possible candidates for Manhattan borough president misstated the current position of Antonio Pagan. He is a City Councilman, not a state Assemblyman.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When BRIGITTE BARDOT retired from the movies in 1973, her only public appearances were on behalf of animal rights. Now, she has something to say about humans.

title: McAda Directs Army Home to Texas
description: Ronnie McAda is going home this weekend. The quarterback of the Army football team will be playing against North Texas of the Big West Conference on Saturday at Texas Stadium in Irving, west of Dallas.

title: 'Thank God I'm A Man!'
description: For any fan of the New York Mets, there is nothing extraordinary about the sight of men praying at Shea Stadium. But the praying I saw there Saturday was beyond major league. Some 35,000 standing, waving guys shouted their love to Jesus at a decibel level unknown even in Shea's occasional brushes with a pennant race. During a marathon rally of sermonizing, singing and praying, the men also repeatedly sobbed and hugged each other -- or, more joyously, slapped high-fives while repeating the chant ''Thank God I'm a man!''

title: In His Own Words
description: JACK KEMP

title: AON AGREES TO MAKE 2 ACQUISITIONS
description: The Aon Corporation agreed yesterday to buy HFS Inc.'s ERA Home Warranty unit and Wesselhoeft Ahlers & Schues OHG, an insurance and consulting business in Hamburg, Germany. Terms of the acquisitions were not disclosed. Under the agreement with HFS, Chicago-based Aon will expand HFS's home warranty program and develop new home warranty products for HFS's Century 21 and Coldwell Banker franchises for 10 years. Aon's German subsidiary HAVAG/Hudig-Langeveldt G.m.b.H. will combine with Wesselhoeft to form a consulting and insurance brokerage in Hamburg. Aon provides insurance and consulting services.

title: North Italy's Separatist Leader Says He Is Willing to Negotiate
description: After weeks of provocative displays and belligerent gibes, the leader of the northern Italian separatist movement says he is willing to negotiate.

title: The Catholic School Miracle
description: Mayor Giuliani deserves at least two cheers for helping to raise private funds that will allow 1,000 low-performing students to attend Catholic schools. The money will increase the chances that these children will become productive citizens. How could anyone quibble with that?

title: Black Movie Channel
description: Plans for the nation's first premium cable channel for films made by and about African-Americans were announced yesterday by BET Holdings, parent company of the Black Entertainment Network, and Encore Media, a movie channel. The two cable companies plan to start the new channel in February, although they have no contracts yet with cable or satellite operators to carry it.

title: NORWEST TO BUY BACK AS MANY AS 4.5 MILLION SHARES
description: The Norwest Corporation plans to buy back as many as 4.5 million shares, or 1.2 percent of its stock, partly to help finance future acquisitions. The purchase was valued at $182.5 million, based on yesterday's price of $40.50. The Minneapolis-based bank, the 12th-largest in the country, said the purchases would be structured so it would be able to use the ''pooling of interests'' accounting method for its acquisitions. The bank said it could also use the shares for employee benefits, converting convertible securities or for other uses. Pooling accounting rules restrict banks from buying back stock after using their shares to make acquisitions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about a campaign appearance in Washington by Bob Dole referred incorrectly in some editions to his schedule after his fall from a stage in California last Wednesday. He did not take a day off from campaigning.

title: It's as if the Wind Has Been Blowing Out All Season
description: Early this season, Earl Weaver gave one of his former Oriole players a bit of advice. ''Earl told me to forget the steal and the bunt, and go for the long one,'' said Davey Johnson, the current Baltimore manager. ''He said: 'Just go for the long one. Don't get a lot of guys who can run. They'll drive you crazy getting picked off.' ''

title: Europe Slaps Turkey, but Some Say the Slap Was Too Hard
description: Turkey's human rights record has come under new criticism in recent days, but several leading American and European officials have warned against judging the record too harshly.

title: I.B.M. Introducing Merlin, Its Latest OS/2 Software
description: I.B.M. plans today to introduce the latest version of its OS/2 software, code-named Merlin. But even I.B.M. executives concede that the new program lacks the legerdemain to make Windows, the much more popular software from the Microsoft Corporation, disappear.

title: Employee of Navy Is Reported Arrested On Spying Charges
description: Federal agents arrested a naval intelligence officer on charges of spying for South Korea, CBS Radio reported yesterday.

title: Whither Our Trucks and Trains? To the Tubes
description: To the Editor:

title: Notification on Sex Abusers Is Barred in Old Convictions
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday made permanent his earlier decision prohibiting New York State officials from releasing the names and addresses of scores of sex offenders who were convicted before Jan. 21, when a law allowing the notification went into effect.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CLARCOR AGREES TO STOCK SWAP FOR UNITED AIR
description: Clarcor Inc., a maker of filtration and packaging products, agreed yesterday to acquire United Air Specialists Inc. in a stock swap valued at $26.3 million. Cincinnati-based United Air makes products including commercial and industrial air cleaners and filters. Its stock soared $2.25, or 50 percent, to $6.75, on the Nasdaq. Clarcor agreed to pay 0.36986 of a common share for each United Air share. Clarcor shares fell 62.5 cents to $21.125. Both companies' boards have approved the deal, as well as the three largest United Air shareholders, who hold about 50 percent of the outstanding shares.

title: Scaling Down for New York in 1998
description: When the Goodwill Games began in 1986, their creator, Ted Turner, was taking a big gamble.

title: Growers' Cooperative Guilty Over Gifts to Ex-Agriculture Chief
description: A California growers' cooperative was found guilty today of illegally giving more than $9,000 worth of gifts to former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy at a time when his department was considering action on several issues important to the group.

title: Family Leave Act Is Good and Can Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Guilty, but Reinstated
description: Fullback LEROY WHITE was reinstated to the West Virginia football team yesterday by Coach DON NEHLEN after pleading guilty to misdemeanor charges stemming from a check-cashing scheme.

title: IMP STOCK DROPS ON DISAPPOINTING EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The stock of IMP Inc. fell 30 percent yesterday after the company said the chip industry's continuing slump would cause more layoffs and a ''very significant loss'' for the second quarter. The chip maker said it had already laid off 89 employees, or 23 percent of its work force, because of the industry slump. It also plans to shut down manufacturing periodically to keep production in line with demand. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., said it planned to take a one-time charge, mostly for inventory writeoffs and financial reserves. IMP said some major customers had requested delays in delivery schedules and reductions in orders. Shares of IMP fell $2 to $4.50 a share.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHAT has to be done to stir up interest in German wines? Twenty years ago, good wines from the Rhine and the Mosel were an integral part of any serious wine cellar. More important, perhaps, they were enjoyed by casual wine drinkers as well, people who buy wine a bottle at a time and consume it that day or the next.

title: Heating Oil Hits 5-Year High As Europe Draws U.S. Supply
description: Heating oil surged to a five-year high as soaring prices in Europe drew supplies away from the United States at a time when stockpiles are lean and refiners are running close to full capacity.

title: Time for Local Candidates
description: The movement to provide free television time for statements from political candidates has spread from the network to the local level.

title: Blacks Split on Sharpton Mayoral Campaign
description: Like many of his fellow black elected officials, Enoch H. Williams, an 18-year City Councilman from Brooklyn, is deeply troubled by the prospect of a mayoral candidacy by the Rev. Al Sharpton. It would, Mr. Williams predicted, make it harder to defeat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, by dividing his opposition.

title: 9 Legislative Districts Ruled Unconstitutional by Judges
description: A Federal court panel has declared nine South Carolina legislative districts unconstitutional, saying they were drawn solely on the basis of race, lawyers involved in the case said.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Impose a Moratorium
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling on Segregation
description: In a groundbreaking decision, a Federal appeals court ruled that New York State education officials and the State Legislature actively ''encouraged the perpetuation of segregation'' in Yonkers in the 1960's and 1970's and that the state must pay the costs of remedying the harm done to black and Hispanic children.

title: Ocean Floor Almost Clear of Crash Debris, Officials Say
description: The football-field sized hangar where investigators are assembling wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 is now nearly filled, prompting Federal officials to predict today that within a week or two the bottom of the ocean would probably be swept nearly clean of fragments of the shattered jumbo jet.

title: No Sympathy for Ex-Wives
description: To The Living Section:

title: A Doctor's Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices Climb On Relief Fed Does Not Act
description: Treasury prices moved higher yesterday on relief that Federal Reserve policy makers left interest rates unchanged.

title: Horizon/CMS Nursing Unit Investigated
description: The Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation, a nursing home operator based in Albuquerque, N.M., said yesterday that the Michigan Attorney General was investigating one of its homes, adding to its legal woes.

title: Citing Abuse by Her Jailers, Amy Fisher Requests Transfer
description: Amy Fisher, who at 16 shot her lover's wife and was convicted of first-degree assault in a celebrated trial, argued today to be moved to a Federal prison downstate, saying she has been raped and harassed by guards at a prison near here.

title: A Lecture by Einstein As a Dotty Old Uncle
description: As the lights come up on ''Einstein,'' a one-man show written by Willard Simms, the physicist is standing in his living room at Princeton on a stormy night in 1946 staring at a blackboard on which is written an equation based on his general theory of relativity. He looks at it for a few moments, much like an artist gazing at a painting he is not satisfied with, then crosses to it, picks up a piece of chalk and makes a slight modification. It is an engaging opening.

title: Healthy vs. Healthful
description: To The Living Section:

title: Festival '96 Declares Itself A Success
description: Final attendance figures are in for the Lincoln Center Festival '96, that 21-day marathon of Beethoven, Vietnamese water puppets and everything else in July and August, and the verdict of the festival's promoters is that the whole thing was a delirious success.

title: Congress Votes to Add Coverage For Childbirth and Mental Illness
description: Women with maternity coverage would be assured hospital stays of at least 48 hours after childbirth, and mental illness would for the first time be put on a par with physical illness under legislation that cleared Congress tonight and that is expected to be signed by President Clinton.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Presidential Pastry

title: Judge Rules du Pont Heir Unfit for Trial in Slaying
description: John E. du Pont today was declared mentally incompetent at this time to stand trial for murder in the shooting of the Olympic wrestling champion Dave Schultz last January.

title: Not an Idle Minute for Brodeur
description: Martin Brodeur set a National Hockey League record last season by playing 4,433 minutes in goal. In desperate need of points in the standing and with little faith in Brodeur's backup, Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire played Brodeur in all but 5 of the team's 82 games.

title: Personal Health
description: THE acronym GERD may be unfamiliar to most people, but chances are that they know the symptoms of this common condition all too well. GERD stands for gastroesophageal reflux disease, better known as acid indigestion or heartburn.

title: Cool to Dole's Campaigning, Talk Radio Tries to Start Fire
description: Talk radio has taken on a fresh edge of crankiness over the nonexplosive state of the Presidential campaign. The grumbling about uninspired talking points has reached the stage where Michael Harrison, an industry watchdog, felt obliged to confront Bob Dole on the air the other day for inexplicably ignoring the brigades of talk radio hosts so predisposed to his candidacy.

title: In the Right Groove for Deadheads
description: One chord was all Medeski Martin and Wood needed to set heads bobbing and hips swaying on Monday night at the Knitting Factory. When Billy Martin played a low-slung drumbeat, Chris Wood locked into a bass riff and John Medeski jabbed syncopated chords on Hammond organ, the trio reconnected music to motion. It was inevitable that a band would arrive to guide the Deadhead audience, which appreciates improvisation, toward the frontiers of jazz. Medeski Martin and Wood's grooves and jams make the transition easy for its collegiate fans.

title: Misperceptions About AIDS
description: Nearly one-third of New Jersey residents believe, incorrectly, that AIDS can be transmitted through shared utensils, coughing and sneezing or working next to someone with the disease, according to survey results reported in New Jersey Medicine, the Medical Society of New Jersey's magazine. The survey of 297 residents suggests that people with AIDS or H.I.V. may still be subject to discrimination, Prof. Jane E. Miller, the study's author, said yesterday. TERRY PRISTIN

title: No Long-Term Link Is Found Between Pill and Breast Cancer
description: EVER since its introduction in the 1960's, the birth control pill has been controversial, most recently because of several studies associating it with breast cancer. But an exhaustive analysis of nearly all of the studies on the subject has concluded that the pills do not increase the long-term risk of the disease.

title: Theater in Review
description: With the Children Back Home,

title: The man who cloaked the famous in mink  now enlists them for an AIDS crisis campaign.
description: THE adman who swathes stars in the fur that ''becomes a legend most'' is calling again on celebrities, this time for a more serious purpose.

title: Nagle Rejoins Falcons
description: In the wake of quarterback JEFF GEORGE's suspension, the Atlanta Falcons re-signed BROWNING NAGLE yesterday. BOBBY HEBERT, who had been playing behind George, will start Sunday when the Falcons face the 49ers in San Francisco.

title: Primeau-to-Isles Rumor Gains Speed
description: Perhaps there was nothing significant about Jim Devellano watching tonight's exhibition between the Rangers and the Islanders, a 5-3 Ranger victory, their first in five exhibition games.

title: Earnings Are Off 67% At Steelmaker Usinor
description: Usinor Sacilor S.A., Europe's biggest steel producer, said yesterday that its earnings tumbled 67 percent in the first half but that an expected pickup in demand would brighten prospects for 1997. Net income fell to a worse-than-expected 800 million francs ($160 million) in the first six months, from 2.4 billion francs in the period a year earlier, as weak demand and lower prices cut revenue.

title: Vodka With the Enemy, but a Chancy Tomorrow
description: Viktor, a lieutenant in the Russian Army, raised a battered tin cup and offered a toast.

title: If Feta Salsa Is Shocking, Consider It a Relish
description: Salsa that includes feta cheese would probably shock Mexican cooks, but almost every uncooked savory sauce is called salsa. Or call it a relish. Either way, it goes well with lamb and corn on the cob.

title: Five Composers in a Multinational Conversation
description: Two English composers, two Chinese composers and an Irish composer -- no, it's not the beginning of a bad ethnic joke, but another fascinating multinational musical salon organized by Joel Sachs, the conductor of the New Juilliard Ensemble. The group opened its season on Saturday night in the Juilliard Theater. No punch line was needed: each composer's conversation sounded lively on its own.

title: National Gallery and the Tate Swap Art
description: For all the exceptional Old Masters to be found in Britain, this country has never boasted a great treasure of Impressionist and post-Impressionist art. Yet its collection of European art from the late 19th and early 20th centuries would look a great deal more impressive if it were not divided between the National Gallery in Trafalgar Square and the Tate Gallery, several traffic jams away on Millbank.

title: Leo Isacson, 86, Upset Winner of a Bronx Congressional Seat
description: Leo Isacson, who flabbergasted political experts in 1948 when he won a Bronx Congressional seat as the candidate of the American Labor Party, died on Saturday at a hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 86.

title: Food Notes
description: Not Just for Indian Cooking

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Leaves Rates Steady, Cheering Administration

title: British Growth Revised Upward for 2d Quarter
description: Britain's economy expanded faster than initially estimated in the second quarter, reinforcing arguments that interest rates would not be cut again. The third estimate of growth in the second quarter showed gross domestic product climbed five-tenths of 1 percent from the first quarter and 2.2 percent from a year earlier. That compares with an estimate in August of quarterly growth of four-tenths of a percent and 1.8 percent yearly growth.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: William J. Curran, 71, Dies; Developed Health Law Field
description: William J. Curran, a law professor who pioneered the development of health law as a separate and proliferating legal specialty, died on Saturday at his home in Falmouth, Mass. He was 71 and had been professor of legal medicine at the Harvard Schools of Medicine and Public Health.

title: Now It's Oscar Madison's Square Garden
description: George Greenberg, the creative director of Fox Sports, jogged across 72d Street yesterday with good news for the waiting film crew. ''Messier's asking what his motivation is,'' he said. ''Gretzky said, 'We're the Odd Couple.' ''

title: Service Corporation Regroups After Loewen Rejects Its Offer
description: The funeral home industry's largest attempted deal appears to be turning hostile. The Service Corporation International said yesterday that it would pursue its takeover of the Loewen Group, despite the Loewen board's rejection late Tuesday of a $3.1 billion buyout offer.

title: Heart Specialist Named to Head Medical School
description: A heart specialist who was an author of a best-selling cookbook was named head of Cornell University Medical College in Manhattan yesterday.

title: His Doctors Give Yeltsin an Unexpected Tonic: He Is Fit for Surgery
description: Calming days of mounting concern that President Boris N. Yeltsin may be too sick to rule Russia, his doctors said today that the Russian leader would go ahead with a bypass operation and was expected to make a full recovery.

title: COMPUTERVISION TO SELL ITS HARDWARE SERVICES BUSINESS
description: The Computervision Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its computer hardware services business, Open Service Solutions, to an investment group headed by J. F. Lehman & Company for $125 million. Computervision expects to receive $100 million in cash and $25 million in preferred stock in the business, which will be known as CV Services International Inc. It will also receive rights to purchase 19 percent of CV Services. Computervision, based in Bedford, Mass., will use proceeds from the sale to pay down debt.

title: Indian Casino In New Mexico Forced to Close
description: Over the last year, three Federal judges and the state Supreme Court have ruled that New Mexico's 11 Indian-run casinos are operating illegally. On Tuesday, one of them was finally forced to close.

title: A Cry for Japan's Lost Isles: Is the Sea Listening?
description: Standing at the edge of Japan, overlooking a white lighthouse, a thick mist and an endless expanse of ocean, Takeshi Murakami struggled to explain why anybody would ever care about the offshore islands that were once his home.

title: S.E.C. Official Urges Change In Stock Prices
description: American stock markets should be forced to convert to a decimal-based system of pricing within three years, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: C. G. Davidson, 86, Member Of Truman Advisory Group
description: C. Girard Davidson, an Assistant Secretary of the Interior under President Harry S. Truman and a member of an informal group that provided policy advice for Truman, died on Friday at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 86.

title: A Rape Near Columbia U.
description: A woman was raped and her friend locked in the bathroom as they were moving into a new apartment near Columbia University in Morningside Heights, the police said yesterday.

title: Practice to 'Deceive'
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, while engaged in an egregious conflict of interest at the Rose Law Firm, prepared the legal document used by her corrupt banking clients and her crooked law firm partner ''to deceive Federal bank examiners,'' concludes the inspector general of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: The Island That Kept A Wedding A Secret
description: The privileged have sought refuge on Cumberland Island for more than 100 years. Throughout the last century, the island's pristine forest of moss-draped oaks has been home to Pittsburgh's Carnegies and New York's Rockefellers and Atlanta's Candlers.

title: French Stir Up a Boulle Run
description: FOR five days, a chateau-hopping gaggle of prosperous Americans had savored the best Paris had to offer, ogling its Gobelin tapestries, inspecting its tortoise-shell Boulle cabinets, sampling the finest Champagnes and sating themselves on foie gras.

title: ARAB-ISRAEL CLASH LEAVES FIVE DEAD IN THE WEST BANK
description: In the worst clashes in the West Bank since the Israeli-Palestinian peace accords three years ago, Israeli and Palestinian forces exchanged gunfire here today, leaving at least five Arabs dead and hundreds wounded.

title: Shut Schools Are Blamed For Problems With Primary
