description: A New York City elections official charged yesterday that the city school system bore significant blame for the widespread problems in the Sept. 10 primary elections in Brooklyn, in which many voters were turned away from polling places because hundreds of voting machines were not delivered on time.

title: Answering a Prayer
description: To The Home Section:

title: Genetics Institute in Deal to Share Biochemical Library
description: The Genetics Institute said yesterday that it had developed a library of several thousand genes and their related proteins that could be scanned for potential new drugs. The company also said it had entered into agreements with Genentech Inc. and the Chiron Corporation, its longtime rivals in biotechnology, giving them first access to the library.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about international coverage by news magazines misspelled the surname of the editor of The Economist. He is Bill Emmott, not Hammett.

title: Calendar: A Project And Shows
description: A Museum's Plans

title: To Belong in America . . . Let Us Count the Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Alarm Around the World, And Calls for Calm Talks
description: The predominant world reaction to the violence between Israelis and Palestinians yesterday was alarm, with many countries saying they blamed the Israeli Government of Benjamin Netanyahu for provoking Palestinian protests.

title: Management Shifts At WPP Unit
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company unit of the WPP Group is reorganizing its top management.

title: O'Donnell Cannot Escape Pressure
description: Neil O'Donnell understands that whatever he does this year will be measured against the $25 million commitment the Jets made to him. But in this 0-4 season, O'Donnell finds himself with a personal record few in the National Football League could have thought possible.

title: Heineken tries a campaign to sell beer with no original thoughts. Just bar talk.
description: ANY good advertising, the saying goes, sparks conversation. But can any conversation spark good advertising?

title: U.S. Auto Makers' Big Cars Give Way to a New Breed
description: James and Eileen Rawlyk, both 27, looked out of place at Stephens Buick here on a recent afternoon as they waited to pick up a 1997 Park Avenue, Buick's biggest sedan. After all, most shoppers were more than twice their age.

title: 49ers' Grbac Will Start at Quarterback
description: ELVIS GRBAC will start at quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday in place of the injured STEVE YOUNG, Coach GEORGE SEIFERT said yesterday in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Man Charged With Stealing $750,000 From 2 Agencies
description: A former village administrator was indicted yesterday on charges that he embezzled more than $750,000 from a Federally financed housing complex and a nursing agency, United States Attorney Mary Jo White announced.

title: Perot Shifts Focus From the Presidency To Dole and Politics
description: Barred from the Presidential debates and denied the prime-time television slots he wants for his lectures on public policy, Ross Perot has found a sharper focus for his 1996 campaign by once again running not so much for President as running against Washington political institutions, particularly Bob Dole.

title: Will's Way Out With a Virus
description: Will's Way, the 3-year-old colt who won the Travers Stakes last month, returned to Belmont Park yesterday from his seventh-place finish in the Super Derby last Sunday with a virus. His trainer, James Bond, said he would miss the Jockey Club Gold Cup a week from Saturday and the Breeders' Cup three weeks later.

title: Grab-Bag Lands Bill Advances But Has Poor Chances of Passage
description: House and Senate negotiators, in their latest effort to enact a big package of legislation on parks and public lands, presented what they called the last chance before adjournment to protect sites from the Presidio in California to the Sterling Forest along the border of New York and New Jersey.

title: Is Hikers' Shop A Paradise Lost?
description: No matter how strong the march of theme retail chains, most big cities manage to hold on to something age-defying that seems the signature of a place. Try to imagine New York City without Zabar's, or Boston without Filene's.

title: Tar Heel Defense Takes the Offensive
description: The end of the 1994 season was a defensive fiasco for North Carolina. Drastic adjustments were needed after the Tar Heels allowed 71 points over the last two games.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Lenny Goodman, Jockey's Agent, 76
description: Lenny Goodman, a jockey's agent for nearly 50 years at New York race tracks and the man who served as coach, tutor and surrogate father for the teen-aged jockey Steve Cauthen, died Tuesday evening at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 76.

title: College Tuition Rates Show Steady Growth, Report Says
description: College tuition continues to rise by more than the nation's inflation rate, a situation that is likely to keep pushing more of the cost of college onto the shoulders of students and their families as government support shrinks.

title: Convicted Sex Offender Admits To the Abuse of Boy in Armonk
description: A 24-year-old nanny pleaded guilty today to Federal and state charges in the sexual abuse of an 11-year-old Armonk boy who was in his care.

title: Wolfgramm, Tongan Fighter, Turns Pro
description: Tonga's Olympic hero, PAEA WOLFGRAMM, said yesterday in Auckland, New Zealand, that he has turned pro and that his first fight is scheduled for Dec. 3 in Los Angeles.

title: At the Peale Center in Pawling, N.Y., Quiet Efficiency Meets Positive Thinking
description: Down a carpeted corridor in a sprawling suburban office building, five women sit in red-upholstered pews on a Monday morning. Each reads through a stack of 25 letters, pausing for a moment after each letter. When a woman finishes a stack, she walks to the front of the room, places it in a cardboard tray marked ''Prayed For,'' and takes another packet from a pile on the altar.

title: Ford Wants to Trim 1,000 Jobs in Britain
description: The Ford Motor Company is planning to eliminate 1,000 jobs at plants in Britain through voluntary reductions and early retirements, a company spokesman said yesterday. He said the move was part of an effort to make plants competitive globally.

title: Uphold the Abortion Veto
description: The politically charged issue of abortion returns to the Senate today in the form of a vote to override President Clinton's veto of a bill outlawing certain late-term abortions and imposing criminal sanctions on doctors who perform them. Last week, the House voted by 285 to 137 to override Mr. Clinton. That leaves only the Senate to stop this campaign-season rush to outlaw a procedure that, despite its distasteful nature, remains the safest method to abort a fetus for valid medical reasons late in pregnancy.

title: Yankees Clinch and Paint Town in Pinstripes
description: After eight innings of lopsided yet memorable baseball, the anxious fans at Yankee Stadium yesterday suddenly went from acting like library visitors to behaving as if someone had unveiled an ''APPLAUSE'' sign before the ninth inning. They stood as one, they shouted as one and they wanted to celebrate as one with their beloved Yankees.

title: Bill Follows Attack on Driver
description: Legislation inspired by the shooting of a New Jersey Transit bus driver in Cherry Hill on Sunday is expected to be introduced today. The measure would automatically classify an assault on a bus driver as aggravated and punishable by five years in prison. The bill would apply to both school bus and public transit bus drivers, said Assemblyman Joseph J. Roberts Jr., Democrat of Brooklawn, a sponsor.

title: Requiem for a Heavyweight Label
description: To the Editor:

title: Fort Howard to Expand
description: The Fort Howard Corporation said today that it would spend $160 million to expand one of its United States tissue-paper plants to meet growing demand. The company, based in Green Bay, Wis., said it would upgrade either its plant in Rincon, Ga., or Muskogee, Okla. The expansion will require about 100 more workers, the company said. Until the expansion is completed, it will use bulk paper purchased from other manufacturers.

title: Banking Bill Retains Consumer Protections
description: To the Editor:

title: Exhausted Woods Skips Buick Challenge
description: A frantic five-week run in which TIGER WOODS won the United States Amateur, turned pro with the sport's richest endorsement deal and played 408 holes at 63 under par ended yesterday when he withdrew from the Buick Challenge in Pine Mountain, Ga., citing exhaustion.

title: Youth Convicted of Murder
description: An 18-year-old was convicted of murder yesterday in the shooting of a Pleasantville grocer who said he had no money but offered his wristwatch.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: House Votes 2 Bills to Curb Illegal Immigrants
description: The House today approved one bill that would crack down on illegal immigration and another that would allow states to deny a public education to any illegal immigrant children who are not enrolled in school by next July.

title: Muzzling a Vicious Pit Bull: Debt
description: THE INDEBTED SOCIETY

title: MANUFACTURED HOME FILES LAWSUIT TO BLOCK MERGER
description: Manufactured Home Communities Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit to block the proposed merger of Chateau Properties Inc. and ROC Communities Inc. Chateau, a mobile-home real estate investment trust based in Clinton Township, Mich., has agreed to merge with ROC Communities Inc., rejecting a takeover bid by Manufactured Homes. Under the proposed merger, Chateau shareholders will receive one share in the merged entity for each existing share, plus a one-time dividend equal to 3.16 to 6 percent of the outstanding common stock and partnership units, depending on how many unitholders convert their units to shares. ROC shareholders will receive 1.04 shares of the merged company for each existing share. For Chateau shareholders, the deal is valued at $23.53 to $24.21 a share. Manufactured Home offered Chateau $26 a share, but the offer was rejected. Manufactured Home, a mobile-home real estate investment trust controlled by the Chicago investor Sam Zell, has accused Chateau and ROC of acting to protect the interests of insiders who hold operating partnership units, at the expense of common shareholders.

title: Don't Let Anyone Tax Internet Transactions
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Upholds Move to Seek Death Penalty in Oklahoma Bombing
description: A Federal district judge yesterday upheld the decision of Attorney General Janet Reno and Federal prosecutors to seek the death penalty for the two men accused of bombing the Federal Building in Oklahoma City on April 15, 1995.

title: Living in the Visual Equivalent of One Hand Clapping
description: ON the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the architects Frank Lupo and Daniel Rowen have designed a New York apartment that is so minimal that the rooms do not have names: an area with a low glass-top table is designated Space No. 1; one distinguishable by a raised sculpture platform is Space No. 2, and an area with white pallets in a closet is Space No. 3.

title: On Bosnia, It's Too Soon to Preach Partition
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad News on Officers' Pay
description: When the Hudson County Board of Freeholders voted in July to dissolve the county's 89-member police force, the officers were promised that they could fill vacancies in the Sheriff's office at salaries in keeping with their experience.

title: PRAXAIR TO SELL STATIA FOR $210 MILLION
description: Praxair Inc. of Danbury, Conn., said yesterday that it would sell its Statia Terminals business for $210 million to an investor group formed by Castle Harlan Partners II L.P. and Statia's managers. After acquiring CBI Industries in March, Praxair said it intended to sell the Statia oil terminals and the construction and engineering units of CBI, because they do not fit with Praxair's industrial gases and chemicals businesses. Statia Terminals, with sales of $135 million, provides storage and related services for petroleum and other products at three terminals in the Netherlands Antilles, Nova Scotia and Texas. Castle Harlan Inc. is a merchant banking firm.

title: Dole Commercial Gets Free Play on Network News
description: Once again, the Republicans have lured television networks into broadcasting one of their political advertisements nationally for a pittance.

title: Judge Criticized for Harassing Fellow Judge After a Romance
description: Judges spend their professional lives making prudent decisions about the misadventures of the people who come before them. But when they step off the bench and tumble into the affairs of the heart, they can be as sadly lacking in judgment as the rest of us.

title: The Peale Center Is a Family Affair
description: Norman Vincent Peale may have passed on in 1993, but the Norman Vincent Peale Center for Christian Living is still growing under the leadership of his widow, Ruth Stafford Peale. Mrs. Peale, who turned 90 this month, is the center's chairwoman.

title: Paul McCartney, Beatle and Deadhead Director
description: The latest project about the Grateful Dead is a film by an unlikely director: Paul McCartney. Not only is Mr. McCartney not known as a Deadhead, but he has never even seen the band perform live.

title: For Fans at the Stadium, That Feeling Is Back
description: It was only moments after the Yankees clinched the American League East title last night and 22-year-old Trevon Donovan was shouting with long-anticipated glee, trading cheers with fans overlooking the railings of Yankee Stadium's circular walkways.

title: TV City Hall: More Laughs Than Issues
description: THIS column was supposed to be about the daunting issue of workfare, and it would have been had the television set in the gym not been tuned Tuesday night to the new ABC hit, ''Spin City.'' There it was, with Michael J. Fox as a deputy mayor in his fictional City Hall.

title: Executive Changes
description: FIRST CHICAGO NBD CORP., Chicago, appointed William Elliott 3d as its top technology officer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Empire Blue Cross Plans To Seek For-Profit Status

title: U.S. Is Squandering Its Influence at U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Checkpoint Systems' Shares Tumble 23%
description: Shares of Checkpoint Systems Inc. plunged 23 percent today after the company said its third-quarter profit would fall below expectations.

title: NatWest Is Planning $5 Billion Bond Sale
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it planned to sell $5 billion of bonds backed by corporate loans. The floating-rate notes and commercial paper will be denominated in pounds and dollars.

title: Sun Shines the Brightest on Cone
description: The Yankees, driven by emotion all season, could not have planned the party that unfolded yesterday in the Bronx any better.

title: Parish, 43, Signs 2-Year Pact With Bulls
description: Center ROBERT PARISH, who has played more games than any player in National Basketball Association history, signed a two-year contract with the Chicago Bulls yesterday.

title: Big City, Small Town
description: To The Home Section:

title: A Contentious Contest Develops in Denver to Fill Schroeder's Seat
description: With Denver's Congressional seat up for grabs for the first time since Patricia Schroeder won here in 1972, a surprisingly contentious race has come down to fan clothing and accessories.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KELSEY GRAMMER, the star of the NBC comedy ''Frasier'' checked himself into the Betty Ford rehabilitation center for substance abuse in Palm Springs, Calif., yesterday, three days after he was slightly injured in an accident in which his car turned over.

title: No Headline
description: He was outgoing and joking about the fact that these doctors had made him feel like an animal in a cage. -- MICHAEL E. DEBAKEY, the heart specialist, after meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. $(A11:1$)

title: Valentine Must Decide On Fate of His Coaches
description: The Mets' season has been over for some time now, even though a fistful of games remain to be played. The drama continues, however, for all but one of the club's coaches.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: William Vaughn, 93, Who Led Kodak in a Period of Expansion
description: William S. Vaughn, a former president and chairman of the Eastman Kodak Company, died at his home in Brighton, N.Y., on Friday. He was 93.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Awards Are Won By Fallon McElligott
description: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis took top honors, winning two awards, at the Creative Excellence in Business Advertising awards sponsored by the American Business Press.

title: Siemens and Mosel In Chip Venture
description: Siemens A.G. of Germany and Mosel Vitelic Inc., a Taiwan semiconductor maker, will spend $1.7 billion the next three years in a joint venture producing computer memory chips, Mosel said yesterday.

title: Rogers Is Poker-Faced Amid Yankee Revelry
description: The clubhouse had the atmosphere of a game-show set, all the clapping and hollering, chaos and cameras. And then there was the stoic Kenny Rogers, tucked away in an isolation booth of sorts.

title: Half-Year Profit Leaps At Big French Insurer
description: The French insurance giant Axa S.A. said yesterday that its profits jumped 52 percent in the first half of 1996. It said the performance was powered by areas outside life insurance and results at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in the United States, which Axa benefits from through its controlling stake in the Equitable Companies of the United States.

title: Islamic Contacts
description: To the Editor:

title: For Its Stretch Drive, Dole Campaign Turns to a Turnaround Artist
description: The G. D. Searle Company was a sluggish purveyor of Metamucil in an otherwise booming drug industry when Donald H. Rumsfeld became its chairman in 1977. By the time he left in 1985, its stock had quintupled. He repeated the trick at General Instruments Inc., a slumbering electronics business whose stock leapt to $51 from $15 a share during his stint there in the early 1990's.

title: Vote Due on Casino Rebate
description: A bill that sparked a battle between Donald J. Trump and Stephen A. Wynn is expected to face its final legislative test in the State Assembly today. It would use a tax abatement to reimburse Mr. Wynn for three-quarters of the cost of cleaning up a landfill where he plans to build a casino complex. Mr. Wynn was given the land free by Atlantic City.

title: Views of Asian Men
description: To The Home Section:

title: Giuliani Is Becoming 'National Spokesman' on Immigration
description: Having received widespread attention for his outspoken positions in favor of immigration and against parts of the new Federal welfare law, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has recently found a new avocation: becoming what an aide calls the ''national spokesman'' for these issues at forums around the country.

title: Gas Leak Being Investigated in Church Explosion
description: Investigators trying to determine the precise cause of an explosion that destroyed a Presbyterian church in Queens on Tuesday said yesterday that they had found no leaks in gas lines outside the church building.

title: A whole lot of nothing or a state of grace?
description: A COOL breeze wafts off the page: walls, white; doors, white; windows, bare; floors, stone or plank; furniture on which no pillow has ever been fluffed. This is minimalism as many witness it in magazines and lavish picture books. And it is enough to strike terror in the heart.

title: Slouching Toward Hartford
description: There is a fatalistic splendor to Bob Dole's campaign.

title: 6 Will Receive Awards for Outstanding Research
description: An Albert Lasker Award in medical research will be awarded to two scientists for studies that paved the way to an understanding that nitric oxide, a poisonous gas, plays an important role as a messenger between cells.

title: BASF and Daimler Cut Workers' Sick Pay
description: The chemical company BASF A.G. has joined Daimler-Benz A.G. in a challenge to labor as they cut sick pay for 264,000 German employees.

title: I.M.F. Urges a Tighter U.S. Monetary Policy
description: The International Monetary Fund called today for tightening of American monetary policy to avoid more drastic and disruptive action later.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: WESTERFED BUYING SECURITY BANCORP FOR $44 MILLION
description: The Westerfed Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Security Bancorp of Billings, Mont., for about $44 million in cash and stock. Security Bancorp stockholders would receive $30 a share in either cash or stock, or both. On the Nasdaq stock market, Westerfed shares rose 73.4 cents, to close at $15.984, while Security Bancorp shares soared $8, or 39 percent, to close at $28.50. Westerfed expects to issue about 1.3 million shares in the deal. Westerfed of Missoula, Mont., is the holding company for Western Federal Savings Bank of Montana. Security Bancorp has assets of $372.2 million.

title: Ramsey and Knicks Lend a Hand
description: CAL RAMSEY, the Knicks' community relations director, was especially proud of the team's participation yesterday in the restoration process of a Harlem brownstone. The Knicks joined the Fannie Mae Foundation in an effort to revitalize the neighborhood and increase home ownership in New York City.

title: Law Sowing Fear and Confusion at Welfare Offices
description: Workers on the front lines of welfare reform, under new orders to deny food stamps to innumerable legal immigrants who had previously qualified for them, are finding that translating Federal law into reality is not coming easily.

title: Study Finds Stunted Lungs in Young Smokers
description: Parents who cautioned in years past that smoking would stunt a child's growth were right, at least in one respect. A new study has shown that lung development is impaired in teen-agers who smoke as few as five cigarettes a day.

title: Adelphi Chairwoman's Business Link Is Proper
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Afghan Rebels Enter Capital

title: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose for the third consecutive session yesterday, as another report, this one on home resales, supported the view that the economy's growth is slowing.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENERGY VENTURES INC., Houston, an international oilfield service and equipment company, agreed to buy Irmaos Geremia LTDA, a Brazilian oilfield pump maker, for about $24 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: A House Filled With Ideas
description: GRAND tradition is the keynote sounded at the second annual designer show house that runs through Sunday at the Abigail Adams Smith Museum on East 61st Street near York Avenue. Twenty-one designers have shopped and stocked the 18th-century landmark mansion and gardens that once served as the carriage house to the even grander estate of Abigail Adams Smith, daughter of President John Adams.

title: Chinese Artists Exalt Their Yesterdays
description: In a China that is rushing wildly toward its own idea of economic development, obliterating a good deal of its remaining cultural heritage in the process, some Chinese artists have found an unusual way of expressing dissent: they have begun looking backward, hoping that nostalgia can serve as a mirror, to remind the country that it has a past.

title: Apathy or Interest?
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Are Arrested and More Face Charges of Terrorizing Blacks
description: More than a dozen people face charges of carrying out ''something akin to a reign of terror'' against black people in Burlington County, officials in New Jersey said yesterday in recounting an investigation that began after a 60-foot-wide swastika was carved in a cornfield.

title: Europeans Approve Credit Lyonnais Rescue
description: The European Commission gave clearance yesterday to the French Government to grant $800 million in assistance to help keep Credit Lyonnais afloat.

title: A Tunnel Tour of the Holy City's History
description: The violence that racked the West Bank today was set off by a dispute over a tunnel that, when viewed separately from the bitter politics of the region, ranks among the most intriguing tours of Jerusalem's rich history.

title: Jobfare, Familiar and Failed
description: Even before President Clinton signed the welfare reform bill, everyone wanted to know where the jobs would come from. Now, belatedly, we have the President's answer: wage subsidies. Instead of giving welfare grants directly to families, states can send the money to employers who agree to provide jobs for the heads of these families. In effect, the welfare grant becomes a wage subsidy.

title: Corrections
description: A Woman in the News article last Thursday about Dr. Shannon W. Lucid, the astronaut who has been in space longer than any other American, referred incorrectly to one of her advanced degrees. She has a Ph.D. in biochemistry, not a medical degree.

title: Jeter Made Difference For Yankees
description: IN that wild game with the Red Sox last Saturday, the Yankees were losing, 11-10, as shortstop Derek Jeter and second baseman Mariano Duncan trotted out for the eighth inning.

title: Kabul Falls to Islamic Militia; Afghans Accuse Pakistan
description: An Islamic fundamentalist army vowing to cleanse Afghanistan of squabbling warlords and install a strict Muslim government moved into Kabul, the capital, on Tuesday night and there were reports today that the city's defenses were collapsing virtually without a fight.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Beliefs column on Saturday discussed ''His Holiness: John Paul II and the Hidden History of Our Time,'' a new biography by Carl Bernstein and Marco Politi. The column cited ''rumors'' suggesting that Mr. Politi's contribution to the book had been greater than that of Mr. Bernstein. A letter this week from Doubleday, the publisher of the book, on behalf of itself and Mr. Bernstein, says, ''Mr. Bernstein, as the primary author, masterminded the project and was responsible for, and delivered, the complete typewritten manuscript.''

title: Lamar Dodd, 86, A Georgia Painter And Art Teacher
description: Lamar Dodd, a Georgia-based arts educator and painter whose style ranged from near-abstraction to moody realism, died on Saturday at his home in Athens, Ga. He was 86.

title: DeBakey Gives a Detailed Account of Yeltsin
description: After months of speculation and rumors about the health of Boris N. Yeltsin, Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, the American pioneering heart surgeon, and Russian doctors gave the first detailed account of his medical condition and prospects for heart surgery.

title: Unorganized? Why Wait Until Spring to Sort Things Out?
description: WITH the appearance of autumn, thoughts turn to storage: where to hide the clutter that piled up when summer activities seemed more important than organizing; the clothes, the books and the bills piling up on the floor; the videocassettes; even the television set that's been sitting in a not-so-convenient spot for viewing. It's time to start burrowing in for the long winter ahead.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DIANA, the Princess of Wales, flew in from London. The fashion industry flew down from Manhattan. Gen. COLIN POWELL came in from Virginia. And ELIZABETH DOLE dropped off the campaign trail for an hour to stop and shop.

title: Empire Is Emerging from a Cloud
description: In converting to a for-profit insurer, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York will also be distancing itself from the scandals that have plagued the company in the past.

title: Post-Season Chances Fading Fast for Lloyd
description: Graeme Lloyd's chances of being included on the post-season roster seem remote now that General Manager Bob Watson has conceded the reliever has a spur in his left elbow and cannot throw a curveball. How can the Yankees possibly consider using a fragile pitcher with an 0-2 record and an 18.00 earned run average (with the Yankees) who is lacking one of his pitches? Especially in the post-season?

title: Putting A Garden Into Words
description: Gertrude Jekyll's Private Garden

title: Potential Flaw In Cash Card Security Seen
description: A potential security flaw has been discovered that might make it possible to counterfeit many types of the electronic-cash ''smart cards'' that are now widely used in Europe and are being tested in this country by banks and credit card companies -- including Visa and Mastercard.

title: ADOBE SYSTEMS INC. (ADBE, NNM)
description: Adobe Systems Inc. reported lower third-quarter earnings yesterday that were in line with Wall Street estimates, reflecting slow sales of its publishing and design software for Apple Computer PC's.

title: Whitewater Sparring
description: President Clinton complained before a television audience Monday night that the independent counsel investigating Whitewater, Kenneth Starr, was more interested in inflicting political damage than in determining the truth. He said he agreed with Susan McDougal, his imprisoned former business associate, that Mr. Starr was ''out to get'' the Clintons. ''Isn't it obvious?'' he asked.

title: Child's Death Focuses Germans' Debate on Rise in Sex Crimes
description: In the Bavarian village of Epfach, a funeral Mass was held today in a church bedecked with flowers for Natalie Astner, a seven-year-old girl who was abducted on her way to school, sexually abused and left, naked and unconscious, in a river to drown.

title: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Georgia

title: Vivian Robinson, Black-Theater Supporter, 71
description: Vivian Robinson, the founder of the Audience Development Committee (Audelco) and the annual Audelco Awards, which honors achievement in black theater, died on Sept. 16 at North General Hospital in Harlem. She was 71.

title: Theodore Sieh, 71, Dies; Promoted Bel Canto
description: Theodore Sieh, the founder and artistic director of the enterprising Bel Canto Opera Company, known for its shoestring productions of unusual operatic works, died on Saturday at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 71.

title: Teachers Step Up Pressure On Issue of Overcrowding
description: In another indication of the magnitude of overcrowding in New York City's public schools, the teachers' union reported yesterday that one of every six classes had more students than allowed under the union's contract with the city.

title: Clinton Aides Say U.S. Might Back NATO Force in Bosnia in '97
description: The United States may support the creation of a NATO peacekeeping force in Bosnia next year that is just as large, and has just as many duties, as the American-led force that is preparing to withdraw from Bosnia beginning in December, Administration officials said today.

title: Gay Analyst Accepts Himself, But His Battles Aren't Over
description: SITTING in the living room of his elegant Park Avenue apartment, with his partner of 17 years across from him and a white wheaten terrier nipping at his feet, Dr. Richard Isay would never be mistaken for a firebrand. With his carefully combed brown hair, meticulous speech and very conservative dress -- white oxford button-down, gray tie and blue corduroys -- this 57-year-old psychiatrist and psychoanalyst seems more like a friendly uncle than an angry insurrectionist.

title: A Husband Defends His Decision to Kill His Wife
description: It isn't only Dr. Jack Kevorkian who is helping people die. As tomorrow night's ''Dateline'' demonstrates, you don't have to have a medical degree.

title: COLE NATIONAL ACQUIRING OPTICAL RETAILER PEARLE
description: The Cole National Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the optical retailer Pearle Inc. from the Pillsbury Company, giving the company one of the best-known eyewear retailing brands. The company plans to sell the European operations of Pearle to an entity organized by HAL Investments B.V., an investment group based in Rotterdam. Cole National expects to pay $165 million for Pearle's North American operations and retain a minority share of the European operations. Cole's stock rose more than 19 percent, gaining $3.875, to $23.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Pearle has 692 retail sites in North America and 183 in the Netherlands and Belgium. Cole, based in Cleveland, already operates more than 1,000 retail outlets.

title: Environmentalists Fight Scouts' Plan to Sell Protected Land
description: The Nassau County Council of Boy Scouts wants to sell 147 acres of untouched woodland in a protected part of Long Island's pine barrens to a golf-course developer for $2 million, infuriating environmentalists and prompting a state agency to offer $1.3 million for the Scouts' development rights.

title: 'Big,' Closing on Oct. 13, Is Living Up to Its Name As a Broadway Disaster
description: In one of the biggest financial disasters in Broadway history, the producers of ''Big'' said yesterday that they would close the musical on Oct. 13, after a six-month run and the loss of the show's entire $10.3 million investment.

title: Lebed Warns of Unrest If Soldiers Are Not Paid
description: In an unusually sharp attack on his own Government's policies, President Boris N. Yeltsin's security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, has warned that Moscow's failure to pay soldiers' salaries could lead to serious unrest within the Russian military.

title: 100 More Newark Officers
description: Thanks to a $7.5 million Federal grant, the Newark Police Department will be able to hire 100 new police officers over a three-year period, a spokeswoman for Mayor Sharpe James said yesterday.

title: Forget Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an auction of millions of dollars' worth of Impressionist paintings and drawings to be held at Christie's in November misspelled the surname of their owner and of her late husband. She is Jane Engelhard, and her husband was Charles W. Engelhard, the president of the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: Lehman's Profit Won't Quell Rumors
description: Lehman Brothers, whose shares have recently been buoyed by rumors of an impending takeover, reported net income yesterday of $77 million for its third quarter, up 8.4 percent over the comparable period a year ago but down substantially from its second quarter, when securities markets were especially busy.

title: For All of His Admonitions, Clinton Shows Ebullient Side
description: President Clinton has issued standing orders to his staff that overconfidence is the cardinal sin of front-running campaigns, and he tries hard to honor that dictum as he swoops around the country, striving to squeeze an extra hour of sunlight from the shortening days of fall.

title: Individuality in a Pianist Trained as a Drummer
description: The jazz community regularly grouses, and probably always has, about the next generation's loss of individuality: music schools have leached the personality out of their charges, and everybody sounds like his mentor. But individuality, even eccentricity, is out there if one looks for it.

title: Violence Returns to Israel
description: The uneasy peace that has prevailed between the new Israeli Government and Palestinians was shaken yesterday by a spasm of violence that could easily have been avoided. There was no need for Israel suddenly to resume a construction project near the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, one of the most sacred sites in the city to both Jews and Arabs. The violent Palestinian response was unjustified but could have been foreseen by anyone familiar with the volatile climate in Jerusalem and the West Bank.

title: Problems may be ahead for the world's vaccine program.
description: YOU probably know the pitch: a few pennies collected for the United Nations Children's Fund by trick-or-treaters at Halloween can protect a child against a killer disease. In this case, the claim is only slightly exaggerated. For merely a dollar -- make that $15 if you include delivery to some of the least accessible places on earth -- Unicef can immunize an infant against diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough, measles, polio and tuberculosis. No surprise, then, that the World Bank estimates that the Expanded Program of Immunization-Plus, a package with the basic six vaccines, ''has the highest cost-effectiveness of any health measure available today.''

title: Ex-Chairman Says Board Had No Details of Adelphi Head's Pay
description: Adelphi University's board was never told the details of the pay raises and benefit increases granted to the university's president, Peter Diamandopoulos, a former board chairman testified yesterday.

title: A Muted Dole Persona
description: Bob Dole is a rare bird among modern politicians. Most, with the help of hired troupes of packagers, strategists and pollsters, make themselves more attractive to the public at large than they are to insiders who know them well and understand their weaknesses as well as strengths.

title: Tyson's Surrogate Mother Testifies
description: MIKE TYSON's surrogate mother, CAMILLE EWALD, and his current trainer, JAY BRIGHT, both testified in Federal Court yesterday in Albany that Tyson's former mentor Cus D'Amato planned to fire the ex-trainer KEVIN ROONEY but did not get the chance before dying in 1985.

title: As Vote Nears, Superstore Plan Faces Growing Opposition
description: When the Giuliani administration first proposed allowing superstores to locate in New York City's manufacturing zones, the proposal was hailed as an innovative way to reinvigorate the city's dying industrial areas while keeping shoppers from spending their money in the suburbs.

title: Going Out on a Ledge To Please the Crowd
description: The trumpeter Roy Hargrove led his big band through a variety show at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night. Mr. Hargrove is an entertainer, but an honest one; he lives for the audience, but also for the challenge of improvisation. So each arrangement draped harmony with a new set of colors.

title: In Orton's Insane World, Nothing Is as Crazy as Sex
description: No sooner has Dr. Prentice, who runs a psychiatric clinic, coaxed his prospective new secretary out of her dress than things begin to go terribly wrong for him. First, his nymphomaniacal wife returns early from a meeting of her coven clad only in her underwear under a coat and bearing a tale of attempted rape by a bellhop in a hotel linen closet; the oversexed bellboy arrives moments later with a blackmail demand; a policeman turns up looking for the bellhop (and a missing piece of a statue of Winston Churchill), and a Government official drops in for a spot inspection, ready to sign a commitment order for them all.

title: Drug Test Lifts Protein Design Stock
description: Shares in Protein Design Labs Inc. soared today after the company reported that a drug it had developed with F. Hoffman-LaRoche Ltd. had proved effective in preventing the rejection of transplanted kidneys in human trials.

title: Loral Agrees To Purchase Satellite System From AT&T
description: Loral Space and Communications Ltd., which left the military contractor business earlier this year, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Skynet Satellite Services, a broadcast satellite subsidiary of the AT&T Corporation, for $712.5 million in cash.

title: Aching Neck Puts Kramer in the Hospital
description: Quarterback ERIK KRAMER, who has missed only one play in the Chicago Bears' last 20 games, was in the hospital yesterday with a herniated disk in his neck and will be sidelined indefinitely.

title: New U.S. Bonds Could Prove To Be Tax Trap for Unwary
description: What could be more enticing to the long-term investor than a promise to protect returns from inflation's corrosive effect?

title: Inmate's Death Tied to Stroke
description: An autopsy on a death row inmate who died late Monday, three days after collapsing in his cell in Trenton, found that he had suffered a massive cerebral hemorrhage, a Corrections Department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Arab Protest In West Bank Explodes With Gunfire
description: At 3:55 this afternoon, the rules changed starkly for Palestinians and Israelis battling each other on the main road into this city.

title: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS SEEKING TO BECOME FOR-PROFIT GROUP
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, once one of the country's biggest insurers of last resort, plans to announce today that it will seek approval from New York State to become a for-profit company, bringing to a close its historic role as a safety net for the sickest people of the state.

title: Pennzoil Picks GGT Group Unit
description: The Pennzoil Products Company, the maker of motor oils, said yesterday that it had named GSD& M in Austin, Tex., to handle its account, which had been handled by Lois/EJL Advertising in Houston for the last 37 years. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Reeves Says Lifting Was Taken Lightly
description: If anyone thinks that Giants Coach Dan Reeves has given up on the season, or that he will become easier on his players because the team is so young, they need only consider what happened in a fiery team meeting this morning.

title: Navy Analyst Accused as Spy for South Korea
description: A civilian Navy intelligence analyst with access to highly classified information was accused today of passing military secrets to South Korea, Federal law enforcement officials said.

title: Taylor at 75: Going Beyond Tributes
description: Billy Taylor has been playing piano in New York for more than 50 years, as well as talking about jazz on radio and television. He comes off as a genial professor, though one who has played with all the significant musicians of what is now the jazz mainstream.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH BUYING BACK COMMON STOCK
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $500 million worth of its common stock. The company, a pharmaceutical concern in Madison, N.J., said the shares would be purchased periodically on the open market, and would be used for general corporate purposes, including employee benefit plans.

title: A Shared Victory
description: For 16 years, officials of Yonkers and the city's civil rights leaders have been locked in a nasty battle over the desegregation of the school system.

title: Prof. Leon Lipson, 75, Authority on Soviet Law
description: Prof. Leon Lipson, a Russian-speaking authority on Soviet law who taught at Yale Law School, died on Friday in his sleep at his home in New Haven. He was 75.

title: Marketing Group Chooses Leader
description: The Direct Marketing Association in New York yesterday named H. Robert Wientzen, a longtime direct marketing executive, to succeed Jonah Gitlitz as president and chief executive, effective Jan. 1.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Decaying Trees

title: Hamilton of St. John's Injures Knee
description: St. John's center ZENDON HAMILTON has an inflamed left knee and is expected to be out for at least three to six weeks, the school said last night. Hamilton averaged 20.8 points and 10.3 rebounds a game as a sophomore last season.

title: Politicians Take On Japan's Finance Ministry, With Caution
description: Six months ago, it seemed that the public's fury at Japan's imposing Finance Ministry might result in change, as political factions were threatening to carve it up and eviscerate its power and influence.

title: Bridge
description: Trying to identify the greatest American player of all time might seem an entirely subjective enterprise, but the American Contract Bridge League recently hit on an objective procedure. It listed victories and second-place finishes in the most prestigious events -- open world and national titles, with emphasis on team play -- and awarded points for each result.

title: Bertelsmann Reports Mixed Picture for Year
description: The German media conglomerate Bertelsmann A.G. said yesterday that a lower tax bill helped raise profits by 11 percent in its latest fiscal year, but its operating profits fell largely because of higher paper costs. The company earned 905 million marks, or $603 million, in the year ended June 30, up from 817 million last year.

title: New York Shipping Family Fined $75 Million for Oil Spill in Puerto Rico
description: For a giant oil spill in Puerto Rico in January 1994, a judge in Federal District Court in Puerto Rico today levied what prosecutors said was the largest criminal fine in the history of environmental law, $75 million, against three corporations owned by a New York shipping family with a history of spills.

title: Union Seeks Approval First And Negotiations Later
description: In an attempt to salvage a deal negotiators virtually struck more than six weeks ago and end baseball's seemingly endless labor war, the players union is seeking pre-ratification of a new agreement before most players go home Sunday.

title: Laboratory Test Devised to Detect Brain Illness, and It May Work for Mad-Cow Disease
description: A new test of spinal fluid can detect Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a fatal, transmissible disorder of the human nervous system, scientists from the National Institutes of Health and the California Institute of Technology are reporting today. The test has also found related diseases in experimental animals and is being studied to determine whether it can indicate ''mad-cow disease,'' which has led to the slaughter of more than 170,000 cattle in England.

title: Doubles Trouble for House Divided
description: This is one of those rare weekends on which tennis will turn to its team players and put on a pluralistic, patriotic front: The United States and Spain are facing off in the final of the Fed Cup competition in Atlantic City. The event, at least for its three-time defending champion, Spain, and its 1994 and 1995 runner-up, the United States, is akin to golf's Ryder Cup: international bragging rights come with the trophy, and membership on the teams is a privilege.

title: Among Crucial Set of Dole Allies, the Gains of Spring Prove Tough in Autumn
description: When Bob Dole was running in the primaries, his most important allies were Republican governors, who put their statewide party apparatuses into high gear to get out the vote for him. But as the general election approaches, many of those same governors are finding that winning broad support for Mr. Dole in their states is an uphill battle.

title: Armenian Troops Move In, and Election Protest Turns Violent
description: Soldiers and plainclothesmen fired weapons in the air and beat dozens of people tonight to disperse tens of thousands who had gathered in front of Parliament to protest Sunday's presidential election, which was marred by fraud.

title: In His Own Words
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON

title: Far Out, Far In, Far and Away
description: Claude Vivier

title: Eccentricity Is So Collectible
description: COLLECTORS of classic Americana -- patchwork quilts and weather vanes -- can certainly satisfy their appetites at the Fall Antiques Show, which opens today and continues through Sunday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street in Manhattan. But the show, which is now in its 18th year, has continued to build on its recent history of stepping beyond the picket-fence norm to include what Sanford Smith, its founder and organizer, called ''complementary items'' -- collectibles with familiar faces but often defiant eccentricities.

title: U.S. Considers Another Evacuation of Aid Workers From Iraq
description: As the Director of Central Intelligence reported that President Saddam Hussein had strengthened his political control over northern Iraq, the State Department announced today that the United States was considering a second evacuation of aid workers involved in relief efforts in the Kurdish enclave.

title: Why Defend Partial-Birth Abortion?
description: The debate in Congress about the procedure known as partial-birth abortion reveals deep national uneasiness about abortion 23 years after the Supreme Court legalized it. As usual, each side in the debate shades the statistics and distorts the facts. But in this case, it is the abortion-rights advocates who seem inflexible and rigid.

title: Little Settled As Documents On F.B.I. Files Stir Debate
description: Clinton Administration officials today released a set of newly obtained documents that they said provide strong evidence there was no intentional wrongdoing in the White House's handling of confidential F.B.I. files. But Republicans in Congress quickly responded that the documents demonstrated just the opposite.

title: Invesco Talks With AIM About Merger
description: Invesco P.L.C. of Britain and AIM Management Group Inc. of Houston said today that they were in merger discussions that could result in the creation of an international fund manager with $144 billion in assets.

title: U.S. Judge May Reopen Primary Polls
description: A Federal judge who has been asked to order new primary elections because of ballot problems that kept many voters away from the polls in Brooklyn said that in at least one race, he may instead reopen the polls so that people who did not vote can do so.

title: Among Arabs, Dashed Hope Brought Resentment to a Boil
description: Just nine months ago, this city was swept up in joyous celebration as Israeli occupation forces withdrew days before Christmas, handing over the traditional birthplace of Jesus to Palestinian rule.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GENE and BOB PRESSMAN said that their father, Fred Pressman, who elevated Barneys New York from a bargain shopper's delight to an emporium of designer fashion, was not the kind of man who would have promoted the use of his name on a trendy Manhattan restaurant.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL

title: A Major in Parties and a Minor in Art
description: If you're looking for an arty party school, the University of California at Santa Cruz might be just the place, with its social headquarters a fraternity house known as El Rancho Grande, shared by five hard-drinking, rock-and-rolling friends. Here, all anybody seems to do is guzzle beer, nosh on pizza, play darts and rerun home videos of the fraternity's recent Halloween orgy.

title: New York Seeks to Tighten Rules on Medical Research
description: Prompted by the case of a healthy 19-year-old college student who died of a heart attack after volunteering for a medical research project, state health officials yesterday assailed the researchers and called for stricter state rules for such experiments.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELIZABETH HUBBARD is accustomed to being recognized wherever she goes in the United States. After all, for 12 years she has played the scheming and powerful Lucinda Walsh on the CBS soap opera ''As the World Turns.'' But she certainly never expected to be showered with adulation in Bosnia.

title: A New For-Profit School Sets Off a Turf Battle in Detroit
description: Like a company invading another market, a cash-strapped Michigan public school district opened a for-profit school in midtown Detroit today with the explicit purpose of making money, infuriating Detroit school officials who called it ''educational piracy.''

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: A Bridge Too Far

title: TriBeCa Dairy Wholesaler Is Link With Pushcart Past
description: Well before a city planner in the 1970's christened the area TriBeCa -- Triangle Below Canal -- the blocks just north of Chambers Street and east of Greenwich Street were the eggs, butter and cheese section of New York. Serious businessmen, usually chomping on immense cigars, stalked about in fedoras making deals involving thousands of dozens of eggs. The hundreds of belching delivery trucks and squirming pushcarts meant it often took more than an hour to drive one block.

title: All-Stars in a Garden Encore
description: Four years ago, Dave Checketts had a brainstorm. With the popularity of the National Basketball Association growing rapidly, Checketts, then the Knicks' president, thought it was time for the All-Star Game to return to Madison Square Garden.

title: A MetroStars Star Returns for Playoff
description: The MetroStars may have Nicola Caricola, their top defender, for tonight's second game of the first-round playoff series with D.C. United. Caricola missed the victory in the opening game of the series with a concussion, but he traveled with the team to Washington yesterday for the game at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium (7:30 P.M., ESPN).

title: Jordan, McGrath And Nestle End Bond
description: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor in New York and the chocolate and confections division of the Nestle Food Company have mutually decided to end their relationship, which dates to the early 1980's.

title: Gingrich Faces 4 New Charges By Ethics Panel
description: The House ethics committee raised four new charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich today, including the potentially devastating question of whether he has provided its investigation with ''accurate, reliable and complete information.''

title: Alcatel Alsthom Cuts First-Half Loss
description: France's largest industrial company, Alcatel Alsthom, which posted the biggest loss in French corporate history in 1995, said yesterday that it had narrowed its losses in the first half and predicted a profit for 1996.

title: Art in Review
description: Patrick Faigenbaum

title: Cheering In Bronx Is Heard Far Afield
description: After 15 years of the sobriety of finishing a baseball season without their team in first place, and often nowhere near it, Yankee fans were able to drink in the sugary taste of success yesterday, and no one more so than Bruce Burdman.

title: Abram Games, Designer of British War Posters, Dies at 82
description: Abram Games, whose powerful profusion of vivid posters cautioned, cajoled, delighted, educated and inspired the British home front during World War II, died in London on Aug. 27. He was 82.

title: Plea in Valet-Parking Case
description: The get-rich-quick investment scheme that prosecutors say James T. Jennings offered may not have been swampland in Florida, but it was close: valet-parking company franchises in unprofitable locations. Mr. Jennings pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he bilked investors in his defunct company, Valet Park International, of Wall Township, out of more than $700,000 between 1991 and 1993.

title: South African Links Top Spy To the Slaying Of Olof Palme
description: The commander of an apartheid-era police hit squad testified today that one of South Africa's most notorious spies had been involved in the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden more than 10 years ago.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Fargo

title: Man Tells How Officer Subdued His Son in Fatal Encounter
description: Wrapping up their case against a Bronx police officer accused of murdering a man whom he was trying to arrest, prosecutors yesterday called their final witness, the dead man's father, to describe how he had watched the officer put his son in a choke hold before handcuffing him face down on the ground.

title: PBS Breaks Further Ground With Debate of Congressional Leaders
description: The Public Broadcasting Service believes it has glimpsed the future of political journalism, and it is, of course, earnest.

title: Kings Take Pursuit of a Player to London
description: The Sacramento Kings will go to international arbitration to determine if their No. 1 draft choice, PREDRAG STOJAKOVIC, will play for the team this season.

title: Armed Troops In Armenia Arrest Dozens Of Protesters
description: Government troops arrested and beat dozens of demonstrators and bystanders today in an effort to end three days of protests against Armenia's presidential election, which was tainted by charges of fraud.

title: Junk-bond funds had their best sales month ever in August.
description: CASH inflows into mutual funds that invest in stocks, having bounced back in August, continued to surge in September. But even more impressive are the records being set in a more speculative arena of the financial markets -- junk bonds.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Overtime

title: Wilson Is Buoyed; Johnson Is Sizzling
description: Paul Wilson finished his season on a positive note today, but his teammate Lance Johnson thinks he is far from finished.

title: Rooney's Case Against Tyson Goes to Jury
description: The former trainer KEVIN ROONEY's claim that MIKE TYSON breached a careerlong contract and owes him $49 million was put in the hands of an eight-member jury in Albany yesterday.

title: A Film Series On a Director
description: Watching ''Pathetic Fallacy,'' the movie that established the Bengali film maker Ritwik Ghatak as one of the greatest South Asian directors, you can feel cinematic echoes that run all the way from Charlie Chaplin to ''The Bicycle Thief.'' This serious comedy, which will have screenings at the Walter Reade Theater this weekend, follows the adventures of a taxi driver who is so devoted to his broken-down Ford that he gives it a name (Jagaddal) and treats it like a trusted human servant, administering praise and punishment.

title: A Crusader for the Faith, Both Saintly and Sexy
description: ''Entertaining Angels: The Dorothy Day Story'' is the kind of old-fashioned Hollywood biography that underlines each dramatic turning point as it churns along on its predictable path toward sudsy deification. In telling the story of the New York-based Roman Catholic crusader who devoted herself to helping the poor, it imagines her life as a series of crises that the screenplay (by John Wells) reduces into neatly circumscribed, carefully rigged little confrontations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The trouble-plagued Royal Opera House in London has yet another problem: whom to replace the golden couple of opera -- ROBERTO ALAGNA, the French tenor, and his wife, ANGELA GHEORGHIU, the Romanian soprano -- as Rodolfo and Mimi in ''La Boheme'' next month.

title: 3 Suffragists (in Marble) To Move Up in the Capitol
description: After 75 years of Washingon exile, a marble statue of three female suffragists is to rise from the Capitol's Crypt into the sunlight of the Rotunda, according to a resolution approved last night by the House of Representatives.

title: Making It In New York, New York
description: THE words rain down on the Yankees seemingly a thousand times a year, from the lips of Sinatra and Minnelli. And for most any day in the long summer months of July and August, ''New York, New York'' is as innocuous as any of the ear candy usually blaring from Yankee Stadium loudspeakers, laying patterns only on the subconscious minds of fans seeking to make quick exits after Yankees victories.

title: Without Wall Street, There Is No Main Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Here's Something to Fear in Immigration Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about European criticism of Turkey's human rights record misidentified a Kurdish separatist group in Turkey. It is the Kurdistan Workers Party. (The Kurdistan Democratic Party is a group in Iraq.)

title: Art in Review
description: Hannah Wilke

title: Outspending Our Foes
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu and Arafat, and the Political Burdens of Their Stubbornness
description: With their elaborate brinkmanship suddenly gone awry and the Israeli-Palestinian agreements in mortal peril, Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat have begun urgently calling for peace. But the question is whether the men or the events are now in control.

title: With Congressional Term Waning, Fund-Raising Events Abound in Capital
description: In a drab reception room at the Capitol Hill Club, a Republican redoubt just a few hundred yards from the House floor, the wine was flowing at a $500-a-ticket tasting to benefit the re-election campaign of Representative George P. Radanovich, a California Republican who runs a commercial winery near Yosemite National Park.

title: Mexico Party Disbands Panel Seeking Graft
description: Over the objections of opposition leaders, the dominant political party has closed down the first congressional commission in decades to conduct a serious investigation of Government corruption, declaring that it found no major irregularities.

title: Assembly Passes Divorce Bill
description: The State Assembly approved a bill yesterday that would allow judges dividing assets in divorce proceedings to weigh the value of a career relinquished by a spouse who stays home to raise children.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13

title: Ping-Pong Rain and Other Gimmicks
description: Customers abound in a rising real estate market, but what brokers really need are listings, or properties for sale. Increasingly, they are resorting to gimmicks.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Bottle Rocket

title: Funeral Industry Leaders Clash Over an Unwelcome Bid
description: Only in the funeral home industry or perhaps the pro wrestling arena -- could someone like Ray L. Loewen reasonably claim the role of Mr. Nice Guy.

title: Inside Art
description: Fighting Over a Legacy

title: Israel at the Brink
description: Barely three months in power, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel suddenly faces a turning point for his Government and his country. After weeks of hesitation about whether to reinforce or weaken the peace he inherited between Israel and the Palestinians, Mr. Netanyahu must now make a choice. If he encourages peace, he may be able to quell the violent clashes that have rocked Israel the last two days and rebuild the mutual trust that has been shattered. If he abandons the peace effort, Israel and the Middle East will almost certainly slip back into violence and enmity.

title: Silicon Graphics Shares Fall on Outlook
description: Shares in Silicon Graphics Inc. were hammered today following the company's report late Wednesday that its fiscal first-quarter results would fall short of Wall Street analysts' expectations.

title: For Jews, a Split Over Peace Effort Widens
description: Michal Cohen Shauli sat astride her motor scooter crying as dusk fell today across Tel Aviv, the sea breeze unfurling the Israeli flag planted in the jagged charcoal tablet that marks the spot where Yitzhak Rabin was gunned down.

title: PFIZER PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO $2 BILLION OF STOCK
description: The pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $2 billion of common stock in the next two years. Pfizer, based in New York, said it would use the repurchased shares for general purposes. The company now has about 625 million common shares outstanding. Pfizer's shares gained $1.50 yesterday, to $78.875, with more than 2.1 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Spain Has Owned U.S., But Now U.S. Has Seles
description: Trump cards can come in handy in Atlantic City, so the United States Fed Cup team, eager to avoid folding against Spain for the third straight year in the final of this event, made sure it brought one along to the boardwalk this weekend in the form of Monica Seles.

title: Dow Corning Selects Grey Advertising
description: The Dow Corning Corporation said yesterday that it had selected Grey Advertising Inc. in New York to handle a new worldwide corporate image account with billings that have not been determined.

title: In His Own Words
description: Bob Dole

title: Even a Brooklyn Fan Could Enjoy These Yanks
description: THIS is a hard column to write. My friends from the old neighborhood are going to disown me. All my journalistic principles are going out the window. My father is going to reach out from the great beyond and swat me one.

title: Assembly Votes for Casino Plan
description: The New Jersey Assembly gave final legislative approval yesterday to the last of several concessions sought by Stephen A. Wynn before he would agree to proceed with a $2 billion casino and hotel project in the marina area of Atlantic City.

title: Bank's Gold Inspires Tales Of Plunder
description: EIGHTY feet beneath Liberty Street in lower Manhattan, 9,000 tons of gold -- you read that right, 9,000 tons -- are stored in the vaults of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. It is, bank officials say, the largest repository of gold in the world. Forget Fort Knox.

title: Art in Review
description: Lyle Ashton Harris

title: Chairman of Jardine Fleming Steps Down
description: Alan H. Smith, the chairman of the Jardine Fleming Group, announced his retirement today in the wake of an investigation that found its star fund manager was cheating clients.

title: FLORIDA OFFICIAL OPPOSES PRUDENTIAL SETTLEMENT
description: The Florida insurance commissioner said yesterday that an agreement by the Prudential Insurance Company of America to pay at least $410 million to policyholders victimized by deceptive sales practiceswas ''fundamentally flawed.'' The commissioner, Bill Nelson, had been among officials from seven states who had objected to an earlier settlement. He said he would take ''whatever steps are needed to improve on the proposed settlement, including, if necessary, testifying against it'' at a Federal District Court hearing expected sometime next year in Newark, where Prudential is based. While the latest plan was being negotiated, Mr. Nelson and officials from the other states said that they thought it might place an excessive burden on policyholders to prove wrongdoing. Robert DeFillippo, a Prudential spokesman, defended both settlement plans. ''Charges that policyholders face an unfair burden in providing evidence are exaggerated,'' he said.

title: No Headline
description: ''I feel like a person who thought he had recovered from a serious illness and suddenly he has a relapse. It's worse when it happens again.''

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Love, Regrets and Revelations
description: THE secrets that bring such immediacy to Mike Leigh's tender and wrenching new film are not confined to the screen. Mr. Leigh, celebrated for his patient, Olympian methods with actors, deliberately keeps those players in the dark as a way of capturing an essential inner light.

title: His Blood Is Colder Than Ice
description: If ''Two Days in the Valley'' attracts a large audience, it could finally rescue the San Fernando Valley from its popular image as an endless shopping center overrun with teen-age airheads shrieking, ''Gag me with a spoon!'' Instead of spoiled mall rats, this comic film noir written and directed by John Herzfeld populates the same territory with Robert Altman-like oddballs viewed through a Quentin Tarantino-ish lens.

title: BMW turns to fashion, and media and retail partners, to promote its stylish Z3 Roadster.
description: MARKETER that borrowed James Bond's license to kill is angling for a license to vogue.

title: Valujet, Grounded for Safety Problems, Is Cleared to Fly Again
description: The Transportation Department gave Valujet Airlines permission to resume flying today, three months after it was grounded for numerous safety violations that came to light after the May 11 crash of one of its DC-9's in the Florida Everglades.

title: Welfare, Workfare and Workers
description: In an era of tight budgets, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has employed large numbers of welfare recipients to clean parks, sweep streets, monitor school cafeterias and perform other services in New York City. But with the ''workfare'' program due to expand to comply with the new welfare law, labor leaders who had cooperated at first are having second thoughts. They fear that a flood of welfare recipients may hasten cuts in the public work force. Their worries are understandable, but the city can proceed with the program and also find ways to accommodate some of the unions' concerns.

title: Randall Short, 41; Wrote on the Arts
description: Randall Short, a staff writer at New York magazine, was found dead Wednesday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 41.

title: U.S. CENSUS FINDS FIRST INCOME RISE IN PAST SIX YEARS
description: Household income rose in 1995 for the first time in six years, the Census Bureau reported today, as the number of poor people in the United States dropped by more than 1.6 million, reaching historic lows for blacks and the elderly.

title: Archer Investors Urged to Hold Off on Vote
description: In a sign of continued conflict between the Archer Daniels Midland Company and its largest shareholders, two influential pension funds called on investors in the company yesterday to withhold their proxy cards until they receive more information about a proposal they are making to require more independent directors on the company's board.

title: Autumn Is Cigar's Time of Year
description: That was Cigar out there at Belmont Park yesterday morning, working out for his next appearance, in the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup one week from tomorrow. And the 6-year-old superstar, with two races left to run in his career, seems to be growing stronger as the season is growing cooler.

title: INSIDE
description: Clues on H.I.V. Immunity

title: Of Gnosticism and the Spark Within
description: OMENS OF MILLENNIUM

title: Toshiba Introduces Digital Video Products
description: The Toshiba Corporation formally introduced its first digital videodisk products yesterday, saying a DVD player for use with televisions will go on sale in Japan on Nov. 1 for 77,000 yen, or $700. Toshiba said the DVD player could be available in the United States by the end of the year. (AP)

title: Discontented Workfare Laborers Murmur 'Union'
description: Angry about their working conditions, some welfare recipients required to work for their benefits say that with the work should come the many protections available to other workers. While not objecting to work itself, these laborers complain that they are occupying a new basement tier in the labor force, one that lacks regulations on hours, wages and safety that other workers take for granted.

title: Ancient Circles
description: To the Editor:

title: 6-Year-Old's Sex Crime: Innocent Peck on Cheek
description: It might have been the most innocent thing in the world, one 6-year-old's kiss on another child's cheek. Or, as the boy's father put it, ''Every child's going to steal a little peck on the jaw, once in a while.''

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Wild Reeds

title: Trenton Outlines Plan to Aid 'Boarder Babies'
description: The Whitman administration outlined a far-reaching plan today to reduce the hospital stays for infants who are ready to leave the hospital, but remain for weeks or months at a time because their families are unwilling or unable to care for them.

title: Man Drowns During a Protest Over Asian Islets
description: A Hong Kong man, asserting China's claim to a sprinkling of rocky islets, accidentally drowned today after leaping from a freighter en route there.

title: T.W.A. Evidence May Have Corroded
description: Technical experts investigating the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 say they are growing increasingly worried that corrosion from salt water may have erased from metal wreckage the critical evidence investigators say they must find to show whether the plane was brought down by a bomb, missile or mechanical failure. Since salvage work began 10 weeks ago, investigators have scanned each shard for distinctive microscopic pits or cracks that are the Holy Grail of metallurgists looking for evidence of a bomb or missile blast. But conditions at the 120-foot average depth in which the wreckage sank are particularly prone to cause aluminum and the other lightweight metals found in airliners to dissolve, several investigators and independent experts in marine corrosion said.

title: After 6 Months, Her Feet Are Back on the Ground
description: Shannon W. Lucid walked out of the space shuttle Atlantis today, propped up by helpers but on her own power after feeling the pull of gravity for the first time in more than six months, NASA officials said.

title: 50 ARE KILLED AS CLASHES WIDEN FROM WEST BANK TO GAZA STRIP
description: Violent confrontations between Palestinians and Israeli soldiers raged for a second day across the West Bank and spread to the Gaza Strip on Thursday, leaving at least 39 Palestinians and 11 Israelis dead. Hundreds on both sides were wounded.

title: Ex-Mayor on Trial, a Rwanda Town Remembers
description: Not far from the town hall in this farming community is a leafy grove of trees where young boys tend to fat cattle and a steady breeze stirs the fragrant air. Underneath the trees are two mass graves, ringed with flowers, where lie the remains of at least 2,000 people killed with machetes during the mass killing of Tutsi in 1994.

title: An Eclipse Draws Crowds, and Telescopes
description: Scores of men, women and children gathered by the shimmering East River last night for a spectacular show that they knew would be free, would not come to town again for several years and would absolutely start on time.

title: France Selling Interest In Credit Local
description: France said yesterday that it was selling its 7.5 percent stake in Credit Local de France S.A., the country's largest lender to local governments. The Finance Ministry said the stake represented 2.8 million shares of Credit Local. At the current price of 440 French francs ($86) a share, the Government would realize 1.23 billion francs.

title: Trains Get Navigation Device
description: For passengers on New Jersey Transit's newest trains, the sound of a conductor announcing an approaching station will be only a memory. Thanks to a new satellite navigation system, passengers will be able to hear a recording telling them where they are and read their location on a screen, Jeff Maclin, a spokesman for the agency, said.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Twister

title: Bet Your Boots We're Environmentalists
description: To the Editor:

title: Mopping Up After Murders
description: Seeing Quentin Tarantino's name high in the credits for the new black comedy ''Curdled'' is like seeing golden arches off in the distance. When you get there, you know what they're serving. Chances are it's been chopped.

title: Art in Review
description: Jackie Ferrara

title: 2 Ex-Officers of 30th Precinct Are Sentenced for Drug Deals
description: Two of the former police officers most deeply enmeshed in the sweeping scandal at the 30th Precinct in Harlem were sentenced yesterday for dealing drugs, illegally breaking into property and taking payoffs from narcotics dealers.

title: BURLINGTON SHARES DROP ON POOR EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Burlington Industries' shares fell 21 percent yesterday after the textile company said earnings for its fourth quarter this year and the first half of 1997 would be hurt by excess inventory of denim among the companies it supplies. Burlington's shares fell $2.875, to a 52-week low of $10.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Burlington, based in Greensboro, N.C., and a leading maker of specialty denim for the fashion industry, said profit for the quarter ending Sept. 28 would be slightly less than the 21 cents a share earned a year ago.

title: A Leopard Learning The Ropes
description: For those who prefer the real thing rather than animated coming-of-age stories about animals, today brings a beautifully photographed account called ''The Leopard Son.''

title: Suicide of the West
description: If the shooting war between Arab and Jew on the West Bank spreads, the responsibility will in substantial part belong to foreigners -- those governments, politicians and journalists who immediately found the Israelis guilty.

title: Corn Prices Fall as Weather Eases Fears of Frost Damage
description: Corn prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as forecasts for warmer weather eased the outlook for frost damage.

title: Belo in $1.5 Billion Deal For Providence Journal Co.
description: The A. H. Belo Corporation of Dallas said yesterday that it would buy the Providence Journal Company of Providence, R.I., for $1.5 billion in cash and stock in a deal that would further tighten the consolidation of ownership in broadcasting.

title: Paribas Earnings Jump Sixfold
description: Compagnie Financiere de Paribas S.A. said yesterday that its earnings rose more than sixfold in the first half, helped by capital gains on its share portfolio and the performance of its Banque Paribas unit.

title: Restaurants
description: Somewhere between the steamed armadillo I was served in China and the truffled cockscombs in the south of France, I lost the ability to be surprised by food.

title: When Men's and Women's Costumes Taunted Each Other
description: ''TWO by Two,'' the new show at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is as much an exhibition of gender politics as it is an exhibition of clothes.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish harvest festival, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City on Saturday and Sunday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: The Most Magnificent Obsession: Books
description: IN one of the routines of Jack Benny, the comic auteur of avarice, an unwary passer-by asks him for directions. Benny responds not with streets but with banks, sending him from Chase to Hanover to City -- on and on, bank after bank. In Benny's imaginative kingdom, the world was a paradise of banks separated by meaningless stretches of nonbanks; he couldn't believe anyone really wanted to go anywhere else. I understand. I feel much the same way about books, and the places and people associated with them.

title: Questions Raised on Plan for Blue Cross
description: For more than a year, the unique role that Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has played in New York's health care system has been eroding steadily, so Wednesday's announcement that its executives wanted to turn it into a for-profit insurer served only as a final acknowledgment: the company was no longer the insurer of last resort for the state's most grievously ill.

title: Covering Up Cruelty
description: The immigration bill just passed by the House has dozens of provisions to harass and torment legal immigrants -- but hardly anyone knows that. The bill's sponsors have covered up its harsh character by disguising it as a crackdown on illegal immigrants.

title: Lag in Health Coverage
description: New Jerseyans were better off financially than most other Americans last year, but a comparatively high percentage were not protecting themselves from the potential costs of catastrophic illness, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.

title: Agnew and Japanese
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Not More for the Fans Counting on SportsChannel
description: SportsChannel never said it, but in the crevices of its Islanders, Nets and Devils schedules for 1996-97 resides an indisputable message: the regional sports network owned by Cablevision will air 15 fewer of the teams' games.

title: Viewing a Year Both Tragic and Joyful
