description: ''Eyewitness 1996,'' an exhibition of the best photojournalism of 1995, as selected by the World Press Photo Foundation, doesn't pull its punches when it comes to pictures of war and carnage or freak accidents. It also firmly champions no-frills reportage but occasionally recognizes photojournalism that combines both journalism and art.

title: Daughter Feasting On Grief
description: GRIEF walks in circles in the National Theater of Greece's hypnotic interpretation of Sophocles' ''Elektra.'' The emotion, like the tragedy's anger-shrouded heroine, traces an orbit of despair that seems as fixed, in its way, as the figures on Keats's urn.

title: New Demands by White House Are Made on Immigration Bill
description: Two days after Republicans dropped President Clinton's major objection to an immigration bill, the White House today demanded additional changes and threatened to delay a catch-all spending bill if Republicans did not comply.

title: Bond Prices Post Increase For 4th Day
description: Treasury prices advanced for a fourth consecutive session yesterday, bolstered by a durable goods report that pointed to a slowing economy.

title: Wandering Through a Place That Never Was
description: One thing can be said for the Spanish artist Juan Munoz: He certainly knows how to create an effect, one that sets the mind racing, spinning out possible narratives and suggestive precedents. Mr. Munoz, who is 43 and lives in Madrid, is known for using cast figurative sculptures and dramatic architectural spaces to create a sense of alienation, spectacle and enigma. His latest and most ambitious installation has just opened on the big skylighted fourth floor of the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea. There Mr. Munoz has built a series of stage-set spaces for the viewer to walk through, populating them with nearly life-size male figures on whom one can spy or eavesdrop.

title: A World of Films, Gathered in Manhattan
description: The 34th New York Film Festival opens tonight with screenings of ''Secrets and Lies,'' directed by Mike Leigh, and closes on Oct. 13 with ''The People vs. Larry Flynt,'' directed by Milos Forman. The festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, includes 29 programs representing 17 countries. All films are shown at Alice Tully Hall, with the exception of the late show tonight and ''The People vs. Larry Flynt'' on Oct. 13, which will be at Avery Fisher Hall. Several special events and film series are planned at the Ziegfeld Theater, 141 West 54th Street, and the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street. A newly restored version of Alfred Hitchcock's 1958 film ''Vertigo'' will have its premiere at a fund-raising gala for the Film Society to be held at the Ziegfeld on Oct. 4 at 7:30 P.M. (tickets, $75); additional screenings on Oct. 5 at the Walter Reade are sold out, but the film will open on Oct. 6 at the Ziegfeld. ''The Rolling Stones Rock-and-Roll Circus,'' a 1968-1996 film by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, will be shown on Oct. 12 and 13 at the Walter Reade (tickets, $12). Many festival screenings are sold out, although a few returned tickets may be available. Tickets are $8 to $20 and are available at the Tully Hall box office, (212) 875-5050; tickets for opening and closing nights are $17 and $30. Unless otherwise noted, the films were made this year. Some films are already scheduled to be released commercially in New York City, and those dates are noted. Here is the schedule.

title: Scenes from a Mile: Shopping Waits
description: Some athletes are born to greatness. Svetlana Masterkova was pushed into it.

title: Ex-Suspect in '89 Blasts Says Investigators Lied
description: A man who was the focus of a bombing investigation and intense scrutiny by the press six years ago asserted today that Federal investigators lied in court papers that detailed their suspicions and enabled them to obtain search warrants in his case.

title: Corrosion May Have Erased Vital Clues From T.W.A. Wreckage, Experts Worry
description: Technical experts investigating the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 say they are growing increasingly worried that corrosion from salt water may have erased from metal wreckage the critical evidence investigators say they must find to show whether the plane was brought down by a bomb, missile or mechanical failure.

title: A Great Big Bang and a Cage Full of Quarks
description: One of a teacher's toughest jobs is to instill a sense of proportion: not just a feel for ''A is to B as C is to D,'' but a deeper sense of the space and time scales defining the hierarchical structure of the universe, and the place of mankind within it. ''Cosmic Voyage'' is a spectacular primer in scales.

title: Veto Is Sustained On Abortion Ban
description: The Senate sustained President Clinton's veto of a bill that would have banned a form of late-term abortion.

title: Unnoticed but Deadly, the I.R.A.'s Secret 'Sleepers'
description: Diarmuid O'Neill was 6-foot-3 with ginger hair and a shy manner that prompted friends to refer to him as a ''gentle giant.'' The 27-year-old, who went by the name Dermot, the Anglicized version of Diarmuid, dabbled in cabinet-making and carpentry in the West London neighborhood where he was born and where he attended London Oratory, a highly regarded Catholic school. John McIntosh, the school's principal, recalled him as someone ''who just got on with his work here.''

title: Images of Joy for the Words of Buddha
description: IN the late 12th century, Buddhism was snuffed out in its homeland. Muslim armies swept down on Nalanda and Uddandapura, the last of India's monastic universities, and met no resistance. The monks were butchered, and their libraries, with an unimaginable wealth of handwritten manuscripts, were put to the torch.

title: Palestinian Police: The Breakdown and the Gunfights
description: The gun battles that raged today between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian police officers in the West Bank and Gaza Strip signaled a breakdown of a carefully constructed system of cooperation between the two armed forces.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Messier Remains on Ranger Sideline
description: Mark Messier doesn't know when he will play his next exhibition game with the Rangers. Messier was to visit a doctor today because he is still bothered by an upper respiratory infection that has been with him for more than two weeks.

title: Protecting Children -- From Air Bags
description: The air bag, one of the foremost safety advances of the automobile age, can be dangerous to infants and children who sit in the front passenger seat. In two dozen accidents over the past three years, a passenger-side air bag has inflated with the explosive force needed to save an adult from injury -- but has killed a child. Seven infants in rear-facing baby seats were killed when the bag, expanding in less than a second at 200 times the force of gravity, slammed against the seat, crushing or inflicting brain damage on the child.

title: Salvadoran Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: $25 and Under
description: I have never been a fan of brewpubs. Many of these bars and restaurants, which brew their own beer and ale on the premises, have one inexplicable thing in common: they brew bad beer.

title: Reappointed, I.M.F. Chief Asks New Funds
description: The International Monetary Fund's newly reappointed managing director, Michel Camdessus, presented a substantial shopping list for his organization today, asking for more than $100 billion in new money to enable the fund to safeguard an international financial system increasingly dominated by volatile capital flows.

title: Art in Review
description: Martin Kersels

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 12 about political contributions by Hollywood figures attributed some statistics incompletely. The data were from an analysis by the Campaign Study Group, financed by The Los Angeles Times.

title: Sexual Identity and the Sitcom
description: I have a confession to make. I am jealous of Ellen DeGeneres. Not for her obvious success, but for the opportunity she might have in her ABC sitcom, ''Ellen,'' to play a lesbian. That is if, as recent rumor has it, her character, Ellen Morgan, comes out of the closet this season as a lesbian.

title: A Coattails Reversal From '94 Races
description: It may be hard to imagine given Bob Dole's standing in the polls, but a Democratic candidate for the United States Senate closed his television commercial with this tag line: ''A majority of the time, I vote with the Republican leader, Bob Dole.''

title: Pepsico Plans $500 Million In Charges
description: Sending a signal that it is losing its global struggle with Coca-Cola, Pepsico Inc. said late yesterday that it was moving to immediately revamp its international operations and that it would take a total of more than $500 million in charges in the third and fourth quarters to cover the costs.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 5
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Abducted Boy Is Set Free After 12 Years
description: When the mother last laid eyes on her baby, it was 12 years ago, and Leonard Joseph Cammalleri was 10 months old, weighed 25 pounds, and had curly dark hair and ear lobes that turned up.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Art in Review
description: Rudi Troger

title: Fertile Images Out of the Desert
description: DESERTS bloom in curious ways for Richard Misrach, who has been photographing them for 17 years and is still coming up with surprises. Right now the art world is blooming for him too, with not one but two current shows devoted to his work: downtown at the Curt Marcus Gallery; uptown at the Robert Mann Gallery.

title: Giants' Offensive Linemen To Face Formidable Force
description: How do you stop someone who has the quickness of a running back and the power of a bull? Minnesota tackle John Randle, perhaps the most underrated defensive lineman in the league, stands 6 feet 1 inch tall and weighs about 280 pounds. To a man, the Giants' offensive line will outweigh him. But in this instance, that means absolutely nothing.

title: U.S. Charges a Money Manager With Fraud in Stock Offering
description: Federal prosecutors added a postscript yesterday to the brief, bright life of Normandy America Inc. -- whose shares traded for one day last year before its underwriters recalled them -- charging its chairman and chief executive, Christopher K. Bagdasarian, with conspiracy, securities fraud, bank fraud and perjury.

title: For Children
description: Apple Picking

title: Muslim Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder and Revenge, the Usual Stuff
description: Like Danielle Steel, John Woo gets his name in a television movie's title. Who is John Woo? He's the Hong Kong action-movie director whose more recent mainstream films include ''Hard Target'' with Jean-Claude Van Damme and the hit ''Broken Arrow'' with John Travolta and Christian Slater. ''John Woo's Once a Thief,'' his first television project, can be seen on Sunday night on Fox.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about an agreement by Republican Congressional leaders to drop a disputed provision of a new immigration bill misidentified the place where Bob Dole's campaign manager, Scott Reed, told two Republican lawmakers that Mr. Dole did not want Congress to pass an immigration bill that President Clinton could claim as his own. (An article on Sept. 13 also included the error.) The meeting, on Sept. 12, took place at the Dole campaign headquarters near Capitol Hill; it was not a Congressional office.

title: Senate Fails to Override Veto of Ban on Type of Abortion
description: Failing to override a Presidential veto today, the Senate kept a form of late-term abortion legal. Anti-abortion groups vowed retribution at the polls in November.

title: Durable Orders Drop 3.1%, but What Does It All Mean?
description: Two days after the Federal Reserve decided that the economy was cooling down enough that no interest-rate increase was necessary, fresh figures today showed that the Fed was right, some economists said.

title: In Blistering Attack, Dole Says Clinton Is Using Scare Tactics
description: Here in the land of the elderly, Bob Dole vociferously denounced President Clinton today, accusing the President of fearmongering and distorting the Republican record on Medicare just to frighten old people.

title: In Defense Spending, How Much Is Too Much?
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Olympic Official Takes a New Job
description: BILLY PAYNE, who led the effort to bring the Olympics to Atlanta, was hired yesterday by Nations Bank Corporation, which was a major sponsor of the Games.

title: Dr. David Min-Chyang Ju, 75, A 'Virtuoso' of Plastic Surgery
description: Dr. David Min-Chyang Ju, a plastic surgeon who developed a suturing technique that lessens the irritation of stitches while still closing wounds tightly, died last Friday at Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 75.

title: Before Being Sentenced to Die, Killer Disrupts a Courtroom
description: The killer of 12-year-old Polly Klaas was sentenced to death today at the close of dramatic courtroom scene in which a comment from the defendant sent the girl's outraged father from the room.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dallas Publisher to Buy Providence Journal Co.

title: Clinton Buoys His Party in Capitol Hill Visit
description: President Clinton began today by signing a bill to insure 48-hour hospital stays for mothers and newborns, and ended it by raising $3 million to help Democratic Senate campaigns around the country. In between, he went to Capitol Hill for a love-fest pep talk with Democratic members of Congress with whom he has not always seen eye-to-eye.

title: Cleveland Rookie to Miss Camp Opening
description: The rookie center ZYDRUNAS ILGAUSKAS, a first-round pick of the Cleveland Cavaliers, has a broken bone in his right foot.

title: Coldwell Banker Moves to Sawtooth
description: The Coldwell Banker Corporation, the residential real estate brokerage owned by HFS Inc., said yesterday that it had named the Sawtooth Group in Woodbridge, N.J., to handle its national account, which had been handled by the Los Angeles office of Grey Advertising Inc. for the last five years. Billings were $17 million.

title: Macabre Surprises in a Medical Plot
description: When last seen in the operating room, Hugh Grant was fainting in the midst of ''Nine Months,'' playing a weak-kneed new father. In a change of pace, he now appears as a brilliant and dedicated young neurologist comfortable with emergency room jargon and unfazed by the sight of blood. So Mr. Grant takes some getting used to in ''Extreme Measures,'' Michael Apted's brooding new medical thriller. Here he is barking out orders, bustling with a solemn frenzy worthy of Monty Python and daring to use words like intubated with ease.

title: Bruno's Picks D.M.B.& B. for Account
description: The Bruno's Inc. unit of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, which owns 255 supermarkets in six Southern states, said yesterday that it had named D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York to handle its account, which had been handled by O2 Ideas in Birmingham, Ala., formerly known as Steiner/Bressler/Zimmerman, since the early 1970's. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Boy Took Grenade to School
description: Three hundred elementary school students had an unscheduled recess Wednesday morning -- and a visit from the Essex County bomb squad -- after a fourth-grader took a hand grenade to school. The grenade was determined to be a nonworking device used for military training, but only after the Edgemont School had been evacuated for an hour.

title: Two Pros Bring Lessons Learned To Their Small College Roots
description: This time last year, Andre Waters was on the sideline with the Arizona Cardinals, winding down a 12-year professional football career. He wondered how he would duplicate the challenges that he had met in his playing days after he retired.

title: Home Video
description: Gazing Into VCR's Future

title: Notre Dame's Throwback Fullback
description: He looks the way fullbacks look in grainy black and white films, the way they appeared in the old televised Notre Dame highlights, when Irish touchdowns were separated by the phrase ''We move now to further action. . . .''

title: Take The A Train
description: No doubt you've heard of Louis Farrakhan. And you may have heard of his sidekick, Benjamin Chavis, who nearly succeeded a couple of years ago in driving the N.A.A.C.P. off a cliff.

title: New Indictment Is Filed by U.S. In Hacker Case
description: In what Federal officials called the most comprehensive computer crime indictment ever, the country's most notorious hacker was charged yesterday in Los Angeles with 25 felony counts involving attacks on computer systems and Internet service providers.

title: Turkey vs. the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: DU PONT SAYS THIRD-QUARTER EARNINGS ARE HIGHER
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it expected its third-quarter earnings to exceed Wall Street's expectations by at least 10 percent, excluding a $50 million expense related to the recall of its Benlate 50 DF fungicide. The chemicals company said stronger results in its petroleum division caused its improved forecast. The Benlate charge is related to crop-damage claims and legal expenses. The fungicide was recalled in 1991. Wall Street had been expecting Du Pont to earn about $1.44 a share for the three months ending Sept. 30, according to First Call Inc. In the comparable quarter in 1995, Du Pont earned $769 million, or $1.38 a share. Du Pont's stock was up $2.125 a share, at $89, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: U.S. Urges Israel to Yield And Close Tunnel Entrance
description: The United States yesterday urged Israel to close a new entrance to an archeological tunnel in the Muslim quarter of Jerusalem in an effort to quell growing violence across the West Bank and Gaza Strip, officials said.

title: WATSON TO ACQUIRE ANOTHER DRUG CONCERN
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Oclassen Pharmaceuticals Inc. for $135 million in stock to expand its drug business. Watson shares rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $34.50, in Nasdaq trading. Oclassen, based in San Rafael, Calif., makes pharmaceuticals for the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of skin diseases. The company is expected to generate revenue of about $34 million this year, Watson said. Last year, Watson, based in Corona, Calif., reported net income of $47.9 million on revenue of $152.9 million.

title: For Many Russians, Daily Struggle Eclipses Yeltsin Issue
description: As the news swept across the city today that President Boris N. Yeltsin's health is better than originally believed, Western diplomats sighed with relief, the stock market rallied and the Kremlin shrugged off Communist calls for the President's resignation.

title: Blue Cross Change Seen As Windfall for Advisers
description: With Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield turning itself into a for-profit company, the people who stand to benefit most, should the conversion succeed, would be the company's executives -- who could get higher pay -- and the eventual stockholders, who would see their holdings grow if the company thrives.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Old Razzle-Dazzle at the Old Shubert

title: DOW WINS APPEAL IN BREAST-IMPLANT LAWSUITS
description: The California Court of Appeal upheld a decision yesterday dismissing the Dow Chemical Company and Corning Inc. from 1,800 breast-implant lawsuits. The appeals court said that the companies could not be held liable for the actions of their Dow Corning Corporation joint venture. Dow Corning won a halt of all breast-implant lawsuits when it filed for bankruptcy court protection in May 1995. Dow Chemical, based in Midland, Mich., released news of the ruling after the close of the stock market. Its shares rose 12.5 cents, to $81.25. Corning shares rose 75 cents, to $38.50.

title: New Studies Offer Powerful and Puzzling Evidence on Immunity to AIDS
description: Scientists have long suspected that some people might be immune to the AIDS virus. But now they are accumulating powerful, direct evidence of the extent and strength of such immunity. And many researchers are stunned.

title: Duncan Injured by Foul Ball
description: The Yankees' Mariano Duncan suffered a freakish injury in the eighth inning of tonight's game when he was drilled in the left wrist by Mike Aldrete's foul ball while in the dugout off third base. Duncan, who homered and singled in a 5-3 loss to the Boston Red Sox, was brought to Children's Hospital for X-rays.

title: Yeltsin's Defense Chief Says Russians Are Alarmed by NATO Plan
description: The Russian Defense Minister said today that NATO should abandon plans to accept new members, warning that an expanded Western military alliance would ''sharply change the geopolitical situation in Europe.''

title: Luck Runs Out at Casino
description: Some people thought it was their lucky day on Sept. 12, when a cash machine at a casino in Atlantic City spat out $100 for every $20 they requested. But luck ran out yesterday for four supervisors at The Grand casino. The four were dismissed for ''failing to take appropriate measures to secure the malfunctioning machine,'' according to a statement from the casino's president, Wallace Barr.

title: Lines That Reveal Souls And Slyly Hide a Name
description: He sits alone in a dark, empty theater, looking content in isolation. We hear the sounds of a pencil scratching on paper while his hands are out of sight; we see the round black eyes that have surveyed the finest and most putrid productions on Broadway since the 1920's. His gaze is ironic, penetrating, sometimes mischievous, and we have the privilege of sharing his perspective in Susan W. Dryfoos's ''Line King,'' a captivating portrait of the artist Al Hirschfeld, which opens today at Cinema Third Avenue.

title: Key's Starting Spot Is Suddenly Insecure
description: Presumably, Jimmy Key was entrenched as the Yankees' third starter for the post-season. Presumably, winning 10 of his last 14 decisions made him untouchable. The presumptions were incorrect because Key is not secure and the Yankees' continued infatuation with Dwight Gooden could shift Key to the bullpen.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JEFFERSON BANKSHARES INC., Charlottesville, Va., said it planned to repurchase as many as 1.25 million shares in a modified ''Dutch auction,'' which would allow shareholders to sell part or all of their shares for between $25 and $28 a share.

title: Loss at AT&T Computer Unit Was $1 Billion Over Estimates
description: The AT&T Corporation's foray into computers cost it $1 billion more than previously thought, a filing the company made yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed.

title: Art in Review
description: '3 Legged Race'

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Last Chance for Sterling Forest?
description: Nearly everyone, it seems, wants to save Sterling Forest, an important watershed straddling the New York-New Jersey border that is now owned by a Swiss insurance company that had planned to develop it. The Swiss are willing to sell it for $55 million under a complex deal worked out by two environmental groups. The states of New York and New Jersey have pledged major contributions, and both the Senate and the House have separately authorized $17.5 million in Federal funding, which is essential to the deal.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: The Jets' Special Teams Are Everything But
description: The Jets don't run often, don't move when they pass and don't score. So today they made a move that could jump-start the team Sunday night at Washington. They brought in a new special-teamer.

title: County Criticizes Its Jail
description: A report commissioned by Union County found that the food served at its jail was so ''disgusting'' that inmates might well go on strike or riot, officials said yesterday. The report also complained about the absence of work programs for state inmates at the jail and the strained relations between management and guards, who have been without a contract since December 1993, said Joseph Salemme, the county administrator. The jail, which has had six directors in a decade, is searching for another director, and Mr. Salemme said a lack of consistent leadership had caused problems there. Patricia Mulcahy, a spokeswoman for the state's Department of Corrections, said the jail's food service passed a state inspection in May.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Shares Top Blue Chips in Slow Market

title: Trump in Deal to Buy 55 Wall Street
description: One of New York City's most historic architectural landmarks -- the 1842 Greek Revival office building 55 Wall Street, whose soaring, ornate rotunda hall is one of the grand interiors of lower Manhattan -- is being purchased by Donald J. Trump for what he said last night was a bargain: $20 million.

title: In a Serious Schumann, Mendelssohnian Brio
description: Schumann's ''Spring'' Symphony is the heftiest and most commanding work on the New York Philharmonic's subscription program this week. But although the Schumann in most ways dwarfed the two Mendelssohn offerings -- the String Symphony No. 12 and the Piano Concerto No. 1 -- it was Mendelssohn's spirit that smiled on the proceedings Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. For all the grandeur of Schumann's scoring, the symphony's loveliest moments are the thoroughly Mendelssohnian figures in the finale.

title: Japan's Premier Calls Elections for October
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto dissolved Parliament today, setting the stage for new national elections that may reconfigure Japanese politics.

title: Companies Begin Treatment for Absenteeism : 'Sick' German Workers Get Corporate Medicine
description: FRANKFURT  Germans have remarkably delicate constitutions, if you believe the statistics.

title: Too Much Ado About Catholic School Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Guilty Pleas in Tax Evasion
description: A Passaic City Councilman, accused by prosecutors of failing to file tax returns since 1984, pleaded guilty yesterday to evading $340,000 in taxes. The Councilman, Peter S. Bruce, 64, a former Passaic County Freeholder, and his son, Peter F. Bruce, 39, admitted in Federal District Court in Newark that they took steps to conceal income from a family-owned construction business, said Perry Carbone, an assistant United States attorney. Another son, Eric Bruce, 32, who pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge, has never filed a Federal tax return, Mr. Carbone told Judge William G. Bassler.

title: After Prayers at the Mosque, Oasis of Peace Is Shattered
description: Friday Prayers at Al Aksa Mosque in the walled Old City here began quietly enough this morning.

title: Victim of an Attack Longs for Independence
description: Some mornings, Shane Daniels slips behind the wheel of his car and dreams about being on his own again. But Mr. Daniels has not been able to do a lot of things on his own since he became a victim of a racially charged attack in the parking lot of a Westhampton Beach nightclub. ''I've come a long way since then,'' Mr. Daniels said, ''but it's still frustrating not to be able to care for myself, always to be dependent on others to help me, to drive me here and there and to therapy.''

title: Gooden Hurts Playoff Hopes
description: Turn left out of the Yankees' clubhouse, walk 300 feet past the auxiliary clubhouse, the visiting clubhouse and the third-base dugout and then make a right. Open the sunflower seeds, sit down and cheer.

title: CBS to Give Clinton and Dole Free Air Time on Radio and TV
description: CBS announced yesterday that it would give free television time to the Presidential candidates for ''unfiltered'' pronouncements on campaign issues. The network will also offer free radio time to try to reach a broader, more varied audience.

title: Southern Rector Chosen to Lead St. John the Divine
description: After a seven-month search, a rector from Atlanta has been chosen to head the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the world's largest Gothic cathedral and the nation's largest church.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: Archer Settles Pricing Suits for $65 Million
description: In a flurry of settlements across the country, the Archer Daniels Midland Company agreed to pay more than $65 million to resolve three separate lawsuits stemming largely from a price-fixing scandal at the company, the company and lawyers said yesterday.

title: From Regulator to Advocate
description: Steven P. Perskie, who as an Assemblyman wrote the law that permitted casino gambling in New Jersey and then became the chairman of the commission that oversees the industry, is returning to Atlantic City. Mr. Perskie, who is also a former Superior Court judge, will become a partner in the law firm Horn, Goldberg, Gorny, Plackter & Weiss, whose clients include Harrah's, Showboat and Donald J. Trump's casinos. Mr. Perskie said that after resigning from the commission in May 1994, he worked for Players International on gambling projects outside the state. The commission requires that a former employee wait two years before appearing before the agency as an advocate for a gambling interest, said Dan Heneghan, a commission spokesman. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Neighborhoods and Megastores Don't Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: Pavel Sudoplatov, 89, Dies; Top Soviet Spy Who Accused Oppenheimer
description: Lieut. Gen. Pavel A. Sudoplatov, a legendary Soviet spymaster who plotted and carried out assassinations with cold-blooded efficiency and claimed to have engineered the theft of atomic secrets from the United States with the aid of four eminent scientists, died Tuesday at his home in Moscow. He was 89.

title: Steinbrenner Satisfied For Now, or So He Says
description: Perhaps George Steinbrenner is merely trying to minimize the inherent pressure on his $55 million team, but he uncharacteristically said today that the Yankees do not have to absolutely, positively win the World Series to make 1996 a smashing success.

title: 10 MORE DIE IN MIDEAST RIOTS AS VIOLENCE ENTERS 3D DAY; MOSQUE IS SCENE OF A CLASH
description: The Israeli police stormed into Jerusalem's Al Aksa Mosque compound today to disperse stone-throwing youths as a wave of Arab-Israeli violence entered its third day.

title: Visual Bridge To and of Art In Queens
description: A CITY of islands could not exist without bridge builders. Their towering monuments of steel and asphalt stitch together a fractured metropolis (while allowing generations of club kids to invade Manhattan each weekend). Their names are legendary. The Roeblings. Robert Moses. Suzy Sureck.

title: Getting Down and Dirty in the Garden Is Big Business
description: At age 45, Lea Rasabi acquired a passion for peegee hydrangeas. Like a teen-ager with a crush, she drove along the streets of her Queens neighborhood this summer, coveting the treelike shrubs that bloom luxuriantly in August. She wanted one for her yard.

title: Alabama Voters Waver Between Old Principles And a New Prosperity
description: The people of Etowah County, explains the Rev. Aaron Johnson, the preacher at the First Baptist Church of Gadsden, are a little bit different. In their distinctly Southern way, they are a tad mistrustful, a bit suspicious. Even in the best of times, it seems, they fear that distant forces may be conspiring to take their jobs and undermine their values.

title: Who, You Might Ask, Is Getting Any Younger?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lackluster Miracles
description: To the Editor:

title: Travelers on Earlier Flight Offer No New Crash Leads
description: When Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded shortly after taking off from Kennedy International Airport on July 17, one of the theories investigators pursued was that a bomb was planted on the plane as it flew from Athens to New York earlier that day and set to detonate on the next leg of the plane's journey.

title: Calipari Flies Nets From Basement to Penthouse
description: Coach John Calipari is counting on a luxury tax of sorts, a payback for the star treatment he gives his players: fly a guy first class, and he'll upgrade his game in return.

title: For Europe's Monetary Union, Italy Debates Deep Budget Cuts
description: In a signal of its new determination to join the first round of countries entering Europe's monetary union, Italy's center-left Government today began debate on a $41 billion budget for 1997 that would effectively halve the state deficit.

title: Jones of 49ers Out
description: A shoulder injury has sidelined tight end BRENT JONES, the second marquee 49ers player knocked out of action this week. Jones will miss tomorrow's game against the Atlanta Falcons in San Francisco. He will be on the sideline with quarterback STEVE YOUNG, who is bothered by a groin strain. ELVIS GRBAC is starting in place of Young. (AP)

title: COLEMAN STOCK DROPS ON REPORT OF DEFICIT
description: The stock of the Coleman Company dropped more than 16 percent yesterday, a day after the company, a maker of outdoors equipment, said it would report a small third-quarter loss. The company cited soft sales in North America and Japan for the disappointing outlook. Analysts surveyed by First Call Inc. had expected earnings of 15 cents a share in the period that ends on Monday. The company, based in Golden, Colo., said its sales were hurt by bad weather, including drought in the Southwest and heavy rainfall in the East, which cut down on recreational activity. Coleman's shares fell $1.75 yesterday, to $14.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SHARES OF PEPSICO SHOW A RETREAT OF 7%
description: The stock of Pepsico Inc. fell 7 percent yesterday after the company said on Thursday that it would restructure its faltering international beverage business and report lower earnings. Shares of Pepsi fell $2.125, to $28.375, in trading of 22.6 million, making it the most-active United States issue. Moody's Investor Service said it would review for possible downgrade its A1 rating on Pepsico's long-term debt, while the Standard & Poor's Corporation upheld its A rating. The restructuring will result in charges of at least $525 million in the second half.

title: North Korea Threatens the South Over Killing of Soldiers From Sub
description: North Korea warned today that rising tensions over the grounding of its submarine off South Korea last week might lead to war, and it suggested that it might have to attack the South.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Discovery and BBC Plan Joint Programming Venture
description: Discovery Communications Inc. and the British Broadcasting Corporation announced a joint venture yesterday under which Discovery will spend more than $500 million to produce new programs and start cable and satellite television channels in the United States and around the world with BBC Worldwide Ltd., the commercial arm of the BBC.

title: Surgery for Suns Guard
description: Suns guard KEVIN JOHNSON underwent abdominal hernia surgery last night in Phoenix and will be sidelined up to two months. Johnson, 30, who has said that this, his 10th season, would be his last, was bothered by pain in his lower abdomen and groin last season and missed 26 games.

title: Sharpton Will Bring Issues to Mayoral Contest
description: To the Editor:

title: Informed Without Mercy
description: The doctor says I am being communicated with to death. He wants me to cut back. I have a 4,000-a-day habit. It will finish me, the doctor says. Scientific studies show -- well, you know what they always show. Whatever it is, it's killing you.

title: South Bend Braces for A Worthy Opponent
description: Those echoes will not sleep late Saturday. They will be awakened early by a mob that transforms a peaceful campus into an amusement park, and by those students whose Notre Dame experience is defined in part by the outcome of special Saturdays on weekends such as this.

title: Transformed by Obsession, Heart, Mind and Soul
description: There are moments of such astounding visual power in Michelangelo Antonioni's film ''Beyond the Clouds'' that you are all but transported through the screen to a place where the physical and emotional weather fuse into a palpable sadness.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: Archives Confirm False Hope Fed Hungary Revolt
description: Newly released documents concerning Radio Free Europe broadcasts during the 1956 Hungarian uprising against the Soviets confirm what many Hungarians remembered and others suspected: that commentators encouraged the Hungarians to battle on in the false understanding that they would receive reinforcements from the West.

title: Stepfather of Elisa In Plea Agreement
description: Elisa Izquierdo's stepfather pleaded guilty to assault charges yesterday for repeatedly slamming the child's head against a wall last fall, three weeks before she was bludgeoned to death by her mother.

title: Ruling in Move Suit Is Appealed
description: Lawyers for Ramona Africa are appealing the Aug. 28 ruling that dismissed a jury finding that the city's former police commissioner and fire commissioner were personally liable for a fire that killed 11 people and destroyed an entire city block.

title: Clinton Sets His Sights as Wide as Texas
description: Armed with shiny black cowboy boots, the obligatory Stetson and his best down-home drawl, President Clinton stormed through Texas today, campaigning for Democratic Congressional candidates and hoping to beat longhorn-size odds by carrying the state for his party for the first time since 1976.

title: Gingrich Ethics Inquiry: Setting Off Alarm Bells
description: So far, nobody outside the House ethics committee, perhaps not even Speaker Newt Gingrich's lawyer, knows just what the committee meant on Thursday when it questioned whether the Speaker had provided its investigation ''accurate, reliable and complete information.''

title: No Headline
description: ''When fixed-cost facilities are not being used heavily, why not charge a lower rate? It makes all kinds of sense to do marginal cost pricing if the facilities are lying idle and you can hire faculty.''

title: It's Not Sexist. It's Only Rock And Roll.
description: Walk through the Baseball Hall of Fame, and you'll see only one kind of athlete: baseball players. Not hockey players, not soccer players, not lacrosse players. Walk through the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and you'll see a motley collection of blues shouters, folk strummers, soul testifiers, country rockers and latter-day beat poets. And next year, on its 10th anniversary, the Cleveland-based organization will induct Joni Mitchell into the halls of its museum.

title: Transportation Projects
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-I.B.M. Workers' Suit Against I.R.S. Gains
description: A Federal judge refused today to dismiss a lawsuit against the I.R.S. brought by 737 former I.B.M. employees who contend that part of their severance payments should not have been taxed.

title: Caminiti Keeps Padres In the Running
description: Most valuable player was solved; first place wasn't.

title: Military Ruler in Gambia Defeats Rivals in Election
description: Two years after seizing power in a military coup that overthrew one of the continent's longest-functioning democracies, this country's leader has defeated three civilian rivals to become Gambia's second elected President in 31 years of independence from Britain in voting that was widely regarded as tainted.

title: Seles-Martinez In Leadoff Spot
description: A seaside casino provided the setting, and Cleopatra did the honors for the Fed Cup draw ceremony this morning at Caesars, where it was determined that top-ranked Monica Seles and Conchita Martinez will clash Saturday in the first of five matches in this final round between the United States and Spain.

title: Judge Blames Board of Elections for Problems During a Primary in Brooklyn
description: Assessing some of the worst polling-place foul-ups in recent New York City history, a Federal judge declared yesterday that ''incompetence'' by the Board of Elections had prevented many voters in Brooklyn from casting ballots during the recent primary election.

title: Seapower: The New Lure for East Asia
description: SINGAPORE  Almost every country in East Asia is modernizing its navy after the end of the Cold War and a shift in defense priorities from land to sea, increasing the risk that maritime disputes will turn violent, analysts say.

title: Minority Support
description: To the Editor:

title: FOXMEYER HEALTH IN TALKS TO SELL UNIT TO MCKESSON
description: The FoxMeyer Health Corporation said yesterday that it was in discussions to sell its ailing drug-distribution unit to a rival, the McKesson Corporation. An attempt to sell the subsidiary to the New Jersey investor, William Taggart, fell through in August, days before FoxMeyer put the unit into Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. A FoxMeyer spokeswoman declined to comment further on the status of the talks, which were reported in The Wall Street Journal yesterday. Officials for San Francisco-based McKesson declined to comment. FoxMeyer shares fell 12.5 cents, to $3.375. McKesson shares rose 62.5 cents, to $48.125. FoxMeyer, based in Carrollton, Tex. put the distribution unit into bankruptcy after drug makers scaled back shipments to the company.

title: Selling Family Heirlooms With the Help of a Pro
description: Helaine Fendelman marches through a split-level house here owned by a middle-aged couple she met 15 minutes ago as if it were hers. She ogles a pair of Italian neo-classical chairs in the foyer.

title: SUNY Tries Off-Peak Pricing At Some Struggling Campuses
description: Airlines do it. Hotels do it. Phone companies do it. They all offer off-peak pricing -- discounts to customers who use their services at less crowded times.

title: Europe Takes Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: A Do-Gooder Gets Lucky
description: When a Chicago stockbroker named Gary Hobson miraculously receives a copy of the next day's newspaper, revealing the future, he does what most people would: he heads for the race track. The difference between Gary and most people is that he gives his winnings to a blind friend so she can buy a seeing eye dog.

title: PEGASUS GOLD ENDS DAYTON MINING BID
description: Pegasus Gold Inc. and the Dayton Mining Corporation said yesterday that they had called off plans for Pegasus to acquire Dayton in a share swap valued at $390 million. The companies announced last week that Pegasus Gold would exchange 0.75 of its shares for each Dayton share. ''It became obvious following the final detail review that this transaction was not in the best interest of Dayton,'' said Wayne McClay, chairman and chief executive of Dayton, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia. Dayton's shares fell 43.75 cents, to $6.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange, and Pegasus rose 37.5 cents, to $10.375. The shares of both companies fell more than 10 percent after the acquisition was announced on Sept. 16.

title: Most U.S. Airliners May Carry Traces Of Bomb Residues
description: Just like the Trans World Airlines plane that crashed off Long Island 10 weeks ago, almost every airliner in service in the United States has probably been used in drills for bomb-sniffing dogs sometime during the last two years, Federal Aviation Administration officials acknowledge.

title: Chief Leaving Ben & Jerry's as Its Sales Are Lagging
description: Following one of the most unusual and widely publicized searches in business history, the professional manager whom Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. chose to be its chief executive is leaving abruptly after less than two years in the job.

title: U.S. Says Baltic Nations Are Not Ready for NATO
description: The United States today dashed the hopes of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania that the three Baltic nations would be among the first new NATO members drawn from Eastern Europe. Defense Secretary William J. Perry said after a meeting of NATO defense ministers here that the three nations were ''not ready'' for inclusion in the Western military alliance.

title: At U.N., Speakers Line Up to Criticize Israel
description: In the first major United Nations debate on Israeli relations with the Palestinians since 1992, the Security Council today heard a succession of speakers go beyond condemnation of the violence in the West Bank and Gaza to general criticism of the policies of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. His Government was accused of stalling peace efforts while allowing tensions to build.

title: Microsoft Forecasts That Its Performance for Year May Weaken
description: The Microsoft Corporation warned yesterday that operating margins might narrow in the 1997 fiscal year from levels a year ago because of slower revenue growth and higher operating expenses.

title: The Gay G.O.P.
description: Anyone who can't picture a same-sex marriage should turn to the new issue of Boston Magazine, which tells the happy story of two men who live together openly in the horsy suburb of Ipswich, where they raise two children in domestic peace, without frightening either the neighbors or the horses. The tale is told in a profile of the couple's famous half: Arthur J. Finkelstein, the legendary G.O.P. political consultant best known to New Yorkers for masterminding the campaigns of Al D'Amato and, most recently, Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Hard Times for Arts School
description: For 114 years, the Newark School of Fine and Industrial Arts has taught high school graduates how to make a living as illustrators and designers. But now, administrators said, the school has a $220,000 deficit, its 33 part-time teachers are working without pay and its enrollment has dropped to 75 students, a quarter of what it was last year. When the state took over the Newark schools in 1995, officials decided that the public school budget would be limited to kindergarten through 12th grade, said Joseph Placide, a spokesman for the Newark public schools. The arts school has been unable to find another source of money, said Elaine Sopko, the school's administrator. The school considered suspending classes, but relented when the students and teachers objected, she said.

title: Beating Victim Longs for 'Control of My Life'
description: Some mornings after everyone else has left for work, Shane Daniels slips behind the wheel of his car and dreams about being on his own again, free to drive himself anywhere he wants to go.

title: Bridge
description: The Pro-Am format, in which players who make substantial contributions are supplied with expert partners, is particularly well adapted to charity bridge events. One such, played Wednesday night at the Parker Meridien Hotel, 118 West 57th Street, raised about $30,000 for the Israel Cancer Research Fund.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: It has been a long week for the student body of Snyder High School, which lost a team captain, Tahid Ramsey, to a football-related death last Tuesday.

title: INNKEEPERS USA TRUST TO BUY RESIDENCE INN HOTELS
description: Innkeepers USA Trust said yesterday that it would buy nine Residence Inn Hotels for about $132 million. Innkeepers, a real estate investment trust, said seven of the nine hotels would be acquired as a package for $110 million from partnerships controlled by Jack DeBoer, the founder of the Residence Inn brand. Mr. DeBoer will serve on Innkeepers' board. Innkeepers, based in Palm Beach, Fla., will acquire the Residence Inn in Portland, Me., for $6.2 million in cash and operating partnership units from Marriott International Inc. The company said it would pay about $18 million for the ninth hotel, which is in Atlanta. Marriott International will manage the hotels.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Deal Reached To Replenish S.&L. Fund
description: Breaking a long stalemate, the Clinton Administration and Republican leaders in Congress have reached agreement on a legislative package to replenish the insurance fund that guarantees deposits at savings and loans. But the carefully balanced deal remained at risk as insurance agents, intent on other parts of the bill, mounted a last-minute effort to win concessions that could undo the legislation.

title: In His Own Words
description: JACK KEMP

title: Argentina Stops for a Day as Millions Strike
description: In the largest demonstration against the economic policies of President Carlos Saul Menem since he took office seven years ago, striking labor unions and a disgruntled public brought Argentina to a near standstill today.

title: Lions Sign Top Pick
description: The Detroit Lions yesterday signed guard JEFF HARTINGS, the last National Football League first-round draft choice to come to terms. Terms were not disclosed, but published reports said Hartings signed a five-year, $5.25 million contract. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Jewish High Holy Days misstated the number of commandments in the Torah. It is 613.

title: Armenia Opposition Urges Resistance to 'Unelected' President
description: With key parts of the capital in a tight military grip for a second day, the underground leader of Armenia's opposition urged followers today to put up quiet resistance, calling the Government an ''illegal power'' that stole this week's presidential elections.

title: Robberies Near Penn Stir Fears
description: A rash of armed robberies of students on the streets surrounding the University of Pennsylvania campus has shaken students and prompted college officials to beef up security at the Philadelphia campus.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTERN RESOURCES INC., Topeka, Kan., said its Westar Security unit had acquired Safeguard Alarms Inc. in another move to expand in the Kansas City market. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Inquiry Into Shackling
description: When a fight broke out after a church service on Sept. 15 at the Essex County Youth Detention Facility, Joe Clark, the director, ordered 12 of the youths shackled for two and a half days, he acknowledged yesterday. ''It's time for us to step up and hold juveniles who are 16, 17 and 18 accountable for their actions,'' Mr. Clark, the former high school principal who inspired the film ''Lean on Me,'' said yesterday. But Mr. Clark's tough brand of discipline, which he said followed a series of violent episodes, has prompted an investigation by the state's Division of Youth and Family Services. Wendi Patella, an agency spokeswoman, said the shackling of minors for extended periods is prohibited.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Florida Firm Of Bribing Brokers in Scheme
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused a Florida firm of paying $477,580 in bribes to seven brokers as part of what it called a stock-promoting scheme that netted $2.6 million in illegal profits.

title: SANDOZ TO SELL UNIT IN THE U.S. TO BASF
description: Sandoz A.G. of Switzerland said yesterday that it planned to sell its North American corn herbicide business to the German chemical maker BASF A.G. for $778 million. The Swiss company said the sale was planned in response to demands by United States antitrust authorities looking into its $22 billion merger with Ciba-Geigy A.G. If the merger between Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy is approved, BASF will pay Sandoz $695 million in cash. It will pay an additional $83 million for net working capital tied up in the unit. The business sold is expected to generate $320 million in sales this year, it said.

title: A New Human Frontier
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Cash Flows Freely In Spite of 'No PAC' Pledges
description: In a Congress where the campaign fund-raising season is in high gear, a handful of lawmakers portray themselves as purer than the rest because they refuse to accept donations from political action committees, long criticized as sources of big money from groups wanting to exert influence.

title: Campus Skeptics Unite Against Aggressive Faith
description: Could it be that in America, where millions of schoolchildren pledge allegiance daily to a ''nation under God,'' it is becoming ever harder to be publicly skeptical about religion? Put another way, are the mid-1990's a lonely time to be an atheist?

title: A Tongue-Lashing Is Offered by Reeves
description: If the Giants lose to the Minnesota Vikings on Sunday, it will not be because of a lack of effort by the coaches, especially the head one. Dan Reeves has worked extremely hard this week to keep the team focused and motivated.

title: Kemp Leads G.O.P. Charge in California
description: Jack Kemp began a busy four-day campaign swing through California today, part of what aides sought to portray as an intensive effort to put President Clinton on the defensive in a critical electoral battleground.

title: Israel's Flight From Real Peace
description: How hard it is to create something new in this world, and how easy to destroy it. It took only a few hours to demolish the delicate web of relations that had been woven between Palestinians and Israelis after 100 years of animosity. Of what was the web made? Of the most abstract things: war fatigue, a lot of good will on both sides and, especially, the maturity and readiness of some great leaders, who were able to rise above their fears and rebel against their own mentalities.

title: School of the Dictators
description: Americans can now read for themselves some of the noxious lessons the United States Army taught to thousands of Latin American military and police officers at the School of the Americas during the 1980's. A training manual recently released by the Pentagon recommended interrogation techniques like torture, execution, blackmail and arresting the relatives of those being questioned.

title: Empire Goes Private
description: The surprise announcement this week by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield that it would convert to a for-profit health insurer seemed to mark the end of its historic role as a nonprofit protector of New York's sickest and poorest individuals -- the people other insurers try to shun. In truth, that role ended earlier this year when a new state law kicked in that requires every managed care plan, not just Empire's, to enroll chronically ill applicants. Another law, passed this year, ends Empire's discounts for hospital fees.

title: Judge's Query On Drug Test Clears a Name
description: When the tennis star Vitas Gerulaitis was found dead in a pool house on a Southampton estate two years ago, the authorities first tested his body for illegal drugs but found none, a medical examiner testified today.

title: Rise of the Religious Right
description: Television appearances notwithstanding, the Christian Coalition did not spring full-blown out of the head of Ralph Reed. ''With God on Our Side,'' a spirited account of the rise of the religious right in recent decades, leaves no doubt of evangelical Christianity's deep roots and abiding power in American life. Paid for by foundations of both the right and left, the six-hour documentary, which begins tomorrow on Channel 13 in New York, is not out to score points but to explore the tangled terrain where religion and politics converge.

title: Dole 'Listens to America,' And Hears Press Criticism
description: When Bob Dole arrived on Thursday here in Dade County, the population center of a state his aides believe he must win but where polls show him trailing, he made only a single campaign stop, for a 42-minute question-and-answer forum at a huge and gritty warehouse in the northwest corner of Miami.

title: Colombians Attribute Cali Crash to Pilot Error
description: The Colombian Government said today that the crash of an American Airlines jet that flew into a mountain near Cali in December resulted from pilot errors. But the Government also called for new cockpit instruments and for changes in navigation charts and computer software that it said would help prevent another accident.

title: COLLEGTE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES

title: Limits on U.S. Leverage: The Needs of Both Sides
description: The armed clashes between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian police officers, which have deeply shaken assumptions about lasting peace in the Middle East, have also shaken the Clinton Administration, which was looking for a quiet life in foreign policy until the Presidential election.

title: School Chief Disagrees With Giuliani, Agreeably
description: As he prepares to mark his first year as Schools Chancellor next month, Rudy Crew can point to at least one accomplishment that eluded his predecessor, Ramon C. Cortines: he has managed to disagree with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in public and private and -- so far -- emerge unscathed.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: Algerians In Paris As City and Country Mice
description: Merzak Allouache's film ''Salut Cousin!'' finds a delightfully zany image of cultural collision in the spectacle of an Algerian rap singer from the slums of Paris reciting the fables of La Fontaine to a slamming hip-hop beat. Mok (Mess Hattou), the would-be rap star who finds himself booed off a nightclub stage, is an irrepressible dreamer and pathological liar recklessly intent on severing his ties to the past and reinventing himself in the big city.

title: Phillips Settles Lawsuit
description: Lawrence Phillips has settled a lawsuit filed against him by Katherine Ann McEwen, a former girlfriend, whom he allegedly abused last year while both attended the University of Nebraska, the Kansas City Star has reported.

title: Meteors and Numbers That Count (Maybe)
description: To the Editor:

title: Alabama Voters Battle Impulses
description: As the Presidential election approaches, voters in Alabama and throughout the South are struggling to sort out conflicting impulses.

title: Post-Surgery, Isringhausen Looks Ahead To Next Year
description: Within hours of undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his throwing arm, Jason Isringhausen was in uniform in the Mets' dugout eager to watch batting practice. ''I'm bored,'' he said.

title: INSIDE
description: False Hope for Hungary

title: Stretching Boundaries to Honor a Diva
description: Let's be clear from the start: for over 30 years Marilyn Horne has been one of the most important artists of our time. There are many appropriate ways to acknowledge this great mezzo-soprano as she enters the last phase of her career. But inviting her to be the guest for a concert on Wednesday night that opened the 28th season of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall is not one of them.

title: Monk Through Another Man's Piano
description: Thelonious Monk's compositions remain the most eccentric of etudes. Their internal rhythms make them skitter away as pianists play them; they offer sometimes perversely minimal themes but then open up into bridge sections that are unexpectedly gorgeous vistas. They're so prevalent now as to be indigenous American objects; several among his catalogue of around 70 tunes have, in fact, been done to death.

title: Does Art Change Things? Or People?
description: Can the arts save the world?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7

title: Harold L. Tinker, 99, Choate Master With a Passion for Books
description: Harold L. Tinker, a revered Choate School English master who spent a good part of his life collecting rare first editions and an even better part giving them away, died on Sept. 21 at his home in West Tisbury, Mass. He was 99 and had maintained his home on Martha's Vineyard for 60 years.

title: A Voice From Past Is Raised in Anger
description: On most mornings, Zhao Ziyang, now 77, his hair completely white, strolls around his elegant courtyard home a few blocks from the Forbidden City like a prisoner stalking the perimeter of his confinement.

title: For Canadians, Is U.S. Gaze Friendly?
description: A hearing before a United States Congressional committee this week that bluntly assessed what a breakup of Canada would mean for the United States attracted little attention in Washington. But it reverberated loudly here, leaving many Canadians either flattered by the attention or resentful of outside interference.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend yesterday about ''Two Days in the Valley,'' a comic film noir on life in the San Fernando Valley, misidentified the female character in the cemetery. She is Audrey, played by Marsha Mason, not Evelyn, played by Louise Fletcher.

title: Family Income Finally Rises
description: The upbeat report by the Census Bureau this week on family incomes and poverty showed that the recovery is finally raising living standards for American families, rich and poor. Income of the typical household rose by almost 3 percent last year, the largest increase in a decade. For the typical black family, income last year was $3,000 higher than in 1992. Poverty rates fell, with the percentage of blacks in poverty, 29.3 percent, falling to its lowest level since data were first collected in 1959. Child poverty fell faster than in any year since the mid-1970's. Even the nation's stubbornly high level of inequality fell more last year than in any year since the late 1960's.

title: A Commercial Tale
description: When the Rangers play the Devils at the Meadowlands tonight, the Ranger announcers on the Madison Square Garden network will read commercials selling Devils tickets.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday, describing a dispute among principals of a ''vulture fund'' that invested in distressed companies, referred incorrectly to the company whose bonds figured in the dispute. The company, Bucyrus-Erie, now known as Bucyrus International, filed for bankruptcy protection in February 1994 and emerged from bankruptcy later that year. It did not go bankrupt in 1988.

title: Redskins' Revival Can Be a Lesson to Jets
description: One team was 6-10, the other 3-13 in 1994. Then they reversed roles; one was 3-13, the other 6-10 in 1995.

title: Mr. Gingrich's Troubles Deepen
description: A House ethics committee that had appeared paralyzed by partisan bickering has taken a startling step in its long-stalled investigation of Speaker Newt Gingrich. The committee of five Republicans and five Democrats voted unanimously to broaden its inquiry, adding four new charges against Mr. Gingrich. These include two new tax issues, the question of whether Mr. Gingrich improperly used the staff and facilities of a private foundation and, potentially most damaging, the question of whether Mr. Gingrich has lied to the committee.

title: For an Old-Time Vamp, Black Latex
description: Olivier Assayas's sardonic ''Irma Vep'' is dimly about Louis Feuillade's silent film serial ''Vampires,'' featuring an actress named Musidora as a plumpish cat burglar scampering across Paris rooftops in skin-tight black. Inspired by this Irma Vep (whose name is an anagram for vampire), a fading New Wave auteur named Rene Vidal (Jean-Pierre Leaud) contrives an hommage.

title: CABLETRON SYSTEMS SET TO PURCHASE NETLINK
description: Cabletron Systems Inc., based in Rochester, N.H., said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Netlink Inc. for about $158 million in stock. The Netlink acquisition will complement Cabletron's primary business of linking computers within a single building or campus by giving it a new line of frame-relay systems that link remote offices with corporate headquarters. Cabletron said it would issue 2.26 million shares for Netlink. Cabletron's shares fell $1.625 yesterday, to $68.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Frame-relay technology allows companies to link far-flung computers at high speeds using the conventional telephone system. It is less expensive than leasing dedicated lines and faster than using dial-up modems.

title: New Charges Against Coach
description: A soccer and softball coach, arrested last month on charges that he sexually assaulted two young girls, was accused yesterday of molesting four more girls between the ages of 8 and 13 and of transmitting pornographic pictures on the Internet, prosecutors said. The coach, Richard Gibbs, 45, who was a volunteer at the Medford Youth Athletic Association, apparently videotaped some girls at the nude beach at Sandy Hook, said Sgt. Jack Smith, a spokesman for the Burlington County Prosecutor's office. About 500 pornographic pictures were found in a computer taken from Mr. Gibbs's home, Sergeant Smith said.

title: Alcoa Cuts 2,900 Jobs, As Expected
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by about 4 percent, cutting 2,900 jobs.

title: Workfare Effects
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Orders a Stay on New F.C.C. Telephone Regulations
description: A Federal court ordered a stay on new Government telephone regulations yesterday so that the GTE Corporation and other local phone companies could present oral arguments against the rules.

title: KODAK AGREES TO BUY AMERICAN STORES' PHOTO GEAR
description: The Eastman Kodak Company agreed yesterday to buy the American Stores Company's photofinishing equipment and run the big retailer's 3 film-development plants and 175 one-hour photo labs. Financial terms were not disclosed. The purchase adds to Kodak's expanding stable of photo labs while giving American Stores, the operator of Acme Markets and Jewel Food Stores, the means to bring high-tech equipment into its labs. Under the agreement, Kodak's Qualex Inc. unit has the right to provide photofinishing services for 10 years to all American Stores, one of the largest food and drugstore operators in the United States. American Stores is based in Salt Lake City.

title: Meteors and Numbers That Count (Maybe)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sitcom, Upscale And Latin
description: ABC's ''Common Law'' is the kind of sitcom that you sense is disappearing even as you watch it. It's not bad. There's a giggle or two to be had. But it's tired. The concept, that is. And that's a shame, because the star, Greg Giraldo, a Dennis Miller look-alike, is a talented stand-up comedian. Furthermore, he's Hispanic, the kind of American who sorely needs more exposure on prime time.

title: Lone Protest Against Braves
description: Saban Brown was the only person to show up today for a demonstration he organized against the naming of Centennial Olympic Stadium for Ted Turner, owner of the Braves.

title: Islanders, Poor on Offense, Decide to Pay Up for Palffy
description: Mike Milbury will be the first to tell you that he had all the leverage; he just didn't have any offense.

title: MetroStars Lose; Must Play Third Game
description: The MetroStars found themselves on the defensive tonight and suffered a 1-0 loss to D.C. United at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium before a festive crowd of 21,242 that created an electrifying World Cup atmosphere.

title: Labor Leader Drops Demand On Workfare
description: The head of New York City's largest municipal union agreed yesterday to drop his demand that the city stop expanding its workfare program in exchange for a pledge by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to consider hiring an unspecified number of welfare workers as city employees.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish harvest festival, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Kings Skip Arbitration
description: The Sacramento Kings said yesterday they have withdrawn from an international arbitration proceeding in London over their first-round draft choice, PREDRAG STOJAKOVIC.

title: New Charges For Man Held In Abduction Of His Son
description: Federal charges were dropped yesterday in Bridgeport, Conn., against Leonard Alfred Cammalleri, the Bronx man accused of abducting his own son 12 years ago, so that the State of Connecticut can try him on kidnapping charges.

title: The Ideal
description: Exotic, androgynous, seasoned, bejeweled: What will beauty look like in 2096? Several leading photographers present their vision.

title: Bettina Slusar, Daniel Goldman
description: Bettina Anne Slusar, a daughter of Patricia Sharp Slusar and Richard J. Slusar of Chatham, Mass., was married last evening in Seaside, Fla., to Daniel Lawrence Goldman, the son of Vivian L. Eveloff and Dr. Arnold M. Goldman, both of St. Louis. The Rev. Harry Houseman, a United Methodist pastor, performed the ceremony with Cantor Lawrence Goldberg at the Seaside Pavilion.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: New Releases
description: NEW EDITION: 'HOME AGAIN'

title: Sneakers Aloft May Show Humiliation or Drug Site
description: To The Editor:

title: Writer Falls for a Bed and There Lies a Story
description: ON her 25th wedding anniversary, during a vacation in California, Stephanie Mittman found ''the marriage bed.''

title: Critics Take Aim at Al Gore Over Former Tobacco Farm
description: Since his impassioned remarks at the Democratic convention about his sister, Nancy, who died of lung cancer in 1984, Vice President Al Gore has been shadowed by questions about his former ownership of a tobacco farm in his home state of Tennessee.

title: After 300 Years, Lenape Return to Sandy Hook
description: The Lenape did not live in teepees, wear feather headdresses or fish at the shore in summertime. Those are just a few of the myths that the descendants of New Jersey's predominant Indian tribe hope to dispel with a Lenapehoking Festival at Sandy Hook next weekend.

title: Even Allies Astonished At Spending On Museum
description: As controller of this modest-size city, Jim McCarthy is expected to review public expenditures with a sharp eye, which is why he became alarmed when aides told him last year that the Mayor had bought a $35,000 cannon.

title: A Jim Crow Sperm Bank?
description: While I was not happy to read the report alleging that Floyd C. Kim- ble is soliciting donations to his Foundation for the Continuity of Mankind only from Caucasians,'' I was more than mildly amused to find that artists also need not apply (Sunday: A Jim Crow Sperm Bank?'' Sept. 1).

title: Country Tranquillity Convenient to City
description: IN 1923 there were 22 estates in what is now the Village of Brookville. Many of them were broken up after World War II, but the area has retained its quiet elegance with zoning that bans commercial development and requires at least two acres for residential property.

title: In This Race, Abinanti Takes on Spano, as in David vs. Goliath
description: THIS is the year and he is the person who can defeat State Senator Nicholas A. Spano. That is what Thomas J. Abinanti, a tenacious County Legislator from Greenburgh, thinks about his chances against the apparently entrenched incumbent who is also chairman of the Westchester County Republican Committee.

title: Fraternity Reigns
description: Our long, hesitant, painful recovery, over the last five decades, from the breakdown of democratic institutions during the Dark Years (2014-2044) has changed our political vocabulary, as well as our sense of the relation between the moral order and the economic order. Just as 20th-century Americans had trouble imagining how their pre-Civil War ancestors could have stomached slavery, so we at the end of the 21st century have trouble imagining how our great-grandparents could have legally permitted a C.E.O. to get 20 times more than her lowest-paid employees. We cannot understand how Americans a hundred years ago could have tolerated the horrific contrast between a childhood spent in the suburbs and one spent in the ghettos. Such inequalities seem to us evident moral abominations, but the vast majority of our ancestors took them to be regrettable necessities.

title: Mediocre Teaching Doesn't Warrant Better Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Landmarks' Guardians Trying to Put a Price on Tackniess
description: With its parade of plastic signs, roll-down metal gates and loud, oversize canopies, West Eighth Street hardly looks like a model of architectural excellence. But obscured beneath the flashy neon and cheap signs is a 19th-century streetscape of proud Greek Revival town houses and classically detailed apartment buildings, all of which are part of the Greenwich Village Historic District.

title: Rabbi's Service to Police Extended to the Auxiliary
description: To The Editor:

title: 3 Candidates Wage Tough Campaign in Drive to Become San Juan's 2d Female Mayor
description: Zipping in and out of buildings with supporters and musicians in tow, Sila M. Calderon, a mayoral candidate, hugged and kissed Nancy Rivera in a recent dizzying campaign walk around the Luis Llorens Torres housing project here.

title: The Old Left
description: DIRECT ACTION

title: Vote in Washington On Sterling Forest
description: The House of Representatives voted yesterday for legislation on parks and public lands that includes money to preserve Sterling Forest from development.

title: Where's the Toga?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: LECTURE

title: Textbooks Indispensable? Not if Teaching Is Creative
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dream Is Poisoned by Mercury
description: Matt Schley, a printmaker who helped recruit fellow artists to buy an old factory here and convert it to SoHo-style lofts, has some advice for others with the same idea: ''Find out the history of that building. On your own.''

title: The Commute
description: Mass transportation in the New York region carries nearly half of all American commuters. Granted, the technology has not always lived up to the challenge. In 1863, New Yorkers were still being hauled along congested avenues in horse-drawn omnibuses and streetcars while Londoners were hopping onto their newfangled subways. But, according to transportation experts, the future of mass transit in New York looks positively avant-garde.

title: The True Terror Is in the Card
description: Although the United States continues to have the broadest protection of free speech, the fewest restrictions on gun ownership and the least Government involvement in business, health care and social welfare of the Western democracies, a small but significant percentage of our population believes that the nation is well on its way to totalitarianism. Some of these people believe that the Government (or the new world order) is on the verge of implanting the universal product code into the skin of every citizen -- if it has not already begun doing so. Your article has done a disservice by fueling such paranoid fantasies.

title: Bringing Dance and Opera to the Streets
description: THERE have been free dance recitals in Grand Central Terminal, at the gardens of Wave Hill and in the catacombs of the Brooklyn Bridge anchorage. Each site-specific work was created with grants through Dancing in the Streets, a group that continues this fall to bring dance out of the theater into communities. ''To us,'' said Kristen Smiarowski, a spokeswoman, ''it's all about the sense of the world as a stage.''

title: Perot Supporters Hope to Use Gains to Build Power Base in 2000
description: Eager to declare the Reform Party's independence from Ross Perot, its founder and primary financier, party officials from six states today formed a steering committee and authorized it to plan a national constitutional convention for next spring.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Primary Care Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: For Those Who Never Really Came of Age
description: LOVINGLY, Helene Reinhardt placed pots of yellow chrysanthemums beneath four of the 366 marble tablets that form a black border on the rim of the amphitheater of the New Jersey Vietnam Veterans Memorial, which opened last year on a grassy hill beside the Garden State Parkway in Holmdel.

title: Where Machinists Can Get Training
description: Regarding the lead article (''The New World of (Skilled) Factory Jobs,'' Sept. 15), I would like your readership to know that Macdac Engineering is pro-actively addressing the shortage of skilled machinists by offering, free of charge, training in off-line Computer Numerical Control (CNC) programming.

title: Southern Exposure
description: IN THE HEAT OF THE NIGHT (1967) is a stinging, racially tense drama about a Southern sheriff (Rod Steiger) and a Northern black police sleuth (Sidney Poitier) investigating the same murder case in a predominantly white powder key of a town in the deep South. The film's only flaw is the mystery itself - a not very intriguing puzzle, although the story pivots on it. The real power of the picture lies in the two performances, helped along with the nimble pacing of Norman Jewison. The initial antagonism between the two men festers unabated until the moment the murder is solved. It's the best scene in the Oscar-winning picture and says volumes. Quincy Jones's score adds ajaszzy edge - SATURDAY at 10:20 P.M. on TBS.

title: Whose Money? And Whose Problems?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebed Calls For Yeltsin To Transfer His Powers
description: In a bold challenge to President Boris N. Yeltsin, his security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, said today that the Russian leader's illness had left the nation adrift and suggested that he temporarily step down.

title: Southern Comfort
description: I was lucky enough to marry a man who introduced me to the simple culinary delights of his native South -- including Krispy Kreme. For the past six years, one benefit of visiting my in-laws in Birmingham, Ala., has been the guaranteed trip to Krispy Kreme for a dozen glazed.

title: And in This Corner
description: Workers often have unkind words for one another. Maybe they say something sarcastic or, more bluntly, call their offender a jerk. But sometimes disputes become more physical: pushing, shoving, even punching. Have you been involved in a fight at work or witnessed one? Send your story to: On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include a phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Catherine Chute, Hull P. Fulweiler
description: Catherine Ann Chute, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer H. Chute Jr. of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Hull Platt Fulweiler, a son of Mrs. Spencer B. Fulweiler of New York and the late Mr. Fulweiler. The Very Rev. Robert Wilshire, the Dean of the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, performed the ceremony there.

title: Building an Image on the Idea of Home
description: DIFFICULT SUMMER. BUT IT HELPED TO watch Twyla Tharp, on a borrowed stage, rehearse her new young company in a new young dance about a new young country. Called ''Sweet Fields,'' the dance is set to a score of early American religious music, including Shaker hymns and compositions by William Billings. Listening to ''Jordan,'' one of Billings's choral pieces, was more soothing than most country weekends. ''There is a land of pure delight, where saints immortal reign . . . Sweet fields beyond the swelling flood stand lasting, living, green.''

title: Space Film Works To Open Series
