description: THE Westchester Symphony breaks tradition this year by beginning its subscription season with a pops concert. Next Saturday night at 8 the ensemble's audience at Purchase College should be lifted out of this world by the fanfare from ''2001 -- a Space Odyssey'' (excerpted from ''Thus Spake Zarathustra'' by Richard Strauss), and they will also hear excerpts of scores by John Williams for two other motion pictures, ''Star Wars'' and ''E.T.,'' along with ''The Planets'' by Holst.

title: Scott Wins Twice on Fifth Avenue
description: The people who staged the Discover Card Mile on Fifth Avenue yesterday were excited because the favorites for their elite races were two of the world's most distinguished runners. Svetlana Masterkova of Russia had won two gold medals for women in this summer's Atlanta Olympics and Fermin Cacho of Spain had won the men's 1,500 meters in the 1992 Barcelona Olympics.

title: Gunman Robs and Kills Teen-Ager in Bronx Playground
description: This was the week when Rafael Sosa, 15, was going to turn his life around, his friends and family members said.

title: The Medicine Cabinet
description: Never mind gene therapy and robotic spinal-cord microsurgery. Some of the real miracles of 21st-century medicine, pharmaceutical experts say, will be found in your medicine cabinet.

title: Doing Our Homework
description: The Schools We Need And Why We Don't Have Them.

title: From Rap's Rhythms, a Retooling of Poetry
description: Even before the slaying of Tupac Shakur this month, the generation inspired by rap had started an intense self-appraisal. Its soul-searching has led it, increasingly, to rap's precursor, street poetry, and has given rise to the ''spoken word'' movement, which has been quietly evolving for several years in clubs, cafes and workshops.

title: Scores Count
description: Johnson's methods are correct. A teaching-to-the-test approach is nothing short of basic common sense for kids who, without help, are apt to perform poorly on important standardized tests. These are the kids who can least afford touchyfeely experimentation.

title: Buchwald in Paris
description: To the Editor: I was reading The Times here in Dallas, and I came across the article about living in Paris. The part about the bread amused me. The part about Ann touched me. I thought, I will write this man a fan letter -- my first! But then I saw that this man was Art Buchwald, who is famous!

title: After Victory Comes 'Dirty' Politics
description: Had the Black Panthers, the N.A.A.C.P. and Martin Luther King Jr. known what Charles Barron knows now, he says, they would have been more successful in their battles against racism.

title: When a Magazine Is Too Brash for the Bottom Line
description: AS Kurt Andersen remembers it, he was having fruit and cereal last February in the private dining room of the 42d-floor office where Henry R. Kravis runs his leveraged-buyout firm. Mr. Andersen, who was then editor in chief of New York magazine, says Mr. Kravis's breakfast message was clear: Consider killing a story about the rivalry between Felix G. Rohatyn and Steven Rattner, two of Wall Street's most powerful investment bankers.

title: Weirdness Makes Sense
description: If the next Einstein were born today, what might he or she be doing in the year 2022, having reached the age, 26, at which Einstein formulated the theory of relativity?

title: Presidential Portraits, Painted in Sound
description: DETAILS of politicians' pri vate lives noble and profane, true and less so -- tend to surface at election time. The beginning of one vignette, from 1914, sounds hopelessly dated: ''When the last distinguished guest had departed, the President asked me to take the harp and go with him to the rear portico of the White House.''

title: All in the Family
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Simpson Again, Race Again
description: AS jury selection in O.J. Simpson's civil trial continued last week, the focus swung inexorably back to race -- this time because Mr. Simpson's lawyers accused their opponents of systematically trying to exclude black people from the pool of potential jurors.

title: Renoir's Paradise, And Those Who Loved It
description: TO MARK THE 75TH anniversary of its opening in September 1921, the Phillips Collection in Washington has organized a kind of birthday party. Presiding over it is ''Luncheon of the Boating Party'' by Pierre Auguste Renoir, which the museum considers its single most important holding.

title: The Artificial Womb Is Born
description: ''One by one the eggs were transferred from their test-tubes to the larger containers; deftly the peritoneal lining was slit, the morula dropped into place, the saline solution poured . . . and already the bottle had passed on through an opening in the wall, slowly on into the Social Predestination Room.'' Aldous Huxley, ''Brave New World''

title: Mechanic Who Restores The Class to Classic Cars
description: WHEN Ralph Lauren needs one of his many classic cars refurbished, he joins a caravan of aficionados who travel to this Cape Ann community on Boston's North Shore seeking Paul Russell.

title: For Rural Japanese, Death Doesn't Break Family Ties
description: Bursting through the unlocked front door of his friend's house, Saio Akita turned left into the living room and bypassed other family members to chat with his buddy, offer him a drink, and ask for some help.

title: Junior Comes Out Perfect
description: The pace and extent of the genetic revolution makes it tempting to speculate about life at the end of the 21st century. Will sex become completely recreational, with the serious business of reproduction going on in carefully monitored tubes? Will the main form of medical treatment consist of gene therapy, designed to replace defective DNA at the squeeze of a syringe?

title: A Space Module For Planet Earth
description: WHEN it comes to to skiing, I am a flailer and a stomper. Not really what you'd call smooth on the slopes. And the reason I confess it now is that I've returned from the Camelback ski area near Tannersville, Pa., the place where I first realized my incapacity on the boards, and the visit took me back.

title: Future Stock
description: I assume that the year 2096 will look nothing as it does in the movies; the planet will not be a desert teeming with ugly men with warts on their faces who chase after Mel Gibson in go-carts. I assume also that both capitalism and democracy will spread, and that investments will return profits and losses to capitalists in much the same way as they do today. I assume, finally, that the reader knows that I know how deeply dislikable people are who go around telling other people what is going to happen in the stock market 100 years from now, mainly because there is no loss in being wrong and no gain in being right. If 100 years ago some Wall Street stock jobber had picked up the Dow Jones industrial average (which first appeared on May 26, 1896) and insisted that the Dow's biggest sector -- farming -- would, in 1996, give way to aerospace, retail and oil and chemicals companies, he would have been thought an idle speculator. In the markets, as in life, the very long term is irrelevant.

title: Race I Over
description: Even though error, chance and ambition are at the nub of the human future, I am fairly sure that race, as we currently obsess over it, will cease to mean as much 100 years from today. The reasons are basic -- some technological, others cultural. We all know that electronic media have broken down many barriers, that they were even central to the fall of the Soviet Union because satellite dishes made it impossible for the Government to control images and ideas about life outside the country. People there began to realize how far behind they were from the rest of the modern world. The international flow of images and information will continue to make for a greater and greater swirl of influences. It will increasingly change life on the globe and also change our American sense of race.

title: Pools, Tennis, Clubs and Now, a Child-Care Center
description: SELF-CONTAINED residential developments that offer pools, tennis, clubhouses and other shared amenities that are operated by a condominium or a homeowners' association have become quite commonplace.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Corrections
description: The On the Map column last Sunday, about the Canal Society of New Jersey, misstated its phone number. It is (908) 722-9556.

title: Bradley Is Looking For Business
description: FAIRFIELD COUNTY residents accustomed to using LaGuardia, Kennedy or Newark airports are being asked to consider an alternative that most probably thought made no sense: Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, about 20 minutes north of Hartford.

title: This Ticket No Longer Costs $1 Million
description: TOP institutional money-management firms are moving into the retail mutual fund market. Investors who previously needed $1 million to participate can now buy into institutional funds through discount brokers for as little as $1,000.

title: Andrea Ribaudo, Gregory J. Millard
description: Andrea Elizabeth Ribaudo, the daughter of Mrs. Frank Gavel and the stepdaughter of Mr. Gavel of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory James Millard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. Millard of Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Edward Scull performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn.

title: New Releases
description: CURTIS MAYFIELD: 'NEW WORLD ORDER'

title: Organically Yours
description: IF you look closely at Janit London's T-shirt, you'll notice that the purple dragon in the logo is wearing sunglasses. She got the dragon from a meditation program; as for the purple, ''Well, you know, everything was purple this, purple that in the 60's and 70's.'' Why sunglasses? She thought about it and replied with a laugh, ''We wanted it to be cool.''

title: THE STATES AND CONGRESS
description: Texas

title: Ambition, in Words and Images
description: The glamour and grit of the city -- as captured by writers and by visual artists -- were celebrated Thursday evening in a double-barreled event, titled ''NYNY: City of Ambition.'' First came the literary part, a reading of fiction and poetry that expresses the dreams, hopes and ambitions that New York inspires. At Symphony Space on 95th Street and Broadway, actors who were born and bred in New York -- Mia Dillon, David Margulies, Isaiah Sheffer and Tamara Tunie -- read from writers spanning the years from F. Scott Fitzgerald to Toni Morrison. (Excerpts from three of the selections are below.)

title: When the Jets Throw in Brady's Direction, Will He Catch It?
description: And now for something different tonight: Kyle Brady as a part of the Jets' attack.

title: The Whiz Kid
description: The Living and the DeadRobert McNamara and Five Lives of a Lost War.By Paul Hendrickson.Illustrated. 427 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.

title: The Stadium Is Safer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How Palestinian Policemen Were Drawn Into the Conflict
description: The fence between Egypt and the Gaza Strip had been torn aside by hundreds of angry demonstrators by the time Zahir, a Palestinian policeman, got his orders on Thursday to try to push all the Palestinian civilians away from the border.

title: Shuttle Bus Connects Liberty Science Center
description: A free shuttle bus service now links the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City with public transportation. The bus takes visitors to and from the Grove Street PATH station and the Colgate Center ferry landing.

title: Separate but Equal
description: BOYS THEMSELVES

title: Motor Mouth From London, With a Brain Attached
description: DOES HUMOR TRANSLATE? DO Americans laugh at what the British find funny? Consider ''Monty Python's Flying Circus,'' a British comedy troupe whose long-running television show was a hit in Britain and on PBS in the United States.

title: Sarah Seaman, H.H. Simmons
description: Sarah Warren Seaman, a daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Warren M. Seaman Jr., was married last evening to Huntington Hardwick Simmons, a son of Sarah B. Simmons of New Canaan, Conn., and Hardwick Simmons of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. George G. Toole officiated at the Towson (Md.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Community Wins Incinerator Fight
description: Effectively capping a heated two-year community fight, an energy company has announced that it will not build a power generator in East New York, even though the proposed project had the necessary permits from the city and was deemed relatively safe for the environment.

title: The Urban Landscape
description: Fantasies about the city of tomorrow are invariably rendered in terms of material reality - mile-high skyscrapers, atomatic elevators, people flying about with jet packs. But suppose the city of the future has nothing at all to do with reality as we now understand it? Suppose that reality ahs been supplanted by fantasy itself?

title: Inflation Is Coming! Inflation Isn't Coming! Bond Shoppers Can Decide
description: ECONOMISTS are excited about them, tax accountants may make a fortune from them, and Government officials say they are good -- and good for you, Average American Investors. But are the new ''inflation-protection bonds'' Washington announced last week really a great new development, or the investment version of the Susan B. Anthony dollar?

title: Dreaming of a Nightclub Where All the Drinks Are Soft
description: ''At one point I was driving around with a nightclub in my back seat packed with coffee pots, cups, snacks, lights, P.A. equipment, etc.,'' she writes in the same article. ''Not to mention six cases of soda that froze and blew up all over my trunk.''

title: Bad Poets Society
description: To the Editor:

title: New Releases
description: JOHN PARISH AND POLLY JEAN HARVEY: 'DANCE HALL AT LOUSE POINT'

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Banish You, My Deer?

title: Isolated Area Fears It Will Become More So
description: When the 3.8-mile, concrete-and-steel snake of roaring traffic known as the Gowanus Expressway was completed in 1941, Red Hook was largely cut off from the rest of Brooklyn, causing what is considered one of the major reasons for the area's decline.

title: Dialing for Dollars, With Competing Flat-Rate Plans
description: AT&T introduced a flat-rate calling plan last week amid much fanfare. Under the program, customers can make a long-distance call anywhere in the country, at any time of the day, for 15 cents a minute.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Chamber Music Promotes Loyalty
description: FRIENDS OF MUSIC, a chamber music organization in its 43d season here, accentuates the positive side of graying audiences. While the nonprofit group worries along with other music lovers about the future of live classical music, its members say the present holds some saving graces.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WESTPORT ARTISTS

title: A Canada Goose Tale Told by Americans
description: THE SCREENING OF Carroll Ballard's ''Fly Away Home'' on Sept. 6, the day after its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival, was a typically low-key, quintessentially Canadian affair. The fund-raiser for Operation Migration, an organization set up by the conservationist Bill Lishman in behalf of endangered species worldwide, was held in a modest 280-seat theater here, an hour east of Toronto.

title: Safir to Shift at Least 500 Desk Officers to Patrols
description: To reverse a recent drop in patrol strength, the New York City Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, said he planned to shift at least 500 officers to street patrol from desk duty.

title: Mary Alice Schweitzer, S.E. Canaday
description: Mary Alice Schweitzer, a daughter of Alice and Fritz Schweitzer of Darien, Conn., and Siesel Edmonson Canaday 3d, the son of Katherine Canaday of Bronxville, N.Y., and Mr. Canaday Jr. of Old Lyme, Conn., were married on Wednesday. Judge Mark D. Fox officiated at Federal District Court in White Plains.

title: Goes to Show, You Can't Keep Good Geese Down
description: The Leopard Son

title: High Is Low
description: At one moment in ''The Shawshank Redemption,'' the hero, played by Tim Robbins, takes over the sound system of the jail in which he's being held. He puts on a record of Mozart, flooding the prison with a duet from ''The Marriage of Figaro.'' The other inmates freeze as the music hits them, their dulled faces transfigured. We're meant to understand that Robbins's good taste is a sign of his innocence, that by bringing high art to his fellow prisoners, he has allowed them to glimpse the long-forgotten country of their own possible redemption.

title: The True Terror Is in the Card
description: As I read Robert Ellis Smith's article on Government-issued ID cards, I remembered growing up in the 1950's and how, in the movies, you always knew when the hero was in a bad place because some fellow would demand to see his papers (The True Terror Is in the Card, Sept. 8). The thought of how close our country may come to being like one of those places is sad. How can we find our way back?

title: Violence Ebbs, Uneasily, in West Bank
description: A tense quiet settled over the West Bank and Gaza Strip today as the Palestinian police sought to prevent new fighting and American mediators pursued intensive efforts to arrange a meeting between the leaders of Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Corrections
description: A film listing on Sept. 8 misidentified the director of ''To Gillian on Her 37th Birthday,'' which is to open in October. He is Michael Pressman; David E. Kelley wrote the screenplay and was a producer.

title: The Pet
description: Outwitted by your microwave? Just wait: tomorrow's home appliances will be even more complicated and their buttons even tinier. What you'll want is a second pair of hands a very small pair of hands. What you'll want is a squirrel monkey.

title: A Partnership to Rebuild Downtown Englewood
description: A generation ago, Armory Street was a solid, middle-class neighborhood just a few steps away from downtown Englewood. Over time, the street deteriorated until it was considered one of the worst streets not just in Englewood, but in all of Bergen County, because of its dreary auto repair shops and drug dens.

title: Great, Sure. But How Great?
description: Can his slender, 35-year-old body endure 82 regular-season games and up to 28 more in the playoffs? Does he dance away from hard collisions as nimbly as he used to? Has he lost the power on his shot? Is that why his goal totals have dropped from 92 in 1981-82 to 54 in 1988-89 to 23 last season?

title: Rebel With a Cause
description: A Desperate Passion

title: Elizabeth Hitchins, Leonard Quigley
description: Elizabeth Katharine Hitchins, the daughter of Nancy Collier Hitchins of Charlotte, N.C., and Charles R. Hitchins of Chicago, was married yesterday to Leonard Matthew Quigley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard V. Quigley of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Raymond D. Scott performed the ceremony at the Myers Park Presbyterian Church in Charlotte.

title: The Kitchen
description: When Martha Stewart thinks Kitchen of the Future, she thinks Einstein: ''Everything should be made as simple as possible, but not simpler.''

title: . . . Is Wall Street's Nightmare
description: IN the financial markets, as in election years, there have been more than a few October surprises, although they do not necessarily have political overtones. The worst recent surprise, of course, came in 1987 when the stock market crashed. That month ended with the Dow Jones industrial average down 23.2 percent, and investors in shock.

title: Deciding What Modern Is
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York defines itself as an ''everything'' museum, covering every region of the world and every period of artistic creation. But in Europe, where major museums are government-owned and given to specialization, the distribution of national treasures requires that museums define periods of art in ways that at times seem arbitrary.

title: Buchwald in Paris
description: To the Editor: The Paris essay was moving and very touching. Since my husband died five years ago, I've also found it extremely painful to revisit some of the cities that the two of us enjoyed together. Paris, of course, is one of them.

title: A Sports Talkfest That Is Still Going Strong
description: LATE one hot night last month, four sportswriters repaired to an Atlanta restaurant for a relaxing post-Olympics dinner. As Mike Lupica of the New York Daily News tells it, they got into an argument and by the time they had finished there was a small audience crowding their table.

title: Peace Prevails
description: In the Buddhist tradition, the future counts for little. Nonetheless, when Tenzin Gyatso, 14th Dalai Lama and the spiritual and temporal leader of Tibet in exile, was asked to speculate on the landscape of faith a century from now, he gave it his best try. He was interviewed in Bloomington, Ind., on a brilliant summer morning, after having laid the cornerstone for a new Buddhist temple.

title: The Honor of Being Present At a Poet's Acts of Creation
description: To the Editor:

title: Leni Wylliams, 35, Dancer and Teacher
description: Leni Wylliams, a modern dancer, teacher and Emmy Award-winning choreographer, was found slain on Sept. 13 in his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 35.

title: Huge Western Wildfires Spur Debate on Controls
description: IF Western sunsets and sunrises seemed suspiciously spectacular this summer, there was a reason. Feeding the orange glow, tons of nitrogen were released into the atmosphere by the worst wildfire season in three decades.

title: When the Forecast Says Snow
description: The Old Farmer's Almanac is predicting a snowy winter, with several major storms. What do you suggest to prepare for this prospect?

title: To Higher Ground in Israel
description: Besieged by the violent conflict surging around them last week, Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat have understandably staked out unyielding positions that leave little range for the conciliatory steps required to end the crisis. Both the Israeli Prime Minister and the Palestinian leader need urgently to move to higher ground. The issue before them is no longer simply the particulars of this fight, and who should blink first, but what is best for the future of Israelis and Palestinians.

title: The Brave New Face Of Art From The East
description: ''CONTEMPORARY ART IN INDIA? THERE IS NO contemporary art in India.'' So an academic friend tartly reminded me a few years ago. How could an avant-garde art exist anywhere in the ''timeless'' cultures of what we monolithically call Asia? If it did, it couldn't be any good. Too Western. Or too Asian. Or too little of one or the other.

title: What's Up, Doc?
description: REWRITESA Memoir.By Neil Simon.Illustrated. 397 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Kenya's Leader Keeps Rivals at Bay
description: With an election looming next year, Kenya's opposition parties are splintered and crippled by infighting, unable to unite behind a single candidate or agree on an agenda with which to challenge President Daniel arap Moi, who has governed for 16 years.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DARKEST ENGLAND

title: Biscuits and Breads With the Texture and Flavor of Corn
description: THIS summer's crop of fresh sweet corn will soon be a memory. With the arrival of fall, it is time to think about corn the way earlier generations did, as a storage grain for milling into meal or flour, extending its shelf life for use in winter.

title: Dining in TriBeCa Among Friends
description: ARQUA **

title: Foul Territory
description: THE baseball season ends today, and the New York Yankees have limped to the division championship. But for one fan, at least -- me, a compulsive Yankee-o-phile for the last 36 years -- it is something of a Pyrrhic victory, not without its thrill but not without a concomitant desolation.

title: Confronting the Specter of Breast Cancer
description: A Distinct Grace

title: Disciplinarian Is Not Sorry For Shackling
description: JOE CLARK was explaining not apologizing, mind you, but ever so patiently explaining -- why he shackled 12 detainees at the Essex County Youth House to their beds for two and a half days.

title: The Metal Detector: Tales From School
description: IT was 7:45 A.M. and the lobby of Martin Luther King Jr. High School had the look of a courthouse, or perhaps an airport full of teen-age travelers lugging Jansports instead of Samsonites. Reluctantly, students dropped their book bags and knapsacks onto X-ray machine conveyor belts, and walked with long faces through tall, door-frame-like metal detectors.

title: Swallowing Bitter Pills for Pay: The Trials of Guinea Pigs
description: LAST November, Adam Schumacher, a junior at the University of Connecticut at Storrs, stumbled into the campus infirmary with a sore throat and found himself with a job offer. If he would use a new gargle on his throat for just an hour, the company sponsoring the test would not only cover his medical bills, but also pay him $50 for his trouble.

title: Explorers Offer the World to the Classroom
description: THE Help Wanted advertisement read ''Three explorers to travel from Venice to Hong Kong fall 1996. Must speak Russian, Chinese or Turkish, enjoy working with children and computers. Will travel five months with GlobaLearn team, a New Haven educational nonprofit organization.''

title: A Historied Time Inc. Editor to Step Down
description: James R. Gaines, who spent 20 years at Time Inc., announced his decision yesterday to step down from the company, where he was the first to serve as managing editor of three magazines: Time, Life and People.

title: Eventful Start For the Fall
description: Honors and charity abound in the worlds of medicine, the arts, antiques and fashion.

title: Is Clinton One? Was Nixon?
description: HOW do you stump a liberal?

title: Liz's Love Life! Oprah's Diet! Dole's Foreign Policy!
description: THEY did it again.

title: Raising a Voice for the Victims of Crime
description: THE victims' rights movement in Connecticut is at a critical point in its evolution says Mario T. Gaboury, director of the Center for the Study of Crime Victims' Rights, Remedies and Resources at the University of New Haven where he is also an associate professor criminal justice.

title: What the Public Had to Say About the Arts Master Plan
description: Being an artist in New Jersey, Ruth Wyand is familiar with the Biblical saying that a prophet is not without honor except in his own country and among his own people.

title: A New Market Focus: The Not-Quite-Retired
description: THE buyers of homes in communities that are designed for older adults have often left full-time employment behind them. But a surprising number of these buyers shrink from describing themselves as retired. They think of themselves as semiretired, or partially retired. They may be ready to downsize their housing, but they still do some work, often for pay.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE

title: At the Casinos
description: Correction Appended

title: It's Autumn, the Time to Appreciate the the Chrysanthemum
description: TO EVERY flower there is a season. At this time of year, what could be more glorious than the chrysanthemum?

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Sept. 8 about new hotels in Puerto Rico misstated the rates for an introductory package at the Westin Rio Mar Beach Resort and Country Club. The package, which was available until last Thursday, ranged from $385 a person for three nights to $1,055 for seven nights, based on double occupancy.

title: Seles and Davenport Give U.S. the Edge
description: The boardwalk was not exactly abuzz. Sure, someone was handing out free tickets to something called the Fed Cup, but nobody could recall a slot machine by that name.

title: Sarah Kunhardt And Tom Horton
description: Sarah Kunhardt, a daughter of Katharine and Philip B. Kunhardt Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Tom Horton, a son of Eva Horton of Portland, Me., and Donald Horton of Saco, Me. The Rev. Philip B. Kunhardt 3d, a brother of the bride who is an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony on the farm of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Cochran in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Mistakes Abound, but Columbia Finds Itself at 2-0
description: Columbia beat Fordham, 17-10, yesterday to accomplish a feat the Lions last achieved 18 years ago: beginning a football season with two victories.

title: Corrections
description: The Vows column and its headline in the Styles pages last Sunday, about the wedding of Bethany Yarrow and Sebastian Gross Ossa, referred to the bridegroom incorrectly. His surname is Gross; Ossa is his maternal family name, in the Hispanic custom.

title: High Is Low
description: At one moment in ''The Shawshank Redemption,'' the hero, played by Tim Robbins, takes over the sound system of the jail in which he's being held. He puts on a record of Mozart, flooding the prison with a duet from ''The Marriage of Figaro.'' The other inmates freeze as the music hits them, their dulled faces transfigured. We're meant to understand that Robbins's good taste is a sign of his innocence, that by bringing high art to his fellow prisoners, he has allowed them to glimpse the long-forgotten country of their own possible redemption.

title: Julia Kuskin and Joel Ian Bell
description: FOR the last seven years, Julia Kuskin, now 31, and Joel Ian Bell, 32, have been part of a clan of siblings and stepsiblings that was created when her mother, Karla Kuskin, married his father, William L. Bell Jr.

title: Jets Better From Afar
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Scores Count
description: Michael A. Johnson, the founder and principal of the Science Skills Center, may ruffle the feathers of liberal educational reformers, but he has the essential qualities of a good teacher (Scores Count,by Sara Mosle, Sept. 8). He cares about his students and wants them to succeed. Apparently, they do.

title: Republicans Are in Position To Pick Up Seats in South
description: When Jesse Helms first ran for the Senate here in 1972, there were only five Republican Senators from the South.

title: Body Guards
description: SANTA EVITABy Tomas Eloy Martinez.Translated by Helen Lane.371 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: New Releases
description: NATALIE COLE: 'STARDUST'

title: Lisa F. Henricksson, James P. Kelly
description: Lisa Fleming Henricksson, an executive editor at GQ magazine, and James Patrick Kelly, the deputy managing editor of Time magazine, both in Manhattan, are to be married this evening at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx. Judge Barbara S. Jones of Federal District Court in Manhattan is to officiate.

title: Temporary Jobs: Putting Your Foot in the Door
description: AS a reporter in the mid-70's, I covered the open-space education fad, in which the absence of classroom walls was supposed to facilitate self-directed study over rote lectures. In practice, the reason for open-space schools had less to do with radical education theory than simple economics. As one superintendent explained, ''It's cheaper to construct than the usual egg-crate building.''

title: Muslim Rebels Overrun Kabul
description: It took nearly a decade to dislodge the Soviet Army from Afghanistan and three more years to oust the government Moscow had installed, but only three days to complete the Islamic revolution.

title: Rams Start Green
description: The St. Louis Rams decided against an all-rookie backfield today at Arizona, starting HAROLD GREEN at tailback ahead of LAWRENCE PHILLIPS. Phillips has been slowed in practice by a sore knee this week, and Coach RICH BROOKS also wanted at least one veteran in the backfield to help quarterback TONY BANKS. (AP)

title: Correction
description: A report in the Postings column on Sept. 15 about a new map of the Upper West Side misstated the phone number for the Identity Map Company. It is (212) 627-1994.

title: Elizabeth Rosenberg, Jonathan Child
description: Elizabeth Rosenberg, a daughter of Ellen Y. and Dr. Jerry M. Rosenberg of Riverdale, the Bronx, is to be married today to Jonathan Kendrick Child, the son of Lenore Hall and Kendrick H. Child, both of Derry, N.H. Rabbi Allan L. Smith is to perform the ceremony at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Fall Foliage
description: To the Editor: Thank you for including Vermont in your recent fall foliage information line listings (Travel Advisory, Sept. 8). While the (802) 828-3239 number you listed certainly provides lodging and foliage information, we highly encourage your readers also to try our (800) 837-6668 number. New Yorkers can also tap the local number we have set up for foliage information, (212) 244-0130.

title: Stock Options
description: As westerns go, THE RARE BREED (1966) is an easy going, leathery film with a plot that makes it something of a novelty. At the center is Maureen O'Hara as a beautiful British woman, newly arrived in America with a prize bull for breeding. In some family-style mix-ups she is drawn to a rich rancher (Brian Keith) and his former associate (James Stewart). The story unwinds with a nice sense of atmosphere and human foibles. Miss O'Hara brings zest to her part and gets help from Ben Johnson and Juliet Mills as her daughter. The last reel is the best, with the men openly vying for both the bull and its fiery owner. Stewart is his customary first-rate self, but the picture is stolen by Mr. Keith, whose sly shenanigans are hard to resist - SATURDAY at 10:30 P.M. on FAMILY CHANNEL.

title: Looking Forward, Looking Back
description: On its 80th birthday in September 1931, The New York Times asked ''scientists and leaders in other fields of experiment'' to envision the world after another 80 years, in 2011. The very first of their forecasts bombed. The United States population would reach 160 million by 2011, said William F. Ogburn, chairman of the President's Commission on Social Trends. In fact, it reached 260 million in 1994, and by 2011 it might well be 320 million, twice what he predicted. Still, considering the perils of prophecy, those scientists and leaders didn't do badly.

title: Old Brahms a Modernist? In More Ways Than One
description: Michael P. Steinberg, a professor of history at Cornell University, is the author of ''The Meaning of the Salzburg Festival.''

title: With Its Back to the Wall, Hampton Drives to Victory
description: The last time Hampton University and Virginia State met, in 1994, Hampton won in a rout, 44-19. Tonight at Giants Stadium it was Hampton that appeared to be in trouble. But a time-consuming, 84-yard drive that culminated in a 2-yard touchdown run by Tyrone Mayer with three minutes left in the game gave the Pirates a 14-10 victory in the Whitney M. Young Memorial Classic.

title: Nicholas Colchester, 49, a Briton Who Was a Top Financial Editor
description: Nicholas Colchester, a prominent British financial journalist, died Wednesday in New York. He was 49.

title: Letting the Viewer Create the Image
description: To the Editor:

title: His Future Unknown, Clemens Tips Cap
description: Roger Clemens handed the ball to Kevin Kennedy, scooped up some dirt from the mound at Fenway Park and began what might have been his last walk back to the dugout as a Red Sox pitcher. The 33,612 spectators howled wildly for their icon, so Clemens waved his cap to them, maybe waved goodbye to a career here, and disappeared.

title: Telemarketing: What Happens If the Phones Stop Ringing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Phyllis Griffin, Howard Epps
description: Phyllis Andrea Griffin, the daughter of Janice Ford Griffin of Boston and Houston and Dr. George E. Griffin, also of Houston, was married last evening to Dr. Howard Robert Epps, a son of Dr. Roselyn Payne Epps and Dr. Charles H. Epps Jr. of Washington. The Rev. Robert E. Hayes Jr. officiated at the West University United Methodist Church in Houston.

title: The Clothes
description: From a carbon-fiber T-shirt to a water-resistant spray: What to wear in 2096.

title: Will All Pupils on L.I. Read by the Third Grade?
description: THE first graders sat on the carpet in front of their desks, facing Nancy Leiderman, their teacher, who stood at an easel that displayed a giant book.

title: The Etiquette Lesson
description: As long as there are humans and solid food, there will be dentists and dentists' offices; as long as there are dentists' offices, there will be fidgety children in waiting rooms absorbing gentle lessons in politeness from Goofus and Gallant of Highlights for Children magazine. . . .

title: It's Autumn, Time for the Chrysanthemums
description: TO every flower there is a season. At this time of year what could be more glorious than the chrysanthemum?

title: Tomorrow Never Knows
description: More than a decade ago, when we published ''The Experts Speak,'' Christopher Cerf and I did not claim that the experts were always wrong in predicting the future. It was just that in our work we had never uncovered any accurate predictions. However, our critics have argued persuasively (we are nothing if not humble) that some prognosticators are right as much as half the time. Hence our conclusion: Prediction is at best an unpredictable business.

title: What Do Mozart and Metallica Have in Common? They Shared a Stage, Sort Of
description: For years, music lovers have headed to Holmdel for concerts even though things keep changing: the performers, the ticket prices and even the name of the concert center (now the PNC Bank Arts Center, formerly the Garden State Arts Center). Here's a random sampling.

title: Caitlin Meehan and Thomas Villante
description: Caitlin Anastasia Meehan, a daughter of Catherine and John Meehan of Tarzana, Calif., was married yesterday to Thomas Joseph Villante, the son of Marilyn and Carmelo Villante of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Dogali performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: PALIMPSEST: A Memoir

title: Quo Lingua?
description: A century hence, our 69th President (assuming nobody will get re-elected) will take the inaugural oath and begin his address, ''Fellow countrymen and women. . . . ''

title: Lydia Frank, Henry Schober
description: Lydia Worl Frank, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Doyle W. Frank of Blairstown, N.J., was married yesterday to Henry Xavier Schober, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Schober of Trumbull, Conn. The Rev. Joseph P. Fallon performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Trumbull.

title: William Rivera and Tara Koslov
description: Tara Isa Koslov and William Alvarado Rivera, both lawyers in Washington, were married there last evening at the Mexican Cultural Institute. . Anthony J. Girandola, a lawyer who is also an Episcopal priest, performed the civil ceremony.

title: At Universal It's Only a Movie
description: ''HOW wet do you want to get?'' asked the guide. ''Very,'' said my 19-year-old daughter. ''Then sit in the front row.'' The big wooden doors -- proclaiming JURASSIC PARK -- swung slowly open like jaws, and we floated inside.

title: Carolyn Clark, David Patterson
description: Carolyn Whitney Clark, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglass W. Clark Jr. of Gloversville, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Seccomb Patterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Patterson of New York. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Welcome to Loser Town, U.S.A.
description: This is a city that loves its losers to death, that grows fat and sassy at tables of rotten stats. What a joy to wake up this morning knowing that our two professional football teams, whatever they do, will still be losers by nightfall. Send a valentine to Shea Stadium; the Mets are lovable again. You can act as cold as you want this winter, the Nets are going nowhere with their new coach, the Knicks are going nowhere with their new players and the Rangers will be presenting the Ice Follies version of grumpy old men.

title: God Is in the Details
description: DON'T CALL IT NIGHTBy Amos Oz.Translated by Nicholas de Lange.199 pp. New York:Harcourt Brace & Company. $22.

title: Young, Charismatic, Catholic
description: From afar, the religious rally at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park seemed like any other outdoor gospel concert. About 150 gathered to hold hands, shake tambourines and erupt with praiseful shouts of ''Hallelujah!'' But at a closer look, there were some incongruities. For one, the music was in Spanish, and the worshipers were mostly Hispanic teen-agers. And while their emotional outpouring seemed akin to a Pentecostal sect, they were in fact Roman Catholic.

title: Laurisa Shappell, Charles Schutt 3d
description: Laurisa Juliette Shappell, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Shappell of Smithtown, L.I., was married last evening to Charles Porter Schutt 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Schutt Jr. of Chadds Ford, Pa. Cantor Ronald Broden officiated at the East Hampton Point, a restaurant and marina in East Hampton, L.I., The Rev. Brenda S. Overfield, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: It's a Wonderful, Uh, Town?
description: Funny, the Statue of Liberty wasn't that close to downtown before. Then again, it didn't have a head before -- not this one, anyway. This statue, part of the New York-New York Hotel and Casino ($460 million, 2,035 rooms, in case you're counting) in Las Vegas, just got its head screwed on on Thursday. The torch arrives next month. (Associated Press)

title: A Tougher Welfare Stance
description: Gov. George E. Pataki plans to renew his push for strict time limits on Home Relief, the state-financed cash assistance program for the poor. Page 39.

title: Sneakers Aloft May Show Humiliation or Drug Site
description: To The Editor:

title: Elizabeth Cook, Douglas Harmon
description: Elizabeth Grace Cook, the marketing manager in the special events department at the New York Public Library, was married yesterday to Douglas Pringle Harmon, a senior vice president at Greenwich Capital Markets in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Richard Murdoch performed the ceremony at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Witness the Madness on Madison
description: The sidewalks of Madison Avenue from 57th to 72d Streets have always been quietly elegant, smattered with Park Avenue matrons who would stroll up and down, dressed in tweed suits and Belgian shoes.

title: Miss Brennan, Mr. MacGregor
description: Jennifer Marie Brennan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Brennan of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to Murdoch Malcolm MacGregor 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. MacGregor Jr., also of Wilton. The Rev. George A. Gallarelli performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church with the Rev. David J. Graybill, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Dole, in Choosing Kemp, Buried A Bitter Past Rooted in Doctrine
description: Even in an age of politics by autobiography, Bob Dole is to an unusual extent running for President on the strength of his own history -- his Dust Bowl upbringing, his sacrifices in World War II, his memories, as he said in his acceptance speech, of ''an America only the unknowing call myth.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SARAH'S PSALM

title: Stacey J. Stern, Bradley S. Albert
description: Stacey Jill Stern, the daughter of Gail and Stanley Stern of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Bradley Scott Albert, a son of Audrey and Kenneth Albert of Pittsford, N.Y. Rabbi Barry H. Greene performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J.

title: In Rhode Island, House Tours by Boat
description: Tourgoers will have a choice of visiting waterfront homes by boat or car during the Rose Island Lighthouse Foundation's Columbus Day Weekend of Home Tours in Newport, R.I.

title: Why Lilco Hopes for a Takeover
description: AROUND the world -- in Western economies, in the former East bloc nations and in developing countries -- government-owned utilities are being sold to private investors. So it should give us pause that the only serious proposal for any government to buy an electric company is right here on Long Island -- the Long Island Lighting Company. Just why is Lilco the only investor-owned electric utility on earth that wants a government takeover?

title: Moscow on the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: When 'Star Trek' Grows Stale: Where to Go to See Real Galaxies
description: THE best way to find out what's going on at New Jersey's major observatories is to call the astronomy clubs affiliated with them.

title: Lawyers In the Temple
description: THE 800 lawyers and media honchos attending the fifth anniversary party for Court TV on Tuesday were so intent on exercising their First Amendment rights that they wouldn't stop talking.

title: A Tree Grows in . . .
description: Most city streets are trimmed with fire hydrants, telephone poles, street lamps and trees -- about half a million of them. Recently, the city Department of Parks and Recreation completed a census of the trees on the city's streets (the survey did not include the city's parks). With the help of 700 volunteers, the department sought out, indentified and counted every tree on each of New York City's 33,278 blocks. Here are some of the preliminary results.

title: Helping Shoplifters to Reform
description: WHEN Linda B., a Long Island college student, took a $20 bottle of cologne from a local department store, she never thought she would be arrested and hauled off in handcuffs. And she never imagined that, a few weeks later, she would be sitting in a classroom with 20 other shoplifters, trying to figure out why she had done it and how she could avoid doing it again.

title: Abstract Works to Catch the Adult Eye
description: THOUGH still in its infancy, the Benny Smith Gallery here has scored with a show that is nothing if not adult. It consists of works -- mostly on paper -- by four established artists, Vincent Baldassano, Rosemary Cove, Bill McGee and Knox Martin, and was organized by a fifth, Martee Levi, who is on her way up.

title: Clinton Sets New Rules on Deadbeat Parents
description: Keeping up his campaign of low-cost efforts to address durable social ills, President Clinton today ordered Federal agencies to take steps to deny Government loans to parents who are delinquent in child support, and to streamline the system for withholding other payments -- like tax refunds -- from such parents.

title: In Alabama, Fairways To Paradise
description: AFTER a long, snowy winter, I decided the time had come to realize one of my golfing dreams: to play the Robert Trent Jones Golf Trail in Alabama. Scattered across the state from the Appalachian foothills to the Gulf of Mexico, the trail consists of seven separate golf complexes, each offering either 27 or 36 championship holes, plus a so-called ''short'' course of either 9 or 18 holes.

title: Hans Busch, 82, Stage Director Of the Indiana University Opera
description: Hans Peter Busch, a stage director of opera who was associated with the Indiana University Opera Theater for 32 years, died on Sept. 17 at Bloomington Hospital in Indiana. He was 82.

title: Ailsa C. Veit And Adam Foulke
description: Ailsa Christine Veit, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter R. Veit of Charleston, S.C., was married yesterday to Adam Wood Foulke, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Foulke Jr. of Bedford, N.Y. The Right Rev. J. Clark Grew, the Episcopal Bishop of Ohio and a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Charleston.

title: Art, but for Whose Sake?
description: IN their Dreamtime cosmology, the Aborigines of Australia believe that long ago the land was featureless and lifeless and then their spirit ancestors created the world. Aborigine songs chronicle the events of the Dreaming, and their rock art celebrates the spirits and the life they created.

title: Big Brother Is Us
description: For much of the 20th century, 1984 was a year that belonged to the future -- a strange, gray future at that. Then it slid painlessly into the past, like any other year. Big Brother arrived and settled in, though not at all in the way George Orwell had imagined.

title: In Howell Township, 17 Years of Standing Up for His Beliefs
description: If abortion protest groups gave attendance awards, Dominick Cutaia would be a contender.

title: A Benefit Recital for Musicians in Sarajevo
description: SEVERAL months ago, members of the South Shore Festival galvanized support for the Sarajevo Philharmonic, replacing seven of the woodwind instruments that had been destroyed during the recent war.

title: Kathleen Laico, Marc C. Antonetti
description: Kathleen McNamee Laico, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Laico of New City, N.Y., is to be married today to Marc Christopher Antonetti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Antonetti of Orange, Conn. The Rev. John Keaveney is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Boniface in Wesley Hills, N.Y.

title: W. 22d St. Warehouse to Become a Condo
description: At the western edge of Chelsea workmen on scaffolding are steaming off the sooty dirt and scraping away the painted ''T'' on the Tower's Warehouse on a 19th-century industrial building at 525 West 22d Street. But not all traces of the building's industrial past will be erased during its transformation from warehouse into condominium apartment building and gallery space.

title: In His Own Words
description: BILL CLINTON

title: 'Give Back to Your Community,' She Said
description: As a Cuban-American, a nursing teacher and a mother of two sons, Campo's article touched me on various levels. I will share his article with my sons so that they can understand the emotional and professional struggles of another Hispanic person.

title: Worthy of a Mention, if Not a Rating
description: FROM time to time we visit a restaurant that has a a terrific soup, a knockout dessert or a romantic atmosphere. For other reasons, however, the place did not warrant a full review. Here we present the results of a few of our recent such forays.

title: A Memorial Fit For a Film Maker
description: ''A Who's Who in Art at Island Cemetery'' $(Sept. 15$) completed my effort, Stan Vanderbeek's desire to be buried in the Green River Cemetery in Springs.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE PRESIDENTIAL ARCHIVEBy John Griffiths.Carroll & Graf, $23.

title: Afghan Restaurant Offers Exotica for Frugal
description: THRIFTY diners, determined to get their money's worth, should take note of the proliferation of Afghani restaurants. Although their increasing numbers do not constitute an invasion, few areas of Nassau and Suffolk are now without one of these bargain-basement storefront spots.

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: Despite the best efforts of linguists, therapists and anthropologists, men and women are still in a muddle.

title: As Dole Sits by Pool in Florida, He May Look Relaxed, but His Aides Say He's Working Hard
description: For the last couple of days, the public view of Bob Dole has been of a man tanning by the pool, a man who looks as if he were on vacation, even though he has less than six weeks to surge from behind to beat Bill Clinton on Election Day.

title: The Road to a Secure Peace
description: This week was to have been a time of joy and festivities for Israelis. Many pilgrims will visit Jerusalem, our capital, in the same way that our ancestors did for millenniums. But this year there was to be something special: an ancient aqueduct, today a tunnel, built by the Hasmonean Kings and rediscovered by archeologists some 150 years ago, was recently opened along the Temple Mount. This tunnel was intended not only to connect Jews with their glorious past but to allow four times as many international visitors to visit the area, bringing a much-needed influx of revenue to merchants in the old city's Muslim and Christian sectors. But instead of festivities, a series of tragic confrontations swept Israel and the Palestinian autonomous areas.

title: The Altered State
description: More than a hundred years ago, physicists tried to stimulate the neurons with direct electric current. It didn't work, and it hurt. Experiments with magnets followed; by the late 1980's, scientists realized the key was rapidly pulsing the current on and off. Recently, Dr. Michael Persinger, a psychologist and neuroscientist at Laurentian University in Ontario, has been experimenting with solenoids, which create gently fluctuating fields at intensities lower than those of, say, a blow-dryer. His electromagnetic device is still experimental and unwieldy, but it may by the year 2096 be simple enough for home use a few AA-battery-size solenoids hidden in a compact headset.

title: Babe Ruth Didn't Call That Homer, And Other Revisions of the Canon
description: BIG league baseball players have become an almost pitiable cliche: remote, haughty millionaires making the rounds of the better drug rehabilitation centers and selling their scribbled names for as much as they can get. Beat it, kid!

title: Tour and 2 Seminars: Buying and Repairs
description: The brownstone comes under scrutiny next month with two seminars and a house tour.

title: County Budgets Feature Tax-Reduction Plans
description: REFLECTING a fair year for the regional economy, the Nassau and Suffolk County Executives are proposing budgets that leave further behind an era of fiscal crisis and express tempered optimism for 1997.

title: Corrections
description: The ''At the Casinos'' listing on page 16 of the New Jersey section today includes an outdated listing for ''Cabaret of Illusions'' at the Grand. It closes tonight after performances at 7 and 9 P.M.

title: A Sorry Sight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Course For Adults Addresses ay Issues
description: THE Scarsdale Adult School, established in 1938, was a ground breaker in offering classes to adults long before phrases like continuing education and lifelong learning were part of the general lexicon. This fall, in addition to more traditional offerings like computer programming, exercise classes and conversational French, the school is again staking new ground by offering a course that addresses the issue of homosexuality.

title: The Talk of the Town
description: CAN Seymour (Pinky) Kravitz save Atlantic City?

title: A New Incentive for Upstairs Housing Downtown
description: A $10-MILLION state program could help bring back housing over downtown stores, space that over the last four decades or so has been replaced by warehouse or office uses.

title: Biscuits and Breads With the Flavor of Corn
description: THIS summer's crop of fresh sweet corn will soon be a memory. With the arrival of fall, it is time to think about corn the way earlier generations did, as a storage grain for milling into meal or flour, extending its shelf life for winter.

title: A Time for Legends, Musicals and More
description: WHAT to consider in a new theater season of singularities?

title: Pataki Renews Call to Limit Home Relief
description: Concerned that cutbacks in Federal welfare benefits will place significant new strains on the state budget, Gov. George E. Pataki plans to renew his push for strict time limits on Home Relief, the state-financed cash assistance program for the poor.

title: House Passes Measure To Preserve Sterling Forest
description: After another round of bitter negotiations, the House of Representatives voted 404 to 4 tonight to pass legislation on parks and public lands that includes a provision to preserve Sterling Forest on the New York and New Jersey border from development.

title: A Wizard Who Saw A Future of Simplicity
description: THE IMPACT OF THE DESIGNER Joe Colombo on the Italian Modern movement of the 1960's was brief but decisive. His first design, a clear plastic arc of light called the Acrilica lamp, won a gold medal at Milan's Triennale in 1964. Two years later Colombo was described as Italy's most prolific and innovative designer.

title: America Remains No. 1
description: We imagine the past and create the future in its image. People in 1896 got much of the coming century wrong; we are unlikely to do much better. Here is how some of the operating myths of 1996 might collapse:

title: Hentgen and Brown Should Get Cy Youngs
description: The month of November is expected to feature more than one runaway election. Barring unexpected developments in the minds of the voters, the outcome of at least two elections could be known before the ballots are cast. Andy Pettitte of the Yankees and John Smoltz of the Atlanta Braves will win the Cy Young awards in their leagues.

title: Victims' Rights and Wrongs
description: The father of Polly Klaas stood up in a California courtroom last week and vented his rage at his daughter's killer. At the sentencing hearing, Marc Klaas said Richard Allen Davis should be condemned to Hitler's circle in hell. Then, after Mr. Davis outraged the courtroom by wildly accusing Mr. Klaas of molesting his daughter, Mr. Klaas lunged toward him and was taken outside. After such an ordeal, is there any juror or judge who would not have felt a large amount of sympathy for Mr. Klaas and his family?

title: On Promise Keepers, Don't Play to Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: In France, Leaders Brace For the Worst From Unions
description: President Jacques Chirac and his unpopular conservative Government hunkered down this week to face a second autumn of unrest over spending cuts that they insist are necessary even with unemployment at its highest level in nearly 50 years.

title: Enter Smiling, the Stylish Carolyn Bessette
description: Since her marriage last weekend to John F. Kennedy Jr., Carolyn Bessette has been breathlessly described as the beautiful and brainy new Queen of Camelot. Interviews with friends and former colleagues reveal a more recognizable young woman: a child of affluent suburbia, with less interest in academics than in downtown clubs, whose extraordinary looks, sophistication and ambition propelled her rapidly upward through the fashion industry in New York.

title: Dominican Villa: Where Quiet Rules
description: THERE are many quiet places on Long Island, but the Siena Spirituality Center in Water Mill seems to be a special one.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Valentine Says Met Workload Is Heavy
description: The past five weeks have been all about next year for Bobby Valentine. The victories and defeats since he replaced Dallas Green as the Mets manager on Aug. 26 have been secondary to Valentine's observation and evaluation of players, coaches and front-office personnel.

title: Princeton Gets Plenty Of Room To Roam
description: Princeton 37, Holy Cross 30

title: The Nanny Track: A Once-Simple World Grown Complicated
description: THE word ''nanny'' sounds simple -- two little syllables, pronounceable, more or less, by the average 2-year-old. But it comes loaded with complicated associations of class, history, money and love. It conjures up Mary Poppins and the English upper crust and sunny sylvan childhoods. To guilt-burdened modern parents, ''day care'' sounds institutional, ''baby sitter'' sounds young and ''care giver'' dry and emotionless. Nanny sounds warm and comforting, like a big hug.

title: Bank Courts the Very Rich in Westchester
description: LET me tell you about the very rich. They are different from you and me,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote. Ernest Hemingway rejoined, ''Yes, they have more money.''

title: Promising Trade-Off for the Needy
description: After 40 years of combating poverty in the obscurity of inner-city St. Louis, George Eberle Jr. now finds welfare experts from around the country knocking on his door.

title: New York in the Silents: An Un-Self-Conscious Star
description: IT IS HARD TO THINK OF New York, the city that never sleeps, in terms of silence. And yet the city has rarely revealed itself so outspokenly as it does in the assortment of 20 features and two programs of historic shorts that constitute ''The Silent City: New York in the Movies, 1898-1929.''

title: Jodi Kramer, Ross Sutherland
description: Jodi Kramer, a daughter of Madeline Kramer of New York and Robert S. Kramer of Dallas, was married last evening to Gordon Ross Sutherland, the son of K. Isla and R. Gordon Sutherland of Auckland, New Zealand. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony at the St. Regis Hotel in New York.

title: As Asthma Cases Rise, Tough Choices and Lessons
description: Six times in the last three months, Jeannine Starks has taken her 9-year-old son, Kevin, to the hospital because he was wheezing and coughing so wrenchingly from asthma that he needed emergency oxygen. Her 4-year-old daughter, Quenecia, has had asthma attacks that have landed her in the emergency room at 3 A.M.

title: Children Will Pay
description: The contours of national life in the next century will depend in no small part on the number and variety of Americans who are alive to shape it. Many of them are already living today,

title: On 'E.R.,' an M.D. Who's Only Human
description: ON A SCORCHINGLY HOT afternoon in the San Fernando Valley, Noah Wyle, with the air-conditioning in his comfortably appointed trailer cranked up full blast, is pondering his wardrobe.

title: Sara B. Leppo, Robert Savage Jr.
description: Sara Beth Leppo, the daughter of Elaine and Harold Leppo of Stamford, Conn., and Robert Francis Savage Jr., the son of Jeanne and Robert Savage of Villanova, Pa., were married last evening at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson officiated with the Rev. James W. Savage, a Roman Catholic priest, who is an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Suspending the Search For Washboard Abs
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the fall of Kabul, Afghanistan, referred incorrectly to the date of a photograph of former President Najibullah. It was taken before his overthrow in 1992, not last week.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Gene Mutation Rebuffs AIDS
description: The most common gene mutation in the white population is turning out to be a real wild card: It makes people resistant to the AIDS virus.

title: But Don't Sweat or Be Too Short
description: ONE week from today, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole will meet for the first Presidential debate of the season. The Dole campaign has all but conceded that Mr. Clinton has superior verbal skills. But Americans will not merely be listening to the two candidates but watching them stand side by side.

title: Torre Leads Yankees With Quiet Confidence
description: WHEN George M. Steinbrenner 3d, principal owner of the New York Yankees, brought the Brooklyn-bred Joe Torre back to New York last winter to manage the Yankees, the 56-year-old Torre asked Steinbrenner whether he should buy or rent a house.

title: French-Italian Fare That Hits the Mark
description: TEN years ago, Papa Marc would have been Continental. Today, this new Glen Cove restaurant calls its food European country cuisine. Its marquee reads authentic Italian and French. A peek at the menu and a taste of the complimentary bruschetta confirms Italy's top billing.

title: Bibi's Moment of Truth
description: There were many telling images from the latest tragic Israeli-Palestinian clashes, but none was more revealing than the first phone call Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made after the crisis exploded. He phoned Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, and asked him to calm things down. Not Yasir Arafat. Hosni Mubarak. Mr. Netanyahu indicated he would call Mr. Arafat only if it were necessary. Necessary? Necessary?

title: The Vatican Sanction
description: HIS HOLINESS

title: Did Apartheid's Police Murder Sweden's Prime Minister?
description: After days of grisly testimony on the atrocities committed by South Africa's apartheid police force, a former police colonel stunned a Pretoria court room last week when he mentioned, almost in passing, that South Africa was involved in the 1986 assassination of Swedish Prime Minister Olof Palme, who held strong anti-apartheid views.

title: On Promise Keepers, Don't Play to Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Danger In Drug World Is Spelled GHB
description: The drug is called liquid Ecstasy, liquid E, liquid X, GBH and perhaps most often, GHB. But by any other name it would still be gamma hydroxybutyric acid, a liquid depressant with anesthetic qualities. And its current popularity -- among club kids, ravers and Internet surfers who have added it to their illegal formulary of designer drugs like Ecstasy and Special K -- is just the latest stop in its unusual trajectory.

title: The I.R.A.'s Explosive Cache
description: Whenever the peace effort in Northern Ireland begins to inch forward, it is halted abruptly, often violently.

title: The Sneaker
description: The sneaker has been around for about a thousand years, since the first South American jungle denizen spread rubber-plant sap on his feet and created an artificial sole. Before another century passes, designers predict, the sneaker will have its own self-powered sole. The sneaker of the 21st century will be made of an inorganic, animated material wired with a flexible film, says Steven Smith, director of advanced design at Reebok. The film collects the energy generated by the motion of the foot and converts it into an energy source to power all the other functions of the shoe: preventing injury, enhancing weak or damaged parts of the foot and promoting overall peak performance from each tendon, ligament in fact, every atom.

title: Through a Lens Very, Very Darkly
description: THE NEW NOIRISH FILM ''Bound,'' an offbeat thriller about a pair of women who take on the mob, opens with a shot that can't help getting a viewer's attention. The camera slides down the interior of a closet with such dizzying speed that the closet is barely recognizable. The camera pans past shelves, shoe boxes, suits and dresses until it takes a quick horizontal turn to reveal a woman, tied up and lying on her side, illuminated by a sliver of light from under the door.

title: Goes to Show, You Can't Keep Good Geese Down
description: Giant

title: Stealing Third, The Shot of a Lifetime
description: To the Editor:

title: Planet Hayden
description: THE LOST GOSPEL OF THE EARTHA Call for Renewing Nature, Spirit, and Politics.By Tom Hayden.280 pp. San Francisco:Sierra Club Books. $22.

title: Armonk Art Show to Aid Library
description: EVERY autumn the leaves turn red and gold, but the colors of fall in Armonk also include the colors of artists' paintings, sculptures, photographs and crafts.

title: A Name That Can't Go Wrong
description: IT TOOK 16 years for the Playhouse Preservation Association, formed to restore the old Tappan Zee Playhouse in Nyack, to accomplish its mission of opening a new regional theater in Rockland County, N.Y. Last night, the theater finally opened, with a new name and even a new address.

title: Coming To Terms With Niagara
description: MY family and I were among the last few people to board the Maid of the Mist IV, one of four tour boats that sail up the Niagara River, past the base of the American Falls and into the U-shaped basin that gave Canada's Horseshoe Falls their name. We had begun our three-day visit to Niagara Falls on a Wednesday, hoping to avoid the weekend crowds, but July is prime viewing time, and the boat was already packed to the railings. The thin blue plastic ponchos stuck to our bare limbs like Saran Wrap as we squeezed our way through 300 other passengers decked out in the same silly outfits and shouting in several different languages.

title: Kent George Jr. and Nina Houghton
description: Nina Houghton, the daughter of Maisie and Jamie Houghton of Corning, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kent George Jr., a son of Mr. George of Wayland, Mass., and the late Patricia M. Gavin. The Rev. Jorge Gutierez performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Corning. The Rev. Alanson Houghton, an Episcopal priest who is an uncle of the bride, took part in the ceremony.

title: No Questions Remain About The Buckeyes
description: They were allegedly a mystery, even to themselves, an untested team that had amassed staggering results against powder-puff opponents. The Ohio State Buckeyes demonstrated today that they are far more than that. Their forceful 29-16 victory over Notre Dame was built upon a consistent control of the line of scrimmage, a strategic approach that at times took their opponent by surprise and a decisive advantage in the phases that the Irish value the most.

title: Maurice Valency, 93, Theatrical Master, Dies
description: Maurice Valency, playwright, author, critic and professor of drama, an erudite man of the theater best known for his adaptations of award-winning plays by Jean Giraudoux and Friedrich Duerrenmatt, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: College Opens a New Building For Its Child-Care Program
description: ONLY a few years ago, Erin Murphy's life looked bleak. A single mother of four children, Ms. Murphy was working at three separate jobs trying to support her family.

title: Tale of a Drug Lord Should Include Customers
description: To The Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Car Rentals in England

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: A 30's Building Where the Duplex Was King
description: DESIGNED by Rosario Candela and Mott Schmidt in the mid-1930's to have more duplexes than any other type of floor plan, the limestone building at 19 East 72d Street shows how the rich really are different -- or at least live that way. Now the building's co-op board is spending over $1 million to renovate the roof and the limestone.

title: The Future of Nostalgia
description: If there is nostalgia years from now, it won't be for us. People are not going to dress up as us or stage re-enactments of our wars or collect our cellular phones, our books on healing and empowerment, our CD's of Old Age music, our pepper grinders, our billions of T-shirts. They will resent what we did to the country, and we will go down in their history as the age of effluvia, with the simple moral: If you love trash too much, you will make yourself stupid.

title: My House for Sale? Yes. Maybe. No!
description: WE sat on our deck with friends on a hot day in late July, grateful to feel the ocean breeze on bare arms and legs. A couple of four-year-olds bicycled up the street. Behind them came a black BMW, not much faster. The speed limit here in Point Lookout is 15 miles an hour.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: In May, we booked travel arrangements on British Airways. Our travel to Barcelona was without incident but, upon check-in at Heathrow for the return we were confronted with a previously unknown policy on carry-on luggage.

title: Industry Partnership
description: To the Editor:

title: Marla Prather, Mortimer Zuckerman
description: Marla Prather, the curator and head of the 20th-Century Art Department at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and Mortimer Benjamin Zuckerman, the chairman and co-publisher of The Daily News in New York, were married on Friday evening in Washington. Associate Justice Stephen G. Breyer of the Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Decatur House, a museum.

title: Down by the Riverfront
description: THE best way to describe people's first impression of the Riverfront Cafe is to tell you about the Millburn couple who drove to the restaurant, took one look around and drove home.

title: Scores Count
description: The problem with Michael Johnson's approach is his overreliance on the New York State

title: A Head Man Quits News While Ahead
description: At tabloids like The Daily News, where headlines of five words or less often speak volumes, Len Valenti has a reputation as one of the all-time great headline writers.

title: Glennis G. Gill, John V. Swinson
description: Glennis Gene Gill, a daughter of Dr. Deena S. Gill of Warrensburg, N.Y., and Michael J. Gill of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to John Victor Swinson, the son of Margaret A. and Kevan V. Swinson of Brisbane, Australia. Rabbi Richard J. Sobel performed the ceremony at the chapel at Point O'Pines Camp, a summer camp for girls in Brant Lake, N.Y.

title: A Warm Economic Wind
description: On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve decided that the economy was purring along so well -- not too hot, not too cold -- that it would pass up its last chance to raise interest rates before the election.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: UNCERTAINTY

title: WASP Stings
description: A GOOD FAMILY

title: DIARY
description: INTEREST RATES

title: Youthful Pulchritude
description: To the Editor:

title: Inflation Bonds May Prove Hard To Sell
description: Inflation bonds are coming. Now the question is whether they will sell.

title: An Old Romance That Refuses to Rekindle
description: Michael Gambon is big not only in size, substance and voice, but also in his singular kind of destabilizing stage presence. There's an element of risk, and therefore of suspense, in everything he does. In this way he well serves David Hare's ''Skylight,'' now at the Royale Theater, where the Irish-born London stage icon is at long last making his Broadway debut. Mr. Gambon and Lia Williams, his co-star, are recreating the roles they originated in London last year in the Royal National Theater production, staged then as now by Richard Eyre, the National's director.

title: Florida Victory No Sure Thing For the G.O.P.
description: It was one of the more spirited strategic arguments within Bob Dole's campaign: Should he spend serious time and money fighting for Florida, where Republican nominees have prevailed in every Presidential election since 1980 but where he has been running behind, or should he husband his resources for the big Midwestern swing states and hope for the best here?

title: The Man at the End of the Bar
description: A SURVIVOR, maybe the survivor, of the days when millions of Americans tuned their radios to shows originating in hotels now speaks volumes from the bar of a Japanese hotel on Park Avenue.

title: When Grisly Horror Is a Family Value
description: TWELVE FRAMED ORIGINAL CARTOON drawings hang along an innocuous-looking corridor, the one that leads to the men's room on the third floor of the New York Public Library at 42d Street. Since 1992, this marbled alley has been called the Charles Addams Gallery and is the endowed site of a rotating exhibition of drawings by Charles Addams selected from the 116 that are owned by the library.

title: For T.W.A. Victims' Families, Frustration at Paris Meeting
description: In a closed conference hall that was tense with frustration, about 170 European and American relatives of the 230 victims of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 met for three hours today with the top American investigator of the disaster. But many came away saying they had learned little more about what brought down the Boeing 747 jetliner 10 weeks ago.

title: Follies
description: SUSPECTS

title: Deborah Newitter, Joshua Mikesell
description: Deborah Helen Newitter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Newitter Jr. of Rye Brook, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Joshua David Mikesell, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Phillip Mikesell of Crawfordsville, Ind. Rabbi Robert Rothman is to perform the ceremony at the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: An 8-Year Quest to Restore a Garden
description: LILLIAN WILLIS knew that restoring a garden would take more than just a hoe and a few plants. It would involve fund-raising, research and certainly other volunteers. It actually involved all those and more.

title: Whose Bills?
description: To the Editor:

title: Required Reading for Brown and O'Donnell
description: MEMO to Dave Brown and Neil O'Donnell:

title: One Man's October Surprise . . .
description: FROM a historical perspective, the biggest October surprise in this Presidential campaign could well be if there actually is one.

title: 'Angela's Ashes'
description: To the Editor:

title: Crossing the Threshold: Stone-Throwing Riots to an Armed Revolt
description: When Palestinian gunfire first rang out Wednesday during a stone-throwing clash with Israeli soldiers in the West Bank town of Ramallah, it transformed both sides.

title: Protesters Fight Traffic With Traffic
description: Marina Belski, Bensonhurst resident and victim of bad timing, could only sit and fume in her white two-door car Thursday morning as she watched the traffic light go from green to red and back again.

title: Elizabeth Conrod, John MacGillivray
description: Elizabeth Ann Conrod, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Conrod of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lieut. Comdr. John Dougald MacGillivray, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Dougald C. MacGillivray of Danvers, Mass. Msgr. Timothy A. McDonnell performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: C.I.A. Chief Charts His Own Course
description: In an Administration that prides itself on singing from the same songbook, there is one voice these days that keeps hitting a discordant note: John M. Deutch, the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Giving Biscuits and Quick Breads the Texture and Flavor of Corn
description: THIS summer's crop of fresh sweet corn will soon be a memory. With the advent of fall, it is time to think about corn the way earlier generations did, as a storage grain for milling into meal or flour, extending its shelf life so it can be used in winter.

title: 'Fools' by Neil Simon Offered in Croton Falls
description: IN the vast and varied oeuvre of Neil Simon, where does ''Fools'' fit in? Nowhere, really.

title: Foundation of Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: Distinctly Spanish, Distinctly Ballet
description: HOT ON THE HEELS OF Joaquin Cortes, the brash young flamenco dancer who performed recently to a packed Radio City Music Hall, Ballet Ullate will make its American debut this week with a program that features the Spanish soul of its varied repertory. But where Mr. Cortes promotes what is being called ''flamenco fusion,'' an amalgam of flamenco and other techniques designed to bring an age-old art into the 21st century, Victor Ullate keeps his company closely identified with a contemporary ballet esthetic.

title: Summer Rains Ruin Orange County's Onion Crop
description: Right up until harvest time, John Cavallaro held onto the hope that this summer's incessant rains had not ruined his entire 300-acre crop of onions. Then he walked his land.

title: Preserving a Shaker Heritage Where a Prison Now Stands
description: LITTLE is left of the once-thriving Shaker community in Enfield and what remains is difficult to detect.
