Some of the plain, dignified 19th-century buildings are enclosed within a state prison; a few that are privately owned stand in the shadow of the giant complex of Lego Systems, the toy manufacturers.

title: Yanks Hope Experience Will Help
description: TO hear Bernie Williams and Tino Martinez tell it, they were so awestruck by their first post-season baseball games last fall that they spent their time in Yankee Stadium and the Kingdome just gawking.

title: For a Foray Into Zen: Be Ready to Listen
description: THE benefits to those at the Empty Hand Zendo here are easily understood: to transform confusion into clarity, suffering into happiness or, at least, acceptance. But the methods of achieving this sense of personal peace are so esoteric that they may seem virtually unintelligible to the uninitiated.

title: Playoff Field Is Set, but Gooden Won't Be There
description: Dwight Gooden's inspirational comeback ended abruptly today when Joe Torre disclosed, before a 4-2 victory over the Red Sox, that the pitcher would not be on the Yankee roster for the first round of the post-season. For Gooden, the glass slipper no longer fits.

title: The Uffizi Begins Taking Reservations
description: To reduce the frustration of the thousands of tourists who line up for hours waiting to get into the Uffizi galleries in Florence every year, city officials have introduced a reservations system.

title: No Headline
description: ''We are still a solid police force, but when the streets are burning, it is difficult to maintain order.''

title: In One Man's Heartbeat, a Sense of Russia's Own
description: BEATS there a heart so feckless, so heroic as Boris N. Yeltsin's? Five years ago, the Russian President showed its throbbing dynamic when he emerged on the Moscow ramparts to snuff the brazen coup d'etat staged by Kremlin reactionaries. ''Aggression will not go forward!'' he shouted, and anyone who witnessed his defiance may forever bless his heart. ''Only democracy will win!''

title: The Fine Art of Murder
description: In a world in which public relations is considered performance art, it's no wonder that Stuart Finley feels disillusioned. Stuart, the 28-year-old narrator of OBSCENE BODIES (HarperCollins, $22), Kim Benabib's perceptive first novel, is an assistant curator in the Old Masters drawings department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where his mentor, the legendary chief curator Harlan Kohlman, has instilled in him a sense of skepticism, not to mention taste and standards. But there is more to Stuart's story. ''Obscene Bodies'' is a murder mystery that opens with a corpse and the observation that ''in some way all of them were accomplices.'' By the time the identity of the body has been disclosed, Stuart will have been drawn into the orbit of Miles Levy, a famous SoHo painter and conceptual artist who is intensely absorbed by his own image, endlessly refashioning it through publicists, dealers and groupies -- and drugs. Filled with eyebrow-raising roman-a-clef characters (Mr. Benabib's mother was a New York painter, his father a dealer), the novel provides a detailed inspection of hipness. But it is the ''obscene bodies'' (overhyped paintings) of the title that bring Stuart's predicament into focus: how to maintain Kohlman's standards in the face of the material rewards available to Levy. By making Levy more than just a one-dimensional con man and by opening Stuart's eyes to the heroic and almost impossible task of the artist to ''make it new,'' Mr. Benabib has given his story both honesty and complexity. Mark Marvel

title: Commission Worries About 'Issue' Ads That Tilt Too Far
description: In a test of free speech against questionable campaign practices, the Federal Election Commission will examine whether some ''issue-oriented'' political advertisements that promote the views of private interest groups violate Federal election laws.

title: No Money for Research? Try Investing
description: ''FUTURE Looks Bleak for Research.'' That California newspaper headline, summarizing recent findings of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, hardly came as a surprise to members of the academic community. Cutbacks in Federal financing for nonmilitary research have been common in recent years. Still, it had to be disheartening to learn that funds for such projects through 2002 are likely to be reduced by 25 percent from current levels.

title: The Choice Seat at This Opera Is Reserved for a Choice Pianist
description: FOR THE NEXT WEEK OR so, amid all the distractions of a new Metropolitan Opera season, security guards may want to keep a watchful eye on those tall display cases in front of the house with the six-foot-high posters listing casts for coming performances. The Met season opens on Monday evening with Umberto Giordano's ''Andrea Chenier,'' but one poster announces the personnel for the matinee on Saturday, the premiere of a new production of Giordano's ''Fedora.'' And the French pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet, who will make his Met debut that day in a nonspeaking role, simply has to have that poster.

title: Barren Bite Out of Broadway
description: Bracketed by Zabar's to the south and the Barnes & Noble superstore to the north, the two-block stretch on the west side of Broadway from 80th to 82d Streets is among the most traveled retail strips in Manhattan. But it's looking desolate these days. Last weekend's closing of Shakespeare & Company on 81st brought the tally of shuttered storefronts to five, two from 80th to 81st and three in a row between 81st and 82d.

title: Hospital Care In the Face Of More Mergers
description: UNAWARE that changes at hospitals have left administrators wringing their hands, Simona Harrison hobbled out of the White Plains Hospital Center here on a recent afternoon blissfully unconcerned. At that moment, she was only happy that recent advances in medical care had allowed her to be going home after just a few short hours.

title: Rich Nations May Forgive Debt of Poor Nations
description: The world's major industrial powers agreed today to forgive up to 80 percent of the debt owed to them by the poorest nations, primarily in Africa, if those countries agree to extraordinary economic reforms.

title: Sanders Is No Star On Offense
description: The Dallas Cowboys thought they could offset the loss of Michael Irvin, who was suspended for the first five games of the season for violating the league's substance abuse policy, by using cornerback Deion Sanders at wideout.

title: As Vegetables Irk Residents, Dealers Unite
description: Peer inside the pink plastic bag of any Chinatown shopper and you will invariably find produce that was harvested only hours earlier on a farm in New Jersey, Long Island or upstate New York. ''For Chinese people, freshness is very, very important,'' said Abraham Tan, president of Valley View Farm, one of the city's largest vegetable wholesalers. To serve Chinatown's burgeoning population, as many as 100 fruit and vegetable stores have opened in recent years, all of them relying on wholesalers like Mr. Tan to supply them with produce two or three times a day.

title: Susan Blumenthal, Adam De Chiara
description: Susan Sarah Blumenthal, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Blumenthal of Suffern, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Christopher De Chiara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alphonso L. De Chiara of East Northport, L.I. Rabbi Louis Frishman performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: Open Audition Offers Actors a Chance to Show Off, and Shine
description: AS he waited behind a screen, A. David Gavilanes folded his hands prayerfully. Realizing he had been noticed, he grinned and stretched. Otherwise, there were few signs of anxiety at an open audition for actors held here recently at the Fleetwood Stage by a consortium of six Westchester theater companies.

title: A Story in Glass  To the Editor: Bill O'Sullivan, in his  detailed walking tour of Graz, Austria (''Where Austrians Find Austria,'' Aug. 11), omitted a visit to the Stadtpfarrkirche, a historic church not five minutes from the main square and whose vivid stained glass panes tell a rather strange tale.
description: Damaged by Allied bombing during World War II, some of the church's panes were replaced about 1950. To the scene depicting the Crown of Thorns and the revilement and abuse of Jesus was added, in the uppermost right pane, a most unlikely pair, namely Hitler and Mussolini, perhaps in a belated act of contrition.

title: Agreement May Avert Cutting of Ancient Redwoods in California
description: Federal and state negotiators reached a tentative agreement today with a timber company to avert logging on thousands of acres of ancient redwood forests in the northwestern corner of California, acquiring the property in exchange for other land and cash totaling $380 million.

title: The Hall of Antiquities
description: Three years ago, Christie's auctioned a coin bank shaped like a man playing cymbals for the astonishing sum of $63,000. The bank had no great value when it was made 100 years ago, but because handmade toys have become as rare as vintage amontillado, the bank is now worth more than all the money it could hold. For those with pack-rat sensibilities, this is a seductive thing to know, for it confirms the belief that nothing should be heaved into the Dumpster. Certainly, collectors in the year 2096 will be willing to pay fortunes for today's ephemera. The questions are: Which pop-culture icons are going to grow in value and which will remain mere curios?

title: Co-op Tax Abatements: The Details
description: ON Aug. 25, this column described a recently enacted amendment to the New York State's Real Property Tax Law that makes property tax abatements available to owners of co-op and condominium units. The column resulted in several inquiries requesting additional information about various provisions of the law.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: Rave OnThe Biography of Buddy Holly.By Philip Norman.Simon & Schuster, $24.

title: New Releases
description: JOHN MELLENCAMP: 'MR. HAPPY-GO-LUCKY'

title: Painting Sort of, Kind of, But Not Exactly Like Picasso
description: WHEN MERCHANT IVORY made ''Surviving Picasso,'' they were beset with an unusual casting problem. The artist's son Claude would not let the film makers use actual art by Picasso. So they had to cast objects that looked like Picassos, but not too much.

title: Racial Politics: Man in Middle
description: Over the last year or so, issues in Community School District 28 have been clearly delineated by race. Blacks from the southern part of the district have usually been diametrically opposed to the views of whites in the northern part, which includes Forest Hills.

title: How Ives Used Faulty Memory to Good Effect
description: Charles Ives composed the sound of a man thinking. I know of no other musician who did. The quiet, tideless beginnings that mark so many of his orchestra pieces seem to undulate without really moving, like brain waves on a hospital monitor. The mind at rest awaits disruption, and disruption is the engine that drove Ives's creativity.

title: The Optimists Are Right
description: The future used to be so much simpler. A century ago, prophets had no trouble knowing what life today would be like. The Popular Science Monthly already realized in 1895 that the 20th century would be ''the Trolley Age.'' In ''Looking Backward,'' the best seller that fomented a national political movement in the 1890's, Edward Bellamy foresaw that the Socialist government of the year 2000 would give each citizen an annual ''credit card'' -- and that the allotted sum would be so generous that the happy citizen wouldn't even want to spend it all. The house of 2000, according to H.G. Wells, would have self-cleaning windows, and the floor would be easy to sweep because the architect would ''have the sense and ability to round off the angle between wall and floor.''

title: Love Bug Bites, and 70-Plus Couple Marry
description: FOR the staff at Marrs Nursing Home here, the recent wedding of Pauline Reeves and Anthony Diaz was not only the social event of the season but also the first wedding ever to take place at the 40-year-old home.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: Hail to the Chief

title: Mad Max Days: No Road? No Problem.
description: THE scene is every environmentalist's nightmare. At the edge of the Anza-Borrego Desert State Park, east of San Diego, a section has been set aside for off-roading. A veritable Mad Max collection of wheeled machines tears up the terrain here -- every driver a Road Warrior with a Gibson-Schwarzenegger-Stallone movie playing in his head.

title: Goes to Show, You Can't Keep Good Geese Down
description: The First Wives Club

title: Ethics Panel Drops 3 Charges Against Gingrich
description: Trying to clean out its desk before adjournment, the House ethics committee today dismissed three charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich and one against Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader.

title: Buchwald in Paris
description: To the Editor: Over the span of 77 years I've seen great nations decline, puny nations rise, giants shrivel and pygmies grow eight feet tall. In short, I felt I'd seen it all and was immune to surprise.

title: English Lessons
description: DROWN

title: Cowgirls Get Inequality Blues
description: KRISTEN DAVID, 24, was seated atop a black bronco in chute No. 6, a claustrophobic box barely wide enough for horse and rider. The bronco was bucking powerfully, threatening to throw and trample Ms. David, who only months before had to be taken by helicopter to a hospital after a spill in a bronco ride at another rodeo.

title: New York
description: Autumn is the best time to see New York City in the way it is best seen. On foot, that is. The city's architecture, its neighborhoods, its street life, its commercial extravagance are best contemplated from a pedestrian's view.

title: White Collars Turn Blue
description: When looking backward, you must always be prepared to make allowances: it is unfair to blame late-20th-century observers for their failure to foresee everything about the century to come. Long-term social forecasting is an inexact science even now, and in 1996 the founders of modern nonlinear socioeconomics were obscure graduate students. Still, many people understood that the major forces driving economic change would be the continuing advance of digital technology and the spread of economic development throughout the world; in that sense, there were no big surprises. The puzzle is why the pundits of the time completely misjudged the consequences of those changes.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WINE AND WAR

title: Stephanie Meade, Phil Kaufmann
description: Stephanie Alice Meade, the daughter of Mereth and Robert Meade of Evergreen, Colo., is to be married today to Carl Phillips Kaufmann, a son of Ruth and Carl B. Kaufmann of Chadds Ford, Pa. The Rev. Francesca Sergi, an interfaith minister, is to perform the ceremony at the barn of Peter Wood, a friend of the Kaufmann family, on Block Island, R.I.

title: Seminoles Stingier Than Tar Heels
description: The rain kept falling today and the Florida State defense kept coming -- eight sacks' worth against the beleaguered North Carolina quarterback Chris Keldorf.

title: Does Decor Sell the House?
description: WENDY OWEN is getting used to the life style. The English-born interior designer, now living in Stamford, decorates in over-scale California style. It includes designing and making her own extraordinary draperies in a third floor ballroom-sized work room like few others: it overlooks the beach. Beyond decorating, she shares an unusual, albeit luxurious, vagabond life style with her fiance, John Isbrandtsen, an investment banker.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on page 15 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the rerelease of the 1956 film ''Giant'' misstates its opening date at the Sony Lincoln Square Theater in Manhattan. It was Friday; it is not Oct. 4.

title: Jobless and Hopeless
description: WHEN WORK DISAPPEARSThe World of the New Urban Poor.By William Julius Wilson.322 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: Catching Rainbows At Rainbow's End
description: It is 7:30 A.M. on a bright and crisp morning, but all the blinds in the small cafe of the Missouri River Trout Shop are drawn tight, blocking out the light. About a dozen men and two women sit at the bare bones tables and booths, hunched over coffee. Nobody has passed out yet, but if the smell of frying bacon gets any stronger, someone might. The guests are in deep discussion, the gravity is palpable. Each of these people is about to go on a mission: fishing.

title: Leslie Jo Duffield, David Hurwitz
description: Leslie Jo Mastin Duffield, a daughter of Janis Bomers and a stepdaughter of Harry G. Bomers of Okemos, Mich., was married yesterday evening at the Kalamazoo (Mich.) Country Club to David Joel Hurwitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel H. Hurwitz of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Richard Weiss officiated with the Rev. Douglas Learned, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about proposals to change capital-gains tax laws for home sales referred incorrectly to the Federal tax treatment of a hypothetical example. In the example, a couple bought a home for $30,000, sold it for $300,000, and then bought a new home for $150,000. The amount subject to capital gains would be $150,000, not $120,000, because the taxable gain in this case is the sale price minus the cost of the new home. If one or both of the sellers were over 55, they could shelter $125,000 of the gain from taxes because of a one-time exemption allowed in the law.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 29, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 THE GREEN MILE: COFFEY ON THE MILE, by Stephen King. (Signet, $3.99.) The sixth and concluding installment of a thriller set on death row. 2 2 THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Scientists visit a Costa Rican jungle that is the breeding ground of dinosaurs. 3 6 MORNING, NOON & NIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $7.50.) The mysterious drowning of a respected tycoon reveals a tangle of scandals. 4 11 THE FIRST WIVES CLUB, by Olivia Goldsmith. (Pocket, $6.99.) Three women conspire to get even with the men who divorced them. 5 5 MELODY, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $6.99.) A young girl, her father dead, is deserted by her mother and left with eccentric relatives. 6 7 THE GREEN MILE: NIGHT JOURNEY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $2.99.) The fifth installment of a serial thriller. 7 2 THE HEIR, by Catherine Coulter. (Topaz, $6.99.) The stormy courtship and marriage of an earl and his cousin in 18th-century England. 8 51 SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Vintage, $12.) A murder trial recalls the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans. (+) 9* 7 ''L'' IS FOR LAWLESS, by Sue Grafton. (Fawcett, $6.99.) AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam, $6.50.) Observations on life by the television star and stand-up comedian. 3 3 A CIVIL ACTION, by Jonathan Harr. (Vintage, $13.) A lawsuit brought by Massachusetts householders against industrial polluters. (+) 4 25 THE LIARS' CLUB, by Mary Karr. (Penguin, $11.95.) A poet recalls her troubled childhood. (+) 5 28 HOW THE IRISH SAVED CIVILIZATION, by Thomas Cahill. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The story of monks who copied Western literature. (+) 6 9 MINDHUNTER, by John Douglas and Mark Olshaker. (Drew/Pocket, $6.99.) The memoirs of the former leader of an F.B.I. team that studies the behavior of serial killers and assassins. 7 1 A FEVER IN THE HEART, by Ann Rule. (Pocket, $6.99.) Accounts of six crime cases that occurred in Washington and Oregon. 8 13 NEW PASSAGES, by Gail Sheehy. (Ballantine, $12.95.) How changing social conditions and longer life expectancies affect our lives. (+) 9 18 SLEEPERS, by Lorenzo Carcaterra. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The true story, the narrator claims, of boys in a reformatory and the revenge they later take. 10 11 MY AMERICAN JOURNEY, by Colin L. Powell with Joseph E. Persico. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The autobiography of the former general. 11* 17 A GOOD WALK SPOILED, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $13.95.) The P.G.A. Tour. (+) 12* 23 PAULA, by Isabel Allende. (Harper Perennial, $12.50.) The novelist tells stories of her family's life as she tends her fatally ill daughter. (+) 13* 141 CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (Harper Perennial, $12.) Daily spirituality. (+) 14* 16 SPONTANEOUS HEALING, by Andrew Weil. (Fawcett, $12.95.) How the body heals itself. (+) 15* 18 GOD: A BIOGRAPHY, by Jack Miles. (Vintage, $15.) Perceptions of the Old Testament Deity. (+) 16* 671 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $12.) Inspiration. (+) 17* 9 MY OLD MAN AND THE SEA, by David Hays and Daniel Hays. (Harper Perennial, $10.) A sailing yarn about a father-and-son voyage. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 1 IT'S A MAGICAL WORLD, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $14.95.) A new collection of ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 105 CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE SOUL, compiled by Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Stories meant to ''open the heart and rekindle the spirit.'' (+) 3 265 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $14.) Principles to practice in the pursuit of success. (+) 4* 23 DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (M. Evans, $12.95.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)

title: Coveted Site Soon to Be Vacated in Casino Country
description: WHEN the state closes Norwich Hospital next month, 900 acres of land and 1.4 million square feet of building space will be put onto one of the hottest real estate markets in Connecticut.

title: Pigeons Hold Sway at a Gas Station
description: THE Hilltop gas station in the Shrub Oak section of Yorktown is more than just a place to get the gas tank filled or a car repaired. In recent months, it has become a small tourist attraction.

title: The Defense Device
description: Someone about to commit a crime undergoes distinct physiological changes: body temperature, blood pressure and heart rate all rise and the body emits a musky scent. This wrist cuff, encompassing laser and microwave technology, would be able to read those vital signs and zap a potential attacker with a disabling arc of electricity. Think of it as a Mace for the 21st century.

title: Dialing 203: But for a Few, A Number to Nowhere
description: Connecticut has always been a little divided. There are Red Sox fans and Yankee fans, Manhattan commuters and Hartford insurance executives, stockbrokers and dairy farmers.

title: Music to Whose Ears? Arts Center and Neighbors Try to Work Things Out
description: The Scottish Festival scheduled today ends the first season of private management at the PNC Bank Arts Center, formerly known as the Garden State Arts Center. But that's not what nearby residents are likely to remember.

title: Bill Tries to Balance Concerns on Immigration
description: The immigration bill the White House and Congressional Republicans agreed to early today includes some of the toughest measures taken in decades against illegal immigration, but has far less to discourage legal immigration than was originally proposed.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 5/

title: A Great Name Like Eskimo Pie Can't Lose. Or Can It?
description: THE Eskimo Pie Corporation, maker of a tasty slice of Americana, has had its share of troubles recently. But to some investors the company may be just as alluring as the treat's one-time jingle -- ''Why not try a gen-u-ine Eskimo Pie?'' -- has been to the sweet of tooth.

title: What the Audience Wore
description: The charity luncheon-fashion show, a popular social occasion in the 1950's and 60's, returned this month in a revival of sorts by Valentino (above), Dior, Ferragamo and others. Such events went into eclipse when more women entered the workplace, and others thought that being seen at a fashion luncheon suggested that they led frivolous lives. Now, lunch is served precisely at noon and guests are out by 2 P.M. The fantasy glamour on the runway here was perhaps less the news than the audience. The guests overwhelmingly rejected the dogma of unadorned black, wearing tweeds and light colors, with brooches, jeweled belts and flowing scarves. The few women in black chose jackets brightened with gold buttons. Pants and knee-length skirts were equally popular at all the luncheons. (Photographs by BILL CUNNINGHAM/The New York Times)

title: Book Irked Church. Now It's a Movie.
description: ''Sleepers,'' a memoir of 1960's life in Hell's Kitchen, has tormented the present-day residents of Clinton since the book became a best seller last year. They say the book -- a tale of rape, murder and cover-up over two decades -- is a hoax.

title: We Are Still Only Human
description: I was raised to be polite, and I am polite, by default. I have learned to depend on my politeness and to hate it, because it so often feels like a hand clutching my windpipe. The politeness that afflicts me is not civility, which is an urbane quality compatible even with cynicism. To be polite in the manner of my Midwestern upbringing is to believe that humans should be judged not by their deeds but by their best intentions. And so I grew up believing in a polite past, the untainted progress of decent men and women tilling a ripe but virgin soil, building stainless, heroic cities. I was taught to imagine a polite future, too: a universal Iowa of the 1950's, but with more efficient appliances and extra longevity and even nicer people. There are worse imaginable futures, and they are all more probable.

title: Seattle Landmark Houses a Theater Company
description: The Eagles Auditorium, a landmark building in downtown Seattle, has been reborn as Kreielsheimer Place, the new home of A Contemporary Theater, the 31-year-old regional theater company known as ACT.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Lucky Bucks

title: Putting More Models in Orbit
description: IT has taken a long time, but a good idea from 1982 at General Motors -- a plan to start fresh and create a car company that does everything right -- has begun to pay off. The Saturn Corporation has sold 1.27 million vehicles in the United States so far, its dealers are finding buyers for every car it can make, and its customers are displaying a zealous affection far surpassing brand loyalty as it is usually known.

title: Bulletin From the Future
description: Emergency supplies of pencils are being distributed at all computer clinics by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The agency warns that the epidemic is spreading on all continents, clogging channels of communication, including live links to human nervous systems.

title: BENEFITS
description: A Designer Show

title: Missteps Reopen the Door to Blood and Tears
description: THE Middle East is an unstable structure at the best of times, and there are moments -- far too many -- when even a small shift of weight causes the entire structure to wobble and crumble.

title: TV Remedy For a TV Malady
description: Frankel's article on the distorting effect television spots have on the political process and the degree to which they are financed by corporate and activist groups is right on the mark.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DARK DEBTS

title: Bosnia's Last Best Hope
description: According to Scott Anderson, intelligent, and educated, liberal and skeptical'' young people, like those he interviewed in his article Bosnia's Last Best Hope (Sept. 8), may finally end the Balkan curse. With such state-ments, Anderson has bought into the international community's policy of leaving the Balkan mess to itself.

title: The Hokies Can't Stop Mighty McNabb
description: Could there have been a turning point in a game with a 52-21 final score?

title: The Next Frontier: Invisible
description: This past summer, I flew across the country to move an atom. Insofar as that statement encompasses nearly the full range of physical matter and our current knowledge of it, I will elucidate. On the afternoon of July 4, I boarded an airplane (one of civilization's largest and fastest assemblages of atoms) in New York City (one of civilization's most outrageous), and five hours and a whole continent of atoms later found myself in a laboratory at the I.B.M. Research Division at the Almaden Research Center in San Jose, Calif., poised to move just one -- to nudge around a single atom of the element xenon, to pick it up and put it back down, to will that atom where I wanted and thereby join a select group of people upon this otherwise massive and madly jumbled sphere of unruly atoms who can say they have truly taken matter into their own hands.

title: Out Go the Pesticides (but Not Just Anywhere)
description: These blue-sky days and chilly mornings fill a gardener's soul with energy -- for digging potatoes and cutting Red Splendor zinnias, and pulling up the old bean plants. It's time to plant cover crops of winter rye, to add nitrogen and tilth to the soil. And to turn the compost pile. (If you don't have one of these environmental pots of gold, make one.)

title: $10 Million Invites Gifts From Others
description: Robert and Anne Bass like to think of it as a sale on chairs.

title: Ban All H.M.O.'s From Muzzling Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES THIS WEEk
description: VIVID performances in an assortment of comedies and dramas lend crisp autumnal zest to the pick of this week's movie crop.

title: The 'Big' That Wasn't
description: As a movie, it made a mint. As a musical, it was one of the most expensive flops in Broadway history. ''Big,'' the 1988 comedy blockbuster starring Tom Hanks, became ''Big,'' the 1996 Broadway bust. Last week, the show's producers announced that it would close on Oct. 13, after having a disappointing six-month run and losing more than $10 million.

title: Buy a Snack, Get a Blind Date
description: If falling temperatures are enough to chill the hearts of most ice-cream vendors, why does Mafoz Sharkar have a smile on his face? Perhaps it's the long lines that form inside his yogurt shop on even the coolest autumn evening as legions of trim, young professionals drop by for a low-fat indiscretion. Or maybe it's because each and every customer, it seems, knows Mr. Sharkar's birthday, speaks a few words of his native Bengali and swears undying loyalty to Nut City, the candy and ice-cream store on Second Avenue and 82d Street he owns with his brother Masud. It could be, however, something to do with Mr. Sharkar's unnaturally happy disposition. ''Our mother always says that Mafoz was born smiling,'' said Masud. ''That's just the way he is.''

title: The 'Black' for '02 Open: Bow to Public Courses
description: SINCE it opened 60 years ago, the Black course at Bethpage State Park has been the course that Long Island golfers love to hate. From its strangling rough to its myriad of sand traps, its layout has frustrated even the best of players.

title: A Conflict Over Church's Move to Raze House
description: A CENTURY-OLD house in Greenport is at the center of a dispute over whether the house is a decrepit wreck that should be demolished or a historic structure that needs to be preserved.

title: Presto! Valujet Lives.
description: AFTER weeks of consideration, the Transportation Department decided last week that Valujet Airlines, which was grounded in June because of widespread safety problems, was fit to fly again.

title: Beauty Is Back
description: Beauty in 2096 will mean less, and mean it better, than it does today. Why not predict a happy outcome for our age of confusion in esthetic matters? Things can hardly get worse.

title: Flying High but Just Off the Ground
description: UP, up and away. The shares of the Pan Am Corporation, a start-up airline that owns the Pan Am name but is otherwise unrelated to the defunct aviation pioneer, have taken off. As the company celebrated its inaugural flight last Thursday, it was also enjoying a stock price that has more than doubled since March.

title: Goes to Show, You Can't Keep Good Geese Down
description: Fly Away Home

title: Turning a New and Improved Corner Under Turner
description: Once the Washington Redskins won Super Bowl XXVI in 1992 -- once they turned the corner on the Hogs and the Posse, and the work of the gladiator receiver Art Monk and the lively football mind of Joe Gibbs became part of their past -- it was as if the franchise had ducked into a cave.

title: Rolling Through Amish Country
description: WHAT better way to end the summer than with a little trip to someplace green and bountiful? Rural Pennsylvania, around and beyond the city of Lancaster, sounded good to my husband, Tom, and me. In high season, though, it was going to be difficult to do on the cheap: we were too late to book an inexpensive farm stay (and I'm not sure I'd be crazy about a place that invited me to help with the chores) and the less expensive motels were mostly on U.S. 30, a garish strip of factory outlets and fast-food restaurants that we had been warned to avoid at all cost. In near desperation I called a discount hotel broker, Accommodations Express, of Atlantic City, which lists the Pennsylvania Dutch country among its specialties.

title: War Wounds
description: DOING BATTLEThe Making of a Skeptic.By Paul Fussell.Illustrated. 309 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: On 'X-Files,' Ms. Reason Amid the Unreal
description: Gillian Anderson's job can be a foul, dirty business: she performs autopsies on otherworldly corpses, wades through rivers as she searches for clues. And all the interesting people she meets end up dead. Her boss thinks she's weird and tries to undermine her by losing the paper work on her most important cases. Lately her young daughter has been getting into the act, running around the work place, waving a severed, decomposing hand.

title: The Price They Paid
description: ASHES OF GLORY

title: Giants Have Hands Full With Moon And Friends
description: The last time linebacker Corey Miller saw quarterback Warren Moon, he had him wrapped up in a bear hug and was throwing him to the ground. The year was 1991, and Moon was playing for Houston and Miller was a silly rookie out of South Carolina who was showing he could be an excellent pass rusher for the Giants. That day, he sacked Moon twice in the Giants' 24-20 victory.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 29, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week> List Fiction 1 1 5 EXECUTIVE ORDERS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) Vice President Jack Ryan has problems after the deaths of the President and members of Congress. 2 5 2 JACK AND JILL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Alex Cross on the trail of serial killers. 3 3 18 THE RUNAWAY JURY, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $26.95.) A woman in a Mississippi Gulf Coast town sues a tobacco company for causing her husband's death. 4 4 8 THE LAST DON, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $25.95.) The aging head of a Mafia family makes plans for his heirs' activities in Hollywood and Las Vegas. 5* 2 7 SERVANT OF THE BONES, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $26.) Events in the Clinton White House as reported by an F.B.I. agent formerly on duty there. (+) 4 1 HOW GOOD DO WE HAVE TO BE? by Harold S. Kushner. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A rabbi's discussion of how a new understanding of guilt and forgiveness can change our lives. 5 4 30 UNDAUNTED COURAGE, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The story of how Thomas Jefferson sponsored Lewis and Clark's exploration of the American West. (+) 6 3 4 ALL TOO HUMAN, by Edward Klein. (Pocket, $23.) The courtship and marriage of John and Jacqueline Kennedy. 7 5 126 MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga. (+) 8 9 52 EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE, by Daniel Goleman. (Bantam, $23.95.) Factors other than I.Q. that contribute to a successful and happy life. (+) 9 10 15 OUTRAGE, by Vincent Bugliosi. (Norton, $25.) The reasons, according to the former Los Angeles County prosecutor, that O. J. Simpson was found not guilty. (+) 10 15 2 ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $24.)
