title: Katherine Karcher, Brooks Clark
description: Katherine Virginia Karcher, a daughter of Mrs. Oliver William Karcher of Memphis and the late Mr. Karcher, was married yesterday to Brooks Sandeman Clark, a son of Joan Stubenbord Clark and Alexander Meeker Clark, both of New York. The Very Rev. James E. Annand performed the ceremony at St. James's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 4 about Sparta misidentified the emperor who was crowned in the town of Mistra in the 15th century. A reader's letter, dated Aug. 4, pointed out that it was Constantine XI, not Constantine II. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Hilary A. Seiden, Gregg A. Smith
description: Hilary Anne Seiden, a daughter of Katherine C. and Steven A. Seiden of New York, was married last evening to Gregg Ashley Smith, the son of Rose C. and Elliot J. Smith of New York. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin performed the ceremony at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Skeptic Takes Sword To Bars' Myths
description: Tall tales and fanciful boasts are not exactly unheard of in saloons, and to rebut them can be to risk a broken nose. But in New York, city of hyperbole that it is, some of the biggest exaggerations may be told by the taverns themselves. The problem is that more than one wants to be the oldest.

title: The Problems With Woodworking
description: EVEN professional woodworkers and cabinet makers make mistakes. The main difference between a professional and an amateur is that the pro knows how to correct his mistakes so they won't show. The following fixes and corrective tips can be handy even if you're not a cabinet maker. They can, for example, be used to correct defects in an old piece of furniture that you're restoring.

title: Fall Foliage
description: To the Editor: Your listing on fall foliage omitted Rhode Island. The Division of Tourism's toll-free telephone number is (800) 556-2684. We would also be more than happy to give callers information about southern Rhode Island, which includes Block Island and Narragansett. Our number is (880) 548-4662.

title: Presidents and Pardons: It's Asking for Trouble
description: IN an era of White House scandal and its pursuit by independent counsels, a new kind of election year ritual has emerged: the Dance Around the Presidential Pardon.

title: Jennifer C. Tesoro, Michael J. Reese
description: Jennifer Clare Tesoro, the daughter of Maureen and Dr. Michael Tesoro of Sharon, Conn., was married there yesterday to Michael John Reese, the son of Deborah and John Reese of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. John D. Regan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the First Church of Christ Congregational with the Rev. Terrence Ryan, a Congregational minister.

title: Da Going Out Guide
Crime
description: The characters in John Harvey's urban crime novels are so defiantly alive and unruly that they put these British police procedurals on a shelf all by themselves. The author animates an entire family in EASY MEAT (Marian Wood/ Holt, $23), studying them in obsessive detail to determine what makes them the way they are. Norma Snape, the matriarch of this sorry brood, was knocked around as a child, setting up a cycle of abuse and neglect that has made her three streetwise kids simultaneously dangerous and vulnerable. If any of these guttersnipes manages to survive this grim heritage, it won't be Nicky, the youngest, who is arrested for savagely beating an old couple and is then found dead in a juvenile detention home.

title: Less Is More
description: How will Americans eat in the next century? Hard to tell. Eating habits change about as quickly as continents drift, which is to say imperceptibly, if at all. Apple pie, steak, barbecued ribs, fried chicken, hot dogs, pizza -- especially pizza -- and Big Macs are what Americans will eat, if Americans have their way. These totems embody the rough-and-tumble optimism of a country composed mainly of people who have fled disaster elsewhere. Even the current hue and cry over health has done very little to sway the self-congratulation inherent in eating high on the food chain.

title: Sarah J. Cottrell, Zachary L. Lazar
description: Sarah Jane Cottrell, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Cottrell of Cutchogue, L.I., is to be married today to Zachary Lane Lazar, the son of Susan Lackner of Denver and the late Edward L. Lazar. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim is to perform the ceremony at the Old Field Club in Old Field, L.I.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: FYI 2

title: Correction
description: Picture captions on Sept. 1 with an article about a camp for the elderly in Brewster identified three women out of sequence. In both the top and the bottom photographs, they were, from the left, Rose Berger, Harriet Uram and Arlene Judd.

title: Emily Roosevelt And Peter Foehl
description: Emily Roosevelt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher du Pont Roosevelt of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Hastings Foehl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Allen Foehl 3d of Westwood, Mass. The Rev. Anne Carroll Fowler, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the bride's parents' house on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Penn State Overcomes Badgers' Mass
description: Wisconsin's bratwurst-fed offensive line averages 6 feet 5 inches and 309 pounds. Any larger, and the Badgers would need building permits. They outweighed Penn State's defensive front by 60 pounds a man. Next to these guys, Nate Newton of the Dallas Cowboys is not a kitchen, but a mere breakfast nook.

title: TV Remedy For a TV Malady
description: Max Frankel overlooked one option for stemming the huge sums of money that are being spent on political television ads (Word & Image: ''TV Remedy for a TV Malady,'' Sept. 8). How about banning them?

title: Love Is All You'll Need
description: The rain pat-patters on the roof. Daisy and her friend Vivienne, who is visiting from France for the day, are sprawled on the living-room sofa.

title: Berkeley Hopes $120 Million Plant Erases an Image
description: SEEKING to overcome what it concedes is a well-earned reputation for being antidevelopment, this city has a new $120 million multipurpose biotechnology plant to show off as a demonstration that such a reputation is outdated.

title: Enough of Whitewater
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Cuisines in a Modern Marriage
description: THE restaurant build-up in South Norwalk continues. Hunan Harmony is a latecomer, offering Japanese and Chinese cuisines in a well-lighted, modernized storefront that extends from a street-level entrance on Washington Street to a parking lot entrance up a few steps, flush with the SoNo Cinema. For moviegoers it couldn't be more convenient.

title: Insurance for Funds: Safety for Whom?
description: INVESTORS might be attracted by Fidelity Investments' plan to insure money market funds because it would increase the safety of their investments. But money fund insurance represents a much bigger opportunity for the fund companies, analysts say: it promises to limit their liability.

title: A Party Chief's Labors Are Not Lost on Tory Voters
description: Blackpool, Britain's gaudy blue-collar resort on the Irish Sea, and the City of London, the country's august blue-suited center of financial activity, can be thought of as the two distant poles of a passage through British public life.

title: What Price Victory? Study Feeds Contention
description: At first glance, a dispute about economic correlations of price and consumption might seem an arcane quibble. But in this election year, some Republicans on Capitol Hill have accused the White House of skulduggery by suppressing a study that maintains it is more cost effective to reduce the cocaine supply by interdicting it in Latin America than to reduce demand by treating addicts in the United States.

title: Luck Be A Portfolio Tonight!
description: IF a sweepstakes awarded you shares in the Fidelity Magellan fund, would that mean you won, or took the booby prize?

title: Illusions Onstage and in the Mind In a Playwright's 'Italian Tragedy'
description: IT'S only a couple of minutes into the first scene of ''A View From the Bridge'' when the narrator, a lawyer named Alfieri, starts talking of ruins and Greeks.

title: From 100 Blocks, a Single, Seamless Image
description: THE exhibition ''Keiji Shinohara: Interpretations in Woodcut,'' at the Wesleyan University Davison Art Center in Middletown is both sublime and a nuts and bolts lesson in the mechanics of printmaking. It might prompt a reflection on how easy making a duplicable work has become since the development of software programs for making art through a series of clicks. Mr. Shinohara's approach is the complete opposite. He is both an artist and a craftsman, and sometimes it requires 100 carved blocks to produce a single, seamless image.

title: Persevering Despite Clouds And Uncooperative Comets
description: Jenny Jump is getting ready for Hale-Bopp.

title: Jodi L. Scherer, Andrew J. Dady
description: Jodi Lynne Scherer, the director of the print division of the Leo Castelli Gallery in New York, and Andrew James Dady, a senior associate at the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, were married last evening in Boston. Rabbi Paul H. Levenson officiated at the Boston Harbor Hotel.

title: For Diners Whose Idea of Heaven Is a Meatless Meal
description: To vegetarians on a quest for restaurants offering more than pasta and salad, the new Veggie Heaven in Teaneck may be something close to nirvana.

title: Amanda M. King, James Cornacchia
description: Amanda Maude King, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth S. King of Brewster, Mass., was married yesterday to James Michael Cornacchia, a son of Joseph M. Cornacchia of Southhold, L.I., and the late Vivian B. Cornacchia. The Rev. George J. Michell performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Southhold.

title: Midtown Outdoors Living
description: FOR a claustrophobic apartment-hunter, the choices are limited. Even the huge prewar apartments generally have a lot of thick walls and smallish, small-paned windows. And the 1980's condominiums may have low ceilings. Lofts might seem like a good choice -- big spaces and, often, big windows -- but there are very few in midtown, where Bruce Presley wanted to be.

title: Galindo's Pro Debut
description: The United States men's champion, RUDY GALINDO, will make his professional debut at the United States Professional Championships Oct. 26, facing BRIAN BOITANO, VIKTOR PETRENKO, KURT BROWNING. (AP)

title: Darlene A. Wood, L.K. Brady Jr.
description: Darlene Ann Wood, a daughter of Diane Wood of Lake George, N.Y., and Raymond C. Wood of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., was married yesterday to Lawrence Kenneth Brady Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brady of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Paul Cox officiated at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Lake George.

title: Man of a Century, Living With Gusto (Especially Each Sunday)
description: LATE on a Sunday afternoon at Bill's Seafood Restaurant, on Route 1 in Westbrook, the music is cascading from a bandstand: ''You must have been a beautiful baby'' . . . ''It had to be you'' . . . ''When you're smiling'' . . . and the audience is swaying, singing along, yelling, cheering, waving.

title: Rego and St. Joseph's Top No. 1 Montclair
description: New Jersey

title: Farming With a Face: How to Buy a Stake in Organic Agriculture
description: PEOPLE like Jim Kinsel's produce so much they buy it before he even plants it.

title: At Last, the Test Ban Treaty
description: Decades after Dwight D. Eisenhower watched his dream of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty dissolve, the world's five declared nuclear powers led a parade of nations last week in signing a treaty to bar nuclear weapons testing.

title: Padres Secure Playoff Spot With Gwynn's Powerful Bat
description: Their team photograph just went up in value.

title: The Opening Woods
description: Autumn has come, and already the weight of the afternoon sun falls more lightly on one's back than it did a few weeks ago. In the country north of New York City, the days seem not only shorter but also somehow thinner too, and every morning that dawns above freezing feels like a morning won back from the inevitable. Nothing is dry yet, of course, but the promise of eventual dryness is in the air. A day will come when every crown of seeds will rattle on the weeds in ditches and fields, when leaves will crunch obligingly underfoot again.

title: Joseph Dunn, 63, Theatrical Director
description: Joseph Dunn, a director in experimental theater, died on Sept. 16 at his home in Hopewell Junction, N.Y. He was 63.

title: 'Give Back to Your Community,' She Said
description: Rafael Campo's poignant article 'Give Back to Your Community,' She Said (Sept. 1) reflected his compassion, which was deepened by his personal experience. There is indeed a universality to suffering. It is apparent that Campo practices medicine with grace and courage.

title: INSIDE
description: A Challenge to Yeltsin

title: 59 1/2 Questions About I.R.A. Withdrawals
description: Q. I'd like to begin withdrawing money from my individual retirement account, but I'm worried about making a mistake and incurring a stiff penalty. Any suggestions?

title: Living With A Radium Nightmare
description: WHEN Eldon and Betty Allin decided to move into a four-bedroom Colonial on Carteret Street in 1961, her father warned against it. ''Don't buy it,'' he told them. ''It's built on a dump.'' He knew because he worked at Public Service Electric and Gas, and had installed all the original gas meters on the block. The Allins bought the house anyway.

title: Desperation or Simple Greed?
description: ACCORDING to the state's Uniform Crime Report, which charts all arrests made in Connecticut, there were 30 percent fewer murders last year and burglary complaints declined 13 percent. Even car thefts were down.

title: Lions Let Brooks Go And Sign Hartings
description: To get enough salary-cap room to sign their first-round draft pick, guard JEFF HARTINGS from Penn State, the Detroit Lions waived linebacker MICHAEL BROOKS on Friday. Brooks signed a two-year, $3.6 million contract in March. However that deal and a sprained knee in training camp sealed his fate. Coincidentally, another former Giants linebacker, PEPPER JOHNSON, will start at middle linebacker in place of Brooks.

title: FOr Veterans of the 90's, It's Desert Storm Mom (On Line)
description: IN a small house set back among the trees in Patchogue, Jacqueline Olsen juggles two families. Part of one is circling her at the moment.

title: No Tailspin From AT&T
description: The announcement by AT&T last week that competition in the long-distance market was taking a toll on profits might have been expected to send telecommunications mutual funds into a tailspin.

title: More and More, a Midday Break for the Soul
description: He came in out of the steady drizzle of an overcast day into the brightly lighted sanctuary of the church, an electrician in jeans and a white sweatshirt, filled with the questions and uncertainties of youth. Henry Rausch, 24, of Paterson, whose job is to provide light had put down the tools of his trade at the lunch hour and come to Christ Church to seek another kind of illumination.

title: Riffs of Prose Were a Part Of the Musical Package
description: ONE CASUALTY OF THE COMPACT disk-era has been liner notes as a focus of attention. Unlike CD booklets, which may languish unread in their cases, the annotations on LP's, especially jazz LP's, were an integral part of the total package, along with the usually arresting cover art. At first glance liner notes may have seemed to promise little more than promotional copy for the enclosed record, but they often contained much more -- personal reminiscences, musical analysis, historical context and a window on the recording process itself. For jazz fans, the best of these notes attached themselves to the experience of listening to the record.

title: The Haves Have Less
description: It's strange how geriatric miracles have defined my life. My birth in 1996 was a minor news story in Britain, of the chuckling tut-tut variety, because my father, Lord Young, was 80 years old at the time. ''Sprightly Peer Sires Heir'' -- you can imagine. And now here I am writing a magazine article at the age of 100. The medical advances of the 21st century have been astounding, and I've had the invaluable aid of a medium; still, it's unusual.

title: Dream Job as Judge Beckons, But It May Last Just a Year
description: Frank J. Barbaro, the 68-year-old Democrat representing Bensonhurst in the Assembly, has finally attained his lifelong dream. But he may only be able to savor it for a year.

title: Your Burglar: A Face-to-Face Encounter
description: MARGARET ROFMAN was asleep on the third floor when the burglar plunged through the screen of the first floor window at 8 A.M. Ms. Rofman, a professional gardener, is usually up at this hour, but boys were playing basketball across her street in Cobble Hill at 3 A.M. and she had turned on the air-conditioner and a white noise machine. She didn't hear a thing. A man reading the newspaper at his rear window saw the burglar and called the police. At 8:20, another neighbor called Ms. Rofman to say that half the 76th precinct was at her door.

title: New Ways to Tally Air Miles on the Ground
description: Several new ways of earning frequent flier mileage while remaining firmly on the ground have recently been introduced.

title: Yankees Need Just 15 Minutes To Sell Out 2 Playoff Games
description: It took the Yankees 15 years to win a division title but only 15 minutes to sell out the 30,186 tickets available to the public for the first two playoff games combined.

title: What to Wear to School?
description: AS he climbed on the back of his mother's chair while waiting to get a new jacket and pants at the Rogers Magnet School in Stamford, 5-year-old Sam Kesler may not have been especially aware that he was about to adopt one of education's oldest and now newest trademarks: school uniforms.

title: Tamara Meadow, B.E. Bernstein
description: Tamara Meadow, an interior designer in New York, and Bradford Eric Bernstein, a principal in Oak Hill Partners, an investment advisory firm in New York, were married last evening at the Essex House in New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony.

title: L.I. VINES
description: Cabernet Sauvignon

title: The Next Hundred Years
description: Reformers, writers and artists have long deployed visions of the future as parables, offering insight into their times. Today, in a third and final commemoration of its centennial, The New York Times Magazine responds to that same impulse, to use tomorrow as a prism through which to cast light on today.

title: Legacies of the 104th Congress
description: With Newt Gingrich leading the parade, the new Republican majority swaggered into Washington in January of last year convinced that their radical agenda had popular appeal. In the beginning, their confidence did not seem misplaced. They dominated the national debate and instituted significant reforms of Congressional procedures. Then they overreached. They shut down the Government in an effort to win huge spending cuts and all they really got for their pains was a reputation -- cleverly manipulated by President Clinton -- for callousness. Now, as the 104th Congress passes into history, the very Republicans who had defied Mr. Clinton are trying to build a more moderate legislative record to take to the voters.

title: Internet Is a Supplement, Not a Substitute
description: To the Editor:

title: Jyoti Vaswani, Sebastian Ruta
description: Jyoti Vaswani, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gobind Vaswani of Jamaica, Queens, is to be married today to Sebastian Ruta, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ruta of Manhattan. Pandit Mohanlal Sharma is to perform the Hindu ceremony at Land's End, a restaurant in Sayville, L.I.

title: Flaming Out
description: THE PIANO MAN'S DAUGHTER

title: Plans Advance for Office Complex in Jamaica
description: MAYBE this time it will actually happen. Twice before, developers have been selected for a two-acre city-owned site in central Jamaica, Queens, and twice the project, which has its roots in the Lindsay administration, has failed to go forward.

title: The Flight
description: Tomorrow's vacation is little more than an hour away: that's the goal of Robert Zubrin of Pioneer Rocketplane and several Government aeronautical engineers who are at work on prototypes of the space plane. The space plane takes off like a standard jet, climbing to 30,000 feet in three minutes. Then the pilot cuts the jets and flicks on the kerosene-fueled rocket engines. Within 30 seconds, the plane breaks the sound barrier and leaves the Earth's atmosphere. Ten minutes later, it is 90 miles up, moving at Mach 19 - 13,000 miles per hour - and silently coasting on the momentum of the burned-out rockets. (Passengers in the upper-deck solarium get a brief but unparalleled view of the galaxies. Seat belts are essential; there's not gravity during this part of the trip.) After three minutes of free fall, the plane has dropped to 150,000 feet and re-entered the atmosphere; here, air resistance slows the plane and enables it to glide (again in silence) for the next 20 minutes. At 36,000 feet, the pilot turns the jets back on and prepares to lando nt he standard runway. Total time from New York to Beijing: 70 minutes. How long it takes to get through airport traffic and security will be another matter entirely.

title: Ralph Posner 2d, Alyssa Prince
description: Alyssa Marlyn Prince, a hunger relief coordinator, and Ralph Posner 2d, a legislative aide to Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, were married last evening at the Concordia Club in Pittsburgh. Rabbi David M. Posner, the bridegroom's uncle, officiated.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: Our War

title: Emily Goldstein, L. Stan Stokowski
description: Emily J. Goldstein, a daughter of Pauline and Samuel Goldstein of West Chester, Pa., is to be married today to L. Stan Stokowski, a son of Gloria Vanderbilt of New York and the late Leopold Stokowski. Charles S. Edwards, a town justice of Manlius, N.Y., is to officiate at a private house in Wainscott, L.I.

title: Donyale K. Harris And Jorge B. Velez
description: Dr. Donyale Kioko Harris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Harris of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Jorge Bernardo Velez, a son of Julia Velez of Miami and Dr. Pedro G. Velez of Miami Lakes, Fla. The Rev. Mariah Britton, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: Passion, Digitally
description: From Leckie & Webster's Connotationally Gender-Specific Lexicon of Contemporary Usage

title: Liza Handman, Charles M. Boone
description: Liza Eleanor Handman, a daughter of Barbara and Wynn Handman of New York, is to be married in New York today to Charles Michael Boone, the son of the Rev. Lillian Boone and Roy Boone, both of Tucson, Ariz. Justice Stanley Sklar of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is to officiate at Studio 450, a party space. Judge Norma L. Shapiro of Federal District Court in Philadelphia is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Southern Comfort
description: What a delight to learn that Krispy Kreme doughnuts have finally arrived in New York (Style: Southern Comfort,'' by Roy Blount Jr., Sept. 8). The 4-to-8-A.M. quarterdeck watch, aboard ships lying dockside at the Norfolk Naval Station, was invariably dark and boring. The only highlight was the arrival, at dawn, of the Krispy Kreme delivery van and, with it, the opportunity to snitch a handful as the doughnuts were carried to the galley.

title: A Town House And the Rent Code
description: To the Editor:

title: Cathleen Vossler, John T. Sullivan
description: Dr. Cathleen Marie Vossler, an emergency-room physician at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center, was married yesterday to John T. Sullivan, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times. The Rev. Francis Braun performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church in Buffalo.

title: Whose Money? And Whose Problems?
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A.
description: Board's Powers In a Co-op

title: Civil War History, Off The Page
description: AT first, the Civil War battlefields outside Washington seem like a quiet respite from congestion and commercialism. For the most part, they were farmland in the 1860's and are still rural today. The lawns, crops, woods and old fences are still settled largely in the way they were when the great battles of Gettysburg, Antietam, Bull Run and Fredericksburg were waged. But whether a visitor knows such engagements regiment by regiment or barely knows the Blue from the Gray, the battlefields don't seem quiet at all. The din of guns, cries and cannon still seems to echo here.

title: Montclair Asks Its Artists To Write and Be Counted
description: With its own museum, art-house movie duplex, the 12 Miles West Theater Company and cappuccino bars on every other corner, Montclair is definitely arty. But just how arty?

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Fruity Institution Adds a Papaya Queens

title: Chemical Heir Is Insane
description: Declaring that John E. du Pont was ''actively psychotic,'' a judge in suburban Philadelphia ruled that the chemical company heir was mentally incompetent to stand trial for the January shooting death of the Olympic wrestling champion Dave Schultz.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-14

title: Air-Crash Pay: Limits Reviewed
description: MUCH of the fine print on the back of an air ticket concerns the Warsaw Convention, a 1929 agreement that governs many aspects of international flights, particularly liability in the event of a fatal accident.

title: New Releases
description: SUZANNE VEGA: 'NINE OBJECTS OF DESIRE'

title: HOUSE BACKS DEAL ON BUDGET FOR '97 IN BIPARTISAN VOTE
description: The House of Representatives tonight overwhelmingly approved a budget deal for 1997 that yields to President Clinton on immigration issues and on some spending priorities but holds fast to Republican demands for $30 billion in overall cuts.

title: City Plans to Auction Off A Bronx Group's Dream
description: Decades ago, the Bronx Borough Courthouse stood gleaming and grandiose, gazing down over boisterous stickball games and lawyers' social dens as the Third Avenue El rumbled by. Then fire and decay devoured the neighborhood bit by bit, and the lavish courthouse tumbled along with it, losing first its purpose and later its windows, roof and doors. For nearly 20 years, it was forgotten.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: Split Image

title: Mad About Fashion: Super Shoppers
description: SYL TANG arrived at Bergdorf Goodman for a recent personal appearance by the designer Marc Jacobs with a page from the September issue of Vogue featuring the model Naomi Campbell in a panne velvet blouse by Mr. Jacobs.

title: In Hoboken, a Dream Is Poisoned by Mercury
description: Matt Schley, a printmaker who helped recruit fellow artists to buy an old factory here and convert it to SoHo-style lofts, has some advice for others with the same idea: ''Find out the history of that building. On your own.''

title: Is Clinton More 'in Touch'? Many Women Say Yes
description: With her 10-month-old son in a shopping cart, Stephanie Salazar raced down the aisles of Toys ''R'' Us on Route 1 one morning last week, searching for a birthday gift for her niece, and decorations and favors for her 8-year-old son's birthday party this weekend.

title: New Releases
description: NIRVANA: 'FROM THE MUDDY BANKS OF THE WISHKAH'

title: Men Swaggered, Women Warred, Oil Flowed
description: Correction Appended

title: Assessing a Career In the Middle of It
description: A STRIKINGLY varied sampling by three artists in that vaguely defined category known as mid-career is currently on view at the Jersey City Museum. The artists are Rochelle Feinstein, with her eccentric take on formalist abstract painting liberally dosed with collage; Cicely Cottingham, whose lyrical, figure-based painting verges on expressionism, and Denise Mullen, whose ultra-refined landscape photography is mounted, somewhat unbecomingly, in hand-made books. While their approaches to art-making are disparate enough that each artist needs to be presented on her own terms and not by way of comparison, there is an underlying issue involved in all three exhibitions: the question of what binds individual paintings or photographs into a larger sequence or ''body of work.''

title: The Origin of Eyes
description: CLIMBING MOUNT IMPROBABLEBy Richard Dawkins.Illustrated. 340 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: What's a 6-Letter Word for Detective?
description: THE title character in ''Oliver's Travels,'' a new four-part BBC miniseries on Mystery, is a compulsive solver of crossword puzzles and an expert anagrammatician. Words are his preoccupation. He is even more intellectual than Morse or Dalgleish. An academic turned sleuth, Oliver journeys through England on the trail of a murderer, drawing clues from the daily crossword.

title: Where Is There?
description: JERSEY CITY is like a big doughnut with a small hole. The town is not really shaped that way; it's more of a feeling. You can go round and round and never be at the center, and after a while you realize something is missing.

title: Markets Crowding Sidewalk Disturb Brighton Beach
description: To The Editor:

title: After the Funeral, Overseeing the Estate Brings New Woes
description: FOR several years, Jerrie Taylor and Joan McGarry had what was possibly the worst job in California. They administered the estate of Ms. McGarry's former companion, a man who in his later years, according to Ms. Taylor, kept his business to himself, holed up in a house surrounded by old car bodies. For most of that time, she said, he did not pay taxes.

title: Sneaky Pay Raises
description: New York State legislators are hinting they may go back into session after the November elections in order to give themselves a pay raise. That sort of hint is the equivalent of a sworn oath.

title: Social Powder Kegs
description: To the Editor:

title: In the West Bank, Arabs Feel Israeli Crackdown
description: The panoramic view from this hillside village descends from olive orchards to the stand of cypress pines around Joseph's Tomb, the site of fierce Palestinian-Israeli clashes last week, to the fallow cornfield where two Israeli tanks prowl behind fresh earthen berms.

title: LEADERS OF ISRAEL AND PALESTINIANS DUE IN WASHINGTON
description: After intensive diplomatic efforts by the United States, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat agreed today to go to Washington this week to seek ways out of a confrontation that has put the entire Israeli-Palestinian peace in jeopardy.

title: Applying Pay-Per-View Idea To the Compact Disk Business
description: The compact disk has been the sort-of obvious solution to many Internet bottlenecks for quite a while now. Faced with the so far insuperable challenge of pumping high-quality graphics, video and other bandwidth-hungry features through phone lines and doing so at acceptable speeds, many entrepreneurs and Web site operators have said, ''Aha! Wouldn't it be nice to distribute such material on CD's that can interact with the Web.''

title: Vietnam in Retrospect
description: To the Editor:

title: Birthday Tribute to a Master Teacher of Indian Dance
description: Dance and drama are inextricably bound in Indian classical dance, as are the spirit and the flesh. That was underscored, both consciously and unintentionally, in a 70th-birthday homage to Guru Kelucharan Mohapatra, a master teacher of the Odissi dance form, on Friday night at Symphony Space.

title: 2 Congressmen Are Learning Hard Lessons in Bitter Race for Senate
description: Between them, Robert G. Torricelli and Richard A. Zimmer have successfully run for the House of Representatives 10 times. But for all their experience, both are learning some new lessons about campaigning in their Senate race.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: No Headline
description: ''We thought the Israelis would be leaving us forever, not returning with tanks. We are really going backward.'' JAMIL DWEIKAT, a high school principal in the West Bank. $(A6:2$)

title: An Earlier Political Kingmaker
description: He was a United States Senator from New York who held the state's Republican Party in an iron grip. He wielded enormous power over fund raising for state candidates in his good graces.

title: Blame Extremists for Violence in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: National Security Experts Plan for Wars Whose Targets and Weapons Are All Digital
description: It was the OPEC meeting in May 2000 that started the crisis. The oil-price hawks, led by Iran, demanded a sharp cutback in production to drive prices up to ''at least $60 a barrel.''

title: Upgrading Train Tracks
description: Amtrak and New Jersey Transit will spend $250 million over the next five years to upgrade 58 miles of track they share on the New York-to-Trenton line, officials said Friday. The agencies will replace wooden ties with smoother, longer-lasting concrete ones, repair overhead power lines and replace air-powered switches, which can freeze in the winter, with electrical ones. The track was last overhauled in the 1930's. Amtrak, which owns the track, and New Jersey Transit, which pays $26 million a year to use it, will share the cost, said Jeff Maclin, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit.

title: Princeton Celebrates 250th
description: ''Going back to Nassau Hall,'' goes Princeton University's unofficial anthem, and state lawmakers will do just that this week. To help celebrate the university's 250th birthday, the Legislature will hold its Thursday session in Nassau Hall, the oldest building on campus and site of the very first meeting of the State Legislature in 1776.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: With Olympic Glory Fading, Athletes Ponder: What Now?
description: Bill Carlucci is home. The bronze medal he won at the Olympics this summer is upstairs in a duffel bag in the house where he grew up. And he is arguing with himself about whether he is done with rowing, the sport that ruled his life for 11 years and made him a champion but not a household name.

title: Jets Execute, and They Get Executed Anyway
description: By kickoff here last night, did you know that the Giants had already defeated the previously unbeaten Vikings? The Jets sure knew. With the late start here, they even watched some of the game in their hotel rooms on television.

title: Kathleen Carlin, 57, Fought for Abused Wives
description: Kathleen Carlin, a social service executive who devoted her professional life to the proposition that men can learn to get along quite well without beating up their wives and girlfriends, died on Sept. 20 at a hospice near her home in Atlanta. She was 57 and had been a leading voice in the movement to stop violence against women.

title: Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Lovers and a Sex Goddess With the Patina of Age
description: ''Prime Time,'' a revue presented by Dancers Over 40 on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, made a strong case for the special gifts of older dancers, some of whom are well into their 70's. But the glossy show, with urbane introductory material written and spoken by Margery Beddow, was also the stuff of prime-time entertainment.

title: Justin A. Stanley, 85, Lawyer Who Headed A.B.A. in 1970's
description: Justin A. Stanley, a Chicago lawyer and a former president of the American Bar Association, died Wednesday in Rush North Shore Medical Center in Skokie, Ill. He was 85 and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

title: INSIDE
description: G.O.P.'s Budget Battle

title: China Banks Shift Slowly Into Commercial Gear
description: HONG KONG  Given the freedom to run their businesses more as commercial enterprises than government cashiers, China's large state-owned banks are showingsigns of adapting well to life in a market economy.

title: The Tricky Business Of Selling Derivatives
description: LONDON  This seems like an easy sell: a method of limiting financial risk in the riskiest places to do business. Yet banks that offer strategies designed to cut multinational companies' exposure to loss from political upheaval and currency and interest rate movements in emerging markets have found fewer takers than they had expected.

title: Dole's Tax Plan Adds Up
description: The centerpiece of the Dole-Kemp economic plan is a balanced budget by the year 2002 and a $548 billion tax cut over the next six years. Democrats swear this can't be done, and some voters are skeptical; they don't believe elected officials have the discipline to produce the necessary savings.

title: American Express Adds Draft to Roster
description: The American Express Company has added the New York office of Draft Direct Worldwide to its roster of direct marketing agencies, to handle assignments with billings estimated at $50 million.

title: Races Supplied Sneak Preview Of Playoff Pressure for 8 Teams
description: The playoffs started early for the Atlanta Braves this year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BERT NEUBORNE, a professor at New York University School of Law and a former legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union, was exceedingly flattered when he got a call last year from the film director MILOS FORMAN asking him to audition for the movie ''The People Versus Larry Flynt.''

title: Immigration Agency Has Record of Success
description: To the Editor:

title: After Another Climb, Whither I.B.M. Shares?
description: Not too many $72 billion companies see their stock prices rise more than 50 percent and fall 30 percent in a single year, but I.B.M., the world's largest computer company, has ridden that roller coaster nearly twice in 12 months. Last year at this time, the stock began a slide that took it as low as $83.125 a share. It then rose to a high of $128.875 in February before falling to $90.25 in July.

title: Gas Rule May Near End
description: Each winter, gasoline stations in the northern part of the state must switch to selling oxygenated gasoline, which cuts carbon monoxide emissions but has drawn complaints from station employees and residents who say it makes them sick. But improvements in the state's air quality mean that this winter could be the last one for oxygenated gas, which contains elevated levels of the ether additive MTBE.

title: Harold Evans bets big on dubious book deals. But that's not what miffs his rivals.
description: HE is the nation's most famous literary mogul of the moment, a former British newspaper editor in a pin-striped, double-breasted suit with the courtly manner and icy nerve of a riverboat gambler who has bet his house stake on the rascals and heroes of headlines.

title: A Charming Bully En Famille
description: Having played far-flung movie characters from Cyrano de Bergerac to a Disneyfied friendly ghost, Gerard Depardieu finds one of his most interesting roles closer to home. He plays a well-heeled, powerful Frenchman named Gerard in a new film by Maurice Pialat, the subtle and disturbing film maker with whom Mr. Depardieu has worked so well (in ''Loulou,'' ''Police'' and ''Under Satan's Sun'').

title: New York May Lose More House Seats, Analysts Report
description: If New York State's population growth continues to lag behind that of other states, it will lose one and possibly two seats in the House of Representatives after the next United States Census, and it will face diminished clout in Congress, government and private analysts say.

title: Strahan Talks Near Collapse
description: Contract negotiations between the Giants and perhaps their best player, defensive end Michael Strahan, have until now had their rough spots without being bitter. But that has changed, and the Giants are in serious danger of losing him.

title: Alomar's Punishment Should've Been Swift And Ended His Year
description: THE last day of the baseball season is melancholy in any ball park about to be shut down for the winter, but it is particularly melancholy in historic Fenway Park. The Sox did not make it into what is now called the ''post-season,'' so from now until April, there will be no Green Monster in left field, no old-fashioned organ music, no view of the skyline from behind home plate. Melancholy.

title: Seles Makes the Difference in Fed Cup
description: Monica Seles has always been a quick study: no wonder she figured out how to wax patriotic and land a Fed Cup, the big international fish that had wriggled away from the United States in the past two finals, on her very first attempt.

title: Their 2-1 Advantage in Ejections Helps Swing Game to the Steelers
description: It didn't take much to set off the tempers here this afternoon. Pittsburgh and Houston were tied atop the American Football Conference Central with 2-1 records entering the game. Both have designs on the division crown.

title: Rejoining A World Left Behind
description: The core of Billy Bob Thornton's ''Sling Blade'' is Mr. Thornton's own arresting performance as Karl Childers, a terse, withdrawn character with unspoiled innocence despite a terrible past. Mouth pursed, jaw jutting, head downcast and eyes avoiding contact, Karl begins the film by explaining, in a gravelly singsong punctuated by bestial little grunts, who he is. And why he has spent 25 years in what he calls the ''nervous hospital,'' from which he is on the verge of being released.

title: Inquiry Needed in Police Shooting in London
description: To the Editor:

title: Creating Parallel Universes for Profit
description: When the billionaire Tony Stark was acquitted of corporate espionage and insider trading this month, sparking street protests by workers who hate him, he experienced a terrifying moment of doubt. Why did he abandon his early creativity as his conglomerate, Stark Enterprises, grew? Why did he give himself over to selfishness and greed?

title: An astrological quirk brings fear and trembling to some corners of the Internet.
description: OF this column really does find its way into the paper this morning and these words are being read, consider it a triumph of will over destiny.

title: Ruling Favors Hindu Festival
description: An annual Hindu festival that traditionally runs late into the night will be allowed to go until 4 A.M. because a Federal judge struck down a midnight curfew for large outdoor events that the township passed in June. Judge John C. Lifland of United States District Court ruled Friday that Edison's curfew was unconstitutional because it was aimed specifically at the Navratri festival, which honors the god Shakti with singing and dancing and attracts up to 100,000 people each fall to a privately owned lot near an industrial park. The ordinance, the judge said, violated the celebrants' rights to free speech and worship.

title: Richest Who Call State Home
description: Eight New Jerseyans are among the 400 wealthiest people in the United States, according to the annual list compiled by Forbes magazine. Donald Newhouse, head of the newspaper portion of the Newhouse publishing empire and a resident of Somerset County, is worth about $4.5 billion, good enough for 12th place in the survey, which Forbes will publish in its Oct. 14 issue. The candy heiress Jacqueline Mars Vogel of Bedminster placed 33d with a net worth of $3 billion, while Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the widow of Johnson & Johnson heir J. Seward Johnson, ranked No. 100 with a fortune of $1.2 billion.

title: Tennesseans Unmoved as Candidates Come to Town, Again.
description: Two years after Tennessee voters gave Republicans one of their best showings in the country with victories for governor, both Senate seats and two House seats, the state has become one of the premier battlegrounds of the 1996 election.

title: Films That Win Acclaim But Not U.S. Distributors
description: If times are tough now for foreign-language films in the United States, they are almost impossible for Eastern European movies. That fact would probably be little noticed or lamented except that a handful of this year's most critically acclaimed films, works that were discovered at the Cannes, Montreal and Toronto film festivals, were made in Russia and Eastern Europe. Most of them have not found American distributors.

title: Another Gwynn Gives Padres Title
description: It must be in the genes. Chris Gwynn, who has spent a lifetime caddying for his big brother Tony, finally stepped in front of a klieg light today.

title: Q & A / Guy-Olivier Segond : Swiss Banks and the Legacy of Nazi Gold
description: With the opening of Allied archives, Switzerland's actions with regard to large sums of money deposited in the country during World War II have come under intense scrutiny in Europe and the United States. For one, Swiss banks have reluctantly agreed to an investigation into what became of the unclaimed deposits of victims of the Holocaust.

title: After Crisis, Czechs Look For Waysto RepairImage
description: PRAGUE  By the time Kreditni Banka, a small Czech bank, was shut by regulators last month, it had lost an estimated 12 billion koruny ($455 million). Ten other Czech banks had already collapsed with hardly a ripple.

title: In One Stroke, A. H. Belo Climbs Into Broadcasting's Inner Circle
description: G. B. Dealey was 26 and restless in a mail-room job at The Galveston (Tex.) Daily News in 1885, and in the way these old success stories so often seem to begin, it turned out the newspaper owner had had his eye on the young man.

title: Credit Offerings During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: I.M.F. and World Bank Clear Debt Relief
description: With the world economy apparently in position to grow steadily and low inflation predicted for the next four years, finance ministers from rich and poor countries today formally endorsed a new plan to lighten the debt burden of the poorest nations.

title: Why People Keep Thinking in the Same Old Ways
description: TYRANNY OF THE NORMAL

title: 104th Congress Falls Short of Revolution
description: Republicans took charge of the 104th Congress with one paramount goal: a balanced budget. They failed. But in the process they succeeded in establishing this Congress as perhaps the most parsimonious ever, making deep cuts in programs that they found useless, wasteful or out of step with their political ideology.

title: At the Wave of a Flag, Winston Cup Packs Up
description: If the National Football League ever decides to abandon Lambeau Field, Green Bay, Wis., will know how Wilkes County, N.C., feels today.

title: Coke Expands Ties With Cliff Freeman
description: The Coca-Cola Company, in another realignment of assignments among its 30 agencies, has expanded its relationship with Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York by awarding Freeman the assignment to produce worldwide creative work next year for the Fanta line of flavored soft drinks. Though billings were not disclosed, Fanta is the third-best-selling brand for Coca-Cola behind its flagship, Coke, and Diet Coke.

title: City Promises To Explain Abuse Deaths
description: Child welfare officials are close to concluding their investigations into the apparent mishandling of two fatal child abuse cases in the Bronx this year and plan to make their findings public, the Commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services said yesterday.

title: Clinton's Choice: Chaos or Diplomacy
description: President Clinton's invitation to the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the leader of the Palestinian Authority, Yasir Arafat, to talks here carries a significant element of political and diplomatic risk.

title: On Line: Issues '96
description: An Internet site devoted to Issues '96 is now available to computer users at http:// www.nytimes.com/issues. A collaboration by The New York Times on the Web and National Public Radio, the site includes news coverage and background material on major campaign issues, as well as forums for discussion, interactive quizzes and links to other Internet resources for voters.

title: Loewen Buys Another Funeral-Home Unit
description: The Loewen Group Inc. said today that it had bought CMS West, a Pennsylvania-based operator of funeral homes and cemeteries, bringing the value of Loewen's acquisitions in three weeks to $100 million.

title: New Afghan Rulers Shock Even Their Backers in Pakistan
description: Since the religious movement known as the Taliban began its rise in Afghanistan two years ago, Pakistan has maintained close contacts with the rebel group's leaders and has supported their drive for power. There have been persistent reports -- routinely denied by the Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto -- that the Taliban received covert supplies of arms, ammunition and money from Pakistan.

title: Bundy Led Ford Foundation to Achievement
description: To the Editor:

title: Shusaku Endo Is Dead at 73; Japanese Catholic Novelist
description: Shusaku Endo, a leading Japanese novelist who wrote about faith and faithlessness, East and West, heritage and modernity, died yesterday at Keio University Hospital in Tokyo. He was 73 and lived in Tokyo.

title: The World Wide Wait: Don't Get Mad, Get Off
description: Web surfers call it the World Wide Wait -- that excruciating delay that many home computer users experience when they try to download graphics and photos from multimedia Web sites.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Martha Entenmann, Matriarch Of the Baked-Goods Family, 89
description: Martha Entenmann, the matriarch of the family that turned a small Bay Shore, L.I., bakery into Entenmann's, one of the nation's largest and best-known baked-goods companies, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, L.I. She was 89 and lived in Islip.

title: Behind the Scenes, D'Amato Wields Vast Power in Albany
description: When New York City police officers wanted legislation in Albany to help increase their pay, they turned to Washington, where Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was eager to be of service.

title: Finding What Was Said Back Then and What Now
description: Bill Clinton foresaw the pocketbook election of 1996 during the second Presidential debate of 1992. ''You have to increase investment, grow the economy and reduce the deficit,'' he said. ''You'll have a shot at me in four years, and you can vote me right out if you think I've done a lousy job, and I would welcome you to do that.''

title: Accounts
description: * Seagram Beverage Co., New York, to Gearon Hoffman, Boston, to introduce the Devil Mountain line of beers including Five Malt Ale and Black Honey Ale. Billings were not disclosed.

title: A dispute over prepaid college tuition programs turns into a full-blown constitutional debate.
description: IT'S rare that a patent dispute raises constitutional issues. But an infringement dispute over prepaid tuition programs has just erupted into a full-blown battle over how heavily a state can tread on the commercial rights of an individual.

title: Applause for Giants, the Old and the New
description: MAYBE the Giants were inspired. At their morning chapel service, they were addressed by Tom Landry, once the only defensive assistant coach on the 1956 championship Giants team that was honored at halftime yesterday.

title: If I Forget Thee . . .
description: ''East Jerusalem is our capital!'' cries Yasir Arafat, seizing on the opening of a long-used tourist tunnel to inflame Palestinians and to trigger an outburst of open warfare in Israel.

title: A Book War: the Pope, Reagan and the C.I.A.
description: The unholy truth about the writers who are publishing new books about Pope John Paul II is that they would probably have trouble agreeing on the number of beads in a rosary -- let alone the legacy of the leader of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Victory Buys Time For Coach
description: The football was flipped into the air, again and again, end over end, and each time it landed securely in the hands of John Cooper. He had reached a place where few coaches have ever been, standing in the sunshine late Saturday afternoon between Notre Dame Stadium and the library mural nicknamed Touchdown Jesus. It was not just the location that made this place so special and rare, it was the circumstances. Cooper's Ohio State Buckeyes had not just defeated Notre Dame for a second consecutive year. They had widened the gap.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Live and on Tape: Stormy Weather, Happy Ending

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Raising a Wall And Unanswered Questions

title: Deep in Gaza, Israelis See Themselves as Bastion Against a Palestinian State
description: Behind freshly filled sandbags, new coils of barbed wire and earth ramparts hastily raised by army bulldozers, this isolated Jewish settlement was enveloped today by a surreal calm.

title: Congress's Leaders Debate Issues With a Seldomly Seen Decorum
description: Congress's four top leaders argued over Medicare, tax cuts, education and poison gas tonight, giving the uncertain Congressional elections unique national visibility and displaying a calm civility rarely seen on the floor of either House or Senate as this session ends.

title: Meanwhile, at Shea, the Mets Lose One Last Time
description: A season that began with Bobby Jones as the Mets' starting pitcher ended the same way yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium. But while Jones's opening day assignment last April was clothed in optimism, his final start marked a merciful end to another futile season in Flushing.

title: Two Jams (Pearl and Traffic) for One Price
description: While Pearl Jam flaunts its principles, its fans suffer for them. The band is on a United States tour of places that aren't tied exclusively to Ticketmaster, whose service charges Pearl Jam calls excessive. For its New York shows, Pearl Jam booked two nights at Downing Stadium, on Randalls Island, where it played its first concert on Saturday night.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: PERFORMANCE ART
description: Surprising Vignettes From a Croatian Troupe

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Some House and Senate Debates Provide Rare Side-by-Side Comparisons
description: Republican and Democratic candidates for Congress faced one another in televised debates across the country this evening, giving voters in many instances their only statewide side-by-side comparisons in races that could determine who will control the 105th Congress.

title: Johnnie Cochran, Author, Takes His New Cause to the Pulpit
description: Nearly a full year after the words ''not guilty'' set his celebrity client free and crowned his own transformation into perhaps the best known and most controversial litigator in the land, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. visited Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday to showcase himself in a different part: inspirational black role model.

title: Burmese Military Tightens Crackdown on Democracy Leader
description: Heavily armed soldiers manned roadblocks today outside the home of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the country's leading democracy advocate, and Government-controlled newspapers accused her of trying to incite riots and undermine national stability.

title: Bridge
description: Winning a major team title at an advanced age is very rare indeed, and the most memorable feat in this category is the 1983 victory of the legendary Oswald Jacoby in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams. He was 81, but was able to play one session a day for three days against America's best players.

title: Adoption Proposal Causes an Uproar
description: David G. James, a Navy transport coordinator here, adopted Patrick and Christian, 6, and 4, this winter, giving the two brothers a permanent home after rootless years in foster care and starting a single-parent family with help from his retired mother.

title: A Teacher Takes Her Work Home
description: One of the perversities of television spinoffs is that they often take a hit movie and eliminate the very reason for its success. That approach creates riddles that viewers never wanted to have answered, like: what would ''Dangerous Minds'' have been without Michelle Pfeiffer?

title: New Shade in the Political Debate Palette: Mellow
description: The introductory fife and drum music hardly heralded rounds of debating musketry tonight in the four-way television confrontation of the Congressional leaders. Rather, a mood of unusual mellowness followed, as if the leaders were more at the business of a legislative string quartet than tooth-and-claw partisan politics with majority control of Congress at stake.

title: Town Thanks Its Doctor After Decades of Healing
description: It is not hard to find a good Doc Pete story. Just ask around in this small college town.

title: Misplaced Leniency
description: A person whose erratic behavior includes episodes of misconduct and colossally poor judgment does not belong on the bench. Yet the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct chose merely to censure State Supreme Court Justice Lorraine Miller, despite a string of bizarre actions that fully justified tossing her out of her job.

title: Corrections
description: An outdated World News Brief about Thailand appeared erroneously in some copies on Saturday. In a new development on Friday, Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa dissolved Parliament and called for elections on Nov. 17. His announcement that he would resign was made on Sept. 21.

title: Which Israel?
description: Israel can always crush the Palestinians militarily. It expelled the P.L.O. from Lebanon; it defeated the intifada, and it has overwhelming fire power today.

title: In Ohio, the Campaign Is Just Now Gearing Up
description: To read the major newspapers and watch television, the race for President is over, with Bill Clinton easily being re-elected in the polls. Even the Doonesbury comic strip's Presidential character, the White House waffle, has started looking ahead to what it is going to be like as a second-term lame duck.

title: 2 Troupes That Pose A Contrast
description: The matching of the Alpha-Omega Theatrical Dance Company and the Rod Rodgers Dance Company in a program on Saturday afternoon at Marymount Manhattan Theater was both fortunate and unlucky.

title: Men and Jobs
description: The two big issues in poor black communities are jobs and men. Not enough jobs to go around and not enough men taking enough responsibility for the well-being of their children. The combined effect on the children is hideous. They are sent into the competitive cauldron of the real world grotesquely unprepared. Many do not survive.

title: Senate Vote Is Next Hurdle For a Forest
description: Sterling Forest, the sprawling tract of woodland on the border of New Jersey and New York, has come the closest in a decade to being preserved from development, although a bill authorizing $17.5 million in Federal funds to help buy the property still faces a major hurdle this week in the United States Senate, conservation and legislative officials said yesterday.

title: Kirshenbaum Gets Apparel Account
description: Two marketers have made decisions on their accounts.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Unabashed Sincerity In Tales of Heartbreak

title: Vikings Run Into a Big-Play Defense
description: Phillippi Sparks, the Giants' fifth-year cornerback, may be the best cover man in pro football. He showed why today when his fourth-quarter interception saved the Giants' 15-10 upset victory over the previously unbeaten Minnesota Vikings.

title: Tribe Stops Study of Bones That Challenge History
description: When Dr. James Chatters was recently asked by the sheriff in this desert community to take a look at a half-buried skeleton on the shore of the Columbia River, Dr. Chatters thought he was in for another mildly intriguing forensic mystery.

title: It's True: The Giants Win Second Straight
description: Stare into the looking glass and you see a picture no one would have imagined. Five weeks into the season the Giants are actually ahead of the Dallas Cowboys. Yikes. Next thing you know Alice won't be in Wonderland, she'll be on the Giants' bandwagon.

title: Bosnia Election Results Certified by West Despite Fraud Charges
description: Bosnia's election, which was intended to foster unity but was stained by accusations of intimidation and fraud, was certified today by the Western officials who ran it.

title: Rabies Death Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Pavel A. Sudoplatov, a former Soviet intelligence official, misstated the role of J. Robert Oppenheimer in the Manhattan Project to make an atomic bomb. He was the scientific director of the Los Alamos laboratory, where the first atomic bomb was made, not the head of the Manhattan Project.

title: Hinckley Tries, Again, to Gain Some Freedom
description: Fifteen years ago, John W. Hinckley Jr. parked his car outside his parents' cedar and stone home here and set off on a trip that ended five days later in Washington where he shot President Reagan and three other men.

title: Reviving Valujet
description: More than four months after being grounded in the wake of a crash in the Everglades that killed all 110 aboard, Valujet Airlines reopens for business today. The Department of Transportation has recertified the carrier, dismissing labor union objections that the airline's top officials are unfit by reason of Valujet's troubled safety history.

title: Insights That Lose Little In Transit
description: Stand-up comedy is often a national sport, with even the best routines of its brightest stars unable to cross borders of language, culture, politics and custom. Comedians are expected to be agents of the normal, exposing the petty foibles, repressions and obsessions of their constituencies. For foreign comics, there are large hurdles to overcome if they are to persuade the audience that it can relate to their experiences.

title: The Madison Avenue consolidation continues, with Lowe consuming a small New York agency.
description: ANOTHER independent agency is disappearing inside a corporate maw, this time a small, creatively focused shop whose principals are taking powerful senior positions with the acquirer.

title: Perfectly Pettitte
description: The white Plymouth rolled out of the parking lot, leaving the tiny field in the rearview mirror and carrying the dejected 6-year-old away from the flag football game that had ruined his morning. The boy sat in the back seat, his hair tousled, his uniform soaked and grimy, and he whimpered and wondered about what had gone wrong.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Mexican Workers Pay the Price of U.S. Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: A Liar With a Flair for Opportunism
description: ''A Self-Made Hero,'' which will be shown tonight at 9 and tomorrow at 6 P.M. as part of the New York Film Festival, is the smoothly told tale of an inspired liar. It follows the opportunistic rise of Albert Dehousse (Mathieu Kassovitz), who must be deemed a veteran extraordinaire, since he begins his career in the French Resistance when World War II is effectively over.

title: Costa Rica Chafes at New Austerity
description: For nearly half a century, Costa Rica has had a reputation as ''the Switzerland of Central America.'' With no army and a stable, democratic political system, the 3.5 million people of this mountainous country have grown accustomed to a standard of living that has made them the envy of Latin America, with benefits that include free education and health care.

title: Talks Yield 3-Year Pact For U.A.W. At Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union concluded a three-year labor contract this evening similar to the union's recent agreement with Ford, leaving General Motors alone without a deal.

title: Going to the Doctor's Kiosk
description: Doctors may not make house calls much anymore, but at two public housing complexes in Newark and Camden, they will soon be making two-way video conference calls. The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey received a $627,000 Federal grant earlier this month to set up medical kiosks inside housing complexes that will resemble ATM's more than doctor's offices. Residents will be able to consult a doctor 24 hours a day, said Dr. Paul R. Mehne, who sought the grant.

title: Moving Beyond the Wires
description: The technology that breathes life into many computer creatures may soon be cut loose.

title: Booming City, Flush With Rats and Dying Children
description: From their two-room shack that clings to the hillside next to a gully carrying raw sewage through one of this city's many slums, Georgine Meme and her nine children set out each morning in search of life's basics.

title: Brooklyn Candidate Campaigns Hard, but He's Not Sure Against Whom
description: Most mornings these days, Vincent J. Gentile follows a ritual of campaigning at subway stations, moving on to gatherings of senior citizens, then filling his afternoons with strategy meetings and more face-to-face discussions with potential voters.

title: On Workfare, Fig Leaves And Silence
description: ''Nothing in this subsection shall preempt or supersede any provision of state or local law that provides greater protection for employees from displacement.''

title: Jets' Best Offensive Showing Is All for Naught, and for Nought (as in 0-5)
description: They made it interesting, they made it close, and they might even have deserved better. But those sounds coming from the Jets' locker room tonight were feet kicking lockers and men cursing their fate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chrysler-U.A.W. Pact Set; G.M. Must Still Negotiate

title: What the Tunnel Means
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: What is the distinction between makeup and cosmetics? That question is to be addressed in New York State Supreme Court with a lawsuit brought by PABLO MANZONI, a makeup artist, against La Prairie, the maker of expensive beauty products.

title: Key Selected Over Rogers For Third Starting Spot
description: Joe Torre had decided to pick his third starter for the division series against the Rangers on the last day of the regular season. So he gathered the jumpy Kenny Rogers and the stoic Jimmy Key beneath the Green Monster at Fenway Park and pretended to flip a coin. Torre pantomimed to perfection and even made Key select heads or tails. He chose tails.

title: Candidates for Congress Meet In a Display of Partisanship
description: In a debate attended by most of Connecticut's Congressional candidates, Republican Representative Nancy L. Johnson tried to cast the current Congress as a moderate body that passed historic legislation with bipartisan support.

title: U.S. USING SWAPS TO PROTECT LAND
description: The Clinton Administration is expanding a program that is significantly reshaping the Government's land holdings, trading surplus public acreage to take environmentally sensitive sites out of private hands.

title: Away From the Big City, Seeking a Better Life but Facing New Tensions
description: One balmy winter night long ago, Jose de la Cruz, a poor man from the Dominican Republic, met and fell in love with a pretty young woman from New York who was vacationing in his hometown.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: A Terse Outsider Enumerates His Woes

title: Mideast Diplomacy
description: Given Benjamin Netanyahu's uneasy relationship with the Clinton Administration, traveling to Washington this week was probably not the Israeli Prime Minister's preferred method of dealing with the crisis in Israel, Gaza and the West Bank. That he agreed to join Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, King Hussein of Jordan and possibly President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Washington suggests that Mr. Netanyahu appreciates the need for intense diplomacy and some flexibility to save a tattered peace.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: An Evening Of Debuts In 'Boheme'
description: Even at the New York City Opera, where giving opportunities to emerging American singers is a house policy, it is not too often that three cast members make simultaneous debuts. But that is what Friday night offered with Graziella Sciutti's rewardingly intimate production of Puccini's ''Boheme.''
